loose_match.content: FROSTED TREES Grace M. Candland All trees in winter are a lovely sight When frost has settled round each limb and branch, As if some elfin artist would enhance Our joy, and make the somber day more bright. These jeweled pencils pointing to the sky Or fragile rods of pure white peppermint Are bits of glory without measured stint To tempt the notice of each passerby. The bitter winds and heaps of ice and snow Reveal a magic beauty all their own, And from their ample frigid arms we know The grand array of springtime buds are blown. Life, too, must have its cold and darksome day And yield its treasure as it slips away. The Cover: The cover "Winter in City Creek Canyon, Salt Lake City, Utah" is from a photograph by Grace O. Tuttle. GENERAL PRESIDENCY OF RELIEF SOCIETY PRESIDENT AMY BROWN Lyman. FIRST COUNSELOR MARCIA K. HOWELLS SECOND COUNSELOR BELLE S. SPAFFORD AT the opening of a new year, we are generally more inclined than at any other time to try to visualize what lies immediately ahead. We wonder what the new year will bring. It is a time also when we are most inclined to make new resolutions, and new plans, taking into account the mistakes and failures of the past and focusing our attention on our highest and most cherished ideals. And now what of this new year? What will it bring? With war raging all around the globe, impoverishing the whole earth, and inflicting on civilization the severest blows which it has ever received, with sorrow and tragedy entering home after home, the future seems discouraging and unpredictable. We therefore face the new year with sad hearts and with our minds disturbed and perplexed and filled with anxiety, apprehension, and uncertainty. It is obvious that our first duty, and that which lies closest at hand, is to do what is humanly possible to comfort those who are sad and bereft and, through earnest and sober prayer, ask our Heavenly Father to bless them and to give us all divine guidance through this period of peril. Let us, however, not lose hope, let us not lose faith. Let us cling to the thought that the thousands, yes millions, of peace-loving, righteous, Godfearing people in the world can, through faith and works and prayers, help to bring about what one philosopher has called "the rule of intelligence, of morals and of law." Let us remember what the Lord said toAbra-ham regarding the righteous as a protection to the wicked. In Genesis 18:26 we read, "And the Lord said. If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare all the place for their sakes." He later declared that he would save the city if only ten righteous could be found. Let us have faith and keep in mind the words of Jesus to his disciples: "And Jesus rebuked the devil; and he departed out of him: and the child was cured from that very hour. Then came the disciples to Jesus apart, and said. Why could not we cast him out? And Jesus said unto them, Because of your unbelief: for verily I say unto you, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say unto this mountain. Remove hence to yonder place; and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you" (Matt. 17:18-20). What the world most needs today is the acceptance and application of the laws of God as these are set forth in the Decalogue, and amplified by the Savior in the Sermon on the Mount. When the children of Israel strayed away from the teachings of their Maker, when they set up and worshipped an idol in the form of a golden calf, through Moses they were given the Ten Commandments written by God with his own hand on tablets of stone. When Christ came to redeem Israel and the world, he restated, emphasized, and amplified the teachings of Sinai. These laws and teachings are fundamental and eternal. And now, today, when so many people have departed from or set aside the laws and teachings of God and, in their place, have set up new man-made philosophies which have brought upon mankind many great and mighty evils the like of which the world has never known before, it is time for us to struggle, as best we can, to apply these fundamental teachings which have been a guide through the ages, and to awaken in the hearts of all people such an interest in the things of God that they will make an effort to live righteous lives and thus help to bring peace and freedom to all mankind. Amy Brown Lyman Marcia K. Howells Belle S. Spafford General Presidency

SUNSET ON NEW YEAR'S EVE Courtney E. Cottam Slowly, upon the twilight's frozen blue. The embered sunrays paint carnelian flame-Flame without warmth, mocking remembered hue Of summer's passion-born, resplendent name. Leaf-barren trees, in icy crystolence, Patterned on sorrow-darkened pain of dusk. Stand mute and statuesque, upraised against The promised grandeur of the sunset-husk. Yet rhythmically, the pulsing undertone Of life flows swiftly, warmly through the earth. Bidding mankind arise and claim his own; The sunset flame is promise of rebirth. Faith turns the year; faith bids the heart look up And fills the New Year's Eve with pledging cup. Award Winners Eliza Roxey Snow Memorial Prize Poem Contest THE Relief Society General Board is pleased to announce the names of the three prize winners in the 1944 Eliza R. Snow Memorial Prize Poem Contest. This contest was announced in the June 1944 issue of the Magazine and closed September 15, 1944. The first prize of twenty dollars is awarded to Vesta Pierce Crawford, 1067 East 5th South, Salt Lake City, for her poem *Tor Recompense." The second prize of fifteen dollars is awarded to Christie Lund Coles, 2648 Hartford, Salt Lake City, for her poem "
Aftermath." The third prize of ten dollars is awarded to Caroline Eyring Miner, 1011 North 8th East, Logan, Utah, for her poem "

That Which Sustains." This poem contest has been conducted annually by the Relief Society General Board since 1923 in honor of Eliza R. Snow, second general president of Relief Society. The contest is open to all Latter-day Saint women and is designed to encourage poetry writing and to increase appreciation for creative writing and the beauty and value of poetic verse. Prize-winning poems are the property of the Relief Society General Board and may not be used for publication by others except upon written permission from the General Board. The General Board reserves the right to publish any of the other poems submitted, paying for them at the time of publication at the regular Magazine rate. A writer who has received the first prize for two consecutive years must wait two years before she is again eligible to enter the contest* There were seventy-one poems submitted in this year's contest. The General Board congratulates the prize winners and expresses appreciation to all entrants for their interest in the contest and the general excellence of work submitted. The Board sincerely thanks the three judges for their valuable assistance in selecting the prize-winning poems. The contribution of the General Board's poem committee is also greatly appreciated. The prize-winning poems, together with photographs of the prize-winning contestants, are published herewith. Prize-Winning Poems Eliza Roxey Snot Memorial Prize Poem Contest VESTA PIERCE CRAWFORD First Prize Poem

For Recompense Vesta Pierce Crawford What shall he find when sounds of cannon cease And after long wandering he returns To his own land, his dream deferred, and peace? And what shall comfort the heart that yearns To lose the memory of sacrifice, What valid solace shall his loved ones give To heal the lost look in a soldier's eyes. By what eternal measure shall he live? Give him the river's song, the shadowed hill, A road that leads to his familiar door, Make his mornings eager and his midnight still Page 6 PRIZE-WINNING POEMS And give to him the love he waited for; Give him this recompense, confirm his choice-Children's laughter home a woman's voice. 11 Metal that made the sword can shape a plow, The tool of promise, strength, security-Give a man the brighter blade, show him how To cleave the ground in furrowed symmetry, This is an ancient truth and long revealed, Dominion of the earth is sure defense, And by this touch a broken man is healed  In seed and soil he finds his recompense. For there is solace where the snow has lain And comfort when the fallow season turns To April's chalice and the sound of rain. Once more, like hopeful grass, the seared heart learns That tenure of the earth alone can bring The jewelled sunlight to the field of spring. Ill In Sabbath twilight let the soldier find The open door, the edifice of prayer. Let all the battered ramparts of his mind Receive the sound of benediction there. Too vivid still he bears the lash of memory. And yet the sacred parables can light The wilderness of doubt that men may see A lambent star above the hills of night. Give him the quietness of sacrament. The Bible's treasured word and organ tone, The union of this brotherhood be sent For recompense that once he knelt alone; And let only luminous words be said In worship when the soldier bows his head. Vesta P. Crawford has five times been a winner in the Eliza R. Snow Poem Contest conducted annually since 1923, and twice in the Annual Relief Society Short Story Contest inaugurated in 1942. She is a member of the League of Utah Writers, the Art Barn Poetry Group, and the Sonneteers. She is a regular contributor to Church magazines and also markets her work with national publications. She is

literature class leader in the Relief Society of the Thirty-third Ward, Salt Lake City. CHRISTIE LUND COLES Second Prize Poem Aftermath Christie Lund Coles I Today I walked with autumn on a hill And all the autumns of our past came back; All the wide acres of my heart grew still As swallows traced the sky in seamless track; My heart was heavy with its aching loss, The honk of wild geese left me as forlorn And desolate as barren trees, across The far horizon where the mist is born. Today I walked with autumn and with this  An hour of stark and timeless quietude; I knew all I could bear of loneliness, I faced infinities of solitude. For memories too, leave but a seamless track. Since loneliness nor tears can bring you back! PRIZE-WINNING POEMS II I remember a day of autumn weather  The heft of the wind and the slant of sun, The edge of cold when winter was at its tether, The scent of trampled leaves as the year was done; And while I walk alone in these same places, I think of you, the wall of slivered rain, The brook-cool air upon our lifted faces. The words we whispered that were said in vain. I know a sudden, dark, recurrent yearning, Remembering that opalescent dusk Lying on valleys where the season, turning, Was marked by jeweled sun on the corn's dry husk; Still I am sure as leaves in autumn weather That in the wind of death we'll be together. Il Sleep, beloved, here where the grass is fluted By the wind on this green and lonely hill. Sleep and be glad that your anguish is muted. Sleep undisturbed by the world at its kill; Now I must stand here alone, bereft, seeing The town where we walked alive and unaware That death could part us, sorrow eat at our being, Betray us, track us down like a beast to its lair. Soon I will go back into the city, Back to the clamor and passions of men, I will not expect nor find any pity, Uncomforted, I will lie awake again With loneliness beyond the name of grief-Yet spring returns.. And life.. And budding leaf. This is the second time Christie Lund Coles has been an award winner in the Eliza R. Snow Poem Contest having received first prize in last year's contest. She also won second prize in the Annual Relief Society Short Story Contest for 1943. HI*"5- Coles is a member of the League of Utah Writers, the Barnacles, the Art Barn Poetry Group, and the Sonneteers. She is a regular contributor to Church magazines and also markets work with Saturday Evening Post, Good Housekeeping New York Times, Tomorrow and other national publications. She has served Relief Society as a member of the Spokane Relief Society District Board and also as a literature class leader in the Park Avenue Ward in Salt Lake City. CAROLINE EYRING MINER THIRD PRIZE POEM That Which Sustains Caroline Eyring Miner Yesterday They knew, who walked the trackless desert miles, Who breathed the dust the oxen powdered fine And forded rivers, trying to divine The way where savage, beast, would not discern Their presence. They who walked in endless files And halted but to dig their graves no sign To mark the spot  they knew the great design Could not be stayed nor curbed by man's concern, They knew they were the instruments of God And these were moments of eternity. The thought sustained them as they slowly trod Their way. This was for their posterity. Because their purpose was divine, complete, Their weariness, their sacrifice, was sweet. Today Within this quiet church they surely know. The warm light filters through the colored glass And gold and silver merge as minutes pass And sunlight touches young and older heads Bent reverently. The flowers in the low White bowl are gay and bright, a lovely mass Of bloom. No harmony can ever surpass This scene of perfect peace. And as he reads, 'The Lord is verily our own good shepherd/' The speaker knows that all assembled feel Secure, despite the warring world, the Lord Who led them here, will to their sons reveal His power in their extremest need. To be So certain is to glimpse eternity. Tomorrow I know that though the sun goes down today. Tomorrow it will rise again; the flower. Remembered perfume, colored dust, an hour From now, in God's own time, will bloom again. These things I know for I have seen. They say I only have the vision of this earth, the power To know the clearly proven fact. The Tower Of Babel was confusion, for those men Sought heaven by building solid rock and stone. Is sweet content the fruit of. Other tree? The peace beyond our knowledge comes alone Through perfect trust and faith and will to see That God yet rules the troubled earth and through The sacrament of sorrow, he'll come to you. Caroline Eyring Miner is a first-time winner in the Eliza R. Snow Poem Contest, but her work is by no means new to readers of Theas she has been a contributor to this publication for a number of years. Her work has also appeared in other Church magazines and is included in Utah Sings. She is a member of the League of Utah Writers, and the Quillers, a writers' group of Logan, Her interest in creative writing is revealed in the subject of her thesis for her Master's degree "The Motivation of Creative Writing in High School." She is a member of the Cache County Library Board, and literature leader of the Cache Stake Relief Society Board. AWARD WINNERS Annual Relief Society Short Story Contest THE Relief Society General Board is pleased to announce the names of the award winners in the short story contest which was announced in the June 1944 issue of the Magazine and which closed September 15, 1944. The first prize of thirty-five dollars is awarded to Ethel Newman Eccles, 4408 First Place, N. E., Washington, D. C., for her story "

Rock Roses of Nazareth." The second prize of twenty-five dollars is awarded to Vesta Pierce Crawford, 1067 East 5th South, Salt Lake City, for her story "The Bureau." The third prize of fifteen dollars is awarded to Dorothy Clapp Robinson, 119 Eiden Drive, Boise, Idaho, for her story "Though A Host Encamp Against Thee." This short story contest, first conducted by the Relief Society General Board in 1941 as a feature of the centennial observance, was made an annual contest in 1942. The contest is open only to Latter-day Saint women who have had at least one literary composition published or accepted for publication by the editor of a publication of recognized merit. The three prize-winning stories are to be published consecutively in the first three issues of the Magazine for 1945. Prize-vanning stories become the property of the General Page 12 Board and may not be published by others except by written permission from the General Board. The General Board reserves the right to publish any of the other stories entered in the contest, paying for them at regular Magazine rate at the time of publication. A writer who has received first prize for two consecutive years must wait two years before she is again eligible to enter the contest. Thirty-one manuscripts were submitted in the contest for 1944. This contest is stimulating Latter-day Saint women to do creative writing in the field of fiction. The General Board congratulates the prize-winning contestants and expresses appreciation to all whose work was entered in the contest. The General Board sincerely thanks the three judges for their excellent service in selecting the prize-winning stories, and acknowledges with appreciation the work of the General Board's short story contest committee. Stories, together with photographs of the award-winning contestants, will appear in the Magazine as follows: January 1945 "Rock Roses of Nazareth" by Ethel Newman Eccles; February 1945 "The Bureau" by Vesta Pierce Crawford; March 1945 "Though A Host Encamp Against Thee" by Dorothy Clapp Robinson. Winning Story Annual Relief Society Snort Story Contest First Prize Story Rock Roses of Nazareth Ethel Newman Eccles A bluish mist hung over the silent little village. The murky darkness trailed off into pale gray above the rolling hills in the distance. Spring in Nazareth was a paradise, and it was spring. Nazareth lay among the hills 1200 feet above the sea. It could be reached from the fertile plain below only by a tedious climb through a narrow, steep, and rough mountain path. Here lived Lydia. Her house was one of the finest; its courtyard one of the most comfortable, and its roof commanded an unsurpassed view. Here she sat in her leisure hours by the window. With soft, brown eyes she looked across the low-roofed houses, built of yellow-white limestone, so dazzling in the sun. From her smooth forehead fell the white woven veil of the young Jewish maiden. It fell in weighty folds about her slender figure. Her dress was low-cut, and of the finest fabric. It spread about her lovely, sandal-clad feet in cascades of purest white. The room was bare save for a few mats lying evenly against the wall. The water jars stood before the door. The landscape of distant hills, the nearer view of square-roofed houses with their purity of line and color. ETHEL NEWMAN ECCLES and the immaculate interior of the tiny house well befitted the spirit of the beautiful Jewish maiden, for Lydia's heart was pure. Many a long day this lovely girl had gone about her household chores with one, great, overwhelming thought lighting the way: The Christ, yes, he was to come; to be born as a tiny babe; and greatest of all great joys, he was to come to a Jewish maiden. Lydia raised herself from the low stool. She passed her hand lightly over her forehead and down her cheeks to her sounding throat. Through the soft folds of her dress she passed her hand, and at last gently she bowed her head in thanksgiving for this strength and loveliness. For might not the Holy Father see fit to crown her womanhood with the greatest of all the desires of a Jewish maiden: to be the mother of the Christ?
Lydia hugged the thought to her heart. In her strong young arms she held, in her mind's eye, the tiny body of her little son. And, in the overwhelming positiveness at the thought, she prayed, in the purity of her soul, that she, of all the Jewish maidens, might be the one chosen to bear God's Son.
Darkness fell, and still Lydia knelt by the little white stool, her head bowed in prayer and her heart beating in wild desire. A strange peace came over her, an assurance that the Holy Father, with his understanding kindness, was near; that he had heard her prayer, she was sure. Would he answer it?
The enveloping peace that had come to her in this sweet hour gave her hope, enveloping, heavenly hope.
It was here that Joses found her when he came with jars of fresh water from the well the small one great hope that some day Lydia would become his wife; for were they not of marriageable age and of the same station?
He stepped lightly over the threshold, leaving his sandals outside. He lifted Lydia to her feet and with his arms around her, with a smile, gently he put his hands to his shoulders and pushed him away. "No, Joses," she said, "the Christ has not yet come to earth. Let us forget that we once had thought..."
The pallor of her face told him what was in her mind; this decision after many sleepless nights. In that moment the young Jewish boy knew that Lydia would only live for the coming of the Son of God.
Each day Joses came as of other days. He carried her water jars and attended to the little tasks that needed to be done. Always the beloved the stately moving Lydia with hungering eyes. Always she was kind, always grateful, but always living in the dreamy future. For her there was but one great thought the Christ would come to a Jewish maiden, one of them. For this Lydia lived.
Day followed day, and her longing became more intense. More and more she lived in herself, and more and more shut Joses away from her life. She busied herself in her garden, which yielded for her sweet-smelling anemones, pink phlox, rock roses, and the asphodel. SPRINGTIME came again to Nazareth, the glorious spring time that only Nazareth can know. Lydia remained strong and hopeful through the brilliant sunshine and color. But when later the trees were barren and the low, dry hills offered endlessly in the distance, disturbing thoughts took hold of her, nervously. It was only a few months later that the signs for which everyone had watched and which everyone believed in came to pass.
Lydia knelt in a manger and honored the Shepherds and wise men, the Christ, the Savior of the world, was born. True, to a Jewish maiden, but not to the lovely Lydia.
It was not long after the coming of the Savior that the news came to Lydia. It was Joses who brought it to her, not as a mockery or in the spirit of exultation. Only that she might need him now a friend. For only Joses knew the disappointment Lydia could feel.
He found her kneeling above the low prayer stool. The folds of her lovely dress and veil fell in soft, loose folds about her. The light of hope and sweetness shone from her clear young eyes as she rose at Joses' entering.
He told her simply and reverently of the message of Christ's birth that had been carried over the land. Lydia sighed and stood before him, poised as if ready for flight. For one short moment she stood before him thus, while the light of hope faded from her face.
Joses watched her anguish. He took her two warm hands in his. "My Lydia," he said, "other sons and daughters of our Father will be sent to earth. Mayhap one will come yet to you that will fill your heart's need."
"Thank you, Joses, that my longing for the Son of God has been wrong in his sight?" Lydia asked.
"For you, my Lydia, there is no wrong," Joses replied. He put his arms tenderly about her. This time she did not draw back. The tears dried on her lashes. She took Joses' strong, kind hand in her own and dropping to her knees beside the little stool, she prayed.
A quiet peace came over her. Bless thou that other Jewish maiden who will joy in her little Son." Thus she prayed because her heart was pure.

loose_match.content: A Few of Our Gifted Utah Women Artists Alice Merrill Home Former Member of Relief Society General Board Part II While Dr. Heber John Richards was visiting and traveling in art centers of Europe with his wife and daughters, Hattie married, in the city of Paris, J. T. Harwood, her former art teacher in Utah. The young couple spent their honeymoon at Pont Aven a French fishing port where they both painted. Hattie Harwood's still life "Pumpkin" won a name for the young artist in a day, when it was accepted and hung in the beautiful Woman's Building of the Columbian Exposition at Chicago. Hattie was a painter of flowers, too. Her still life was distinguished. Hattie's father and her grandfather, Dr. Willard Richards, who was first editor of the Deseret News, were both college men of high attainments. Hattie, too, possessed a legal mind. She read her father's scientific works, took extension courses in research, and such studies as geology and astronomy at the University of Utah. Hattie's mother, Julia Johnson, was a daughter of Ellis Johnson, biologist and horticulturist of Southern Utah in pioneer days. Both mother and daughter had the gift to propagate rare house plants. The Harwoods went to California in search of greater art opportunities. The young mother, stricken with a toxic goiter, was forced to lie in bed. From books brought her from the public libraries, before her death, she went, in imagination, with the North and South Polar Expeditions. Ruth Har-wood, poet and illustrator, is their daughter. Harwood painted several lovely portraits of his beautiful wife. A school collection should be named for her and contain some of her own work, and also some of Harwood's portraits of this gifted woman.  Hattie Richards Harwood PETUNIAS AT WINDOW UTAH WOMEN ARTISTS Rachel Grant Taylor THE HOME OF YESTERYEAR Rachel Grant Taylor   In Rachel Grant Taylor's recent water colors is seen a rich flowering of a gift to paint. The Heber City Central School has named its collection for Rachel Grant Taylor. The school children purchased Rachel's "Blossoming Trees" and the artist presented "Yesteryear's Barn." The Alice Merrill Home gift was Rachel's "Pleasant Valley Hill Foliage." This painting of charm reveals oak brush which is almost moving. The whole landscape seems diffused with a soft light reminiscent of the end of day. Also there is a feeling of the last day of summer. This painting, purchased for a gift painting to honor Bathsheba W. Smith, pioneer artist, is a part of Mrs. Taylor's collection. Rachel's love for art is not stronger than her husband's, for John H. Taylor, though modest of his prowess, is an art collector in his own right and cherishes his art collection. Ruth Ballard Snow   a Utah artist who resides at Arlington, Va., is winning for herself a place among contemporary American artists. Mrs. Snow holds membership in the Society of Washington Artists, and Virginia Art League. Her work has been exhibited at the Philips Memorial Gallery and with the Society of Washington Etchers, Carnegie Library. Recently, at the Seventeenth Biennial Exhibition in the Corcoran Gallery of Art, she won honorable mention. She is an art instructor at Corcoran Art School, being assistant to Nickolai Cicousky, the noted figure painter. Formerly in Utah as head of Granite High art department, her work was more or less profound. Ruth married Dale C. Snow and went to Washington where her husband was employed with the Government.  Ruth Ballard Snow PORTRAIT OF MY MOTHER Opportunities came fast from the day she entered Corcoran School to continue her art studies. The work of this artist has found ready sale in Utah when she exhibits with the Utah Art Colony of which she is a cherished member. In the East, sales follow her exhibitions. Mrs. Snow's father, the late Melvin J. Ballard, has been recognized for his eloquence as a preacher and he could have made a place for himself in the concert hall with his fine baritone voice. Like her father, Mary Ruth, as she is often called, possesses a fine presence, is a good speaker and wins friends by her charming personality. Her mother has the gift of design. The writer, with President Emmeline B. Wells, visited the Ballard home in Portland as guests of the Northwestern Mission. Mrs. Ballard's home management, her hospitality, her entertainment of guests, and the work of her hands shown in clothing her children and decorating the home, revealed an artistic temperament which carried over to Mary Ruth. Grace Cutler Solomon, granddaughter of the late John C. Cutler, has gifts in her own right. A water colorist of varied attainments, she writes verse and paints pictures as did her poet uncle, Alfred Lambourne. This young artist's Winter Exhibition contained a subtle "Winter Fields" as well as "House of Memories," which bravely depicted a quaint pioneer home  both water colors were snatched up by a private collector. Grace C. Solomon GARDEN FLOWERS UTAH WOMEN ARTISTS 19 -Ida May Savage ANCIENT POTTERY Mrs. Solomon is often represented by a design which is fancifully created from one flower. Several collections have chosen her design from a magnolia or some other favorite flower. This ambitious artist is able to maintain a beautiful home and family life with her gifted husband, C. Francis Solomon. Recently she, with her daughter, was in Chicago, brushing up at the Chicago Art Institute. Ida May Savage was blue-eyed, fair, a true blonde, with a charming personality. She was a promising student of Harwood and painted flowers with flower quality. There was grace and charm in her compositions and she painted only clean color. Daughter of Charles R. Savage who made a circle of love for art around him, Ida died too young, and to keep her memory green the lovely creations of her hand could well be brought together to establish a school collection with her dear name attached thereto. Mary Teasdel   a much traveled person, was a graduate of the University of Utah. She studied piano, voice, and an extended art course under J. T. Harwood and continued in Paris for three years. On her return home, Miss Teasdel was elected third president of the Utah Art Institute when, with the help of Cyrus E. Dallin, her close friend, the New York and Boston artists sent outstanding canvases to the annual exhibition held at the old Social Hall. Mary took her mother with her for a second trip to Europe. Miss Teasdel was a brilliant conversationalist and correspondent. Perhaps no other art teacher was more inspiring than Mary. She possessed a remarkable vocabulary and her knowledge of art was broad. The writer has heard her criticisms in class lectures illustrating a certain problem in art. She would say, "Velasquez the Spanish painter would render the problem this way; Rembrandt used this method; Rubens treated it like this; and James McNeill Whistler (who was her main inspiration) would have this version."  Mary Teasdel BLOSSOMS Any art student would be fortunate to be under Mary Teasdel's wing. J. T. Harwood, her teacher, had the first painting from Utah hung in the Salon. Mary Teas-del was next to be hung in the Spring Salon. She had the honor of having three miniatures chosen for the French Exposition in 1900. Two of her portraits are in the State Alice Art Collection which received the $300 prize. She had the gift to achieve simplicity in her work, for in her fine use of colors as well as in the painting of rich fabrics, she accomplished perhaps the greatest quality of art  repose. Thirty-two of Mary Teasdel's paintings hang in a memorial collection as a civic collection at the Smithfield Carnegie Public Library. HILMA Mole Payne   One of Utah's virile artists and named among the 500 American artists   paints with enthusiasm Utah's blue skies, the Weber River, cottonwood trees, blossoming orchards, spring, and reflections in both pond and running brook. Hilma Mole studied with Harwood at the University of Utah. A trip abroad visiting the galleries of both the Old World and the United States did much for this ambitious artist. Hilma begins right by first creating a design for her pictures. She is a colorist and knows her tools well; and so produces works of art. Coupled with the ability to work, Hilma has the necessary qualifications to make what we call a "born artist." She is also a financier. Last fall when the pickers failed to appear at the Payne orchard, she gathered 400 bushels of apples and sold them, too. The Wasatch High School Hilma Mole Payne Art Collection in Heber City is among the best of Utah's thirty public school collections. In addition, her work is hung in many other picture galleries and private collections in the State. A. J. Payne, her husband, and James, the son, are proud of the accomplishments of this woman who is winning a name for herself in the Utah Art Colony exhibitions. Mr. Payne, a native of Tennessee, once kept the missionaries from being mobbed, and then made friends with the mobbers who joined his Sunday School class.

In accordance with the recommendation of the Shaw Commission, still further investigations were undertaken in Palestine. Sir John Hope Simpson spent three months inquiring into problems of land settlement, immigration, and the development of the mandate system. The Hope Simpson Report was published in October 1930. By 1937, the total population was nearly 1,400,000, of which about 400,000 (or over one-fourth) were Jewish. According to informed observers, it was calculated that if immigration were allowed to continue at the rate reached in 1935, it would overtake the Arab figure in twelve years, and that if it continued at only half the rate, at 30,000 per year, the two peoples would be approximately equal in 1960. As the year 1936 approached, the prevailing Arabic unrest in Palestine was heightened by a number of external incidents. Among them was the war mentioned above against Italy in Ethiopia, the conflict with its serious repercussions affecting both the British and the French in Egypt and Syria, both neighboring Arab states. In Syria, the Arabs successfully demanded and received a guarantee of republican government. The most important demands included: (1) the establishment of a democratic government, (2) prohibition of the transfer of Arab lands to the Jews, and (3) a drastic curtailment of the immigration of Jews. The White Paper issued for the bitter purpose, a "competent committee" should be set up "to determine the absorptive capacity of the country" and that "there should be an immediate interim suspension of the Jewish immigration."
Failure of High Commissioner Sir Arthur Wauchope, to respond satisfactorily to Arab demands, and led to the proclamation, on April 19, 1936, of an Arab National Political Strike directed against the British Mandatory Government. Organized terrorism was let loose upon the countryside. There were strikes in the towns; guerilla warfare in the highlands; looting and armed bands of Arabs roamed over the whole of Palestine. During the six months that the strike was in progress, there were about 400 Jewish and 1,600 Arab casualties. Quick military action by the British brought the Strike to an end in October 1936.
Like previous uprisings, the National Arab Strike was followed by the dispatch of a British Court of Inquiry, this time the Peel and Woodhead Commission, which was to investigate the underlying causes and to propose remedies." The "underlying causes" of the friction were found to be the same as those which had led to the disturbances of 1920, 1921, 1929, and 1933, namely, "the desire of the Arabs for national independence and their hatred and fear of the establishment of the Jewish National Home." Among the recommendations made by the Commission were the following: adequate political representation for the Arabs through a Pan-Arab assembly; restrictions and safeguarding of the sale of Arab lands; censorship, for the time being, of Jewish immigration; and finally, the formation of Arab cooperative societies on the same pattern as those founded by the Zionists; and the increased restriction of Jewish immigration based upon the principle of "political" and "economic absorptive capacity of Palestine," which, for five years after its initiation, would limit Jewish immigrants to an annual maximum of 12,000 persons. The application to Palestine of the Mandate System in general and of the specific mandate in particular implied the belief that the obligations thus undertaken towards the Arabs and the Jews respectively would prove in course of time to be mutually compatible owing to the conciliatory effect on the Palestinian Arabs of the material prosperity which Jewish immigration would bring to Palestine as a whole. Reduced to its simplest terms, the recommendation of partition envisioned the establishment of two sovereign independent states, plus a mandated area or enclave, which should contain Jerusalem and Bethlehem. The Arab state would comprise Trans-Jordan Palestine, and Transjordania. The proposed Jewish National Home would, by the Peel recommendation, be reduced in size to an area equivalent to that of the State of Delaware, but it would include, in the better sense of the word, the more productive areas of Haifa and Tel Aviv, the latter, the target important city area in Palestine. It was stipulated, further, that both Arab and Jewish states would be required to enter into military alliances with Great Britain, and that, for the present, the important naval base and anchorage terminus at Haifa would be left in British hands.
The Peel Report was not well received by either the parties most involved. The Arabs rejected the report uncompromisingly. They demanded unequivocally an arrangement which would regulate the Jews to minority status throughout the whole of Palestine. The Twentieth Zionist Congress was not satisfied with the proposed new state boundaries, yet recommended further negotiations with the British Government along the lines of partition. So the Arab and Jewish delegates met separately with the British representatives of the British Government, and the conference became, in effect, two parallel conferences, and when the British representatives sought to be mediators. In the end, as it turned, by both groups, the conference came to an untimely end.
AS a result of the failure of the Arab-Jewish conference, the British Government, on May 17, 1939, issued its official statement of policy with regard to Palestine in what is commonly known as the MacDonald White Paper. This document envisaged the establishment, within ten years, of an independent Palestinian state, in which both Jews and Arabs were to participate equally, according to population, in a representative form of government. When once established, the independent state would be obligated by treaty relationship only with Great Britain. A transitory or probationary period of ten years was specified for the development of self-government. If, at the end of this period, the British Government should consider that the establishment of the independent states should be postponed, the British administration could remain unchanged. (2) Regarding the character of the Jewish National Home in Palestine, the British Government announces its adherence to the Balfour Declaration of 1917 which was given in the Command Paper of 1922; namely, that the terms of the Balfour Declaration did not contemplate that Palestine as a whole should be converted into a Jewish National Home, but that such a home should be founded in Palestine. (3) The fact that more than 300,000 Jews had immigrated to Palestine since 1922 and the fact that the National Home had risen by 1939 to some 450,000 approximately one-third of the entire country, gave conclusive evidence that the Mandatory Power had been carrying out its obligation. While the Arabs have acclaimed the new British policy, the ardent Zionists have denounced it, and maintain that "it betokens a surrender to Moslem Terrorism." The British answer to this latest criticism, is well expressed in the concluding paragraph of the Chamberlain White Paper: His Majesty's Government cannot hope to satisfy the partisans of one party or the other in such a controversy as the Mandate has aroused. Their purpose is to be just as between the two peoples in Palestine whose destinies in that country have been affected by the great events of recent years, and who, since they live side by side, must learn to practice mutual tolerance, goodwill and co-operation. Complicated and difficult as the Arab-Jewish problem in Palestine appears, the writer ventures the following conclusions: (1) The only hope of the realization of Zionist ambitions for establishment of an exclusive Jewish National Home, a state controlled politically by a preponderate Jewish population, rests either in the application of the principle of expatriation or partition to the solution of the problem. In the case of the former, the problem is complicated because of the intense nationalistic aspirations of the Arabs already on the land; in the case of the latter, in the opinion of the writer the more feasible solution, the problem becomes involved because of the vast amount of capital already expended by the Zionists in the reclamation of the whole of Palestine, and because of the intense cultural and religious interests of both Jews and Arabs in shrines such as are included in the proposed Jerusalem enclave and which, in any plan of partition, must necessarily be excluded from the control of either race. (2) It appears from an examination of the postwar commitments with regard to Palestine, that both Zionists and Arab Nationalists have exaggerated their claims and falsely accused the British Mandatory Power of a breach of faith in their behalf. (3) Whatever the ultimate solution, this much is certain, the success of any future homeland for either Arabs or Jews in Palestine will depend upon their collaboration, cooperation, and mutual conciliation.

A Stone, in Place of Bread "Or what man is there of you, if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone?" (Matt. 7:9). THIS soul-searching question of the Savior recalls to one's mind the almost sublime relationship which exists between a child and his parents? the sweet dependency, utter trust, and confidence of a child in his parents, and the feeling of security enjoyed by the child because his parents ever strive to provide a protecting bulwark between him, in his youth, and the world at large. The parent, on his side, treasures his God-given eternal gift and plans and dreams for his future joy with almost a selfless love. In the early, formative years of a child's life before he has reached the years of accountability at the age of eight, the foundation of his character is built largely upon his observation of the actions of his parents and the training that they are able to implant as a guide to his conduct. Rarely does a parent fail to provide the necessary food for the full development of his child's physical body; but, in the matter of his full spiritual growth, how often does a man, "if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone?" These early years are the golden time in which to feed a child the bread of life, the time to train him to pray, to keep holy the Sabbath day, to pay his tithing, to observe the Word of Wisdom, to uphold the Church authorities and in all his daily conduct to train him to live in such a way that the Spirit of the Lord may ever dwell with him. Any laxness in the strict observance of the laws of the Church by his parents will be noted by a child, and may have a lasting influence upon his future life. A mother who drinks tea or coffee opens wide the door for her child to reject other parts of the Word of Wisdom which she herself does observe. A father who allows liquor to be served in his home, even though he himself does not partake of it, is inviting his children to become partakers when they are grown. Page 30 The use of alcohol with its attendant misery and degradation is becoming more widespread each day, and all that any Latter-day Saint parent can do, by example and precept, to impress upon his children the tragic effects which alcohol has upon the lives of those who use it, is absolutely essential. These are but two instances of the many which might be cited where a parent offers to his child a stone in place of bread. In the matter of setting an example to one's children it might be profitable for Latter-day Saint parents also to consider the significance of these words of the Savior: Verily, verily, I say unto you, the Son can do nothing of himself, but what he seeth the Father do: for what things soever he doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise? (John 5:19) At the beginning of the new year, then, let any parent who may have been lax in the example he has set his child, set his house in order, and provide at all times for his child the bread of everlasting life. M.S.S. The Y. W. M. I. A. Observed its Diamon Jubilee. The Y.W.M.I.A. observed its diamond Jubilee, Tuesday, November 28, 1944, with impressive services conducted in the Lion House in the same room where President Brigham Young assembled his daughters seventy-five years ago and effected an organization whereby the daughters of Israel might "get a living testimony of the truth" and "improve in everything that is good and beautiful." This Association originally known as the Retrenchment Association, later as the Young Ladies' Mutual Improvement Association, and at present as the Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association, has, during its seventy-five years of existence, touched the lives of tens of thousands of the daughters of Zion, helping them to develop their talents, obtain knowledge of the gospel, and to live happy, useful lives in conformity with gospel standards.
An opening feature of the observance in the Lion House was the reading by Presiding Patriarch Joseph F. Smith of words spoken by President Young in founding the Association. President Lucy G. Cannon then spoke, relating interesting facts and incidents connected with its beginning. She also talked of the earnestness with which the daughters of President Young accepted their assignment as members of the Association, and also gave interesting statistics showing its activities and growth. Among the honored guests were Ruth May Fox, age ninety-one, only living past president of the organization who delightfully reminisced, and two of President Young's daughters, Mrs. Mabel Y. Sanborn and Mrs. Fannie Y. Clayton. A very impressive and appropriate feature of the occasion was the marking of the organization room by an artistic plaque bearing an inscription relative to the founding of the organization including words of President Young used in inaugurating the Association. Elder George Albert Smith, after paying tribute to the organization and those identified with it through the years, dedicated the plaque.
The Relief Society General Board recognizes the importance of the Y.W.M.I.A. in the program of the Church, and acknowledges with gratitude its excellent contribution in guiding and directing the daughters of Zion. It congratulates the Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association on its past achievements and wishes for it continued growth and accomplishment. B.S.S. NOTES TO THE FIELD Remodeled clothing TODAY, when clothing is of wartime quality and prices are high, many women are finding it advantageous to search their closets for used clothing of prewar quality to remodel into attractive, serviceable garments. Children's clothing, at present, presents a special problem in that it is not only expensive and of wartime quality, but in many localities it is difficult to buy. The wise, thrifty mother is clothing her children with garments remade from used clothing. Following are a few suggestions for remodeling clothing: General Suggestions for Procedure 1. Be sure used material is worth using again. Don't waste time on worn, threadbare, or moth-eaten materials that won't last. 2. Be sure old articles are carefully picked apart, washed or dry cleaned, and pressed before using. Most woolen materials can be washed, 3. Be sure fabric is suitable for the planned remodeled article. Don't use materials of a weave, weight, or color not suited to the uses to which the remodeled article will be put. Some fabrics have a definite "adult" look and should be used in remodeling articles for adults; other fabrics are more suitable for children's clothing. Don't use material that is too heavy for small children's clothes. 4. A style should be chosen when remodeling to fit the material so that a minimum of piecing need be done. 5. Don't use original buttonholes, loop fastenings, etc., unless they are substantial. Generally, the original garment receives most wear at these points. Page 32 6. Be careful of color combinations. Poor color combinations may readily spoil an otherwise attractive garment. 7, Material that is worth using is worthy of good workmanship. The same fine workmanship should go into remodeled articles as goes into articles made of new material. Suggestive Remodeling Projects A. For boys 1. Pants from adults' pants 2. Overcoats from adults' overcoats (if material isn't too heavy). 3. Snowsuits from old suits or coats, or from woolen or heavy part-woolen blankets. 4. Shirts in small sizes from adults' shirts, especially from dress shirts where, frequently, only the collar is worn. 5. Shorts from men's shirts (if material is strong enough). 6. Sport coats from men's coats (if they have patch pockets). If pockets are set-in, then a sleeveless jerkin could be made, or the back and sleeves could be used for part of a sport coat and a contrasting material could be used to complete the garment. 7. Coveralls or play suits for the small child who crawls or for the toddler ?either boy or girl?from the backs of the legs of old overalls. B. For girls 1. Suits from men's suits (if fabric and color are suitable). 2. Small gored skirts or jumpers from men's coats. 3. Coats from ladies' coats (if material is sufficiently youthful looking)- 4. Dresses from adults' dresses (if fabric and color are suitable). 5. White blouses from men's white shirts. NOTES TO THE FIELD 33 7. Panties from shirt tails, from the bottom of underslips, or from underslips used with sheer party or formal dresses. 8. Front aprons from men's shirts. 9. Jerkins from soft woolen articles. 10. Envelope handbags, lapel ornaments, half hats or flowers for the hair, and other accessories, from old bright felt hats. General Suggestions 1. Pieces cut from old suits or coats, crocheted around and sewed together make good afghans. VICTORY Evelyn Fjeldsted If one can work a score of years To prove a fact that few can see And still, undaunted, can persist? This is an unseen victory. If condemnation one must face Because of someone's treachery, If he can know that truth in time Will free?this, too, is victory. If through misfortune one has lost His earthly goods and trusted friends, If he with hope can build again? This, we agree, is victory. Mama's Boy Alice Morrey Bailey TOMMY 34 Mama's Boy
By Jane Mercy Bailey
TOMMY began to get the feeling even before Billy punched him in the ribs. It was afternoon, and Miss Deering was putting number work on the blackboard. ?Lookee here? Billy said displaying the small plastic jeep, shining new from the top of his pocket. Tommy looked at it with interest, wishing he could have one just like it. ?And lookee here," said Billy, showing a bright toy and a pack of marbles, still in the red mesh bag. They were beautiful marbles of clear, polished glass, and caught the light in small pools of blue, yellow, crystal, and green. Tommy?s fingers wanted to touch them, but he didn?t reach out. Billy always had new things-new pencils, new erasers, and new toys.
"Where'dja get them?" Tommy asked. "Glancing around, Billy leaned closer. "Come with me down to the five and ten after school, and we'll get you some."
"I haven't any money," said Tommy.
"Don?t need money. You just take them. I'll show you how."
"But we would be stealing?"
"Naw! All the kids do it. They don't get of stuff down there."
"I don't want to. My mother wouldn?t want me to,? said Tommy. ?Yah! Ha! Mama?s Boy,? Jeered Billy, forgetting not to whisper loud. Miss Deering looked at them, which meant not to disturb the class. When Tomy tried to be still the feeling came stronger and stronger. He looked out the window, but that didn?t help. Only there was dirty snow, and black smoke and chimneys and ugly brick walls. It wasn?t like Still valley where you could see the foothills, except for the cotton woods along the creek bed.
All these things crowded in on Tommy until he couldn't stand it?even the things in the room, the wigwams and the green trees and the reared-back Indians that the second graders had painted on wrapping paper with poster paint. All at once Tommy had to get out, or he was going to bawl. He had to see mother. 
Miss Deering's voice reached out to stop him when he left his seat and went toward the door, but he went right through the sound, like wading the little canal when the current was swift. Sometimes she just let him go, but today she followed him out to the hallway where he was putting on his galoshes.
"Tommy, come back," she said. "You know it won't do any good to go home. Your mother won't be there until five. Why won't you stay until school is out?"
Tommy didn't answer. He went on fastening his galoshes.
"Don't you want to be promoted? If you keep going home every day in the middle of the class period you will not learn all you should. You will have to stay in the second grade a long time, and people will think you are dumb!"
Still Tommy didn't answer. It was just words that the teacher was saying. The sound of her voice beat up in his ears in waves, like irrigation water backing up against a dam. She put her hand on his shoulder, but he only weighed eighty-one pounds, and down the steps.
Maybe mother would have a headache and would have sick leave, like she did one Saturday, when she was home all day. She pulled him in bed with her and he was warm and comfortable, almost like being in Still Valley again.
It was nice there, especially in summer, when the cottonwoods floated gauzy seed pods down, and when you could lie on your stomach on the bridge and fish for pretty rocks, or look into the glassy water until you could see yourself speeding upstream.
Mother's fingers were sometimes butter-gooey from making cake, and you could like to see if the setting hen had stolen her nest in the woodpile. Mother knew why a four-leafed clover had four leaves, and where God was, and why the old sow grunted instead of talking.
"Heavenly Father, make mother have a headache,? he prayed as he knelt down, and then almost skipped. He almost remember that she had been sick a little before she went to work. He was sure she would be home this time.
BUT mother didn't have a headache, and she wasn't home. The furniture was there?the new pink davenport and the overstuffed chair that you couldn't put your feet on, but the house was empty. Tommy ran through it shouting: ?Mother! Mother!? so loud his ears rang when he quit, but there was no answer. 
The little hand on the clock was between two and three, so Tommy took it down off the shelf and set with it between his knees on the linoleum. Then, because the kitchen had cold breakfast dishes on the table, and the back looked like old hens at molting time, and the bathroom had damp floors on the floor. Tommy waited and waited and cried awhile because he thought she might not come at all, and it seemed like a million years until the little hand was on the five, and she opened the door.
"Mommy!" he said, and was so startled he couldn't tell what she looked like.
"Tommy Haman!" she said, snatching the clock from him. "If you touch my alarm, I'll never get to work on time."
It was then he noticed the two straight marks between her eyebrows, and that her hair was tight in little iron curls and her mouth was sticky with red stuff she used to ?keep herself up.? When she saw that he sat so till and that his mouth was dumb with the lump in his throat she hugged him and said: ?I?m sorry.? She even smiled, but her face was like the apartment when he came home. Her features were there, like the furniture, but she was gone. ?We have to hurry now-get the house cleaned, supper and to bed with you Mother?s having company-some of the girls from the plant.? "I don't want them," said Tommy. "Call them up and tell them not to come."
"Why, Tommy! That wouldn't be polite. Besides, this is your daddy's last night on swing shift, and he'll be home evenings after this."
They weren't girls, though, when they came. They were big ladies, like mother, and they sat in mother's living room and laughed and all talked at once, and sounded like the pallets when you jumped suddenly into the coop and said "Boo!" Tommy was shut in the bedroom and he still wanted his mother.
"Mother! Mother!" He shouted until the cackling all stopped, and mother came through the slit of light from the opened door.
"There's a Tiger in the closet," he said, so she left the door open a little crack, and said "nonsense."
"Children are certainly a headache," she said when she got back to the living room. Maybe Heavenly Father had answered his prayers.
Tommy's always been such a mama's boy," she went on, and Tommy, hearing her, winced with shame. "You know he gets so homesick for me he just gets up and leaves the schoolroom every day just like that?nobody can stop him when he chooses any day."
"His father wants me to quit work and stay home," his mother continued.
"That would be a mistake," said a lady, and her voice sounded like she thought she was smart. "He'll have a mother complex if you don't look out."
"That's just what I think," agreed his mother. "Besides, I want to get a few things."
"Do you think you'll go back to the farm after the war?"
Tommy held his breath, listening. "I'll say not! Never a new thing, and nothing but work! I didn't know how bad it was until we moved. I finished paying for my overstuffed just the other day. Now I want to get two tables and two blue lamps?"
Tommy's stomach hurt with disappointment, and he cried a little because he couldn't remember what his mother looked like with her hair loose and her eyes soft, but the next day he didn't come home. When his teacher came, he chewed his pencil and thought fast about the blue lumps and about her thinking he was a mama's boy. And after school, when out he went with Billy down to the five-and-ten.

PEBBLES Norma Wrathall I took some pebbles from the brook, Their colors glowing clear and bright With shades of blue and amethyst, And coral streaked with white; But as they dried upon my hand They were as dull and drab as sand. Rare moments snatched from life's swift flow Fade as we long to hold them fast; Dear cherished dreams grow old before We catch a fleeting glimpse at last; And yet, in retrospect they seem Like pebbles shining in the stream.

Forward, Without Fear Dorothy Clapp Robinson "Watch your words," Matt Lewis had cautioned the girls as two officers came into camp. They were hunting Niels. They accused him of stealing a sack of food. Niels hearing them from the side of Johanna's sick bed slipped away. Ann Kristin thinking to save both him and the sick girl confesses to taking the food. Instead of freeing Niels the officers decided to take both of them, and started to hunt for the "big Swede." They were saved by Jake who pretended he had also been hunting Niels. He told the officers where to go to find him. After they had gone, the girls persuaded Jake to stay and eat with them. Patty Lou transferred her anger at him to Ann Kristin, demanding to know just where she got so much food. Ann refused to tell, then Helga discovered Ann's ring was missing. That broke down the resentment Patty Lou had always felt toward Ann Kristin. So she told them that Tom Bedloe had taken their money. He had also taken her money?claiming to have given it to Elder Lewis. The two men were just starting out to find Bedloe when Helga came running for help. Johanna was dying. CHAPTER VI THE Camp of Israel was a long way from the banks of the Mississippi. A long way in time, in wearied footsteps, and in heartaches over what had been left behind. In the same crowded cemetery Johanna and Edward Lewis lay sleeping side by side. Because she had so loved the city, which to her had meant Zion, Niels and Matt had taken Johanna there, where her bones could rest in the shadow of the temple. A week later they had placed Edward Lewis beside her. Still later, they had begun the series of moves that had, two years later, placed them on the plains of Iowa not far from Winter Quarters. Twice Jake had been able to move their few belongings, and twice Matilda Lewis had put them in her own overloaded wagon. Ann Kristin was thinking of all this and much more as she walked toward her home. It was late afternoon and hot, but the heat was dry. Not sticky as it ha'been along the river. Ted Lewis, walking beside her, sighed. "Tou should not have come with me, Ted," Ann Kristin told him. "It is too much walking." 'Pooh. I can walk as far as any girl." Then he sighed again. "I wish I was a sheep herder. That was a big band of sheep. I bet there was a million sheep in it." *] am afraid not quite so many. If there had been a million brambles, there would have been more wool." "Have we got enough wool to make Anna a coat?" he asked. "Well," Ann Kristin looked at the mat of dirty wool in her apron, "there is enough for a pair of stockings, perhaps. Tomorrow I shall follow the herd again. Perhaps then we will have enough for a coat." "You can't go out alone," Ted warned. "The Injuns might see you." "But there will be more wool farther out. There were too many women following the herd today." "I am going to marry Anna when Page 37 I grow up. I like girls with yellow I grow up. I like girls with yellow hair."
"That will be a long time. Anna is only ten."
"Oh, not so long," Ted answered wisely. "I'm not going to be an old bachelor like Matt. He says he has enough of women. I'm not going to make an excuse. She says she is in love with someone, and is too stubborn to know it. Anyway, Becky didn't wait for him. She got married."
"Was he in love with Becky?"
"Gosh, yes. He walked her to all the meetings and dances. Anyway, I have to go west before I get married or maybe I won't. I might be a freighter like Jake and Matt or even a scout like Jim Bridger."
"Does your mother say whom he is in love with?" Ann Kristin asked, hesitantly.
"Who is in love?" Ted demanded. "I do not know. You said your mother?"
"Ah, don't care if I am in love with Anna. She says it is quite safe. Golly," he cried suddenly, "look at the dust. It's a wagon train. They will have the mail. Maybe Patty Lou will get her letter."
"Perhaps," Kristin wasn't sure she wanted Patty Lou to receive her letter. That would mean she would leave them. "Jake might be with them."
"It is a long one. Let's run," Ted urged.
Ann Kristin shook her head. "You run, Ted. Probably if you can across the coulee you can meet them."
The boy dashed away, his bare feet skimming over the dry earth. It was incredible after all the walking he had done. She watched closely. She could tell by the dust that it was a long train. Probably on its way to Winter Quarters, or perhaps even to Fort Laramie or Fort Bridger. It would bring mail and very likely more saints. It would lay over here in camp all night. Her pulse quickened. If Tom did come back and news of the saints scattered among the trail. There would be no news for her, unless she held the thought a moment, unless Tom should write to her.
The evening of Johanna's death, Jake and Matt had visited the trader, Willkins, seeing them had given them more satisfaction than information, for Willkins, seeing them in time, had bolted his door and fled, thereby establishing his guilt. Becky had never found him. Nor had he ever returned to Ann Kristin for his answer. The humiliation of it had left its mark.
Of all the scars there was none so deep as that caused by the death of Edward Lewis, and none that had brought with it such deep humility. They had chosen to leave Norway, the death of her parents had not been preventable. Poverty she was learning to endure, and camping would, in some happy day, be a thing of the past; yet she would never be able to forget what she had done to her. "Tell Evelin she can't do it. It will be too hard. To make it harder to bear, almost in last words had been to her. "Tell Evelin not to blame herself," Ann Kristin was learning to trust my Maker."
The weeks had passed, Tom said. "Pa had done a good work and his time had come. Let's honor him by working for the future, not the past. There is too much to do to spend time in grieving or regretting."
Ma, her eyes told Ann Kristin she would always grieve; and the girl wondered again at the depth of her love and understanding, her capacity for forgiveness. FORWARD, WITHOUT FEAR 39 Love of a gospel that would foster such growth grew in Ann Kristin, and dissolved the fibers of her uncertainty and self-concern. When the moves came, they clung to Mrs. Lewis. Her family accepted their presence as one more feature of the unnatural life they were leading. In the two years Matt had been with his mother only twice, briefly, and both times had avoided Ann Kristin. CIRCLING the camp, Ann Kristin approached her home. It was a sod shanty the girls had erected themselves. It was the best home they'd had for two years. It would keep them warm when winter came, if they were still here. Here, as at Camp Lewis, much of their living was done outside. Helga and Patty Lou were sitting before their shanty waiting for Kristin. Patty Lou was holding a skein of yarn over her wrists, while Helga wound it into a ball. Little Anna was toddling between the two trying to reach the thread. She was small boned like Johanna, and with Johanna's flaxen hair, but her eyes and features were much more like Niels'. They all adored her, but to Helga she was the sum total of life. She was all the lovely things Helga had lived and loved, and still hoped for. "This is all the yarn I have," Helga sighed with regret, "and I haven't any more wool." "You-all?,"" Patty Lou corrected herself, quickly, 'you use more wool than any dozen women in camp. Why don't Kristin come? It will be evening directly, and no sign of her." Helga took Anna, protesting loudly, on her lap and began undressing her. "She must have stopped to visit someone. No. No," as the baby tried to push off her lap, "come, Helga will sing you a song." She rocked back and forth as she sang softly, "Sof du min lilla, min alsk-ling, ar du jom?" "Do you reckon she is fretting over Tom Bedloe?" Patty Lou interrupted. "She's powerful dreamy lately. She doesn't sing any more." "Ann Kristin has too much sense to be unhappy over a man like Tom Bedloe." Helga spoke shortly, "I think it is something else." "Do you reckon she is in love? That Bill Hooper comes here plenty often. I see him watching her when he thinks no one is looking. Do you reckon she loves him?" "It is quite possible. Girls her age are usually in love, if they aren't married. I thought Bill came here to see you." "I thought so, too, at first." Patty Lou sighed. "I won't do any complaining about it but it does seem mighty queer. Every man that comes to see me falls in love with her. I reckon I got to get used to bearing burdens." She changed the subject abruptly. "Do you reckon that wagon train will ever get here?" "It should be here by tomorrow at the latest. That is what the scout said." "That no-account Jake Nickols had better be here. We are getting mighty low on food." Helga looked up from the baby. "Patty, how can you continue to take food from Jake when you don't love him?" When she found Patty Lou did not intend to answer, she continued. "He sent word he would be here, and he has never failed to keep his word, except when he swore to catch Tom Bedloe; but he'll do that, eventually "S-sh. Here comes Kristie." Helga looked around. Anna gave a squeal of delight and tried to wiggle out of Helga's arms. Kristin stooped to kiss her. "I can't take you now, Alskling, my lap is full." "What have you got?" Patty Lou asked. For answer Ann Kristin opened her apron and showed them. "We heard that a band of sheep was passing so I dismissed school and followed them. All the wool nearby had been gathered, so I had to go a long way. I am going again in the morning, while it is cool. You want to go with me, Patty?" "Not me. If it is so far the other women haven't already picked it, I'd never make it." "You are lazy?oh, I forgot. A wagon train is coming into Camp. The mail might be here already." "Sure-enough?" "Sure-enough." In an instant, Patty Lou was up and away. Ann Kristin went inside. After washing, she put on a clean apron. VOUR supper is on the table," Helga called. "There are some string beans. Sister Andrews brought them to pay for Danny's schooling. What do you think she said?" Ann Kristin waited to answer. She put a slice of bread on the plate of beans. Going outside, she sat on the box where Patty Lou had been. "What did she say?" she asked. Breaking a crust from the bread, she handed it to Anna. "She said how thankful she was to be in the same camp with a great lady like you, so her little crippled Danny could learn to read and write. It is we who are blessed. If you could not get pupils we would starve." Ann Kristin smiled at her sister's extravagant statement. "You knit and Niels sends flour, not to mention Jake's occasional contributions. I wish I needn't charge. I could weep when I see what sacrifices parents make that their children may have a little learning." "Most parents are like Sister Andrews. What makes you so restless? Are you tired?" "A little." Then she asked quickly, "Do you know what day this is?" "July 10, 1846. Four years to the day since we sailed from Norway. That was a long time ago. Almost another world." "Quite another world. Four years* ago we were those proud Mortensen girls. We had no thought of anything but marrying well and settling down to a well-ordered existence in the parish where generations of Mortensen?s had lived and died. Then?," She stopped and Helga picked up the thought. "Then father heard the gospel, and here we are. Camp of Israel, Indian Lands, U. S. A." "Since we never get mail, no one is interested in our address. Where will we be next?" Helga's ears caught the threatened sob in her sister's voice. She saw that Ann Kristin was studying FORWARD, WITHOUT FEAR 41 her hand. She could use it now, but it would never look normal again. She chuckled. "Farther west. And we were so sure our troubles would be over when we reached Nauvoo." She got up and went inside to put Anna in her cradle. Coming back, she took up her knitting. She suggested that Ann Kristin do the same; but Kristin was in no mood for knitting. "Do you suppose we shall ever be married and have homes of our own? I mean real homes with flowers and gardens and pastures and cattle? And milk to drink once more?" "I doubt it." Helga's practical mind saw only the present. "Even if we should go west to the Rocky Mountains or into Oregon, I should think the Indians would keep us living in forts. Would you mind?" "Mind." Ann Kristin turned the word about. "Mind? I ache to get settled. Every girl wants a home and a family. What is there?but I am glad I am here and very thankful. Our lives in Loftshammar were stale and without purpose, in comparison." "Hmm-m. Plenty of purpose I would say. We worked and ate and lived in houses, and went to school and directed the work of the servants?." "Helga," Kristin interrupted, "do you remember the stories mother used to tell us when we were children? I loved most the stories of the early Christians. Because they were true to their faith they changed the history of mankind. Do you suppose?do you think our suffering will be remembered even in a small way? Look what our people are doing. Sister Lewis for instance. She is a cultured, refined woman. She has lost every material possession except what can be hauled in one wagon. It is seven years since she left her home. She has lost her husband." "Now, Kristie, let's not go into that again." "She has lost everything, yet she acts as if she had the riches of the world at her feet. Even under these primitive conditions she never lowers her standards. Surely such faith and devotion will?." "You are such a dreamer." "But it can't be wasted effort, Helga, nor insignificant. It means more than our eyes can see or our understanding grasp. Something great and powerful will come from it." "I am not interested in history. What I want is a home right now, and a family and a place where we can worship in peace." "Do you know what Sister Lewis told me? Because we are not sure of the future, we must face it with full confidence. We must go forward, without fear. We must hold and appreciate each little moment of happiness that comes our way. But you needn't worry. You will have Niels and Anna." Helga did not answer for a moment. When she looked at her sister, her eyes were troubled. "I could not endure having him take Anna away from me, but he has never spoken of marriage. In a year and a half he has written once." "But he has sent messages and supplies by Jake. Niels was ever a man of few words. You know, Min Alskling, in Norway you would not have looked at him except as you would look on any laborer, but we are not in Norway. When you 
are not in Norway. When you are gone, I will be alone."
Helga threw up her hands. "Who could be alone in this camp?"
"Many people are alone, even in a crowd."
"I understand what you mean. At home, Kristin, you had your pick of the boys. Why do you refuse the attentions of the young men here? Are you grieving for Thomas Bedloe?"
Ann Kristin's eyes had been turning restlessly to the prairie. The setting sun had brushed it with a bright varnish. Her glance came back suddenly to meet her sister's. "It still hurts. I suppose that is pride." She got up and moved about. "How could he have been so charming and yet so sedentful? I always ask myself that when I walk with Bill Hooper or Phil Westover. Tom seemed as sincere as they. Do you think there could have been a mistake?"
"No. Matt is not the kind to jump to hasty conclusions. We know for certain Tom did not give Patty Lou's money to Elder Lewis."
DUSK was settling over the prairie. Shadows lengthened, and mingled into a dusky curtain. Patty Lou had started a small fire. The smoke caught at Ann Kristin's heart. It was so long since Patty had danced. "See what I have. My letter from papa."
"Did the wagon train get in?"
"Only the mail." Unexpectedly she dropped to the ground and began to cry. "Just think. My first letter in two years. He is a good writer. See!" Pride dried her tears. "And he sent me this. What is it?"
She passed a slip of heavy green paper to them. Kristin scrutinized it.
"Patty, it is money. You must take it to a bank. We had similar ones in our box."
Patty Lou snatched it. She turned it over and over. "I've never heard tell of such money."
Kristin explained. Patty's eyes widened with delight. "Jake it to Nauvoo on his next trip. It is going to be lonesome without you, Patty Lou."
"Without me? Why should I go clear up to Nauvoo? Jake can get my things for me."
"It will save time. You will have to go there anyway back on your way back to Alabama."
"Who said anything about going back to Alabama?"
"Patty Lou Turner. Didn't you tell your father you would go home if he sent the money?"
"I did not. I said I was tired of living like a woodchuck. I'm sorry if he misunderstood. This money will buy a wagon. Maybe Niels and Jake can get us some oxen. Then we can go on being uncomfortable for another right smart spell."
Ann Kristin did not know whether to kiss the girl or shake her. "You can't do it. It would not be honest."
"Why? He's my very own papa, isn't he? If he don't know me by now, like a dumb shame."
The girls laughed. "That was so like Patty Lou. If she actually made a promise nothing could swerve her from it, but no one else was so adept at evasion. She turned their logic aside so cleverly they were left smiling. Helga's fine sense of honor was outraged. "A fine saint you are."
Patty Lou began to cry again, then, dry sobs that shook her slender body. Kristin was provoked at Helen for being so harsh.
"Don't cry, dear," she said softly.
"Don't you think I want to go home? Do you think it is easy to stay here? I love my family."
Ann Kristin looked at Helen, and then they were crying, hugging relief for themselves and despair for Patty Lou who had cried for so long. Their tears did what their argument had failed to do. Patty Lou wiped her eyes on her apron. Holding up the slip of paper, she kissed it dramatically.
"Goodbye?" She stopped short. The creaking of wheels brought them to their feet. Jake was driving into their dooryard. Behind him were three other wagons. Patty Lou looked at the driver in the first and her face paled. Jake jumped to the ground. The hand she held out to him was trembling violently.
"Jake?Jake?is it??"
"Yes, honey. It's them."

VISITING TEACHING Oakland Stake (California) RUTH S. HILTON, stake Relief Society president, reported in 1944 that at the officers' meeting in connection with the 1943 ward Relief Society conference ?we suggested and urged that special meetings or conventions be held in all of the wards for the purpose of honoring and giving instruction to the visiting teachers, as well as to furnish opportunity for personal expression of problems by the visiting teachers themselves.
