"Especially honored at the program was Emma Nay who had the longest unbroken visiting teaching record?67 years of service. Awards for long years of service as visiting teachers were also given to Sena Larsen. Second Ward, 40 years; Hannah Rentier, Third Ward, 46 years; Mattie C. Nielson, Fourth Ward, 44 years; Tessie Oldroyd, Glenwood, Ward, 20 years; Mae Nielson, Sigurd Ward, 35 years; Hannah Anderson, Koosharem Ward, 35 years. Individuals having perfect attendance records for one year or more were Carol Salisbury, Edith Balle, Emily Nebeker, Elvira Dastrup, and Myrtle Bagley. "A beautiful vase of flowers was VISITING TEACHERS OF MANCHESTER WARD, SOUTH LOS ANGELES STAKE, which reported in August 1944, that for eight successive months all 27 districts had achieved 100 per cent visiting teaching by the second week of each month. Alta Boice is ward Relief Society president and Delia Wilson, the visiting teachers' message leader. presented to the Richfield Second Ward in recognition of 13 1/2 consecutive years of 100 per cent visiting teaching. Lovely vases of flowers were also given to the Boxcreek and Richfield First Wards for obtaining Magazine subscription rates of more than 75 per cent. "The awards were made by Ivy Ashby, Maiben Thomson, and Let-ta Staples of the Sevier Stake Relief Society presidency. "After the program, a lovely tea, carrying out a blue and gold color scheme, was enjoyed in the recreational hall. The committee on arrangements included Ruth Rowley, Marvel Dewey, and Vilda Helquist, with all members of the stake board assisting." Idaho Falls Stake (Idaho) IDETTA E. MERRILL, president of this stake Relief Society, reports that a stake visiting teachers' convention was held last September to which were invited the stake presidency, advisory high councilman, ward bishops, ward Relief Society executive officers, and visiting teachers. The aim of the convention was to explain the modification in funds, the change in meetings, and to increase an appreciation of the teachers' duties. The stake board presented a model teachers' training - report meeting. Stake board members representing visiting teachers gave verbal reports as the stake secretary called the districts by number. The stake message leader gave a sample lesson, and the president's message included the information regarding discontinuance of collections and the combination of report and training meetings. NOTES FROM THE FIELD VISITING TEACHERS OF IDAHO FALLS STAKE at a stake visiting teachers' convention, September 24, 1944 "We prepared skits for the wards to present, demonstrating visiting teachers confronting the problems of (1) making friends where they were formerly not welcome; (2) solving the visiting of the out-lying district; ad (3) showing teachers ability to meet emergences. A second group of skits depicted incidents proving the value of service done by visiting teachers. ?Refreshments were served and a spirit of friendliness was enjoyed.?

THE FLEXIBLE HOUSE Adeline J. Haws To Marie and Leonard Tanner The flexible house on a corner stands And the back door faces the street. It's easy as easy to get inside With loads of good things to eat. Although it was built for only two. It more oft has ten or more, Sleeping somewhere between its walls? On bed, on couch or floor. Nobody ever saw it bulge? It was never known to shrink? But to hold all the folk it holds sometimes It must have stretched, I think. The table is short or the table is long According to who is there; But food never enters hungry lips Without a 'Thank You" prayer. Oh, the flexible house could tell some tales Of happy hours, I ween. If it could talk and tell the things That it has heard and seen. There's a parlor with plenty of room for fun. And windows that open in, A mantle with pictures, a fireplace, A kitchen with stove and bin. Yes, the flexible house is a happy house Because it is a part Of the folk who made it the Flexible House In the bigness of their heart.

entries.title: The Salvage of Tin Is Essential

loose_match.content: The Salvage of Tin Is Essential Tin, used in small proportions and almost exclusively in combination with other strategic metals, is a concealed war weapon, and a deadly one. It goes into every war machine, on land, sea, or in the air. A battleship contains 76 tons of tin. The intricate machinery of a submarine calls for more than 3 tons of tin. A destroyer must have 490 pounds of tin for its electrical system alone. Every heavy bomber must have 48 pounds of tin, every medium tank 35 pounds, every Diesel engine 13 pounds. Airplane motors, cannon, machine guns, bomb sights, gas masks, torpedoes, and hand grenades, radio, telephone, and telegraph equipment?all demand tin. Tin, known among the ancients as the "devil of the metals," because of its unique effect on the physical properties of other metals when combined with them, is the hidden but irreplaceable component in the alloys that go into war equipment and in the solders that hold many of the parts together.. Also for medical items tin is indispensable. The fighting man's individual morphine hypodermic syringe (syrette), his emergency sulfa ointments, blood plasma, and other medicaments are kept free from contamination in containers of pure tin or tin-coated steel. All these urgent military needs as well as essential civilian demands for tin must be met out of a diminishing supply of this metal.. Though this country has long been the world's largest consumer of tin, it has produced practically none, for workable tin deposits are almost nonexistent in the United States?or anywhere else in North America. Ever since the beginning of the war, the United States has been learning to do without tin for all but the most essential uses. Tin coated containers may be used only for those products which must be packed in tin. The use of tin has been banned for kitchen utensils, galvanized ware, toys, costume jewelry, Christmas tree ornaments, and many other items. Tin foil is permitted to be used for electrotype machines, electrical condenser, and a few other essential purposes, but none can be made available to wrap such items as tobacco, chocolate or cheese for civilians... An important factor in filling the gap is the salvaging of tin from tin cans. Billions of cans, each containing 1 per cent pure tin by weight, go into American homes each year. They are the most dependable source of tin in the Nation today... Since the launching of the tin can salvage program in the spring of 1942, collections have grown from 1,000 tons a month to 20,000 tons, or approximately 200,000,000 cans, at the present time. But the country's 8 detinning and 6 shredding plants are able to handle tin cans at twice the current rate. Two out of three tin cans going into homes are still being lost in garbage piles?a loss that the United States can ill afford.-War Board Salvage Your Tin! Page 48

Special Problems in Housekeeping Claire P. Dorious Oh wad some power the giftie gie us to see oursels as others see us!?Robert Burns Spots and Stains. One important wartime job is to take care of what we have. A spot or stain spoils the appearance of any fabric. Commercial laundries and dry cleaners are not always available. The wise homemaker learns to care for the family's clothing and all household fabrics herself. Fresh spots are removed more easily than old ones. It is always better to remove spots and stains before washing or cleaning the entire garment. Knowing the nature of the spot simplifies the job. Two precautions should be kept in mind: first, not to destroy the surface or finish of the material, and second, not to rub so hard that any of the dye is removed from colored fabrics. If possible, it is always safer to experiment with a small sample of the fabric. Stain Removers. Stain removers may be divided into absorbents, solvents, and bleaches. Absorbents are used mainly for the removal of grease spots. Fresh chalk, talcum powder, Fuller's earth, dry starch, cornmeal, and dry cleaning powders are absorbents. In using absorbents, spread the stained fabric on a flat surface. Cover grease spot thickly with absorbent. This may be worked around gently with the fingers. Sometimes it is necessary to leave the absorbent on the spot for several hours. It is then brushed carefully. Repeat if necessary. Grease spots are sometimes removed by placing the fabric between, two sheets of white blotting paper and pressing the spot with a warm iron. Several thicknesses of paper towels serve the same purpose. These treatments are effective for fresh stains on white or light colored fabrics. It is almost impossible to brush all traces of an absorbent from dark materials. Solvents. Solvents are used to dissolve a stain. Cleaning fluids, alcohol (denatured or wood), ammonium hydroxide, ether, carbon tetrachloride, or commercial solvents with this base may be used when water fails. When using solvents, lay the material, spot side down, on a pad of cloth or white blotting paper, apply the solvent with a soft cloth rubbing from the edge toward the center of the spot. Change the pad occasionally and also change the sponging cloth as soon as it is soiled. Caution: Most all cleaning fluids are inflammable. Be careful to use them in small quantities, work in well ventilated room, and keep stopper in bottle while working. Bleaches are used in the last attempt to remove a stain. They should be applied very carefully. Javelle water, oxalic acid, potassium permanganate, hydrogen peroxide, sodium hydro-sulphite are usually more successful for bleaching purposes than lemon juice or sour milk. Bleaches will injure fabrics unless directions are followed carefully. Method to use?Stretch the stained portion of the material over the top Page  of a bowl 1/2 to 1/4 full of hot water and fasten tightly with a rubber band, then apply the remover with a medicine dropper. Be sure to rinse out all bleaching fluid with clear water after the stain has been removed. Apply the water very carefully. Clorox, a commonly known bleach, may be used to remove some stains if directions on the bottle are followed carefully. Fruit stains are removed by stretching the fabric over a bowl and pouring hot water from a height through the spot. Miscellaneous Stains: Iron Rust-Lemon juice and salt or oxalic acid made into a concentrated solution are effective. Any good commercial iron rust remover is good for white cotton or linen. Do not use for silk or colored materials. Ink?Apply stain remover with medicine dropper. A small amount of ammonia, added to hydrogen peroxide is helpful. Two tablespoonfuls of ammonia added to the hot water will produce fumes that are often effective. Heavy Grease?Rub a small amount of clean, unsalted fat on the spot and work it around with the fingers. Wash in warm water and heavy suds. Turpentine is a well-known solvent for fresh paint to use on the hands, wood or glass. Household Pests. Most pests are remarkably adaptable. They will climb high or low in search of food. Houseflies are the most common and the most dangerous of all household pests. They may be carriers of such diseases as typhoid, tuberculosis, cholera, diarrhea and dysentery. The housefly lays it eggs in decayed animal or vegetable matter. Hence, absolute cleanliness both inside and out is necessary for its extermination. All windows and doors should be well screened. Ants are not actually harmful but their persistence is annoying. Sodium fluoride powder (poisonous), is quite effective, but keep it away from children and pets. Some sprays are also helpful. Mice. To avoid mice, guard against their entrance, by closing up all holes and cracks. The wooden snap trap is the best mouse exterminator. Cheese is not as popular with mice as freshly fried bacon, oil sardines, or peanut butter. Moths. A preliminary cleanout will da much to prevent moths. A good spray or some moth preventive should be used before storing. Store in moth-proof bags or closets or cedar chests. Cockroaches feed mainly on dead animal matter and cereals. Try to obtain expert advice. A mixture of equal parts of fresh pyrethrum and sodium fluoride is very effective. Bedbugs are no respecter of persons. Powders and sprays are effective if introduced into the places where the bugs are hidden. Mosquitoes like houseflies are carriers of disease. Their extermination should become a community project. Elimination of all breeding places is necessary. Expert advice may be obtained from a county agent or the state board of health. House rats carry disease. They are destructive and are filthy in their habits. Cutting off the rat's food and water supply is the surest way of {Continued on page 64) LESSON DEPARTMENT

Theology Church History Lesson 7?The Nauvoo Period Dr. H. Wayne Driggs For Tuesday, April 3, 1945 Objective: To study the major events numbered in the bright and dark years in and about the city of Nauvoo the Beautiful. THE bitter sorrows born in the struggle to establish the center stake of Zion in Missouri, served to throw the cause of the Church into sharp relief against political weaknesses of the State and Nation in which the kingdom of God was to rise. Little did the mobs of Missourians realize how they indirectly helped to "bring about Zion." The persecution which these unscrupulous ruffians, in fiendish delight, heaped upon the saints perfected a unity of purpose among the followers of the Prophet which God had sought, but failed to get completely during their rise to power in the days of Kirtland. For within a period of but little more than six years, a marshland, fit but for an abiding place of malarial diseases, leaving naught to recommend it but its site upon a beautiful horseshoe bend in the Mississippi River, was to shine forth a city, the like of which the State of Illinois had not known. A city graced with a temple of God whose white stones and spires were to catch the eyes of travelers for miles up and down the Father of Waters. Nauvoo the Beautiful it was to be called. The saints, now bound together in deeper love through common suffering, were to work this wonder as evidence of the fruits of the kingdom. The winter of 1839 found from ten to twelve thousand Latter-day Saints in a most pitiable condition upon the lands of Illinois. The hospitable citizens of that State donated thousands of dollars in provisions Page 51 and clothing to these suffering people. With the arrival at that early hour they laid the corner stone of the temple and heard the fulfillment of the revelation so given by the Prophet, much to the chagrin of their enemies who had declared, under oath, that these words of the Mormon leader should go unfulfilled.
With the coming of the summer of 1839, the future city of Nauvoo began to take shape above the marshy land. Blessings of the Lord, both temporal and spiritual, came abundantly. In August, seven apostles departed for England, from which place was to come a rich harvest from the missionary work begun by Heber C. Kimball and those associated with him in the opening of the British Mission. As a result, some three thousand souls came to Nauvoo by July 1, 1841. At that time, too, Brigham Young, who had been in charge of a permanent shipping agency in Great Britain, arrived with some of his brethren.
While the missionaries to England were abroad, the Prophet Joseph left his followers and made a trip to Washington to present before the officials of the National Government, there, the grievances of the saints sustained during their expulsion from the State of Missouri. Such had been the publicity of the crimes committed that the whole country had been made aware of the "Mormon problem." They now, too, held "a balance of political power in the State of Illinois" came the cry. It was upon this trip that the Prophet met and talked with President Van Buren, who at first listened to the story of the Church but, later, in fear of his own political life turned a deaf ear to justice saying, "Your cause is just, but I can do nothing for you, and if I take up

LESSON DEPARTMENT 53 for you, I shall lose the vote of Missouri." In disgust, the Prophet left the "city of politicians." His trip was not in vain, however, for during his journey he spoke to large audiences about the cause of Truth. Edward Hunter of Chester County, Pennsylvania, later a presiding bishop of the Church, came into the fold as a result of hearing the message delivered by the Prophet at this time. With the winter of i840-'41 came a most liberal charter granted to the city of Nauvoo by the legislature. So broad were its provisions that great good for the Church and its people was seen by the Prophet. A day or two after this instrument of government went into effect, on February i, 1841, a university and a Nauvoo Legion were organized. The Prophet became the head of the latter, holding the rank of lieutenant-general. Newspapers sent reporters to cover the news of the "Military Prophet." Joseph Smith's fame now had spread to two continents. Publishers sought his word for printed distribution. The result was a short account of the founding and rise of the Church, as written by the Prophet, in which, succinctly, were put the "Articles of Faith," the subject of the Relief Society theology lessons for the past three years. As one reads these, he is impressed with their simplicity and direct expression of the power of godliness. "We believe" they state. Ours is a faith that leads on to an understanding of the will of God; not a religion of the mind that is shaped from the touch-and-go interpretations of his word by men. The year 1842 found the Prophet and his people at the height of their prosperity. The Times and Seasons, a noted publication of the Church, carried the gospel truths abroad to the world. On March 17th of that year, the Relief Society for the women of the Church was organized. Everywhere, the peace of beautiful homes and thriving industries made Nauvoo a haven of rest for the twenty thousand souls who had come to Zion?a blessing and joy this was to the heart of their Prophet, who prophetically, though, had seen the bitter darkness that lay just ahead for him and his people, even as he then stood radiant in the shafts of sunlight that pierced the thickly darkening clouds. Suggestions for Active Reading and Discussion With the help of the suggestive readings given below have the class carry on the discussion as follows: first, answer the question; second, read the assigned part in the Doctrine and Covenants to discover wherein we must "give heed unto his word" which has been written especially for our life in this day. 1. Were the Prophet here today what questions of a spiritual nature might you have liked to ask him? Read sections 129, 130. Perhaps, in part, some of the questions raised by the class will be answered. The thought here is to have the teacher and class come a little closer to the natural and direct way in which the Prophet enlightened his people. Read the two epistles written by the Prophet to the saints, enjoying them much as you would a letter. These were written during the Nauvoo period when he was forced to go into hiding because of his enemies. Here is as near a personal visit with this man of God as we who were not privileged to know him in life can come (Doc. And Gov. 127, 128).

Visiting Teachers' Messages Sources of Strength?The Beatitudes Lesson 7?Blessed Are the Peacemakers Elder Bryant S. Hinckley For Tuesday, April 3, 1945 "Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God" (Matt. 5:9). Objective: To show that enduring peace between men and nations, in the home and abroad, will come only through the adoption of the precepts of the Master. TO be able to compose differences, reconcile those at variance, promote harmony and happiness is a rare and precious gift, and this is within the reach of the humblest. We may not be able to write a book, accumulate a fortune, distinguish ourselves in the field of statesmanship or politics, we may not startle the world with inventions, but we can all contribute to the peace and happiness of those about us, and, in so doing, we become real peacemakers. Such indeed are the children of God. Whosoever cherishes hate in his heart, whoever makes it easier for men and women to suspect each other, to mistrust each other, that individual, regardless of his profession, is fighting against peace. Whoever is hard to live with in the home, whoever is a promoter of strife between man and man, whoever creates discord, discontent, and misunderstanding, whoever preaches selfishness, whoever fosters prejudice is a disturber of peace. On the other hand, if we are peacemakers, if by what we say, by what we are, by what we do, we preach the "Gospel of Reconciliation"; if we promote peace in the home, peace in social circles, peace between nation and nation, then we are making common cause with the Prince of Peace. His gospel is the gospel of peace. Enduring peace between men and nations, in the home and abroad, will come only through the adoption of the precepts of the Master, and through magnifying these precepts by actually applying them in our daily lives. "Peace on earth" is not to be established by congress and parliament, nor by any group of international representatives, peace cannot be legislated into existence for it comes from within. The only way to build a peaceful community is to build men and women who are lovers and makers of peace. Each in of your Father which is in heaven, dividual holds in his own hands, in a... Widtsoe, Conference Pamphlet, October 1943. Literature New Testament Lesson 7?New Testament Epistles Dr. Howard R. Driggs For Tuesday, April 17, 1945 IT is somewhat difficult for folk today with widespread mail service, the press, and the radio at their command, to visualize how severely limited were the means of communication in the long ago. In these days, gospel messages may be broadcast with electric speed over all the world. With the Savior and his apostles, gospel teaching was largely restricted to places within walking distance, and to conversing with the few who cared to listen. It was a kind of home-to-home missionary service, with occasional opportunities to give the divine message to larger groups, attracted by the marvelous works and words of the Master.
Later, when Paul was carrying forward in the realms of Greece and Rome, he wrote epistles to help him spread the truth. These gospel letters were far more, however, than ordinary communications. In letters, they carried greetings and cheer and courage to the different branches of the Church and, at times, to individuals. They sometimes dealt also with specific problems that troubled the saints. But more than this, they were masterful interpretations of the gospel of Jesus Christ. As such they hold a high place in the world's great literature.
The epistles found in the New Testament, written not only by Paul, but by other evangelists, have classic qualities. Though addressed for the most part to specific congregations, they ring with truth for people of all time. Outside the gospels, no other religious works have been more often quoted in the Christian world; nor have any had a more profound influence in guiding action along ways of righteousness. Most of the epistles preserved for us in the New Testament were produced by Paul. How many other gospel letters this ardent missionary wrote, we do not know. Through the busy, troubled years of his ministry he was constantly speaking?portraying the gospel with fervor and clarity before varied types and classes of people from common folk to kings. A hint of his eloquence comes to us in the complimentary remark of King Agrippa: After Paul, as a prisoner, had pleaded the cause of Christ before him, the King said, "Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian. And Paul replies, "I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds" (Acts 26:28-29). His persuasive eloquence vibrates in the epistles preserved for us. These gospel letters reveal not only a clear mind, but a fervent soul. They are the blossoming and the fruitage of years of devotion to the cause of truth, which, with direct commission from the Savior, he had made an intrinsic part of his own being. It was dearer to him than life itself. Oliver Wendell Holmes once said, in effect, that sermons should not be written until they had been spoken many times?this to round and polish them as pebbles are smoothed and perfected by rolling with the waves on the beach. Paul doubtless often voiced the profound truths, and the reasons for his belief in Christ, before he wrote his epistles. When he did address" one of these gospel letters to saints he had helped to bring into the fold, he was ready for such written expression. He talked to them fervently with his pen; and in doing so, he often expressed great truths with literary finish and force. Following are a few of his many lines that bear out this statement: For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation (Romans 1:16), For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord (Romans 6:23). The Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God (Romans 8:16). Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good (Romans 12:9). And my speech and my preaching was not with enticing words of man's wisdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit and of power (I Corinthians 2:4). Let all things be done decently and in order (I-Corinthians 14:40). If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable (I Corinthians 15:19). O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory? (I Corinthians 15:55). But I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be corrupted from the simplicity that is in Christ "(11 Corinthians 11:3). Be not deceived: God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap (Galatians 6:7). 'Taul," says Dinsmore, "had a rare power of condensing much wisdom in a sentence. That is why preachers find him so rich in text." LESSON DEPARTMENT 57 Not all parts of his epistles, it is true, are of the highest literary standard. At times, as critics have pointed out, his sentences are not close-knit; and in places he lacks directness and simplicity. Yet, one quality is never lacking, and that is sincerity. The great evangelist spoke and wrote under the inspiration of the Master, who had called him to his mission to help save mankind. It is this spirit that gave undying vitality to his words of truth and light as he himself so well said: 'The letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life." Under the impulse of the poetic spirit, Paul rises at times to unsurpassed literary excellence. An outstanding example of this is the poem ?for such it may well be called?on Charity* (or Love), I Corinthians, chapter thirteen. Read its beautiful lines aloud, thoughtfully: Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal. And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing. And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing. Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things. Charity never faileth: but whether there be prophecies, they shall fail; whether there be tongues, they shall cease; whether there be knowledge, it shall vanish away. For we know in part, and we prophesy in part. But when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away. When I was a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child; but when I became a man, I put away childish things. For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known. And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity. Observe the perfect balance, the cadence of the lines in this gospel poem. It has the qualities of Hebrew lyric, with something of Grecian polish added. Note also such picturesque expressions as "sounding brass and tinkling cymbal," "suffereth long and is kind," "vaunteth not itself; is not puffed up." Mark too, such upbuilding spiritual suggestions as "seeketh not her own," "thinketh no evil," "rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth." With clarity and charm the lofty theme is developed to its simple impressive close. Its literary excellence is well described in these words of Thoreau: "Perfect sincerity and transparency make a great part of beauty, as in dewdrops, lakes and diamonds." Other writers of New Testament Epistles, though producing fewer of these than did Paul, still have bequeathed to us some precious gospel letters. Of these we have in the New Testament: one by James; two by Peter; three by John; and one by Jude, the brother of James. To James, the apostle who was cruelly slain by the tyrant Herod, Latter-day Saints will ever be deeply indebted. It was he who wrote the *Some translators prefer the word love. Either form is beautiful. lines that inspired a boy, Joseph Smith, to seek the Lord in prayer. "If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him. But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea, driven with the wind and tossed" (James 1:5-6). Acting on this sound advice, Joseph took the first step that led to the restoration of the true gospel of Christ in these latter days. In the Epistle of St. James will be found other inspired lines. A few of them follow: Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above (James 1:17). Let every man be swift to hear, slow'' to speak, slow to wrath (James 1:19). Be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only (James 1:22). What doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? Can faith save him? (James 2:14). Doth a fountain send forth at the same place sweet water and bitter? (James 3:11). And the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace of them that make peace (James 3:18). Good counsel, given in a sweet spirit, characterizes the Epistle of James. One feels in his lines the heart of a man who has tested the truths of life, and is giving them forth as a father talking in plain, but kindly words, to his children. In the Epistles of Peter, likewise, we get closer to the man himself. His gospel letters reveal a vigorous leader in the cause of righteousness. With forthright sentences, tempered with wisdom and love, he lays down fundamental principles in his trenchant lines of counsel: But the word of the Lord endureth for ever. And this is the word which by the gospel is preached unto you (I Peter As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby (I Peter 2:2). Having your conversation honest among the Gentiles: that, whereas they speak against you as evil doers, they may by your good works, which they shall behold, glorify God in the day of visitation (I Peter 2:12). And above all things have fervent charity among yourselves: for charity shall cover the multitude of sins (I Peter 4:8). But grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ (II Peter 3:18). Echoes of the Gospel of Saint John are found in the three epistles written by this "beloved disciple." He re-emphasizes the manifestation of God through his only begotten Son, Jesus Christ. He impresses the truth that Jesus was sent to propitiate, not only the sins of the Jews, but the whole world. He stresses also the truth that, if we walk in the light of the Savior, we are in fellowship one with another and with God. From these lines of John's gospel letters we can catch something of his spirit: He that saith he is in the light, and hateth his brother, is in darkness even until now (I John 2:9). He that loveth not, knoweth not God; for God is love (I John 4:8). LESSON DEPARTMENT 59 Perfect love casteth out fear (I John 4:18). For there are three that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one (I John 5:7). I have no greater joy than to hear that my children walk in truth (II John 1:4). Discussion and Activities 1. (a) What incidents of the New Testament show the modes of travel in those days? (b) Why was it necessary to teach the gospel orally for the most part? 2. (a) When an epistle was written by Paul or the other apostles, how would it probably be sent? (b) How would it probably be presented to the different groups of saints? 3. (a) What is your opinion of the "learning by heart" kind of education? (b) What quotation from any of the New Testament epistles have you "learned by heart?" 4. Try this little test. First, without help from the New Testament, complete and write on a slip of paper each of the following beginnings of sentences from the epistles. Then turn to the epistles and verify your results. A. "For there is no respect of person..." (Romans 2:11). B. "Being then made free from sin, ye became..." (Romans 6:18). C. "Vengeance is mine; I..." (Romans 12:19). D. "Know ye not that a little leaven..." (I Corinthians 5:6). E. "For God is not the author of confusion, but..." (I Corinthians 14:33)- f. "And where the spirit of the Lord is, there..." (II Corinthians 3:17). G. "And he gave some, apostles; and some,.." (Ephs. 4:11-12). H. "Children, obey..," (Colossians 3:20). I. "Pure religion and undefiled..." (James 1:27). 5. (a) What are outstanding literary qualities in the epistles of the New Testament? (b) Illustrate by pointing out the qualities you name in the quotations given in this lesson; or in other quotations of your own selection.

Social Science Modern Applications of Ethical Principles Lesson 6?Honesty, the Core of Character Dr. Harold T. Christensen For Tuesday, April 24, 1945 Lesson link: The discussion last time centered around truth and its perversions. It was shown that truth is the very framework of ethics, but that because of abuses; such as ignorance, lying, cheating, hypocrisy, expediency, et cetera, the highest morality is frequently never reached. Lesson aim: To analyze the ethical aspects of character and to show that honesty is at the heart or core of it all. THE last hundred years or so has " been described as the age of science. During this period, more than at any other time, man has been occupied with the discovery and analysis of facts. And in this quest for factual truth man has been largely successful, for he has greatly extended the boundaries of his understanding, making possible, thereby, a speedier progression and a higher morality. But facts alone are not enough. In spite of the world's technological advancement, it is doubtful that it is any more happy or any more moral than before, as we have shown in an earlier lesson. Knowledge means power; but power used without principle is a curse rather than a blessing. The misapplication of facts is as often to blame for the ills of man as is the ignorance of facts. Science cannot substitute for virtue. The right application of knowledge and the right use of power are far more important than knowledge and power in and of themselves. Technical education without adequate ethical orientation is of questionable value. It is time for man to realize that character building is the most important business of life. Character Versus Reputation It was shown last month that truth is frequently abused and distorted in an attempt at self-benefit. The highest morality depends upon our ability to strive for: Truth instead of falsehood Intelligence rather than ignorance Information in place of confirmation Straight thinking in place of fantasy Sincerity in place of indifference Certainty along with sincerity Intellectual honesty instead of self-justification. Analytic searching rather than dogmatic defending Conviction in place of skepticism Confidence without arrogance or self-pity Self-interest without cheating Humility without self-depreciation Statesmanship rather than politics Honor rather than expediency Genuineness rather than hypocrisy Principle rather than profit Whenever truth becomes neglected or perverted in any of the ways discussed (or any other way for that matter) morality suffers. Dishonesty is the willful abuse of truth, whether it be on the covert, the verbal, or the overt plane. Some people are dishonest because they won't think straight, others because they lie, and still others because they cheat. But most dishonest individuals offend on all three of these levels covering up deceit with more deceit. Because of this all-too-common tendency to cover up or hide the real self from others, there is frequently a fundamental difference between a person's character and his reputation. Character is what we are, while reputation is what we seem to be to others. If everyone was entirely honest, character and reputation would be identical; but since all are not honest, man is easily fooled and injustice is perpetuated. A Sunday School teacher assigned the twenty-fifth chapter of St. Luke to be read for the following week. When the class reassembled he asked how many had read the assignment, and about one-third of the hands went up. "Well," he remarked to the startled group, "you are just the ones I want to talk to for my subject is on lying, and there isn't any twenty-fifth chapter in St. Luke." Several years ago Eddie Cantor offered a $5,000 prize to high school students for the best essay on peace. Out of the thousands of entries a young man was selected and taken to New York City to be honored and awarded the prize. But before the end, it was discovered that he had copied a large proportion of his essay word for word from a magazine article published a few years earlier. Needless to say, he went home in disgrace and without the prize, all because he had failed to understand the meaning of plagiarism. These are only two of many examples that could be given to illustrate the existence of basic dishonesty in society around us. Studies reveal that quite a high percentage of our young people copy and cheat in school. But the problem doesn't stop there. Even a cursory self-analysis along with an examination of society at large will reveal that cheating is not confined to school nor to the young alone.
Those who seek to build or protect their reputation by deceit will do well to remember that, "nothing is secret that shall not be made manifest, neither any thing hid that shall not be known and come abroad" (Luke 8:17).
The Role of Honesty in Character
Hugh M. Woodward (Humanity's Greatest Need, pp. 137-150) following an arrangement by Mrs. Noenetta Richardson, summarizes the major qualities of character by comparing them to the construction elements of a building. The aim or motivation for building the temple of character is found through self
unfoldment and service to humanity. The temple is located on the mount of service beside life's highway. The great sustaining pillars which support the entire structure are self-respect, self-effort, self-control, and self-poise. The foundations of the temple are honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and courage. The floor is made up of perseverance, temperance, frankness, and humility. The doors for entrance into the temple are faith, a passion for the truth, an interest in all life, constant industry and effort, and a wakeful conscience. The windows of the temple, which represent the attitude of a righteous soul, are a genuine interest in life, a sympathetic understanding of others, tolerance, and love. The color scheme is cheerfulness blended with refinement, kindliness, gentleness, and gratitude. The crowning feature of this temple of character is made up of charitableness and altruistic service.
Some of these features of character we have already discussed in earlier lessons, and others will be examined on later dates. While the scheme obviously is not perfect as it stands, it is at least suggestive. With close study, it may seem desirable to add additional qualities of character and mentioned here or to rearrange the order and relative position of those given. But, perfect or not, such a scheme should at least prove helpful in any character analysis.
To the writer the most significant thing about this temple of character is the including of honesty in the foundation. It would be impossible to even conceive of character without honesty, for any structure founded on deceit and falsehood is founded upon sand and rather than rock and must inevitably fall. Furthermore, a careful scrutiny of the other factors of character listed here will reveal that they are all related to basic honesty. Honesty, then, may be considered as the core of character. Character Building The roots of character reach back into infancy and early childhood. Character building starts soon after birth and continues throughout life, as the individual learns and absorbs the moral codes of those about him. But the first impressions are the most important, for they arrive when the personality is most pliable, and they set the stage or determine the focus for later ones. As the twig is bent the tree is inclined. Parents sometimes fail to realize the tremendous responsibility that is theirs in shaping the characters of their developing children. Aside from their frequent neglect of moral instruction in the home, impression and example are often of the wrong sort. It is likely that we teach more by what we are than by what we say, and for this reason many children go wrong. Righteousness is contagious, but, unfortunately, so also is unrighteousness; and too many parents are in the second class. Sometimes children are woefully neglected, sometimes they are bossed and shoved around in the spirit of ownership without any training in responsibility and self-control, and sometimes they are actually encouraged by their parents to lie or cheat or in other ways be dishonest and unsocial. Children are a blessing, a gift of the highest order. But with every gift comes a responsibility, and, unfortunately, there are many modern parents who fail to realize this. Irresponsible parenthood is back of most of the immorality of the day. While the home is the first and the most primary nursery of character, it does not stand alone. The church, the school, and other groups or persons that the individual contacts and from which he absorbs culture are also involved. Morals do not come ready-made, and the making of morals is the responsibility of us all. Character building requires instruction and example of the right kind; respect for individuality and personality; opportunity for responsibility and self-control; and all of this from parents, teachers, and associates who come in daily contact with the young. Whether our children develop into immoral expedients or honorable characters depends, in a large measure, upon us. Adult ethics (or lack of ethics) and juvenile delinquency are intrinsically related. "God Give Us Men" Abraham Lincoln represented the type of manhood so much needed today when he said, "I am not bound to win, but I am bound to be true; I am not bound to succeed, but I am bound to live up to what light I have. I must stand with anybody that stands right; stand with him while he is right and part with him when he goes wrong." It is this type of resolution and courageous honesty that forms the core of character. Too many people in the modern world lack the strength that comes from honor, for LESSON DEPARTMENT 63 they have no honor; too many are Machiavellian, living for profit rather than principle. There must be no compromise with right and truth. What we need today is men and women who know the right and who have the honesty and the courage to live it, even when others aren't looking; men and women of fidelity, integrity, and honor. In conclusion let us say with J. G. Holland: God give us men! A time like this demands Strong minds, great hearts, true faith, and ready hands; Men whom the lust of office does not kill; Men whom the spoils of office cannot buy; Men who possess opinions and a will; Men who have honor; men who will not lie; Men who can stand before a demagogue And damn his treacherous flatteries without winking; Tall men, sun-crowned, who live above the fog In public duty and in private thinking; For while the rabble with their thumb-worn creeds. Their large professions and their little deeds Mingle in selfish strife, lo! Freedom weeps. Wrong rules the land, and waiting Justice sleeps. Problems for Thought and Action 1. Defend the statement that character building is the most important business of life. Have we departed from character emphasis in this age of science? Discuss pro and con. Why is factual knowledge alone insufficient for righteousness. 2. What is the difference between character and reputation? Why is there so often a difference between the two? What are the three levels of dishonesty? Give illustrations of dishonesty on each level. Why is a dishonest person so often dishonest on all three levels? Discuss. Is anyone one hundred per cent honest? Discuss. 3. Here is an actual case that might be used for debate or lively discussion: A young man in returning home from a party about three o'clock in the morning accidently awakened his mother, who then asked him the time of the night. He answered, "Plenty after twelve" but said it in such a way as to make it sound like "twenty after twelve." Technically he told the truth; but actually, by intention, he gave the wrong impression. The question is, was he lying? Think of other examples of "technical honesty" and decide whether the question of honesty is to be judged on the basis of words or intended meanings. 4. Name the major elements in the temple of character outlined in the lesson. If you have a blackboard available it might be well to try your hand at drawing the temple and labeling ' the various parts. Discuss the entire scheme and see if there are any suggestions for adding other elements or rearranging those listed. Show how honesty is central and basic in it all. Could the other qualities exist without honesty? 5. Why are the habits and attitudes learned in the early years of life so deeply engrained in the character complex? Why are parents so important in the process of character building? Name and discuss some of the mistakes parents make with reference to character training of their children. Discuss the places of the church and the school in character formation. 6. Read aloud and then analyze Holland's poem "God Give us Men." Find examples of honesty in the lives of Abraham Lincoln, George Washington, and other great men, and then show how their honesty has paid them dividends. In looking ahead to the next lesson show how the virtues of love, service, and tolerance would be largely negated without honesty as a starting point. Selected References Bennion, Milton, Moral Teachings of the New Testament, pp. 119-152 (out of print). Irwin, Will, Character a la. Caite, Reader's Digest, June 1938, pp. 27-30. James E. Talmage, Articles of Faith, p. 429. President Heber J. Grant, Gospel Standards, "Significant Gospel Themes? Honesty," p. 30. Doc. And Gov. 10:28; 42:21. ODE TO CHILD PSYCHOLOGY Mildred R. Stutz I filled my head with a store of knowledge From doctors, pamphlets, hospitals and college. I studied eugenics, genetics, and zoo, I've reaped information wherever I go. I delved through psychology and child care. Vitamins, diets, clothing, and hair, Punishment, teething, and education, Corrective guidance and sanitation. My schedule told me just what to do, I fed him at six, at ten, and at two. A bath at nine-forty then sleep 'till eleven, And his cod-liver oil came strictly at seven. He was in bed by six?although he might shout, The door was closed tight and the lights were turned out. With such competent training, I can't comprehend Why it's all forgotten before he turns ten. He's the subject, the object, and source of my wrath. It's a full day's job to give him a bath. He crawls through the windows and slides down the stairs. His falsetto soprano rends the air. He bangs the door and swings on the gate. He kicks up the flowers, and comes to meals late. He teases, he kisses, he stumbles, he shouts, He questions, he answers, he argues, he doubts. I've finally concluded that it's useless complaining. For boys will be boys in spite of their training. LAST NIGHT THEY PLAYED HIS SONGS
Anna Prince Redd
He left? Without saying goodbye? Just, "Hey, Mom!" as he pedaled away? His little-boy voice, consumed by space, Eludes my heart,
No sound comes back to me. Aeons ago he left? Without saying goodbye? But that melody, all his songs? And he sat close to me. Work Meeting COMBINATION APRON AND SEWING BAG ANY woman who sews, darns, mends, or does fine needlework, crocheting or knitting will appreciate an apron with pockets to hold her thimble, scissors, and tape measure, and keep her sewing clean, too. This combination apron and utility bag* is very convenient and practical. Materials required?1 1/6 yds. Fabric, preferably heavy, washable print or solid color, "Yi yards cord or ribbon for draw string and to tie envelope accessory holder, bias binding, two wooden rings, beads or buttons. To make?Cut two pieces of material 16 3/4 inches by 22 inches for bag (A) (Illus. 1). Seam the bottom and sides. Turn down 1 3/4 inches at top for hem. Stitch hem, then stitch 3/4 inch from edge of hem to make a Ya inch casing to enclose draw string. Leave seam on outside of casing open for draw string. Cut one piece 10 1/2 inches long by 22 1/2 inches wide for apron part (B) (Illus. 2). Make 1/4 inch hem on each side. Sew lower edge to inside of back of bag, stitching Y inch below (C) hem stitching. Make a second stitching over hem stitching (E) and through apron to hold apron in place and to cover raw seam. Make pocket (D) 4 1/2 inches by 13 1/2 inches finished with 3/4 inch hem at top. Stitch to back of bag and over lower edge of apron, allowing top of pocket to come to stitching (E). A small, envelope-style folder may be made (Illus. 4), the pocket to hold small scissors, skeins of floss, buttons, thimble, etc., the strip of outing flannel to hold needle and pins. When the apron is pinned and C and tied with ribbon or cord attached at point H, a very compact sewing equipment case results (Illus. 5). This may be kept in small pocket in apron. Band for top of apron and tie strings may be cut from remaining material. When one stops sewing, the apron top may be folded down into the bag, the draw strings pulled, and presto, one has a utility bag to hang on one's arm to take places, or to hang by the draw string in a convenient place ready for future use. Further suggestions on aprons will appear in the March issue of the Magazine. *This apron design was originated by Ruth T. Oscarson, first counselor in charge of sewing, Granite Stake Relief Society Board, Salt Lake City, Utah. ILLUS. APRON BAG Inside View-Front of Bag Removed APRON BAG Shown as Bag SEWING EQUIPMENT CASE ILLUS. 5 Se | SEWING EQUIPMENT CASE Folded Page 96 SONG FOR A KITCHEN Miranda Snow Walton There are homes without a bedroom, where davenettes suffice, There are homes where parlors play no leading part; There are homes that have no dining room, no pantry, nor a bath, But the home without a kitchen is a home without a heart. It's a sort of filling station for a boy of nine or ten; It's the family trysting place with apple pie; And the smell of hot, brown gingerbread upon a frosty night Is a memory you'll cherish 'till you die. It's the room where you'll find mother, where little folks can come To tell their troubles, and have broken hearts made whole; Oh, a house can be most anything, a mansion or a shack, But the home without a kitchen is a home Without a soul. Forward, Without Fear Dorothy Chpp Robinson CHAPTER 7 AGAIN Ann Kristin was out following the trail of the sheep. She was a long way from camp, and alone, and because of that the sack she carried was nearly full. She was glad to get away from the others. There were so many new people in camp, and so much happiness. Newcomers were hunting relatives and friends. Letters were being read and discussed. Women, the more fortunate ones, were bargaining eagerly for new foods to relieve the monotony of their diets. Patty Lou was still going around in a daze trying to be with Jake and her family at the same time. There had been a happy gathering in the Mortensen dooryard the evening before. Around the campfire, while the Turners ate, a story had been told and retold. "How did you come? How did you know where to come? Who told you where to find me?" "Jake did," Jinny, a younger sister, had answered, "and you-all are even prettier than he said." Her letter had been months reaching them. After his first unreasoning anger at the thing that had taken his daughter away, Mr. Turner had fallen to wondering. He suspected she had no intention of returning home. It had taken him some time to arrange the transfer of money to her, then he had begun to investigate. He was curious about Page 98 the power that could keep a girl like her among strangers. "So," the story had ended, "we came on to Nauvoo. Everything we own is in these three wagons. Brother Matthew Lewis baptized us the same time he did Jake." Patty Lou turned slowly to face Jake who sat beside her. Her eyes filled with tears of happiness. Jake, frightened by them and the solemnity, tried to grin. "You-all ready to quit being cagey and marry me?" "Jake Nichols. You are blind as a badger. I've been counting on it right along." "Will you-all mind?" "I love doing what pleases you." "Make her give a definite promise," Mr. Turner advised, and the others smiled their agreement with him. "I am not inferring this time," the girl turned serious. "I am so happy with the way the Lord has blessed me, I will do anything to show him." Forgetting the presence of the others, Jake answered, "Oh, Patty Lou, you good-for-nothing Honey Chile. I been waiting for this moment all my life, and that's a right smart spell." Nestling one hand in his, the girl gave her father the other. Looking about to include them all she said simply, "You are my family." Niels' eyes had said the same thing to Helga. Little Anna had awakened, and she passed from her father FORWARD, WITHOUT FEAR 99 to Helga and back again many times. Niels had a wagon and ox team now, and a cow he had lead all the way from Nauvoo. Being a property owner had given a new proud lift to his shoulders. Only Ann Kristin was alone. So very much alone, she told herself as she picked snags of wool from the brush. Matt Lewis had come in with the wagon train but she had not seen him. For all she knew he might have brought a wife with him. Even so, she was deeply affected by what the Turners had said of him. He was a true son of his father. There would never be any doubt of his integrity, nor of his devotion to the cause. The girl who married him would be lead inevitably into the celestial kingdom. Perhaps he wasn't married, but would go on tomorrow with the freight. He was working with Jake between the settlements and Fort Bridger. SUDDENLY Ann Kristin realized she was miles from camp. In all directions there was nothing but hot sky and brown prairie. A tremor of apprehension went through her. There might be Indians lurking near. She had been following a dry water course, now she walked to the top of a short rise and looked about. To the southwest a spiral of dust was rising as if in warning. She dropped abruptly to the ground and watched from behind the brush. She would have to crawl back down and find a hiding place?if there was a hiding place. It was a single horseman, and as she watched her fear vanished. It was a white man. Probably a scout, or some one following the sheep, for he seemed to be looking for some one. Several times he rose in the stirrups and looked about. Ann Kristin rose and waved. Instantly the rider saw and came galloping toward her. It was Matt Lewis. He stropped his horse and sprang to the ground. "What do you mean coming out here alone?" he demanded. "Don't you know there are Indians? You might get lost." "Is that what you came out here to tell me?" "Someone had to tell you." "If you came out here to quarrel-." "Who's quarreling? You?." They both stopped abruptly. He lifted his hat and ran his finger through his damp hair. It was the same hat he had worn the first time she had seen him. "You are thin," he said unexpectedly. "Why shouldn't I be? We walked from Montrose. Your mother helped haul our things. We were fortunate not to have to carry them." "Next time there will be room to ride. I have a wagon and team of my own now. Jake and I are hauling freight." "Yes, I know. Jake told us." For the life of her she could think of nothing else to say. Her torn faded dress, her worn shoes, the bag of greasy wool embarrassed her. She was holding on to the bag with her bad hand. It was no longer withered but it would always be a little stiff. "Did you??" she began, "No," he read her thought, "but it is no longer important. I found out all I needed to know." He had been holding the bridle reins. Now he looped them over his arm. His gaze wandered a moment as if he were searching for words. '1 found your money box/ he said, abruptly. "You found it!" He nodded. "Not the money, naturally. One of the saints had bought it from Bedloe. It was a good strong box and evidently he could not resist the price it would bring. How he got it off the boat we probably will never know, nor how they managed to open the trunk without arousing suspicion. We knew it was yours by the initials of your father carved on the inside. Jake and I visited Wilkins. We made sure he did not see us coming this time. Under pressure he confessed. Bedloe was the leader of an organized band of thieves. Some of them, like himself, posed as saints to more easily win the confidence of the unsuspecting immigrants. But we did not find Bedloe." Then Ann Kristin knew, too, that the affair was no longer important. What was important was her changed attitude, her increased strength. The sudden knowledge that men like Matthew Lewis could always be trusted. She could touch suspicion and still know faith, one could accept trials and still know peace. She could be friends with Matt. "You know now that I signed the paper innocently?" Instead of answering Matt looked at her. His gray eyes were reddened by wind and sun. Dust lay a hard veneer over his features, but the hardness of distrust was gone. He spoke simply. "T have always loved you, Ann Kristin, from that first moment on the wharf." Color drained from her face. She let the wool fall. He stepped closer. "Could you?I'm not polished like Bedloe, I have nothing to offer you." "You have everything," she raised her eyes to him and wondered at her own temerity. "You have the Priesthood, heritage, honor, and a great kindness. Perhaps with you. Matt, I could forget the selfishness of my past." With a whoop of joy he caught her up and swung her about as he had his mother. Then he set her down abruptly and almost timidly took her in his arms. Later, from the pocket of his faded flannel shirt he took a small object wrapped in buckskin. "Mother's ring," she cried out and reached for it. "Where did you find it?" With one hand he held her back. His grin reminded her of the day she had seen him teasing his mother. "This is mine. I got it from Wilkins the same night he took it from you. I gave him five dollars and defied him to refuse to sell. I think he knew then I was suspicious. He didn't dare squawk." "Oh, my dear, as scarce as money was?and you have kept it all this time." "I knew this hour would come. I had to know it." He slipped the ring on her finger and then held her hand in both of his. She looked at the ring and tears brightened her eyes. "All our lovely things are gone. Except this." "But you have something much better. Strength and fortitude, and understanding." His compliment was so similar to hers she started to laugh. His smile FORWARD, WITHOUT FEAR 101 widened and then they were both laughing. Quick spontaneous laughter that brought back the lines of youth to their faces. He tied the wool on the saddle and they walked back to camp, savoring the minutes together. There was so much to talk about and their hands kept touching. "We will be married tomorrow' he said at length. "Mother will be very happy. She sent me to find you. You can stay with her until we get settled, or would you rather be with Helga?" "With your mother, then you can be with both of us between trips." "I am not sure how long the trips will last. Much depends on what the body of the Church does. We can't settle here permanently. The saints are leaving Nauvoo and vicinity as fast as they can dispose of their property, and get wagons or carts to haul their few belongings. All must be gone by spring. Those in power have decreed it, which makes it much harder to sell anything. Especially land. Now Iowa, Nebraska, and Missouri are petitioning the Federal Government at Washington to refuse us permission to settle within the confines of their boundaries." "But where can we go?" "Brother Young is asking permission to settle in the Far West. That would entail much planning and more suffering. If there is a place of rest we will find it. I hope it will be next year. Take mother, for example. It is seven years since she gave up her home. In all that time she hasn't really been settled." "BUT the trouble of the saints was soon forgotten. They talked as young people in all ages have talked. The past was forgotten and the future was not yet upon them. Only the present was theirs. So short a present. A mile from camp two men came riding hard out of the west. Matt stopped and his hand went to his gun. Even when he saw they were white men he did not relax. "What news?" he asked as they pulled in their lathering horses. "Plenty. Brother Young is behind us. He wants to meet all the men." They were off again, and now the future was upon Ann Kristin and Matthew. The old sickening apprehension swept over her. His lips closed to a hard straight line, and his steps quickened. As they entered camp, they saw the buggy approaching. They stopped until it passed. Brother Young and two other men were in it. "Go on," Ann Kristin told him. "I?ll take the wool home. You can tell me later." Without a word he hurried away. Holding to the bridle reins she led the horse past tents, shanties, and wagons. Before her own home she tied the horse to a wagon wheel and removed the wool and saddle. There was no one around. Even the Turners were gone, except Jinny and she soon left. "Why don't you-all come to the meetin"?" she asked. "Everybody is goin'." Ann Kristin refused. She felt the necessity of fortifying herself for Matt's return. If the news were bad ?but she closed her mind to it. Perhaps the meeting meant they could settle in the Rocky Mountains, or even stay here. That would be wonerful, She took up her knitting, but as time passed her fingers moved faster and faster. Surely, surely, the Lord would not try them longer, but why didn't Matt come, or Hel-ga, or some one? When she could stand the suspense no longer she got up and moved about. She was too tired to walk. Succumbing to a sudden whim she decided to dress up and go to the meeting. From a trunk she took the dress she had worn the day she left the River Maid. The one that had made her appear "over-decorated." She had not worn it since that day. She shook it out and ran a cold flatiron over it. The shoes were there, too, and the hat. She arranged her hair as it had been. When she had finished she surveyed herself in the small mirror she had. What she saw was not too reassuring, but such things as wrinkles and coarse rough hands were minor annoyances. Remembrance and expectation supplied what poverty and primitive conditions failed to grant. The transformation was complete even to the ring on her finger. For a moment she looked at it, then raised it to her lips and kissed it softly. Gathering her skirt in both hands she started for the meeting. "Kristie." "Oh," she dropped her skirt. Matt was standing in the doorway. His eyes lighted at the bridal picture before him, but love could not entirely erase the bleakness from his eyes. She moved quickly to him. His smile faded. "Is it a mob or an order?or do we stay here?" she asked breathlessly- "Neither. It is war. War with Mexico." "But what has that to do with us? Surely after the way we have been refused homes?." "the Government would not expect us to help protect others' homes? Yes, it expects just that, and it is our country, Kristin. Brother Young is here with an army man to get recruits. Jake and Ezra have volunteered." "But?but we are to be married. We have been unhappy so long." Matt stepped inside. He put his arms about her shoulders and drew her close. He tilted her chin so their eyes met. Her hat fell off but neither noticed. "Let me explain, dear." "Yes?but, oh Matt, not now. Not when you have work and?." "I must go. Try to understand. An older man, Niels perhaps, can do my freighting. The army pays seven dollars a month for privates, besides the clothes issued. I was a top sergeant in the Nauvoo Legion. I am hoping Captain Allen will give me a rating. If I go, other young men will go." "How many do they want?" "Five hundred. Think what seven dollars a month coming to five hundred of our homes could mean." "But war! Life is ours now. You can't throw it away now. War is brutal and savage. There are Indians, and Mexico, where is Mexico? Matt, I may never see you again." "Yes, it may even mean that. Even so, we have nothing to fear. The future is all ours." "I want the present. Matt, don't go. Don't ask me for another sacrifice." "Where is your strength, your faith?" FORWARD, WITHOUT FEAR 103 "1 haven't any strength. I haven't any faith. I don't want any. I want you." For a long minute he held her close trying to still the trembling of her body, but he said nothing. She laid her face against the rough cloth of his shirt. When she raised her eyes to him, the youth and gaiety were gone from them, "I am all right now/' she said quietly. "When do you go?" "Tonight. Now." 'Tonight?" "We must be in Council Bluffs by the sixteenth. It will take hard marching to reach there by then." "And the others?" "Niels and Helga, Jake and Patty Lou are being married by Brother Young. They wanted to send for you, but I wanted these few minutes with you alone.". -But-but-." "There is no time for that for us." He took her hand and slipped the ring from her finger. Then he put it back. "Our lives are like this ring. They are not to be lived in a straight line from one year to another, but in a circle, from eternity to eternity. There is no end to them, so we shall never be apart, not days, nor deserts, nor Indians can separate us for long. 1 will be back." After a moment she answered, "I know you will. I'll go to your mother. And you will come there, wherever our home is." The clear note of a bugle came to them. With a prayer in her heart and a smile on her lips she watched him stride away. She turned quickly then to put together her few belongings. Niels and Helga would want this cabin. She and Sister Lewis would go on together without fear. She whispered the last aloud. THE END FEBRUARY Leone E. McCune Ghostlike February, In your tattered gown. Hovering sad and lonely, Trailing up and down. You drift in the hollow 'Neath the moonlit hill. You shriek around the corner, Weep upon my sill. I hear you at dawning; Moaning sad and low, Wandering like a lost soul. Knows not where to go. You will follow winter When the sun rides high, And pussy willows unfold To a clear blue sky. NOW is the time to get your tool kit ready. You, no doubt, will have many occasions to use it before the repair man comes around again. Take an inventory of what you have, to see if you can find the following: hammer (two sizes), screwdriver, a pair of pliers, a three-cornered file, a cross-cut saw, folding rule, small can of machine oil, scissors, jack knife, awl, rubber force pump 'plumber's friend', nails, screws, tacks, scraper for removing old paint, pipe wrench, friction tape, auger, turpentine, putty, plastic wood and paint brushes in good condition. You may need additional tools, but the above list is a good beginning. Good tools are a good investment. They are now very scarce, so it pays to take good care of what you have.
Electrical Repairs?Caution. Remember that live wires are dangerous. Avoid handling electric cords, switches, etc., with wet hands. If you are repairing a wall outlet or switch, remove the fuse in the circuit.
What to do when your lights go out?It may mean a blown-out fuse which indicates there is something wrong with the electrical equipment or the manner in which it is used. The fuse is a safety valve for the electrical system. It consists of a link of soft metal which melts and opens the circuit when too much current passes through the wires. If it fails to operate, the wires in the walls would become overheated, char the insulation and possibly cause fire.
Fuses must never be tampered with. Keep all electrical equipment in good repair and avoid overloading the circuit.
How to replace a fuse. First, find the cause and remove it. The blown-out fuse will have a cracked or blackened "window." Disconnect the lamp or appliance responsible. Touching only the fuse, grasp it by the rim, unscrew it. Screw in a new one and close the switch. Never use pliers. If you are timid about handling fuses, pull the main switch, usually located near the fuse box. Buy only fuses which carry the laboratories' inspection label. Remember, the proper rating of a fuse is determined by the size of the wire to be protected. Keep an extra supply of fuses of the proper rating on hand at all times. Your power company will give you all the necessary information.
Faucets. The most common repair any home owner can make is to repair a leaking faucet. First disconnect the water supply. Grasp the faucet handle firmly in one hand, using the wrench in the other to unscrew the nut around the faucet. A piece of cloth or paper inserted between the nut and the wrench protects the faucet from bite-marks. When the faucet handle comes out, bring with it the defective washer, unloosen the screw at the center of the washer, using a screwdriver. If the screw should stick, apply a few drops of oil and give it a few taps. When replacing the new washer, buy one, turning the dull side toward the supply pipe. Replace the screw on the handle shaft and tighten nut. Composition washers may now be purchased which serve for both the hot and cold taps.
Sinks and Toilets. In order to repair the valves by which water enters and leaves the flush tanks of toilets, one needs to study the inside mechanism of the tank. It is very simple. Any plumbing supply house will be glad to show you. Any one can learn to use a "plumber's friend" or suction plunge. This handy tool is indispensable for clearing sluggish drains. The ball should be half submerged and worked up and down. Drains should be cared for when the first signs of clogging appear. Sometimes it is advisable to use a commercial flushing chemical. If so, always follow the direction on the can very carefully.
Leaky Pipes need a plumber. Temporary menders of pipes: putty, cement, friction tape or adhesive plaster wound round enough times usually stop the leak. These are only temporary measures, however, and will not last long. If the water pipe becomes frozen never apply a blow torch. The sudden heat may burst it. Apply cloths soaked in hot water. This method is slow but perfectly safe. Become familiar with the water system in your home so you will know how to turn the water off in case of an emergency. If a leak in the ceiling occurs, first, shut off the water supply; second, take an awl or ice pick and bore a hole through the ceiling where the water is dripping and relieve the plaster of the load above. This has saved many a large plastering bill.

A broken table leg can be mended with a dowel pin glued into holes bored into each section of the break. In order to do this, holes will have to be made in each of the broken pieces. These holes should be less than one-third of the diameter of the leg and about one and one-half inches deep. The dowel should be as long as the holes. Sometime chair legs become loose. If the legs are bolted on, tightening the nuts may be all that's needed. If they are screwed on, the frame may be tight enough by driving the screws in farther with a screw driver or resetting them.
