How to Choose a Painting Alice Merrill Horne Former Member Relief Society General Board HOW should one go about choosing a painting? When one considers that a good work of art is purchased not for one person, not even for one generation, but for posterity, then one realizes that the most careful study is needful in choosing a painting.
Art is universal. No one country can claim all the gifts. Each individual is endowed with a degree of talent though not every soul is permitted to realize himself. The human soul is the finest instrument and can hardly fail to discern beauty. Even a little child will select the best picture in a collection. The best poem, the greatest symphony, the most profound work of art is declared as such, is set apart as such, by universal taste. Art critics have no part in the selection of masterpieces for the reason that each generation evaluates its own productions thus, we learn to put faith in the masses.
Each nation has pride in its own gifts and seeks to save its best productions, and that is why we visit other countries. In witnessing their handiwork, their precious, treasured paintings and sculptures, we can learn the causes of greatness and can estimate the scale of a nation's attainments and culture. In this way, admiration for the best is developed, establishing friendly relations between nations.
The world's cultural loss because of the present satanic world conflict is of colossal proportions. The heartbreaking truth is that it may take
generation to reveal the full cultural loss that has been sustained by the invaded countries of Europe, Asia, and Africa. The gentle, peaceful countries, now subjected to force, have seen their treasures of arts and crafts, and fabrics of handlooms torn from them. They were ruthlessly pillaged for the low purpose of degrading, impoverishing, and conquering them. Knowing well the value of art, the aggressor nations have thus schemed to lift their own financial and cultural life by seizing art productions from those gentle people who created them.
The world has learned to recognize the need for works of art. Let us consider how a picture is selected for its rightful place in the field of art:
(1) A picture should be a design. Women of this day are truly designminded. It will be easy to get right into the spirit of design. Shall we sit down and design a rug? I have long pictured Relief Society members designing rugs as do the artminded, rug-weaving Orientals.
(2) Every woman desires a tiled bathroom floor, so let us design such a floor.
(3) Make a design for a counterpane using the motif grapes, grape leaves, or a petunia. Oak leaf and acorn pattern could be used.
(4) Do you make real lace? Then you would find a delightful exercise in creating a rose design for a real lace collar.
(5) Make a sego lily design for a bedroom pillow. Page  (6) Using the mountain maidenhair fern and a wild rose, create a design for a tablecloth. (7) By this time you will be prepared to design a picture. Design your Picture Go out with your sketching pad and colored crayons, and put in a blue sky with a white cloud. Place a hill with white snow patches that will repeat the white cloud. Draw in a farmhouse. Now add a group of Cottonwood trees which will seem to love and protect the house. Make a path that leads to the front steps. The trees will have some leaf buds opening, to repeat the greens on the lawn and garden in front of the house. R Now organize what you have sketched into a diamond in a square. Millet liked to compose his pictures that way. Values in a Picture Look at your picture and answer these important questions: 1. Is the sky a dome or is it flat like a vertical wall? 2. Does the foreground come forward to meet you? 3. Does the background stay back? 4. Does the farmhouse stay in front of the trees? 5. Do the trees stay in front of the hill? 6. Is the sky behind the hill? 7. Do you feel there is another side to the hill? 8. Does the path come to you? If you answer "yes" to these questions, you have what artists name "good values." The "values" of a painting is important for you want to feel spatial relations. It would feel awkward to make a house you could not walk around. A Dominating Theme In your picture there should be a dominating subject. You might use a dozen other subjects, but each and all of these should be subservient to the main point of interest. So, please, do not choose a painting which is divided in interest, in other words, constitutes two pictures instead of one. Therefore, always search for the dominating theme and discover if all of the minor details are needed to strengthen the dominating theme. An exercise in Painting greens An artist once asked me to give him a criticism on his exhibition. Three paintings hung side by side: The first, Yellowstone Park; the second. Southern Utah; the third. Salt Lake Valley looking toward the Wasatch Mountains. "I fear you will not like my criticism." "Please tell me what you see in my work." Nothing could keep me from giving an honest criticism where it was so much needed. "You are lazy. You are not observing. The way you paint green accuses you. Green is what the light makes it. Your greens seem to have all been mixed in one pot. Notice that the greens at the top, as well as at the bottom in your Yellowstone Mountain, are exactly like the patches of green at the top and bottom of the Wasatch Mountains. Now compare the greens on your Dixie Mountain. There is no variation. If you will study the greens in any landscape, such as you have painted here, I am sure you will find light greens, dark greens, warm greens, and cool greens. Do you need glasses or is it laziness working on you, that you do not see that the greens at top, bottom, and middle distance are very different?" When I saw his work a year later, it had changed markedly, and how he was enjoying the greens.
Horticulture versus Variety
Do you like pictures of trees? It is a favorite subject of mine, especially the way the spaces between the trees are painted is of vital interest. A row of trees exactly alike with spaces between equally uninteresting would satisfy a horticulturist, but so much monotony would slay an art critic. No two spaces should be alike. In your favorite picture of trees you may find several little pictures in between like trunks and boughs of trees.
Inasmuch as you are buying a picture for yourself and posterity, remember always that the best picture is worth two of the second best, three of the third best, and I do not recommend the fourth best for posterity.
Europe has many collections that have been brought together for
posterity. It is ever true that nations are known and remembered by what was accomplished in art before that nation was cleft in twain by designing men of that or some other land.
After all, there are only two kinds of art, good and bad and, oh yes, there is the middling good which, like the middling good egg, can't be used. The better a work of art is, the more people recognize its superiority. So-called art critics praise gawky productions, such as nudes painted from wooden mannekins with the human figure distorted, but just so long as the great common class does not admire such work, it will be recognized as bad art.
Best Pictures Survive
Pictures that lift the taste of the people are of great and lasting worth. But, after all, something is of still greater importance; namely, the artists who paint the good pictures. Without the artists, there can be no progress in art, but if the artists are loved by the people, supported by the people, why might we not have a renaissance of our own? But whatever happens, we must continue to buy good pictures for the sake of posterity.
AN INESTIMABLE JEWEL
It is not merely for today but for all time to come that we should perpetuate for our children's children that great and free government which we have enjoyed all our lives. I beg you to remember this, not merely for my sake, but for yours. I happen, temporarily, to occupy the White House. I am a living witness that any one of your children may look to come here as my father's child has. It is in order that each one of you may have, through this free government which we have enjoyed, an open field and a fair chance to develop your own genius and intelligence that you may all have equal privileges in the race of life, with all its desirable human aspirations. It is for this the struggle should be maintained that we may not lose our birthright not only for one lifetime but for two or three years. The matter of the world is worth fighting to maintain for this inestimable jewel. A. Lincoln

Your Part in Utah's Centennial Prepared by the Utah Centennial Commission David O. McKay, Chairman; A. Hamer Reiser, Secretary *"at the request of the Church Beautification Committee. 
DESPITE war-imposed handicaps, Utah will celebrate her Centennial in 1947 appropriately and well, because her citizens descendants of pioneers possess to a degree, at least, the sterling characters of the pioneers themselves.
To celebrate the Centennial fittingly under the pressure of war and its aftermath, will require idealism, vision, fortitude, and an abundance of hard work.
Time is running against us, and, as it runs away in wartime, it takes with it opportunities to obtain materials and labor for the extensive program of construction contemplated in the original plan of the Centennial Commission. Adaptations and simplification of that plan may therefore be imperative.
Features of the Commission's original plan, in which materials are a minor part, can, nevertheless, be developed in wartime. These include many of the cultural and spiritual aspects of the celebration. History, music, and the other arts, and the modern facilities for their expression, can be utilized for the presentation of the essential message of the Centennial. These can be effectively employed locally in community projects large and small. Schools, churches, clubs in all parts of the State can be busy hives of productive activity in furtherance of the fundamental Centennial theme.
To a substantial degree certain of the most important physical aspects
of the Centennial can be developed, war or no war.
In the course of doing our daily tasks, even in wartime, every one of us can, by spending an extra hour today and another tomorrow, work at transformation in a year's time in the appearance of his home, farm, shop or factory. If each of us can have the help and co-operation of family, neighbors, and associates in business, church or club activities, and, in his turn, will give a full measure of help and co-operation with an eye to the beautification of his surroundings, the State of Utah can be adorned with attractive villages, towns, and cities well before the close of the Centennial year.
War-imposed restrictions may aid rather than hinder us in this achievement. Deprived of means and opportunity to travel, we can spend our time, energy and money at home and have, as the outcome, the satisfaction and pride of having our own products and arrangements, neatness, and beauty in our immediate surroundings.
Who has not enjoyed a merited sense of satisfaction and pride upon seeing, as the result of his handiwork, a neatly kept lawn; a well-cultivated and arranged garden; beautiful shrubs, stately, healthy trees; a well-laid-out farm, efficiently managed; an orderly and attractive home, shop or factory! Whoever has not had this experience has been denied one of the most gratifying of emo-
Page 70 YOUR PART IN UTAH'S CENTENNIAL 71 There is beauty and inspiration in every manifestation of care and pride in the use and preservation of machinery, tools, equipment, furniture, buildings, fences, houses, barns, and shops. It takes the soul of an artist and a poet to keep alive the appreciation of orderliness and craftsmanship which was so plentiful in Utah pioneer communities. One needs only to take the time to examine the buildings erected by early settlers of this State to discover a high standard of care and craftsmanship in the construction and adornment of their buildings. These are the evidences of culture, artistic sense, self-respect, and character in craftsmanship which we today must emulate, and by doing so honor ourselves as being worthy of our pioneer ancestry. Our Centennial Celebration will be empty and unworthy, if we do not exhibit unmistakable evidence of civic pride and of the sturdy virtues of industry and good husbandry, orderliness, neatness and love of beautification, which are such eloquent expression of the idealism of the pioneers. They dreamed dreams of beauty for their mountain homeland, and they worked hard to make those dreams real in productive fields and blossoming landscape. NATURE has made Utah beautiful with unmatchable color and variety. We who love her wall aid her, and will never let it be truthfully said of us that "man is the great de-facer." If we sincerely admire her and love her for her beauty, we delight in paying our homage to her by doing everything we can to enhance her beauty, and nothing to mar it. Utah, the Star of the West, gains her physical beauty and color from nature, and her brilliance and luster from the sterling character of her citizens, who express their virtues in the attractiveness of their persons, personalities, and property. The Centennial Celebration of 1947, war or no war, will call the people of the State upon the stage, in the center of the spotlight, to exhibit the fruits of their pioneer heritage. Shall we earn the applause of the audience, as being worthy of the admiration which our famous ancestors have won? A good, practical example of collective community action toward beautification is offered in the situation in certain Salt Lake City areas where fast-growing, short-lived trees were planted in the early days to provide quick shade. These have now spent themselves and are dead. Equipped with available city-owned machinery, responsible groups of individuals, civic clubs, priesthood groups or quorums, by working to a well-planned schedule and assignments, could remove the trees in a short time, cut up and save the wood against times of local need and, at the same time, improve the general appearance of the community, remove hazards to life and property and make ready for planting of new trees according to the city's plan. A similar project in many Utah communities can be the starting point for wartime community beautification. Every community, through the action of individuals and organized groups, can participate in annual or more frequent "clean-up and paint-up" campaigns, and can thus put in (Continued on page 128) Second Prize Story Annual Relief Society Short Story contest

The Bureau Vesta Pierce Crawford VESTA PIERCE CRAWFORD YOU remember your Grandma Watts, don't you? Bertha Carlson, she was, before she married me. You remember when she died, but that was a long time ago and you were living in California. I suppose Bertha was very much like other women, only better. But when we were young I thought there was one particular thing about her that was peculiar. She set her heart on a piece of furniture. Page 72 I remember the first time Bertha mentioned wanting a bureau. We called them bureaus then, although I hear your wife referring to them as chests of drawers. We needed bureaus badly because the houses had no built-in cabinets. We had just moved into our first home one room. There sat Bertha on the floor with a heap of bundles around her, all her wedding finery. She held some lacey things in her pretty hands and she looked at me with coaxing blue eyes.  John,  she said,  I do wish I had a bureau.  I bent down and put my arms around her and kissed her auburn hair, and I said, "Don't you worry, Bertha. I'm the one that's going to get you a bureau and everything else you want." I didn't know then what I've learned since or I wouldn't have made promises. I never would have made promises. It takes a long time to learn things, and sometimes you don't learn until it is too late. Bertha must have thought of that bureau a lot after she first mentioned it. Just before our first baby came she asked about it again. She had all the clothes about done, stacks of them, but where she got the cloth from I don't know, for I wasn't making much. Dry farming, you know depends on the weather. You don't have a regular income. So, as I said before, I don't know where Bertha got the cloth for the baby clothes. Maybe her folks gave her some or she might have cut up some of her wedding things.
I can't forget that evening. It was November and the wind rattled the door. Bertha was sitting by the kitchen range with her crochet hook flying, and there, piled on the table were the baby things. She said she felt pretty good and she laid down the crocheting and started to fix my supper. She began to move the things off the table. Then she stopped and said, "John, dear, I do wish I had a bureau. It would be nice if I had some drawers to put these things in."
I put my arm on her shoulder and I asked, "How much do they cost?"
"Maybe fifteen dollars," she said, "or twenty-five for a big solid-oak one."
But I didn't have a five in my pocket.
The next day I went to the store and got a big empty dry-goods box, and together we lined it with cloth and put the baby clothes in it, and Bertha seemed contented.
Queer about women, though. She had her heart set on the bureau. Never asked for much else, and I made up my mind I'd get the bureau for her as soon as ever I could. That wasn't easy to do, for we always needed something else worse a new cook stove, a carpet, some tools or machinery. Then we had to build on to the house and make it larger, as you see it now, with this fancy porch and the bedrooms and all. We had five children and we needed the extra rooms.
When I saw Bertha getting old and frail looking, I was worried. She never mentioned the bureau any more. I did manage to buy some furniture, a sofa, and a leather chair, and a desk for the parlor. We got along and we tried to be kind to each other. But even when I was alone, her voice seemed to be ringing in my ears. This was strange, for Bertha was a quiet woman by nature and she was never one to nag about anything. Once when I was sitting at sundown on a ledge above the river a light wind was blowing. Then, all at once, I thought I could see Bertha coming up the cliff, and I thought I heard her say, "John, I do need a bureau."
I was terribly ashamed of myself and I made up my mind to get the bureau at once. Our youngest daughter, Emily, was going to get married. Her mother kept sewing and sewing, and there were patterns and goods and thread scattered all about and stacks of new things around. One afternoon I came in early from the field, and there sat Bertha at the sewing machine, treadling fast. She stopped suddenly and looked up at me. In a minute tears were streaming down her face. She turned away and treadled again. Emily went over and touched Bertha's gray hair and asked, "What's the matter, Mother?"
I knew what it was. She wanted that bureau so that Emily's wedding things could be put away and kept in good shape until she was ready for them.
This time I was surely going to get the bureau. I told Emily my plans. I was going to surprise her mother by bringing home a bureau. On the way to town I met Bart Sanders. He asked me if I wanted to buy his mowing machine. He was moving away and the machine was a good buy. I needed it the worst kind for my own mower was broken down, and was always at the blacksmith shop just when I needed it most. A good machine would be an investment. I told Bart I would take it and pay cash down. I hated to do it, but I thought that sometime later I could buy a better bureau for Bertha and she would be that much more pleased. She could afford to wait a while longer since she wasn't expecting the bureau anyway. I went home with the mowing machine and showed it to Bertha and Emily, but I didn't say anything about having intended to spend the money in another way. SIX months later our Emily got married. Bertha and I were alone in the house. Alone. I tell you I never heard so much silence. Then one night after supper when I was sitting at one side of the table and Bertha across from me, she said quietly,  You didn't get it, did you?" I shifted around in the chair. "Get what. Bertha?" Her voice was level. The bureau. Emily told me you were going to get a bureau to keep her wedding things in. I believed you really would. But it doesn't matter any more. Now the children have come and gone there isn't anything left to use a bureau for." Her face was gray and she didn't say anything more. After a while she went into the bedroom and closed the door quietly. I don't remember how long I sat at the table. She wouldn't need a bureau now, she had said, but a woman can always use a bureau. Five years after Emily was married the lucern seed crop was good. I had some extra money in my pocket. I hitched up and drove the wagon fifteen miles over to Mayfield and tied up at the Emporium. They had lots of bureaus, big high solid-oak ones, and wider ones made of white maple, and polished walnut bureaus with six drawers. Then all at once I saw the one 1 wanted. It was a beauty. Painted green, and over that, for trimming, big pink roses. It had golden looking handles and carved legs with shining casters. I bought it. Fifty dollars, but it was worth twice that. I loaded it on the wagon, covered it with an old quilt, and drove home. I remember, yet, how anxious I was to get there. Bertha had gone out somewhere. I set the bureau by the bed in our room and then I went into the kitchen to wait. What would she say? What would she think of the green paint and the pink roses? It was fall, and when Bertha came in she was wearing her coat, a gray coat buttoned up tight. "Well, John," she said, "when did you get home?" "Just now." "Where have you been?" "Nowhere." She took off her coat and started for the bedroom. I held my breath. She stood in the doorway. She kept standing there.   "Bertha," I said, "don't you like it?" Finally she turned around. Her face was as gray as ashes and she was THE BUREAU 75 " trembling. She tried to smile and I had a queer idea that she was trying to make the years drop off I had queer idea that she was trying to make the years drop off her. She walked toward me slowly and put her hand on my shoulder.  John,  she said,  You got the burequ after all.  But she didn t put a thing in the drawers. Time after time I looked, but there was never the least trinket put in the bureau. One day I asked,  Bertha, don t you like the bureau?  You didn t look at me  Sure,  she said,  I like it fine. It s the handsomest bureau I ever saw.  But I wasn t satisfied and I wasn t pleased with myself. I went to the window and watched the rain beating down and there was no comfort in it. The room was too quiet. I knew it would always quiet.

I AM PEACE Ivy Houtz Woolley Drenched with blood are my robes of white, My eyes have wept out all their light; Bruised are my feet with broken steel, Sad is my heart; my senses reel  For I am Peace. I have been crushed and wounded sore. Unheard is my voice in cannons' roar, Unfelt my touch, save by dying ones As they clasp their hands 'round smoking guns-But I am Peace. The mother alone with her empty chairs Can hear my voice, yet she hardly dares To hope that I am still on earth To spare the ones that she gave birth Still I am Peace. I must spur forth, fling wide my door. To bring my countries back once more, And turn their darkness into light; They shall live through this dreadful night  For I am Peace.
A Pioneer Story

The Big Horn Basin Pauline Taggart Pingree Member of Relief Society General Board GRANDMOTHER Janet McNiven was left a widow with two small children, a son, James, and a daughter, Jessie, when she was a young woman. She lived in Edinburgh, Scotland, until 1863, when she heard the gospel preached by the Mormon missionaries and became convinced of its truthfulness, and was baptized.
As did most people during the early days of the Church, she desired to come to Zion, so she sold her business and all her household belongings, said goodbye to her kindred and friends, and started out with her two children for a new world and a new life.
They crossed the Atlantic Ocean in the good ship Underwriter, leaving Scotland the middle of March and arriving in New York on May 22, 1861. These saints, with others, were presided over by Charles W. Penrose, Milo Andrus, and Homer Duncan. The six weeks' voyage was very rough; many were ill, and one man died and was buried at sea. A weary trek across the plains followed their arrival in America. Imagine the heartache of grandmother with no companion to help her share her responsibilities! She had supreme faith, however, that she would reach her destination and be able to make a home for herself and children in Zion. She was a woman of very thrifty. She had a natural talent for nursing, and she always seemed to know what to do in an emergency and there were many emergencies on the plains. Fortune seems to smile upon those women who roll up their sleeves and put their shoulders to the wheel; upon women who are not afraid of dreary, dirty, irksome drudgery, who do not turn aside for obstacles, whether great or small. "He alone is great who by a life heroic conquers fate."
Grandmother and her two children did arrive safely in Salt Lake, and after a time she was married to Robert Hogg. Her joy at being in Salt Lake with the saints was shortlived, however. Brigham Young was calling men to go north, east, south, and west to start new communities. Grandmother, her husband, and children were sent to the little valley of Morgan where they settled in the town which is now known as Milton, about five miles from Morgan City. Here they built the first house in that locality. The first winter they had only one sack of flour and a very few necessities, and the winter was very severe.
Jessie (my mother) was now nine years of age. There were no schools of any kind in Morgan County and very few books. Mother learned to read and spell from the songbooks in Church. She was a beautiful singer, and she loved to memorize hymns as well as to sing them. In Page 76 THE BIG HORN BASIN 77 A. O. WOODRUFF AND JESSE W. CROSLEY, JR., ON WAY TO BIG HORN In time, she became a fluent reader and a lover of good

literature. Mother was married in the Endowment House in Salt Lake City to George H. Taggart when she was only sixteen years of age. The ceremony was performed by President Joseph F. Smith. Father had been sent with his father to Morgan to build a flour mill which was the first one in that part of the State. Mother's first child was born when she was seventeen years of age, and from then on her children came about every two years. The family was very poor, and she was tried in many, many ways; but she was naturally of a cheerful, determined disposition, with a good sense of humor, and she made the best of every situation. There were no doctors in the community, so grandmother decided to be an obstetrician. She was the only one in Morgan for many years, and she did most of her work without monetary compensation. She must have been a good midwife, for she cared for my mother through sixteen, completely successful confinements. There was no chloroform in those days and child bearing was not the relatively easy matter it is today. I can see grandmother now with a little black lace bonnet on her head, a shoulder shawl, and a satchel, about which we were very curious as children. She would come every day for ten days, then, with the help of the older children, mother would again assume her responsibilities. As Christmas time approaches, my thoughts always revert to my childhood. Our Christmas presents were few and simple. Among the presents I shall always remember were the silver rings father made for us out of silver coins. Dimes were used in making those for the smaller children, and quarters were used for the larger ones. He made our doll cradles, beds, sheet-iron stoves, with an oven and stovepipe, for mud pies. Mother always knitted new stockings for us; I was quite a young lady when I had my first "store stocking."
As the family increased in number and the boys grew older (there were ten of them), father began to wonder what to do with us all. Being a tradesman, he had no land excepting the acre on which our home was built. For young people to leave home in those days to find work in the cities was considered a dangerous thing. About this time, the year 1900, Governor DeForest Richards, and Secretary of State Fentemore Chatterton visited President Lorenzo Snow and counselors asking for a colony of Mormons to be sent to the Big Horn Basin in Wyoming. President Snow appointed Owen Woodruff, of the Council of the Twelve, to take charge of the project, as he had been out to Burlington, Wyoming, and had organized a ward there. He had been shown the Greybull Valley and had seen the crops produced there, samples of which he had brought back to Salt Lake. He found that a permit had been issued August 10, 1896, to the Cincinnati Canal Company to build a canal that would irrigate a large tract of land on the north side of the Shoshone River. This company had sent the Honorable Frank Mondell, who at that time was United States senator from Wyoming, to make a report on the feasibility of building the canal. He had reported that it was impossible to accomplish such a project, so it had been abandoned and the permit had expired and had been advertised for bids by November 14, 1898.
Elder Woodruff filed an application for this same tract of land on January 11, 1900, before the Land Board of Wyoming. On February 2, 1900, Elder Woodruff requested the following gentlemen to meet him in Ogden, Utah, for the purpose of making a trip to the Big Horn Basin with a view to establishing a colony there: Byron Sessions of Woodruff, Rich County; H. K. North, Salt Lake County; George H. Taggart, Morgan County; John and William Simmons, Charles A. Welch, and John Croft of Morgan County; Brigham L. Tippets and William B. Graham of Bennington, Idaho; John Stephens and S. P. Sorenson of Montpelier, Idaho; Bishop N. P. Larsen and Mr. Gumsey of Thomas Fork, Bear Lake County. Most of these men had been farmers in their own communities, but none of them had had any scientific training of any kind. However, after going over the tract of land, the party decided there was a future for the country, that it was good cattle land, and that the opportunity for home building in many places was good.
Elder Woodruff made a report to the General Authorities of the Church. It was favorably received, and he was appointed to take charge of the colonization. Franklin S. Richards drew up articles of incorporation for the Big Horn Basin Colonization Company. The organization of this company was effected in Salt Lake City, April 9, 1900, but the company was organized under the laws of the State of Wyoming.
THE first settlers left their homes in Salt Lake City and began their journey to the Big Horn on April 13, 1900. They started in the Year, in order to avoid high water season, as many streams had to be forded, there being no bridges over most of them. THE BIG HORN BASIN 79 MORMON PATHFINDERS TO THE BIG HORN BASIN, WYOMING Front row: George H. Taggart, Byron Sessions, Abraham O. Woodruff, William B. Graham, Brigham L. Tippetts, S. P. Sorenson. Back row: Charles A. Welch, Hyrum K. North, John Stevens, William G. Simmons, John J. Simmons. The people were organized into companies similar to the way in which the early Mormon pioneers had been organized. My father was captain of one of these companies. My two brothers, John Robert and Bruce, and two sisters, Rebecca and Nettie, were in this company. (Mother and the other members of the family remained at home until later.) They traveled one whole month before they reached their destination. The same distance and practically the same route is now traveled in eighteen hours by automobile. They encountered many difficulties. There were no roads, just trails; and the weather was bad all the way. During the heavy storms the horses were without food except for the oats the men had taken with them. The men would tie quilts about the horses to keep them from freezing to death, while they, in turn, would sit around a campfire to keep themselves warm. There was considerable sickness, one little child dying of pneumonia. Father made a coffin for her from the end gates of wagons, and she was sent back to Utah for burial. The broken-hearted parents had to carry on. The group arrived in the Basin May 24, 1900. Tents were pitched as there was not a house within a radius of fifty miles. Just three days later the first ecclesiastical organization was effected with 127 persons present. PIONEER COMPANIES NUMBERS 2 AND 3 AT HAMS FORK A Sunday School, Mutual Improvement Association, and Relief Society were organized. Lucy F. Grant, sister-in-law of President Heber J. Grant and wife of Morgan Grant, was the first Relief Society president. This was a new country in very deed. The people were faced with many obstacles and trials of all kinds. There were no roads, no towns within fifty miles, no doctors within a hundred miles. Some of the people lived in tents, some in sheep wagons, and all realized it would be months and perhaps years before they would enjoy the real comforts of life. There was no mail service, and letters had to be taken to some roadside ranch many miles away, where the stagecoach would pick them up. Rattlesnakes, lizards, - spiders, et cetera, were plentiful, and everyone had to be on the alert for them at all times. There was no feed for animals, except salt sage and a little grass. There was scarcely any grain in the country. Food had to be freighted in, and everything was very expensive. On May 28, 1900, these good people knelt in prayer on the spot that was to be the head of the canal, and they asked for God's blessings upon them. Elder Woodruff officiated. Then the work on the canal began in earnest, and very hard work it was, lasting for weeks and months, with the wind constantly blowing and the dry sand flying. It was decided that each morning and evening while work was going forward on the canal a bugle would call the camp members together to sing praises to God, and to ask for his aid. Elder Woodruff, in outlining the task that was before them, admonished the people to be united, not to profane the name of Deity, to keep the Word of Wisdom, pay tithing, and keep the Sabbath Day holy. He promised the people that if they would do these things the Lord would be a kind of Zion unto them and their children. He said, "And that you may be united, I view, as an apostle of the Lord Jesus Christ, call each and everyone of you upon a mission to help build up this country, and if you will do this, the Lord will bless you forever."
Men who had only gone to see the country were so impressed they decided to remain. To enable a people to perform any work, whatsoever, requires that they have faith in the ultimate result. No farmer would plant unless he expected to reap; no builder would build unless he expected to complete the structure; no man or woman would act unless there existed a faith that the destination would be reached. So, likewise, the commandments of God are obeyed because there exists a faith that certain blessings will follow obedience. Through faith our ancestors accepted the gospel, and by that same faith they left their homes in the Old World and came to a new land feeling sure they would be able to make a better future for themselves and their children, no doubt without fully realizing the many trials that awaited them. This was true of the people who went to the Big Horn Basin in April 1900. They went with faith because the Church Authorities advised it and provided them with a mission. They had great hope in the future of themselves and their children. However, they did not fully realize the trials and hardships that lay ahead.
The great canal took four long years to build and, when completed, it was 37 miles long, 24 feet wide on the bed, 16 feet wide at the bottom. It was built at a cost of $150,000. It
was never bonded, and when completed there was a credit balance of $3,000.
The people who worked on the ditch were given stock with the understanding that their land would cost them $6 per acre. It was later discovered it would cost them $7.50 per acre or $240 for 40 acres. Work had to be discontinued for a short period after the first six months, as there was no money with which to continue. A special fast meeting was held and everyone was asked to fast all day, and to implore the Lord to send some work whereby money could be earned to see the project through. Not many days passed before work was resumed in the following manner: The chief engineer of the Burlington Railroad Company, Mr. S. P. Weeks, came to Elder Woodruff and told him he would like our people to build twenty miles of railroad. He said his company had heard that the Mormons were colonizing in the Basin, so had decided to build a line into the country. This was indeed good news, and contracts were signed for twenty miles of grading. Thus the prayers of the people were answered. While doing this work our people held devotional exercises night and morning, and no job was undertaken without calling upon the Lord for his help.
IT was October of 1900 that mother and the rest of the family joined father and the four children who were with him. The stark had made a camp on what is known as Sage Creek. I was about halfway between the head of the canal and the end of the project. It was here that mother and the family first located. The wind blew constantly in this country and it was a very common thing to see tents tagged-el and household belongings carried away, and what was left would be filled with sand. The water in Sage Creek was very bad and had to be boiled before it could be used. Mother would take the wood ashes and put them into a large barrel which she would have the boys fill with water. The ashes would clarify the water so it was somewhat better for laundering.
While we were living at Sage Creek an epidemic of smallpox broke out. There were no doctors to be had, so my mother, relying upon her own knowledge and wisdom and the help of her Heavenly Father, nursed not only seven members of her own family back to normal health, with no complications or bad after effects, but she aided others who were stricken. It was marvelous how nearly everyone survived this epidemic.
After a few months, father moved us down to the banks of the Shoshone River where the water was better and where there was some shade from the broiling sun. When we would get discouraged, we were reminded of the faith of our grandparents, their trials in crossing the plains and establishing homes in desert country in the early days. Did not Grandfather Taggart leave his wife and two little children at Winter Quarters and go with the Mormon Battalion to Mexico? We were reminded of his bleeding feet, with shoes gone when he arrived in California; of grandmother having to work to support herself and children while he was away. Father would
Church as a boy of seventeen, making three trips across the plains without pay. Boys and men had been asked to volunteer for this work. No, there was no turning back. We had to live up to their example and carry on.
In the late fall of 1901 mother and the younger children moved to the Cowley Flat where the town of Cowley is now located, while father and the older children worked on the railroad. Here the families lived in tents until spring when the men folk began building their homes. That was a terrible winter. Typhoid fever paid the community a visit. Mother nursed the afflicted day and night. Her anxiety for the members of her family who were working on the railroad, especially for the girls who did the cooking for the men, was very great. I shall always know within my own heart that God was watching over us while mother was assisting others, and that because of the faith and prayers might and morning by the whole group, consisting of more than 150 men bearing the holy Priesthood of God, and because of the private supplication of each individual, we were indeed blessed by the Lord and protected from evil.
When the work on the railroad was completed, the men went back to work on the canal, which was completed in 1904. Crops were then planted and home building progressed. All the houses were built of logs. Father built us a very comfortable but humble home which surely seemed like a castle to us at the time. Of course, there were no electric lights, washing machines, irons, heating pads, vacuum cleaners, etc. in these homes. The joy of such things was not known until long afterward. THE BIG HORN BASIN 83 New School LOG HOUSE WHERE FIRST SCHOOL WAS HELD IN COWLEY Coal-oil lamps were used exclusively. (Lanterns were carried at night so one would not get lost on the prairie.) Baths had to be taken in the wash tub, which was no small task for us as we had a large family and water had to be hauled from the river a distance of four miles, and it had to be used sparingly. I am reminded of Alice Morrill's poem "The Pioneer Mother" which is so applicable here: A limitless expanse of wilderness surrounds her cabin home. The sun glares hot and pitiless by day, by night, the weird winds moan. Deep in her heart she makes a grave; lays there her hope of luxury, And gives her life, a ransom for the generations yet to be. In summer, the children went barefoot to save their shoes for winter. Clothing was handed down from one child to another until it was worn"*out. Sewing bees by the women were the social gatherings. At these gatherings or bees, quilts were made, rags were sewn for carpets, and burial clothing was made. There were no undertakers and when death came the women had to take complete charge. During the first few years, my father made all the caskets, and we girls used to help him line and trim them. My father made violins for the boys and guitars for the girls. They were beautifully made with wonderful tone quality. There was always music in our home as we were all blessed with musical talent a talent also possessed by father and mother. Our home was open to all, and there were many happy gatherings there. Young people are pretty much the same in any locality. They like to dance, to play ball, have concerts, shows, etc. This was true of the young people in this settlement. The meeting house, which consisted of one large room with a stage at one end and which was heated by a large stove, was used for all community recreation, such as dancing, shows, basketball, etc. It was rather difficult to get the spirit of worship in the building on Sunday where the night before a heated basketball game had been played.
The people of this pioneer community believed in education. The first schoolhouse consisted of two large rooms built of logs and heated by a large stove. The settlers yearned for higher education in all its phases. In a new country the people have to provide all such things for themselves; and while they may not always provide that which is most satisfying, they meet the needs to a certain extent.
Much trouble was encountered by the people the first time the water was turned into the great canal. The ground was terribly dry (in fact, I don't believe it had had a good soaking since the time of Noah), and much of it was so sandy that it simply could not hold the water; so repair work on the canal had to begin immediately and go on constantly. Senator Mondell stated at one time that the Sidon Canal project would never have been successful except for the rare courage of the Mormon people.
The first year the crops were fairly good, then alkali came upon the land. This was like a plague to the people. Nothing would grow where alkali prevailed. So a drainage system had to be worked out; large trenches were built at great expense to the people who were not prepared to meet such a problem. In time, however, the land was drained and crops were again planted.
When the Government decided to open a road into the eastern part of Yellowstone Park beginning at Cody, Wyoming, our people contracted to build sixteen miles of it. When this road was completed
the people once more. While building this road into the Yellowstone the same procedure was followed as on the railroad work morning and evening devotional exercises were held daily, with Church services on Sunday. Some of the best meetings I have ever attended were held out under the pine trees, and many times God seemed very close to us. One whole summer was spent on the Yellowstone Road project and this road is now the east entrance to Yellowstone Park. Many tourists prefer this entrance. It is very scenic and people are curious to see Buffalo Bill's town of Cody. Buffalo Bill (William F. Cody) was a very interesting character and he was very friendly to our people. He paid them a great tribute. He had secured a permit to irrigate all the land on the north side of the Shoshone River from Eagles Nest to the Big Horn River, but he said, "If the Mormons want to build a canal and irrigate the land lower down the River I will relinquish both land and water to them, for if they say they will do this I know they will; they are the kind of people who do what they agree to do." He did what he said he would do, without compensation, much to the disgust of his partner who wanted $25,000 for the transfer. When the transfer was completed Buffalo Bill said, "Now my dream will be realized for I have wanted to live to see this country developed into a great agricultural region, and the Mormons will fulfill my dream."
Father passed away in August 1924, age 76, and mother six years later, at age 77, leaving a large posterity. Mother was a Relief Society THE BIG HORN BASIN 85  Courtesy Bishop James Harston - COWLEY WARD CHAPEL AND AMUSEMENT HALL, COWLEY, WYOMING of the Cowley Ward Relief Society for eight years. (The desire of their hearts was granted in that they were privileged to live to see the members of their family grow up and establish homes of their own. All the children were married in the Church but one, which, according to the Mormon philosophy of life, is very important. Their descendants love and respect them and appreciate the wonderful influence they have exercised over them.) Father and mother were faithful members of the Church all the days of their lives. Mother's last advice to her children was for them to continue to live the gospel and be faithful and true to God. As I write of my mother, I am thinking of many more wonderful women like her who worked with her for the benefit of the Big Horn community. They were good neighbors and wonderful souls. Many of them are still torch bearers in the Big Horn Basin. THE final chapter of this great country is yet to be written. I have not pretended to write a complete history. Many of those first pioneers have become very prosperous, some became discouraged and left the country, others have comfortable homes and good farms. Some have failed, materially speaking, but have gained spiritually; others have not progressed at all. However, we find these things to be true in every locality. Wonderful highways now connect the various communities, and with the automobile it is now possible to keep in close touch with the outside world. The railroad passes through these communities assuring mail twice each day. The three towns of Lovell, Byron, and Cowley all now have good chapels, school-houses and amusement halls. The Holly Sugar Company built a large sugar factory in Lovell which has been in operation for many years. Lovell, in the year 1900, boasted four families, two of which were bachelors. Honesty IN considering life as it must be met today, one is forced to recognize the need for straight thinking, courage, steadiness of purpose, stability of character, and a firm belief that God is at the helm. We must acknowledge the need for mankind to accept in practice, as well as in theory, the great moral principles of the ages, a desertion of which has always brought sorrow or destruction. We must realize that character building is in reality "the most important business of life," and that character is built through the adoption of moral virtues such as simple honesty, truthfulness, and love. Dr. Harold T. Christensen in a Relief Society

social science lesson declares honesty to be the "core of character." He says, "It would be impossible to conceive of character without honesty, for any structure founded upon deceit and falsehood is founded upon sand rather than rock, and must inevitably fall." Yet, mankind throughout the ages has deserted this fundamental virtue. Strange as it may seem, he has done this in an attempt at self-benefit. But always in the end it has rebounded to his injury. The Bible furnishes us a good example of this. A certain man named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a possession. Instead of turning it all to the apostles, as was the plan, they held Page 88 back part of the price, being dishonest with both man and God. Peter severely rebuked Ananias. Upon hearing the words of Peter, Ananias fell down dead, and his wife likewise. Examples of dishonesty are all too plentiful. Every day we hear or read of dishonest behavior or we encounter it in some form or other. An item in a local paper, issued immediately following Christmas, reported that the Christmas season of 1944 closed with one of the worst shoplifting periods in history. At one drugstore losses from larcenists were estimated as high as $500 a week, and a special office had to be set up to "reprimand" shoplifters. Shoplifting, store managers agreed, was not confined to needy persons as several influential citizens were caught with stolen goods. One store manager declared, "The number of adults guilty of shoplifting would put any juvenile delinquency campaign to shame." He estimated his losses would run into thousands of dollars for the month of December. Dishonesty takes many forms. It appears as lying, cheating, stealing, deceiving. It asserts itself in thinking and in motives. It may be expressed by word, by deed, and by implication. It may be directed against man and God, and there are many who are dishonest with self. EDITORIAL No matter what its form or against whom it is directed, dishonesty is destructive and demoralizing. It injures the one who practices it. And wrongs the one against whom it is directed. It in no way builds nor strengthens nor benefits. Honesty, or any other moral virtue for that matter, cannot be established in a day. Moral instruction to take root must be started early and it must be continuous. Morality cannot be taught merely by precept; precept must constantly be supported by example. Parents, mothers in particular, must realize their tremendous responsibility in this respect. Knowing how desperately the world is in need of a return to the absolute moral principles which have always served mankind, recognizing how urgent is the world's need for honest men and women-men and women of character?we should give full attention to the building of such men and women. If we would conscientiously begin iK)w to train our youth to be strictly honest and virtuous, if we would teach them to put principle above immediate personal gain, the next generation would have a world fit to live in. Considering the obstacles the early pioneers encountered and the struggles they had in order to get along during the first few years, they did remarkably well and proved themselves to be strong souls. "The tendency to preserve, to persist in spite of hindrances, discouragements, and impossibilities: it is this that in all things distinguishes the strong soul from the weak." In the final analysis it does not make much difference where we live, but how we live; it is this that determines our success in life. Therefore, I would say to all people "Labour not for the meat which perisheth, but for that meat which endureth unto everlasting life" (John 6:27). Work Meeting 
THE question of serving lunch at noon in connection with Relief Society work meetings, is fairly general throughout the organization, and has the approval of the General Board although not instituted nor required by the Board. Various plans are in effect for providing this lunch. For example, in some wards, groups of members are assigned to supply the lunch for the entire group once a year, in others, each member brings her own lunch and is supplied with a supplementary drink or dessert by the Society; and, in other instances, the Society meets the entire expense, assigning committee members to prepare the food. The
matter of meeting the expense of such lunches was considered at a meeting of the General Board, November 29, 1944, when it was decided that all Relief Societies should be authorized to use funds of the Society for this purpose, leaving it optional with local Relief Societies as to whether they meet this expense entirely, or whether they supplement lunches brought by members individually, or in assigned groups.
Although approving the custom of providing lunches at work meetings which extend over the lunch period, the General Board urges that such lunches be very simple.
