EARLY SPRING RAIN
Ora Lee Parthesius
The sky is soft as a dove's gray wing, And through the silvered pattering Steals fragrance. Is it mignonette Or lilacs worn by some coquette? . . . Yes, winter's flirting with the spring! No Tongue Can Tell Marguerite J. Griffin "OUT there we talk of death quite calmly," said a young sailor, home on leave after seeing action in the South Pacific. "We talk over what has happened to this one and that one of our friends. We never spare the details. We talk of death quite as matter-of-factly, as if we were discussing a newspaper item. We might as well. It's all around us out there, and we know it. I've seen more things than I can tell you."
He was much changed, this young man, from what he had been when he had gone away. Two years older? Yes, but more than that. His ordinarily fair-skinned face was bronzed from the rigors of sea life. But there were shadows across his brow, faint ones easily removed by his ready smile, but still lurking there in moments of repose. There was a firm new purpose to his jaw, as though, whatever his naval rank, he was master of himself no matter what the days might bring. And all this change because he had seen more things than tongue can tell. Physical suffering he had seen because he served with the medical corps. Death he had seen. Men dying before his very eyes. Men dying without a whimper, without a complaint.
"After one bombing we went about on deck helping the wounded. They were lying all about. I saw a fellow who had been my best friend lying over his gun. I thought he was dead, but when I came up to him he recognized me and he said: 'Do not move me for the others are
about done for.' But I had to do something for him. He was my friend. He died an instant later in my arms, and then I was glad, seeing his condition. This is something I will never forget as long as I live. Yes. Death is something we talk about quite openly. It's there and you have to face it."
That was the thing that made this boy different from what he had been before. He had been face to face with death. He knew he would go back to face it again, but in the meantime he would serve as best he could and smile all the while. While life lasted there were things to do for the living and last respects to the dead. Time enough to worry about danger when it struck. Two years ago he had been a young, care-free boy. Today he is a man, brave, master of himself and his emotions. And what has wrought the change? One thing. His ability to face reality, look it squarely in the eye, and spend his strength getting the most possible joy out of the real things of life, people, places, and comradeship.
What are you doing, mothers of these boys who have become men overnight, who have seen more things than tongue can tell? What are you doing to change your own souls that would like to cringe and shrink into citadels strong and sure? What am I doing to prepare myself against the day when my sons must go forth to face the pains of life and death upon their own? How do we mean to face the problems of our own
lives courageously? We believe we could endure the dangers our sons face more easily than to know that they, in whose veins flow our own blood, must suffer, endure, and perchance die. But if our task is great, we must be greater.
I have seen mothers become whimpering old women, old long before their time, after their sons had sailed away to front-line action. I have seen them become helpless neurotics who can't stand to hear a news broadcast, who can't bear to read a paper. If it were helping these boys, then it would have purpose. But worry, anxiety cannot reach out and stop the bombs from falling. Instead, they twine like tentacles about the one who conceived them, crushing from her all the breath of life, like an octopus with its overpowering grip.
Again I have seen mothers, with heads erect, lock their secret heartaches into a dark corner of their beings, and valiantly go forth to take their parts in the many duties of life at home. Why the difference? Why does one cringe and one remain indomitable. The reason is simple, depending upon whether you fight with life or against it, whether you look the whole thing squarely in the face like the young seaman. It is whether you, too, know that death is there and will admit it, or whether you are trying to avoid it, to fight your own small futile fight, you know. Since Adam, men who have lived upon this earth have died. In that one thing all humanity are brothers. You know that each man must die, but don't push the knowledge back into a far corner of your heart and refuse to face it. Well, bring it out into the
light and let the sun shine upon it for awhile. You are going to die. Your son is going to die. No matter how you live, or grieve, or worry, you cannot change this fact. War doesn't make much difference then. It only makes you more aware that death stalks the earth.
BUT you say: "My boy is so young! What a pity a life is cut short in youth!" So we always feel. A pity to die so young! But what does it matter if life be long or short? The important thing is, how have we lived and how have we died. The day to an honest man, busy with his constructive work, may seem all too short. The same day to a criminal waiting to pay for his crime upon the gallows may seem a fortunate eternity. But the day had twenty-four hours, and if it rained it rained for both. The difference is only in the human heart, in the way of life. One man knows the peace of honesty, the other the remorse, the despondency of a life which must pay for wasted deeds. Who, then, can measure a life, if it be long or short? Better to say it was rich or poor. Rich in valiance, in love, in honor, or poor in fear, in selfishness, in smallness of spirit. True it is, today many a youth gives his life, brief in years, but full of valor. "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends."
"Beloved, think it not strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened unto you." A strange thing? It has happened over and over in this world, but there has appeared with it the strange. It is something we have never felt before. It is a thrust to our courage. But we are not alone. Dogs that help? Every soul who has lived has had to face his Gethsemane, even the Son of Man. "Forasmuch as Christ hath suffered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves likewise with the same mind: for he that hath suffered in the flesh hath ceased from sin."
As human beings we must suffer some things over which we have no control, sickness, financial reverses, death, but at least if we seek an honorable way to life we can spare ourselves many heartaches of our own making.
There are so many things to benefit humanity that need to be done. Your sons are doing a big part of them. There is much remaining for us to do at home. There will always be a need for worthwhile tasks, well done.
"And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell." And what person is it we should fear? None other than our own selves. True we must answer the call of death, for that is an event of life through which all must pass, but how we die and how we live
that is our own affair. We can chart a course which will steer us safely through troubled waters or we can let our souls crack up in the storm. It is for us to choose.
"And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me." Hear the words of the Son of God who gave his life upon the cross to break the bonds of death, that the sea might one day give up the dead that are in it, that he might say unto the dry, parched, shattered bones of war, "Behold, I will cause breath to enter into you, and ye shall live: and I will lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and ye shall live; and ye shall know that I am the Lord." The same Lord who said: "These things I have spoken unto you, that in me ye might have peace. In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world."
As he leads let us follow, and while our days endure in the world we, too, can overcome the trials that beset our days, we can take up our cross and follow him. We can feel his peace which is so sweet no tongue can tell. THE SNOWBALLS Olive Rose Helton A bit of gleaming white, A breath of sweet perfume, A tiny snow-white bud, And then a large full bloom. Now sparkling in the sunlight, Now shadowed by the trees; No lovelier flower in springtime, Than snowballs in the breeze. Work Meeting UTILITY APRONS IN most present-day households the homemaker finds it necessary not only to do her own housework, but to learn how to conserve her energy so she can accomplish all the tasks she desires to do. These aprons are practical in any kind of household but they are invaluable in homes where there are busy mothers and small children. The large pockets become convenient "catch-alls" for numerous articles which become misplaced. If the pockets are lined with oiled silk or a plasticized material they can also be used to carry a damp cloth for wiping off stray fingermarks, a cloth for furniture polishing, a whisk broom, etc. Such utility articles might be made on a Relief Society Work Meeting in the spring or for a coming bazaar. The apron (Illus. I) is very easily made using 3/5 yd. Of material 27" wide for the apron proper, and 8" of contrasting material for the pockets. The apron is most effective using a light color for the background and a very dark color for the pockets. The apron (Illus. 2) can be made in medium size using 21/8 yds. Of 35" material. If a head bandana is made of the same material, a very smart effect is achieved in this utility costume. The apron ties and is also buttoned down the back. The large pockets end a little beyond the side seams. This apron is unusually effective if a bright gay, solid color is used. Bias tape in a contrasting color makes an easy finish to use for binding. TIE APRON BUTTONED APRON NOTES FROM THE FIELD Vera White Pohlman, General Secretary-Treasurer Regulations governing the submittal of material for "Notes from the Field" appear in the Magazine for February 1944, page 104. MESSAGES FROM THE MISSIONS (Continued from February Magazine) East Central States Mission THE following reports from four of the branches of this mission were received during 1944. Their Mission Relief Society President, Leone W. Doxey, submitted all but one. "In the country district of Gretna, Virginia," wrote Sister Doxey, "we have a Relief Society with sixteen members, thirteen of whom are not members of the Church. "The meetings of tlie Gretna Relief Society are held Tuesday afternoons in the home of Sister Maria Rowland, 'Granny,' as she is lovingly called by all who know her. The home is a fine old Virginia farmhouse that had been the home of her husband's father and mother. Granny moved into it as a bride. She is now nearly eighty years old and has been a member of the Church for more than forty years. She teaches the theology lessons in Relief Society and is an inspiration to everyone there." Mrs. L. H. Snow, president of the Chadottesville (Virginia) Relief Society, wrote July 20, 1944: "In and around this city and also other big towns, we see many beautiful little country churches closed for lack of preachers. Women from Page 184 some of these churches are joining the Relief Society and are glad to get something to do. I wish you could see our women working, making rugs, quilts, et cetera. The people in the country want to piece quilts so Iam taking them the material. I am also taking them samples of a miniature redchecked apron and a tiny pair of blue and white striped overalls, to help in the collection of contributions to the building fund. A note in the apron pocket has space for filling in the woman's name and her waist measurement, and carries the suggestion, "A penny for every inch." A similar note in the overall pocket suggests that the men pledge either work on the chapel or a cash donation. We also have one member in Hampton, and she is making something for the bazaar in October. Some members up in the Blue Ridge near Standardsville are making quilts?one woman gave the top, filling, and bottom for a quilt last night. This project is getting every one doing something, and in that way they learn what we stand for and what we are doing in trying to teach the gospel. The people are hungry for the gospel and for friends." Sister Doxey reports an unusual Relief Society meeting held at Fairmont, Virginia, which came to her attention through Sister Crozier Kimball, a short-term missionary. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 185 RELIEF SOCIETY OF HARKERS ISLAND (NORTH CAROLINA), EAST CENTRAL STATES MISSION Picture submitted March 1944 by M. LA. President Raymond Guthrie who stated: This Society was organized in 1923 under adverse circumstances and almost unbearable persecution. Although at that time the membership was very small it has since grown, through the faith and charity exercised by the sisters, to the present membership of 30. Left to right, front row: Virgie Lewis, Annie B. Guthrie, Annie Rose, Annie Lee Lawrence, Edith Willis (Secretary), Gertie Willis (1st Counselor), Letha Lewis (President), Blanch Willis (2d Counselor), Lillian Davis (teacher), Belva Gillikin, Mamie Hamilton, Clara Willis and Edith A. Willis; second row: Nettie Brooks, Naomi Guthrie, Flora Belle Willis, Hannah Guthrie; third row: Glennie Guthrie, Mattie Whitley, Bessie Hancock, Nannie Willis and Hattie Rose. "Sister May Sloter, Relief Society president in Fairmont, had announced on Sunday that the work meeting would be held the following Wednesday afternoon. The time arrived for the appointed meeting and no one came but the president. She felt discouraged and somewhat upset, but she had said there would be Relief Society meeting so she conducted one. She announced the song and sang it, opened the meeting with prayer, sang again and then sat down and quilted for an hour. At the end of the hour she sang another song and dismissed the meeting with prayer. She put her work away and returned to her home with joy and satisfaction in her heart. Sister Sloter is loved and respected by the members of the Fairmont Branch and though the membership is small, after this example of faithfulness, all who possibly can now attend the meetings." Northern California Mission MARY SMITH ELLSWORTH, recently released president of Relief Societies of the Northern California Mission, wrote last June: "During the year thus far I have visited in every district with President Ellsworth. The most outstanding thing I find is the increased spirit of unity and cooperation and love among all our sisters. Our Relief Society meetings are held in most branches immediately following Sunday School; while the men Attend Priesthood meeting, the Relief Society and Primary convene. RELIEF SOCIETY MEMBERS. THEIR HUSBANDS AND FRIENDS, TOYON BRANCH, NORTHERN CALIFORNIA MISSION at the party at Toyon Community House, March 17, 1944 commemorating the 102d anniversary of the organization of the Relief Society. Inset shows presidency with birthday cake, with President Lorena Humphries in center, and Counselors Mary K. Hirst and Mabel Kloss, left and right, respectively. Transportation facilities are more available on Sunday, especially in our outlying districts and where many of our people are engaged in war work. "It is the earnest desire of President Ellsworth to establish a suitable place of meeting for every branch in this mission, and in this the sisters are doing their full part. This year two chapels have been dedicated and property has been purchased in eight branches. The sisters have given dinners not only for their own members, but, in several instances, have served for various clubs and groups who have paid them well. They have held rummage sales to dispose of clothes collected from neighbors and friends as well as our own members. Prior to the sales, these articles are washed or cleaned and mended; they bring in a very good price and help those who need them. High-type character balls and parties which included wholesome and amusing games have placed the sisters in touch with many, thus affording opportunity to teach the gospel by example as well as precept. "We have in the mission, now, 260 local missionaries, many of them our Relief Society sisters. We feel thankful for this, for our younger mothers are gaining experience and knowledge that will qualify them to teach their children the gospel. We appreciate the excellent lessons given us by the General Board. They breathe the pure spirit of the gospel, impel us to action, and help to qualify us for real missionary work." Anna Duckett, secretary-treasurer of the Toyon (Redding, California) Branch Relief Society submitted last July the accompanying pictures and the following article by Eva S. Richards, a member: They Are Still Pioneers NOTES FROM THE FIELD 187 RELIEF SOCIETY SINGING MOTHERS OF SAVANNAH BRANCH (GEORGIA), SOUTHERN STATES MISSION Mission Relief Society President Effie Meeks says this is a splendid singing group which is a factor in maintaining interest in Relief Society work there. "In the shadow of snow-capped Mt. Shasta lies a minute branch of the Church?the Toyon Branch. It is situated on the hills and bluffs overlooking the Sacramento River and Shasta Dam, the world's second largest concrete structure. "The construction of this dam has brought people from all over the world, both as workers and visitors, and so the Toyon Branch is very cosmopolitan with representation from Canada, Australia, Germany, England, Sweden, Holland, as well as most of the states, from coast to coast. "The dam is fifteen miles from the nearest California town of any size, and its construction brought five or six thousand persons, some of them Mormons, into a wilderness of red clay, turpentine pines, manzanita, and poison oak. "Some of those who came early in the construction period spent that first miserable winter (three months of constant rain) in canvas tents; but spring comes early in this part of California and by April 1938, homes were started. Poison oak brush was plentiful and had to be cleared; even smoke from its burning carried contamination. Most of the work of clearing was done by women and children, for the work shifts on the dam changed every two weeks for some, while others worked a constant shift of day, swing or graveyard. "The homes usually had their beginning as one-room affairs, but as the men earned steadily, the homes grew. Wells were dug in very unpromising terrain, with accidents, and even casualties, a common occurrence. MEMBERS OF THE NEWLY ORGANIZED RELIEF SOCIETY AT PLYMOUTH. MASSACHUSETTS standing in front of the National Monument to the Forefathers which overlooks the bay. Left to right: Kate Burgesis, Marjorie Pickett, Elder Harold Dance, Estella Hutchins, and Elizabeth Pickett, Relief Society president. The other members unable to be present when picture was taken are Cora E. Bartlett and Cora Ann Glass. Delightful homes with electricity and modern conveniences are seen in the once-wilderness. And now, six years later, "The women worked long and hard to build these homes even though they knew they were to live there but a few years. Some of the women were sickly, some were old, some were having children, but they all had the desire for a home of their own. One family took the red clay, formed it into bricks, and, in one year, built for themselves a spacious six-room home that is now one of the social centers of the branch. "Gardens were made in the red clay by the women and children who carried fertilizer and sand from the river banks. Much to everyone's amazement, the gardens produced. The daughters of the pioneers are still helping to make a garden spot in the West, and are seeing that their children are raised in the culture of home and Church. "The Toyon Branch covers ten square miles. All of the visiting teachers are women who have families of small children, but their work has been done efficiently and on time. The loid anniversary of the organization of the Relief Society was observed March 17 by the Toyon Branch? Crystal candles, wild ferns, redbud and forsythia decorated the community house and an unforgettable program was presented. The war and the closing scenes at Shasta Dam are now sending this group on again to new fields, to new homes. They will carry their spirit of love and endeavor into new communities that have never heard of Mormons or witnessed their industry. "Good luck to you all and Godspeed?modern pioneer women." New England Mission ELDER FOLEY C. RICHARDS was auxiliary supervisor for the mission at the time he submitted the following account, last August: "Again the Relief Society plays the pioneer role in New England, this time in the 'Pilgrim Town,' Plymouth, Massachusetts, where America's forefathers settled three hundred and twenty-four years ago. "On May 23, 1944, a Relief Society was organized there?the first organization of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to be established in Plymouth. Under the direction of President William H. Reeder, Jr., Bertha S. Reeder, mission Relief Society president, and Elder Ted L. Miller, district president, this Society was organized with six members. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 189 FOUR RELIEF SOCIETIES OF THE WESTERN STATES MISSION (Pictures submitted by Luceal R. Curtis, recently released president of the Relief Societies of this mission.) Top row, left to right: Relief Society at Salida, Colorado; Relief Society at Fruita, Colorado, observes the 102d anniversary. Bottom row, left to right: Belle Fourche (South Dakota) Branch also celebrates 102d anniversary of Relief Society; Relief Society at Grand Junction, Colorado. Three of these were Latter-day Saints at the time; one has subsequently been baptized, and the other two are earnest investigators of the gospel. All are the fruits of recent missionary labor. 'These good sisters are enthusiastically meeting together each week, and the future of their group is promising indeed. Each has had to face the usual criticism which attends one who is willing to subscribe to 'Mormon' beliefs, and the Church can be justly proud of them for their Pilgrim spirit of loyalty to their convictions and for their service which makes possible this Latter-day Saint organization in New England's oldest town." Lola Humphreys, writing in the fall of 1944 as auxiliary supervisor, reported the successful Relief Society convention held September 2', at Cambridge, Massachusetts (the mission headquarters) for Relief Society officers. She continues: 'The careful planning which took place several weeks in advance, contributed greatly to the success of the conference which was very well attended by approximately 75 Relief Society officers. "During the forenoon session, a detailed and instructive outline of the duties of the officers was given by Mission Relief Society President Bertha S. Reeder. The remaining time was spent in the bearing of testimonies. At noon, a delicious buffet luncheon was served in one of the rooms of the Cambridge chapel from a table very attractively arranged with candles and flowers. In the afternoon, several talks were given in the homes of different Relief Society branches, and the Singing Mothers of Hartford, Connecticut, offered three beautiful numbers, at intervals.
"The enthusiasm and zeal with which Sister Reeder discussed the problems and with which she delivered her remarks were transferred to every one present. In spite of the fact that some of the members had had travel much more capable of carrying home the day before, they all felt much more capable of carrying on their duties after the convention."
A comprehensive mimeographed bulletin was distributed, carrying a concise and explicit digest of duties of officers and of new instructions, and also a narrative history of the several local Relief Societies in the mission for 1943-44, indicating the problems, activities, and accomplishments of each.
Hawaiian Mission
OLIVIA S. Waddoups, former Relief Society president of this mission, wrote in March 1944: "Brother Waddoups is superintendent of the Leper-asylum here at Kalaupapa. We find a wide field for service to these people who, though entirely confined for life within this area of about 12 square miles, are very happy, cheerful, and contented. They are also very war conscious, buying bonds and stamps to the extent of three times their quota. They are well taken care of by the Territory. We have a very modern hospital, two capable doctors whose wives are nurses in the hospital, five other nurses; 12 Catholic Sisters who manage the hospital, five other nuns; two Catholic priests; one Congregational minister, his wife and three members of his family; the plantation manager and planter; and the general manager for the United States Public Health Service; the Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church; four Brothers who are in charge of the Leper Home for Men; the Catholic, with Reverend Alice, a real Hawaiian lady, to look after her congregation; and our L.D.S. Church. The Elders visit us monthly, and we have a patient here who is the Presiding Elder. We have the smallest congregation but our members are very active and interested.
"The Relief Society sisters who are well enough to get out are very active. Last Sunday we held an anniversary meeting commemorating March 17. We all came dressed in white; there were 9 of us, and 12 young girls and 16 of the Priesthood. I am sure this was the most unique anniversary meeting in the Church. All but two of us are victims of the disease?myself and Sister Kalahau, a very little one, but we try to keep who is blind but who leads the group in their singing. In the group that furnished the singing there were four blind, two on crutches, and others who needed help to get around. But they sang beautifully, and bore testimony that the Lord was good, and kind, and that they were very grateful for the Relief Society organization.
"All in all, we have a little world, a very little one, but we try to keep happy, busy and helpful. We take every precaution possible. We have several people here who have been here over 40 and one 53 years, working with the patients in every way, in the hospital, dressing their wounds, bathing them, and giving (Continued on page 192) The Shape of Peace Eva Willes Wangsgaard I God of all men and nations, Light in Light, I, who am spent with fear and sorrowing, Ask for a ray to follow through this night Darkened by earthen gods to which men cling. There have been other years when I have seen Your star go down like ice from winter's bough, But never has my heart been caught between, And never was it torn as it is now. So soon we shall be called upon to stem The tides of war and plan for peace to be! That words once lifted over Bethlehem Take definite shape and purpose, we agree; But when the board of diplomats convenes, What shall our blueprint be? And what our means? II The concept of a structure strong enough To hold all men in concord that will last. To bind great powers, long inured to bluff. Into a kindred whole, is a plan so vast As to exceed the limits of the brain. This is a vision only dreamers see, A pact no sage has ever hoped to gain In any form of practicality. We have no precedent on which to build. It well may be that such a scheme may fail-So great the distance from the grandeur willed To grandeur sculptured to a working scale! The Relief Society In Church Welfare Elder Marion G. Romney Assistant to the Council of the Twelve Apostles and Assistant Managing Director General Church Welfare Committee 

"FROM the beginning, the women of the Christian Church have shown their surpassing faith and devotion. Only one apostle stood near the Cross while the Christ was crucified, but Mary, the mother, was there, and Mary Magdalene, and Mary, the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedee's children, and the women that followed Him from Galilee. It was Mary Magdalene who was first at the tomb when the Sabbath had ended, and to her Christ vouchsafed the first view to mortals of His resurrected body.
"From that time until now woman has comforted and nursed the Church. She has borne more than half the burdens, she has made more than half the sacrifices, she has suffered most of the heartaches and sorrows.
"In the modern Church hers has been the abiding, unquestioning faith, the pure knowledge that has enheartened the Priesthood and kept it going forward against all odds. Her loving trust, her loyal devotion were the faithful anchor that held when storms were fiercest." (President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Annual Conference Report, April 1940, p. 21.)
The "women of the Christian Church" include the sisters of the Relief Society, and to no group does this sublime tribute more aptly apply.
One hundred and three years ago, the Prophet "assisted in commencing the organization of the Society." In illustrating its objects, he said that the "sisters might provoke the brethren to good works, in looking to the wants of the poor, searching after objects of charity, and in administering to their wants," (Relief Society Handbook, pp. 21-22). And later in the same month he wrote that its "object is the relief of the poor, the destitute, the widow and the orphan, and for the exercise of all benevolent purposes." He was assured "that with the resources they will have at command, they will fly to the relief of the stranger; they will pour in oil and wine to the wounded heart of the distressed; they will dry up the tears of the orphan and make the widow's heart to rejoice." (D.H.C. Vol. IV, p. 567.)
To guide them in this work, the sisters were to "receive instructions through the order of the Priesthood which God has established, through the medium of those appointed to lead, guide and direct the affairs of the Church in this last dispensation." (D.H.C. Vol. IV, p. 567.)
That the bishop is included in this "order of the Priesthood" is clear from the fact that before the Relief

Society was organized, the Lord had given instructions for the care of the poor of his Church in the revelations received by the Prophet. In these revelations all the powers, functions, and responsibilities necessary for caring for the poor were given to the bishop.
"The Prophet expressed the view that for the sisters to assist in administering to the wants of the poor was one of the best means to the saving of souls, which was the ultimate aim of the Society.
"The century-old record of love-inspired service by the Relief Society is an enduring tribute to its members. Surely the Prophet spoke with prophetic accuracy when he said: 'I now turn the key in your behalf in the name of the Lord, and this Society shall rejoice, and knowledge and intelligence shall flow down from this time henceforth; this is the beginning of better days to the poor and needy, who shall be made to rejoice and pour forth blessings on your heads." (D.H.C., Vol. IV, p. 607) Since March of 1842, in every place where members of the Church have gone, and in all circumstances, the hallowed influence of these women has been actively present. Into countless homes they have gone to take food when hunger threatened; to take clothing and fuel to protect from cold; to nurse in time of illness; to prepare the dead for burial; and to comfort the aching heart. Neither the number of services engaged in nor the amount of time given in them can be set down, for no record has or could have been kept.
"Until recently, the Relief Society visiting teachers in making their monthly visits have gathered charity funds from which aid supplemental to that rendered by the bishop has been administered. In this activity the sisters have rendered a worthy service, resulting in much good and often sorely needed, for in some places there has been little searching after or administering to the poor other than what the Relief Society women have done.
"Under the impetus of the Church Welfare Plan, however, the bishops are more fully discharging the part of their bishop's calling. Into their hands is coming the production of the annual Church Welfare budget, as also increased funds from fast offerings. The Relief Society sisters are therefore relieved from the necessity of maintaining a separate charity account, but their duties toward helping the poor have increased in other ways. This is as it should be, for the Bishop and

the Relief Society president have been described as the father and the mother of the ward, and in all well-organized families the father is the provider.
"With the development of the Church Welfare Plan the Relief Society's sphere of activity in welfare work has, as stated, been extended, however, and not restricted. Relieved of the necessity for maintaining and administering an independent charity fund, the sisters are more fully devoting their time to caring for the members of the ward family. They are extending such services as caring for the sick (within the past eighteen months in a rather large city on the fringe of the Church my wife and I were confined to our hotel with illness; one person only sought us out to render aid; it was the Relief Society president); comforting the distressed and sorrowing; training the teachable to sew and cook, as also other arts of home-making; adroitly showing mothers and other homemakers how to get the most out of the means at their disposal. THE RELIEF SOCIETY IN CHURCH WELFARE 133 Thus ministering among the people with sympathetic understanding, they are winning and sacredly guarding the confidence of ward members; advising, the bishop in private, as a wise mother does her husband, of the circumstances and needs of each family and ward member; and then administering in the homes, from the substance supplied by the bishops from fast offerings and bishops' storehouses, the assistance determined upon by the bishop in consultation with the Relief Society president. Sometimes with consummate skill they properly "provoke the brethren (the bishops) to good works, in looking to the wants of the poor, searching after objects of charity, and in administering to their wants," as the Prophet Joseph said they might. Much of the foregoing work and ministration is of a confidential nature requiring special skill, and is therefore to be done under the immediate supervision of the bishop and the Relief Society president. THERE is another field of activity, however, in which every member of the Society may and most of them do participate. It is in the production of the Welfare budget. Annually, each ward undertakes to produce, in so far as it may, commodities food, clothing, and fuel  which may be needed during the coming season by members of the ward who will not be able to care for themselves. Certain surpluses to be made available to other wards are likewise produced. From the total of these surpluses, all bishops in the Church may obtain needed commodities which cannot be produced in their own localities. This is the annual Welfare budget. What the ward undertakes to produce is determined by the bishop and the ward Relief Society president, in consultation with the stake welfare committee. The budget, therefore, reaches the ward through the welfare organization from the General Church Welfare Committee, and members of the General Relief So-city Presidency are advisers to that Board. The production of the budget is a ward responsibility under the leadership of the bishop and his ward welfare committee, of which the ward Relief Society president and work director are members. In too many instances the raising of the finances for the clothing budget is improperly left to the Relief Society. This is a ward responsibility, and should be arranged for by the ward welfare committee as a whole, under the leadership of the bishop. The Relief Society should not be asked to bear this whole burden. An objective of Church Welfare is to afford opportunities for those who need or may need the commodities to produce them, in so far as they may and will. But the fact remains that the production of such items as bedding, clothing, kitchen and bathroom linen, as also the processing of meats, fruits, and vegetables, is assigned to and in large measure accomplished by the Relief Society sisters. This is a tremendous undertaking, far and away greater than could be accomplished out of the funds formerly collected by the Relief Society, and carrying succor and relief to many more needy than the funds formerly collected could provide for. The following figures will suggest the increased activity for helping the poor which has come to the Relief Society sisters participating in this service, and will suggest also the amount of that service and the numbers joining therein. Reports reveal that in 1943 alone  1944 statistics are not yet available  the Relief Society sisters made through their sewing services nearly a quarter million (244,636) articles, and that nearly three quarter million (709,494) hours were given to this service; 32,892 women per month participated; 23,114 of these articles were quilts of high quality and utility value. Not all of these items were for the Church Welfare budget, but a substantial part of them were. Canned for the bishops storehouse program, in 1943, were 1,300,000 cans of vegetables, fruits, jams, and spreads, and 33,800 cans of meat, fish, and fowl. Most of the work involved in this processing was done by members of the Relief Society. We doubt if any other women's philanthropic organization in the world can parallel this remarkable record. Sisters of the Relief Society, your unbroken record of loyal service to the objects set before you by the Prophet of the new dispensation deserves the approval of heaven and the plaudits of men. It is gratifying to know that, at the beginning of your second century, you are continuing with all the good works of the past, and that you are, at the same time, moving in to wider fields of service with renewed faith and vigor. May the Lord grant that, ministering under the power of his spirit, you may so serve the distressed of this and future generations that they may have added cause "to rejoice and pour forth blessings on your heads."

EASTER TIME Ruth H. Chadwick As the drabness of the winter Melts beneath a warmer sky. All the gentle, stirring breezes Invigorate, and cry The message of each living thing-Each blade of grass so green. Each swelling bud, each quivering tree. The urge of powers unseen. This gift of life, again renewed, A throbbing, pulsing force, Rises from its winter's sleep To beautify its source. These symbols of the springtime, Flaunt new banners of the year; Then Easter comes around to bless. And sanctify and cheer.

Are We Getting Ready for 1947 One-Hundredth Anniversary Program? The Honorable Herbert B. Maw Governor of the State of Utah Prepared by Governor Maw at the request of the Church Beautification Committee. THE State of Utah is definitely and officially in favor of a state-sponsored celebration of the hundredth anniversary of the arrival in Salt Lake Valley of the Utah pioneers. The Utah Statutes provide that "the exposition provided in connection with the centennial observance shall be officially opened on May 1, 1947, and continue to October 15, 1947." This law was passed in 1939. It followed the recommendations of a committee authorized by a joint resolution adopted by the Legislature in 1937. The Act states that its purpose is "to commemorate the advent of the pioneers into Salt Lake Valley, to portray fittingly the natural resources and scenic wonders of Utah, the prehistoric culture of the west, the development of irrigation, farming, mining, forestry, transportation, culture and the arts." The law authorizes a Centennial Commission of fifteen members, selected "without regard to political or other affiliations" who serve without compensation, to be confirmed by the State Senate and to hold office as members of a body corporate for ten years, thus continuing until the completion of the celebration and exposition, and the winding up of its affairs. The members include President David O. McKay, of Salt Lake City, as chairman; Former Governor Charles R. Mabey, J. F. Fitzpatrick, S. O. Bennion, David H. Thomas, John M. Wallace, D. M. Draper, Gus P. Backman, Donald P. Lloyd, and Postmaster L A. Smoot, all of Salt Lake City; Mrs. Rosella F. Larkin and J. A. Howell, of Ogden; F. P. Champ, of Logan; A. O. Ellett, at that time a Provo resident; and Senator Ward C. Holbrook, of Bountiful. The late Nephi L. Morris, of Salt Lake City, was a member of the Commission at the time of his death. The Commission was instructed by the Act creating it to "plan and arrange for a fitting centennial observance in the year 1947, with appropriate provision being made therefor in such communities and at such scenic, historical, cultural and recreational centers of attraction from Yellowstone Park on the north to Boulder Dam on the south and from the Salt Flats on the west to the Dinosaur Quarries on the east, as the Commission may designate, and to hold and maintain an exposition on some appropriate site to be selected by it." Page  The Centennial Commission has wide authority to proceed as its considered judgment may direct. In retrospect, this project for a new kind of World's Fair one in which the main attractions were to be some of the world's greatest wonders and some of its most attractive scenery "in place" must appear a bold one, and worthy of the sturdy independence of the pioneers who came to this desert region a century ago and here developed a new form of western culture based on irrigation, the range, and the mine. Such plans were all the more remarkable because, at the time they were forming, this State and the world at large were steeped in the most severe and most widely spread economic depression in history. Many citizens were pinching their last few pennies. Schools and other public institutions were getting along on pittances far below their needs. At such a time, it required both courage and leadership on the part of men of vision to rally support for an undertaking which would require large expenditures, one from which the returns, though perhaps certain, would be largely intangible. Then war intervened. A far-seeing National Government inaugurated an emergency defense program in 1939 and 1940. After December 7, 1941, this country was plunged into the most destructive struggle in all history. Wartime needs would not be denied. Men and women were summoned to battle. Vast projects were initiated. Labor shortages became acute. Rigid priorities were established. Today, Utah boys and girls are fighting and dying on the battle-fronts of the world to preserve that way of life for which their pioneer ancestors gave their all. We cannot and we must not let them down. Is all, then, lost? Has everything been sacrificed on Mars' bloody altar? Must we entirely forego the duty we owe to the founders of this commonwealth, to honor their courage and their self-sacrifice, to pay fitting tribute to their daring and resourcefulness? Is there no way in which we can renew the ideals for which they lived and died? Those ideals have made this State and the Intermountain Region great. They have stirred the hearts of men to battle for freedom and to love their fellow man. The men and women Utah desires to honor were not in the habit of giving up their plans because difficulties confronted. Their sons and daughters and those who followed the pioneers into this land will profit by their example, will display the same independence and leadership. Utahns will not permit the murk of war to blot out the centennial of the State's founding. Wartime conditions may restrict the extent of the celebration. They cannot obliterate the memory of the Utah pioneers, nor can they quench the ardor and enthusiasm of the celebrants. WHAT sort of celebration shall be attempted if the war with Germany and Japan is still being desperately waged in 1947? Are we prepared with an adequate program if world peace has come by that time? Or if either of the remaining Axis foes is still on his feet? The answer to these queries becomes fairly obvious. Such observance of the centennial is always possible Torius Knaphus THE HANDCART as will not require great expenditures of manpower suitable for military service or war industry work. In the meantime, plans must be formulated blueprints drawn, if you like ready to be put into action the minute manpower and materials become available should hostilities cease or slacken. It would seem basic, for example, that, in order to celebrate properly, the State must take on a holiday attire. This is something in which each resident can join. There is nothing in war's demands that requires broken down fences, filthy corrals, dilapidated outbuildings or unpainted homes. Rather do neatness and order go hand-in-hand with efficient, productive labor, and that is one of the essentials of the war effort. Let Utah, then, dress up in honor of her pioneer founders. That much groundwork for an adequate celebration certainly is possible. Other forms of observance which require little or no extra drain on the State's manpower can be encouraged. An art exhibition, an Easter pageant, a State or County Fair, any activity which has become a customary and periodic outlet for community effort can tell the story of a century during which civilization and the modern way of life were established on the unpromising and hostile desert. Let the management and sponsors of all such community events redouble their efforts to make the 1947 version far excel all its predecessors. It will prove an eloquent tribute to the greatness of the enterprise the Utah pioneers instituted. These are but suggestions for a beginning of the groundwork of the centennial program. Other and more definite features will be worked out as circumstances permit. The main idea is that this great historic occasion can and must be fittingly commemorated. The spirit of the pioneers of western irrigation is not dead. That same indomitable courage and ingenuity which enabled them to direct the harsh natural forces to man s benefit will encourage us their sons and daughters, to pay adequate tribute to our forefathers  accomplishments. THE RELIEF SOCIETY MAY 1 begin by saying that the Relief Society of the Church is far and away the greatest woman's organization in the world. It is great not alone in its aims and purposes, which are to alleviate the want, misery, and suffering of humanity; not alone in its almost earth-wide reach, for it covers the bulk of the Christian world; not alone in the achievements of its activities, though it has brought to the needy, living where it worked, food, clothing, shelter, fuel; not though it has nursed those who were sick, buried the dead of the poor, comforted those who were downhearted; not though it has sustained those who were weak in spirit, built up righteousness in the hearts of the wayward, and brought the living truth into the homes of all who give it an abiding place, to their salvation and final exaltation,  the Relief Society is greatest, not alone because of all these, but because its directing head and the great bulk of all those who make up its membership share as of right in the blessings and promises of the priesthood borne by their husbands the Holy Priesthood of God; greatest because its leaders and members have the right to the inspiration of the Lord in the carrying on of their work; greatest because in their work of now almost a century they have been richly endowed by that inspiration, they have been constantly directed by the Spirit of the Lord which has never departed from them since the Prophet brought a few (18) of the sisters together and set them about their work. These, Sisters, have been your sacred opportunities, and your glorious, Christ-like achievements. President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., Relief Society Conference Address, "Our Homes," October 3, 1940. If I can stop one heart from breaking, I shall not live in vain; If I can ease one life the aching. Or cool one pain. Or help one fainting robin Unto its nest again, I shall not live in vain.    Emily Dickinson

Easter and the Second Coming of the Lord Elder Leo J. Muir Former President Los Angeles Stake And Former President Northern States Mission (Chicago) AS thoughtful and devout Christians celebrate the coming Easter season, their minds and hearts are likely to be beckoned forward to the coming of the Master, rather than backward to his resurrection. Christ's triumphant arising from the tomb is being overshadowed by the nearness of his second coming to the earth. The early future promises to realize for mankind the prophetic salutation: "Ye men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up into heaven? this same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into heaven."
Here indeed is heaven's supreme salutatory to mortal man. This proclamation has provoked more discussion and speculation than any other word or prophecy. The unbeliever has jested about it and ridiculed it. Many people have predicted the immediate fulfillment all down the generations of time. The devout have fearfully and reverently invoked God's day for its fulfillment.
The signs of the times point to the early coming of this glorious spectacle the coming to earth of the Lord Jesus Christ in the clouds of heaven. That we might contemplate this auspicious occasion in its full significance let us review briefly the scenes in the great drama which closed with this marvelous prophecy. The events of the Passion Week are punctuated by a few sentences which stand out in bold relief against the dismal background of shame and sorrow.
Out of the peaceful, yet disturbing, ceremony of the Last Supper came the immortal injunction: "This do ye in remembrance of me." From the shadowed precincts and the deep anguish of Gethsemane came the grief-laden prayer of the Master: "O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me; nevertheless not as I will, but as thou wilt."
"And they crucified him" is the laconic account of the cruel and gruesome tragedy of Golgotha. These colorless words a conjunction, two pronouns, and a verb record the fact of the execution of the Son of God, who died that death may be no more. On death's own battlefield, Christ the Lord destroys death for the children of men.
"Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews" was the accusation written in three languages: the Hebrew, the Greek, and the Latin. The first of these is the tongue through which God had revealed his will to his prophets; the second is the language of culture and the learning of that day; and the third, the language
Page 139 of the conquering race which then held the Holy Land under subjection. This superscription, thus written, heralded to all people the alleged reason for the conviction and crucifixion of the Christ. The "Chief Priest of the Jews" protested that the accusation was not right: that it should indicate that Christ had said he was King of the Jews. Pilate stubbornly refused to alter the superscription and there it stood. It must have pleased the heart of Jesus to know that his true status as King of the Jews was so boldly proclaimed.
"Truly this was the Son of God" was the emphatic verdict of the Roman centurion who had, as an officer on guard, observed the stupid and brutal performance.
"He is risen" came as the calm and solemn assurance of the angel who answered the excited inquiry of "Mary Magdalene and the other Mary." Though calmly spoken, and to these two women alone, these angelic words reflect the triumphant climax in this eternal drama. And what triumph it was indeed; not alone for the resurrected Christ, who knew full well that he would arise, but for these faithful women and for all the disciples to whom they carried the glorious message. They restored that if Christ arose from the tomb, man also will arise from his tomb. In this fact mortal life finds its loftiest hope. No greater boon could be fashioned for the souls of men. The two women doubted not the report of the angel, but, at his bidding, hastened "with fear and great joy" to carry the glad tidings to those whom Christ affectionately called "my brethren." On the way they met the Christ,
and were requested to summon his disciples to meet him in a mountain in Galilee. Here in the uplands, against the sky, the Christ whose ministry was now given new force and power gave final instruction to those who should follow him.
"All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth. Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost: Teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you: and, lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world." In these humble, yet powerful words, the Master transmitted to his "brethren" the spiritual momentum of the resurrection. As all power was given unto him in heaven and in earth, so a measure of that power would be theirs. Possessed of that power, they were to go forth teaching all nations and bringing them into the fold of Christ. No greater task was ever given to man! But these were empowered men. Their leader had risen from the tomb. The glory and the power of the resurrected Lord motivated their deeds. The Lord's assurance "Lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world" became at once their authority and their commission. The labor and sacrifices of these men in the dark years that followed, bear indubitable evidence that they were motivated by this authority and commission. Thus the divine drama ends. The story of the mortal sojourn of the Christ is told.
NOW comes a new disclosure of eternal import. The risen Lord ascends into the heavens, as was expected. But, "while they looked steadfastly toward heaven as he went up, behold, two men stood by them in white apparel; Which also said. EASTER AND THE SECOND COMING OF THE LORD 141 Ye men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up into heaven? This same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into heaven." Thus, as one drama is ended, a new one is proclaimed. As the people in his day looked forward to his resurrection, the generations following thereafter have looked forward to his second coming. Such is our situation today. This generation of men may well witness the fulfillment of this earth-shaking prophesy. But we must be ready for it, for Christ is to come to a people prepared for him. Where is that people? Will the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints be prepared to play that role? Let us ponder for a moment those words of the Roman centurion: 'Truly this was the Son of God." Centuries before the birth of Christ, Isaiah had foretold that men should call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, "God with us." Joseph called his name Jesus. Herod, seeking to destroy the infant Christ, asked, "Where is he that is born King of the Jews?" Heaven had proclaimed him Wonderful, Counseller, The mighty God, the everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace, Jehovah, Messiah, Son of David, the Word, the Lamb of God, the Lion of the house of Judah, the Redeemer, the Brightness of the Father's glory, the God of Jacob, the Glory of his people Israel. The Master bore testimony of his own mission in this fashion: "I AM," "I am the bread of life," "I am the way of truth and the life," "I am the resurrection and the life." The Christ has been introduced by the Father in these endearing words, 'This is my beloved Son." The scriptures proclaim that the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy, and it is affirmed that the government shall be upon his shoulders and of his kingdom there shall be no end. All this was unknown to the Roman centurion, yet without this knowledge, this officer of the law deduced the profound truth, the most significant fact in the story of mortal life: "Truly this was the Son of God." Upon that question all men must take their stand. "There is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved." "Every knee must bow and every tongue confess that Jesus is the Christ." One does not need the discernment of the Roman centurion to comprehend that the power of the Lord Jesus Christ is today dominating the course of world events. He has promised that he will pour out his spirit upon all flesh. Addressing himself to the house of Israel, he has said: "Then will I sprinkle clean water upon you, and ye shall be clean: from all your filthiness, and from all your idols, will I cleanse you. A new heart also will I give you, and a new spirit will I put within you:... I will put my spirit within you, and cause you to walk in my statutes, and ye shall keep my judgments, and do them.... I will call for the corn, and will increase it, and lay no famine upon you.... Then shall ye remember your own evil ways, and your doings that were not good, and shall lothe yourselves in your own sight for your iniquities and for your abominations." Following these assurances of the cleansing of Israel and of her repentance comes this notable pronouncement: "Thus saith the Lord God; I will yet for this be inquired of by the house of Israel, to do it for them."
It would seem proper to assume that this action on the part of the house of Israel must precede the second coming of the Lord. When the house of Israel however, it may be constituted or represented makes this request of the Lord God "to do it for them," we may be assured that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints intrusted as it is and has been with the commission to gather Israel, and with the keys and authorities of the dispensation of Abraham will assume vast and definite responsibilities in this momentous work. The God of Israel. The mountain of the Lord's house has been established in the tops of the mountains, and has been exalted above the hills; and all nations have flowed unto it. So also has John gone forth in the spirit of Elias, and has turned the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just; and has thus "made ready a people prepared for the Lord."

MARCH MOODS Jeanette P. Parry March with a snowy overcoat. And ice about his chin. Is blowing up another storm Before springtime comes in. The pussywillow, wise and gay, Has donned a warm, fur coat; She smiles at teas and fashion shows Where subtle perfumes float. The snowdrop, foolish child of Spring, Stands barefoot in the storm; She thinks her filmy, short, white dress Will serve to keep her warm.
