loose_match.content: Though A Host Encamp Against Thee Dorothy Clapp Rohinson JULIA scraped the coals closer under her bakeoven. Even if she was nearly eleven, bread-making took the starch right out of her. The wood Isaac brought didn't make good coals. She was going to tell Pa well, maybe not now. Lately Pa didn't seem to love them any more than Heavenly Father did. It wasn't as if they didn't know, 'cause they did. All year the saints had talked and prayed about it, and if that wasn't enough there were her own secret prayers. No, Heavenly Father didn't have the excuse of not knowing; but Pa might not know about the chopping. At noon she had tried to tell him. "I am not leaving." He had scowled at her. "Nothing short of the United States Army will move me." Julia didn't know about the United States Army. All she knew was Johnson Army. Everybody was moving south to get away from him. Everybody, but them. Julia wasn't hankering for a move. She'd had too many of them. This place in the canyon was the only real home she could remember. But burning it and moving south would be better than the chopping. DOROTHY CLAPP ROBINSON "Brother Williams says he is following the Move so his family will be safe." For a moment Pa hadn't spoken. When he did, his voice was the way it sometimes got when they talked about Ma. "Maybe I should have taken you to your grandma; but Grantsville is a long way." He looked about the Page  room. "I snaked these logs out of the canyon. Your Ma helped me raise them. I will put my trust in the Lord and stay here." When Pa used that tone of voice there was no use going on. Trusting was all right for him. He was an old man, nearly thirty-six, and old men are not afraid. Dorcas Williams had whispered to her about the chopping. She said when Old Johnson Army got to the Valley, if he found any young'uns there, he would cut off their ears, and maybe chop off both hands and both feet. Like Squaw Bill. She'd done something and the bucks of her tribe had chopped off her hands. Now she lived with the Williamses. After banking the fire Julia went outside. At the woodpile she found a long, thick sliver. She would use it to try the bread. Sister Williams had put her on to that. No sense trusting to looks. The first time she had baked after Ma died, she had her lesson. Because the bread was brown she'd thought it was done. Spreading one of Ma's snowy dish-wipers on the hearth, she had lifted the oven to turn out the bread. Instead of coming out in loaves, the crust had broken; and dough had run all over the dishwiper. She'd scooped it back in a hurry with her bare hands, so none of it would be wasted. That had been a mess with burned hands and only slow-poke Sally to help. As Julia started toward the house with her sliver, she saw a curl of smoke far down the Valley then another. The burning had started! That meant Old Johnson Army was close. She sat down on a stump and tears trickled down her thin cheeks. Oh, Ma, why couldn't you have stayed. Pa would listen to you. President Young when he was up to see Pa said, "You're a brave girl, and don't worry, Ma is happy." Huh. Heaven must be something; or Ma had changed in a hurry. She knew Hi was only ten months old and that Sally was slow as molasses in a snowdrift. Well, maybe Old Johnson Army would kill all of them. It would be a relief, at that, to turn Sally and Isaac over to Ma. FOR supper they had bread'n'milk and Injun-meal mush. Pa got a slice of the new bread. He worked hard, and if he liked it, he might listen about the chopping. He liked it. He even said Julia would soon be as good a breadmaker as her mother; but when she tried to talk "Move" he laid down his spoon and looked at her. "I am not being chased out of my home again. Besides, when you put your trust in the Lord you leave it up to him." "We'll be alone. Everybody is go- "Some won't go. You wouldn't want to go without me, would you?" "No-o." She blinked back the tears that stung her eyeballs. The young'uns had all stopped eating to listen. "No, but there is Tommy and Baby ." Pa broke a crust of his new bread and gave it to Baby Hi, who was in the highchair by him. He put an extry spoonful of molasses on Tommy's mush. The quiet was something turrible, and Pa's hand shook sb some of the molasses spilled. At last he looked straight at Julia. He really was an old man. "I have thought about it, and THOUGH A HOST ENCAMP AGAINST THEE 145 prayed about it, and listened to counsel. I am going to stay." Just then Isaac tipped over his milk. Julia boxed his ears, but by the time she'd cleaned it up Pa was gone, saying he was going to work late at the gristmill. He took John with him. John was two years older than Julia, and worked with Pa now. Later, Julia lay staring into the darkness. She was in Pa's bed in the front room so she could watch Tommy and Baby. There was no use closing her eyes when Old Johnson Army stayed right in front of them. She raised on her elbow. By the light of the moon shining through the open doorway she could see the little ones. Baby Hi had one chubby fist under his cheek. Tommy was on his back with arms and legs outstretched. Just imagine that old sooner hurting them! She didn't care if Pa got clean out of patience with her; she was not going to see them hurt. If neither Pa nor Heavenly Father was going to do anything, she would have to. SLOWLY an idea came to her. It grew and grew. She would get Bally from the pasture. He was gentle and would carry five. She would bundle some didies and food, and they would leave before Pa got back. With them gone, Pa and John could hide. It was terrible to go again your own father, but she had a duty to the young uns. Slipping out of bed, she dressed hurriedly. As she stood a moment in the doorway, a lump swelled in her throat. Something just like one of Ma's arms held her tight to the place. The moon was high. The mountains had moved close and the run-along song of the crick was enough to wake the dead. Warm chills ran up her back. After the heat and dust of the plains it was like well, like having Ma after not having her. Leaving the yard, she walked toward the pasture where they kept Bally. The gristmill stood out like a ghost. It was made of logs, like the house. Until lately, both had seemed so safe and strong. Especially after the plains. She couldn't remember Nauvoo much, and about all she could remember of Winter Quarters was tents and wagons. She could remember how cold the Platte River was for she had fallen into it. She could remember an Injun trying to buy her, and she could remember Jim Bridger's squaws. Leastways she could remember their bright blankets. But her best remembering was of heat and dust, and how tired her legs got gathering buffalo chips. She had never rightly understood about the moving. Everyone said, have faith, the Lord will give us a home, but that hadn't stopped the wagons. Until they reached the Valley, it hadn't. No one had kept up with the moving more willingly than the Phippens. She didn't blame Pa for not wanting to start that again. Still-. Bally wasn't in the pasture. Just her luck to have Pa using him. She'd sneak up. If the mill was running, she might get him away without being heard. There was no light in the mill. The big door was open but there was no sign of Pa or John. The inside dark was so quiet she could hear a rat gnawing. What if they had skipped? For shame, Julia Phippen. Pa'd never do that in Kingdom Come. You thought that 'cause you are doing it to him. But she was taking the young'uns to safety. A sound from the hillside made her turn. She waited breathlessly until it came again. It was Bally sneezing. Now what was he doing up there? Slipping from shadow to shadow she approached a small grove on a near slope. Within the grove was a small cave where the young'uns often played. Among the trees the light was dim, and, for a moment, she could see nothing. Then she saw them. They must have been using him, for Bally was tied to a quaker. Pa and John were piling brush and dead branches over the mouth of the cave, but helter-skelter to make it look natural. 'Think anyone will find it?" she heard John ask. "Never," Pa answered. "We can move it after the trouble is over." Julia forgot Bally. She forgot why she had come. She remembered only that here was more trouble, and different than she had dreamed of. Now she couldn't run out on Pa no matter what he had done. Back in bed she tried to smother her hard breathing. Directly she heard them come in. Baby Hi fussed a little as Pa lay down beside him, but almost at once Pa was snoring. Then Julia looked at her thoughts. They had buried something. It must be turrible or they wouldn't make a secret of it. Maybe they had killed an Injun, or maybe even Old Johnson Army. Maybe he had come sneaking around to do the chopping and they had beat him to it. Pa was in Dutch either way. If it was Johnson Army, the Gove'-ment  she didn't know what that was but everyone talked about it-would be on his trail. If it was an Injun her heart beat suffocatingly. You can't fool Injuns for long. Besides, Pa might be called before the Brethren. He might even be in danger of hell-fire. The scriptures said something about shedding innocent blood. She hoped Injun blood wasn't too innocent, but who had the say-so? Every way she looked there was a thick black wall. She just had to have help. She'd try Heavenly Father again. Ma had been strong on prayer. Slipping out of bed she knelt down and put her face against the bedding. Protect them all, especially Pa and John, and if it had to be a killing they'd done, let it be Johnson Army. Some good would come of that, but killing an Injun would be all bad. Let Pa lose his stubborn streak and light out, come daybreak. Maybe they could still catch up with the others. Suddenly, she realized she was talking more to Ma than to Heavenly Father. Likely he would overlook it, seeing she was one of his newest angels. JULIA woke, heavy with dread, but the morning was so bright she could almost believe she dreamed about the cave. If her prayer was to be answered, now was the time. Pa was stirring the mush when she entered the kitchen. She hastened to wipe off the table and set out the dishes. All the time she listened for the word from Pa, but it didn't come. Her mush stuck in her throat. Maybe Heavenly Father THOUGH A HOST ENCAMP AGAINST THEE 147 hadn't liked the way she prayed after all. She hadn't said thy will 'cause she wanted her will this time. Three times she caught Pa looking at her. He told her again what a good bake she got on the bread. He warned Isaac and Sally he'd tend to them if they didn't help more. As he was leaving, he took his gun. "Keep no bring the young'uns up to the mill when your work is done. They can play around up there." Julia made herself real busy so she wouldn't look at him. Her last hope was gone. A heavy ache inside made her feet big and her hands slow. Pa pretended to be working hard, but he stopped every little while to stand looking. Most often his eyes turned toward the canyon where lay the road into the Valley. He kept his gun close beside him. The sun hadn't found the bottom of the canyon yet when a rider came pounding up to the yard of the mill. It was Jim Ashley, and Pa came out to talk to him.  This is your last chance" Julia heard Jim say. "Tomorrow will be too late. What's a mill anyway?" "The saints will need flour wherever they are." Pa spoke real slow but every word stood out. "Mills don't grow on trees. I am staying with mine." Julia was right proud of him for a minute; but if Brother Ashley couldn't budge him, no one could. The best she could do was keep the young'uns close around. What happened to one would happen to all. About noon Lafe Cartright came by. He had been left to do the burning if it came to that. Some, he said, had got in a hurry and done the burning themselves. Pa agreed that was foolish. "Well, it will soon be over," Lafe called, as he rode away. Julia was past all feeling. If the worst, was to come, it would, only she hadn't thought God would be one-sided. She had tried to be good; as good as Dorcas, but the Williamses were safe. 'Course she couldn't put all the blame on Heavenly Father, but if he could move mountains why couldn't he change Pa's mind? As soon as Lafe was out of sight, Julia moved Baby Hi close by the mill steps. She called Tommy to come play on the blanket with him. She tried to mend, but the patch kept puckering. Finally she threw it aside. The minutes were endless. Suddenly, John let go with a loud yell from the roof of the mill where Pa had stationed him. "Here they come." Quicker than skat Pa shinned up the corner of the mill and was looking to where John pointed. Isaac and Sally climbed the big tree that hung over the crick. "I can see them," Isaac shouted, and Sally added her, "I can, too." Julia started to climb the mill, but halfway up she turned back. The mill roof was too far away. She stood on a stump near the babies. She looked where the others were looking, and, suddenly, she saw a thousand or maybe even a million points of light, like the sun hitting guns. "What is it?" she called, eager to share what the others were seeing. "The Army," Pa was breathing hard like he had been running. "Johnson's Army. Caught up with us at last." "I can't see good," Sally cried. Trying to move, she slipped and fell into the water with a yell and a splash. By the time they had pulled her out and changed her clothes and rubbed arnica on her bruises, the Army was gone. Pa went back up and locked the mill, and then he helped lay out an early supper. He even got a jar of Ma's sarvis-berry jelly. Three times in the night, Julia heard him walking around. LATE evening of the next day, Jim Ashley came back. Pa hadn't been at the mill all day, and it seemed he couldn't wait for Jim to get there. He went a piece to meet him. When he came back he sat down on the doorstep. He looked so happy Julia sat down beside him. The young'uns, except John, were in bed; and darkness filled all the hollows. "What did Jim say?" she asked finally. "It's over." Pa's voice sounded as young as John's only it didn't squeak. 'The Lord was with, us even as I doubted." Julia looked at him in surprise. "Were you afraid?" "I was scared stiff." "What's Johnson's Army, Pa, and why did the saints have to move?" "We thought we were in for trouble again. We thought the soldiers would take our homes and we were not going to let that happen again. We would burn them first. That is why men were left to set fires." The gid looked around at the mountains in the back, with the moon just peeping over the rim. She looked at the lake in the distance, and the sloping Valley between. It was wonderful to have a home that was safe and strong and a Pa that was scared but stayed anyway. She could talk to him now. Words tripped over her tongue trying to get said. She told about the chopping and how she thought Johnson Army was a cruel giant. She even owned up to her feelings against him and Heavenly Father. Pa listened without saying a word. It was bright moonlight now, and she could see slow tears run down into his whiskers. He drew her close against him. "Poor little young'un," he said, "I have been so wrapped up in my own worries I have overlooked yours. I have expected too much of you, but it seems like you are my right hand." Julia hardly breathed. She didn't want to spoil the sweetness of that moment, but she must know one thing more. "What about the Injun, Pa?" "What Injun?" his voice was puzzled. "The one you buried in the cave." Slowly Pa's eyes came alive. He started to laugh, quietly at first, then lively. She hadn't heard such fun in his voice since before Ma took sick. "The Injun we buried was flour. That is why Brother Young was up to see me. We thought we might lose the mill but we couldn't take chances on the flour." Through the soft light she could see the trust in his eyes. "We were wrong, both of us. We forgot there are many ways for prayers to be answered. His way was much better than yours or THOUGH A HOST ENCAMP AGAINST THEE 149 mine. The Army has gone on down to the Jordan. There isn't going to be any trouble." Suddenly the breadmaking, the care of the young'uns were mere trifles. Heavenly Father had remembered them. A verse Ma used to read came to her mind. "Some put their trust in chariots; and some in horses: but we will remember the name of the Lord, our God." Yes. She would always remember. Dorothy Clapp Robinson, third prize winner in the Relief Society Short Story Contest for 1944, is well known to Magazine readers through her excellent contributions to this publication. Mrs. Robinson is a gifted writer of prose, poetry, and fiction. The continued story "Forward Without Fear" which was concluded in the February 1945 issue of the Magazine is her work, She is a contributor to other Church periodicals as well, and she frequently markets her work with national publications of recognized merit. She has been active with writers' groups whose purpose is to stimulate creative writing, improve writing techniques, and acquaint writers with markets for their work. At present, she is president of the Idaho Writers' League. Mrs. Robinson appreciates the efforts of fellow writers and aids and encourages them in writing through intelligent analysis of their work. She is a capable teacher and a devoted Latter-day Saint. She is now serving as counselor in charge of education on the Boise Stake Relief Society Board.

TO A LOST FLYER Bessie Jaivis Payne In memory of Captain Lee Jarvis Hailing Killed in action May 5, 1944 Dedicated to his mother Rose Jarvis Hailing Wings approaching in the sky, Slowing as they pass me by. Dipping now in brief goodbye  O'er this home. Wings against the azure deep, Eager flight into the street. Straining eyes that must not weep  Till peace is won. Wings upon the sun-splashed hills Casting shadows o'er the rills. Soaring high, as my heart thrills  Then you're gone. Wings above the ocean's foam Winging far from friends and home. Must you never cease to roam  Dearest one? Broken wings in downward sweep, Swiftly be the fate you meet. Rest now in eternal sleep  Oh, my son.

entries.title: The Story of a Gifted Lady
entries.author: Leah D. Widtsoe

loose_match.content: The Story of a Gifted Lady Leah D. Widtsoe ALICE MERRILL HORNE HE was an unlearned, ordinary looking farmer's lad, who had spent his days at farm drudgery, for his parents were struggling to make the farm produce a scanty living for their growing family. But within him dwelt the power to see beauty in the glowing sunsets, the bright tints of autumn, and the glorious light effects on the mountains, clouds, and valleys wherever he worked. Even the good earth talked to him as he turned the brown fur-Page 150 rows for spring planting. He also possessed the gift of putting on paper or canvas or anything on which he could lay his hands, the pictures which crowded through his mind. So, instead of spending his scanty earnings on new clothes, or guns and powder, with which to kill God's innocent creatures, he bought paper, crayons, paints, and oils, and transferred the pictures of his mind to paper or canvas, until his home was crowded with the results of his leisure efforts. At first his mother encouraged him, but later began to feel that he should be spending his time on something more profitable. Then one day, through a lucky chance, he met A Fairy Godmother She took the time to visit his home, recognized his gift, and told him that he should cultivate it. When told how impossible that would be financially, she volunteered to sell his pictures, thereby helping him to raise money with which to attend a great art school in the East. Then this dainty, but indomitable, art patron went to a number of the well-to-do people in the city, told them the story of the gifted farmer's lad, and soon had sold enough of his pictures to enable him to achieve the ambition of his life. This good lady has rendered similar service for many of Utah's gifted sons and daughters. She has been, and still is, a real fairy godmother THE STORY OF A GIFTED LADY 151 to them, and through her encouragement has taken a leading role in making Utah art conscious. Wouldn't you like to know more about her? Her life story begins in the days when the pioneers were called to settle remote parts of the (then) Territory, and it bristles with tales of Indian unrest as well as the romance of state-building. It is as exciting and interesting as any which begins with the intriguing Once Upon A Time Once in a very great while, an especially gifted spirit is sent to earth to take a body and become a blessing to many people and the state, as well as to family and friends. Such a precious spirit came to the frontier log cabin home of Clarence Merrill and Bathsheba Smith, who were each descended from stalwart Utah pioneers. The father was called by Brigham Young to learn telegraphy, and then to settle first at Cove Creek Fort, that outpost of Indian activity, and later to take care of telegraph operations at Fillmore, which was then the capital of Utah Territory. There a baby daughter was born to them, and was named Alice Smith Merrill. She grew to be a lovely child, who was later to honor highly the name and the lineage she bears. Two of her great-grandparents. Patriarch John Smith and his wife Clarissa Loomis Lyman, were pioneers of 1847, and all four of her grandparents were early pioneers also. Her grandfather, George A. Smith, was both Church historian and first counselor to President Brigham Young, while her grandmother, Bathsheba W. Smith, was the fourth general president of the Relief Society. Two of her great-grandparents passed away before reaching the "Valley." Thus Alice is a true daughter of pioneers, and the fourth generation of believers in the restored gospel of Jesus Christ. The girlhood of this favored child was passed in the ideal environment of a fine, two-story brick home (evolved from the log cabin) located in a quarter block of garden and orchard, in company with a large family of brothers and sisters to help make life a round of merriment as well as of struggle. There were vegetables and fruits to be gathered in summer, wild strawberries and native black currants, choke cherries, and service berries to be brought from the canyons; fruit to be canned and dried in autumn; with quilt blocks to make and rags to be sewed for carpets during the long winter hours when school was out. These chores were varied with pleasurable activities, for her parents were leaders in the Fillmore Dramatic Society, as well as being gifted with musical talents. Around the family hearthstone the family often re-enacted stirring scenes from history or from Shakespeare, each dressing, as best he could, in character. The mother always had a lovely flower garden, and Alice early learned to appreciate the beauties of mountains, streams, blue skies, and cloud effects, as well as the glories of summer gardens and winter scenes of snowy grandeur. In fact, the love of beauty seemed to be a part of her very being, for she sought it in the everyday tasks as well as in her moments of leisure. She loved to draw, and early showed aptitude in transferring to paper the images of her mind. She was a good student also, for when but a child she took a prize in the old rock schoolhouse as the best reader. Then when but eight years old came her Great Adventure After the passing of her grandfather, George A. Smith, her grandmother ("Aunt Bathsheba" to all the other daughters of Zion) was living alone, and lonely. So she invited her granddaughter, Alice, to come to "the city" and live with her in the old Historian's Office, next to the magnificent Gardo House, which was then the official residence of the president of the Church. What a rare experience for this beauty-loving child! Here she helped her grandmother read and sort old letters, classified the hundreds of pictures her grandfather had brought from his trips to Europe and the Holy Land, met and learned to know all the great men and women of early Mormon history, who were intimate friends of her grandmother. From a child to young womanhood, she became associated with the early development of the Relief Society in the new Zion; also the Retrenchment Society, as well as the suffrage movement for Women's Rights, so-called. Meetings for these activities, as well as those of the Women's Deseret Hospital, Woman's Exponent (the pioneer women's newspaper), and many others of pioneer interest, were all conducted in her grandmother's back parlor. Alice was an ardent listener and youthful participant. It is no wonder that she became "organization-minded." When but nine years old she felt to organize the young girls into a society, which they called "The Juvenile Association." She chose six counsellors  instead of two among them the youngest daughter of Brigham Young, Fanny V., Katie B. Fen ton, Lutie Y. Thatcher, Lulu Clawson, Ada Croxall, Edna Wells, with Daisy Woods, a granddaughter of Emme-line B. Wells, as secretary. They visited and prayed for the sick, and later joined, in a body, the first organized Primary Association. Meanwhile, Alice was using her pencil and sketch book as well as attending school. While in Miss Mary Cook's school, she won the prize for the best drawing a sketch from memory given by Dr. Ellen B. Ferguson. Later, she won an award given by the early Utah artist and teacher at the University of Deseret  now the University of Utah-George M. Ottinger. Still later, she won a medal offered by the artist J. T. Harwood, which was awarded by John Hafen, one of Utah's greatest artists. This was naturally a stimulus to her innate desire to produce pictures herself, and to foster in others the love of art, to which her life has been devoted. But art did not claim all her interest. In 1887, she was graduated from the University of Utah. She wrote her thesis on two of Shakespeare's women  Lady Macbeth and Ophelia. Her interest in good literature has always been keen. In 1890, Alice married George Henry Home, also a descendant of stalwart pioneers. He was an ideal husband for this talented woman, for besides being a fine man Jn his own right, he was openminded enough to recognize the

gifts of his talented wife and to encourage her THE STORY OF A GIFTED LADY 153 to use them. It takes a big man to do that. In 1893, they visited the Columbian Exposition in Chicago, and later went to New York, Washington, Boston, San Francisco, and the Northwest, visiting especially the art galleries and other places of interest. In 1894, the young husband was called on a mission to the Southern States. Alice, being a good soldier, taught art in the public schools while he was gone. She also undertook serious work in art from J. T. Harwood, who had just returned from study in the Julian and Beaux Arts Academies of Paris, France. She also studied from Mary Teasdel, student of James McNeill Whistler. In 1898, she was urged by many friends to run for the legislature. In this, as in her many other activities, her husband counselled her acceptance. Said he, "Wifey," (his pet name for her) "if you want to help Utah to become art-minded, you will have to get in there and work for it." She was elected, and made herself noteworthy by introducing a bill which provided for an annual exhibition and state art collection. Georgina G. Marriott as director of fine arts at the State Fair put the exhibition into Alice's hands, and for five years she made the Art Gallery famous. Instead of giving many prizes, the best pictures were purchased, making them the property of the State as well as encouraging the artists. This greatly encouraged art studies and Utah artists also, establishing the nucleus of an art collection by the State of Utah, which was named in honor of the originator, "The Alice Art Collection.  ALICE MERRILL HORNE AS A GIRL Thus the Utah Art Institute was established, making Utah the first state in the Union to own a state art collection. Many prominent people made gifts of paintings, and this collection of over seventy pictures is now housed in the upper galleries of the State Capitol. After an existence of over forty years and an expenditure of over $60,000, the act was repealed in the interest of the so-called "Modern Art" (or is it art?) which at great expense is trying to convert the public to what is considered the New Art. Mrs. Home has remained true to her ideals of real beauty, however, and has turned much of her interest to sponsoring and providing art exhibitions for the public schools of the State. She has established over thirty art collections, of from fifteen to fifty paintings, by Utah's best artists. Hundreds of exhibitions have been held, and many thousands of dollars have thus been turned to Utah artists aside from the greater value of instilling a love of beauty and art in the lives of the younger generation. For fourteen years from 1902 to 1916 Mrs. Home was a member of the Relief Society General Board, and while there was active in preparing lessons on art appreciation and landscape study, which were used by the 40,000 members of the Relief Society. A book on this subject "Devotees and Their Shrines, A Handbook of Art" was later published. Another book written in dramatic form called "Columbus Westward Ho!" was published and used in the public schools for a time. Many other interests claimed her attention during all these years of active service. She is a charter member of the Daughters of the Utah Pioneers, and was instrumental in framing its constitution and bylaws; she was also its second general president. She sponsored a "Clean Milk for Utah" campaign, and as chairman of Public Health helped, with others, to arouse enough public sentiment to cause rigid inspection to be enforced for the benefit of all, especially babies. Four milk stations were opened in different parts of the city. Many babies died in Salt Lake City among them her own baby son, George Henry, Jr.  while the next summer only one baby death was reported! Mrs. Home was also active, with others, in organizing the Smokeless Fuel Federation, and for many years has labored to encourage the use of smokeless fuel and byproducts from Utah coals. She, with other forward-looking women, was instrumental in the formation of the Women's Chamber of Commerce, which has labored to make smokeless fuel a possibility for improving the health of Utah residents and the beauty of her towns and cities. Honors Have Sought Her For her many activities, Mrs. Home has rightly received merited recognition. In 1904, she represented the National Council of Women, as well as the National Women's Relief Society, at the International Council of Women, held in Berlin, Germany. In 1934, she was chosen by the Salt Lake City Council of Women as one of the first outstanding women, named by that body, for her many contributions and life-long promotion of art among the citizens of the State. Her latest honor was received in 1942, when she was given a Medal of Honor from the Academy of Western Culture for her civic service, especially in the promotion of Utah art appreciation and production. A large reception was held in the President's Suite at the Hotel Utah, with Mr. And Mrs. Alexander Schreiner, and Mr. And Mrs. Lee Greene Richards in charge of the ceremonies. Many prominent Utahns came to meet the little lady so greatly honored. All these awards have been richly deserved, and have done honor to the donors as well as to the recipient. One might think that a life so crowded with achievement would be enough for one small lady, but there remains yet to be told Her Great Achievement' In addition to the many activities enumerated above, her greatest hon- THE STORY OF A GIFTED LADY 155 or and award is the gift of Motherhood. Six children three sons and three daughters have come to bless the home of this favored family. Five of them have grown to a useful maturity Mary, Lyman, Virginia, Zora,' and Albert. They are all members of the Church and are leaders in their fields of labor. Two of them, Dr. Lyman and Dr. Albert, are successful doctors of medicine, while the two married daughters-Mary, Mrs. Leo C. Winder, and Zora, Mrs. J. G. Jeppson are making good homes and raising fine families. They are all active in civic betterment. Mr. Home met an untimely death in 1934, mother has continued to carry on her home duties as well as her many public activities. Alice has always had a sweet, attractive face; but to those who know her best, it seems that the halo of white hair frames a face growing more mellow and charming with the passing years. Though now approaching what some may designate as 'getting on in years," she still seems as young as ever, and is active in staging art exhibits in the Tea Room or a nine-window art show at Zion's Co-operative Mercantile Institution, or some school where art-appreciation is needed. When one sees her "toting" around the heavy pictures, placing them where they receive their best light, or may be seen to the best advantage (so that possible sales may reward the artist), one feels to exclaim, "What a Woman!" How wise to foster a life interest which may remain when children are grown and home ties are lessened! How much better it is to have work to do that helps others more than oneself, rather than to sit idly at home, allowing or expecting one's children to "take care of one's old age." What a glorious thing is independence! Wliat an achievement to know that one's life work is being well done, in spite of circumstances or the passing years. Such a blessing is the well-earned reward of our gifted lady, Alice Merrill Home. And here, dear friend, while you are living and working, is our bouquet of appreciation and admiration! GIFTS Grace A. Cooper When gods of sound and goddesses of color send Down gifts to man, their gems and blooms and music blend; Like silence, drugged, the pearl-gray fog escapes the bay, Soft murmurs from the golden glow of summer day Join whispered converse of the leaves of verd and jade; Late roses echo reds of rubies' deeper shade. When beryls raise their batons, all is statue-still, Then amethysts and violets, in cadence, trill; Turquoise and larkspur improvise a symphony, The diamond and jasmine play their melody. Between the black and darkened clouds are silver rifts  For gods and goddesses, to mankind, blend their gifts. Sixtii LJears Kjigo Excerpts from the Woman's Exponents, March i and March 15, 1885 "For the Rights of the Women of Zion and the Rights of the Women of All Nations" Love. This is a little word of only four letters, yet how potent, how powerful, and with it comes our liberty or bondage. If we love right, we are free; free in our souls, pure in our hearts, let come what may, though oft through surrounding circumstances and worldly influence we are swerved from the right, not having the moral courage to resist evil, or know for ourselves the sad results of weakness and hatred until too late.... Where can we find pure love? In the homes of the Latter-day Saints; there it sits enthroned. If sorrow and death visit such a household there is comfort and relief at hand.... Our principles are perfect, and we will continue to love them and strive to live them, God being our helper; protect the rights of others, envy no one, be pure in our daily walk in life and leave the result in God's hands. Zina D. H. Young. Editorial Notes: On Saturday, March yth, a number of ladies, intimate friends of Mrs. Rachel R. Grant, met at her residence in the 13th Ward, it being the anniversary of the lady's birthday. The time was spent in social converse, supper being announced at six p.m., when the guests repaired to the residence of Apostle H. J. Grant, where a sumptuous repast had been prepared for the occasion. The table was handsomely set out, and the viands were delicious. Mrs. Lucy Grant, the amiable hostess, and her sister, Mrs. JuHa Woolley, with Miss Maggie Ivins assisting, waited upon the ladies in the most charming manner, and every one seemed to thoroughly enjoy themselves. About ten o'clock the party broke up. Many good wishes were expressed for the lady who is a great favorite with her friends. May she live to enjoy many more years of prosperity and happiness.  R.S. REPORTS Alma Ward, Mesa City. Editor Exponent: Owing to our isolated situation we see but few communications from this part of the country in your valuable paper, hence the liberty I take in penning a few lines to you, hoping you will be kind enough to give them space in your paper. We were organized May 31st, 1883, under the direction of President McDonald, with Anna Klienman, President; Henrietta Standage and Laureta Staples, Counselors; Sarah M. Mullens, Secretary; Sophronia A. Standage, Assistant Secretary; Hannah M. Stewart, Treasurer. We have thirty-five names enrolled, with an average attendance of nineteen. We hold our meetings semi-monthly, and have a very good time. The sisters are trying to live their religion and serve God. The Exponent is read in our meetings, with other Church works, striving to render them a source of benefit and mutual improvement. Wishing f Jr the success of the Exponent, I remain, Your sister in the Gospel, S. A. S. Bluff City. Editor Exponent: Thinking that a few lines from Bluff City would not come amiss, we take pleasure in writing that our Relief Society is trying to keep along evenly with the rest of the branches of the Relief Society as near as possible under the circumstances, with a good spirit and feeling at heart. We hold our testimony and teacher's meetings once a month, and our working meetings once in two weeks. We are few in number, but our meetings are well attended and our desire is to do all the good we can in helping to build up the Kingdom of God in this far off land.... We have had a very pleasant winter and the health of the people is very good. There has been no sickness nor death, for which we feel very thankful, and realize as a great blessing. Ever praying for the welfare of Zion, we remain, Your sisters in the Gospel, Jane M. Walton, President; Irene Haskell, Secretary.

Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon FOR the first time in the history of Utah, or of any other state in our country so far as can be learned, a woman has been selected as legislative chaplain in the person of Dr. Maud May Babcock who occupies that position in the Utah State Senate. Years ago, President Brigham Young's daughter, Susa, attended a class in voice building at Harvard University, taught by Miss Babcock. The pupil did not rest until Miss Babcock was in the employ of the University of Utah, where she built up one of the best known speech departments in the country, serving for fifty-two years, longer than any other faculty member. She became a convert to the Church, was the first president of the Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association in the Eighteenth Ward, and introduced the study of literature into the Mutual program.
FIVE women have been elected to the Utah House of Representatives: Mrs. C. L. Jack, Mrs. J. B. Bearnson, Mrs. Clara L. Jarvis, Mrs. Della L. Loveridge, and Miss Frances B. Smith. Mrs. E. E. Erickson is the only woman senator. She outranks any other Utah woman in length of legislative service. Singularly honored this year with the chairmanship of the important educational committee, she is also a member of the committee on appropriations, on state and municipal
affairs, on public institutions, social relations, and relief.
MISS ERIKA MANN, daughter of the great novelist, Thomas Mann, who exiled herself from Germany and became an American citizen, recently spent seven months in the occupied countries and on the first-line battle fronts of Europe. In Salt Lake City, she gave an account of her experiences, with comments on allied policies, and suggestions for attitudes in postwar problems.
AMIDST the beauty of her native land, one of the most spiritual and beloved Hawaiian Latter-day Saints, Mrs. Lilia Wahapia Kaneihalau, passed away in November. In another forty-five days she would have been 120 years old. For ninety-one years she had been a member of the Church, and served for thirty-three years as president of the Relief Society,

released in 1926 at her own request due to her age.
FRANCE has a woman mayor for the first time in history. She presides over Thann, one of the liberated towns in Alsace.
HENRY WISE MILLER, husband of the late Alice Duer Miller, author of The White Cliffs of Dover and many other beautiful poems, has written a book on the life and works of his wife. Page 157 

VOL. 32 MARCH 1945 NO. 3

Gratitude For Church Guidance ONE hundred and three years will have passed this March seventeenth since the first auxiliary of the Church, the Relief Society, was established for the benefit of its members and for the good of others. In that year, 1842, the Church had risen triumphant through its first twelve momentous years. It had been driven from New York to Ohio, from Missouri to Illinois, and already the necessary laws and powers for the coming forth and future progress of the Church had been revealed and confirmed. It was during that all-too-brief period of calm between the lashing storms of persecution, while the Church lay, as it were, at safe anchorage on the broad blue waters of the Mississippi at Nauvoo, that a few of the Church women gave utterance to their longing to be formed into an organization so that their united efforts might more speedily and effectually accomplish tasks allotted to them. It is significant that these women did not themselves inaugurate a society, but turned to their Prophet-leader for guidance. At a time and place set by him, he organized them, and under his continued tutelage thus was instituted the Relief Society which grew in one hundred years from a membership of eighteen to over one hundred thousand. The broad basic principles which Page 158 have always governed the Society were laid by the Prophet Joseph Smith; however the planning and putting into execution of these policies have always been entrusted to the officers and members of the Society, who fully merited the confidence thus reposed in them, manifesting a devotion to duty, throughout the years, which has resulted in an immeasurable amount of labor, of loving service, and of enlightenment. Relief Society is obedient to the leadership of Church authorities today as it was one hundred years ago, and stands ready to accept and support new policies as they are deemed desirable. So guided and so conducted, the advancing years will find the Society growing ever more powerful, more potent in building testimonies of the gospel in members, more fully fulfilling its high destiny. On this one hundred and third anniversary, Relief Society members acknowledge the gratitude of their hearts for the guidance of the general and local authorities, for their zealous, watchful care to the end that the services rendered by Relief Society women are being extended in everwidening spheres to keep pace with the accelerated need for such services in the expansion and progression of the Church. M. C. S. EDITORIAL 159 Sarah Eddington?Ida Peterson Beal EARLY in the New Year, two faithful and devoted former members of the General Board of Relief Society passed to the great beyond, in the persons of Sarah Eddington and Ida Peterson Beal. The death of Sister Eddington occurred on January 9, and that of Sister Beal on January 6. In many respects the lives of these two good sisters were similar. They were both daughters of early Utah pioneers, were reared in families where faith and devotion to the gospel were paramount, and their testimonies of the mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith and the restored gospel were fervent and strong. Miss Eddington was born June 13, 1861 in Salt Lake City. She was the daughter of William and Sarah Fry Eddington, English converts. From her childhood days she was active in the Church in many capacities. She served as a valued member of the General Board of Relief Society for seven years ?from March 1914 to April 1921. Previous to this she was a member of the General Board of the Y. W. M. LA. For twenty-five years. She was an untiring worker, always willing to do more than her share. She was an efficient committee member and travelled extensively for both the Relief Society and the Y. W. M. IA. Although she was rather frail and delicate physically, she used to say, "Send me on the long, hard trips; I have no home to take care of, no husband, and no children. I am free and my chief interest in life is the Church and its progress." Sister Eddington was especially gifted as a public speaker. She was both eloquent and impressive, and was always able to hold her audience whether it was made up of children, young people, or those of mature years. IDA PETERSON BEAL was born in Ephraim, Sanpete County, Utah, on February 7, 1876, the daughter of President Canute Peterson and Chariotte Eckstrom Peterson. Her Church interests and activities began early and continued throughout her life in the various auxiliary organizations of the Church. She was appointed to the General Board of Relief Society in August 1927, where she served faithfully and efficiently for thirteen years. Sister Beal received her education in the schools of her native town, at the Snow Academy, and at the Brig-ham Young University. In the last named institution she majored in music under the tutelage of Professor A. C. Lund, and became one of his star pupils and one of the sweetest singers in Zion. She took the leading role in the first opera produced by Brigham Young University. Sister Beal had many opportunities for study and travel, and she made the most of them. She accompanied her husband, Dean T. A. Beal of the University of Utah, to 
New York where, for three years, he studied at Columbia University. She later accompanied him to Europe where, for one year, they both took advantage of educational and cultural opportunities there. Probably Sister Berit's greatest contribution to the General Board was as chairman of the music committee in which capacity she directed the annual
organization, and was instrumental in developing the great central chorus of Singing Mothers. However, she travelled extensively to stake Night Society conferences where her lovely spirit and sweet personality won friends and supporters to the great Relief Society cause.
A.B.L.

PRAYING HANDS Clarence Edwin Flynn On broad, green fields are many hands that labor, Turning to sun and rain the fresh, sweet soil. Wielders of hammer, pen, and loom, and saber. Alike must live upon their daily toil. Under the summer sun they do their duty, Loosing the ground that roots and stalks may grow, Coaxing to richness and productive beauty The waving ear and tassel, row on row. Comes a bright day when autumn's sun is slanting Its mellow rays across the golden grain. They gather then the harvest of their planting. Grateful that they have labored not in vain. All these are praying hands. An old petition Their labor makes?one that has long been said By those of every country and condition: "Give us, we ask, this day, our daily bread." Notes TO THE FIELD Materials for the 1945 Welfare Clothing Budget THE following information regarding materials for the 1945 welfare clothing budget has been received by the General Board from the General Church Welfare Committee: In the fall of 1944 the Clothing Committee submitted a report to the General Welfare Committee which covered the materials that would be needed for the 1945 welfare clothing budget assignment. At that time, information which had previously been supplied by government officials in Washington indicated that it was probable that the materials for this clothing assignment would be made available to the Welfare Program. In the latter part of December the situation changed and it then became apparent that most of the materials, which we proposed to use, were still critically needed in the war effort. It has, therefore, been decided that while present conditions exist, it will not be advisable to file for priorities. The clothing program will proceed as materials become available to which we are properly entitled on a quota basis. The most recent information from the wholesale houses with which the General Committee has heretofore done business is that there is no immediate prospect of securing the clothing materials in the quantities that are required to fill the 1945 budget assignment. It is the plan of the General Committee to keep in close touch with the market and take advantage of the full quota of materials as they become available. This means that it will not be possible for the General Committee to supply the materials needed so that the budget can be completed during the first six months of this year as many of the Relief Society sisters desire. It is hoped, however, that materials will be available so that the budget can be completed by the end of 1945. As materials are received, they will be allocated in a fair manner to those to whom the budgets have been assigned. The question has arisen as to whethei stake or ward welfare committees shall be encouraged to purchase materials from lo cal sources to complete their clothing assignments. If materials can be purchased at wholesale prices without working a hardship on the community, it will be proper for the stake and ward welfare committees to purchase such materials and advise the General Committee so that the General Committee will not overpurchase later on. However, if it is necessary to go into the retail markets and pay retail prices and take from the shelves of local merchants materials that are needed to meet the general needs of the local community, such purchases should not be made. Where quilting is done, the General Committee can supply the batts needed from stocks now on hand. During the time that materials for welfare sewing are not available, the General Board recommends that Relief Society women devote themselves to other sewing activities on the
work meeting day. Page 161
