Marshalling Our Forces for Home Safety Nellie O. Parker Member of Relief Society General Board Chairman Home Division, Utah Safety Council WHILE the best of the country's young manhood are giving their lives that we here at home may be safe and free, the accident casualties every year in our homes are more than 35,000 killed and 120,000 permanently injured, to no purpose and without good reason.
More than half of all accidents occur in and around the homes, and the greatest percentage of the victims are children under five and elderly people over sixty-five years of age. They are victims of ignorance, of carelessness, recklessness or neglect. Accidents do not happen, they are caused by some unsafe practice or condition.
The first National Home Farm Safety Conference was held in Chicago, February 17-18, 1942, to focus attention on the seriousness of the nation's home and farm accident situation, and to afford an opportunity for an open discussion of the problem so that plans could be made for a nation-wide safety program. As a result of this study, the Home and Farm Safety divisions were added to the National Safety Council program. Since then, a majority of the states have included a home and a farm safety division in their safety organizations.
Utah has kept in step with the na-
Traffic Safety Council was organized in 1939. In 1942, the State ranked second to Oregon in the Western Division for the best traffic safety record, and, in 1943, received the national grand award in the traffic safety contest.
The Utah Safety Council was formed May 19, 1944. Its scope was expanded to include the activities of the Utah Traffic Safety Council, the Women's Safety Council of Utah, and all other groups working in the interest of safety. The consolidation of these groups work under one head was made in the interest of efficiency and against duplication of effort.
The Home Division is new in the State and, as in the National Council, is in the pioneer stages of its plans.
A great nation-wide program has been inaugurated in which all our forces are harnessed to bring a safety consciousness to all Americans. The greatest stress is being placed on education and engineering, two of the three "E's" of safety. Enforcement, the third factor, cannot be used in the home as in industry and traffic.
This program of education should disseminate the knowledge of the safe use of the many products of this machine age that have found their way into our daily living. Individuals must be made conscious of unsafe conditions and unsafe practices.
Page 162 MARSHALLING OUR FORCES FOR HOME SAFETY 163. They should be awakened to a personal responsibility in guarding their own safety as well as that of others, and should exert every energy to assure their freedom from accidental injury. The importance of teaching safety in the home is being recognized as the first requisite in the safety program. It is believed that a child brought up in an atmosphere of safety will not be content with unsafe conditions and practices in later years, and that this training wiH have a profound influence on safety problems in general?in the home, on the highway, in industry. To assist in the education for home safety, the Red Cross has added another service?courses of instruction in accident prevention. It is now offering a course "Home Accident Prevention." Tliere is need, at present, for certified teachers to impart this knowledge to all groups of people. Those who take and fulfill all the requirements of this course can become certified teachers. It is an opportunity to help conserve human life, and also to destroy one of the potent forces which lead to distress and suffering. The Home Division of the Utah Safety Council is sponsoring classes in home accident prevention as a part of its program of education for home safety. It is issuing an appeal to people, in all groups and walks of life, to take advantage of the course not only for the benefit to themselves in their own homes, but also for the opportunity it gives them to do a fine human service. The Home Division is also planning for a designated week from April 8-14 wherein home safety can be specifically emphasized by all means available?by radio, by the press, by programs in churches, clubs, and schools, and by exhibits and surveys. It is hoped that by these activities a public awareness to the existence of hazards may be awakened, and a general desire to remove or avoid them be stimulated. The world would be a much better place in which to live if accidents could be prevented and, by marshalling all our forces to this end, much can be accomplished. 10 A LITTLE GIRL Jo Adelaide Stock Joy fills my heart, sweet, when I see The precious promises in thee. Thou art to me the soft perfume That sleeps within a summer's bloom. Thou art a song as masters sing Of love and youth and stars and spring; Thou art the bubbling of a fount; The cap of snow upon the mount. Thou art the gentleness of rain; Thou art the sweetness after pain; O thou'rt laughter after sorrow, Promise of the new tomorrow. Thou art dawning after dark. And the carol which a lark Showers down like unto leaven, On its way to God and heaven!

March Designs For Summer Hazel D. Moyle OF all the year's calendar, March is the least loved month. . . . And passing few are they who speak, wild, stormy month, in praise of thee." . . . Yet March has an important place in the year's garden work.
It is true that we can do but little out of doors at this early season?a fact which we soon discover when we venture out into our wet and sodden flower beds. But we can find solace, at this time of year, for that first hunger for green growing things which springs up so violently in the breast of every garden lover. We can not only elect our winter-weary selves, but we can assure our gardens an early and abundant bloom next summer by starting seeds indoors in early March.
Certain vegetables can also be started indoors with profit; that intriguing new tomato, "Change Jubilee" must be grown from your own sowing of seeds if you are to enjoy its piquant flavor and unusual appearance come next August, for few nurserymen offer ready-grown plants of this new variety.
One can, it is true, now purchase most kinds of annuals all readygrown for planting out when May arrives, but such ready-made plants under the present war conditions command a fairly high price. If your planting spaces are large, it will certainly pay you to try to raise your own plants. One can, if she is successful, reap an entire garden-full of plants by means of a few packages of seeds plus a little honest effort.
And there is the added advantage of being able to select just those colors, varieties, and kinds that suit one's own personal tastes.
It is especially profitable to make early March sowings of such annuals as the following: petunia, the most brilliant blooming of all (plant the low bedding varieties for garden decoration, and the giant ruffled kinds for cutting); lobelia, that tiny low-edging plant of such blazing, glowing blue color; snapdragon, rivaling petunias for constant all-year bloom, plus variety in coloring (we plant many shades of pink, flame, yellow, and crimson); verbena, these soon completely cover any wide space with a gorgeous, low carpet of fragrant color; stock . . . Ah me! the lovely, clean perfume of blossoming stocks; and ageratum, flower of soft blue, an exquisite peacemaker among our flower beds (plant this near the front line). All of these need an early start indoors if you are to have them blossoming from late June and on until snow flies.
THE requirements for indoor seed planting are few. Foremost is a suitable room in which to keep the seed boxes. The ordinary, well heated living room is too hot and dry for really good results. Choose, if you can, a cooler room, one that is light and airy, and where you can have plenty of ventilation. It should have at least one good sunny window. You might make use of your kitchen to keep the boxes when the seeds are germinating, for they can be kept in any warm room under a table out of the way at this stage, but the moment the tiny things begin to push up the soil, they must have light and air. An unheated, sunny room would be ideal after they are up.
Use a wooden box four inches deep and from twelve to eighteen inches long; too much depth of soil is not conducive to healthy growth, yet it should be deep enough to accommodate the young roots.
The soil used is of the greatest of importance; you should mix this as carefully as you would your Christmas pudding. A sandy soil is best, and some experts use one-third pure sand, one-third good clean dirt, and the last third, real black leaf mold or housewives' garden compost. You may be able to purchase a small sack of soil all mixed and ready to use from some florist or nurseryman, should you not have the above ingredients, and this might be the means of your real success in the venture.
A layer of broken flower pots, small pebbles, and coarse peat moss should be placed in the bottom of the seed box, then the prepared and sifted soil is placed over this rough drainage to fill the box to within one-half inch of the top. Press the whole down firmly with some board or even a paper magazine to insure no air pockets, especially at corners and edges. Then you are ready for the sowing of seeds.
And here is where we make our greatest mistake, for most amateur gardeners sow the seeds too thickly. Each seed should be sown separately, even the tiny ones such as the petunia. Prepare the box by scattering a
pinch slowly and carefully, then sift a little fine soil over them and press the surface lightly with a spoon. Larger seeds can be planted in rows, covering them with soil three times their own diameter. Do not sow too many, a package of seeds will raise several hundred plants; judge your needs accordingly, and strive for a few well-grown plants rather than too many that are crowded and puny.
Water by placing the seed box in a large pan or tub containing an inch or two of lukewarm water. Let it stand until the moisture has soaked up into the soil and shows on the surface, then remove the box and drain off for a few moments. Cover with a pane of glass to prevent evaporation, and to maintain even moisture and temperature. On top of the glass place a newspaper to exclude light as germination is best in dark. Place the box in any warm corner to germinate.
You should restrain yourself from peeking into the box for a few days, for most of the varieties named above require from ten days to two weeks to germinate. Nevertheless, keep your eye on them, for the soil should be kept moist but not wet, and just as soon as you see the little hummocks pushing up the surface, the paper should be removed to give them light. And as soon as they begin to show green (and no matter how often you have seen this miracle happen, it is always thrilling) the glass should be removed.
You must assist your young charges to grow up straight and sturdy by turning the box often as the plants lean towards the light. As soon as two pairs of leaves have developed, they should be transplanted into other boxes of soil to stand two inches apart. They will now need a richer soil. Prepare additional boxes as before except that another part of old, well-rotted manure is added to the soil mixture, and one can also include chemical fertilizer now with excellent results. Purchase any good brand available, and follow directions given on package for its use.
As the plants grow they will need more fresh air. One can now shift them outside to a cold frame or any improvised shelter made from an old wooden box if you have a glass cover to fit over the top. An old window frame will serve to protect the glass, or with a rug or old blanket to cover them during cold snaps or nights. As the days grow warmer, the glass covering must be lifted. Strive to harden your plants to the outdoor world, do not fail to cover or protect them if the weather changes. They can be planted out in the garden as soon as all danger of frost is over, usually in May first.
In the meantime, the outdoor garden work has begun. Digging and preparation of soil for planting should be started as soon as the ground has dried out sufficiently to permit digging. Use that old method of testing the ground by taking up a handful of soil and squeezing it to a ball; if it will then crumble and fall apart easily, the soil is ready for digging, but if it remains a wet ball, wait a few days longer for it to
dry. Real damage is done to garden soil by working it while yet, it does not recover its loose, springy mellowness if dug too soon; and roots find it hard to penetrate.
Trees, shrubs, and especially roses and lilacs should be planted the moment the ground is dry enough to work . . . do not delay a moment if you want them to have a good early start and to prosper well. They can establish early root growth during the cool, early spring before the sun has gained power.
Clean-up time also arrives during March, but be careful in removing any coverings. Loosen and take away coverings gradually. The rose bushes, too, will need their yearly pruning during late March or early April . . . just as soon as killing frosts are over, but not too soon. We must all learn to judge when this time arrives.
Be warned and leave climbing roses strictly alone at this season (so many amateurs want to trim them in early spring). Wait until the leaves unfold, and then remove only the wood that is actually dead.
So we see that March, though she has won such a poor reputation for herself, can be made to yield much in beauty for later months if the home gardener will but use her to good advantage.
March with grief doth howl and rave, And April weeps?but O ye hours! Follow with May's fairest flowers ?Dirge of the Year"?Shelley RELEASED Thelma Ireland Earth was held, entombed, a prisoner Of the warden, Winter King, Until wafted from her dungeon By the gentle breath of Spring.

The Lonesome House Olive Woolley Burt GRANDMA JACKSON never did know just what made her choose a different route home on that sunny, spring day. It might have been, she realized later, the invitation in the south wind that reminded her so of her birthplace; or it might have been the red and yellow tulips in the yard next to Let-tie's, flaunting their individuality almost insolently. But whatever the cause, Grandma Jackson did not turn east at the drugstore corner as she should have done. She went west, instead, and walked two blocks out of her way just so she could pass the park, brave in its new spring dress. Having passed the park, Grandma Jackson didn't even then turn toward Will's house, but wandered along slowly, savoring the sweetness of spring that was carried to her country-born senses by the soft breeze. She came, finally, to a little side street and turned down it, just because it was something like a country lane, with the street unpaved, a ditch of clear water running beside the curb, and tall trees arching over the sidewalk. And it was down this little side street, just about the middle of the block, that Grandma Jackson came upon the little house. It was an old, weather-beaten house, set back from the shady street in a yard overgrown with grass and flowers. Crocuses and daffodils, tulips and hyacinths, that and once apparently been planted in neat borders along the walk, now sprang up everywhere in the lush grass, making the shaggy lawn a veritable crazy patch of gay color. Grandma Jackson put her hand on the rickety gate and looked wistfully into the yard. It was so homelike, so poignantly familiar ? it looked so much the way she felt-little and old and gray, but with vivid, insurgent thoughts. She pushed the gate gently and it swung open, so she went down the neglected walk. The house was obviously empty. The wide porch across the front sagged toward the grassy earth, but Grandma Jackson didn't notice that. She was thinking what a nice porch it would be to sit on of an evening, rocking and dreaming till time to go to bed. She crossed the porch and peered in at the dusty, small-paned windows. She couldn't see much except the bright squares of sunlight on the bare, wooden floor. She went to the door and tried the knob gently; and, when the door yielded, she shrugged her small bent shoulders and walked resolutely in and looked around. There were two rooms. In the one which Grandma Jackson instinctively called the living room were three windows, two facing south and one west. They'd get all the winter sun there is, she thought, seeing her little rocking chair there between the two windows, a crocheted rug beneath her feet, a gray Page  cat purring contentedly in the patch of sunlight. She went into the bedroom and sighed. It was just the right size for her old-fashioned bed and highboy. In the little lean-to kitchen, an old rusty cook stove had been left, and Grandma Jackson's lips curved into a tender smile at sight of it. It was on just such a stove that she had done her first cooking for William; it was at just such a stove he had used to sit of a winter evening, his stockinged feet in the open oven. There was nothing like a coal stove for real warmth and comfort, Grandma Jackson told herself softly. Let the young folks have their furnaces and their gas and oil?a good coal stove was the thing to warm old bones by. She tried the back door, and found it, too, unlocked, so she went into the little back yard, fenced in, and overgrown with currant bushes, a small strawberry patch, and grass everywhere. She heard a trickle and looked about her and found the reason for the lush greenishness. A very tiny spring bubbled through the tangled mass at one side of the yard and ran down a choked ditch to join the ditch along the curb in the front. Grandma Jackson smiled triumphantly, as if she had discovered a looked for treasure. That was why this street was different from all the others. There must be several of these small springs along the block and they gave that special loveliness to the grass and the trees. It was a long time before Grandma Jackson could tear herself away from the little house. She loved it already, as if they two had some secret affinitv. But she knew she shouldn't stay so long. Will's wife, Clara, would be worried. If Lettie had phoned as she usually did to see whether her mother had made the short trip from her house to her brother's safely, they would all be out searching for her. They always told her to go straight along, and here she had flagrantly ignored their advice. She pulled the doors shut carefully and went slowly down the path and out of the rickety gate. She looked back from the sidewalk, and the house peered at her lonesomely from the two windows, the porch roof bent like a wistful eyebrow above them. Grandma Jackson waved gently, to reassure the little house, then squared her shoulders and turned her face purposefully toward her son's house. She arrived before Lettie phoned, before there was any uproar over her vagary. She went to her room and took off her hat, and hung it carefully in the crowded little closet. She looked at her beloved old bed? a piece of furniture Clara hated? and touched the pieced quilt gently as she passed. It would look just right?but she musn't think of that. Downstairs she looked about for her rocker. This had grown to be an unconscious gesture on her part, derived from the habit Clara had of moving Grandma's rocker from place to place in the room, so it wouldn't wear the nap off the carpet. Grandma saw where the little chair now stood and went to it and sat down and tried to knit, but the chair was in a dark corner, and her eyes were dim, and she was dreadfully tired, so she just sat. Will's two grandchildren, noisy and dirty, came into the living room THE LONESOME HOUSE and began to climb over Grandma and her chair. She loved the little fellows, but their hands were sticky. If she got up and took care of them, Clara and Trudy would be offended, taking it as an insult to their own care of the children. So Grandma shrank into herself as much as she could, and let the boys have their way uncomplaining. That night Grandma Jackson dreamed of the little house. It was furnished with her own things, and she was living in it quietly, happily. Her children and their children and grandchildren came to see her and she was glad to have them because, in her own house, she could gently but firmly keep them in their places. She awoke and lay staring into the dark, and the longing for the little gray house became so acute it was a physical aching. But it was useless. There was no way to relieve the ache. If she had only saved a little money! But how could she, with four children to rear and educate? They had all had such good minds ?such great possibilities. She had scrimped and saved, and then spent freely to send them to college, to get them established in their chosen fields. She sighed and turned over and determined to sleep. What couldn't be cured must be endured, she knew from past years of wanting and going without. But she couldn't keep back the tears that squeezed under the soft wrinkled lids with their thin gray lashes; she couldn't stop the ache that tortured her old, tired heart. THE next afternoon Grandma Jackson put on her straw bonnet and took her knitting bag and said, almost too casually, "Well, Clara, it's such a nice day, I think I?ll take a little walk." Clara looked at her mother-in-law, surprised. "Why don't you wait till it's cooler?" she shouted, and Grandma Jackson shuddered involuntarily. Clara always yelled at her in the belief that she was deaf, and Grandma's quiet assurances to the contrary had no effect. "I'll just walk down the shady side of the street," Grandma protested. "But you may get a sunstroke!" Clara fussed. "Lots of old people do, walking in the sun." "I'll keep in the shade," Grandma repeated, determined not to be talked out of her little excursion. "Well," Clara was openly doubtful. "Don't go too far, I'll be worried till you get back. I'll be watching out for you." "No, don't Clara," Grandma begged. "If I get a wee bit tired, I'll stop in at Anabelle Truman's. She's been begging me to come, and I'm taking my knitting along." Grandma saw the triumphant look that leaped into Clara's eyes, and smiled secretly. Clara thought she had slyly found out where Grandma was going. She smiled sweetly at the old woman now. "Be careful crossing the streets," she shouted, and Grandma escaped into the afternoon sun. She walked demurely enough down the street toward her old friend's house, and right on past. She turned the corner and hurried along, straight to the little side street, straight to the rickety gate halfway down the block. There Grandma Jackson stopped and waved greeting to the little lonesome house. It was just as she had remembered it! It hadn't been a dream. Grandma pushed open the gate and walked up the path to the porch. She sat down on the low step, took off her hat, and laid her knitting bag beside her. When Grandma Jackson realized she was thirsty, she remembered the little spring, and went around the house to the back. There was noth-ink to drink from, so she knelt on the grass and scooped up the cold water in her wrinkled old hands and drank it lovingly, gratefully. She was suddenly young again, with young William laughing beside her. She got up carefully and went to the back stoop and sat there, thinking of William and of their children. Suddenly, Grandma Jackson realized that when she thought of her children she never thought of them as they were now?grown men and women with children of their own. She thought of them as babies at her breast, as little folks starting off to school, as youngsters with problems of their own they brought to her, even as laughing soldiers going off to the last war?but never as middle-aged individuals ? never as married folk. Somehow, she had to admit to herself, they didn't seem much like her children any more. She wished that she had been able to keep one of them, at least, hers. Then she shook her head impatiently, she didn't wish any such thing. At last. Grandma got up with a sigh, went around to the front and, picking up her hat and knitting bag, she started home again. That was the first of her secret visits to the little house. As the days passed and the delight of spring grew into the reality of summer. Grandma's little afternoon walk became such a habit that Clara forgot to wonder and to ask questions. She had evidently talked it over with Will and Lettie, and they'd made up their minds to let her alone in her queer vagary. All old folks had some strange ways, and this was harmless. Grandma Jackson was glad for this acquiescence, and she took every advantage of their apparent indifference. First, it was Will's pruning shears. She had noticed that the currant bushes would have to be trimmed back, so she slipped the shears into her knitting bag one day, and when she got to the little house, she hurried around to the back yard and set to work. The pruning done, the uncouth state of the strawberry bed cried aloud for correction, so the next afternoon, Grandma Jackson pulled strawberry suckers till her hands were sore and her legs trembled, and her back ached, but she was happier than she had been for years. Bit by bit, the back yard took on a more civilized air, and the bushes and vines, as if grateful for attention, sent out showers of fragrant blossoms. The old lilac tree was so burdened that Grandma picked an armful of the lovely flowers, and then, not knowing how to explain them at home, she looked about for some way of keeping them here. She put them in an old bucket and set them inside the door, and the next day she went out of her way to go to the five-and-ten cent store to get a crock to put the blossoms in. In the store, she saw a tiny teakettle THE LONESOME HOUSE 171 and she suddenly thought how nice it would be to have a cup of postum of an afternoon when she had finished her work. So she bought the teakettle and some postum and wafers. TT was by easy stages like this, that Grandma Jackson moved into the empty house. At first, she sat on an old box, but one day Claude tucked a little check into his letter? a thing he frequently did?and Grandma bought a tiny second-hand rocker, and had it delivered, giving the man explict directions to put it in the back yard, as she wouldn't be there 'with her other things" for a day or two. And once the rocking chair was placed between the two windows, it would have taken more resolution than Grandma possessed to convince herself that she was trespassing, or that she had no right to these harmless afternoons. AT home, Lettie and Will and Clara mentioned how much happier Grandma looked. Will said, "Well, Grandma, I guess those afternoon walks of yours are just what you need. Maybe we've kept you too cooped up. You look better than you have in all the years since father died." Nobody bothered Grandma in her little house. No one ever came to the door or gave any sign of being interested in what went on there. That is until one afternoon, when the woman who lived next door, whom Grandma had sometimes seen in her little yard hanging out clothes or playing with her three children, came dashing over, her hair all tumbled, her eyes frantic. She pounded on the back door and Grandma Jackson opened it fearfully. Seeing the frightened creature before her, Grandma Jackson wanted to say "Come in! Tell me what's wrong!" but she couldn't do that, so she stepped out onto the little porch, pulled the kitchen door shut behind her, and asked, "What's the matter?" "My baby!" the woman gasped. "Something has happened to her. Can't you hear her screaming? I don't know what's the matter! I can't get a doctor? someone's on the line and won't let me have it. I'm frantic?" Grandma Jackson didn't wait to hear any more. She hurried along, her little old legs taking her through a gap in the fence, past the frightened mother. Yes, she could hear the baby screaming, the particularly anguished cries that accompany severe and unidentified agony. Grandma Jackson picked the child up and held her a moment, watching her carefully. Then the wrinkled, experienced fingers began to feel carefully over the little legs and body and arms. As the gentle pressure reached the child's face and ear, the screams became more piercing, and the child shrank under the soft touch. Her two little brothers, watching, frightened, began to cry. "It's her ear," Grandma Jackson said. "Has she put something in her ear?" "She couldn't!" cried the mother, "she hasn't had anything small enough!" Grandma Jackson looked at the two little boys, but the mother flung her arm around them. "Not them, either!" she cried. "Baby was lying on her quilt in her play pen on the lawn. They couldn't have reached her."
"It's an ant then," said Grandma. "Get me some warm oil and a warm linen rag."
While the mother was getting the materials, Grandma soothed the baby, then she laid her on her left side and very carefully poured the warm oil into the tiny ear. She laid the warm linen against it and fanned the child over on her right side.
Gradually the sobs began to moderate, and in a very short while the exhausted baby slept against Grandma's lap, with only an occasional sob to remind them of what she had been through.
Grandma removed the linen and held it toward the mother. On it lay a black ant, drugged by the oil.
When Grandma Jackson laid the baby gently in her crib and took the small boys' hands to tiptoe with them from the room, the mother said, "I don't know how I can thank you, Mrs.?"
"Jackson," said Grandma. "Mrs. Jackson," she repeated, the phrase pleasing her with its recognition of her as something besides a grandmother.
"It must have been terribly painful. Won't you have a glass of cool lemonade before you leave?"
So Grandma Jackson sat down and drank lemonade with her neighbor.
"You don't know how glad I am that you're my neighbor," Mrs. Cook said, sincerely, after they had introduced themselves. "I am so dumb with the children. When anything happens I go all to pieces. I'm sure I came over to welcome you before," she explained, a little ashamed that she had not met this kind old woman until necessity demanded it, "but you are there so seldom?". She hesitated and flushed, and Grandma Jackson knew that this little woman must have peered through the windows, must have seen the barren rooms.
"Well, you see," Grandma began honestly, not caring to hide the facts from these sympathetic ears, "I'm not there much. Just an hour or two in the afternoons. You see?" and she went on to tell her new friend how she had found the house, how she had fallen in love with it, how she had finally moved in.
Mrs. Cook listened understandingly, but when Grandma had finished, she asked, "Why don't you tell your children? I'll bet if they knew, if they understood how you feel, they'd be glad to get it for you. I know I'd want my mother to have anything?if only she were alive!"
Grandma Jackson patted her neighbor's hand.
"Yes," she agreed. "I suppose they would. But it is silly, my having a whole house, when Will has an extra room. And I have no way of keeping in?light and coal and food and everything. We sort of talked it over when William died, the children and I, and we decided it would be smarter for me to stay at Will's and help Clara with the children. They were younger then, you know, and I could help a lot and stay with them at night when Will and Clara wanted to go out. And then, it isn't far to Lettie's, and I can run over and help her. I'd rather live with Lettie," she added wistfully, "but?" "Well," Mrs. Cook comforted, THE LONESOME HOUSE 173 "you can probably enjoy the little house as long as you want to. We've lived here four years and have never seen anyone around the place. Oh, right at the first of the war boom/' she corrected, 'people looked at it. But it isn't modern, you know, and so run down, no one wanted it." Now that Grandma knew her neighbor, she could ask for nothing more. She was so happy that she sometimes awakened in the night, and lay trembling, fearful of losing the little house and all it stood for in her lonely days. Then Claude wrote, asking her to come to visit him for awhile. Grandma Jackson had always gone when her baby boy called, but this time she didn't want to go away. She shook her head and wrote to Claude, but said nothing to Will or Lettie. A more urgent invitation came, and Claude wrote to Will, too, to persuade his mother. There was no way to explain her reluctance at going away without revealing her secret, so at last, under Will's and Lettie's insistence, she packed and went. She stayed two weeks and wired Will, "Will be home on the 8:15 P. M. Tuesday." TAILL was at the station to meet her. He seemed more jovial than before, really happy to have her back again, she thought. He took her to the house, asking questions about Claude and Helen and the boys, all three of whom were in service. Clara and the children also seemed extra glad to see Grandma again, and she thought, "Maybe they do like to have me here. Maybe it's a good thing to go away, so they can miss me once in a while." But when she went upstairs to take off her things, she stood still inside the door to her room, her heart shaken, her lips trembling like a lost child's. And she knew, then, why they had insisted on her going away. Clara had had a chance to do over Grandma's room. She had got rid of the ugly wooden bed she hated, and the old highboy, and the room was bright and streamlined and modern. A narrow, hard little bed stood where the big bed had been. Her old patchwork quilt, even, was gone! In a few minutes. Grandma took off her hat and coat very quietly, and hung them in the closet. She went downstairs and joined the family, not saying a word. They seemed strangers to her now, rather cruel strangers, and their titillating joviality was not deep enough to hide the nervous shame they felt at tricking her. At last Will could stand it no longer. He said, "I guess you noticed that Clara's redone your room, Grandma?" he asked tentatively. Grandma nodded. She couldn't speak. "You'll like it better, once you get used to it. Did you notice we put in a little bathroom, all your own? He was too enthusiastic, and Grandma said, wishing to ease his embarassment, "Yes, it's very nice." She wouldn't let them know?oh, she would never let them know-but if her little house was gone, too, how could she bear it? She saw Will's pitying glance as she went up to bed. She walked slowly, she knew, though she tried to straighten the bent shoulders. And, once in the hard, narrow bed, she buried her tired old head in her arms and wept. All the next morning, Grandma kept her eyes on the cloek. She could hardly eat, could hardly talk, waiting for the time to come when she could slip away and see what had happened to her little house. As soon as she decently could, she said, "Guess Til take a little walk, Clara," and left before anyone could interfere. Grandma Jackson nearly ran all the way to the house. She was possessed of a strange feeling she couldn't define, and she was dreadfully afraid. But it was still there, gray and withdrawn and lonely, as she had left it. She paused at the gate long enough to wave a greeting, to let the house know she was back, and then she went up the walk and opened the door. For the second time within a few hours she stopped still and stared about her. There it was, just as she had dreamed it would be, with her rocker between the two windows, a round crocheted rug in front of it, even a fat gray cat, that rose and stretched and came and rubbed against Grandma's legs. Her old, pedal sewing machine that Clara had persuaded her to sell, was under a window, piled high with fluffy white curtaining. When Grandma got her breath, she walked cautiously across the floor and peered into the bedroom, and there was her old bed with its patchwork quilt, her highboy, with William's picture in its funny frame on top of it. It was all she could do to get into the kitchen, and to stare at the little stove, shining and black now, and the row of new small kettles in the cupboard sparkling with yellow paint, exactly like her very first kitchen. Grandma sank down in the little rush-bottomed chair beside the oldfashioned sink, and the tears ran down her face. She wasted no time thinking she had blundered into someone else's house?this was hers ? every bit of it. But how it had come to be she had no idea. She was still sitting there when she heard knocking on the door, and she went slowly to open it, her heart pounding, thinking that maybe, after all, she had been mistaken, or dreaming, or crazy. Will and Clara and Lettie and Lettie's little girl, Rhoda, stood there, beaming and laughing. "How do you do, Mrs. Jackson," Will boomed, the noise in his voice and the laughter in his eyes trying to cover up the love and tears that threatened him. "Won't you invite us in, Mother?" Lettie's arms were about her. "Were you surprised. Mother? We were almost scared to do it, but oh. We wanted so for you to have it, and we were afraid you would object?" "It is rather foolish?," Grandma made her lips say, but Will shook her tenderly. "Not at all. Don't worry about that room at our place. We can find some war worker to rent it to. And as for keeping the place up," he smiled deep into her eyes, "don't pretend you don't know about allowances! You understood them well enough when we went to school. And now you're going to have a dose of your own good medicine!"
As they talked it all came out, how they had become suspicious of her daily walks and had followed her, how Claude had talked to Mrs. Cook and how Claude had been worked in on their scheme.
After they left Grandma set about getting her first real supper in years. Her hands trembled as she lit the fire and filled the teakettle. She set the table and stood looking at it in the light of the friendly little kerosene lamp, when Mrs. Cook came to the door.
"May I come in, Mrs. Jackson?" she asked, "and formally welcome you as my neighbor?"
Grandma Jackson pulled forward the little chair and Mrs. Cook sank into it. The old woman noticed
that her neighbor's cheeks were pale, her lips pinched with weariness.
"Are the children in bed?" she asked, and as Mrs. Cook nodded she urged, "stay and have a bite of supper with me, then, you look a mite peaked."
The younger woman leaned back, wearily.
"I am tired," she said. "The children have been little terrors today. Sometimes," she said softly, "I hardly think I can ever go through it again."
Grandma Jackson smiled understandingly.
"Children are a chore," she agreed as she served the food, "and at times you can hardly see how they're worth it. But they are, my dear. They are."

THE VISITING TEACHER'S PRAYER Eva M. R. Salway Humbly, we thy handmaidens come to thee today, Praying for thy guidance, in all we do and say. Asking for a blessing on the work now to be done, That we may feel thy presence, as we enter in each home. Give to us thy wisdom for all problems that arise, Help us to be cheerful, and faithful, loving, wise. Grant us thy Holy Spirit as we enter in each door. Help us bring peace and comfort, and glorify thee more. Help us to comfort sorrow, or guide the erring feet. Encourage all that's good and brave, as we our sisters meet. Bring to us remembrance, as we our topic teach, And help us more than all of these, to practice what we preach.

Rehabilitation of Disabled Soldiers and Sailors Excerpts from a Report, Office of War Information THE readjustment and happiness of wounded soldiers and sailors with compassionate physical disfigurements or disabilities or nervous manifestations will depend in large measure on the way their families and friends and the public at large behave toward them.
Thanks to modern therapy, many of the men suffering from even the severest wounds will be rehabilitated and enabled to lead lives of normal activity, engaging in industry, business or professions. But the most modern medical and psychiatric care, the finest surgery and appliance, expert rehabilitation, vocational training and employment opportunities are far from being all that is needed by the men who have suffered disfigurements and disabilities. The OWI passes along a number of suggestions, made by the Surgeon General of the Army, concerning everyday behavior on the part of friends, family and acquaintances most calculated to lessen the inevitable difficulties of adjustment of disfigured and disabled veterans.
If a formerly able-bodied man returns from combat with a disfigurement or other serious disability, he is almost certain to be emotionally disturbed. In other cases the wound he brings back may be mental.
In case after case, maimed young men have been freed from their black thoughts and bitterness, and have had their self-confidence restored, by the professional?expert and difficult?rehabilitation treatment they have received, as soon as possible after injury, in Army and Navy hospitals and in the hospitals of the Veterans' Administration. Disabled merchant seamen are cared for in United States Public Health Service Marine Hospitals.
In all these institutions, the restoration of self-confidence, as an aid in the restoration of physical health, is the immediate aim of doctors, nurses, and other personnel.
Details of accomplishments in the field of physical rehabilitation are becoming increasingly familiar to American readers of newspapers and magazines. Injured muscles are brought back into play, new or unused muscles are trained. When necessary, efficient surgical appliances are carefully fitted to replace amputated hands, feet or limbs.
Nervous disabilities resulting from combat experience are treated with equal care. In some cases prolonged psychiatric treatment is necessary; occupational therapy cures others rapidly.
When he has recovered his physical or psychic health and is discharged from the Army or Navy hospital, the serviceman in need of vocational training is eligible to receive it from the Veterans' Administration if he has suffered a ten percent or greater disability, resulting in a vocational handicap, while in service.
Page 176 REHABILITATION OF DISABLED SOLDIERS AND SAILORS 177 If not, the same training is open to him through the Vocational Rehabihtation Division of the United States Office of Education. Vocational training in the Veterans* Administration and other institutions is directed toward preparing the wounded man not only to fill a job in which his wound will not be a handicap, but to do important work which he will enjoy and for which he is temperamentally suited. In all cases, even those capable only of self-employment at home, the goal is useful, functional, independent living?not dependent, permanent residence in hospitals. After vocational training comes employment, and here many agencies are working for the wounded serviceman. In summary, Americans can rest assured that their wounded soldiers and sailors are being given the most modem medical and psychiatric care, the finest surgery and appliances, expert rehabilitation, vocational training and finally employment opportunities that confirm their hard-won feelings of independence. All these things are being provided, and provided by persons and organizations expert in their field, professionally equipped to further the welfare of wounded ex-servicemen. BUT the American people?the families, friends and acquaintances of the disabled and disfigured men, and the public at large?have a responsibility in the matter, too. It is up to them to further the men's progress during rehabilitation by considerate and cooperative behavior. Men who are working hard to acquire new self-confidence, or who have acquired it, must not be jolted out of it by thoughtless, uncontrolled manifestations of pity or horror or distaste or false cheeriness or too-eager curiosity or other emotionalism. For the purpose of increasing public awareness of some of the problems faced by disabled and disfigured men in their search for rehabilitation and normal living, and for the purpose of indicating to what extent public cooperation can be of benefit, the Surgeon General of the Army has set forth a series of guide-posts not only for the families and friends of such men, but for all who may come in contact vdth them. The suggestions are intended especially for the period of rehabilitation in hospitals or vocational training centers, but they also hold good for later, after the wounded men's return to civilian life: 1. Treat the maimed person as the normal person he always has been and continues to be. Disfigurement does not make him into a different person, though it may well result in his growing to be a bigger one. If you are disturbed by the disfigurement, discipline yourself so that your disturbance is not apparent. It is up to you to make him realize-without talking about it?that you feel about him exactly as always, and that his disfigurement is unimportant compared with your affection or friendship. The only difference could be an even increased respect for him. There is much to be gained from contact with a person who has suffered a handicap and overcome it. Such a person often gains extraordinary largeness of character from his fight and his success; and those around him, in turn, gain from his example. Treating disabled men as normal people is particularly important in cases of mental disability. Often, in cases of this kind, the average person retains ancient prejudices, and approaches a patient either with distaste or as though he were a child or a fool. It should be kept in mind that vast strides have been made in recent years in the treatment and rehabilitation of the mentally and nervously afflicted. They are simply ill?and their illnesses are usually curable. It should be emphasized also that excessive praise of a disabled man because of his disability is not helpful. 2. Don't ask questions or give advice. The man who has been disabled or disfigured may want to talk about himself or he may not. Respect his wishes. Do not mention the disfigurement unless he does. If he does not want to talk about himself, talk about things he is interested in, or about objects in the room, or hobbies, or details of common interest. Don't talk about the war or about subjects related to his injury. Don't pry or hint. The best answer to give a wounded man who asks you "Am I going to be good for anything?" is "If you want to be good for something, determination helps." If you are related to a wounded or disfigured man, make it your business to know about the rehabilitation and accomplishments of persons as badly handicapped as he is, or more so, and be able to tell him about them ?not in a preachy way, but factually. Let him see that you know about them and that you assume he will take full advantage of his opportunities. 3. Be casual and lealistic?not over cheery. The man you are visiting may feel depressed. It is his right to feel so. It is an offense to his dignity and his common sense to go into a routine of transparent "cheeriness." The express intent of cheering up is seldom convincing or effective. Nor is it usually convincing or beneficial to try to minimize the crippling effect of maiming. By facing the reality ofc a man's disability yourself, you can help him face it. Personal anxieties and problems of all kinds lose their capacity to frighten if they are brought out into the open, squarely faced and talked about. A disfigured man who finds his friends acting naturally and casually about his disfigurement will more easily avoid being the kind of person who goes through life shrinking if a child asks, ''What's the matter with that man?" If a person has one leg, it is better to admit that fact and not try to conceal it. If one is deaf, the hearing aid should be worn openly, not treated as an embarrassing detail. A hearing aid or an artificial leg is just that and nothing more. The only difference it makes is that one hears or walks better with it than without it. 4. Don't wait on the injured man too much. Even though a disabled soldier or sailor be surrounded with sympathy, waited on hand and foot by nurses and given countless attentions, he may still despair. He may still view himself as a martyr-an attitude REHABILITATION OF DISABLED SOLDIERS AND SAILORS 179 which brings little happiness to him and no benefit to anybody else. If his faith in his ability to do things is restored the rest of the treatment is easy.
If there is something the patient can do for you, let him do it. Help-
ing others is an important part of rehabilitation. The families of men who have returned to their homes can greatly help them by letting it be seen that they expect self-reliance and cooperation, and by not being pessimistic or over-solicitous.

No Tongue Can Tell Marguerite J. Griffin "OUT there we talk of death quite calmly," said a young sailor, home on leave after seeing action in the South Pacific. "We talk over what has happened to this one and that one of our friends. We never spare the details. We talk of death quite as matter-of-factly, as if we were discussing a newspaper item. We might as well. It's all around us out there, and we know it. I've seen more things than I can tell you."
He was much changed, this young man, from what he had been when he had gone away. Two years older? Yes, but more than that. His ordinarily fair-skinned face was bronzed from the rigors of sea life. But there were shadows across his brow, faint ones easily removed by his ready smile, but still lurking there in moments of repose. There was a firm new purpose to his jaw, as though, whatever his naval rank, he was master of himself no matter what the days might bring. And all this change because he had seen more things than tongue can tell. Physical suffering he had seen because he served with the medical corps. Death he had seen. Men dying before his very eyes. Men dying without a whimper, without a complaint.
"After one bombing we went about on deck helping the wounded. They were lying all about. I saw a fellow who had been my best friend lying over his gun. I thought he was dead, but when I came up to him he recognized me and he said: 'Do not move me for the others are
about done for.' But I had to do something for him. He was my friend. He died an instant later in my arms, and then I was glad, seeing his condition. This is something I will never forget as long as I live. Yes. Death is something we talk about quite openly. It's there and you have to face it."
That was the thing that made this boy different from what he had been before. He had been face to face with death. He knew he would go back to face it again, but in the meantime he would serve as best he could and smile all the while. While life lasted there were things to do for the living and last respects to the dead. Time enough to worry about danger when it struck. Two years ago he had been a young, care-free boy. Today he is a man, brave, master of himself and his emotions. And what has wrought the change? One thing. His ability to face reality, look it squarely in the eye, and spend his strength getting the most possible joy out of the real things of life, people, places, and comradeship.
What are you doing, mothers of these boys who have become men overnight, who have seen more things than tongue can tell? What are you doing to change your own souls that would like to cringe and shrink into citadels strong and sure? What am I doing to prepare myself against the day when my sons must go forth to face the pains of life and death upon their own? How do we mean to face the problems of our own
lives courageously? We believe we could endure the dangers our sons face more easily than to know that they, in whose veins flow our own blood, must suffer, endure, and perchance die. But if our task is great, we must be greater.
I have seen mothers become whimpering old women, old long before their time, after their sons had sailed away to front-line action. I have seen them become helpless neurotics who can't stand to hear a news broadcast, who can't bear to read a paper. If it were helping these boys, then it would have purpose. But worry, anxiety cannot reach out and stop the bombs from falling. Instead, they twine like tentacles about the one who conceived them, crushing from her all the breath of life, like an octopus with its overpowering grip.
Again I have seen mothers, with heads erect, lock their secret heartaches into a dark corner of their beings, and valiantly go forth to take their parts in the many duties of life at home. Why the difference? Why does one cringe and one remain indomitable. The reason is simple, depending upon whether you fight with life or against it, whether you look the whole thing squarely in the face like the young seaman. It is whether you, too, know that death is there and will admit it, or whether you are trying to avoid it, to fight your own small futile fight, you know. Since Adam, men who have lived upon this earth have died. In that one thing all humanity are brothers. You know that each man must die, but don't push the knowledge back into a far corner of your heart and refuse to face it. Well, bring it out into the
light and let the sun shine upon it for awhile. You are going to die. Your son is going to die. No matter how you live, or grieve, or worry, you cannot change this fact. War doesn't make much difference then. It only makes you more aware that death stalks the earth.
BUT you say: "My boy is so young! What a pity a life is cut short in youth!" So we always feel. A pity to die so young! But what does it matter if life be long or short? The important thing is, how have we lived and how have we died. The day to an honest man, busy with his constructive work, may seem all too short. The same day to a criminal waiting to pay for his crime upon the gallows may seem a fortunate eternity. But the day had twenty-four hours, and if it rained it rained for both. The difference is only in the human heart, in the way of life. One man knows the peace of honesty, the other the remorse, the despondency of a life which must pay for wasted deeds. Who, then, can measure a life, if it be long or short? Better to say it was rich or poor. Rich in valiance, in love, in honor, or poor in fear, in selfishness, in smallness of spirit. True it is, today many a youth gives his life, brief in years, but full of valor. "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends."
"Beloved, think it not strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing happened unto you." A strange thing? It has happened over and over in this world, but there has appeared with it the strange. It is something we have never felt before. It is a thrust to our courage. But we are not alone. Dogs that help? Every soul who has lived has had to face his Gethsemane, even the Son of Man. "Forasmuch as Christ hath suffered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves likewise with the same mind: for he that hath suffered in the flesh hath ceased from sin."
As human beings we must suffer some things over which we have no control, sickness, financial reverses, death, but at least if we seek an honorable way to life we can spare ourselves many heartaches of our own making.
There are so many things to benefit humanity that need to be done. Your sons are doing a big part of them. There is much remaining for us to do at home. There will always be a need for worthwhile tasks, well done.
"And fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell." And what person is it we should fear? None other than our own selves. True we must answer the call of death, for that is an event of life through which all must pass, but how we die and how we live
that is our own affair. We can chart a course which will steer us safely through troubled waters or we can let our souls crack up in the storm. It is for us to choose.
"And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me." Hear the words of the Son of God who gave his life upon the cross to break the bonds of death, that the sea might one day give up the dead that are in it, that he might say unto the dry, parched, shattered bones of war, "Behold, I will cause breath to enter into you, and ye shall live: and I will lay sinews upon you, and will bring up flesh upon you, and cover you with skin, and put breath in you, and ye shall live; and ye shall know that I am the Lord." The same Lord who said: "These things I have spoken unto you, that in me ye might have peace. In the world ye shall have tribulation: but be of good cheer; I have overcome the world."
As he leads let us follow, and while our days endure in the world we, too, can overcome the trials that beset our days, we can take up our cross and follow him. We can feel his peace which is so sweet no tongue can tell.

THE SNOWBALLS Olive Rose Helton A bit of gleaming white, A breath of sweet perfume, A tiny snow-white bud, And then a large full bloom. Now sparkling in the sunlight, Now shadowed by the trees; No lovelier flower in springtime, Than snowballs in the breeze. Work Meeting UTILITY APRONS IN most present-day households the homemaker finds it necessary not only to do her own housework, but to learn how to conserve her energy so she can accomplish all the tasks she desires to do. These aprons are practical in any kind of household but they are invaluable in homes where there are busy mothers and small children. The large pockets become convenient "catch-alls" for numerous articles which become misplaced. If the pockets are lined with oiled silk or a plasticized material they can also be used to carry a damp cloth for wiping off stray fingermarks, a cloth for furniture polishing, a whisk broom, etc. Such utility articles might be made on a Relief Society Work Meeting in the spring or for a coming bazaar. The apron (Illus. I) is very easily made using 3/5 yd. Of material 27" wide for the apron proper, and 8" of contrasting material for the pockets. The apron is most effective using a light color for the background and a very dark color for the pockets. The apron (Illus. 2) can be made in medium size using 21/8 yds. Of 35" material. If a head bandana is made of the same material, a very smart effect is achieved in this utility costume. The apron ties and is also buttoned down the back. The large pockets end a little beyond the side seams. This apron is unusually effective if a bright gay, solid color is used. Bias tape in a contrasting color makes an easy finish to use for binding. TIE APRON BUTTONED APRON

NOTES FROM THE FIELD Vera White Pohlman, General Secretary-Treasurer Regulations governing the submittal of material for "Notes from the Field" appear in the Magazine for February 1944, page 104. MESSAGES FROM THE MISSIONS (Continued from February Magazine) East Central States Mission THE following reports from four of the branches of this mission were received during 1944. Their Mission Relief Society President, Leone W. Doxey, submitted all but one. "In the country district of Gretna, Virginia," wrote Sister Doxey, "we have a Relief Society with sixteen members, thirteen of whom are not members of the Church. "The meetings of tlie Gretna Relief Society are held Tuesday afternoons in the home of Sister Maria Rowland, 'Granny,' as she is lovingly called by all who know her. The home is a fine old Virginia farmhouse that had been the home of her husband's father and mother. Granny moved into it as a bride. She is now nearly eighty years old and has been a member of the Church for more than forty years. She teaches the theology lessons in Relief Society and is an inspiration to everyone there." Mrs. L. H. Snow, president of the Chadottesville (Virginia) Relief Society, wrote July 20, 1944: "In and around this city and also other big towns, we see many beautiful little country churches closed for lack of preachers. Women from Page 184 some of these churches are joining the Relief Society and are glad to get something to do. I wish you could see our women working, making rugs, quilts, et cetera. The people in the country want to piece quilts so Iam taking them the material. I am also taking them samples of a miniature redchecked apron and a tiny pair of blue and white striped overalls, to help in the collection of contributions to the building fund. A note in the apron pocket has space for filling in the woman's name and her waist measurement, and carries the suggestion, "A penny for every inch." A similar note in the overall pocket suggests that the men pledge either work on the chapel or a cash donation. We also have one member in Hampton, and she is making something for the bazaar in October. Some members up in the Blue Ridge near Standardsville are making quilts?one woman gave the top, filling, and bottom for a quilt last night. This project is getting every one doing something, and in that way they learn what we stand for and what we are doing in trying to teach the gospel. The people are hungry for the gospel and for friends." Sister Doxey reports an unusual Relief Society meeting held at Fairmont, Virginia, which came to her attention through Sister Crozier Kimball, a short-term missionary. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 185 RELIEF SOCIETY OF HARKERS ISLAND (NORTH CAROLINA), EAST CENTRAL STATES MISSION Picture submitted March 1944 by M. LA. President Raymond Guthrie who stated: This Society was organized in 1923 under adverse circumstances and almost unbearable persecution. Although at that time the membership was very small it has since grown, through the faith and charity exercised by the sisters, to the present membership of 30. Left to right, front row: Virgie Lewis, Annie B. Guthrie, Annie Rose, Annie Lee Lawrence, Edith Willis (Secretary), Gertie Willis (1st Counselor), Letha Lewis (President), Blanch Willis (2d Counselor), Lillian Davis (teacher), Belva Gillikin, Mamie Hamilton, Clara Willis and Edith A. Willis; second row: Nettie Brooks, Naomi Guthrie, Flora Belle Willis, Hannah Guthrie; third row: Glennie Guthrie, Mattie Whitley, Bessie Hancock, Nannie Willis and Hattie Rose. "Sister May Sloter, Relief Society president in Fairmont, had announced on Sunday that the work meeting would be held the following Wednesday afternoon. The time arrived for the appointed meeting and no one came but the president. She felt discouraged and somewhat upset, but she had said there would be Relief Society meeting so she conducted one. She announced the song and sang it, opened the meeting with prayer, sang again and then sat down and quilted for an hour. At the end of the hour she sang another song and dismissed the meeting with prayer. She put her work away and returned to her home with joy and satisfaction in her heart. Sister Sloter is loved and respected by the members of the Fairmont Branch and though the membership is small, after this example of faithfulness, all who possibly can now attend the meetings." Northern California Mission MARY SMITH ELLSWORTH, recently released president of Relief Societies of the Northern California Mission, wrote last June: "During the year thus far I have visited in every district with President Ellsworth. The most outstanding thing I find is the increased spirit of unity and cooperation and love among all our sisters. Our Relief Society meetings are held in most branches immediately following Sunday School; while the men Attend Priesthood meeting, the Relief Society and Primary convene. RELIEF SOCIETY MEMBERS. THEIR HUSBANDS AND FRIENDS, TOYON BRANCH, NORTHERN CALIFORNIA MISSION at the party at Toyon Community House, March 17, 1944 commemorating the 102d anniversary of the organization of the Relief Society. Inset shows presidency with birthday cake, with President Lorena Humphries in center, and Counselors Mary K. Hirst and Mabel Kloss, left and right, respectively. Transportation facilities are more available on Sunday, especially in our outlying districts and where many of our people are engaged in war work. "It is the earnest desire of President Ellsworth to establish a suitable place of meeting for every branch in this mission, and in this the sisters are doing their full part. This year two chapels have been dedicated and property has been purchased in eight branches. The sisters have given dinners not only for their own members, but, in several instances, have served for various clubs and groups who have paid them well. They have held rummage sales to dispose of clothes collected from neighbors and friends as well as our own members. Prior to the sales, these articles are washed or cleaned and mended; they bring in a very good price and help those who need them. High-type character balls and parties which included wholesome and amusing games have placed the sisters in touch with many, thus affording opportunity to teach the gospel by example as well as precept. "We have in the mission, now, 260 local missionaries, many of them our Relief Society sisters. We feel thankful for this, for our younger mothers are gaining experience and knowledge that will qualify them to teach their children the gospel. We appreciate the excellent lessons given us by the General Board. They breathe the pure spirit of the gospel, impel us to action, and help to qualify us for real missionary work." Anna Duckett, secretary-treasurer of the Toyon (Redding, California) Branch Relief Society submitted last July the accompanying pictures and the following article by Eva S. Richards, a member: They Are Still Pioneers NOTES FROM THE FIELD 187 RELIEF SOCIETY SINGING MOTHERS OF SAVANNAH BRANCH (GEORGIA), SOUTHERN STATES MISSION Mission Relief Society President Effie Meeks says this is a splendid singing group which is a factor in maintaining interest in Relief Society work there. "In the shadow of snow-capped Mt. Shasta lies a minute branch of the Church?the Toyon Branch. It is situated on the hills and bluffs overlooking the Sacramento River and Shasta Dam, the world's second largest concrete structure. "The construction of this dam has brought people from all over the world, both as workers and visitors, and so the Toyon Branch is very cosmopolitan with representation from Canada, Australia, Germany, England, Sweden, Holland, as well as most of the states, from coast to coast. "The dam is fifteen miles from the nearest California town of any size, and its construction brought five or six thousand persons, some of them Mormons, into a wilderness of red clay, turpentine pines, manzanita, and poison oak. "Some of those who came early in the construction period spent that first miserable winter (three months of constant rain) in canvas tents; but spring comes early in this part of California and by April 1938, homes were started. Poison oak brush was plentiful and had to be cleared; even smoke from its burning carried contamination. Most of the work of clearing was done by women and children, for the work shifts on the dam changed every two weeks for some, while others worked a constant shift of day, swing or graveyard. "The homes usually had their beginning as one-room affairs, but as the men earned steadily, the homes grew. Wells were dug in very unpromising terrain, with accidents, and even casualties, a common occurrence. MEMBERS OF THE NEWLY ORGANIZED RELIEF SOCIETY AT PLYMOUTH. MASSACHUSETTS standing in front of the National Monument to the Forefathers which overlooks the bay. Left to right: Kate Burgesis, Marjorie Pickett, Elder Harold Dance, Estella Hutchins, and Elizabeth Pickett, Relief Society president. The other members unable to be present when picture was taken are Cora E. Bartlett and Cora Ann Glass. Delightful homes with electricity and modern conveniences are seen in the once-wilderness. And now, six years later, "The women worked long and hard to build these homes even though they knew they were to live there but a few years. Some of the women were sickly, some were old, some were having children, but they all had the desire for a home of their own. One family took the red clay, formed it into bricks, and, in one year, built for themselves a spacious six-room home that is now one of the social centers of the branch. "Gardens were made in the red clay by the women and children who carried fertilizer and sand from the river banks. Much to everyone's amazement, the gardens produced. The daughters of the pioneers are still helping to make a garden spot in the West, and are seeing that their children are raised in the culture of home and Church. "The Toyon Branch covers ten square miles. All of the visiting teachers are women who have families of small children, but their work has been done efficiently and on time. The loid anniversary of the organization of the Relief Society was observed March 17 by the Toyon Branch? Crystal candles, wild ferns, redbud and forsythia decorated the community house and an unforgettable program was presented. The war and the closing scenes at Shasta Dam are now sending this group on again to new fields, to new homes. They will carry their spirit of love and endeavor into new communities that have never heard of Mormons or witnessed their industry. "Good luck to you all and Godspeed?modern pioneer women." New England Mission ELDER FOLEY C. RICHARDS was auxiliary supervisor for the mission at the time he submitted the following account, last August: "Again the Relief Society plays the pioneer role in New England, this time in the 'Pilgrim Town,' Plymouth, Massachusetts, where America's forefathers settled three hundred and twenty-four years ago. "On May 23, 1944, a Relief Society was organized there?the first organization of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to be established in Plymouth. Under the direction of President William H. Reeder, Jr., Bertha S. Reeder, mission Relief Society president, and Elder Ted L. Miller, district president, this Society was organized with six members. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 189 FOUR RELIEF SOCIETIES OF THE WESTERN STATES MISSION (Pictures submitted by Luceal R. Curtis, recently released president of the Relief Societies of this mission.) Top row, left to right: Relief Society at Salida, Colorado; Relief Society at Fruita, Colorado, observes the 102d anniversary. Bottom row, left to right: Belle Fourche (South Dakota) Branch also celebrates 102d anniversary of Relief Society; Relief Society at Grand Junction, Colorado. Three of these were Latter-day Saints at the time; one has subsequently been baptized, and the other two are earnest investigators of the gospel. All are the fruits of recent missionary labor. 'These good sisters are enthusiastically meeting together each week, and the future of their group is promising indeed. Each has had to face the usual criticism which attends one who is willing to subscribe to 'Mormon' beliefs, and the Church can be justly proud of them for their Pilgrim spirit of loyalty to their convictions and for their service which makes possible this Latter-day Saint organization in New England's oldest town." Lola Humphreys, writing in the fall of 1944 as auxiliary supervisor, reported the successful Relief Society convention held September 2', at Cambridge, Massachusetts (the mission headquarters) for Relief Society officers. She continues: 'The careful planning which took place several weeks in advance, contributed greatly to the success of the conference which was very well attended by approximately 75 Relief Society officers. "During the forenoon session, a detailed and instructive outline of the duties of the officers was given by Mission Relief Society President Bertha S. Reeder. The remaining time was spent in the bearing of testimonies. At noon, a delicious buffet luncheon was served in one of the rooms of the Cambridge chapel from a table very attractively arranged with candles and flowers. In the afternoon, several talks were given in the homes of different Relief Society branches, and the Singing Mothers of Hartford, Connecticut, offered three beautiful numbers, at intervals.
"The enthusiasm and zeal with which Sister Reeder discussed the problems and with which she delivered her remarks were transferred to every one present. In spite of the fact that some of the members had had travel much more capable of carrying home the day before, they all felt much more capable of carrying on their duties after the convention."
A comprehensive mimeographed bulletin was distributed, carrying a concise and explicit digest of duties of officers and of new instructions, and also a narrative history of the several local Relief Societies in the mission for 1943-44, indicating the problems, activities, and accomplishments of each.
Hawaiian Mission
OLIVIA S. Waddoups, former Relief Society president of this mission, wrote in March 1944: "Brother Waddoups is superintendent of the Leper-asylum here at Kalaupapa. We find a wide field for service to these people who, though entirely confined for life within this area of about 12 square miles, are very happy, cheerful, and contented. They are also very war conscious, buying bonds and stamps to the extent of three times their quota. They are well taken care of by the Territory. We have a very modern hospital, two capable doctors whose wives are nurses in the hospital, five other nurses; 12 Catholic Sisters who manage the hospital, five other nuns; two Catholic priests; one Congregational minister, his wife and three members of his family; the plantation manager and planter; and the general manager for the United States Public Health Service; the Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church; four Brothers who are in charge of the Leper Home for Men; the Catholic, with Reverend Alice, a real Hawaiian lady, to look after her congregation; and our L.D.S. Church. The Elders visit us monthly, and we have a patient here who is the Presiding Elder. We have the smallest congregation but our members are very active and interested.
"The Relief Society sisters who are well enough to get out are very active. Last Sunday we held an anniversary meeting commemorating March 17. We all came dressed in white; there were 9 of us, and 12 young girls and 16 of the Priesthood. I am sure this was the most unique anniversary meeting in the Church. All but two of us are victims of the disease?myself and Sister Kalahau, a very little one, but we try to keep who is blind but who leads the group in their singing. In the group that furnished the singing there were four blind, two on crutches, and others who needed help to get around. But they sang beautifully, and bore testimony that the Lord was good, and kind, and that they were very grateful for the Relief Society organization.
"All in all, we have a little world, a very little one, but we try to keep happy, busy and helpful. We take every precaution possible. The Shape of Peace Eva Willes Wangsgaard I God of all men and nations, Light in Light, I, who am spent with fear and sorrowing, Ask for a ray to follow through this night Darkened by earthen gods to which men cling. There have been other years when I have seen Your star go down like ice from winter's bough, But never has my heart been caught between, And never was it torn as it is now. So soon we shall be called upon to stem The tides of war and plan for peace to be! That words once lifted over Bethlehem Take definite shape and purpose, we agree; But when the board of diplomats convenes, What shall our blueprint be? And what our means? II The concept of a structure strong enough To hold all men in concord that will last. To bind great powers, long inured to bluff. Into a kindred whole, is a plan so vast As to exceed the limits of the brain. This is a vision only dreamers see, A pact no sage has ever hoped to gain In any form of practicality. We have no precedent on which to build. It well may be that such a scheme may fail-So great the distance from the grandeur willed To grandeur sculptured to a working scale! THE RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE VOL. 32, NO. 3 MARCH 1945 Notice January 16, 1945 REPORTS reaching us indicate that there may be considerable numbers of our boys who are being returned from the various battle fronts in the world to the United States for treatment in hospitals. While our local Church officers in stakes and missions are taking such steps as are available to them to learn who these boys are in order that they may visit them and give such spiritual and other aid and comfort as may be possible, nevertheless, because not all of our boys have the  L. D. S." tag designation, and are generally listed merely as "Protestants" and not as members of our Church, it is not possible for our Church officers to be sure they locate and identify all of our wounded brethren. If the parents or wives of wounded men and women, if any, will send to the office of the First Presidency the names and addresses of their sons, husbands, or daughters who have been wounded and who are in this country for hospital treatment, we will see that their names reach the proper officer stake, ward, or mission so that such officer may be able to get in touch with the wounded and render such service as may be possible. THESE ARE THE THINGS I HOLD OF DEAREST WORTH Roberta Bates These are the things I hold of dearest worth; An evening sky of gold, And rose, and blue, The peace of wooded hills, Bird song, the murmuring of rills, Green lace upon each April twig, And, after showers, The scent of good black earth Mingling with flowers, And, best of all, as each day ends? Laughter and friends. I Remember? Elder Rodney B. Taylor
