RECENTLY while attending a reception in a Utah community, the discussion of the Women's Clubs came up. It seemed that most of the matrons present belonged to at least one club and some to more than one. These women were sort of the town's "four hundred," and spent considerable time discussing the merits and demerits of their respective clubs. Previously, a member of one had referred to another club as the "tea drinkers' club."
This sort of split the community wide open, and at this gathering the crack had not entirely closed. These women were considered good Latter day Saints, and I wondered why more of them did not give vent to their energies through the Relief Society, my pet organization of the Church. They seemed to crave excitement or glamour and to consider the Relief Society a little, should I say, too sedate for them.
In reading our Church history, one is particularly impressed by the number of doleful, mournful experiences our people passed through, leaving one to wonder if they ever had any pleasure or joy?and so with Relief Society. I don't believe the Society puts its "best foot forward." Let me tell you about one of the times when it entertained Nobility, and said, 'Let there be a feast,' and there was a feast."
While I don't profess to remember way back when knighthood was
recall the tail end of the Gay Nineties. Much has been written about the American way of life during this time, but, as Mormons, I suppose we were so busy cutting sagebrush, digging ditches and killing the snakes, that there was not anything very gay about it for us. However, this was not the case up in a little Mormon community in Canada. I'll never forget mother trying to dress up to look like a Gibson Girl!
We had only been up there a few, short years, and had succeeded in establishing an outpost of civilization; it was just a year or two before the turn of the century.
Most of the saints made this eight-hundred-mile trek by wagon train in quest of land. A few were called by the Church to colonize this prairie, and, rather hurriedly, others joined them.
For those who came in quest of land their every wish was satisfied. The prairie spread out for hundreds of miles with not a fence in sight. It was all covered with luxuriant wild hay. Why the grass grew so high that I, as a boy, couldn't find a bare spot on which to play marbles. Prowled up, this land would produce sixty bushels of wheat per acre; however some years we would have a drought, wouldn't raise anything. Most of us, coming from Utah, were irrigation-minded, and so we set about digging a canal and making an irrigation system. Nowadays we get the money from Government and call it a project; but in those days we had to do it ourselves, and we didn't have much with which to do it. Page 208 I REMEMBER 209 It was the first irrigation system in Canada, and caused favorable comments for us, as a people, throughout the country. This was indeed welcome as we had been followed by much ugly rumor from Utah.
Shortly after the completion of the canal, the bishopric received a letter saying that a person of noble lineage, who was also a very high Government official (actually a real English Lord) had condescended to pay us a visit ostensibly to inspect the canal, however we had a pretty good idea that we, as a people, would be scrutinized. At any rate, we were indeed thrilled at the thought of entertaining His Lordship.
Of course every privilege has its responsibilities. There was the problem of entertaining His Lordship which was brought very vividly to our attention by a little English doctor, recently from England, and who was about the only gentleman in our midst. While the saints bragged of having an M.D., it sort of had a hollow ring to us. It seems in those days, when an English boy graduated from a medical school, he invariably went to the colonies to "practice" on the colonials for a couple of years before returning to England to establish his profession. We knew we served more or less as guinea pigs to him, but we also knew that he was better than no doctor at all.
Upon hearing of His Lordship's intended visit, the little doctor was more or less terrified at the thought of us entertaining him. He knew only too well that our facilities for such an occasion were somewhat limited.
There were about fifty houses in the town, some of them being sod. There were also three business houses, a little general store, a blacksmith shop and?you would never guess the other so I'll tell you?a millinery shop! My father ran the general store; he used to advertise everything from candles to coffins but there wasn't much in the store. He used to make the coffins "on order" and I used to dread hearing of someone dying of pneumonia or being drowned to death by a horse, because it meant an all-night vigil for me, holding a light by which father might see to build the coffin. He had learned the carpenter trade working on the Manti Temple before going to Canada, so bending and gluing boards, lining them with white satin inside, and white figured plush outside, and mounting the silver handles seemed to be no effort for him. But as for me, I'd get sleepy and let the light fall over, and sometimes the chimney would fall off and smash on the floor?not only that, but the next day I'd be so sleepy I could not go to the funeral. The funeral was something not to be missed in a country where nothing ever happened except snow, wind, wheat blizzards and more wind. Among the bishopric they owned a pair of beautiful black percheron stallions imported from France. In the event of a funeral, they would be hitched together to draw the hearse. It was an inspiring sight. Sometimes right in the procession they would get in a fight, but several sharp cracks of the bishop's whip would fix them. It was a sight not to be missed by any boy.
And now for the millinery store. It seems the sisters could put up with sod houses, wind, snow, and mud, but they must have their hats. In those days a hat really meant something. A man's standing in the community might be judged by the number and quality of the ostrich plumes in his wife's hat. So you see, hats were important. Hence the millinery shop on this outpost of civilization held a high place.
Mother used to keep her hat on the highest shelf in the house, totalling two or each of us youngsters. About twice a year she made a trip to the hat shop to have the artificial fruit updated, the moths killed in the ostrich feathers, and perhaps a little bunch of flowers added. After a few years of this the hat was indescribable. When mother would reach up and get that hat down, we youngsters knew something big was "brewing," perhaps a long trip, a visit by a General Board member from Salt Lake City or, in this case, Nobility.
As the day for the reception drew near, the little doctor became a little more panicky. The millinery store became more a beehive of activity. The bishopric contented itself with writing the speech of welcome.
The speech of welcome, we considered a masterpiece. Nearly everyone in town having had a hand in writing it. It started out by saying how proud we were to be residents (not citizens) of Canada (most of us were homesick for Utah). Then it continued by telling His Lordship in a roundabout way what fine people we were, and ended by asking him for a telegraph line, a railroad, a bridge across the St. Mary's River, and a schoolhouse. It was deemed wise not to ask him for too much at one time.
Inasmuch as the doctor spoke very good "Oxford English," it was decided he should read the speech of welcome. Not only that, but the doctor owned a pair of highstepping English hackneys coach horses, and a rubber-tired rig. It was a luxurious outfit to be sure. So it was decided to have the doctor and his wife represent the official welcoming committee.
I might add that this pair of hackneys were fed from seed cold oats in slats in the roof of the hayloft. Their water was equally high, consequently their necks grew straight up. When traveling their heads were very much erect. Should they have been turned out to pasture they would have starved, as they couldn't get their heads down to the level of the grass. I suspect the little doctor of importing these horses to impress upon us that, after all, we were just "colonials."
Nevertheless, I, as a boy, tried checking up the load of my deliveries to see if I could look like the doctor's horses but I didn't accomplish much. The first trip out he fell down and broke the shafts of my delivery wagon.
The bishopric in those days was our police department, fire department, judge, jury and all, rolled into one. They gave the orders and we followed them out as best we could. We knew that inasmuch as the bishopric had brought us through this far, they would have no trouble in entertaining an English Lord. The really hard part of the reception, that is the giving of the banquet, was turned over to the Relief Society. Mother used to say it seemed no that when a job became too big for the bishopric, they turned it over to the Relief Society sisters.
The next few days drifted rather quietly along. The sisters checked their respective silverware and table linens. The bishopric put the finishing touches on the speech of welcome. The doctor and his two hackneys clipped and groomed to a state of perfection. Then another letter came saying that not only was His Lordship coming, he would be accompanied by his two beautiful daughters. To the bishopric this just meant the setting of two more plates; however, Father Bill, to realize the repercussions the news would cause among the sisters.
From reading English newspapers, the sisters knew full well the two ladies in question. They were the "toast of the Empire" and had been entertained extensively in the stately halls of Europe?Paris, Vienna?and other parts of the world. And further, the sisters felt that they would be met and would not face them in their present wardrobes, shabby from the trip to Canada.
After considerable tumult, meager savings were dug up, livestock sold, and a messenger was dispatched posthaste to the nearest city to replenish our stocks of apparel. The millinery shakes were long since bare.
Dressing up mother in those days was some job. Nearly every member of the family would help. There was the matter of the skirt, a much pleated, folded, voluminous affair of many layers. Mother, being the wife of the Store Owner who was also a High Councilman, had to dress like part. In this case she had gained a few pounds, and waist lines were supposed to be very small. We fit her to the dress, which was a simple matter. She meekly went without her dinner and then, by holding her breath and wiggling a few times while father drew the corset strings taut, we got her down to a size where she could get into her dress and the "Gibson Girl" effect. But some of the sisters required a complete new outfit.
For the few days before the big event, the town was a bedlam of activity. But the day before His Lordship's arrival found everything in readiness. Table linens all pressed, silverware highly polished, and wardrobes in tiptop shape. The place of meeting was the only large house in town, and, by opening some doors, two rooms could be made into one.
After the banquet, the plans called, for the townspeople to drop by in twos and threes to meet the party. After which, the doctor would drive them and the bishopric on an inspection tour of the canal. At long last, we were ready.
Early the next morning, the sisters could be seen converging on the reception house from all directions, carrying food, silverware, linen, flowers, dishes, and even furniture! It looked like a gala day except for the fact that a strong north wind had sprung up, which immediately was followed by a thunderous downpour of rain.
The rain being very flat, soon there were floods, and after a couple of hours of this deluge, the countryside took on the aspects of the Pacific Ocean. Every few blocks in this prairie were buffalo wallows, and, when wet, they were bottomless pits for a carriage. We began to realize that all our plans and preparations were all for naught if it did not stop raining, when up drew a carriage bearing some Church officials, members of a General Board from Utah. This sort of complicated things for the sisters, but at least if the rain did not abate, there would be someone to eat up this feast. Needless to say these Church officials were very pleasantly surprised, if not awestruck, when they came in and beheld this banquet room resplendent with gleaming white linen, highly polished silverware, the most delicate and lovely chinaware decorated with wild flowers, and at the end of the table a beautiful red plush chair standing. It was sort of a sentinel for all that was grand. I never knew that such things existed. Needless to say being a boy I was not privileged to try it out. Some sister evidently had smuggled that chair through from Salt Lake in the back of a covered wagon, perhaps unknown to her husband. Now here it stood in all its glory surrounded by a wilderness, waiting the touch of Nobility. As the morning drew on, the storm grew in intensity and assumed proportions of a cloudburst, and we began to realize that our chances of shaking the hand of Nobility were very slim indeed. By noon, the skies seemed to split wide open, the rain fell in sheets and the whole countryside was swimming. Luckily, we had these Church officials with us, and in those days they were always hungry, so that all our efforts wouldn't be wasted. Shortly after noon, we had several more terrific claps of thunder and the wind and rain continued. The bishopric went into a huddle with the Relief Society president. After all the dinner was ready to be served, it seemed the Relief Society, too, had a weakness for visiting General Board members, and Nobility or no Nobility, the dinner was served. Occupying the brilliant red plush chair in all his splendor was the bishop. He was flanked by his counselors, the Church officials, and a few prominent townspeople. Judging by the appetites of these visiting churchmen, they must have been on the road quite some time and perhaps traveling without purse or scrip. Eventually, the dinner was all eaten up, the sisters were congratulated on being such good cooks, after which the organ was rolled out and the brethren sang a few songs. However, having just partaken of such a sumptuous repast, they soon all settled down in chairs. The room echoed to their hymn "All Is Well, All Is Well" accompanied by the gentle patter of rain on the windows. The brethren were soon drowsy and some cat napping. It was a peaceful scene to behold indeed-"All Is Well, All Is Well" with the exception of one little lively girl of 'perhaps eight years with long spindly legs, who was upstairs, downstairs, hither, thither and yon all at the same time, followed by her two pigtails. I Remember 213 ON one of her numerous trips, she happened, by chance, to look out the window, and wheeled and screamed?"The Lord is coming, he's coming, he's coming?and he is bringing the whole British Army with him."
Instantly the whole house seemed to be electrified?British Army, British Army, the Lord?rain?mud?no dinner?these murmurs seemed to permeate the very atmosphere of the room. At this time His Lordship's appearance would be distracting enough, but a British Army besides, in fact any army, would be most unwelcome.
The saints swarmed to the windows, and sure enough coming across those golden, rain-soaked prairies, was a large body of horsemen. They were surely but slowly making their way straight for the house.
Only a few minutes previous, observing the bishop "enthroned" on that red plush chair, I had decided that when I grew up I wanted to be a bishop?but he was now a very distracted figure, which somewhat dampened my ardor?and the rest of the men looked as if their dinners had turned to lead.
Eventually, the party drew up on the front lawn?preceded by the little doctor bearing the speech of welcome, who took up his prearranged post on the porch.
His Lordship was thoroughly chilled and soaked and had to be pried out of the saddle, and he stomped into the house right past the doctor, speech of welcome and all.
His Lordship's beautiful daughters did not fare much better. He looked like two hens who had been out in the rain all night and were more to be pitied than envied.
It seemed that back at His Lordship's starting point that morning, Canadian officials had tried, in the face of such threatening weather, to prevail upon His Lordship not to attempt the trip, but he had merely shrugged his shoulders and inferred that the punctuality of the British Aristocracy was a thing not to be trifled with, and go he would, also his daughters.
Since a carriage would probably have stalled, they were all mounted. In normal weather an honor guard of perhaps twelve Royal Canadian Mounted Police would have accompanied persons of such lineage, but in this case the guard was not only doubled but trebled. We were indeed relieved to learn that "the whole British Army" had turned out to be mostly "Mounties" whom we had learned to know as protectors. As a boy, when I used to see one coming in his scarlet red coat I thought of all the bad things I'd ever done.
The Indians around us were taught that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police were the sons of the "Great White Father" (King of England) and if they displeased the Mounties, the "Great White Father" would wreak vengeance on their heads.
At this point, to use a military phrase, the Relief Society "took over." They immediately discerned that what His Lordship and ladies needed most was to get warm and have their coats and other clothes dried. They went into a huddle, and after a few hurried whispers they would now go to work with clocklike precision. Several slipped out the back door and began catching, killing, and frying chicken as they have never done before or since. Youngsters were sent around town to spread the alarm that we were all caught "flat footed." Other sisters set about drying His Lordship's tunic. Imagine the thrill the sisters in this outpost of civilization must have received in carefully untangling and drying the gold braid with which it was draped. One of the bishopric was dispatched posthaste to my father's store to see if, perchance, there was anything left in it after the previous dinner. He came in the store all excited and said, 'The Lord has come and there is not a bite in the house to eat! Have you anything?" My father replied, "Well I'm not surprised. I've been preaching for years if we were not more careful, the Savior would be dropping in on us and our lamps would be empty, and now this?" They went over the store shelves and discovered seventeen cans of oysters. They were stocked in the store for such occasions as wedding receptions, visiting apostles, or, in this case. Nobility. They were so expensive it was considered next door to sacrilege to use them for anything else. The Mounties dismounted and we turned their horses, all fifty head, into the host's haystacks. At least they were going to be well fed. The sisters hurriedly summoned Brother Fofalite, an Italian convert, a very fine musician and our choir leader. It was common knowledge about the town that the bishopric was not any too well pleased with Brother Fofalite?it was thought that he had the choir spend too much time on operatic arias and neglected such good old hymns as "Come, Come Ye Saints" and "High On the Mountain Tops." Nevertheless, Brother Fofalite was an expert musician, but in twenty years of farming, he was never known to raise a crop. The sisters soon had the banquet room again in order. With the splendor of the Mounties and their scarlet red uniforms, the atmosphere of the room took on a tone of brilliance. Eventually, His Lordship and Ladies regained their composure. Brother Fofalite appeared and accompanied on the organ a quartette of the sisters who sang, artistically, several difficult operatic renditions with which the Noble Party was very much surprised. Following this the town's "Oomph Girl" (yes, we had them in those days, too) sang a song in "rag time" which immensely pleased the Mounties, but evidently passed clear over His Lordship's head. By this time the rain having subsided, once more the sisters began converging on the banquet house from all parts of town, bringing even more dishes, furniture, and food. My admiration certainly went out to the Relief Society sisters, even though I knew full well we'd probably be on a mush and milk diet for the rest of the summer. The dinner was served in excellent style. The whole party was enthusiastically pleased with its reception "at the hands of the Mormons." The storm lifted and they were shown the canal and sent happily on their way. Thus the Mormons in Canada were judged and came through with flying colors. Thanks to the Relief Society and all seventeen cans of oysters, the day was saved, and we all lived happily ever afterwards. Mysteriously, that red plush chair was never seen again from that day to this. THE EASTER GIFT Grace M. Anniversary programs held throughout the Church testified to the love of the women for their organization and to the appreciation of the members of the Church for its efforts and accomplishments. The milestone reached on March 17, 1945 reminds us that Relief Society women have been working, serving, and studying together for 103 years. Their organization which was founded by a prophet of God on a broad, liberal, and adequate foundation has enabled them to meet assignments, requirements, and needs as they have occurred during this long period of time. Their experiences in this great. Society, dedicated to service and education, have been manifold, varied, and stimulating. In their labors they have learned how to be helpful in overcoming the difficulties and hardships of daily life, how to be helpful in solving problems incident to migration and pioneering, and how to be helpful in the adjustments and readjustments confronting individuals, families, and society in this great century of changes and developments resulting from discoveries, inventions and new and different conditions. And because of these activities which have constantly required strength, foresight, and ingenuity, and bePage218 cause of the intelligent study put forth in regular class work, learning how best to live and improve and enrich life, great development has come to these earnest and able workers. Thus it is seen that the Relief Society with its two-fold program has brought unusual opportunity to the women of the Church who have partaken of its advantages?opportunity for human service and opportunity for spiritual, intellectual, and emotional development. Through human service there has been engendered in their hearts a love and sympathy for others, the spirit of the golden rule, and that respect for human personality which was taught and practiced by the Master himself. And through regular educational study and research the lives of all who participated have been enriched. Their motto has been "The Glory of God Is Intelligence." To the women of the past we pay tribute. We are indebted to them for their vision, self-sacrificing efforts, and untiring labors. They have left us a rich heritage of faith and devotion to the Relief Society cause and to the restored gospel. Their testimonies of the divine mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith and their lives of service to the Church have been an inspiration and strength to us. To our co-workers, we offer congratulations for their like devotion and fortitude and for their great accomplishments in these days of apprehension and anxiety; Our prayer is that the Lord will bless and sustain them. And to the new and vigorous young leaders and workers who are coming into the service we say, look backward as well as forward; strive to properly evaluate the past and use it as a foundation for the future; and look forward with faith and a long view. And close the book?a tear left to my memory! Come in for Dessert Edna K. Ward THE homemaker today who must be hostess, cook, and maid is discovering many short cuts. Elaborate entertaining, and many-course, complicated meals went out with whipped cream and two-inch-thick steaks. Entertaining at all might require justification with so many homemakers working in war industries, busy in Red Cross canteens and sewing centers, serving as nurses' aids, and Gray Ladies. Returning home worn from the work of thee day, it requires courage to undertake the entertainment of our friends, and yet it is in times of stress that the companionship of the friends we see so seldom gives a lift to their morale and also to our own. If we can find a way to extend this courtesy with simplicity, consistent with rationing restrictions, we may foster the place of the home in the lives of our children and our friends. The trend of modern life in America has seemed to be away from the home and home interests. A dinner downtown or at some club, lunches and snacks at the drugstore for children as well as adults, has made the home mean less in the lives of many than it did in pioneer days. Home influence has decreased in direct proportion. No one has time for elaborate meals these days, but any meal should be worthy of the time you do give it. Badly planned meals are neither fun to prepare nor to eat; the food that appears daily on your table has to be Page 220 prepared by someone?and that someone must like what she is doing or the result will be far from satisfactory. For cooking is a peculiar occupation; to succeed, it must combine the best of both work and hobby. Only when cooking is viewed and approached as an art, which it is, is the burdensome repetition of the task turned into a self-gratifying performance. If you give it your heart and mind it can be as satisfying as painting pictures. Colorful china, linen, flowers from your garden are your "brushes and oils." With them you can create a background that makes even the simplest meal more glamorous. Foods in themselves have their own natural beauty. It's mixing them up?the reds, greens, yellows and whites? that gives your meals the most appetizing effect. Though the first impression of the dining table is only momentary, like a landscape just before sunset, the real fun is in creating it, and that will last until you create another. And there's more involved in it than just the "looks." Digestion depends upon the psychological reaction to our senses. Food that is well cooked and nicely served creates a healthful response in the attitude of the mind toward food. Emotional disturbances, fear, anger, anxiety, unrest banish appetite and stop the flow of the digestive juices. Happy influences, harmony, and beauty stimulate and promote these vital functions. COME IN FOR DESSERT TABLE SET FOR DESSERT And so in these busy times let's make home meals and company meals as simple and nutritious and beautiful as possible. To simplify home entertaining even more, it is possible to substitute a single course ?invite your friends for dessert. This touch of hospitality may be the occasion for a pleasant evening at home. It is hoped the suggestions given in this article may call forth original ideas that will be practical in the individual home. In planning an evening dessert, the invitation can be extended on short notice. A call on the telephone in the morning with the explanation that you are serving only dessert, and arranging an hour convenient to both hostess and guest, makes the occasion informal. The hour may be seven-thirty or eight o'clock. The planning must include the table setting and the menu, and perhaps the entertainment to follow. A small table may be set for four in the living room or the dining-room table may be used for a larger group. This is an invitation to use our choice pieces of china and silver ?the lovely compotes that mother prized or the chocolate pot that father brought from England or Germany when he returned from his mission. The table cover may be doilies or a luncheon cloth. The table mirror makes an attractive foundation for the display of a low centerpiece of ivy, leaf, berry, fruit or blossoms, each in season. Candles always add soft light to any evening meal. The service should be your nicest dessert plates or crystal sherbets with dessert spoons and forks. If hot chocolate or postum is used, the hostess may serve it at the table in either tea cups or after-dinner cups. The dessert also may be served by the host or hostess at the table. If one does not have help, to have everything on the table eliminates the confusion of someone leaving to bring things from the kitchen. Salted nuts are easily prepared at home and can be included, and homemade candy will always be appreciated. A few suggestive menus and recipes are given at the end of this article. A FTER lingering in the candle-light with good food and interesting conversation, the party may move to the living room and its cheery fire, or to the summer terrace. A planned evening might include discussion of current events, of civic problems or neighborhood projects, a book review, a report on a current magazine. Too often magazines in the home are read by only one member and the contents are unread by the others. Much valuable and interesting material is appearing in the better magazines today. If one or more of those present would undertake the review of some article of interest, it would be a stimulus to his own development and of interest to all. For those who like music, an evening of singing around the piano can be delightful, as can also be an evening spent in listening to recorded symphonies. If a guest is known to have a hobby, he may like to demonstrate it or discuss it, and games always make an evening enjoyable. Where cups are filled with wishes And these I daily scatter Of almost every kind. To help some soul along. This urn of pain, not pleasure, Is cherished fragile ware That holds my rarest treasure? The thoughts of friends who care. Perennials For All-Year Blossoming Hazel D. Moyle ?FLOWERS are among God's finest thoughts of beauty, taking form to gladden mortal gaze?bright gems of earth, in which, perchance, we see what Eden was?what Paradise may be!" These are the sentiments of a famous philosopher. Do we not, then, need flowers round our homes now as never before to comfort our spirits and give us hope and courage during these dark and busy war times? To me the meanest flower that blows can give? Thoughts that do often lie too deep for words. So said the poet Wordsworth. Let us not deprive ourselves of these lovely symbols of truth and beauty: every home should be a citadel of tranquillity ?during these troubled times, a place where our faith can be restored and our dreams renewed. We need our flower gardens in which to reclaim our ideals? but just how are we to find time to grow flowers, with the daily schedule of everyone already so overcrowded? The answer may be found in the planting of perennial flowers, for these plants are more or less permanent additions to the garden, once they have become established. The perennials live over year after year, many of them giving increasing bloom and beauty as the years Page 224 pass. They become old friends, reappearing with punctual precision each at its appointed time. We have chosen six well-known and easy-to-grow perennials as being essential for every garden, for by planting these six indispensables any home flower lover can enjoy bloom from spring until fall frosts arrive, and almost every back yard can find room and time to cultivate such a simple planting. While there are many other beautiful and worthy flowers that can be grown without a great deal of skill or extra work, we believe the following should be in every garden, not only for their desirability and beauty, but because they thrive with ordinary care in almost any location. The peony comes first on the list, because it is the earliest to bloom and also because of its long life. Last year I saw a fine old peony plant that had flowered each spring for thirty-five years without replanting ?and it was a garden in itself with its great mass of nearly fifty large double blooms. Remember, when you set out roots of the peony next fall (for this plant should never be planted in spring), that in order to enjoy such a performance of flowers, perhaps for the rest of your lifetime, you should see that it is planted correctly. Choose a spot in full sun, well PERENNIALS FOR ALL-YEAR BLOSSOMING 225 away from trees and overhanging growth, and dig a hole at least two feet deep. In the lower half of this hole you must place good, rich nourishment for those future years of bloom, old barnyard manure should be used generously and well tramped down. Then a layer of ordinary, good garden loam should be thrown in, upon which to set the roots. The pink buds or eyes should be placed one inch below the surface of the soil?this is of the greatest importance for too deep planting is the cause of many failures in blooming?firm this soil well before planting, so the new roots do not settle too deeply, then fill up the hole and water well. Choosing from the bewildering wealth of lovely and desirable varieties offered in the catalogues, becomes a major problem for any flower lover, but if you will use the rating of each kind as given by the American Peony Society, printed plainly in front of the description in all reliable catalogues, this will assist you greatly in making your choice. Good points are rated up to ten which would make a perfect flower. There are actually some with the highest rating of 9:09 that are now very cheap in price. Any variety receiving a rating of 8 or more should be a good choice, those of lower rating usually having some fault or other. Remember that by choosing early, midseason, and also late-blooming varieties, you can enjoy a long season of bloom, and, if you have room, do include that grand old flower, the Decoration Day peony, officinalis. This is available in pink, red and white. It is a flower of satiny luster and it also blooms two weeks or more before other varieties. The second perennial on our list is the iris.... And who would do without this wonderful flower! Designed just for the busy gardener, this accepts our hot, dry climate with amiability, demanding little care. Ordinary unmanured soil suits it well, its one absolute requirement being an open, sunny situation. In order to bring out the full beauty of the lovely, silken iris flower, the plants should be well watered while buds are forming, and during the flowering. (You can prolong the blooms and make them much larger, too, by watering generously at this time.) But for the rest of the year they can stand neglect. If you have not grown any of the newer varieties of iris, then you have a treat in store. Every garden should find room for the exquisite, great, orchid-like bloom of the variety "William Mohr," which can now be purchased for a mere trifling twenty-five cents. A still newer and lovelier variety in named "Ormohr," costing a dollar or more. Iris experts have recently produced one named "El-mohr," the same breath-taking size and beauty, but taller and of a deeper colored mulberry-purple. Being a rare, new type (producing a seven-inch flower), this demands a high price, however, in a few years, we can all enjoy it at a reasonable price. "Purissima," a beauteous white variety, and "Wabash," notable prizewinner with great blue-purple falls and white standards, also deserve every gardener's consideration ?but choose for yourself according 
226 to your own tastes and purse and space.
This can be transplanted at almost any season, even when in full bloom. So if you see some flower that you covet, this coming June, there is no reason why you should not take a start home with you.
THE third perennial on our list is the flaunting 'oriental' poppy. For sheer glamour and breath-taking beauty, one need look no farther than the new varieties of this fine old flower with their beautiful, silken flowers of such melting colors as coral, geranium-pink, flame, cerise and shell-pink. The finest of all is named 'Wonderkininde,' a great flower of lustrous watermelon pink, as large as a dinner plate.
This plant has one strict requirement: it should be planted during its dormant season, which is from August until late fall. Spring planting brings only failure, so be sure to order your plants when the poppies bloom during late May and June. Once established, there are few more faithful garden subjects, and their requirements are just ordinary garden care.
July brings the splendid towers of blue of the modern delphiniums. Even one or two of these spike-like flowers can lift any garden out of the ordinary. While these proud blooms require a little more attention in staking and watering than others of our list, they are well worth the trouble. A lower and more spreading type named 'Delphinium Belladonna' can be grown with less care, and is longer lived than the tall new hybrids. Both are lovely.
The midsummer phlox is number five on our list?where could we find a finer flower for this time of year? The great, magnificent heads of bloom can now be had in a bewildering variety of vibrant and flaming colors. In cooler sections of Utah and Idaho this perennial fairly outdoes itself. Plant your phlox in most ground where they receive morning sun, but where they are shaded in the late afternoon. And if yours is a hot, dry garden, prepare the ground well with very old manure, then mulch the surface each spring with peat moss, lawn clippings, or more old manure. And if the flower heads are clipped off as soon as they have faded, others will form just below, and you can enjoy phlox for many weeks. Soak the plants deeply by allowing the hose to run without a nozzle during the blooming period.
Our last flower is the chrysanthemum, for this is the queen of all fall flowers and one that brings an entire new season of beauty into your garden. Recent hybridizing has brought us many new types and varieties, many being early enough to bloom and valuable in colder sections where ordinary chrysanthemums seldom flower. The University of Minnesota has worked for years on an early and extra-hardy strain, and a splendid list of kinds and colors of these are now available as well as many other desirable new kinds and colors.
The cushion mums, growing into a low, bush-like plant, each so floriferous that one plant becomes a garden in itself, are also brilliant and lovely. One can now have chrysanthemums of almost any color except blue, and the taller Chrysanthemums will do in just PERENNIALS FOR ALL-YEAR BLOSSOMING 227 ordinary good garden loam, but will pay handsome dividends in deep color and profuse bloom if the plants are given a little extra feeding during the growing year. This is easily done by applying a one-inch mulch of old, well-rotted manure (cow manure is best) around each plant at two-or-three week intervals. First cultivate the surface, then apply the manure, and follow immediately with a thorough, deep soaking, preferably with the nozzle of the hose removed. Do not sprinkle as this sometimes brings mildew. This mulch helps to keep the soil moist at the same time it supplies mild feeding. With this, our sixth perennial, the year is brought to a close with a brilliant fanfare, a fitting farewell to summer. And the joyous part is that these same plants do not die, but when spring once more returns they arise from their winter's sleep in response to some mysterious call? The gentle heat and soft repeated rains, Make the green blood to dance within their veins, Then, at the call, emboldened out they come. And swell the gems, and burst the narrow room; Broader and broader yet their blooms display, Salute the welcome sun and entertain the day, "Spring"?Dryden THE RESTLESS HEART Courtney E. And Once to Grandma Doris Palmer GRANDMA Stanton looked wistfully after the mail truck, fading fast disappearing down the dusty street. Grandma had walked the six blocks to the little post office in the heart of the small rural town of Lakeview, for the past five days, and had received no word of any kind from any of her five children. They were all married now, and had families of their own. This was the first year Grandma hadn't had birthday cards and gifts sent in plenty of time for her birthday. Now only one short day remained.
"I'm sure there will be something tomorrow, Grandma," Donald Harmon, postmaster and owner of the small grocery store adjoined, comforted her, "I'll bet your birthday will be remembered all right."
"Oh, I am sure it will," Grandma tried to reassure herself, "but I never bet in my life, Donald Harmon."
"Well, you would lose this bet," Donald called after Grandma's retreating figure. Everyone in Lakeview loved and understood Grandma Stanton. She always put on a brave front, and underneath had a sweet and sensitive nature.
There was no time to stop and talk with friends who called to her as she hurried home?not this morning. Granddad was getting the ground ready for the vegetable and flower garden. They were late in getting it planted anyway.
Grandma viewed their large, comfortable home with mixed feelings as she approached. The house was of colonial design, set back from the road amongst a group of oak and fragrant locust trees. To the right was the family orchard. The trees were already covered with pink and white blossoms. On the left was the vegetable garden. Two cedar pines decorated the front gate, one on each side of the walk.
The Browns lived one block nearer town, and the Hudsons two blocks farther north. The Hudsons paddled the three Jersey cows Grandma insisted on keeping. She did love to take care of milk, and make her own yellow butter and creamy buttermilk.
Grandma and Granddad had been among the first settlers in Lakeview, and had watched its growth with pride and interest; but they had sold their farm to the Hudsons when the two boys had chosen other professions, two of the girls had married business men and Mary had married a young doctor in the nearby college town. It was there she had attended school and won a teacher's certificate, only to get married the following season. Now the old house was empty of young voices.
Granddad was leaning on the plough handles waiting for Grandma's approval of the ground. Maybe it was not deep enough, and Granddad was not taking any chances. His hat was pushed back from his ruddy face, disclosing the shock of gray curly hair that was so like a little boy's. His bright blue eyes were twinkling at Grandma as she came through the gate."No packages, Maw?" he questioned, glancing at her empty hands. "Not a blessed thing, Dad. Do you suppose something's the matter with any of them?"
"Now, don't go to supposin', or you'll have 'em all sick," Granddad interrupted. "Don't some of the teachers graduate next month?"
Grandma thought a minute. "Why I believe Lanie graduates from high school and little Lennie from grammar."
"Well, em's mighty dang expensive to graduate 'em nowadays, Maw. Jane says they reckon on presents and a lot of fine new clothes."
Grandma sighed. "Yes, I know, Dad. It's not like when we went to school. We were only too glad to be able to go. Maybe that's why Ellen and I never bought 'em presents, but they could write a fine long letter. Mary was coming to visit next month, or as soon as school was out and John could get away." Grandma was trying to find excuses for her children and, as usual, she succeeded. So now she brushed the little uneasy feeling behind her, and proceeded to boss Granddad and the making of her garden.
"Dad, can we get the vegetables planted this afternoon? Dear, dear, there is so much to do. We will just have to," Grandma decided. "I can plant my flowers in the morning."
Granddad nodded his gray head and pushed his hat to a perilous position, squinting at the heavens. Off to the southwest were angry-looking clouds tumbling over each other as though driven by the thunder that could be heard ever louder as the men plowed.
"Thunder shower comin', Maw. Better get your little chicks in. It'll be here soon. It'll be the very thing for the garden. Get up, Dane," he clucked to the big gray horse, "Let's get this finished."
Grandma raised her pleasant, seamed face to the growing wind and sniffed it eagerly. You could already smell the rain. That sweet, earthy smell. It was on just such a night that many years ago, it seemed to Grandma, that Robert came running in, his round face dirty and excited. "Mother! Jane said I could just taste the dirt after a rain. She told a lie didn't she, Mom?" He had been disappointed when she had told him that Jane just thought she could, because the smell was so fresh and strong. Grandma smiled at the remembrance.
Lennie's mischievous face then came before her, as he hurried to the chicken yard. His curly, white head could be seen now and then of the day bobbing up and down amongst the chickens. He would delight in these little chicks, she thought, picking up the different colored little bits of fluff, and putting them in the box with their mother where they chirped contentedly. Somehow Lennie never did hurt them or hold them too tight after Robert did. She had always told him he should raise chickens.
Grandma's thoughts often strayed back to the time when her family was at home. As she hurried about the neat, sunny kitchen preparing the simple dinner, she wondered if Mary still loved home-cured ham. She placed thick slices of it beside the pitcher of creamy milk. Robert used to drink milk until she couldn't see how he managed to eat anything else. It wasn't so long ago that Lennie, home from college, had put his arms around her, giving her a "bear hug," as he called it. He had bragged that no one in the world could turn out such nifty-tasting bread out of common flour. If she could just have them all back together again to cook for and pamper, it would be heavenly. She brushed away an obstinate tear as she went to call Granddad.
It sprinkled a little as they were eating "It's just teasing," Granddad said, "we'll get a good one tonight. Be better for the garden anyway. It might have been too wet to plant this afternoon."
That evening after the garden was planted and the chores and supper over with, Granddad let the paper he was reading fall to the floor and looked at Grandma with twinkling eyes. Granddad's eyes were always twinkling lately, more than usual it seemed.
"Anna Brown was over this morning while you was uptown," Granddad remarked with an air of great importance. "She wanted to know if you would save all your cream tonight and in the mornin'. She went on up to Hudson's to see if they would have some."
"My lands, what's she goin' to do with all that cream?" Grandma's eyes were wide with wonder.
"Well, she said some of her school chums were comin' on a visit, and she wanted something nice and coolin'. So I reckon she is making ice cream. If'n, it sure would taste fine these warm days."
"Yes, it would, Dad. We might make some. If Ann didn't want more'n half, there would be plenty for Grandma's birthday tomorrow. Grandma was wondering who Anna's chums were that were coming. It was a shame the girls couldn't come now, too. Especially Mary. She would know them all. Her thoughts went back to their neglect of her birthday. It was the first time they had forgotten it since they had all left home.
THE Stantons were almost always up with the sun, but Grandma beat the sun this fresh spring morning. It had rained during the night and everything was washed clean, and was being brushed with gold as the sun sent its golden rays among the scented trees. The birds acted as though they would burst their throats with the silvery notes they spilled forth to gladden the world. Grandma's heart was light as she prepared breakfast, pausing now and then to breathe deeply of the clean, fragrant air. Granddad came in with the milk and admonished Grandma not to forget the cream Ann wanted. ?Too wet to plant your flowers this morning, Maw. I do not want to plant your flowers this morning, Maw. Reckon I could plant 'em this afternoon, if you won't be too blamed busy," Granddad offered.
"Well, I'll just keep the few dahlia bulbs I've got and you can plant the rest. I'll show you where I want them before I go for the mail. Maybe I'll stop a minute at Ann's on my way back."
"I wouldn't stop there if I was you, Maw. Ann will be busy, I reckon, with the party for her friends."
"Well my lands, that's why I'm stoppin', Maybe I can find out who it is comin'," Grandma was surprised at Granddad's lack of interest in the coming friends. Ann had always been like one of their own daughters.
"Ain't you goin' to make a cake today, Maw? One of them fruit cakes the boys like so. You could make a cake for your birthday while I'm plantin' your garden for you." Granddad was one of the boys who liked the cake he suggested.
"It looks like I would have to, if I get one," Grandma said fretfully. "Ann sent me one last birthday, but ain't five new with her friends today."
Grandma had to wait a few minutes for the mail truck to arrive. There was no one else in the post-office but herself. Donald Harmon and herself. She fidgeted around looking at the labels on the canned goods, until Donald had begun to sort the mail.
"I guess no one else is so anxious there as me," Grandma remarked, a sensitive smile playing around her mouth.
"It's been kinda quiet all mornin' here," Donald answered, flipping the list he'd left over, hating to look into the eager eyes watching him so expectantly. "I guess there ain't anything Grandma. There was no packages a'tall this morning, ain't there anything else you want?" he questioned, trying not to notice the tears Grandma was dabbing at furtively.
"Yes, I want to get some currants and citrus. Oh yes, and some brown sugar," she replied, trying to steady her voice. Pshaw, she never was good at hiding her feelings.
"Sounds like a cake was in the makin', Gram-ma. If it's as good as the last cake you brought to Rilla's wedding social, I'll sure be good." "Now, Donald, you are just try-in' to make me feel good," Grandma scolded, picking up her packages. "Maybe I'll send you a piece of it," she called back from the door.
Grandma was feeling pretty blue as she made her way back. She left old and out of everything.
A sound of great activity met her as she paused at the little iron gate leading into Anna's. Maybe Ann would like the ice cream when she was so busy. Grandma hesitated, one hand on the latch. Curiosity got the better of her, however, so she marched up and knocked on the door. There was a sudden quiet as Ann came and opened the door. "Why, hello Grandma," Ann said loudly. "I never expected to see you over here. I thought you were planting flowers." "It was too wet this morning and Dad's plantin' some this afternoon," Grandma explained shortly.
"Come on in, Grandma," Ann invited after a hasty glance over her shoulder.
"I was wonderin' if I couldn't come in," Grandma said, her quick eyes taking in the drops of colored frosting scattered on the dining table.
"Hello, Grandma," Helen Larsen cried, running up and kissing Grandma's withered cheek. "I'm coming over tonight, if I get through helping Ann in time. It's your birthday today, isn't it?" Ann broke in. "Mary mentioned it in her last letter. Let's see, that's been two weeks ago," she said as though thinking. "We should have had a party on Grandma, Helen," Ann said indignantly.
"At my age?" Grandma scoffed. "I?m gettin? too old for such doings." "Wait till I get my hat, Grandma, and I'll go with you and get my cream." Ann ran into the bedroom as Grandma started collecting her bundles. "You know, I never had a party in my life," Grandma confided as she placed the jug of cream in Ann's hands. "Why, Grandma, honestly? We will certainly have to give you one sometime," Ann promised, a slight flush stealing over her face. "Now Ann, I ain't askin' for a party, but I have always wanted one," she added wistfully, a faraway look in her e3'es. "Well, I must hurry." Ann quickly dropped the money in Grandma's hand. "Now don't forget, you have a party coming sometime in the future. Grandma," and Ann's face wore a happy smile. Granddad said he had to go uptown in the late afternoon and wanted to know if Grandma was going with him. "Well, I was going to see Grandma Hudson but I'm kinda tired, so guess I'll just rest a bit," she replied. "I reckon you better Maw, the Larsens are comin' over tonight and you don't want to feel tired." Granddad got home just in time to milk. It was growing dark when he finally came in for supper, making much over the fruit cake Grandma had placed in front of them. "It's not my birthday. Maw," Granddad teased her. "Oh hush, Dad." Grandma didn't want to be reminded of it. She couldn't help feeling the children had neglected her. Grandma and Granddad were quietly reading when a loud knocking and shuffling of feet brought Grandma to the door. The sight that met her startled eyes nearly made her faint. The whole front porch was crowded with people. In the front of the group were her own five children, loaded down with bundles. Packed around them was the whole town, it seemed to Grandma. The words "Mother" and "Surprise" were mingled together as Grandma was picked up and placed inside, to be instantly smothered with arms from all directions. Everyone began talking at once, trying to answer the puzzled questions Grandma couldn't keep from asking. "You tell her, Anna," Mary called above the excited crowd. "Well," Anna began, "Mary and the rest of your family had the idea of bringing a surprise party on you, and asked Granddad to meet them on the 5:30 stage. That is all there is to it, except I was afraid you would catch on when you were at my place today. We were decorating the birthday cake when you walked up to the porch, and I had to make you wait at the door while Helen whisked it into the kitchen." "But how could you children get away alone?" Grandma wanted to know further. "Well, we just decided it would be nice to be home together again, so we just left our present sweethearts for our former one!" Lennie broke in, sitting with one arm around his happy mother. "We can only stay a few days, except for Mary. She is staying and John is coming and bringing the youngsters in a few days, for a longer visit." 241 "I think we should sing some songs to start the evening right and bring back old times," Robert suggested, getting up and motioning Ellen to the piano. "Let's begin with 'When You and I Were Young, Maggie' and say 'Mary' instead of 'Maggie' when we come to it."
"Oh I don't believe I can stand much more," Grandma said in a shaky voice.
After a few songs and games, Grandma looked up to find Granddad's twinkling eyes on her. "Dad, you old cheater, did you know all about this and never told me?"

THESE ARE THE THINGS I HOLD OF DEAREST WORTH Roberta Bates These are the things I hold of dearest worth; An evening sky of gold, And rose, and blue, The peace of wooded hills, Bird song, the murmuring of rills, Green lace upon each April twig, And, after showers, The scent of good black earth Mingling with flowers, And, best of all, as each day ends? Laughter and friends. I Remember? Elder Rodney B. Taylor

RECENTLY while attending a reception in a Utah community, the discussion of the Women's Clubs came up. It seemed that most of the matrons present belonged to at least one club and some to more than one. These women were sort of the town's "four hundred," and spent considerable time discussing the merits and demerits of their respective clubs. Previously, a member of one had referred to another club as the "tea drinkers' club."
This sort of split the community wide open, and at this gathering the crack had not entirely closed. These women were considered good Latter day Saints, and I wondered why more of them did not give vent to their energies through the Relief Society, my pet organization of the Church. They seemed to crave excitement or glamour and to consider the Relief Society a little, should I say, too sedate for them.
In reading our Church history, one is particularly impressed by the number of doleful, mournful experiences our people passed through, leaving one to wonder if they ever had any pleasure or joy?and so with Relief Society. I don't believe the Society puts its "best foot forward." Let me tell you about one of the times when it entertained Nobility, and said, 'Let there be a feast,' and there was a feast."
While I don't profess to remember way back when knighthood was
recall the tail end of the Gay Nineties. Much has been written about the American way of life during this time, but, as Mormons, I suppose we were so busy cutting sagebrush, digging ditches and killing the snakes, that there was not anything very gay about it for us. However, this was not the case up in a little Mormon community in Canada. I'll never forget mother trying to dress up to look like a Gibson Girl!
We had only been up there a few, short years, and had succeeded in establishing an outpost of civilization; it was just a year or two before the turn of the century.
Most of the saints made this eight-hundred-mile trek by wagon train in quest of land. A few were called by the Church to colonize this prairie, and, rather hurriedly, others joined them.
For those who came in quest of land their every wish was satisfied. The prairie spread out for hundreds of miles with not a fence in sight. It was all covered with luxuriant wild hay. Why the grass grew so high that I, as a boy, couldn't find a bare spot on which to play marbles. Prowled up, this land would produce sixty bushels of wheat per acre; however some years we would have a drought, wouldn't raise anything. Most of us, coming from Utah, were irrigation-minded, and so we set about digging a canal and making an irrigation system. Nowadays we get the money from Government and call it a project; but in those days we had to do it ourselves, and we didn't have much with which to do it. Page 208 I REMEMBER 209 It was the first irrigation system in Canada, and caused favorable comments for us, as a people, throughout the country. This was indeed welcome as we had been followed by much ugly rumor from Utah.
Shortly after the completion of the canal, the bishopric received a letter saying that a person of noble lineage, who was also a very high Government official (actually a real English Lord) had condescended to pay us a visit ostensibly to inspect the canal, however we had a pretty good idea that we, as a people, would be scrutinized. At any rate, we were indeed thrilled at the thought of entertaining His Lordship.
Of course every privilege has its responsibilities. There was the problem of entertaining His Lordship which was brought very vividly to our attention by a little English doctor, recently from England, and who was about the only gentleman in our midst. While the saints bragged of having an M.D., it sort of had a hollow ring to us. It seems in those days, when an English boy graduated from a medical school, he invariably went to the colonies to "practice" on the colonials for a couple of years before returning to England to establish his profession. We knew we served more or less as guinea pigs to him, but we also knew that he was better than no doctor at all.
Upon hearing of His Lordship's intended visit, the little doctor was more or less terrified at the thought of us entertaining him. He knew only too well that our facilities for such an occasion were somewhat limited.
There were about fifty houses in the town, some of them being sod. There were also three business houses, a little general store, a blacksmith shop and?you would never guess the other so I'll tell you?a millinery shop! My father ran the general store; he used to advertise everything from candles to coffins but there wasn't much in the store. He used to make the coffins "on order" and I used to dread hearing of someone dying of pneumonia or being drowned to death by a horse, because it meant an all-night vigil for me, holding a light by which father might see to build the coffin. He had learned the carpenter trade working on the Manti Temple before going to Canada, so bending and gluing boards, lining them with white satin inside, and white figured plush outside, and mounting the silver handles seemed to be no effort for him. But as for me, I'd get sleepy and let the light fall over, and sometimes the chimney would fall off and smash on the floor?not only that, but the next day I'd be so sleepy I could not go to the funeral. The funeral was something not to be missed in a country where nothing ever happened except snow, wind, wheat blizzards and more wind. Among the bishopric they owned a pair of beautiful black percheron stallions imported from France. In the event of a funeral, they would be hitched together to draw the hearse. It was an inspiring sight. Sometimes right in the procession they would get in a fight, but several sharp cracks of the bishop's whip would fix them. It was a sight not to be missed by any boy.
And now for the millinery store. It seems the sisters could put up with sod houses, wind, snow, and mud, but they must have their hats. In those days a hat really meant something. A man's standing in the community might be judged by the number and quality of the ostrich plumes in his wife's hat. So you see, hats were important. Hence the millinery shop on this outpost of civilization held a high place.
Mother used to keep her hat on the highest shelf in the house, totalling two or each of us youngsters. About twice a year she made a trip to the hat shop to have the artificial fruit updated, the moths killed in the ostrich feathers, and perhaps a little bunch of flowers added. After a few years of this the hat was indescribable. When mother would reach up and get that hat down, we youngsters knew something big was "brewing," perhaps a long trip, a visit by a General Board member from Salt Lake City or, in this case, Nobility.
As the day for the reception drew near, the little doctor became a little more panicky. The millinery store became more a beehive of activity. The bishopric contented itself with writing the speech of welcome.
The speech of welcome, we considered a masterpiece. Nearly everyone in town having had a hand in writing it. It started out by saying how proud we were to be residents (not citizens) of Canada (most of us were homesick for Utah). Then it continued by telling His Lordship in a roundabout way what fine people we were, and ended by asking him for a telegraph line, a railroad, a bridge across the St. Mary's River, and a schoolhouse. It was deemed wise not to ask him for too much at one time.
Inasmuch as the doctor spoke very good "Oxford English," it was decided he should read the speech of welcome. Not only that, but the doctor owned a pair of highstepping English hackneys coach horses, and a rubber-tired rig. It was a luxurious outfit to be sure. So it was decided to have the doctor and his wife represent the official welcoming committee.
I might add that this pair of hackneys were fed from seed cold oats in slats in the roof of the hayloft. Their water was equally high, consequently their necks grew straight up. When traveling their heads were very much erect. Should they have been turned out to pasture they would have starved, as they couldn't get their heads down to the level of the grass. I suspect the little doctor of importing these horses to impress upon us that, after all, we were just "colonials."
Nevertheless, I, as a boy, tried checking up the load of my deliveries to see if I could look like the doctor's horses but I didn't accomplish much. The first trip out he fell down and broke the shafts of my delivery wagon.
The bishopric in those days was our police department, fire department, judge, jury and all, rolled into one. They gave the orders and we followed them out as best we could. We knew that inasmuch as the bishopric had brought us through this far, they would have no trouble in entertaining an English Lord. The really hard part of the reception, that is the giving of the banquet, was turned over to the Relief Society. Mother used to say it seemed no that when a job became too big for the bishopric, they turned it over to the Relief Society sisters.
The next few days drifted rather quietly along. The sisters checked their respective silverware and table linens. The bishopric put the finishing touches on the speech of welcome. The doctor and his two hackneys clipped and groomed to a state of perfection. Then another letter came saying that not only was His Lordship coming, he would be accompanied by his two beautiful daughters. To the bishopric this just meant the setting of two more plates; however, Father Bill, to realize the repercussions the news would cause among the sisters.
From reading English newspapers, the sisters knew full well the two ladies in question. They were the "toast of the Empire" and had been entertained extensively in the stately halls of Europe?Paris, Vienna?and other parts of the world. And further, the sisters felt that they would be met and would not face them in their present wardrobes, shabby from the trip to Canada.
After considerable tumult, meager savings were dug up, livestock sold, and a messenger was dispatched posthaste to the nearest city to replenish our stocks of apparel. The millinery shakes were long since bare.
Dressing up mother in those days was some job. Nearly every member of the family would help. There was the matter of the skirt, a much pleated, folded, voluminous affair of many layers. Mother, being the wife of the Store Owner who was also a High Councilman, had to dress like part. In this case she had gained a few pounds, and waist lines were supposed to be very small. We fit her to the dress, which was a simple matter. She meekly went without her dinner and then, by holding her breath and wiggling a few times while father drew the corset strings taut, we got her down to a size where she could get into her dress and the "Gibson Girl" effect. But some of the sisters required a complete new outfit.
For the few days before the big event, the town was a bedlam of activity. But the day before His Lordship's arrival found everything in readiness. Table linens all pressed, silverware highly polished, and wardrobes in tiptop shape. The place of meeting was the only large house in town, and, by opening some doors, two rooms could be made into one.
After the banquet, the plans called, for the townspeople to drop by in twos and threes to meet the party. After which, the doctor would drive them and the bishopric on an inspection tour of the canal. At long last, we were ready.
Early the next morning, the sisters could be seen converging on the reception house from all directions, carrying food, silverware, linen, flowers, dishes, and even furniture! It looked like a gala day except for the fact that a strong north wind had sprung up, which immediately was followed by a thunderous downpour of rain.
The rain being very flat, soon there were floods, and after a couple of hours of this deluge, the countryside took on the aspects of the Pacific Ocean. Every few blocks in this prairie were buffalo wallows, and, when wet, they were bottomless pits for a carriage. We began to realize that all our plans and preparations were all for naught if it did not stop raining, when up drew a carriage bearing some Church officials, members of a General Board from Utah. This sort of complicated things for the sisters, but at least if the rain did not abate, there would be someone to eat up this feast. Needless to say these Church officials were very pleasantly surprised, if not awestruck, when they came in and beheld this banquet room resplendent with gleaming white linen, highly polished silverware, the most delicate and lovely chinaware decorated with wild flowers, and at the end of the table a beautiful red plush chair standing. It was sort of a sentinel for all that was grand. I never knew that such things existed. Needless to say being a boy I was not privileged to try it out. Some sister evidently had smuggled that chair through from Salt Lake in the back of a covered wagon, perhaps unknown to her husband. Now here it stood in all its glory surrounded by a wilderness, waiting the touch of Nobility. As the morning drew on, the storm grew in intensity and assumed proportions of a cloudburst, and we began to realize that our chances of shaking the hand of Nobility were very slim indeed. By noon, the skies seemed to split wide open, the rain fell in sheets and the whole countryside was swimming. Luckily, we had these Church officials with us, and in those days they were always hungry, so that all our efforts wouldn't be wasted. Shortly after noon, we had several more terrific claps of thunder and the wind and rain continued. The bishopric went into a huddle with the Relief Society president. After all the dinner was ready to be served, it seemed the Relief Society, too, had a weakness for visiting General Board members, and Nobility or no Nobility, the dinner was served. Occupying the brilliant red plush chair in all his splendor was the bishop. He was flanked by his counselors, the Church officials, and a few prominent townspeople. Judging by the appetites of these visiting churchmen, they must have been on the road quite some time and perhaps traveling without purse or scrip. Eventually, the dinner was all eaten up, the sisters were congratulated on being such good cooks, after which the organ was rolled out and the brethren sang a few songs. However, having just partaken of such a sumptuous repast, they soon all settled down in chairs. The room echoed to their hymn "All Is Well, All Is Well" accompanied by the gentle patter of rain on the windows. The brethren were soon drowsy and some cat napping. It was a peaceful scene to behold indeed-"All Is Well, All Is Well" with the exception of one little lively girl of 'perhaps eight years with long spindly legs, who was upstairs, downstairs, hither, thither and yon all at the same time, followed by her two pigtails. I Remember 213 ON one of her numerous trips, she happened, by chance, to look out the window, and wheeled and screamed?"The Lord is coming, he's coming, he's coming?and he is bringing the whole British Army with him."
Instantly the whole house seemed to be electrified?British Army, British Army, the Lord?rain?mud?no dinner?these murmurs seemed to permeate the very atmosphere of the room. At this time His Lordship's appearance would be distracting enough, but a British Army besides, in fact any army, would be most unwelcome.
The saints swarmed to the windows, and sure enough coming across those golden, rain-soaked prairies, was a large body of horsemen. They were surely but slowly making their way straight for the house.
Only a few minutes previous, observing the bishop "enthroned" on that red plush chair, I had decided that when I grew up I wanted to be a bishop?but he was now a very distracted figure, which somewhat dampened my ardor?and the rest of the men looked as if their dinners had turned to lead.
Eventually, the party drew up on the front lawn?preceded by the little doctor bearing the speech of welcome, who took up his prearranged post on the porch.
His Lordship was thoroughly chilled and soaked and had to be pried out of the saddle, and he stomped into the house right past the doctor, speech of welcome and all.
His Lordship's beautiful daughters did not fare much better. He looked like two hens who had been out in the rain all night and were more to be pitied than envied.
It seemed that back at His Lordship's starting point that morning, Canadian officials had tried, in the face of such threatening weather, to prevail upon His Lordship not to attempt the trip, but he had merely shrugged his shoulders and inferred that the punctuality of the British Aristocracy was a thing not to be trifled with, and go he would, also his daughters.
Since a carriage would probably have stalled, they were all mounted. In normal weather an honor guard of perhaps twelve Royal Canadian Mounted Police would have accompanied persons of such lineage, but in this case the guard was not only doubled but trebled. We were indeed relieved to learn that "the whole British Army" had turned out to be mostly "Mounties" whom we had learned to know as protectors. As a boy, when I used to see one coming in his scarlet red coat I thought of all the bad things I'd ever done.
The Indians around us were taught that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police were the sons of the "Great White Father" (King of England) and if they displeased the Mounties, the "Great White Father" would wreak vengeance on their heads.
At this point, to use a military phrase, the Relief Society "took over." They immediately discerned that what His Lordship and ladies needed most was to get warm and have their coats and other clothes dried. They went into a huddle, and after a few hurried whispers they would now go to work with clocklike precision. Several slipped out the back door and began catching, killing, and frying chicken as they have never done before or since. Youngsters were sent around town to spread the alarm that we were all caught "flat footed." Other sisters set about drying His Lordship's tunic. Imagine the thrill the sisters in this outpost of civilization must have received in carefully untangling and drying the gold braid with which it was draped. One of the bishopric was dispatched posthaste to my father's store to see if, perchance, there was anything left in it after the previous dinner. He came in the store all excited and said, 'The Lord has come and there is not a bite in the house to eat! Have you anything?" My father replied, "Well I'm not surprised. I've been preaching for years if we were not more careful, the Savior would be dropping in on us and our lamps would be empty, and now this?" They went over the store shelves and discovered seventeen cans of oysters. They were stocked in the store for such occasions as wedding receptions, visiting apostles, or, in this case. Nobility. They were so expensive it was considered next door to sacrilege to use them for anything else. The Mounties dismounted and we turned their horses, all fifty head, into the host's haystacks. At least they were going to be well fed. The sisters hurriedly summoned Brother Fofalite, an Italian convert, a very fine musician and our choir leader. It was common knowledge about the town that the bishopric was not any too well pleased with Brother Fofalite?it was thought that he had the choir spend too much time on operatic arias and neglected such good old hymns as "Come, Come Ye Saints" and "High On the Mountain Tops." Nevertheless, Brother Fofalite was an expert musician, but in twenty years of farming, he was never known to raise a crop. The sisters soon had the banquet room again in order. With the splendor of the Mounties and their scarlet red uniforms, the atmosphere of the room took on a tone of brilliance. Eventually, His Lordship and Ladies regained their composure. Brother Fofalite appeared and accompanied on the organ a quartette of the sisters who sang, artistically, several difficult operatic renditions with which the Noble Party was very much surprised. Following this the town's "Oomph Girl" (yes, we had them in those days, too) sang a song in "rag time" which immensely pleased the Mounties, but evidently passed clear over His Lordship's head. By this time the rain having subsided, once more the sisters began converging on the banquet house from all parts of town, bringing even more dishes, furniture, and food. My admiration certainly went out to the Relief Society sisters, even though I knew full well we'd probably be on a mush and milk diet for the rest of the summer. The dinner was served in excellent style. The whole party was enthusiastically pleased with its reception "at the hands of the Mormons." The storm lifted and they were shown the canal and sent happily on their way. Thus the Mormons in Canada were judged and came through with flying colors. Thanks to the Relief Society and all seventeen cans of oysters, the day was saved, and we all lived happily ever afterwards. Mysteriously, that red plush chair was never seen again from that day to this.

SPECIAL ACTIVITIES A Seminary Relief Society RAY L. JONES, principal of the Midway L. D. S. Seminary at Lewisville, Idaho, is giving seminary students an insight into the operation of Church auxiliaries by organizing the students into groups patterned after the auxiliaries. His account of the sample Relief Society in the seminary during the 1943-44 school year states: "The organization has consisted of three girls?a president chosen from the Church history class, a first counselor from the New Testament class, and a second counselor from the Old Testament class. The purpose of this organization has been threefold: 1. To acquaint all seminary students with the purpose and value of the Relief Society; 2. To give students opportunities to serve their fellow classmates; 3. To train student officers for future leadership in the Relief Societies of their wards and stakes. "The principal project carried out by this organization during the past year has been the writing of letters to the servicemen from the five wards of the school district. These letters have included the following features: 1. A mimeographed letter from the Relief Society officers; 2. News from the high school, home wards, and from the boys in the service; 3. A message from the stake presidency, ward bishopric, and the high school principal; 4. Personal notes written on the back and margins of the mimeographed letter by seminary students. "The first letter was mailed, in November (1943), to 150 servicemen, the second, in February, to more than 200, and the third letter, in May. Dozens of letters have been received from the servicemen expressing their appreciation for being remembered. These replies have come from all parts of the United States and from the battle fronts of the world, including India, North Africa, Italy, England, the Aleutians, and the South Pacific. The student Relief Society officers have organized and supervised all phases of this letter-writing project, and in addition have carried out the following activities: 1. Sent get-well cards to students who have been absent because of sickness; 2. Sent sympathy cards to students who have had a death in the family; 3. Written or visited sick students in hospitals; 4. Suggested and assisted in making beautification improvements in the seminary building; 5.
