SPECIAL ACTIVITIES A Seminary Relief Society RAY L. JONES, principal of the Midway L. D. S. Seminary at Lewisville, Idaho, is giving seminary students an insight into the operation of Church auxiliaries by organizing the students into groups patterned after the auxiliaries. His account of the sample Relief Society in the seminary during the 1943-44 school year states: "The organization has consisted of three girls?a president chosen from the Church history class, a first counselor from the New Testament class, and a second counselor from the Old Testament class. The purpose of this organization has been threefold: 1. To acquaint all seminary students with the purpose and value of the Relief Society; 2. To give students opportunities to serve their fellow classmates; 3. To train student officers for future leadership in the Relief Societies of their wards and stakes. "The principal project carried out by this organization during the past year has been the writing of letters to the servicemen from the five wards of the school district. These letters have included the following features: 1. A mimeographed letter from the Relief Society officers; 2. News from the high school, home wards, and from the boys in the service; 3. A message from the stake presidency, ward bishopric, and the high school principal; 4. Personal notes written on the back and margins of the mimeographed letter by seminary students. "The first letter was mailed, in November (1943), to 150 servicemen, the second, in February, to more than 200, and the third letter, in May. Dozens of letters have been received from the servicemen expressing their appreciation for being remembered. These replies have come from all parts of the United States and from the battle fronts of the world, including India, North Africa, Italy, England, the Aleutians, and the South Pacific. The student Relief Society officers have organized and supervised all phases of this letter-writing project, and in addition have carried out the following activities: 1. Sent get-well cards to students who have been absent because of sickness; 2. Sent sympathy cards to students who have had a death in the family; 3. Written or visited sick students in hospitals; 4. Suggested and assisted in making beautification improvements in the seminary building; 5. GOLD-GREEN DAY Eva Willes Wangsgaard It doesn't matter to this gold-green day That war's unnatural thunder tears the earth; For such is full ten thousand miles away, And April is concerned with life and birth. The tulips lift enameled bowls knee-high, The cups and saucers of the daffodils Are hung like new-dipped pottery to dry, From hyacinths, star-bottled perfume spills. Here life is gentle, an insistent force That reaches ever up, with death a friend Incipient in leaf and bud, whose course Runs parallel, a haven in the end. War leans his weight with death, but April weaves New life from broken forms the earth receives. The Cover: The cover "Proud Parents" is from a photograph by Grace O. Tuttle taken on the Deschutes River at Bend, Oregon. "

Look Unto the Rock, Whence Ye Are Hewn" Elder Daryl Chase Director of Latter-day Saint Institute, Logan, Utah IN recent years we have had many reappraisals of our national history. Since the outbreak of war, with all of its cost in treasure and lives, Americans have been attempting to evaluate democracy and discover how we reached our present national position of power from the simple, tragic beginnings of Jamestown and Plymouth of three hundred years ago.
American history is being rewritten in the agony of our present suffering and in the hope which we cherish of a better world. This does not mean that any significant changes will be made in our dates of history. Children will give the same answers as their grandfathers did regarding such questions as, "When was America discovered? How many sailed on the Mayflower?" etc.
On the other hand, better answers to the questions which follow must be made by young Americans than were made by their fathers, if we are to build on the political and spiritual foundations of Jamestown and Plymouth. I refer to such questions as these: What were the driving motives of the early American colonizers? What were the basic political ideals back of the instruments of government established by them? Can the marked differences which are apparent between the Spanish and English settlers in the New World be explained by the accidents of discovery (by the direction the wind happened to blow their ships), or must these differences be accounted for by factors quite outside the category of winds, rivers, harbors, and precious metals?
At the present time, there is a definite shift on the part of the interpreters of America's past from their emphasis on her material strength to that of her spiritual heritage. This shift is definitely in the direction of historical accuracy, and at the same time will serve as a morale builder to all thoughtful citizens. Men do not want to suffer or die, merely to shift a border or to keep their country the richest nation on earth.
It seems to the writer that it would be well for Latter-day Saint historians and Church interpreters of the past to follow the current trend of our secular historians and rewrite much of our early Church history with a shift in emphasis upon the purely religious and spiritual heritage of the saints.
A Latter-day Saint student may know the exact dates and places of every important event in Church history and remain quite ignorant of the real significance of the past to him. I once had a supervisor visit my class and demonstrate "how to teach Church history. The period lasted fifty minutes, and the whole time was spent in teaching the students the exact distance from Palmyra to the Smith farm. I think that all readers of this article will agree that a few minutes spent on the geographical setting of the Smith farmstead would have been time well spent, but the major part of that 50-minute period should have been occupied, not in pointing out how far the Prophet was from New York City, but rather how close he was to God.
Chronologies and assembled quotations from past leaders will never supply sufficient spiritual nutriment for the growing youth of any age. And at the present time, when the basic beliefs and practices of the Latter-day Saints are being attacked at home and abroad, the student is forced far below the surface of history when he attempts to protect the Church, or when he searches the past for some meaning of the present or for guidance into the future.
AS I reflect upon the early history of the Church, several very important facts emerge from all the names and dates and geography associated with our beginnings. One is this: The Restored Church is very young. Many great and worthwhile achievements have already been made to the everlasting credit of the Church, but this fact still remains: One hundred and fifteen years is a very short time in the life of a vital, growing institution, and every Latter-day Saint should be aware of this important fact of his history.
Young men and women are delighted to learn that everything has not been done for them either in the Church or in the nation. It is thrilling to everyone to help build a beautiful ward or stake house or temple, but good janitors and watchmen of any structure are very difficult to find because such work is dull and uninteresting. Young people can become very enthusiastic about contributing to a young church (which we are), but may remain quite indifferent to a call merely to protect an old institution.
I can never read very far in Church history without feeling that we are still in our beginnings, that only the foundation stones have been laid for this spiritual structure which we call the Church, and I am sure that many Latter-day Saints share this point of view with me. I once asked a brilliant young college teacher why he was converted to the Church what it was that first attracted him to Mormonism. He replied that first, it was the good lives of several Latter-day Saints whom he knew that did appeal and second, it was the attractive fact that this Church is young and is on the offensive, whereas the church which he grew up in was very old and was merely living on the material and spiritual resources of an ancient past. He said: "I am a Mormon; I can help build a future with my faith, my education, and my talents; here is a young, living organism; in the church I left I felt that the best I could do was to protect an ancient monument."
When we look below the surface of our beginning, we soon discover another fact: We are not only very young, but, like the Primitive Church, the people who first gathered in eastern New York and northern Ohio to make the new covenant, were among the lowly when judged by their material possessions. The Church started rich in things of the spirit, but very poor in the wealth of this world.
Practically all material assets of the Church on which we can depend today, cannot be traced beyond the tithing of President Grant. A few men of wealth from 1830 down to the present time have joined the Church, but most of the converts, foreign and domestic, have answered the description Paul made of the early Christian converts at Corinth: "For ye see your calling, brethren, how that not many wise men after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called" (I Cor. 1:26).
We misread the story of Plymouth if we place any motive above those of religion and civil liberty as the driving force back of the Pilgrim migration. Many motives may have been back of our forefathers joining the Church, but paramount among them all were the convictions that they were entering the kingdom of God, that Christ's Church was restored upon the earth. They were primarily in search of spiritual riches, and any other interpretations of our early history are distorted and badly unbalanced.
Year by year, we increase our number of public buildings and our corporate wealth. The youth of the Church and all new converts inherit the fruits of the industry and frugality of the pioneer saints. But to the kingdom seekers of the present we have little to offer of a nonmaterial nature which was not present in the Church as the Founders gathered
ings at Kirtland, Ohio, and Jackson County, Missouri. In that early poverty the elders could say to the investigator: "Repent of your sins, exercise faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, and we will baptize you for the remission of your sins and lay hands on your head for the reception of the Holy Ghost." At that early period when they were so poor in this world's goods, the elders could also say: "Through the power of the priesthood which has been restored, you can make covenants with the Lord which are mortality which, if kept faithfully, will be binding in the worlds to come."
Our assurance of immortality is firmly based upon the same evidence which attracted the first converts; our concepts pertaining to the nature of God and the meaning of life are the rich heritage of a not-too-distant past.
In the Nauvoo period when the Church was about fourteen years old, Sidney Rigdon, in reminiscing over the first few months of the Church, said:
I recollect in the year 1830 I met the whole Church of Christ in a little old log house about 20 feet square, near Waterloo, N.Y., and we began to talk about the kingdom of God as if we had the world at our command. We talked with great confidence, and talked big things, although we were not many people.
We had big feelings.
We knew fourteen years ago that the Church would become as large as it is today. We were as big then as we ever shall be. We began to talk like men in authority and power. We looked upon the men of the earth as grasshoppers. (D.H.C. Vol. VI, p. 288.)
The great plans (which we have partly achieved) which the early brothers and sisters made in their rude cabins, the sureness of their position, their faith in the ultimate triumph of their work wit' all centered in spiritual realities which challenged the best within them. The prevailing spirit of that early period was: What can I contribute to this cause? There was neither social prestige nor corporate wealth to attract the investigator until quite recent times.
To repeat: The Church began very poor in the goods of this world but very rich in the treasures of the spirit.
THERE are some churches which verge on being downright anti-intellectual; they oppose, or view with suspicion, all steps forward in science and art. There are many churches which may not be classified as anti-educational but, in the main, they are indifferent towards learning in general. Intellectuality of any kind does not reflect the spirit of their gospel. The thoughtful observer can plainly see that the trend of modern life everywhere is to move farther and farther away from that type of institution.
Everyone acquainted with current Latter-day Saint history knows something about the fine schools which the Church has built, and that most of the Church activities can be placed under the general heading of education. This fact holds true whether one considers the programs outlined for the priesthood quorums and the Relief Society, or those which are planned for the little children and the youth of the Church. Some critics admit that the Church is now very interested in education, but suggest that what was true in the past was
sition by the national trend for universal education as a safeguard to American democracy.
Every Latter-day Saint who has read his early history with care knows that early records to which everyone must refer show that Joseph Smith and many of the early saints had very little formal schooling, but the same records also show that they had great faith in what we now call the educational process, accepting its divine approval and extending its influence beyond the grave. It is a plain fact of history that from the very beginning of the Church, education and salvation have gone hand in hand in the restored gospel plan of exaltation.
To say that Joseph Smith was zealous for education is not a rhetorical phrase written to please the ears of present-day, cultivated Latter-day Saints who take pride in their schools and educational programs; it is a simple unadorned fact. At this point let us recall just one of the many statements of the Lord given to Joseph Smith pertaining to education, at a time when the problems of food, clothing, and shelter were daily, pressing problems to most of the saints: "Teach ye diligently and my grace shall attend you, that you may be instructed more perfectly in theory, in principle, in doctrine, in the law of the gospel, in all things that pertain unto the kingdom of God, that are expedient for you to understand" (Doc. and Cov. 88:78).
Furthermore, the Prophet's interest in education did not stop with oral utterances; He was an eager student to the hour of his death. He kept the best educated members of the Church close to him; he was not LOOK UNTO THE ROCK 199 afraid of their learning; they were his resource men and counselors. Recently in a class where we were studying the life of the Prophet, a student asked this question with evident surprise: "It states in Josiah Quincy's account of his visit to Nauvoo that the Prophet read from his Hebrew Old Testament in order to make a certain theological point clear; how did he happen to know Hebrew?" The correct answer, of course, is obvious: he learned it the way all men learn Hebrew; he employed a good teacher (Professor Seixas, the best Hebrew scholar of his day) and he sat in a beginner's class and "sweat it out" with the other brethren who were also eager to learn. It is one thing to utter a pulpit exhortation about the necessity of learning; it is quite a different thing to spend your money to employ a teacher and then burn the midnight oil over a Hebrew grammar in addition to doing the laborious, daily-routine, executive business of the Church. The Prophet set a good example before his people in attending classes and in organizing schools, but the most important of all his contributions in this field was the close association which he always made between education and the most sacred teachings and activities of his life. Many times we quote the following in support of education, quite unaware that it is found in the dedicatory prayer given by revelation, uttered by the Prophet at the completion of the Kirtland Temple: And do thou grant, Holy Father, that all those who shall worship in this house may be taught words of wisdom out of the best books, and that they may seek learning even by study, and also by faith...." (Doc. And Gov. 109:14). Apparently, education of the people and temple building were inseparable in the Prophet's mind. In the plans which he proposed for the temple to be built at Far West, one finds that two of its three stories were to be reserved for educational activities. (Comprehensive History of the Church, Vol. 1, p. 440.) The Latter-day Saint student who reads the early history of his Church and does not discover how eager the founders were to raise up a learned generation unto the Lord, have missed an important fact, and a very stimulating one. Emerson said that "Every institution is but the length and shadow of a man." A careful reader of early Church history will learn that the length and shadow of Mormonism is not that of any man limited by the rough life of the American frontier. Rather, it is the length and shadow of the Son of man who placed man's limitations only within the bounds of truth and righteousness.

BRIDGES Grace A. Gooper Burned bridges retain a nostalgic scent That lingers and clings?is haunting, despite me-I will not look back through the haze unspent. Lest one unscathed plank remain to invite me.

Rufus Kay Hardy President Levi Edgar Young Of the First Council of the Seventy ELDER RUFUS K. HARDY (Died March 7, 1945) ALL who knew him have praised his goodness, his kindliness, as much as they have his love for right. Bearing testimony of the truth of the gospel of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ was his great passion. Called as he was to go to the South Sea Islands to give the gospel to the Polynesian people, he not only spent one period of his youth among them, but three times was he called by the Church to go to that people. That which made the people understand the light and beauty of his message was the manner in which it was put forth. In their traditions we find their ancestors believing in God the Creator of heaven and earth, and Page 200 man created in the image of God. They knew of the Redeemer of the world and deeply did President Hardy know that some day, the people of those islands of the sea would come to a knowledge of the restored gospel through the Prophet Joseph Smith. For over a decade he served as a member of the First Council of the Seventy, a position he dignified and to which he gave all honor. He had a fine idea of accuracy and a desire for the exact truth, which grudged no time and pains in tracing out even what might mean a small matter. He had a sound and calm judgment which subjected his own and all people's inferences to a searching review. With these fine characteristics, he threw the whole force of his nature into the work of the Seventy of the Church. The dignity of the work was in keeping with its importance. The missionary system is a means to an end; and every seventy, a missionary, should bring his soul to the desire to go forth and "preach the gospel to all peoples of the earth." He wanted the seventies to become students and teachers, but ever given to the deep knowledge that each one by the grace of God has that eternal testimony that God lives, that Jesus is the Christ, and that Joseph Smith is a prophet of God to usher in the new age of the gospel of salvation. So he lived and died, knowing that the forces which are to make the world the world it ought to be are now within it.

Samuel Otis Bennion President Antoine R. Ivins Of the First Council of the Seventy IN the death of Samuel O. Bennion the Church has lost one of its most valued and valiant servants. He leaves behind a vast multitude of friends. While we knew he had been laboring under the handicap of an uncertain heart for some time, none of us expected him to leave us when he did. Practically all of his mature years have been devoted to the missionary work of the Church, for it was soon after his marriage that he accepted a call to the Central States Mission where he spent the next twenty-eight years of his life, presiding over the mission for twenty-six of them. Upon that mission he stamped his personality, and to an even greater extent he leaves his mark upon the Church through the many men and women who worked under his direction in spreading the 'glad tidings of great joy" to the world. He taught them faith in God and humility, honesty, devotion, integrity, industry, and the other virtues which characterize true Latter-day Saints. From the Central States Mission he came to the First Council of the Seventy which gave him another wide field of activity. Here he came into closer touch with the presiding officers of the Church, in its general offices, and throughout the wards and stakes, and widened the circle of his influence. While at Independence he had the Liahona and printing plant to manage which experience qualified him to direct The Deseret News when he moved to Salt Lake City. President Bennion's parents were sturdy pioneers and he gained from them a physical and intellectual endowment which qualified him for life, under the rigorous conditions of our beloved West. ELDER SAMUEL O. BENNION (Died March 8, 1945) He was equally at home as a stockman and farmer, a business man or a preacher of the restored gospel. Almost seventy-one years was the measure of his mortal life, and they were filled with acts of kindness and helpfulness. Our prayer is that God will give strength and courage, confidence and solace to his good wife who through all of these experiences stood by him. Page 201

Let Us Honor Them The Honorable Charles R. Ma bey Former Governor of the State of Utah Prepared at the request of the Church Beautification Committee  ALL great movements of history have their leaders. The farther they recede from the present, the greater the halo that surrounds them, and the dimmer the figures that made their leadership possible. In that famous march of the ten thousand of ancient Greece, our mental eyes embrace but one personality: Xenophon; all the others are shadows. The children of Israel wandered forty years in the wilderness under the guidance of Moses; him we recall, the several hundred thousands of his followers are ghosts fast disappearing in the night of the centuries. Caesar crossed the Rubicon, but where are the legions that marched at his back? Him alone do we

remember. The Mormons trekked across the plains and founded this mountain empire, and at once when we recall the event, Brigham Young stalks across the stage.
It is not that we think less of the men and women who took part in these great movements. We know that not one of these geniuses could have become great without followers who were likewise great. The common man and woman of Mormondom were not a whit behind the moving spirits of every historic epoch. Side by side with Brigham Young were ten thousand other men far less known, but equally as resolute, equally as bold, equally in enterprise, equally as loyal to a mighty cause. Had accident or the purposes of the Almighty chosen them to the supreme command, they would not have been found wanting. Each one that came here and endured to the end was a giant in faith, in courage, in steadfastness. The victory in the fight against the forces of nature and those of evil is always achieved by the common soldier. In following the fortunes of these stalwarts, one feels that he is watching the stride of supermen and that the life of each is as interesting as that of his leader.
Never before or since did men and women display such boundless energy. Within ten years of their arrival here the valleys of Utah had been taken up, villages or towns had been established as far east as Colorado, as far south as Arizona, as far north as the Salmon River in Idaho, and as far west as the Carson Sinks, to say nothing of the settlements in San Bernardino and the Mormon River district of California.
Wherever the colonists penetrated, there went law and order, thrift and frugality, and a decency in living seldom equalled and never surpassed. Roads were laid out, bridges built, towns surveyed, lands broken up and cultivated, homes, schools, and meetinghouses erected. In a primeval mountain fastnesses were conquered and the ring of the woodman's axe became familiar to the denizens of canyon and stream. LET US HONOR THEM 203 EVERY GREAT MAN IS BACKED UP AND SUSTAINED BY GIANTS IN FAITH IN COURAGE IN STEADFASTNESS STOCKRAISERS PROFESSIONAL MEN WOMEN STATESMAN BUSINESSMEN BUILDERS FARMERS ARTISANS A LEADER Water was diverted from a thousand channels and poured out upon the thirsty soil, thus making of a desert a fruitful field. The four corners of the globe were scoured to secure seeds that might thrive in this section, and soon the husbandman produced crops that were the envy of farmers in less favored places. MANY of the converts to the new faith were splendid artisans. Saddlers and farriers, brick and rock masons, carpenters and cabinetmakers, millers and lumbermen, wheelwrights and waggoners, blacksmiths and cobblers, all the trades known to civilization, were represented in practically every town by skilled workmen. Whatever was needed in the shape of home appliances and utensils, farm implements, or clothing for the body, could be and was produced. Sugar mills and tanneries, looms and spinning wheels, were soon in operation. Mass production with its thousand and one articles so common today-cereals, breakfast foods, bacon, ham, canned vegetables and fruits, and gadgets that make the housewife's labor a joy?had not yet made their appearance on the Western stage. In consequence, the local craftsman fabricated his wares with much pride therein, fully aware of their worth. Most pioneers had not had the blessing of an education, but they loved learning with passionate devotion. One needs but to scan the early issues of The Deseret News, note the advertisements and see how many of them have to do with educational subjects. Schools functioned in every village and hamlet, side by side with the plow and the scythe. For example, on September 20, 1848, Joseph Holbrook moved with his flocks and herds ten miles north of Salt Lake, and within a month had made a school-house of bullrushes and mud so that his children and those of Anson Call might receive tutelage. This is but one of hundreds of similar happenings, and by 1850 the University of Deseret was established. State, municipal, and county governments were formed and wholesome laws enacted. The crime, the drunkenness, and the general lawlessness that usually characterize newly founded communities were absent wherever these pioneers were in the ascendancy. When one realizes this and the self-sufficiency of the new colony, one sometimes wistfully wishes oneself back in its quiet seclusion, untroubled by the worries that harass the world today. This people was not wealthy in jewels and precious stones, in gold and silver, in magnificent mansions and palaces of pleasure, but its plain, homespun existence made for solidity, stability, and honesty, qualities which are sorely needed in this year of grace, 1945. Is it any wonder that we honor them?

entries.title: Come and Grow Old with Me
entries.author: Bertha A. Kleinman

loose_match.content: COME AND GROW OLD WITH ME Bertha A. Kleinman Come and grow old with me. As trees grow old, Each season adding newer, finer wood? A timbered arch defying storm and cold, And nobler for adversity withstood. God made a tree? He likewise fashioned me To brave the rain, the thunder?shock and blast, A weathered oak that sheds security, From fruited boughs uplifted to the last. Come and grow old with me. The eventide Is rich with harvest after storm and strife; There is no age, for where the Gates swing wide New wood still blossoms on the Tree of Life!

entries.title: We Will Give the Tenth Unto Thee
entries.author: Camilla Eyring Kimball

loose_match.content:
We Will Give the Tenth Unto Thee Camilla Eyring Kimball and we ourselves know whether we give wholeheartedly with a feeling of gratitude and thanksgiving or with a feeling of compulsion or parsimony.
There are those Church members who worry about the use to which the Church funds are put. It is interesting to notice that it is not the full tithe payer who is thus concerned, but usually the member who wishes to find an excuse for his nonpayment of tithes in a declaration of his disapproval of the handling of the funds. There was a wealthy member of the Church, living in a small community, who openly declared that he would not pay tithing, but that each year he would give a sizable sum to some public charity or needy individual, for which he received newspaper publicity. He was heard to say, "I think I am a better judge of where my money will do the most good than the bishop or Church authorities are." This man gave to be seen of men and so has his reward. The tithe payer who gives with love and trust, unbinded by men, surely will receive a far greater reward, for he is storing up for himself treasures in heaven.
IN obeying the law of tithing, we have a tangible way of showing that our religion is not merely a form, but a living, active force in our everyday lives. In times of stress, such as the period in which we are now living, we feel, more than at any other time, a real need for activity to combat the evils at work around us. We cannot give passive lip service and keep our faith alive. What more definite, combative force can be found than the act of
going all the way in the payment of an honest tithing to our Heavenly Father?
Our boys who are fighting on the battle fronts all over the world are fortifying themselves with the force of true, honest living by sending their tithing from India, Alaska, Africa, Italy, England, and the islands of the Pacific. Their letters bear testimony of the strength which this tangible act of obedience gives them. It is a strand in the life line which ties them closely to the body of the Church and to our Heavenly Father. This is no lip service, but a concrete evidence of a desire to obey the commandments and so be worthy of blessings.
As Latter-day Saint parents, our responsibility to our children is not complete when we provide them with food, shelter and clothing. We are commanded: "And they shall also teach their children to pray, and to walk uprightly before the Lord" (Doc. and Cov. 68:a3). There is a definite time to teach a child to pay tithing, and it should not be postponed until he is old enough to earn an income outside the home. An opportunity should be made for children, when they are very young, to earn their spending money by doing regularly and well, definite chores at home. They should then be taught to budget their money carefully, teaching them that the first tenth belongs to the Lord, and is not theirs to spend otherwise. Thus, they will learn the habits of honesty, thrift, and independence. The payment of tithing can easily be made a habit if there is never an exception allowed, even though children may feel they need the money for something else. and we ourselves know whether we give wholeheartedly with a feeling of gratitude and thanksgiving or with a feeling of compulsion or parsimony. There are those Church members who worry about the use to which the Church funds are put. It is interesting to notice that it is not the full tithe payer who is thus concerned, but usually the member who wishes to find an excuse for his nonpayment of tithes in a declaration of his disapproval of the handling of the funds. There was a wealthy member of the Church, living in a small community, who openly declared that he would not pay tithing, but that each year he would give a sizable sum to some public charity or needy individual, for which he received newspaper publicity. He was heard to say, "I think I am a better judge of where my money will do the most good than the bishop or Church authorities are." This man gave to be seen of men and so has his reward. The tithe payer who gives with love and trust, unlauded by men, surely will receive a far greater reward, for he is storing up for himself treasures in heaven. TN obeying the law of tithing, we have a tangible way of showing that our religion is not merely a form, but a living, active force in our everyday lives. In times of stress, such as the period in which we are now living, we feel, more than at any other time, a real need for activity to combat the evils at work around us. We cannot give passive lip service and keep our faith alive. What more definite, combative force can be found than the act of going all the way in the payment of an honest tithing to our Heavenly Father? Our boys who are fighting on the battle fronts all over the world are fortifying themselves with the force of true, honest living by sending their tithing from India, Alaska, Africa, Italy, England, and the islands of the Pacific. Their letters bear testimony of the strength which this tangible act of obedience gives them. It is a strand in the life line which ties them closely to the body of the Church and to our Heavenly Father. This is no lip service, but a concrete evidence of a desire to obey the commandments and so be worthy of blessings. As Latter-day Saint parents, our responsibility to our children is not complete when we provide them with food, shelter and clothing. We are commanded: "And they shall also teach their children to pray, and to walk uprightly before the Lord" (Doc. And Cov. 68:28). There is a definite time to teach a child to pay tithing, and it should not be postponed until he is old enough to earn an income outside the home. An opportunity should be made for children, when they are very young, to earn their spending money by doing regularly and well, definite chores at home. They should then be taught to budget their money carefully, teaching them that the first tenth belongs to the Lord, and is not theirs to spend otherwise. Thus, they will learn the habits of honesty, thrift, and independence. The payment of tithing can easily be made a habit if there is never an exception allowed, even though children may feel they need the money for something else. Sometimes children earn money and carefully save it for a special purpose, and are tempted to let the Lord wait until later for that which is his. Parents would do well to be firm in permitting no exceptions to the rule that the tithe comes first; it is not ours to spend. It should be designated for the one, sacred purpose. Thousands will testify to the greater joy and strength which comes from strict and unfaltering obedience to this law of the gospel.
In preparing a Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association class of young girls to make an excursion to the temple to be baptized for the dead, I was astounded to find how many of them had never paid tithing, nor felt they had ever owed any. Many of them had earned small allowances at home, but just had not been taught that they should be tithed. We only learn to do by doing, and it is most important that parents create the opportunity for the forming of this habit in very young children. Some parents make the excuse that it would be a burden for the bishop to keep a child's name on the tithing record for a very small sum. Any
bishop worthy of the calling feels a real thrill when a child comes to pay his tithing, even if it be only a dime. A child's tithing receipts should be among his most prized possessions, tangible evidence of his worthy standing in the Church?not to be exhibited, but for his own satisfaction. The amount is not the important thing; the child's or the widow's small tenth is just as acceptable in the eyes of the Lord as the thousands paid by the rich man.
The Lord has spoken through his prophet Malachi: "Prove ye all the tithes into the storehouse, that there may be meat in mine house, and prove me now herewith, saith the Lord of hosts, if I will not open you the windows of heaven, and pour you out a blessing, that there shall not be room enough to receive it." Blessings of health, of harmony in the home, the feeling of peace and well-being in one's soul, of love and good will toward one's neighbors, cannot be bought with money, but only by keeping the commandments. These blessings may be ours if we can say as did Jacob, "and of all that thou shalt give me I will surely give the tenth unto thee."

THE EASTER GIFT Grace M. Candland Today The darkened earth is filled with guilt and gloom, Swift marching feet and screaming bomb and shell Obscure Christ's resurrection from the tomb. Men race to death through groaning sea and sky, And mourning fills the breaking hearts who tell Of youthful slain, and starving children's cry. The gift of life is but a myth today, Men's carnal minds rush on to living hell. The urns of faith have fallen to decay. Tomorrow Come, stand beside the Easter lily fair And look within its graceful waxen bell, The buried bulb has risen to beauty there. To know that from this darkness and the strife Beyond the reach of tears and sad farewell, There is the promise of immortal life. Eternal message, like a flag unfurled. Bright star of hope, no other can excel The Easter gift unto a dying world.

Sixty Years Ago Excerpts from the Woman's Exponents, April 1, and April 15, 1885 "For the Rights of the Women of Zion and the Rights of the Women of All Nations" Editorial Notes: The General Conference of the Church will be held this year in Logan, instead of Salt Lake City. This is the second time only that the General Conference has not convened here. The other instance was in St. George in April 1877. Correspondence: Nutrioso, Arizona, Feb. 13, 1885, Editor Exponent ? Thinking perhaps a few words from far away might be interesting is why I write. We left St. George the last of June 1883, and after an agreeable visit to Panguitch Lake and various settlements we returned to St. George to the fall conference and soon after bade adieu to our much cherished home, and the Temple and its pleasant associations. We had a very prosperous journey of 500 miles through an indescribable wilderness of sterile barrenness, and came to this place in good health and spirits, although tired, worn and weary. We here found most of our family in peace, comfort and reasonably prosperous in the midst of the saints. This is a pleasant, fertile, but small, valley, truly in the tops of the mountains, with beautiful scenery of low hills and openings of timber for farms, with the necessary water, this being a rainy climate. We have here the best built and finest little town in Arizona; the dwellings of frame painted white, with good, substantial frame barns and outhouses; a cooperative store in healthy and prosperous condition. We have a good frame meeting house, also white, which is also our school house. Our meetings are well attended, also our day and Sunday schools, not forgetting the prosperous condition of our Primary and Relief Society. The Brown brothers have a steam saw mill in successful operation, to whose enterprise and energy much of the prosperity of this little town is to be credited. Yours respectfully, T. This was the great moral disease that Jesus Christ found in the world and prescribed for; and so long as your people follow His directions closely and attentively they will live and grow and prosper; but when riches, pride and selfishness grow up among you, then you will have only a form of godliness without its power, as the religious orders of this country, and the spirit of the world in all of them and the spirit of Christ not found in them.?John M. Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon MRS. MARTHA SPENCER WOODWARD has passed away at the age of ninety-six. She was a daughter of Martha Knight Spencer and Orson Spencer, pioneer author and first regent of the University of Deseret. Inheriting her father's literary tastes, she was the prime mover in organizing the Ladies' Literary Club in Salt Lake City. DETURNING from European battle fronts, Anne O'Hare Mc-Cormick says that, seen from a cold spur of the Apennines, the old Main Street that had seemed "drab and standardized and cramping" to American boys, looks like "some gold-paved thoroughfare in Paradise." IN her medical student days, Mrs. Lillian Bettinger developed a "guilt feeling" because of the destructiveness of dissecting human bodies. She compensated by sculpturing as a hobby. Later as assistant to a famous plastic surgeon, she utilized both these anatomical and artistic skills in developing the best method known today of making artificial fingers, noses, hands and other "prosthetic" parts, even matching remarkably the shade of human skin (and there are two million shades of skin). People type-write and perform other near-miracles with these parts. Her system has helped thousands of soldiers; she hopes soon to help war-crippled children. AN Appreciation ANOTHER birthday of Relief Society has just passed. Anniversary programs held throughout the Church testified to the love of the women for their organization and to the appreciation of the members of the Church for its efforts and accomplishments. The milestone reached on March 17, 1945 reminds us that Relief Society women have been working, serving, and studying together for 103 years. Their organization which was founded by a prophet of God on a broad, liberal, and adequate foundation has enabled them to meet assignments, requirements, and needs as they have occurred during this long period of time. Their experiences in this great. Society, dedicated to service and education, have been manifold, varied, and stimulating. In their labors they have learned how to be helpful in overcoming the difficulties and hardships of daily life, how to be helpful in solving problems incident to migration and pioneering, and how to be helpful in the adjustments and readjustments confronting individuals, families, and society in this great century of changes and developments resulting from discoveries, inventions and new and different conditions. And because of these activities which have constantly required strength, foresight, and ingenuity, and bePage218 cause of the intelligent study put forth in regular class work, learning how best to live and improve and enrich life, great development has come to these earnest and able workers. Thus it is seen that the Relief Society with its two-fold program has brought unusual opportunity to the women of the Church who have partaken of its advantages?opportunity for human service and opportunity for spiritual, intellectual, and emotional development. Through human service there has been engendered in their hearts a love and sympathy for others, the spirit of the golden rule, and that respect for human personality which was taught and practiced by the Master himself. And through regular educational study and research the lives of all who participated have been enriched. Their motto has been "The Glory of God Is Intelligence." To the women of the past we pay tribute. We are indebted to them for their vision, self-sacrificing efforts, and untiring labors. They have left us a rich heritage of faith and devotion to the Relief Society cause and to the restored gospel. Their testimonies of the divine mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith and their lives of service to the Church have been an inspiration and strength to us. To our co-workers, we offer congratulations for their like devotion and fortitude and for their great accomplishments in these days of apprehension and anxiety; Our prayer is that the Lord will bless and sustain them. And to the new and vigorous young leaders and workers who are coming into the service we say, look backward as well as forward; strive to properly evaluate the past and use it as a foundation for the future; and look forward with faith and a long view. A. B. L.

TO MY GRANDCHILDREN Maude Hatch Benedict When I am gone, will eager children look Within the pages of this timeworn book, Their questing eyes find nothing here to show Fulfilled ambition, finished task; will they know Pride?that I left footprints here below? Will all the little tasks of love be lost Forever, as a fluff of thistledown-No heartache, tears, frustration's cost. Nor valor shown, when I am gone-No thing of me to spur them to go on? Or will they say of me, "she still belongs. Her life was made of sunshine and of songs, Where she walked some radiant memory Of charm, of wit, of kindliness in giving, The paths she trod made surer by her living!" 4 Will they smile, a wee bit wistfully, While thumbing through this dog-eared old scrapbook- And for a moment will they pause to listen For my heartbeat in its pages; will they look Further, wishing to know more of me. And close the book?a tear left to my memory!

Come in for Dessert Edna K. Ward THE homemaker today who must be hostess, cook, and maid is discovering many short cuts. Elaborate entertaining, and many-course, complicated meals went out with whipped cream and two-inch-thick steaks. Entertaining at all might require justification with so many homemakers working in war industries, busy in Red Cross canteens and sewing centers, serving as nurses' aids, and Gray Ladies. Returning home worn from the work of thee day, it requires courage to undertake the entertainment of our friends, and yet it is in times of stress that the companionship of the friends we see so seldom gives a lift to their morale and also to our own. If we can find a way to extend this courtesy with simplicity, consistent with rationing restrictions, we may foster the place of the home in the lives of our children and our friends. The trend of modern life in America has seemed to be away from the home and home interests. A dinner downtown or at some club, lunches and snacks at the drugstore for children as well as adults, has made the home mean less in the lives of many than it did in pioneer days. Home influence has decreased in direct proportion. No one has time for elaborate meals these days, but any meal should be worthy of the time you do give it. Badly planned meals are neither fun to prepare nor to eat; the food that appears daily on your table has to be Page 220 prepared by someone?and that someone must like what she is doing or the result will be far from satisfactory. For cooking is a peculiar occupation; to succeed, it must combine the best of both work and hobby. Only when cooking is viewed and approached as an art, which it is, is the burdensome repetition of the task turned into a self-gratifying performance. If you give it your heart and mind it can be as satisfying as painting pictures. Colorful china, linen, flowers from your garden are your "brushes and oils." With them you can create a background that makes even the simplest meal more glamorous. Foods in themselves have their own natural beauty. It's mixing them up?the reds, greens, yellows and whites? that gives your meals the most appetizing effect. Though the first impression of the dining table is only momentary, like a landscape just before sunset, the real fun is in creating it, and that will last until you create another. And there's more involved in it than just the "looks." Digestion depends upon the psychological reaction to our senses. Food that is well cooked and nicely served creates a healthful response in the attitude of the mind toward food. Emotional disturbances, fear, anger, anxiety, unrest banish appetite and stop the flow of the digestive juices. Happy influences, harmony, and beauty stimulate and promote these vital functions. COME IN FOR DESSERT TABLE SET FOR DESSERT And so in these busy times let's make home meals and company meals as simple and nutritious and beautiful as possible. To simplify home entertaining even more, it is possible to substitute a single course ?invite your friends for dessert. This touch of hospitality may be the occasion for a pleasant evening at home. It is hoped the suggestions given in this article may call forth original ideas that will be practical in the individual home. In planning an evening dessert, the invitation can be extended on short notice. A call on the telephone in the morning with the explanation that you are serving only dessert, and arranging an hour convenient to both hostess and guest, makes the occasion informal. The hour may be seven-thirty or eight o'clock. The planning must include the table setting and the menu, and perhaps the entertainment to follow. A small table may be set for four in the living room or the dining-room table may be used for a larger group. This is an invitation to use our choice pieces of china and silver ?the lovely compotes that mother prized or the chocolate pot that father brought from England or Germany when he returned from his mission. The table cover may be doilies or a luncheon cloth. The table mirror makes an attractive foundation for the display of a low centerpiece of ivy, leaf, berry, fruit or blossoms, each in season. Candles always add soft light to any evening meal. The service should be your nicest dessert plates or crystal sherbets with dessert spoons and forks. If hot chocolate or postum is used, the hostess may serve it at the table in either tea cups or after-dinner cups. The dessert also may be served by the host or hostess at the table. If one does not have help, to have everything on the table eliminates the confusion of someone leaving to bring things from the kitchen. Salted nuts are easily prepared at home and can be included, and homemade candy will always be appreciated. A few suggestive menus and recipes are given at the end of this article. A FTER lingering in the candle-light with good food and interesting conversation, the party may move to the living room and its cheery fire, or to the summer terrace. A planned evening might include discussion of current events, of civic problems or neighborhood projects, a book review, a report on a current magazine. Too often magazines in the home are read by only one member and the contents are unread by the others. Much valuable and interesting material is appearing in the better magazines today. If one or more of those present would undertake the review of some article of interest, it would be a stimulus to his own development and of interest to all. For those who like music, an evening of singing around the piano can be delightful, as can also be an evening spent in listening to recorded symphonies. If a guest is known to have a hobby, he may like to demonstrate it or discuss it, and games always make an evening enjoyable. In these changing times should thought not be given to the preservation of the home and the reestablishment of its place in the lives of both children and adults? Practically all entertainment was provided by the members of the family in former times, with a resultant development of those taking part. Such growth is not promoted by sitting in a darkened movie under the emotional drive of scene and symbol in a world of unreality. Whatever one can do to add to the meaning of the home will be helpful in maintaining the kind of citizenship that has e made America strong. Every mother who gives thought and care and effort to the creation of an interesting and cultured home, adds a touch of sweetness and enrichment to the lives of all who spend an hour within its walls. Home is a woman's rightful throne. Suggestions For a spring evening use a bowl of violets with yellow doilies or tablecloth, and have a tiny violet corsage on each napkin (for the men, too). Serve: Meringued peaches*, custard sauce*, cookies, lemonade, or orange-cream-filled* sponge cake, hot postum. Green is spring's own choice. With green doilies use your best white china and white lilacs. Your table will look as crisp as a white starched pinafore. Serve: Vanilla ice cream with hot cherry sauce or crushed strawberries, warm cup cakes, french chocolate* or lemon meringue pie, beverage. *Meringued Peaches: Drain canned peaches or peel, stone, and cut in half fresh peaches. Place on cookie sheet or baking pan. Top with COME IN FOR DESSERT 223 meringue, leaving in peaks. Place in oven and bake 325? for 10-15 minutes. Do not cook too fast. Meringue: Add two tablespoons sugar to each egg white. Add 1/8 teaspoon baking powder. Beat egg white until stiff. Add the sugar and baking powder and beat until glossy. * Custard Sauce: 1 cup milk 3 egg yolks /4 cup sugar 1 tbsp. Flour Vanilla flavoring 1/2 cup cream. Beat egg yolks, add the sugar and flour. Gradually add the scalded milk, cook until thickened. (Use a double boiler to prevent scorching.) Cool. Add flavoring. Whip cream and fold into the custard. To obtain cream for whipping: Spoon top carefully from milk bottles (not the children's milk). From a 2-quart bottle you can get 12-16 teaspoons of cream that will whip. Save in refrigerator in a bottle until you have enough (3-4 days). * Orange-Cream Filling: 3/4 cup sugar 5 tbsp. Flour 1/2 teasp. Salt 1 tbsp. Orange rind 1/2 cup hot water 1 cup orange juice 4 egg yolks | tbsp. Lemon juice 2 tbsp. Butter Mix sugar, salt, flour, and orange rind. Add orange juice and hot water. Cook until thick, stirring constantly. (Use double boiler or turn heat low.) Add beaten egg yolks and butter and continue to cook 3-5 minutes. Add lemon juice, beating thoroughly, and cool. Split sponge cake and spread on thickly, and fill center hole. Frost with seven-minute icing or whipped cream. *French Chocolate: 3 squares unsweetened chocolate 1/2 cup water Hot milk 3/4 cup sugar Dash of salt cup cream Combine chocolate and water and cook for 4 minutes, stirring constantly. Add sugar and salt and cook 4-6 minutes longer. Cool. Whip cream and fold in. Place one rounding tablespoon in each cup, and pour over hot milk. Stir to blend. Serve at the table, putting chocolate mixture in a silver bowl and hot milk in that special pot or pitcher. The chocolate mixture may be kept in the refrigerator for several days.

THE CUPBOARD OF MY MIND Ann Young Hughes My thoughts are pretty dishes. This rare old china platter The cupboard is my mind, I fill with gems, and song. Where cups are filled with wishes And these I daily scatter Of almost every kind. To help some soul along. The saucer thoughts are shallow-I throw them all away For lovely bowls that hallow My heartfelt thoughts today. This urn of pain, not pleasure, Is cherished fragile ware That holds my rarest treasure? The thoughts of friends who care.

Perennials For All-Year Blossoming Hazel D. Moyle ?FLOWERS are among God's finest thoughts of beauty, taking form to gladden mortal gaze?bright gems of earth, in which, perchance, we see what Eden was?what Paradise may be!" These are the sentiments of a famous philosopher. Do we not, then, need flowers round our homes now as never before to comfort our spirits and give us hope and courage during these dark and busy war times? To me the meanest flower that blows can give? Thoughts that do often lie too deep for words. So said the poet Wordsworth. Let us not deprive ourselves of these lovely symbols of truth and beauty: every home should be a citadel of tranquillity ?during these troubled times, a place where our faith can be restored and our dreams renewed. We need our flower gardens in which to reclaim our ideals? but just how are we to find time to grow flowers, with the daily schedule of everyone already so overcrowded? The answer may be found in the planting of perennial flowers, for these plants are more or less permanent additions to the garden, once they have become established. The perennials live over year after year, many of them giving increasing bloom and beauty as the years Page 224 pass. They become old friends, reappearing with punctual precision each at its appointed time. We have chosen six well-known and easy-to-grow perennials as being essential for every garden, for by planting these six indispensables any home flower lover can enjoy bloom from spring until fall frosts arrive, and almost every back yard can find room and time to cultivate such a simple planting. While there are many other beautiful and worthy flowers that can be grown without a great deal of skill or extra work, we believe the following should be in every garden, not only for their desirability and beauty, but because they thrive with ordinary care in almost any location. The peony comes first on the list, because it is the earliest to bloom and also because of its long life. Last year I saw a fine old peony plant that had flowered each spring for thirty-five years without replanting ?and it was a garden in itself with its great mass of nearly fifty large double blooms. Remember, when you set out roots of the peony next fall (for this plant should never be planted in spring), that in order to enjoy such a performance of flowers, perhaps for the rest of your lifetime, you should see that it is planted correctly. Choose a spot in full sun, well PERENNIALS FOR ALL-YEAR BLOSSOMING 225 away from trees and overhanging growth, and dig a hole at least two feet deep. In the lower half of this hole you must place good, rich nourishment for those future years of bloom, old barnyard manure should be used generously and well tramped down. Then a layer of ordinary, good garden loam should be thrown in, upon which to set the roots. The pink buds or eyes should be placed one inch below the surface of the soil?this is of the greatest importance for too deep planting is the cause of many failures in blooming?firm this soil well before planting, so the new roots do not settle too deeply, then fill up the hole and water well. Choosing from the bewildering wealth of lovely and desirable varieties offered in the catalogues, becomes a major problem for any flower lover, but if you will use the rating of each kind as given by the American Peony Society, printed plainly in front of the description in all reliable catalogues, this will assist you greatly in making your choice. Good points are rated up to ten which would make a perfect flower. There are actually some with the highest rating of 9:09 that are now very cheap in price. Any variety receiving a rating of 8 or more should be a good choice, those of lower rating usually having some fault or other. Remember that by choosing early, midseason, and also late-blooming varieties, you can enjoy a long season of bloom, and, if you have room, do include that grand old flower, the Decoration Day peony, officinalis. This is available in pink, red and white. It is a flower of satiny luster and it also blooms two weeks or more before other varieties. The second perennial on our list is the iris.... And who would do without this wonderful flower! Designed just for the busy gardener, this accepts our hot, dry climate with amiability, demanding little care. Ordinary unmanured soil suits it well, its one absolute requirement being an open, sunny situation. In order to bring out the full beauty of the lovely, silken iris flower, the plants should be well watered while buds are forming, and during the flowering. (You can prolong the blooms and make them much larger, too, by watering generously at this time.) But for the rest of the year they can stand neglect. If you have not grown any of the newer varieties of iris, then you have a treat in store. Every garden should find room for the exquisite, great, orchid-like bloom of the variety "William Mohr," which can now be purchased for a mere trifling twenty-five cents. A still newer and lovelier variety in named "Ormohr," costing a dollar or more. Iris experts have recently produced one named "El-mohr," the same breath-taking size and beauty, but taller and of a deeper colored mulberry-purple. Being a rare, new type (producing a seven-inch flower), this demands a high price, however, in a few years, we can all enjoy it at a reasonable price. "Purissima," a beauteous white variety, and "Wabash," notable prizewinner with great blue-purple falls and white standards, also deserve every gardener's consideration ?but choose for yourself according 
226 to your own tastes and purse and space.
This can be transplanted at almost any season, even when in full bloom. So if you see some flower that you covet, this coming June, there is no reason why you should not take a start home with you.
THE third perennial on our list is the flaunting 'oriental' poppy. For sheer glamour and breath-taking beauty, one need look no farther than the new varieties of this fine old flower with their beautiful, silken flowers of such melting colors as coral, geranium-pink, flame, cerise and shell-pink. The finest of all is named 'Wonderkininde,' a great flower of lustrous watermelon pink, as large as a dinner plate.
This plant has one strict requirement: it should be planted during its dormant season, which is from August until late fall. Spring planting brings only failure, so be sure to order your plants when the poppies bloom during late May and June. Once established, there are few more faithful garden subjects, and their requirements are just ordinary garden care.
July brings the splendid towers of blue of the modern delphiniums. Even one or two of these spike-like flowers can lift any garden out of the ordinary. While these proud blooms require a little more attention in staking and watering than others of our list, they are well worth the trouble. A lower and more spreading type named 'Delphinium Belladonna' can be grown with less care, and is longer lived than the tall new hybrids. Both are lovely.
The midsummer phlox is number five on our list?where could we find a finer flower for this time of year? The great, magnificent heads of bloom can now be had in a bewildering variety of vibrant and flaming colors. In cooler sections of Utah and Idaho this perennial fairly outdoes itself. Plant your phlox in most ground where they receive morning sun, but where they are shaded in the late afternoon. And if yours is a hot, dry garden, prepare the ground well with very old manure, then mulch the surface each spring with peat moss, lawn clippings, or more old manure. And if the flower heads are clipped off as soon as they have faded, others will form just below, and you can enjoy phlox for many weeks. Soak the plants deeply by allowing the hose to run without a nozzle during the blooming period.
Our last flower is the chrysanthemum, for this is the queen of all fall flowers and one that brings an entire new season of beauty into your garden. Recent hybridizing has brought us many new types and varieties, many being early enough to bloom and valuable in colder sections where ordinary chrysanthemums seldom flower. The University of Minnesota has worked for years on an early and extra-hardy strain, and a splendid list of kinds and colors of these are now available as well as many other desirable new kinds and colors.
The cushion mums, growing into a low, bush-like plant, each so floriferous that one plant becomes a garden in itself, are also brilliant and lovely. One can now have chrysanthemums of almost any color except blue, and the taller Chrysanthemums will do in just PERENNIALS FOR ALL-YEAR BLOSSOMING 227 ordinary good garden loam, but will pay handsome dividends in deep color and profuse bloom if the plants are given a little extra feeding during the growing year. This is easily done by applying a one-inch mulch of old, well-rotted manure (cow manure is best) around each plant at two-or-three week intervals. First cultivate the surface, then apply the manure, and follow immediately with a thorough, deep soaking, preferably with the nozzle of the hose removed. Do not sprinkle as this sometimes brings mildew. This mulch helps to keep the soil moist at the same time it supplies mild feeding. With this, our sixth perennial, the year is brought to a close with a brilliant fanfare, a fitting farewell to summer. And the joyous part is that these same plants do not die, but when spring once more returns they arise from their winter's sleep in response to some mysterious call? The gentle heat and soft repeated rains, Make the green blood to dance within their veins, Then, at the call, emboldened out they come. And swell the gems, and burst the narrow room; Broader and broader yet their blooms display, Salute the welcome sun and entertain the day, "Spring"?Dryden

THE RESTLESS HEART Courtney E. Cottam Do not seek for me in the quiet heart Of a June-blown, golden rose, Nor in the twilight-shadowed pause That marks the daytime's close. Look for me where the poppy breaks, In a splash of flaming red; Where lightning opens a silver path. There my dancing feet will tread. For mine is a restless, burning heart. That spurns the weakling's cry; My pagan soul serves the storm god's might-In spirit, the fearing die!

The Strength of the Pack Mary Petteison 
"MOTHER, why are you up so early? It's only a quarter after six!" Jane exclaimed as she came into the kitchen in her night gown.
Her mother continued to sift flour into her mixing bowl till the sifter was empty. Setting it down she said firmly, "Don't you realize what there is to do today? I have to be in court for Steven at half past nine."
Jane's mouth made ready to answer, but her mother, anticipating contradiction, went on to say, "I know I don't have to be there till ten o'clock, but I want to be off the street before everyone in this community is on his way to work or to shop. Besides I'll have to prepare something for lunch that I can set down in a hurry, because you know I'm due at the Supply Depot at one o'clock."
"It makes me sick to think that Steve would be so silly as to get mixed up in a scrape with that tramp of a Rink Shader. When I asked him what he did it for he told me it was none of my business. I'd like to know if it isn't." Jane finished scornfully.
Jane's mother turned and faced her. "He's my son and I don't want you to talk that way about Steven, but he was wrong to tell you it was none of your business. It is the whole family's business. What we'll have to do is to try to keep it from happening again. We must try to help him to live above his
things. I feel as if it were all my fault," she sighed.
"I don't see why," Jane protested. "I do, and it's hard to take," her mother answered remorsefully.
Jane heaped two self-praise. "See what I've done, I've kept myself and helped you with the living expense. I've had nice friends, too."
Mrs. Paige answered in a kindlier tone, "Yes, you've done fine, but you must remember we've sort of worked together,' and for the first time Jane noticed that her mother had been crying.
"I'll come right back and help you, Mother," Jane said sympathetically, as she hurried off to dress.
"Jane," her mother called into the hall, "be careful not to waken Lorna, but when you get dressed go upstairs and rouse Dwight and Ned. Breakfast is at seven this morning."
Steven came into the kitchen with his shoes in his hand and sat down to put them on. His mother looked at him sadly. "Here is a clean shirt, and you had better put on your best shoes, I want you to look neat and respectable. Hurry and get dressed because you know you have to report at school before you come to court."
Mrs. Paige walked hurriedly along the streets of Riverton. She carried no umbrella though rain seemed imminent. Above all, she hoped she could not meet not be overtaken by anyone she knew. She was too full of doubts and regrets to carry on conversation. She remembered how often in her sorrow her friends had persuaded her to get out among people. "Children that are watched too much don't get along any better than those that are put on their own responsibility" had been offered as sound advice.
Just as she reached the street corner on the opposite side from the court house, she saw Judge Alden ascending the steps. She quickened her gait, wishing to speak with him before he settled down to office routine. She entered the main hall just as he was going into his office. "Good morning, Mrs. Paige," he said cheerfully, and closed the door.
Full of misgiving and disappointment, she went into the Juvenile Court and seated herself on the east side of the room, four seats back from the Judge's table.
A crash of thunder echoed through the building and the rain began to fall copiously. She sat watching the ever-flooding window, lost in the problem which faced her. At length she murmured, "There's no use of talking to the Judge about my trouble. I know the ins and outs of it myself." She remembered the day when Steven had come in confidently and asked, "Mother, will you buy me a wheel, nearly all the boys have one?"
"No! I can't afford to buy you a bicycle," she had replied curtly, "now let that end it." He had not spoken more, and she recalled now that he had never mentioned it again. And Once to Grandma Doris Palmer GRANDMA Stanton looked wistfully after the mail truck, fading fast disappearing down the dusty street. Grandma had walked the six blocks to the little post office in the heart of the small rural town of Lakeview, for the past five days, and had received no word of any kind from any of her five children. They were all married now, and had families of their own. This was the first year Grandma hadn't had birthday cards and gifts sent in plenty of time for her birthday. Now only one short day remained.

"Well, you would lose this bet," Donald called after Grandma's retreating figure. Everyone in Lakeview loved and understood Grandma Stanton. She always put on a brave front, and underneath had a sweet and sensitive nature.
There was no time to stop and talk with friends who called to her as she hurried home?not this morning. Granddad was getting the ground ready for the vegetable and flower garden. They were late in getting it planted anyway.
Grandma viewed their large, comfortable home with mixed feelings as she approached. The house was of colonial design, set back from the road amongst a group of oak and fragrant locust trees. To the right was the family orchard. The trees were already covered with pink and white blossoms. On the left was the vegetable garden. Two cedar pines decorated the front gate, one on each side of the walk.
The Browns lived one block nearer town, and the Hudsons two blocks farther north. The Hudsons paddled the three Jersey cows Grandma insisted on keeping. She did love to take care of milk, and make her own yellow butter and creamy buttermilk.
Grandma and Granddad had been among the first settlers in Lakeview, and had watched its growth with pride and interest; but they had sold their farm to the Hudsons when the two boys had chosen other professions, two of the girls had married business men and Mary had married a young doctor in the nearby college town. It was there she had attended school and won a teacher's certificate, only to get married the following season. Now the old house was empty of young voices.
Granddad was leaning on the plough handles waiting for Grandma's approval of the ground. Maybe it was not deep enough, and Granddad was not taking any chances. His hat was pushed back from his ruddy face, disclosing the shock of gray curly hair that was so like a little boy's.
