Belle Smith Spafford Called to Be Ninth General President of Relief Society, April 1945 Marianne C. Sharp First Counselor in General Presidency "O ye that embark in the service of God, see that ye serve him with all your heart, might, mind and strength, that ye may stand blameless before God at the last day" (Doc. And Gov. 4:2). THE admonition of the Lord contained in the above verse of the Doctrine and Covenants, a favorite quotation of Belle Smith Spafford, has been heeded by her throughout life. This observance coupled with the manner in which she has developed her great capabilities in working for the Relief Society resulted in the call by the First Presidency, on April 6, 1945, of Sister Spafford to become the ninth general president of Relief Society.
President Spafford will be welcomed to her new position by a host of friends, members of the Relief Society throughout the United States and in the stakes of Canada and Mexico, whom she has met during the past ten years while she has traveled extensively in the interest of the Society. They will recall her affectionately for her friendly interest in regard to their special problems, and the ability which she has demonstrated in helping to solve them.
It was just ten years ago this April 1945 that Sister Spafford was called by President Louise Y. Robison from her position as counselor to President Marie Tanner of the Wells Stake Relief Society to become a member of the General Board. In December of 1937, she was asked to assume the added responsibility of being editor of Thefollowing the death of Sister Mary C. Kimball. During the eight years that Sister Spafford has edited the Magazine it has had a phenomenal growth in subscriptions   increasing from 40,000 in 1937 to 72,000 as of April 1945. The excellence of the contents has been of a high order which has steadily improved over the years, reflecting the advancement of the women of the Church in writing skills. It was in 1942 that a short-story contest was inaugurated by the General Board which has resulted in encouraging Church women to enter the field of fiction and improved the content of the Magazine in that line. As editor she has consistently manifested a great desire to meet first, the spiritual, and then the literary reading needs of the readers of the Magazine. When Sister Lyman was called to become general president, in 1940, she retained Sister Spafford as editor, and gave to her the added responsibility of serving as an editor of A Centenary of Relief Society published to commemorate the first hundred years of the Society. The knowledge gained from this experience has given to Sister Spafford a broad understanding of the rise and development of the Society which will prove invaluable to her in her new position.
In addition to editorial duties, President Spafford has always carried her full share of General Board responsibilities, and has done preeminent work as the chairman of important committees. Her ability in this line was signally recognized in November 1942 when she was called by President Lyman to succeed Sister Donna D. Sorensen as her second counselor in charge of educational work. The faithful performance by President Spafford of every call which has been made upon her for Church service whether to serve in the Sunday School, the Young Women's Mutual Improvement Association or the Relief Society, to which so many years of her life have been devoted, has culminated in the present call to head the great Relief Society.
BELLE SMITH SPAFFORD was born of goodly parents. She has never known the loving, watchful care of a father for her own father, John Gibson Smith, who was born in Toode, died when he was only forty years old and before Belle Smith Spafford was born. Her young mother was thus left to face life alone and to rear her six children and an orphaned son of a brother. The family resided in Salt Lake City. Sister Smith was a true Latter-day Saint, and her wise sayings are often quoted by her descendants and continue to guide them in their daily conduct.
Sister Spafford received her schooling in the Salt Lake City schools, at the L.D.S. high school and is a graduate of the University of Utah Normal School. The teaching skill which she gained in the years she spent teaching in the Salt Lake City schools and at the Training School at the Brigham Young University has been reflected in the professional supervision which she has given to the better teaching of the lessons taught in Relief Society. She pays high tribute to the influence on her life of that great personality President George H. Brimhall who imbued her with the importance of religious and spiritual values in education, and of that outstanding educator, President Franklin S. Harris, for helping her to appreciate the values of high educational standards and the necessity of continuous application in improving one's teaching skills.
President Spafford is the wife of Willis Earl Spafford who is Field Deputy of Internal Revenue. Without his tender care which he always has guarded her, without his unselfish acceptance of the calls which have been made upon her time, increasing with the passing of the years, without his full support and wholehearted co-operation, it would not have been possible for Sister Spafford to have continued her Church duties and at the same time to have cared for her family of two children. Their daughter Mary at the present time is doing postgraduate work in social work at the University of Utah, and their son, Earl Smith Spafford, is in the navy serving as a hospital apprentice at Portsmouth, Virginia.
In leading forward this greatest of all women's organization, President Belle Spafford's great concern, as has also been that of her predecessors in this office, will be to follow out, implicitly, the desires of the Priesthood in regard to Relief Society, and to so plan and so shape its activities as to fully support the great Church Welfare Plan, and to foster and strengthen in Relief Society members a living testimony of the gospel.
It will be a joy to me to work under the guidance of Sister Spafford in the general presidency of Relief Society. She is a thorough Latterday Saint and is guided in her decisions by the standards of the gospel. She is a considerate and fair fellow worker, always ready to undertake the major part of any assignment and to help out in any need, at the same time, however, expecting a high standard of performance in return. She is a tireless and prodigious worker. For the past eight years she has spent many hours of each working day on some phase of Relief Society activity, and her assignments have been many and varied. The great honor which has come to President Spafford may be considered as a merited blessing on her years of self-sacrificing and devoted service.
RELIEF SOCIETY Amy Jeanne Donnei One hundred years have vanished down the skies As apple blossoms disappear with spring, And still the work goes on! Strong, lingering, A Prophet's inspiration and command Still guide us, with a love that never dies. Throughout the years a valiant, growing band Of mothers, loyal, humble, kind and true. Has sought and helped the needy, lit anew The flame of hope in many a careworn heart, Soothed many a fevered brow with gentle hand, And strong and steadfast, gladly borne its part In trouble, and when famine swept the land. Dear Father, by whose blessings all these years Thy daughters have grown numerous and strong. Facing the coming years with quiet eyes, Humbly we pray for wisdom to do right. And courage that strides onward though through tears. And deep humility and faith in thee. That we may do thy will, and with the light Of truth and kindness and the Spirit's fire Hold high the standard that the Prophet gave With God's command and covenant unto Those mothers that he blessed so long ago. If we can be as gentle and as kind. As valiant, righteous, generous, and true As those first mothers, then our hearts' desire Thou wilt have granted, for we ask of thee But to be worthy of the name they bore. And of thy blessings on us, as of yore.
Marianne Clark Sharp First Counselor in General Presidency, April 1945 President

PARALLEL Alice Money Bailey I Strong and lithe they were, and full of grace  The legend sons of Helaman  for such, In tenderness, he called them, loved them much, Though they were soldiers his the right of mace Above them. Striplings all, they were  each face Unbearded; sweet of mouth as yet no touch Of war was theirs, no guilty shame, no clutch Of fear: The pure in heart! The swift of pace! And when he asked: "Would ye go out to fight?" They answered: "Yea! To free our fathers' land"  Rehearsed their mothers' teachings how the right Prevailed. In soberness they took the brand. Nor wavered in belief the God of might Would hold their precious lives within his hand. II Troubled in his soul and torn with doubt Was Helaman for on the plain below The battle raged. On Nephite friends, the foe Had turned the Lamanites and runner, scout Brought only news of tragedy and rout. For Antipus was slain, and blow on blow Was dealt his reeling columns. Tardy, slow. The leader sent his sons to draw them out. They fought as gods that day. Each flashing sword Was steeled by righteousness, the searing strain Of conflict ribbed by faith. At last, the horde, Abject, surrendered. Helaman, in pain Of fear, set forth to count. Proud words record Not one of his two thousand lads was slain! III The centuries roll out on a disk of time That turns upon itself" for still men lust For power and riches, fame and toss the crust Of beggary to brother men each age a mime Of ages gone before. The parts, sublime And wretched all are there the foul, the just, The valiant. Nations leap to glory, rust. Decay, and crumble. Man alone is prime. Still mothers teach their youth simplicity. Obedience, faith and love 'and how to shun The coils of earth how touch infinity. Still are some who pray when day is done, Who know the source of power Divinity  And still in battle Sons of Helaman.

Gertrude Ryberg Garff Second Counselor in General Presidency, April 1945 Edith Smith Elliott THE wise selection of Gertrude Ryberg Garff as second counselor to President Belle Smith Spafford of the Latter-day Saint Relief Society will be a blessing to the women of the Church. Her training and background fit her admirably for her new position. Above all else, she has a firm testimony of the gospel of Jesus Ghrist, and although young in years, she is old in experience. Sister Garff was born in Hyrum, Utah, to Charlotte Critchlow and Eric William Ryberg. Both the Critchlows and the Rybergs contribute a rich heritage to Gertrude. Her mother's forbears rank high in early educational fields and were participants in the American Revolution. Sister Ryberg has been a leader, active in Relief Society. Gertrude's father's parents were converts to the Church from Sweden. They settled in Logan, Utah, and played a forceful part in the development of that community. Brother Ryberg has been a successful contractor and is an outstanding executive in the business world. Sister Garff was five years old when the family moved to Salt Lake City in Wasatch Ward. She is fortunate to have had parents who trained her in the paths of knowledge and righteousness. She has always had great faith in her Heavenly Father, which has been a great source of comfort to her. She has been a firm believer in the fact that GERTRUDE R. GARFF *'faith without works is dead," so she has willingly done her part.   She completed her early studies in the Salt Lake City schools. Desiring further knowledge and training, she entered the University of Utah. At the end of her second year she received and honored a call to fill a mission for her Church. She was assigned to the Eastern States Mission under the presidency of Brother James H. Moyle. Here she labored as a field missionary in Jamestown, New York, and in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. Her special assignment was radio work. Her mission strengthened her testimony in the divinity of Christ and gave her a religious schooling that has helped pattern her life.
Her mission furthered her desire for learning. She knew that the "glory of God is intelligence," so when she returned home she once more entered the University and graduated in 1935 with a Bachelor of Science degree. Her major was in textiles, with a minor in foods and child welfare.
IN October 1935, she married Mark Brimhall Garff, son of Tryphena Brimhall (sister of President George Brimhall) and George P. Garff. She had met her future husband (who had been home two years from a Danish mission) at a Granite Stake conference where they had both been called upon to discuss their missionary experiences.
In September 1937, Brother and Sister Garff were again called to the Lord's service this time to preside over the Danish Mission with headquarters in Copenhagen. Their son Mark was only two and one-half months old so this made the planning for so long a journey a major problem. However, with faith in God they lost no time settling to the task before them. Both were very young to be given so important an assignment but, in spite of this, they made an enviable record. Sister Garff learned the language so that she could assume her full responsibilities as head of the women's auxiliaries, with a special and personal interest in Relief Society. She won the love and trust of the Danish saints. Her warmth and understanding made her role as "mission mother" a source of strength to the
in the welfare of young people was ever apparent not has it even ceased since she returned to Zion.
Besides discharging her many missionary duties admirably, Gertrude found time to study the social, historical, economic, and cultural aspects of the Danes. She learned to love and appreciate these Norsemen. A lover of art, crafts, literature, and music, she spent any free time she had in museums, art galleries, and opera houses.
She enjoyed the companionship of her baby. She used to take him with her on bicycle rides in and around Copenhagen tucked into the baby's seat on the front of her bicycle.
When the war clouds gathered and broke into World War II, our missionaries were called home. The first available space that President Garff could obtain to transport his wife, little son, and several Scandinavian missionaries to home shores was on a tramp steamer. President Garff had to remain to reorganize the mission on a local basis. We can well imagine the anxiety of that parting. Faith alone made it possible. The ship had to take a northern route up around Iceland for safety. The voyage lasted seventeen days and the passage was unusually rough. Gertrude and the baby arrived home in November, in time to spend thanksgiving with her father and mother. By Christmas, President Garff returned safely and the little family was grateful to be reunited.
The following January 1940, Sister Garff was appointed a member of the General Board of Relief Society under its new president, Amy Brown Lyman. Sister Garff and Sister Lyman had developed a close friendship in Europe which Sister Lyman was presiding over the women's auxiliaries of the European mission. Sister Garff has said of her many occasions that she doesn't know how she could have carried on her great responsibilities had it not been for Sister Lyman's frequent letters of direction and encouragement. Sister Lyman's deep understanding of people and their problems, with her helpful disposition made it natural for Gertrude to turn to her for counsel and advice. She was very happy to be called into a continued association with so noble a character.
Sister Garff is friendly and approachable. She works well with people. She has the courage of her convictions, yet is pliable to the extent that if she is shown a better way she willingly accepts it. She attacks each assignment with an open-mindedness intelligence.
Gertrude and Mark have three young children: Mark R. (eight years), Charlotte (four years), and baby Georgia (one and one-half years). These human treasures along with her splendid husband receive her untiring devotion.
From her husband, her father, and her mother, she will receive maximum support in her new position.

FROM UNNAMED MOUNTAINS Dott J. Sartori From unnamed mountains marred with violence You write "How are the hills of home this year?" A tendril groping for some permanence To twine beyond the loaded bandoleer Here are the counterparts of memory. The canyon, cleft within your exiled brain. The misted peaks, become reality. I troll the ageless certitudes again Down to you from a wind-washed eminence Where russet soil has settled on this tier Of rock. The evergreen still drives its lance Into the sky, a changeless cavalier. The butterflies thread woods along the stream. Woof of the forest and weft of your dream. Assurance of unaltered majesty In the long-lived profile of a precipice, I send, and faith no stricken earth nor tree Shall disillusion your returning eyes.... Upon the northern slope, the aspen stems Glow silver-green, pale as a luna moth; The fern is beaded lace between the hems And petticoats of cool and living cloth. This boulder sheltered daisies small as these The age, when under Pinta's listing spars, Mutinous eyes, from strange and fearful seas, Were lifted to the same familiar stars. On some dark retina, now dust, once lay Horizons I delineate today.

Marcia Knowlton Howells First Counselor in the General Presidency, 1940-45 President Amy Brown Lyman MARCIA K. HOWELLS DAUGHTER of a Relief Society stake president and relative of one of the two elders who assisted the Prophet Joseph Smith at the organization meeting of the Relief Society, Marcia Knowlton Howells has, since her childhood days, been familiar with Relief Society work and activities, and she has always loved, appreciated, and honored this great woman's auxiliary of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Her mother, Minerva Richards Knowlton, was a life-long member of the Society and served for many years with distinction as Relief Society Page 272 president of Davis Stake, which at that time covered the whole of Davis County. In addition to traveling about, supervising and directing the welfare, health, and civic activities in this progressive unit. Sister Knowlton planned and prepared the courses of study used in her wards. The General Board at that time did not provide, as it does today, a uniform course of study, and stakes were left to prepare their own work. Marcia, no doubt, remembers seeing her mother work long hours and far into the night over her outlines, after a hard day of household activities. Her grandfather's uncle. Dr. Willard Richards, accompanied Joseph Smith and John Taylor to that important meeting in Nauvoo, Illinois, on March 17, 1842, when the Relief Society was organized, and assisted by acting as temporary secretary until the organization was effected and Eliza R. Snow was appointed permanent secretary. His name is listed among the seven donors who, on that memorable occasion, made charity contributions and thus established the first charity fund of the Society. With this unusual Relief Society background, a rich heritage in itself for a Relief Society worker, with her long years of service in the organization, and with her exceptional ability, Sister Howells has been able to make outstanding contributions to MARCIA KNOWLTON HOWELLS 273 the Relief Society cause in both ward and stake as well as on the General Board. I first met Marcia Knowlton at the summer cottage of Sister Heber J. Grant at Brighton where we were both guests. I was immediately attracted to her because of her charming and interesting personality, her fine qualities of heart and mind, and her boundless energy and interest in life. And from that time on I have loved and admired her and have enjoyed association with her as a fellow worker in civic and Church activities. SISTER HOWELLS was called to the General Board of Relief Society on February 2, 1929, and on January 1, 1940 was appointed first counselor in the general presidency. As a Board member she has given generously of her time to important committee work, and has traveled extensively throughout the Church attending stake and mission conferences and conventions. Her work in the general presidency has been largely of an administrative nature. As manager of the temple and burial clothes department and general director of the Mormon Handicraft Shop, she has demonstrated unusual executive and managerial ability, carrying forward her labors in these connections with efficiency, diligence, and dispatch, and achieving, withal, phenomenal success. Directing the work of these two important departments, always a challenge, has been especially taxing the last few years because of the shortage of materials and merchandise and because of war restrictions; but Sister Howells has always regarded this assignment as a rare privilege which she has enjoyed. She appreciates the distinctive and important service and opportunity these projects provide or offer to the people of the Church. As a member of the general Church Welfare committee, with special assignment to the clothing committee, and as work director on the General Board, Sister Howells has given time and attention to the clothing and sewing plans of the Church Welfare program, and to the sewing activities which are carried on in the regular work meetings of the Society. She has also assisted with the preparation of that portion of the General Welfare budget which has to do with the clothing program. Sister Howells has represented the General Board in many community activities, notably those which have had to do with health and welfare work. She was state chairman of the May Day Child Health Day in 1939. She is at present a valued member of the executive committee of the board of directors of the Utah Tuberculosis Association. She recently helped to direct the establishment of the splendid library of which the U. S. O. Of Salt Lake City has been so proud. In 1939, she attended the National Conference of Social Workers at San Francisco, following which she attended a social service institute at the University of California at Berkeley. In 1941 in company with Sister Donna D. Sorensen, she represented the Society at the biennial meeting of the National Council of Women. Sister Howells has been a wise, safe, and helpful counselor. Blessed with intelligence, broad experience, and sound judgment, and fortified with a burning testimony of the gospel and with an understanding of the responsibilities and obligations resting upon those who serve in a Church capacity, she has been able to recognize the relative importance and value of the many questions and problems presented for consideration and action, and to help to make wise, reasonable, and safe decisions. She is an able presiding officer and a gifted and fluent public speaker, with an excellent vocabulary. She gave promise of these fine qualities of leadership when, as a young woman, she served as president of her class at the L.D.S. high school, and as vice-president of the student body of that institution; also later during her four-year period of teaching.
She was educated in the public schools of Farmington, at the L.D.S. high school and University of Utah, preparing herself for the teaching profession at the latter institution. In 1910, she was married to Dr. Thomas J. Howells, a leading physician of the State, and an able and progressive specialist in the field of public health. He was for many years the Salt Lake City health commissioner, in which position he gave excellent service, and is at present a member of the State Board of Health.
Sister Howells is a generous, devoted, and unselfish friend. She is never happier than when doing something for others. When her friends are in trouble she is among the first to visit and comfort them. I count it as one of the distinctive privileges of my life to associate with and share work with Marcia Knowlton Howells.

MEADOW LARK Grace M. Candland Returning friend of early spring, I hear Your call from low, green marsh and leafing tree, A lilting song of joyous melody Divinely sweet to each attentive ear. And then my heart grows light, I seem to know That His kind care, perhaps, had thought of me. And of my need of just such ecstacy When clouds obscured the way that I should go. May I, like you, blithe messenger, renew In some despairing life the will to see That lowly things send forth incessantly A song of life that thrills one through and through. Dear meadowlark, your floating notes of bliss Are one rare treat I would not care to miss.

Vera White Pohlman General Secretary-Treasurer, 1940-45 President Belle S, Spafford FEW persons called to a position of trust and responsibility come to that position better qualified through native ability, training, and experience than did Vera White Pohlman when, in January 1940, she was called to serve as general secretary-treasurer of Relief Society. Thoroughly familiar with the history, rulings, and policies of the Society, acquainted with General Board office procedures, having a knowledge of the requirements of Reliei Society Magazine work, and intimate with the work of the Relief Society welfare department through twelve years of previous service in the general offices, her Relief Society background was rich. Prior to her appointment as general secretary-treasurer she had served with the Salt Lake County Department of Public Welfare, where she organized recording and filing systems and supervised the stenographic and clerical staff. She had also been employed as statistician with the State Emergency Relief Administration (F. E. R. A.) which was succeeded by the State Department of Public Welfare, where she served as director of its bureau of research and statistics, contributing much to the development and establishment of its policies and procedures, and to the training of personnel in this new function of state government in Utah. VERA W. POHLMAN All of this experience was invaluable in her Relief Society assignment which had so much to do with welfare work, important record keeping, the formulating and establishment of rulings, policies, and procedures, and the training of personnel. At the time of the appointment of Vera W. Pohlman as general secretary-treasurer, Mrs. Amy W. Evans wrote of her: "With her natural ability for details, her experience in welfare work, her fund of information regarding and thorough understanding of all phases of Relief Society work, her faithfulness to trust, and her dependability, Mrs. Pohlman will make a very efficient and valuable general secretary." Page  This prognostication has indeed been fulfilled. Her record of efficient service to the Society in this responsible position will ever stand a credit to her and a blessing to the Relief Society. Vera W. Pohlman has a brilliant and an analytical mind. She has a marvelous capacity not only to quickly and clearly see a problem or a situation, but to see all that is in any way related to it; she readily recognizes the influence of one situation upon another and can accurately foresee results of action. This rare capacity has made her of inestimable value in executive councils, in committee work, and as a member of the General Board, enabling her to arrive at sound conclusions and to guide others to do likewise. Mrs. Pohlman is a tireless, enduring worker. No amount of time or effort is considered, nor is any thought of saving herself allowed to enter into the performance of her duties. During the early years of her incumbency as general secretary-treasurer when, in addition to the regular duties incident to this position, she was reorganizing the offices and setting up new and more economical and efficient systems of management, she also carried a tremendous responsibility and did a vast amount of work in connection with Relief Society centennial plans and activities. During this period she worked long into the night, denying herself recreation and relaxation. Every minute was devoted to duty. THERE are few people who take greater pride in their work than does Vera Pohlman. Careful, painstaking, accurate effort accompanies all that she does from the smallest unimportant bit of work to the heaviest and most essential of tasks. Perfection is her standard of measurement. Vera fully appreciates the importance of the Relief Society cause. She loves the women of the Church and has a sincere desire to serve them. She continuously strives to make things clear, easy, and convenient for them, and she is never happier than when she feels she has been of service. She has met with thousands of Relief Society women in her visits to the stakes and missions of the Church. In 1943 she traveled continuously from early September until mid-December, meeting with Relief Society women representing 142 stakes and missions. The many expressions of appreciation for these visits bear evidence of the regard felt for her by Relief Society women because of her efficiency and knowledge of Relief Society work, and of their love and admiration for her because of her willingness to serve them. Special mention should here be made of a few of Mrs. Pohlman's special contributions to Relief Society. She has prepared new, simplified visiting teacher report books, and has revised ward and stake record books. The revised record books allow for the inclusion of valuable information, much of which was formerly not included, particularly with regard to the sewing program. This information permits a clear picture of the status of all phases of Relief Society work and materially aids the General Board to better plan and more effectively direct the Society. Mrs. Pohlman's personal ability to interpret figures and give them life and vitality is a rare gift.
In 1941, she prepared family record forms for use of Relief Society presidents in making a family analysis. These forms, endorsed by the Church Welfare Plan, are in use at the present time and are a guide and an asset to Relief Society presidents in analyzing the situation of families under care and in making sound recommendations to bishops regarding family needs.
Relief Society publications have benefited by the skills and knowledge of Vera W. Pohlman. She is a gifted writer, meticulous in the preparation of material for publication and is familiar with technical publishing details. She has continuously edited "

Sixty Years Ago Excerpts from the Woman's Exponents, May 1 and May 15, 1885. "For the Rights of the Women of Zion, and the Rights of the Women of All Nations" What Can A Woman Do? No doubt many members of the Institute have wondered what vocation in life they should adopt by means of which they could earn their own livelihood, thus promoting self-reliance and the ability to do something sufficiently remunerative to enable them to fight the battle of life single-handed, if necessity required it, or circumstances compelled them to do so. As there is always a possibility that reverses may come to all of us is it not wisdom to give some consideration to this subject? It would be impossible to define just what course any member should follow to become entirely successful; in this matter, as in many others, we must be our own judges. One thing I can say with certainty, and that is this: In making up our minds we should not adopt any kind of labor in the slightest degree degrading. Whatever we try to do, let it be the labor we love; something we can do enthusiastically. People are rarely successful who work mechanically. Some persons have thought, and do so now, that the only labors a woman should perform must be of a domestic character; that to be a household drudge is all she is capable of being; but such persons must be told that at the present time there are hundreds of ladies in the civilized world making themselves famous as authors, physicians, surgeons, public speakers, painters, sculptors and lawyers. The advanced situation of the women of today grants to her all the privileges she may seek to enjoy; and if for any reason she does not choose to marry, there is no law to compel her to do so. This being the case she should know how to take care of herself, and earn her own living...  C. R. S.  A Pleasant Party. Editor Exponent: One of the most enjoyable affairs that ever happened in Deseret came off on the 2d of April in the form of a surprise party in honor of the Prest. Of our Society at the Relief Hall. Sister Eliza Whicker has been president of this society for seven years, and is a noble and well respected sister. The tables were spread with a sumptuous repast and the company seated when our beloved President arrived. After dinner the ceremonies were continued by presenting Sister Whicker with a neatly gotten up and appropriate address in a suitable frame, and several other presents by the sisters, followed by a programme, consisting of speeches, songs and recitations Sister Whicker addressed those present for a short time, thanking the sisters for their kindness; said she prized the address more than gold or silver. A vote of thanks was then returned to the committee for their exertions, and the entertainment closed with singing and prayer. Respectfully, Mary A. Bishop, Secretary. Deseret, Millard Co., April 8, 1885. The exhibition of Decorative Art work at Young Bro's on Main St., which commenced on May 12th, and has been continued since up, to the present, is something wonderful in the way of ornamentation, and requiring less natural ingenuity, it would seem, than embroidery done by hand. Everything, large or small, can be executed on the Domestic machine, on satin, silk, plush, canvas, etc., with chenile, arrasene, crewels, embroidery silk, tinsel, applique, mosaic and etching. Crowds of people were attracted every day to see the handsome and elaborate display of goods, and to watch those who were engaged in running the machines, doing all sorts of fancy ornamental work of different varieties and patterns with the people looking over in wonder and amazement. Surely this is something under the sun. Page 278

Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon DEAN Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, sixty-seven-year-old American delegate to the United Nations Conference at San Francisco, holds the degrees of Philosophy of Literature, and, from three universities. Doctor of Laws. She has long been a close student of international affairs. She was present at the dinner at which President Wilson enunciated his Fourteen Points. She was active in the Commission to Study the Organization of the Peace, as also in the Association to Aid Scientific Research by Women, and in the American Committee on International Intellectual Co-operation. PARIS expects to lead the world again in fashions. Before all the Germans were driven out of France, forty style salons in the capital were presenting fashion shows. Women came to them on bicycles and shivered in the unheated rooms. THE First White House Conference on Rural Education has been held at the instance of Charl O. Williams, competent woman director of the Field Service of National Education Association. Fifty-two per cent of the Nation's teachers are rural. Their average salary is $967 a year. Per capita, Washington charwomen receive more than do 44,000 teachers. AFTER doing a magnificent job of flying   principally ferrying army aircraft  the WASPS (Women Airforce Service Pilots) have been disbanded. Though their work was one of the most dangerous kinds and required highly skilled women, they were never given military status as were other women's military organizations. SOMETHING Is Lost" a poem by Utah's own Christie Lund Coles, has been chosen by William Rose Benet for publication in The Saturday Review of Literature, a magazine which finds its way to all literary editors and writers. IRENE CURIE received, in 1935, jointly with her husband, Frederic Joliot, a Nobel prize in chemistry. For a time the Germans confiscated their Paris laboratories containing the gram of radium purchased for Madame Curie at the price of $100,000 by women of the United States. The laboratories were later returned. PEARL BUCK'S collection of short tales. The First Wife; and Other Stories gives a deep insight into Chinese life. IN America, 900,000 copies of young Betty Smith's A Tree Grows In Brooklyn have been sold. Page 279 

VOL. 32 MAY 1945 NO. 5

Relief Society Achievements 1944-45 THE month of May brings to a close the Relief Society educational season. In spite of curtailments and handicaps due to the war, the 1944-45 season has been a successful one marked by unusual development for Relief Society women and great accomplishment for the Society. With few exceptions, high standards have been maintained in all phases of the work, and Relief Society workers may justifiably view this past season with satisfaction and pride. The General Board sincerely appreciates the efforts of Relief Society officers and class leaders as well as the strength of Relief Society membership. It commends each one for her devotion to the Society, for the time, energy, and ability she has given to the work, and for the part she has played in the growth and advancement of Relief Society. It recognizes the support Relief Society women have given to the war programs sponsored by the Society, and the service they have rendered in their respective communities. The elements which make any organization successful are good beginnings or a sound foundation, a purposeful and worthy program, a capable leadership, and a devoted membership. Relief Society has all of these. It was organized by the Prophet "under the Priesthood after Page 280 the pattern of the Priesthood." No more worthy objectives could animate any organization; namely, to develop its members spiritually and intellectually, and "to manifest benevolence irrespective of creed or nationality." For more than one hundred years the leadership of Relief Society, including the general, stake, mission, and local leaders, under the direction of the Priesthood has been sincere, energetic, capable and above average; and no organization could boast of a more devoted membership? women who are bound together by the ties of the gospel and who value their organization as an auxiliary of the Church and as a medium through which women may attain full self-realization and render satisfying service. To be a part of such an organization is a blessing and a privilege. True, in the process of performing our part, those of us who have contributed to the onward march of the Society during the past season may have met with discouragements and with obstacles which have had to be surmounted under difficulties, but the surmounting of these, rather than retarding us, has actually developed and strengthened us. In total, the benefits that have accrued from efforts put forth should leave Relief Society women satisfied and happy at the end of this educational season. BSS.

Howard S. McDonald Appointed President of B.Y.U. THE First Presidency announced on Wednesday, March 14, 1945, following a meeting of the board of trustees of the Brigham Young University, the appointment of Howard S. McDonald as the new president of the Brigham Young University to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Dr. Franklin S. Harris who resigned to become president of the Utah State Agricultural College at Logan. Mr. McDonald has served as superintendent of schools in Salt Lake City since July 1 of last year. In that short period of time he has made an outstanding record of achievement in this position. Previous to that appointment he was deputy superintendent of San Francisco schools.
President McDonald is a devoted member of the Church. He was a missionary in the Eastern States, a stake M.I.A. and Sunday School officer in both the Cache and San Francisco Stakes, and served as counselor in the San Francisco Stake for five years before becoming president of that stake. His wife is the former Ella Gibbs of Brigham City. They have two daughters.
The General Board of Relief Society extends its congratulations both to President McDonald and also to the Brigham Young University on his appointment.
Relief Society members appreciate the opportunity of sending their sons and daughters to a college where not only courses in higher education are offered but, in addition, a training and association are provided which are not found elsewhere and which may prove a potent force in the lives of their children in strengthening and increasing their testimonies of the gospel.

He's Coming Home, Let's Spruce Up! The Honorable Earl J. Glade Mayor of Salt Lake City Prepared at the Request of the Church Beautification Committee WITH 30,000 of Salt Lake City's sons and daughters scattered to the far reaches of the wide, wide world, and sacrificing their comforts of home and their associations with loved ones, and sometimes giving their very lives, it is indeed difficult for us on the home front to focus our thinking on the centennial celebration for 1947. A grateful Utah capital city is earnestly praying that, surely by then, this crushing, devastating war will be over, and our own brave boys and girls will be right here again in the old home town. But ours must be an alert home town! It must be not only on its toes; Salt Lake City must be on its tip-toes! If the 173,218 Salt Lakers will all just catch the spirit of homecoming, it will not be such a Gargantuan job to make a brilliant centennial showing. Here's How: Every home owner should take a 1945 spring inventory of "dress-up musts" and give them the works! New parking to be seeded; new concrete walks to be laid; a new roof for the home; two coats of fresh paint all around. Aged and decaying trees should come down. Alleys should be cleaned. During 1945 and 1946, neighborhood should vie Page 282 with neighborhood in this great home-coming dress-up! We shall be doing it for our own ?the best youngsters in the world! What we say for Salt Lake City, of course, goes also for every town in the State. The proposed 1947 centennial might well catch the spirit oi a great homecoming celebration/ Just as the pioneers in 1847 found their haven in Salt Lake valley, so, too, will our own young men and young women in the armed services be grateful?yes, unspeakably glad to be home. Business and Industry on the Job, Too! Just as each home must step out and dress up, so, too, must business and industry?new store front, new display windows, new interiors, new and finer signs. Down with shacks and dumps! Out with rubbish and junk! City, county, and State administrations must tie in with each other in selling their respective communities as being good places in which to locate new industries. Surely, by 1947, there will be some determinations regarding Geneva Steel which, if good fortune breaks just right, may prove the basis of an entire new economy for the Inter-mountain Empire. The newly electrified Northwest of Seattle and Portland will want Utah steel for their rapidly growing manufacturing industries, which will also undoubtedly help largely to supply a new China and a new Russia, as well as the great new Westl Salt Lake City Also to the Front! HE'S COMING HOME, LET'S SPRUCE UP! 283 The city corporation must also bend every effort to meet this call for a home-coming spruce-up. To the very utmost of our finances must our highways be put in shape. The incumbent administration is devoting its energies to getting the city out of debt and at the same time carrying on municipal improvements every way in its power. This is a Herculean task! At this time, new, large feeder water mains are being laid to take care of the homes on the higher east and north bench elevations. Salt Lake City parks are being put in the finest shape in their history. The mile track in Liberty Park, for instance, is being paved this year. And an ambitious paving program, together with extensive improvements, is also proceeding in the City Cemetery. Salt Lake City seriously needs an auditorium of ample capacity. Such a structure would provide the locale and facilities for many new community achievements. The easy way to finance this vital need would be to go in debt for it, by bonding. We are hopeful of being able to find another way, for borrowing would just add to our financial slavery. Our present bond retirement plan is a courageous one, and if strictly adhered to, will get our city reasonably out of debt in a few years. Utah's capital city must do its share to prepare for the great centennial home-coming. By getting the utmost out of every dollar expended, great achievement in city beautification can be wrought. Possibly, pending developments in municipal financing on which we are earnestly working, will help us also to meet the perennial community stumper: "Well, Mayor, what are we going to use for money?" Maybe, one of these days, we'll surprise the man who throws that question at us, by having an answer ready that will be an answer. Let's just see!

entries.title: All-Year Care of the Rose Beds
entries.author: Hazel D. Moyle

loose_match.content:
All-Year Care of the Rose Beds Hazel D. Moyle "A rose is a rose is a rose is a rose? says that woman poet, Gertrude Stein, meaning, no doubt, that to say it is a rose is enough, for does not all mankind acknowledge the rose as the acme of perfection, the queen of all flowers! The back-yard flower gardener might, however, be inclined to add a more practical word or two to this poetic roundelay. Well do we know that roses do not grow in such obliging and supreme beauty unless we follow a few rules and regulations. We may purchase the finest and newest modern rose bush, guaranteed to be bigger and better than any other ever seen, but if we do not give that plant a little regular care, its blooms may prove to be disappointing. Roses do demand certain attentions, but few other flowers give such generous returns for the little they do demand. The plants often live and flower abundantly each year for a lifetime, requiring no replanting, resetting or dividing. The modern hybrid tea rose, which is the type now planted so universally in our gardens, blooms not once a year, but it often sends out two, three, and even four crops of flowers in a single season. Fall roses rival those of June in our Utah gardens, some rose lovers actually claiming that they excel the earlier crops. With the cooler weather, their colors are even richer and more brilliant than during the warm June days. Page 284 The attentions that roses demand are simple, the important point is, they must be given regularly. First of all comes the job of uncovering the plants in early spring (that is, if you live in a cold section where they need winter protection). Begin loosening the coverings as soon as the hard freezing is over, but do not actually remove it on the first warm day. Gradually uncover so that the tender wood which has been covered all winter can become accustomed to air and cooler temperatures. Likewise, do not cut the long old wood back until the buds begin to swell. Go slowly, even though you are impatient to begin work, because of late cold snaps of weather. But do not put off pruning until the top buds are actually growing actively, for this will take much of the stored-up strength of the plant which will then be lost as the plants are cut back. Consider all these conditions well, then use your best judgment as to the best time to begin. In pruning the hybrid tea roses, cut out all the weak and crooked branches at their base, preserving only the heavy strong canes. Cut out also any that grow toward the center and interfere with sun and air. Then shorten those you have selected to remain from eight to twelve inches. Sometimes winter has already done this and we have no choice but to cut away the dead wood down to the remaining plump buds. In colder sections the entire top growth may have been killed, but be comforted and cut away the dead wood even so, for fresh new growth will soon spring from the roots and you will still reap roses come year. A later, but perhaps an even better crop.
CLIMBING roses need little pruning in early spring except the cutting away of dead wood ... and be warned that it is often difficult to detect just how much is actually dead. Leave your climbers strictly alone until growth actually begins so that you can be spared the sad experience of finding that you have removed branches that would otherwise be sporting a crop of lovely roses when June comes.
The best time to trim the climbers is just after they have bloomed. Such varieties as "American Pillar" and "American Beauty Climber" should have the old canes that have just bloomed cut away at the base to make room for the vigorous new shoots that will be found springing up from the root. These old canes of this type of climber do not bloom again and merely encumber the plant with dead wood. Get them out of the way as soon as possible after they have flowered. Such strong, large-flowered climbers as "Silver Moon" and "Dr. Van Fleet" need only the removal of the oldest wood occasionally after they have become established, to prevent the plant from spreading and also to keep it vital and alive. If left too long without this attention, it becomes almost impossible to remove old dead branches that will gradually choke it to death. These varieties need restraining as they mature (after two or three years' growth).
A thorough cultivation of the soil of the rose bed is of the greatest importance as soon as it is workable in spring, and this will bring to light many pests that have buried themselves during the winter. Many claim that this is the best defense against the rose beetle, most devastating of all rose pests. Cultivate and stir right up to the base of each plant and stir in any mulch of manure that you may have been able to apply over the winter.
And now we come to that subject of regular care which roses demand throughout the entire summer: cultivation, watering, and spraying. Of these three, cultivating comes first. We must keep the soil from getting hard and baked and firm, for the plants must have air, food, and moisture. Water will not penetrate unless the surface is kept loose and open, and our plants will then sulk and produce poor, slimy blooms. By beginning early and cultivating regularly the day following each watering, when the soil will again have sufficient aeration, this task is made easy, and it will at the same time prevent all weeds from growing.
Use a long-handled, three-pronged cultivator, or any other convenient small tool that will suit your taste, but wield it often and regularly so that your soil will remain loose and open. A mulch of either old, well-rotted manure or of peat moss, or even of lawn clippings can be a great help in keeping the soil from baking, and this will also keep the ground cool and prevent weeds and conserve moisture. If we are fortunate enough to be able to put a two-inch layer of manure, then this will also act as a mild and steady feeding, as well as making an excellent mulch. Roses need rich fare, and they especially thrive on manure. Chemical fertilizers can be applied, too, if the manure is not easily procured, but these must be used strictly according to directions of the brand you select. In using this type of fertilizer, first loosen the top soil, then scatter the fertilizer in a circle about each plant, then apply a deep watering immediately. Such an application can be applied in the spring, and repeated two weeks after the first crop of bloom is over. Rose plants need plenty of moisture, although water should be applied by soaking deeply instead of sprinkling. Remove the nozzle from the hose and allow to run until the ground is well saturated. Then leave the beds until they begin to dry out before applying more moisture. Such a watering will last for a week's time if it is followed by a cultivation the following day. Pest control is also a regular requirement. The best control is to apply one of the all-purpose sprays available at all nursery stores, beginning with an early application as soon as the leaves have begun to open well, and continuing at two-week intervals during the growing season. By sucha program, one can prevent the many ills and pernicious pests from getting started. Remember that no matter what chemical spray or dust you use, it must be applied from underneath so that it reaches the underside of the leaves as well as the upper parts, for it is there that most of the creatures hide out. And the entire plant must be covered to catch any of the chewing insects no matter where they attack. Should your plants show signs of mildew?our most common plant disease, which manifests itself in a grayish, powder-like substance coating the leaves, use Massey dust, also secured at the nursery store, and if this is not procurable, apply dusting sulphur with a dust gun, coating the entire plant and repeating the application until the trouble disappears. There is one pest for which we have as yet found no cure. The villainous rose beetle appears in early June, just as your most lovely roses are coming into full flower, and it thrusts its terrible, long proboscis or beak into the very heart of the flower, despoiling and completely ruining its exquisite perfection. You must hand pick this creature if you would be free from its devastation. Arm yourself with a small pail of water and a little kerosene, then go forth to battle. Shake or flip each black, small bug (you will find them sitting stupidly among your treasures), into the water where it will drown. Its only redeeming feature is that the rose bug does not remain long, but eventually disappears, digging itself into the ground to lay its eggs for another generation of trouble for the next year. The early cultivation of the soil which we advised above will bring to light and destroy these new generations of this pest Active cultivation and feeding of the rose plants should stop after mid-August so that the wood may ripen and harden to withstand winter. New, soft growth will not withstand hard freezing. Winter pro-(Concluded on page 320)

Ten Miles to Calico Martha Robeson Wlight PART II THE next morning none of the neighbors showed signs of making a midweek trip to Og-den. The rutted road past the dugout remained empty. At breakfast, her father squinted quizzically at Tilda. 'Figgered how you're goin' to get your wheat to town?" *Tt*s a problem/ she admitted. "But I got to?today." "A squaw would drag it on poles ?a travois." Tilda stared at her father. A shiver of delight rippled over her? not just because his suggestion was practical, but because of what it signified. First he had offered the twine. Now he'd got the answer to her transportation problem. Then her face fell. "I don't know how you make a travois." "I'll show you after breakfast." And as soon as he finished eating, he brought the axe. "We'll fix your drag now, Tildy." While he selected and cut the right size willows, she yanked and slashed off wild grapevines to serve as ropes. When the travois was finished, it had a lashed platform for the wheat and a pair of shafts for Tilda. She cleaned herself up, braided her hair, and put on the hat her mother had woven for her from pond rushes. Ma brought a lunch?two pieces of cornbread and a cucumber?wrapped in a piece of flour sack. Pa carried out the wheat and placed it on the travois platform. Tilda laid her lunch beside the sack. She was dressed in her Sunday homespun, and wore her shoes. "Take your flipper," ma directed. "You might meet something." Tilda laughed, but she stowed the slingshot and a handful of pebbles in her skirt pocket. Pulling the drag along the road, Tilda pretended she was an Indian girl on the way to greet her warrior lover. She threw her hat on the wheat and hung her long braids over her breasts. With her belt and a turkey feather she found, she made an Indian headband. She had just donned it when old Bishop Robinson rode i|p behind her. "Mornin', Gal," he said heartily. He had twinkling eyes. "Good morning. Bishop Robinson." He cocked his gray head to one side. "Let's see. Whose gal you be? I can't place all these children growing up so fast." "I'm Mathilda Dawson." "To be sure. Say, what you got there, Sister Tildy?" "A bushel of wheat I gleaned. I'm taking it to town." "It's a right hot day for dragging. To save you the trip to Ogden I'll give you two dollars for your wheat." Tilda remembered that though the bishop was a righteous worker for the Lord, he had the reputation of being a shrewd trader. Page  "What say, Tildy?" he prompted. "Whose field did you glean?" "Brother Burnett's/' "He grows good wheat. Tell you, I'll make it three dollars." She didn't want to offend Frank's grandfather. She must refuse politely. "Thank you, Bishop, but I got to take this to town." "Why's that?" The old man shifted his weight in the saddle. "I got to buy me some calico dress goods." His wise eyes crinkled at the corners. "Couldn't you buy the goods with the money? Easier than drag-gin' your sack so far." "Calico's dear. Three dollars ain't enough." Would he be mad? He chuckled, "That's the best I can offer. Well?" She shook her head. "Maybe you'll get more." He clucked to his horse. "Giddap." The dust settled on Tilda. She plodded ahead. The heat grew intense and she stopped briefly to remove her shoes. It felt more comfortable to walk barefoot. Did squaws get this tired? After what seemed a very long time, she came to the river. She would have to carry the wheat across. Tilda caught up her skirts and fastened them around her waist with her belt. She pierced the feather through one of her braids. She unloaded the sack on a ledge jutting out from the river bank. Bending her shoulders, she hauled the heavy load onto her back, then walked cautiously into the shallow stream. The rocks on the bottom were slick. Minnows brushed against her legs. It was hard to keep her balance, but she reached the opposite bank and slid the sack to the ground. Tilda drew a long breath. She recrossed the river, got the travois and her shoes and hat, and brought them over, too. Now she'd eat her lunch. "What's that you're so scared o' wettin', little Injun?" A squat, red-headed man stepped from behind a tree. A tall, gray-haired man and a half-breed joined him. They had rifles. Tilda faced them defiantly, though she quaked inside. "I'm no Indian," she said with dignity. "This is wheat. I see you're strangers. If you are on your way to California, you're headed in the wrong direction. You go through Salt Lake." "We done found that out," mumbled the gray-haired man. "Boys, we can use that wheat, eh?" 'An' take a load off the gal's shoulders," laughed Redhead. "It's my wheat!" Tilda crouched desperately over the sack. "You get more," said the half-breed in threatening gutterals. The tall stranger roughly shoved the girl aside and slung the sack over his shoulder. "Run back home or I'll smack you." Lowering her head like a goat, Tilda butted him. He stumbled and the wheat slid to the ground. But Redhead grabbed her arms. "You big bullies!" she sobbed, and kicked her captor's shins. "Ain't you a hellion though!" There was admiration in his tone. "Now, Sis, skedaddle. Else I'll turn you over my knee and paddle you." A hot flood of mixed humiliation and rage engulfed Tilda. They went into the bushes with her wheat. TEN MILES TO CALICO 289 Two weeks of hard work! The tall man spoke to horses, then she heard wagon wheels creak. Tilda gulped her last sob. She wouldn't let them do it! She felt in her pocket for her flipper and pebbles. In a jiffy she put on her shoes. Those men didn't know this country. If she could make them think Indians were after them, they'd whip up their horses and maybe the jolting wagon would bounce the sack overboard. Keeping in the underbrush beside the rutted road, Tilda hurried after them as silently as she could run. She soon caught up to the walking team. Through the bushes she saw a covered wagon. The tall man drove. His companions rode saddle horses, in front and behind. She placed a stone in her slingshot, aimed carefully, and let go. "Damned hornet!" cursed the driver. Blood dripped from his cheek. "No, that warn't a hornet, what was it?" Tilda smiled grimly. In quick succession she fired her second and third shots. The half-breed and Redhead swore in pain. "That must've been a arrow creased me!" howled the driver. The girl started yelling, in imitation of Indian war whoops. She took deep breaths, opened her mouth wide and patted her palm against it. Tilda shot more jagged pebbles, and dodged about in the bushes. She made a great commotion, but stayed hidden. Redhead wheeled his mount beside the driver and shouted, "To save our scalps we gotta leave the wagon! Climb on behind me!" The half-breed was already in panic-stricken flight. The tall man and Redhead fled after him into. The underbrush. This was much more than Tilda had hoped. She ran to the wagon, scrambled to the seat, and started the horses at a brisk trot toward town. She'd deliver her wheat in style. In half an hour she backed up before Horrock's elevated unloading platform. As Tilda wrapped the lines around the brake handle, Frank Robinson came out of the store. Her successful coup against the three thieves made her feel like swaggering a little. She waved casual recognition to Frank so he'd know that he didn't matter any more. "Hello!" she called. He stood staring. Tilda climbed over the seat into the bed of the wagon and tugged her sack of wheat to the low tailgate. She poised there to step off onto the platform. The team moved and she lost her balance. Girl and wheat tumbled to the ground together, landing in thick dust. Her skirts were partly over her head. The old sack burst, and she was half buried in grain. The fall didn't hurt Tilda. Her first thought was of how she must look. She sat up and frantically yanked down her petticoats. She was so mad that she began to bawIl like a roped calf. Several men had seen her mishap. Frank jumped off the store platform and rushed to help her. Tilda was spitting dust and wheat. They were in her mouth and ears and hair, and inside her homespun waist. Her angry tears made mud smears on her cheeks. Since evidently only her feelings were hurt, the picture was too much for Frank and the other onlookers. They all laughed. Tilda stopped crying and glared around. "There's nothing funny, about it! That was nice, clean wheat. Now look at it!" Frank helped her to her feet and broke off his laugh. "No, it wasn't funny, Sister Tilda." With a white handkerchief he awkwardly tried to brush the dust from her face. "Thanks," she said in her stiffest tone. She jerked away. Some grains under her clothes were scratching her. She couldn't get them out with men around. "Mr. Horrocks won't take dirty wheat." I?ll borrow a sieve from him," Frank offered. "The dust'll blow off. I'll get a new sack." He leaped to the platform. Frank Robinson was kind, but he had laughed at her. And again he had seen her looking like all-get-out. So far as he was concerned it was no use to try to make herself appear pretty with a new dress. He'd never forget the sight she had been in Burnett's field, and now here sprawled on the street with her skirts over her head. Served her right for being so vain. Still, she had set out to get that calico, and she would?not to attract Frank, but to keep from being like ma. He came back with a shovel and sieve and a sack. The other men drifted down the street. Tilda and Frank didn't talk while they sieved her wheat and filled the new sack. The breeze blew away the dust. Frank carried the sack into the store. "Mr. Horrocks," he announced, "here is Mathilda Dawson with some wheat." The storekeeper peered over his spectacles at Tilda. "I don't want wheat unless it's prime good. No smut." "I gleaned it from Brother Burnett's field," she said quickly. "Well, I'll take a look." Mr. Horrocks ran the full length of his arm into the sack and pulled up a fistful of kernels. He examined them critically while her heart filled her mouth. "Yes, it's good wheat. Frank, take it back to the bin." Tilda breathed again. "How much will you give me?" "I'm payin' three dollars a bushel to-day." "Why!" she exploded. "Bishop Robinson offered me three. Reckon he'd have taken it to Salt Lake and sold it there for ten dollars." Horrocks looked at her shrewdly. "Can't compete with Salt Lake prices. I admit it's good wheat, but five is the best I'll do." "All right!" she accepted. "I mean five dollars in trade," the storekeeper amended. "All right," Tilda repeated. "And cash money if there's change." "Yes. What do you want. Sister Tilda?" "Calico for a dress. Green. Maybe white vines or leaves in it." "I've got some nice green. Only six bits a yard." The merchant selected a bolt of cloth. The lovely pattern and colors thrilled Tilda. This was worth all her hard work. She fingered the calico and her eyes lifted ecstatically. Then the joy in them died. On the shelf above Mr. Horrock's head stood a silver caster set. Exactly like ma's picture! Tilda couldn't speak. She just stared and pointed. "That?" The storekeeper reached TEN MILES TO CALICO 291 up for the caster. He set it before the girl. "Pretty, ain't it? Took that in trade for some grub. Feller toted it all the way from back East.' 'H?How much d'you want for it?" she forced herself to ask. Again Horrocks peered at her shrewdly. "Well, that's real silver and worth more, but you can have it for five dollars. I don't have much call for such knickknacks." Tilda looked from the silver table-piece to the calico. She must not get like her mother. But if ma had this real caster set! Would it make her feel not so old? "Got something to wrap it in so I won't scratch it carrying it home?" The words were dead sounds that made hollow echoes of the longings she had killed. "Here's the flannel the set was wrapped in," said the merchant. Frank Robinson returned from the rear of the store. "She had 'most half a peck over a bushel, Mr. Horrocks." "You have six bits change coming. Sister Tilda," the storekeeper calculated. "I'll go get it from the money drawer." Slumped in misery, she gazed wistfully at the calico. Frank picked up the bolt. He flipped it round and round to show a length of the goods, then draped the cloth over her shoulder and smoothed it down to hang straight. It covered most of the front of her ugly dress. His rough fingers caught on her braids. "With your yellow hair?," he paused, looking into her eyes. "The green makes you like?like a daffy-dil. Like Spring." Numbly Tilda stared down at herself. At Frank's hand on her shoulder. At Frank. It was like a husband helping put a dress on his wife. His face turned brick red. He licked his lips. "I was terrible forward." His words stumbled. "I meant you'll be so beautiful in it." He wheeled and hurried out of the store. Tilda knew then the uttermost depths of wretchedness. Frank would never see her look like Spring. She'd always be in the dead blacks and rusty browns of a winter tree. Completely lifeless looking. For only a moment she had been transformed to beauty in his sight. Now she was ugly again. Mr. Horrocks brought her change. Her fingers closed listlessly over the two silver coins. She watched him wrap up the caster. She took the bundle in her arms. "I could use more fine wheat like you brought," he remarked. Tilda burst through her numbness as if she had snapped rope bonds. Why, she hadn't half gleaned Brother Burnett's field! She could get another bushel of wheat as easily as the first! "Here!" Tilda thrust the coins into the storekeeper's hand. "I'll be back with just as good a sackful. Take this money as part payment for six yards of that calico. The green! Be sure to save it for me. Promise!" she demanded. He chuckled, "It's a bargain. Sister Tilda." "T'll bring the wheat in two weeks," she said. Tilda wanted to dance on the road home, but she had to be careful of the caster set. How ma's eyes would pop! Pa's, too. Tilda did a few cautious hop-skips, and sang, (Concluded on page 319)

THE momentum of the 1943 Magazine subscription campaign, when 13,000 new subscriptions were added, carried over into 1944, resulting in a further increase of more than 4,300 additional subscriptions. By the end of the year the subscription list had reached a new high figure of 71,200, an increase over the 66,790 subscriptions reported at the end of 1943 of 4,210 or six per cent.
More Than 1000 Names On Honor Roll

Subscriptions From Non-ranking Societies Also Appreciated In addition to the stakes, missions, and mission districts whose local Relief Societies attained rates sufficient to place the entire area on the honor roll, 63 stakes and 10 missions are represented not by a rating for the stake or mission as a whole, but by one or more of their local Relief Societies which attained honor-roll status. Accordingly, a total of 134 stakes (all but 14) and of 16 English-speaking missions (all but 2) are represented on the 1944 honor roll by one or more local Societies. It is regretted that a few (Beaver, Panguitch, South Ogden, and Moon Lake Stakes, and the Hawaiian Mission) which were so represented in 1943 by high-ranking local Societies are not represented by even one ward or branch this year. Nevertheless, we are mindful and appreciative of the thousands of subscriptions which have helped to swell the total subscription list but which were obtained by local Relief Societies whose individual rates did not entitle them to a place on the honor roll. It is hoped that the accomplishments of the year 1944 will encourage these Relief Societies to renew their efforts during 1945 and match the achievements of their sister Societies.

NOTES FROM THE FIELD Vera W. Pohlman Former General Secretary-Treasurer Regulations governing the submittal of material for "Notes from the Field" appeal in the Magazine for February 1944, page 104.CAMPAIGNS
Cottonwood Stake
THIS stake has demonstrated that success may be attained by working steadily toward a goal. In 1942, this stake's rate of Magazine subscriptions was among the lowest in the Church?26 per cent. Stake and ward Relief Society workers, determined to increase the rate, made the greatest numerical increase in the Church during 1943 (from 211 to 580 subscriptions) but, nevertheless, fell slightly short of the honor roll with 71 per cent of their members as subscribers. They still persisted in their efforts, and now appear on the honor roll for 1944 with a stake rate of 90 per cent, and with 6 of 8 wards represented.
Merle S. Muir, stake counselor in charge of the Magazine, wrote of this accomplishment:
"It is a satisfying climax to a huge effort and one of which we are very proud. This happens to be the first time in the history of our stake that we have been fortunate enough to achieve the honor roll. We hope it won't be the last. You will notice our subscription rate is 90 per cent for the stake and that 5 wards have over 100 per cent. All credit is due our ward Magazine representatives and officers for their effort and support. We found them willing and enthusiastic workers, and I'm sure the satisfaction they feel in their ward and stake report repays them for their efforts. As a stake we appreciate beyond words their efforts.
"Our biggest desire now is that each will read and enjoy her Magazine and realize the spiritual and temporal help it gives. As a stake we express our appreciation to the Magazine staff for the splendid Magazine they give us. We enjoy and appreciate the privilege of working in the Relief Society and the association it gives us."
Zion Park Stake
JESSIE H. GIBSON, stake Magazine representative, wrote last January commending the ward Magazine representatives and officers for their efforts which placed this stake on the 1944 honor roll with a rate of 91 per cent. Five of the 7 wards of this stake also appear on the honor roll with high rates.
Her letter continues: "We feel especially proud of the record of Della Hardy, Magazine representative of Springdale Ward, who has placed the Magazine in every home in her community whether members of our Church or not. Several Magazines were also sent to other communities as Christmas presents. NOTES FROM THE FIELD 315 She exceeded her good 1943 rate of 86 per cent by the exceptional rate of 154 per cent for 1944. We feel that her leadership deserves a little special mention and hope it will inspire other Magazine representatives to try a little harder next year." Boise Stake CAROL R. FLAKE, president of * the Boise Fourth Ward Relief Society, wrote last August: "At the suggestion of Dorothy Clapp Robinson, counselor in the Boise Stake Relief Society and supervisor of the Magazine representatives, I am sending in this account of our 'Dollar Day' which launched our Magazine campaign. Lillis Me-lander is our representative. "A large group of our sisters met in the pleasant surroundings of Elm Grove Park where a program was presented featuring the importance of the Magazine to the entire family. Talks on the subject. Things I Like About the Magazine' gave interesting and varied reasons for having it in the home. Our stake Relief Society president, Josephine Anderson, and Counselor Dorothy Clapp Robinson, commended us for our achievement of 104 per cent in the 1943 campaign and urged us to include at least 6 subscriptions this year to be sent to our Church missionaries. Accordingly, our members deposited voluntary contributions in an attractive dish which was afterwards awarded as prize to the one guessing nearest to the correct total of $8.14 which was received. "The program was interspersed with the singing of several original Magazine pep songs composed by various members, including the following: HERE IS OUR MAGAZINE Irene Read Tune "Idaho" (State song) You've heard of the wonders of our Magazine And all of the good it can do. It educates, stimulates, brings out the best But not half has been told to you. Chorus So here is our Magazine, Winning its way to the top. Once you've subscribed it will always come, You never will let it stop. You will read it, morn, noon, and night. Keep it in sight?'twill make your life bright. You will love it, its praises you'll sing, Sing of our Magazine. Our agent will take your subscription today. And benefits soon you will glean. When your family looks forward each month for the day When the postman brings their Magazine/ I'LL SUBSCRIBE FOR ANOTHER YEAR Edith Mathews Tune "Auld Lang Syne" Is my subscription up to date? I surely want to know. I cannot miss a single book Because I need it so. Our Magazine, our Magazine, Its pages I hold dear, I need its influence in our home? I'll subscribe for another year!" As indicated by the foregoing report, the Boise Stake Relief Society officers suggested that each ward contribute 6 gift subscriptions for women in foreign missions, and some of the wards exceeded this assignment. The stake board itself set the example, sending in seven gift subscriptions, one in the name of each ward of the stake. This is another stake which exceeded its good 1943 rate of 80 per cent by a 1944 rate of 95 per cent for the stake as a whole. Five of the 7 wards appear on the honor roll, all of them with rates well above those of last year, four of them over 100 per cent. Western States Mission LUCEAL R. CURTIS, recently released Relief Society president of this mission, wrote in September 1944: "Since March 17 our mission has had as one of its projects the binding ofs. One Relief Society now has a complete set of the Magazines bound and in its library. Two other Societies have 7 bound volumes and a great number have 3. These Magazines were bound to celebrate my three years in the mission. When they had them bound they sent, on July 15, a birthday card stating that they now had in their libraries bound volumes of the Magazine for 1941-42-43." For the third successive year this mission has achieved a place on the honor roll, this year with a higher rate of 81 per cent, and with nineteen of thirty-five branches represented, thirteen of them with rates of 100 per cent or over, including Sheridan Branch with the exceptional rate of 157 per cent.OPENS THE DOOR SPIRITUAL LITERACY SOCIAL KNOWLEDGE Magazine Campaign Poster, West Ensign Ward, Ensign Stake. ELIASON, stake Magazine representative of this stake which appears on the honor roll with a stake rate of 78 per cent and with four of six wards represented, suggested that each of the ward representatives make a poster for display in each Relief Society room. Each poster was to be original, to give some indication of the value derived from the lessons and other material published in the Magazine, to create interest in the Magazine among non-subscribers, and to serve as a constant reminder to subscribers to renew promptly. At a party held at the close of the campaign month, October in this stake, each ward representative was asked to bring her poster, and the display created much interest. A feature of the party for ward representatives was the surprise demonstration of selling the Magazine which was given by Hazel Spencer of the North Eighteenth Ward (on the honor roll with 140 subscriptions, 79 per cent), with stake Relief Society president, Alice B. Steinicke, as the potential subscriber. These gift subscriptions are received with great appreciation by those to whom they are sent, principally missionaries and officers of new mission branch Relief Societies who may not have been able to subscribe immediately themselves. It might interest you to know that I have been a constant subscriber for the Magazine ever since it was first published and still enjoy reading it at the age of 85 years.?Salt Lake City, Utah. Thanks for a good Magazine that is still the same in price and value, in spite of high prices and shortage of material and help.?Snowville, Utah. Have neglected writing to you and letting you know how much I thought of Thelma Ireland's poem "Moonlight on the Mountains." I have it framed and also it was read at the Woman's Club, and the P. E. O. Of this city. We thought it fine ?Creighton, Nebraska. Because of illness I have neglected sending in my renewal to our Magazine, but I won't miss a single copy of it.
