Utah Shall Blossom Abundantly Elder Irvin T. Nelson Supervisor of Landscaping on Temple Square... The desert shall rejoice and blossom as the rose. It shall blossom abundantly, And rejoice even with joy and singing (Isaiah 35:1-2), THE State of Utah, on her Centennial eve, should be ready to blossom, yes, to blossom abundantly. Let there be trees and lawns, shrubs and flowers. Let the whole State blossom as our planting dictates, as the rose, as the lilac, as the peony, as the lilies and poppies of the field. Remember this, however, unless we plant, there can be no blossoming. To this end, each person who loves his State should show that love by planting something to clothe her in beauty. Before blossoming can come, there must first be plowing and planting, hoeing and watering. Even before a sod is turned, there must be the mind's vision of what is to come. There must be patience, too oh, the long years of waiting before some flowers bloom! Our pioneer forebears showed us the way, with patience, with vision, with labor. The standards set by them are worthy ones for us today. They were fired by the injunction of their Prophet given in the stress and suffering of Jackson County, Missouri: "Zion must increase in beauty, and in holiness. Yea, verily, I say unto you, Zion must arise and put on her beautiful garments." Through all the hardships of the pioneers, there crystallized one yearning, a home again, in security, where they could worship as they pleased. In Nauvoo, they showed how they could make even a swamp blossom with real homes. But for many of the pioneers, as they trudged the weary miles to Salt Lake Valley, or waited at Winter Quarters, or in a foreign land, there was only patience and work and looking forward to the blossoming that was to come when they reached the Valley. And many of them went down into Death's Valley, instead of on to Zion. They died holding fast to a dream of homes, safe from enemies, and, in due time, the peace of shade trees and the joy of roses. But those dreams were not buried on the plains. Those who were permitted to come to the Valley worked with an added zeal, because of the true souls who had given their all, and it was not long before real homes began to blossom 'in the valleys. Stubborn soil was cultivated and made to produce food and clothing were urgent necessities. But not by bread alone did they live. Their homes held safe the treasures of the spirit. Beauty, as well as utility, was in their gardens. In those covered wagons were carried not only fruit trees and corn for the planting, but also rose bushes and geranium slips. With their own hands the pioneer built homes and filled them with handiwork and, seeing the State must be organized. Plans their work was good, then came the must be made. Now is the time for us to show that we appreciate our heritage and our desire to pass it on. As war conditions improve, cities, counties, and the State must be organized. Plans must be made. Work must proceed. As individuals we should not say,  I wish I could hire someone to make me a beautiful garden.  Do it with your own hands and there will be the joy and the singing. JULY Courtney E. The New First Presidency THE women of Relief Society, along with tens of thousands of other Latter-day Saints, rejoice that even though a great and beloved leader, President Heber J. Grant, has been taken from our midst, another has been raised up to guide and direct the affairs of the Church. It is comforting to know that in these days of anxiety and sorrow the earth is not without a prophet, seer, and revelator, one appointed to receive and make known the will of the Father for his children on earth. It is not by chance nor by the whims of God or man that one is called to hold so exalted a position upon earth. The Lord has told us that he rules in the heavens above and in the earth beneath in all wisdom and prudence. He showed unto Abraham "... The intelligences that were organized before the world was; and among all these there were many of the noble and great ones; Arid God saw these souls that they were good, and he stood in the midst of them, and he said: These I will make my rulers; for he stood among those that were spirits, and he saw that they were good; and he said unto me: Abraham, thou art one of them; thou wast chosen before thou wast bom" (Abraham 3:22-23). Even though these great and noble spirits were chosen for their earth work before the world was, this is not enough. Page 414 They must prove themselves here; they must continue in righteousness as they live from day to day upon the earth. Thus President George Albert Smith comes to his position as head of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. A great and noble spirit, born of goodly parents, he has devoted his life to the service of his fellow men and to the work of the Master. He has labored diligently in building the kingdom of God upon the earth. He has traveled far and wide carrying the gospel message by precept and example. He has sat in the highest councils of the Church, being ordained an apostle by President Joseph F. Smith when only thirty-three years of age. For the past two years he has been President of the Council of the Twelve. President Smith comes to the position of highest authority in the Church beloved by members everywhere. His tender nature, his kindly ministrations, his thoughtful considerations, not confined to the prominent alone, but extended to the least of God's children, often at the expense of great personal inconvenience, have won him a host of friends within and outside the Church. Blessed are the Latter-day Saints to have such a president in this day of tribulation.
His two counselors, President J. Reuben Clark, Jr., and President David O. McKay, are men seasoned in wisdom and experienced in the work of the Church. They, too, are chosen men of God, men who through the nobility of their lives and the greatness of their leadership
have won the love, respect, and confidence of their fellows the world over.
The newly sustained First Presidency holds the esteem and confidence of Latter-day Saints everywhere. We acknowledge the good ness of our Heavenly Father in raising up able men to lead his Church, to guide his people, and to carry forward his work.?B.S.S.

This Night to Remember Christie Lund Coles HE didn't say anything . . . he didn't need to. At the touch of his hand, she stood up and fitted into the curve of his arm while her hand slipped slowly up the shoulder of his dark coat. Their bodies moved together with the effortless grace of water.
The sky, through the high gymnasium window, was lighted by a full moon over which clouds moved like wind-blown thistle. A trumpet trio had stepped to the front of the stage and was harmonizing an old waltz. The lights were dim and these young people who had never learned to waltz, moved slowly, shuffling their feet, stardust in their eyes.
Boys in uniforms with girls clinging to their arms stepped through the side doors into the night. But Felice and Chad continued dancing silently, easily, as if there were no time, no future, only the rhythmic moments.
But when the tune was ended they moved to join several other boys and girls. One of the boys said, "Say, maybe we're lucky to be in engineering. For the time, at least, tonight is just another night to us. But to these other kids it's the last for a long time. They're trying to cram a lifetime into a few hours."
"How right," Chad agreed, easily, gaily, though Felice thought she saw the flesh darken above his white collar. He turned to her rather quickly and his arm tensed. "Are we five?"
She nodded, smiling into his brown eyes, and they moved toward the open door.
ONCE outside, their feet seemed automatically to go toward the south lawn of the campus where the maples in their riotous colors formed a parasol of lace over their heads, where the oaks and the silver birch stood quivering against the sky. They walked slowly, unhurried ly as they had done on many nights before, their hands clasped lightly together, a silence?deep and understanding?between them.
Finally, she said, "The boys look cute in their uniforms, don't they Chad?"
"Fine," he agreed, then clearing his throat, "It will seem strange around here with so many of them gone."
As they walked they saw couples in various places, a boy and a girl sitting close, talking in fast, incoherent sentences, trying to say things that would bridge the time until they met again.
Felice repeated, "Trying to cram a lifetime into a few hours. How can they know which are the important things to say? How could one choose?"
"Yes, how?" he repeated, steering her to the left until he brought her to a birch tree where they paused. "Remember?" he asked quietly, running his hand over the bark that had been cut with a sharp knife to form their initials. "Weren't we silly? Page  Each trying to out-talk the other, both afraid we would never have another chance to say the things we felt." "I suppose that's how it is with them tonight. They are afraid... And well they might be." "Would you be afraid?" he asked, leaning his tall length against the tree, looking down at her, a quizzical smile upon his lean features. "Perhaps. I don't really know." "What was it you said that first night, "Love isn't a part of time.' " "Oh, that. I said, 'Love has nothing to do with time or space or age.' I must have read it someplace. And sophomores are so wise." He laughed shortly, "And not wise at all when we are seniors. Who was it said that when he graduated from high school he knew it all but when he finished college he realized how much there was that he didn't know." "I wonder if anyone ever feels that he knows a whole lot?" she asked, her narrow forehead wrinkled becomingly. "I'm sure I don't. And I doubt if anyone does in these times. But let's talk about us." "There'll be plenty of time for that. In fact, there has been some little time spent on the subject... Or don't you remember?" "Sure do, lady," he assured her. "But I'm just checking to be sure I remember rightly. Are you still taking good care of that frat pin I gave you? Does it mean as much as it did before?" She looked surprised, "Why, of course, Chad." He took her hands in his, "Does it still make you dizzy when you think about me?" "But, sir, spare my blushes. Don't hold everything I say against me." There was laughter in the brown eyes she lifted to his and her wide, young mouth was parted softly. Suddenly, he pulled her to him and kissed her slowly, gently, then harder, hungrily, as though to solace a deep hurt or a dark fear. She drew back, "Now, what good would thinking about you do, after that." He tweaked her ear, laughing gently, "Come on, Twerp, if we hurry we can see Orion." "Really. Isn't it funny you've been saying that every week for over two years and it still gives me the same thrill. Seeing those stars sort of puts us in our place." LATER, when they came out of the observatory building, they paused to let the wind brush cooling fingers through their hair. They looked down over the sleeping college town, the beloved campus, the blue hills to the west. She sighed, "Another Friday night... Just like the others, yet somehow different. And now home." "Just one more thing," he whispered, huskily, laying his hand on her silken hair, "I love you." "And I love you, Chad. Lots." "I've got to tell you," he began swiftly, "I'm going, too. I'm going with the others tomorrow. I enlisted. I should have told you but I wanted tonight to be just as the other nights had been. As long as you didn't know, it was okay. But... But, if you had known I would have been tempted to ask you to run away from the crowd tonight, to ask you to marry me . . . or something."
His words had followed on one another so quickly that her choked, "Oh, Chad," had been lost in the web of them. Now, he stopped, holding her by the shoulders with his hands, looking intently into her eyes.
Her voice caught in her throat as she asked, "Could you have treasured anything more . . . than . . . tonight?"
He lifted her chin in his hand, shook his head. "No, Twerp. I'm sure of one thing, lifetimes can't be lived in that. It's like running backwards . . . you never quite catch
up with yourself. I'll know you are here, waiting. That's enough."
"And I'll know, I'll know every minute, Chad, that you'll be coming back. Tonight will be doubly precious because it was just like other nights."
They looked long at one another, kissed. When he let her go, she said, "There's just one more thing, Chad, . . . Your sister told me this morning that you were leaving."
He gave a short laugh before he whispered, "You did joke!"
Then his fingers curled hard about hers, they started down the hill, a silence?deep and understanding?between them.

The Martyrdom of Joseph Smith For Tuesday, October 2, 1945 Objective: To indicate the worth of a great testimony and its supreme value to the onward development of the Church. JOSEPH SMITH, prophet of the * nineteenth century, stood one January day in the year 1844 to address the newly appointed officers of peace for the city of Nauvoo. As mayor of the city he spoke, and within his voice was heard the prophetic tone of impending danger for himself and people. Some thirteen years had passed since the ?little flock" who first believed this modern seer had gathered at the home of Peter Whitmer that April day in 1830 to organize the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. And what bright yet bitter years these had been! Half a continent had been spanned in the march of missionary endeavor. Yes, even the Old World, too, had heard the elders sent by express command of a latter-day prophet. Now around him thousands of saints had gathered, and had builded Nauvoo, the most beautiful of cities then to be found on the rich and fertile soil of Illinois. Could it be that the time had truly come when Zion was to rejoice and but hold in memory those trying days of Kirtland and Independence? His words on this January day seemed not to indicate this for he said:... I am exposed to far greater danger from traitors among ourselves than from enemies without, although my life has been sought for many years by the civil and military authorities, priests, and people of Missouri; and if I can escape from the ungrateful treachery of assassins, I can live as Caesar might have lived, were it not for a right-hand Brutus. I have had pretended friends betray me. All the enemies upon the face of the earth may roar and exert all their power to bring about my death, but they can accomplish nothing, unless some who are among us and enjoy our society, have been with us in our councils, participated in our confidence, taken us by the hand, called us brother, saluted us with a kiss, join with our enemies, turn our virtues into faults, and, by falsehood and deceit, stir up their wrath and indignation against us, and. Bring their united vengeance upon our heads. All the hue-and-cry of the chief priests and elders against the Savior, could not bring down the wrath of the Jewish nation upon His head, and thereby cause the crucifixion of the Son of God, until Judas said unto them, "Whomsoever I shall kiss, he is the man; hold him fast.? Judas was one of the Twelve Apostles, even their treasurer, and dipt with their Master in the dish, and through his treachery, the crucifixion was brought about; and we have a Judas in our midst. (Essentials in Church History, pp. 360-361; D. H. C. Vol. VI, p. 152) What group of traitors from within would now essay the role of Judas and, pincer-like, provide the other prong of opposition to join with those mobocrats, from without to encircle and destroy the Prophet and his work? Somehow the storm of hate which ten years before had set the cry in Missouri, "the Mormons must go," now insidiously smoldered within the very councils of the Church. William Law, the Prophet's second counselor, together with his brother Wilson, William Marks, Leonard Soby, Robert Foster and others took offense at their leader's words and pulled away into a council of apostates who were secretly to pledge themselves to destroy Joseph Smith and his party; in fact, it was later discovered that William Law was in league with the Missourians who ever since the escape of the Prophet from their State had vowed to reach across the border line of Illinois and claim their man.
Realizing the price God had set upon the strength of a testament, (Hebrews 9:16-17), Joseph Smith repeatedly forewarned his followers of his coming death, first by visioning the ultimate need of a land beyond the rim of the great western mountains to which the saints might press for safety; and second, through his frequent words concerning the threats upon his own life. At a conference in October of 1843 he said, "This generation is as corrupt as the generation of Jews that crucified Christ; and if he were here today, and should preach the same doctrine he did then they would put him to death. I defy all the world to destroy the work of God; and I prophecy they shall never have power to kill me till my work is accomplished, and I am ready to die." (Essentials in Church History, p. 365; D.H.C. Vol. VI, page 58.)
Some eight months following this meeting with the saints, Joseph Smith with his brother Hyrum was martyred in Carthage Jail, having calmly willed to surrender to the Prophet's enemies in the assurance that the true priesthood and spirit of the Lord necessary to establish the Church of Jesus Christ were again on earth. His courageous mission had made this so. Now the work of God was a living reality as evidenced by testimonies of hundreds of faithful and devoted saints. The story of the swift and final days ending with the death of the Prophet will ever live in the hearts of those who love him, for with the unselfish gift of his own life, they may now lay claim upon the force of his testimony.
Let us briefly follow the steps of the story to see how boldly this modern seer of his own free will made the supreme gift for the Church of Christ he again established. It should be remembered that ever through the struggle to bring again the work of God in the latter days, the powers of evil bored from within as well as without. Men who at first were true, turned false, to join with those who ever hated the truth. With the increase of Church membership and the promise of peace and plenty for the saints mounting, fear and jealousy stole into the hearts of Joseph Smith's enemies. He had now become a figure of national interest. As lieutenant general of the Nauvoo Legion, as mayor of Nauvoo, and as candidate for the office of President of the United States, prominent citizens sought him, wondered at his wisdom, and often inwardly feared the divine power of his office as prophet of God. Those who could curry favor of him for their own advantage did so, and those who feared, sought secretly either to work upon the ignorance and hatred of fanatical mobocrats to bring about his overthrow, or, by failure to act in the cause of justice, used their office to wink at infractions of the law. Thus because of the words of weak-willed officers, the saints suffered; their Prophet time and again was arrested, then arraigned before a court of justice to stand trial, only to be set free.
So between the cross fire of writs which shuttled back and forth between the Governors of Missouri and Illinois, he threaded his way in and out of the trials where enraged deputies lay in wait to ambush him. Such had been his lot up to that January in the year of 1844.
During the months of February and March which followed, often his thoughts and acts were turned to constructive plans toward the fulfillment of the Rocky Mountain prophecy of August 6, 1842. It was decided to send some twenty-five men to explore all the mountain country, carrying the gospel message wherever they went. Any man who could "raise $500, a good horse and a mule, a double-barrel gun, one barrel rifle and the other smooth bore, a saddle, and bridle, a pair of revolving pistols, bowie-knife, and a good saber" might volunteer. Visioning the future of his people, the Prophet predicted that within five years the saints would be out of the power of their enemies, and asked that his
words might be written down that none "need not say they had forgotten the saying."
Spring of the year 1844 was to see events that led up to the fulfillment of Joseph Smith's predictions concerning his own death. Within this season came the dark combinations of apostates. Men who before had been high in the councils of the Church met at the fifth. Chauncey L. Higbee, Robert D. Foster, Joseph H. Jackson and Wilson and William Law together with Austin Cowles, Francis M. Higbee, Charles Ivins and Charles A. Foster were implicated in a conspiracy to kill the Prophet. When exposed, the first five named were excommunicated. Imbithered, they, with others, attempted to organize a church of their own with William Law at its head. Their efforts were doomed to failure. Frustrated, they then sought other means to satisfy their alleged plans, and they hit upon a malicious course of airing their hatred of the Prophet and his cause by means of the press. Their organ, the Nauvoo Expositor, appeared June 7, 1844. It was filled with vile slander aimed at Joseph Smith and many of Nauvoo's leading citizens. Striking at the most vulnerable spot in the body armor of saints, they attacked the Nauvoo Charter, a document of most liberal and far-reaching grants, under which the then thriving commonwealth on the bend of the Mississippi had come into being. The citizens of Nauvoo could not and would not accept this underhand thrust at their very existence. Within three days the city council met and declared the Expositor a public nuisance. The city marshal, John P. Greene, with a few men then proceeded to the printing office where they pied the type and burned the printed papers. The day following, Francis M. Higbee made complaint before Thomas Morrison, a justice at Carthage, for riot and destruction of the press. The warrant required the Prophet to go before Morrison or some other justice of the peace for trial. Here was the explosion the mobs were waiting for. Assemblies of mobocrats, speeches, resolutions, extermination orders for the "wicked Mormons" threatened the saints on every hand. Nauvoo was placed under martial law with its Legion mustered for protection.
In his effort to comply with the law, Joseph Smith appeared before Daniel H. Wells?a non-Mormon justice, but after hearing the case discharged the matter. Enemies of the Prophet claimed the trial was unlawful. It became necessary for Joseph to appeal to Governor Ford of Illinois for protection. In a letter dated June 16, the Prophet requested the Governor to make a trip to Nauvoo in order to halt the threatening danger of the saints. Ford came, but stopped at Carthage, where he surrounded himself with the worst apostates who, in league with the mobs, drowned any cry for justice. President Smith and all those accused were commanded to come and appear before Thomas Morrison of Carthage for trial, if not peaceably, then to the clank of muskets and force.
June 22nd found the Prophet with his brother Hyrum and eight of his close associates at a meeting in an upper room of his office. Shortly after the curfew hour, Hyrum came down from his room to the
House to greet Reynolds Cahoon with these words, "A company of men are seeking to kill my brother Joseph, and the Lord has warned him to flee to the Rocky Mountains to save his life. Good-bye Brother Cahoon, we shall see you again." (D.H.C. Vol. VI, page 547). It had been the decision of that evening to have the Prophet flee.
The next morning, the Governor's posse arrived in Nauvoo to find no Prophet. Shortly after noon that day, Emma Smith sent word by Orrin P. Rockwell to have her husband return; he having the night before just crossed the river. The most cutting part of the message bore the news that some of the leading brethren had accused the Prophet of cowardice. Realizing, then, that there would be those who would mistake the true reason for his departure, which was for the safety of his people, Joseph determined to return "and see the thing out." Hyrum stood one with him.
The next day found these two brothers with the accused members of the city council and a few friends riding to the town of Carthage. Behind them the green and pleasant city of Nauvoo lay under the warmth of an early morning sun in June. The rattle of hoofs and the stretch of saddle leather talked their recedies. It was a company of about sixty mounted militia, under the command of Captain Dunn, who reined to a stop the little party. Orders were to have the Nauvoo Legion surrender all state arms. Meekness and might again had met. The Prophet spoke:
I am going like a lamb to the slaughter, but I am calm as a summer's morning. I have a conscience void of offense toward God and toward all men. LESSON DEPARTMENT 433 If they take my life I shall die an innocent man, and my blood shall cry from the ground for vengeance, and it shall be said of me "He was murdered in cold blood!" Essentials in Church History, p. 376; D. H. C. Vol. VI, p. 555) Defenseless and at the mercy of their enemies, once more the saints found themselves as the hour of midnight saw their Prophet in Carthage ready to stand trial on the false charge of treason against the State of Illinois. The two days that followed are black upon the calendar of eternal justice. A Governor's broken pledge, an illegal summons, the impatient cruelty of a mob that would not wait for the law, all crowded the remaining earthly hours for the Prophet and Hyrum Smith as they sat in the Carthage Jail. It was after five on the afternoon of June 27. Elder John Taylor had just finished singing for the second time, at the Prophet's request, "A Poor Wayfaring Man of Grief." There was a discharge of arms at the outer door of the jail. Dr. Willard Richards hastened to the window to see about one hundred armed men at the door, many with blackened faces. The guard at the door fired into the air, as a flying wedge of men burst through the door and up a flight of stairs into the room that held the Prophet and his party. Shouts rang out as a shower of bullets poured into the room. Hyrum Smith fell crying, 'l am a dead man." Joseph, struck by two balls, lunged for a window?to fall into a circle of murderers, his parting words a testimony, "O Lord, My God!" It was done. The testator of the latter day work had sealed his life's mission with blood to give enduring strength to the cause he championed. What greater gift could any prophet bestow upon his friends? Suggestions for Active Reading and Discussion With the help of the suggested readings given below have the class carry on the discussion as follows: first answer the question; second read the assigned part in the text to discover wherein we must "give heed unto his word." The class period for this opening les-soTT can be a very challenging one. There is within the story of the martyrdom much to be felt as well as discussed. The great shock of learning how innocent men were struck down by the very ones who ought to have loved them for the words of life they had taught can but leave the heart hurt and the mind forever wondering. There can be no real end to the brutal story of the death of Joseph and Hyrum Smith. Such a lesson as this will bear rereading many times just as the tragic news bore retelling many times during those last days of June in the year 1844. I. What are the personal blessings you now possess which will always put you in the debt of the Prophet Joseph Smith? One or two from each person will provide interesting facts to be discussed. Following this oral report have section 135 of the Doctrine and Covenants read. 2. Discuss the meaning of Hebrews 9:16-17 in the light of Doc. And Gov. 135. The following question may be used if needed for further class activity or it may be assigned for home study: What are some of the significant interesting events that led up to the final days of martyrdom of Joseph and Hyrum Smith? Read chapters 31 to 35 in Essentials in Church History by Joseph Fielding Smith. & Visiting Teachings? Messages Sources of Strength?Charity Dr. Lowell L. Bennion Preview of Lessons for 1945-1946 MESSAGES for visiting teachers this year are based on Paul's masterful and inspiring discourse on charity found in I Corinthians, chapter 13. The subject is appropriate, for charity, as Paul defines it, lies at the heart of the gospel of Jesus Christ. Then, too, the Relief Society was organized, above all other reasons, to cultivate and express the spirit of charity. In this preview we shall consider the meaning of charity and give an overview of the messages which are to follow. What did Paul mean by the word "charity"? It is clear that its meaning was not restricted to almsgiving as it sometimes is today. This is evident from Paul's early statement: "And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing." To Paul charity also meant more than generosity and tolerance, attitudes which are implied in the expression?a charitable heart. Paul used charity as we use the word love. Such was the meaning of charity in 1611 when the King James translation of the Bible was made. More modern translations of the Bible use the word love because of the more restricted meaning which has come to be associated with the word charity. Thus "love" is a synonym for "charity," although charity seems to have its own distinctive meaning as well (See Moroni 7:47). Love is the greatest principle of the gospel of Jesus Christ. For this assertion we have the word of the Master himself. It is interesting to contemplate what a certain lawyer may have anticipated as an answer to the question he put to Jesus, "Master, which is the great commandment in the law?" Did he, perhaps, expect Jesus to quote one of the Ten Commandments? If so, he must have been surprised to hear the answer. "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind. This is the first and great commandment. And the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself. On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets" (Matthew 22:35-40). The lawyer may well have been surprised, but not because these commandments were new, for they are included in the Mosaic law in Deuteronomy 6:5 and in Leviticus 19:18, respectively. The new thing in Jesus' restatement of these ancient laws was that he brought them together, made the second like unto the first, and made everything else in the Law of Moses and the Prophetic writings depend on these LESSON DEPARTMENT 435 two, on love. Love was to be the matrix, the warp and woof, and the heart and spirit of life. The apostle Paul, recognized for his faith in Christ, also knew that this faith must lead to love and must always be accompanied by love to be of worth, as he declared: "... And though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing." (I Cor. 13:2) "For all the law is fulfilled in one word, even in this; Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself (Galatians 5:14). A world ravaged by war and filled with hate is starving for love and charity. Children, parents, neighbors, fellow-Church members, the stranger within our gates, the widow, the orphan, the returning soldier, and our "enemies" all need the charity Paul describes. What do we mean by charity? How can we express our charity in daily life? These are questions to discuss through the year. The answers are suggested in this year's topics: 1.

Christ's Example Objective: To show that Jesus in his own life exemplified true charity, demonstrating that a life of charity is filled with love and is free from self- pity, intolerance, envy, and hate. 2. "Charity Suffereth Long and Is Kind" Objective: To inspire patience and kindness in our human relations. 3. "Charity Envieth Not" Objective: To show that the cultivation of the spirit of charity will help rid our lives of envy. 4."Charity Vaunteth Not Itself, Is Not Pulled Up? Objective: To show that true charity is self-forgetting. 5. "Charit}* Doth Not Behave It-self Unseemly" Objective: To show that charity is tactful and courteous because it is inspired by a reverence for life. 6. "Charity Rejoiceth In the Truth" Objective: To show that one who is truly charitable rejoices in the truth. 7. "Charity Hopeth All Things, Charity Endureth All Things" Objective: To show that charity meets offense with patience, understanding, and hope. 8. "Charity Never Faileth" Objective: To encourage people to put their trust in charity as the unfailing means of improving themselves and influencing others for good. (For excellent suggestions on how these messages are to be taught, see The, pp- 403-404). Suggestion: Every visiting teacher would enjoy and profit by the frequent reading of I Corinthians, chapter 13.

SALT FLAT DESERT Thelma Ireland In the valley stretch the salt flats Which the purple mountains hug. And the contrast makes the desert Look just like an ermine rug. Lesson I?Christ's Example For Tuesday, October 2, 1945 Objective: To show that Jesus in his own life exemplified true charity, demonstrating that a life of charity is filled with love and is free from self-pity, intolerance, envy, and hate. JESUS said, "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart; and ye shall find rest unto your souls. For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light" (Matthew 11:28-30).
Jesus had seen the yoke upon the oxen, how it aided them in pulling the plow. Thus, he likened himself and his teachings to a yoke which, if taken upon ourselves, would make it easier for us to bear the burden of life. More than anything else this yoke was to be the principle of Christ-like love or charity.
The life of the Master was big with love "as a tree with blossoms in the spring." His charity knew no limits, no bounds, neither height nor depth. It was everything which Paul said of charity?patient, kind, free of envy, unselfish, courteous, sincere, enduring, and unfailing.
Jesus did not discriminate in expressing his charity for men. Only the self-righteous hypocrites came under his condemnation (Matthew 23). To the rest of mankind he gave freely of himself. When his disciples rebuked parents for bothering Jesus with their young children, "he was much displeased." Moreover, he used the occasion to teach a great truth (Mark 10:13-16). So aware was he of the needs of people,
that he was sensitive to the touch of faith by the woman who dared only to feel his garment (Mark 5:24-34). Here again we may contrast the attitude of his less sensitive disciples who wondered that Jesus should discern a single touch in the midst of a crowd. Pharisees and scribes marveled and murmured because there "drew near unto him all the publicans and sinners for to hear him" (Luke 15:1-2). Out of compassion he fed the weary multitude. (Mark 6) His last prayer to be recorded in full was a petition, not for himself, but for his disciples and all who should believe in him, "that they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us. . . ." (John 17:21). As he hung on the cross his final request in behalf of the Roman soldiers who had carried out the orders to crucify him, was, "Father, forgive them for they know not what they do," (Luke 23:24).
A life full of charity such as that of Jesus has no room in it for selfpity, intolerance, envy, or hate. It will not be overcome by pain, suffering, and sorrow, for it will always know the joy and spiritual renewal that accompanies love. Truly Jesus' yoke of love and charity is easy, and his burden light to those who take them upon themselves. LESSON DEPARTMENT 437 Literature The Bible in Our Literature Dr. Howard R. Driggs Preview of Lessons for 1945-1946 ONE central purpose motivates this course. Its lessons are intended to help those who make an active study of them to get a clearer, more appreciative understanding of the vital role played by the Bible in the creating of our literature. Each lesson offers an alluring quest with-in this broad and fertile field. Rewards of devoted work will be more intelligent, more recreative reading, with greater skill to select literature really worth reading. From the class viewpoint, these rich returns will come only if the course as an air-pilot might say, is kept "on the beam." Manifestly, in the limited time that can be allotted to the lessons, the main goal must be kept ever clearly in view. Each lesson, it is true, will prove an "open sesame" to treasures of literature; yet the natural temptation to linger too long over the gems, must be resisted by teacher and class member if the larger, spiritual end is to be attained. It is hoped, of course, that individuals and groups will be inspired to carry on beyond the classroom in further uplifting enjoyment of precious literature that is found. Both definiteness and flexibility mark the study plan. Every lesson, a unit in itself, helps to carry forward the central theme. It points the way to discovering how the Bible, in different ways, is woven with artistry into the type of literature with which the lesson deals. At the same time, it opens opportunity to draw freely upon not only time-tested literature but promising literature of the living present, for appropriate selections and quotations to add convincing concreteness to the main message to be impressed. Lesson 1.

Our Literature Before the Bible Came A study reaching back into the legendary past?when our days were named ? and songs and sagas in vigorous, alternative lines were created. Typical selections from this folklore will be used in portraying the background of primitive thought, feeling, and ideals which were later to be illumined, shaped, and spiritualized through the influence of the Bible. Lesson 2. How the Bible Is Woven Into Our Literature A study of both the outward and inward phases of the shaping of our literature through the influence of the Bible. Such more tangible aspects, as Biblical allusions and expressions, as well as those more spiritual in nature. Biblical themes and ideals, will receive attention in this lesson. Lesson 3. Bible Influence as Revealed in Our Lyric Literature A study of typical songs inspired by stories and living truths of the Bible. Selections to impress the depth and breadth of its influence in the creation of our lyric literature will be made from the classic carols on through the years down to the present. Some precious lyrics will be included in the lesson for special consideration. Lesson 4. Bible Influence on Our Epic or Narrative Poetry This study will center attention on certain outstanding poet story-tellers who were markedly influenced by the Bible in their creative work. Chaucer, Milton, Tennyson, Longfellow are among these. A limited selection of their well-known story poems will be used to make the message of this lesson clear and concrete. Lesson 5. Bible influence in Our Drama This study, beginning with brief attention to the old plays created to impress Bible stories, will specifically deal with other dramas through the years centering around Biblical characters and themes. Attention will also be given to the influence of the Bible in shaping and spiritualizing dramas that grip and hold the hearts of humanity. Lesson 6. Bible Influence on Our Fiction This study naturally, like those preceding, must be severely limited to consideration of a few typical and worthy novels whose themes or central characters are essentially Biblical. Its range will be from tested earlier fiction to present creations which reveal classic qualities. Brief attention will be given to the more general spiritual influence on other worthy fiction. Lesson 7. Bible Influence on Essays and Oratory Again the scope of the lesson will be restricted to the study of a few inspiring types of the essay and to certain outstanding orations that show plainly Bible influence. These will be taken from past and recent literature of these two important kinds of expression. Reliance of great writers and speakers on the Book of Books will be made clear. Lesson 8. Bible Influence in Literature for Children A forward-pointing study to help parents get closer to the book companions of their children and grandchildren. Children's literature, except for Mother Goose and Fairy Tales, is mainly of more recent creation. What of the Bible influence is revealed in most of the books produced for children today? In this lesson, directed opportunity will be given to make some selective research to answer this question, and out of it to bring to our children more well-written, Bible-inspired literature of living appeal for them. Text and References First, the lessons themselves are to be the guiding text. Each of these units should be carefully studied by teacher and members of class. Questions for study should be thoroughly considered before the lesson is given; and the suggested activities carried through, both before and after the lesson. Second, for general references the following will be found most helpful: The Bible?King James Version (also Modern Reader's Bible ?"by Moulton). General reference books may be added later. Note: Specific references will be given with each lesson. Lesson I?Our Literature Before the Bible Came For Tuesday, October 16, 1945 TN one of Longfellow's Tales of A Wayside Inn, "The Saga of King Olaf' is a poetic portrayal of the bringing of Christianity to the "Land of the Long Night." This old tale, first told to Longfellow, it is said, by the famed Norwegian violinist, Ole Bull, reveals that the message of our Master was carried into that stern realm not by any meek spirit, but by a hard-hitting viking. LESSON DEPARTMENT 439 Ringing lines from the lyric which opens the Saga, suggest the contest that lay ahead of this champion of the gospel. They sound also a keynote for this course. THE CHALLENGE OF THOR I am the God Thor. I am the War God". I am the Thunderer, Here in my northland. My fastness and fortress Reign I forever! Jove is my brother; Mine eyes are the lightning; The wheels of my chariot Roll in the thunder, The blows of my hammer Ring in the earthquake! Force rules the world still, Has ruled it, shall rule it; Meekness is weakness, Strength is triumphant. Over the whole earth Still is it Thor's-Day! Thou, art a God, too, O Galilean! And thus single-handed Unto the combat. Gauntlet or Gospel, Here I defy thee! Following this vigorous lyric, in spirit and form suggestive of songs of the long-ago Norseland, comes a stirring ballad, sketching Olaf's adventurous youth, and a spiritual awakening which led to his leadership in carrying the cause of Christ into his homeland. Opening lines of this ballad are: KING OLAF'S RETURN And King Olaf heard the cry. Saw the red light in the sky. Laid his hand upon his sword, As he leaned upon the railing. And his ships went sailing, sailing Northward into Drontheim fjord. There he stood as one who dreamed; And the red light glanced and gleamed On the armor that he wore; And he shouted, as the rifted Streamers o'er him shook and shifted, "I accept thy challenge, Thor!" With swiftly moving lines, the ballad goes on to tell how Olaf's mother, Queen Astrid, after her husband, king of Norway, had been slain by a usurper, fled with her son to a haven with "Hakon old"; how, still pursued, she again fled, this time to be captured and enslaved. Later, Olaf as a boy was recognized and restored to freedom by an uncle. Then he became a roving viking, and finally converted in Sicily by a hermit, was baptized into Christianity. Fired with the purpose of avenging his father, reclaiming his realm, and spreading the gospel through the reconquered nation, Olaf had come with his ships and fighting followers back to old Norway. He would illumine that region of the 'long night" with what had enlightened his own life. What the ideals, the inlook and outlook on life, of the rugged Northland folk were before Christianity came is mirrored in literature they created. Fortunately, in the Icelandic Eddas preserved for us, we have a wealth of their myths and legends, expressed in their vigorous, forthright style, to get us closer to their feelings and thoughts?their gods and heroes. And these same gods and heroes were in the main the very ones worshipped by not only the Scandinavian peoples, but by all Teutonic folk. In the Nihdungenlied a main source of the tales portrayed in the Wagnerian operas, are the same basic stories and characters as those in the Norse sagas. Anglo-Saxons, from whom came the English and Lowland Scotch, carried these tales across the Channel when they made their conquest of England. This, so far as we know, was their earliest literature. And it still is actively with us. Indeed, we pay something of tribute, though mainly without thought of it, to certain of the mythical Teutonic gods in our names of the days. Nature worship with something of mysticism seems woven into the conceptions of these deities of the Northland. Baldur, god of the sun, beloved for the light and warmth he brought to the Land of the Long Night, was honored in Sunday, first day of the week. Monday was named for Mani, a beautiful youth, who rode his shining steed, Alswider, across the night sky. Tyr, courageous war god, who gave an arm to assure the binding of the terrible Fenris Wolf, is remembered in Tuesday. Wodan, the all-father, with the ravens. Thought and Memory, on his shoulders, and with valiant heroes slain in battle, and beautiful shield-maidens, the Valkyries, ever about him, is perpetuated in Wednesday. Thor, fighter of frost giants, whose beard flares in the northern lights, whose eyes flash in the lightning, gave his name to Thursday. Freya, goddess of love and beauty, who rides through the sunny skies of spring and summer scattering flowers and fruits and bringing bird songs to cheer the northern realm, is remembered in Friday. Saturday, reserved for the last day of the week, comes from Surtur, fiery leader of the forces of evil, who, the gods ever feared, might break forth with destructive power in the last days upon their nine worlds. Confronted with conceptions such as these descriptions suggest, the bearers of our Savior's message had a difficult mission to implant principles of the everlasting gospel. Olaf, meeting Thor's challenge with blow for blow, succeeded in winning back his kingdom, and in making Christianity the official religion of his realm. Real conversion, as always, was a slower process. It had to come by weaving into the lives of the people the principles and practices of true religion. No small part of this was done through the infusion of the story and the spirit of the Savior into the national holidays. Yuletide, for example, which through untold years had been a time of feasting and drinking and wild revelry in celebration of the annual victory of Thor over the Frost Giants, was now commemorated as Christmas, in honor of Christ who came to bring "Peace on earth, good will toward men." Easter, likewise, was made no longer just a celebration of the advent of spring, with joyous pageantry in honor of the beautiful goddess Oestara. It was a holy day in soulful remembrance of the resurrection of our Savior. Another profoundly significant phase of this spiritualizing development came through the intrinsic changes wrought in our literature. Just as the old gods of Greece and Rome fell in both a material and a spiritual sense as Christianity rose, so did the gods of the Northland rather suddenly disappear. Only in Iceland, separated from the mainland by about eight hundred miles of ocean, did the sagas persist in 
original form for some centuries. That is why these stories are best preserved in the Icelandic Eddas.
Like the classic mythology of the Greeks, these sagas are, from in art viewpoint, great literature. They reflect the culture, the customs, the emotional life and ideals of that long ago. Something of a natural poetic skill was in the ancient skalds who created the strange stories. They had ample time to practice the art of story-telling during the long nights. And, since there was no printing press then, it had to be not story-reading, but story-telling.
One of the choice old tales out of the Northland impresses the basic value and the need for more such story-telling in our lives. In this mythical tale we are told that at one time, the gods, to commemorate a decisive victory over the Frost Giants, decided to create a man. It was agreed that, when the new being had been fashioned in his earthly image, each god should endow him with some precious gift. So they came, one after another to fulfill this pledge. One of the gods touched the lips of the newly created man that he might have the gift of speech; another touched his throat that he might sing. A third god touched his eyes that he might see; not only with his outward, but his inward or spiritual eye; still another touched his heart that he might have sympathy for all creatures.
And, lo, when this man spoke, it was as no other had done before. In his words one could hear the song of birds, the whispering of the breezes, the roar of the ocean, the prattle of children. All the music of man and of nature at the same time. In wondrous voice, and he became the first poet.
Basic truth is in this old tale. The poet does portray in musical lines the life he knows. In consonance with this, one feels through these sagas the courageous struggle with harsh elements?cold and darkness. Winds howl and breakers crash on rocky shores. Then comes ecstasy with the advent of the brief seasons of sunshine and revelry. Heroes of battle are extolled and tragedy accepted with something of a fatalistic attitude. Extravagant exploits are detailed, all to help while away the lengthened hours. In keeping with some of the "tall tales" and radio story-acting today, these old sagas were primarily for pastime. They gave entertainment?rather than recreation.
Had our literary development stopped there, it would have never been completely soul-satisfying; Entertainment is wanted, but not that alone. What was lacking to round out and enrich literature of long ago was just what the Bible brought. It was an infusion of spirituality, new conceptions of life, the message of the Savior. That these stalwart folk of a new life came to bring to minds to new heights.
Discussion and Activities
1. (a) Why may our English literature be said to have its roots in Teutonic lore? (b) In what ways are the mythological gods and heroes of the Icelandic Eddas and the Nibelungenlied kept in daily remembrance by English-speaking folk? Illustrate.
2. (a) What essential message is given by these mythical gods? Illustrate. (b) Which of the Commandments does this story emphasize? What are the aims it turning folk from the worship of such deities? 3. Which lines in "The Challenge of Thor" suggest a basic cause for much of the conflict that has raged in the world from long ago until now? 4. What battle line in Europe was named for a Teutonic hero round whom an epic was created in legendary times? Tell briefly something of the story. 5. Olaf, as a fighting viking, opened the way for Christianity into his realm. What more was needed to bring the followers of Thor to accept and practice the gospel principles in their lives? Tell, for illustration, how their holidays were changed to help implant the story of the Savior, 6. (a) What is the basic difference between literature that merely entertains and that which brings real recreation? (b) To which type did the old Norse tales in the main belong? (c) What helpful guidance is greatly needed in our literature-reading practices of today? Suggested Activities 1. Read aloud the ballad "King Olaf's Return" in Longfellow's Tales oi A Wayside Inn, observing the viking spirit, the story, and musically descriptive lines. 2. Find some tale from the Northland and read it. In any of the following books, or some school reader, such stories may be found: Myths from Northern Lands, Guerber, American Book Co. Old Norse Stones, Mabie, Rand Mc-Nally Co. Age of Fable, Bullfinch, E. P. Button (Everyman's Library). Story of Siegfried, Baldwin, Scribners.

ALLEVIATION Fae Decker Dix Under a pale sky, After the sun has set, I come to this valley Appealing for solace. Broad are its wheat fields, Crystal bright the stream's flow, Wild geese cry plaintively. And fly to the still hills. Something lifts within The shackles of my heart, I, too, will seek the hills At even-tide! LESSON DEPARTMENT 443 Social Science Modern Applications of Moral Principles Dt. Harold T. Christensen Preview of Lessons for 1945-1946 THIS is to introduce the second year's series of the social science lessons dealing with problems of social ethics. As suggested by the title, our chief concern is with modern applications rather than with historical or philosophical abstractions. The world today is in trouble, and the only way that it can right itself is by a return to virtue. Major principles of morality were outlined last year but, since each of these has such a direct bearing upon the problems we are about to examine, it is suggested that the class leader review the earlier lessons occasionally and use them whenever possible as background material for the discussions ahead. The lessons prepared for 1945-46 are built around certain modern problems to which the application of ethical principles is sorely needed. Titles and lesson aims are as follows: Lesson 8.

Patterns of Prejudice and Persecution Lesson aim: To emphasize the prevalence of bigotry in the modern world and to show how its existence stands as a threat to democracy, Christianity, and the good life. Lesson 9. Problems oi Personal Conduct Lesson aim: To stress the importance of personal cleanliness, balanced conduct, and self control to the good life. Lesson 10. Leisure and Morals. Lesson aim: To demonstrate a relationship between modes of recreation and morality, and to suggest ways for improving the morals of society by making better use of leisure time. Lesson 11. Women and Morals Lesson aim: To analyze some of the social and moral problems peculiar to women in this modem world, and to emphasize woman's moral role and responsibility in the field of ethics. Lesson 12. Morals In Marriage and Family Relationships Lesson aim: To analyze our most basic social institution from the standpoint of moral conduct, listing some of the common faults, and pointing out some of the principles necessary for correction. Lesson 13. Some Broader Applications of Social Ethics Lesson aim: To examine some of the inequalities and inhumanities existent in the world today, and to show that justice, when not violated, leads to both peace and happiness. Lesson 14. Morality and the Church Lesson aim: To examine religion as a moral force in life; and to point out some of the pitfalls, as well as principles, in religious ethics. Discussion questions and references at the end of each lesson are given to stimulate and guide in a general way rather than to prescribe or limit the work of the class. The teacher should read as widely as is practicable, using Church literature day Saint viewpoint, eliminating, and library materials freely. But and adapting materials as the needs she will need to be discriminating and interests of the class reveal also; sifting according to the Latter themselves. Lesson 8?Patterns of Prejudice and Persecution For Tuesday, October 23, 1945 Lesson link: Last year's lessons in this department were based upon the belief that much of the world's sorrow and suffering could be alleviated by a quick and complete return to virtue. It has been through deserting the great moral principles of the ages that individuals and nations have got into trouble, and the only way that this trouble can be dissolved and real happiness brought to the earth is by an enriched understanding of moral principles and a genuine willingness to apply them in life. Lesson aim: To emphasize the prevalence of bigotry in the modern world and to show how its existence stands as a threat to democracy, Christianity, and the good life. PREJUDICE means pre-judgment on the basis of bias, or without sufficient examination or understanding of a thing. Persecution refers to the act of annoying, oppressing, or attacking someone else to cause him injury or suffering. Prejudice is a perversion of truth and persecution is a desertion of the brotherhood principle. Both are immoral.
"Why persecutest thou me?"
These words of the Lord to Saul might well be applied to many of us in this modern day. Saul, it will be remembered, was prejudiced against the saints and had been persecuting them bitterly for some time. Then, while on the road to Damascus, he was accosted by the Lord who gave him to understand that persecution of the saints was at the same time a persecution of the Saviour. Saul repented, was converted, and later became an apostle in the church (Acts, chapter 9). But just as Saul offended city and worked against his own salvation by harming his fellow men, so do those today who, failing to catch the vision of a Christian world and the spirit of brotherhood which is an essential part of it, remain intolerant and antagonistic toward their fellow men. Selfishness, ingratitude, intolerance, discrimination, oppression?all of these and more are marks of prejudice and persecution. They are offensive to God and are a mockery of morality, and yet the world is full of them and their kind. Unless altruism can push aside selfishness, love outdo hate, and world brotherhood supplant provincialism and the exploitation of peoples, the future will not be bright and mankind will not find the peace and happiness to which it is entitled.
Personal Animosity
When people become too self-centered they lose the "social sense" discussed in an earlier lesson, and through indifference and hate they neglect and abuse their fellow men. Egoism and arrogance lead to selfishness, antagonism, and oppression. The desirable person is the one who is interested in others; thoughtful of their needs, sympathetic with their sufferings, charitable toward their shortcomings, appreciative of their services, and helpful in all things. LESSON DEPARTMENT 445 Love, fellowship, and fraternity are basic in any system of morality. But many of us during some of the time, and some of us during most of the time, fall far short of this ideal. We verbalize the good life in our worship and then fail to actualize it in life. Practice, unfortunately, too, often lags behind preachment. How many of us, for example, give even when we are not asked to, and give unselfishly with no thought of publicity or personal advantage? It has been said that for some people "faith, hope, and charity" means merely having faith in the hope that they won't be asked to give charity. Society is full of handicapped and unfortunate people. How many of us are actively looking for them with the idea of doing something to help relieve their suffering? Or, in contrast, how many of us merely rest on the smug feeling of personal self-righteousness and figure that other people can take care of themselves. If the latter, we would do well to remember that self-righteousness is really not righteousness at all; moral action of the highest order is always oriented toward society. We are our brothers' keepers. The "good Samaritan" will always get closer to heaven than the pious but selfish egotist. When social relationships disintegrate farther than selfish indifference and neglect, when they become actively antagonistic and hostile, then all the more be the need for a return to virtue. When individuals become malicious and militant in their abuse of others, resorting to ill-willed gossip, slander, and other forms of attack, to destroy what they don't like, then morals take a holiday. No system of ethics can be built upon animosity and hate. Let us remember the words of Christ when he said, *'Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you" (Matthew 5:44). If we can love our enemies as well as our neighbors, as Christ enjoined us to do, then we will have no enemies?except the enemy of evil itself. And this, of course, is the good life at its best. Partisan Animosity But partisan animosities are just as prevalent and just as serious as personal ones, perhaps even more so. Religious persecutions furnish one of the clearest examples of this prejudice, intolerance, and persecution in the world today. Many pages of the world's history are bloody with accounts of religious persecutions and wars. It is not our purpose to recount these historical details here, but it is our purpose to point out that war and bloodshed are antithetical to the Christian ideal, and the very fact that there has been so much shedding of blood in the name of religion is evidence enough that this ideal has seldom if ever been reached. Jewish persecution, or anti-Semitism as it is called, has reached new peaks in ferocity and brutality during the last decade or so. Coming mainly from Germany, the movement has spread over practically all the world until now no place is entirely free from its vicious influence. Its spirit is one of hysterical bigotry as intense as the world has ever known. Already there are signs that anti-Semitism may be gaining momentum in America. May it never come! Anti-Catholicism is another example of religious bigotry. There are plenty of instances where individuals have been defeated in office or deprived of other opportunities just because they were Catholics. This should never be permitted to happen in America. Latter-day Saints have so long been the recipients of intolerance and persecution from the outside that they ought themselves to be some of the most tolerant people on earth. Knowing what it is like to be on the receiving end of bigotry and mob violence, we ought to be particularly kind and sympathetic toward other groups now. And perhaps we are. But a little critical group introspection wouldn't hurt, and if made honestly it might lead to the discovery that we are sometimes indifferent or even intolerant toward some of the minority groups suffering at the hands of the prejudiced. Tolerant participation is the answer to religious persecution. The solution to religious conflict does not require an acceptance of foreign dogma. But it does require a tolerant understanding of other groups' points of view and a willingness to work together even without complete uniformity or agreement. Conviction concerning one set of dogma should not preclude tolerance toward others. The Crisis in Morality Partisan animosity and bigotry by no means end with religious persecution, but our space is short and perhaps this will suffice to illustrate. The reader may wish to supplement this with additional examples from economics, government, or other fields. But the point that the very moral structure of our society is being threatened, due to bigotry and a tendency toward expediency, must not be lost. Both Christianity and democracy were founded upon the principles of equality and fraternity; their ideas were humanitarian and unitarian in nature rather than exploitive and individualistic. One need only search the scriptures and then compare them with the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States to know that this is true. And yet we haven't been living that way; our practices haven't been in line with our professions; our actions haven't conformed to our ideals. Christians in name, we have nevertheless been quick to slander and' to persecute. Democratic in the framework of government we have nevertheless maintained our prejudices, fought for selfish vested interests, and discriminated against unfortunate minorities. All of this is undemocratic. It is also un-American, if we are big-souled enough to identify the American way with the right way. The crisis in morality is also a crisis in Christianity, and in democracy, and in the American way of life. The future of all of these institutions depends upon the victory of love over hate, altruism over selfishness, fraternity over bigotry. LESSON DEPARTMENT 447 Problems for Thought and Action 1. To provide a brief review of last year's lessons, show how happiness, progress, freedom, truth, honesty, and brotherhood all fit into an integrated moral system. Note: The class leader will find it advantageous to reread the last lesson from last year's series; i.e. Lesson 7, "Brotherhood, the Key to Greatness." 2. What do we mean when we say that morality is socially oriented? What did Jesus mean when he said, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?" Discuss. 3. Distinguish between personal and partisan animosity and illustrate each. What should be our attitude toward the handicapped and the unfortunate? Why? Use scripture to support your position. 4. Give examples of anti-Semitism. Of anti-Catholicism. Of anti-Mormonism. Compare. Why should Latter-day Saints be particularly tolerant of other peoples? Are we more tolerant than other people? Give examples on both sides of this question and make suggestions for improvement. What is the solution for religious persecution? Discuss. 5. Do you agree that Christianity and democracy are ethical ideals that have not yet been reached? Make suggestions for reaching these ideals. Do you think that the world would then be any more happy? Any more moral? Why? Selected References Standard Works: Bible: Proverbs 16:16-19; Matthew 5:43-48; 6:14-15; 7:1-5; Mark 12:28-31. Luke 6:27-28; 10:25-37; 23:33-34; John 8:3-11; Acts 9; I Corinthians 13:1-13; Ephesians 4. Books by Latter-day Saint Authors: Discourses of Brigham Young, "Our Fellow Men," chap. 24, pp. 417-432. Taylor, President John, Gospel Kingdom, "Truth, Error, and Tolerance," p. 49- Talmage, James E., Articles of Faith (12th Ed.), "Religious Intolerance'"; "Intolerance is Unscriptural"; "Toleration Is Not Acceptance," pp. 398-404. Missions to the Indians Elder A. William Lund Assistant Church Historian 

Corrected OCR Transcription
THE translation and publication of the Book of Mormon, a record of a part of Israel on this continent (now known as the American Indians), created a great desire on the part of the Prophet Joseph Smith and the early elders of the Church to visit some of the remnants of the Lamanites (as designated in the Book of Mormon) and preach the gospel to them and give them copies of the Book of Mormon. Upon making inquiry of the Lord respecting this matter, the Prophet, in October 1829, received the following:
And now, concerning my servant Parley P. Pratt, behold, I say . . . I have appointed unto him that he shall go with my servants Oliver Cowdery and Peter Whitmer, Jun., into the wilderness among the Lamanites. And Ziba Peterson also shall go with them yea, even as I have said, so it shall be. (D. & C. 32:1)
Making immediate preparations for their mission, these four elders visited some encampments of Indians near the city of Buffalo, New York, where they spent some time instructing them in the knowledge of their forefathers. These Indians were of the Cattaraugus tribe, and they received the brethren kindly. As some of their number could read English, two copies of the Book of Mormon were left with them. These elders continued their journey westward, preaching in the different villages through which they passed. At Kirtland, Ohio, they tarried some time, where quite a number in that vicinity believed their testimony and came forward and obeyed the gospel. Among these were Sidney Rigdon and a large portion of the church over which he presided. These missionaries were very successful in their labors and organized a small branch of the Church in Kirtland. One of these converts, Dr. Frederick G. Williams, accompanied the missionaries to Missouri.
After leaving Kirtland, on their journey westward, they visited the Wyandot tribe of Indians near Sandusky, Ohio, with whom they spent several days. "We were well received," writes Elder Parley P. Pratt, "and had an opportunity laying before them the record of their forefathers, which we did. They rejoiced in the tidings, bid us godspeed and desired us to write to them in relation to our success among the tribes farther west, who had already removed to the Indian territory, where these expected to go."
On arriving at Independence, two of the company secured employment, while the other three crossed the frontier and began their labors among the Indians. They visited the Shawnees, spending one night with them, and the next day crossed the Kansas River and began their labors among the Delawares. They sought an interview with the chiefog the Delawares, known among the whites as Chief Anderson. Page  He was the ruler of ten nations or tribes, and consequently possessed great influence among the Indians. He had always opposed the introduction of missionaries among his people, and therefore did not at first extend a very hearty welcome to the brethern. Through an interpreter the brethren made known their errand and explained to him the Book of Mormon and the information it contained for his people. They asked to be heard before a full council of his nation, a proposition which the chief took under consideration until the next day. Next morning the conversation with the chief was renewed, but he was not inclined at first to call the council. As he began to understand better the nature 'of the Book of Mormon, he changed his mind and asked the brethren to suspend their conversation until the council could be assembled. A runner was dispatched to the tribes and in about an hour forty leading men were assembled and seated in grave silence to hear the message concerning the book of their forefathers. Oliver Cowdery, at the request of the chief, addressed the assembly. He told them that a history of their people had been faithfully kept by their prophets and wise men, Which was buried in the earth. This record had been brought forth and translated and published and the missionaries had brought some copies of the book, one of which he wished to present to the great chief. The chief replied that they would build a house and have the missionaries come and read the book to them. The missionaries spent several days with the people and considerable excitement prevailed when the news reached the frontier settlements in Missouri. The jealousy and envy of the Indian agents and sectarian missionaries were excited to such a degree that the missionaries were ordered out of the Indian country as disturbers of the peace and even threatened with military action in case of noncompliance. They left the Indian country and commenced laboring in Jackson County, Missouri, among the whites. Here they made several converts who were baptized and added to the Church. Thus ended the first Indian mission, in which the brethren had preached the gospel in its fulness and distributed the record of their forefathers among three tribes: the Catteraugus Indians, near Buffalo, New York, the Wyandots, of Ohio, and the Delawares, west of Missouri. The Prophet Joseph Smith later met with delegations of Sac and Fox and Potawatomi tribes, but there is very little recorded of these labors. During the troublesome times that the Church Went through, including the martyrdom of the Prophet Joseph Smith and his brother. Patriarch Hyrum Smith, there was not much work among the Indians. However, President Brigham Young established friendship among the Indians by his policy "that it was better to feed the Indians than to fight them." Courtesy John Galbraith In 1854, Jacob Hamblin, with Ira Hatch, Samuel Knight, Thales Haskell and A. P. Hardy, were called to go to Santa Clara and there open a ' mission among the Indians. This mission reached into Arizona among the Moquis, Pimas and Navajos. No more thrilling tales of adventure can be found than in the life of Jacob Hamblin among the Indians. His honesty, fairness and friendly treatment of the Lamanites made them feel that he was their great friend. Jacob Hamblin spent most of his time from 1854 to 1877 in helping the Indians to a better life. AT the April Conference in 1855, forty-one missionaries, under the direction of Alfred N. Billings, were called by President Young to establish a mission among the Ute Indians, who resided in the vicinity of Elk Mountain, near Moab, Grand County, Utah. It is recorded that they were accompanied by Arrapeen, a converted ehief. The company consisted of forty-one men, fifteen wagons, sixty-five cows, thirteen horses, two bulls, one calf, two pigs, four dogs, twelve chickens and a splendid supply of provisions. Upon their arrival at their destination, they found about ten acres of land planted in corn, melons, squash and pumpkins. The seed had been secured by the Indians from an exploring party under the direction of W. D. Huntington, who had visited with the   Indians the year before. It had been planted in Indian fashion and the yield was fairly good considering the preparation of the soil. These missionaries built a fort, then started to clear the land for planting, and sought a location for a dam, which they knew they must have to bring water on the land. Soon they met St. John, Chief of the Elk Mountain Indians. The missionaries tried to show and teach the Indians the white man's way of working and living, as well as interesting them in the principles of the gospel. It was not long before the friendly Indians applied for baptism and on the 23rd* of July, fourteen men and women were baptized. Through the good work of Arrapeen, the neighboring Navajos visited the fort and asked to make peace with the Utes. As time went on more Indians were baptized and the brethren thought that all was going to be well with them. But as the crops began to mature, the Indians destroyed the potatoes and gardens of the pioneers. Then they started to steal the cattle belonging to the mission. The elders decided to change the location of the herd grounds so they could more carefully watch their animals. This angered the Indians and a skirmish followed, in which one of the Indians was killed. Chief St. John was their friend, but his son Charles led in the depredations and he and his followers threatened to kill every white settler. So the missionaries decided to return to Manti. Some of the friendly Indians accompanied them part way and expressed their desire for the white missionaries to live among them. Also in 1855, a site having been selected in the upper valley of the MISSIONS TO THE INDIANS 455 Salmon River Basin (now in Idaho) among the Bannock and Shoshone Indians, a company of twenty brethren, mostly from Salt Lake County, Utah, was organized with Thomas S. Smith as president. Traveling to Bear River, they continued through Malad Valley to Snake River until they reached the Salmon River Pass. On the 14th of June they selected a site on what is now known as Lemhi River. They immediately commenced to make improvements and soon had a blacksmith shop in working order, burned coal, and built a corral for the stock. Soon they had built seven houses besides breaking and planting several acres of land and doing considerable fencing. They called their location Fort Lemhi, in honor of Limhi, a Nephite king mentioned in the Book of Mormon. Assisted by the Indians, the settlement proved a success and the Indians, who were anxious to learn the white man's ways of agriculture, were assisted by the brethren. The families of the first settlers and others from Utah soon arrived. President Brig-ham Young visited the settlement in 1857. A second fort was built that year, north of the original fort, and a considerable amount of grain and vegetables was raised. In February 1858, while several of the brethren were busily engaged in mowing hay and hauling timber, a large party of Bannock and Shoshone Indians, many of whom lived around the fort and had previously been very friendly, made a sudden break upon the herd of the settlers, drove off most of the stock belonging to the fort, killed George McBride and James Miller and wounded President Thomas S. Smith and other brethren. This uprising of the Indians led to the abandonment of Fort Lemhi by Latter-day Saints later in 1858, the settlers returning to Utah. On the journey, Bailey Lake, one of the party, was killed by Indians on Bannock Creek. It is believed that this sudden Indian outbreak was caused by the fact that United States soldiers, under General Albert S. Johnston, were encamped near Fort Bridger in the winter of 1857-1858, engaged in a punitive expedition against the people of Utah, who were falsely charged with disloyalty to the United States. Misinformed in regard to this matter, the soldiers are said to have influenced the Indians to make trouble. Space will not permit of an article giving full details of the very great work accomplished among the Indians by the Church. Suffice it to mention that missionaries were sent among the Poncas in Nebraska and South Dakota, the Pueblo Indians in New Mexico, the Mohaves in Nevada and California, the Maricopas and Papagos in Arizona, the Zunis in Arizona and New Mexico, the Creeks in the Indian Territory, and the Utes and Shoshones in Utah and Idaho. TWO incidents are worthy of mention, showing the power of God that accompanied the missionaries in their labors. In 1857, Ira Hatch and Dudley Leavitt were among the Mohaves. These Indians showed a great dislike and distrust of the missionaries and planned their destruction. However, the humble prayers of these two brethren changed the Indians' attitude of hate to one of love and the missionaries did much good among that tribe. In 1878, Brother Llewellyn Harris was laboring among the Zunis. Smallpox broke out among the Indians, causing many deaths. Brother Harris administered to a very sick boy, who was healed. The Indians made known to Brother Harris their desire that he administer to all of their sick. He commenced to do this but found he could not reach them all so the sick were brought to a large house where Brother Harris administered to more than four hundred Indians. Through the mercy and blessings of God, following these administrations, most of the sick were made well. Successful wards of Indians have been established at Washakie, Utah, Indianola, Utah, and Papa-go, Arizona. Through the patient and loving help given by kind, good and faithful men and women, such as Bishop Hicks and his wife at Papago, the Indians have been made to realize the great blessings that the gospel has brought to them. May the day speedily come when more of these Lamanites may be brought to see the gospel truths and become as they once were "a white and delightsome people."
