NAVAJO HEADDRESS William Luce 1. One of the distinguishing features of the Navajo is his headdress, This same headdress is worn by both the men and women and is especially striking because of its simplicity. Many now use the modern comb but a few still use a bundle of tied together instead. The hair, comb, and strands of yarn are only requisites for milady's hair-do, The two women are the wife and daughter of Jack Frank who sometimes reside at Blanding, Utah. 2. After a thorough combing, the hair is gathered together. 3. Then the center of the yarn is twisted around the hair close to the head. 4. The two ends of the yarn are held by the younger squaw while her mother rolls the hair by lapping it over and over. 5. The rest of the yarn is now twisted around the knot of hair and tied. 6. And the finished coiffure! More songs were sung, and as the fire began to die and children slept, the violin and all present sang "The Spirit of God Like a Fire Is Burning" and truly it was! Dawn brought a gorgeous, shimmering Sabbath atop the mountains. There were bacon and eggs salted with sand and flavored with smoke. There was the clang of sheep bells, and the cook at the neighboring camp calling "Come and get it." And then All gathered in a circle in a grove of shining, silver-coated aspens. What a temple! Carpeted with tall spreading ferns, embroidered with pink, gold and purple flowers, it was topped with a turquoise sky! The purple, red, yellow, and orange blouses and shirts of the participants stood out in gay relief against the green above and beneath. What a picture I beheld as I looked up the sloping stage where Brother Ralph Evans, President of the Navajo-Zuni Mission, stood, with hand raised in welcome, and waiting beside him was the violinist, Clarence (Joe) Hunt, with bow ready for action. The latter was a friend of President Evans, from Blanding, whom he had not seen since "swimming hole" days. Instantly I pictured them as boys holding their noses and going down into the water in a splash of boyish ecstasy. Now they stood before me, clean, tall men fired with divine enthusiasm, ready to "feed my sheep." A grove of aspens has always suggested the Sacred Grove to me, and that thought raced through my mind just as the violin softly played "Oh How Lovely Was the Morning" and Mary Jumbo and her two girls sang the words beautifully. Then George Bloomfield told the story of Joseph Smith's first vision; of his receiving and translating the plates; of Christ's coming to the American continent; of Moroni's promise; and then he very forcefully urged these people to appreciate their book, and closed with his testimony. There was a brief pause after Clyde, the interpreter, finished. Then little, quiet, shining-eyed, immaculately dressed Sister Polacca stood up and told of a manifestation which brought her into the Church. I had heard this related several times before, and it was now told exactly as it had been told on every occasion before, but the setting, the aspen filled grove, and her big, brown eyes looking deeply into my soul as she spoke, gave me the impulse to take her into my arms and crush her to me and bathe her with my grateful tears. Thus I did at the close of the meeting. People wept unashamed, and everyone knew that she had spoken the truth and that she was a choice spirit touched by the divine and raised up to lead her people in the path of righteousness. Then the white people were asked to move back, and every Navajo sat at her feet while she told of this manifestation all over again in her native language.
The meeting was closed, and as I gathered the children and trudged up the hill to its lunch, a feeling of resentment filled me at the thought of breaking so fine and perfect a spiritual thread to perform the earthly task of eating.
The afternoon meeting was rich with testimonies of both white and Navajo missionaries. Children of both races sang and spoke. We had been together a long time, and the white people were showing signs of fatigue. President Evans said, "The sun is getting low, and you are tired. I'll leave it to you shall I talk to you or shall we go home?" An old, white-haired Navajo man slowly uncrossed his legs and said, "When the sun goes down, the moon will come up, so let us have the talk." What philosophy, and how we whites need it in this rushing world! After the talk, the natives still wanted more and the war news was given them.
The long-looked-for conference was over; farewells were said, and we were the last to leave. It had all been perfect. As we reached the summit, there came, almost as a grand finale, the form of a huge, shaggy brown bear and her cub crossing the red-gold path of the setting sun.

Not to the Swift Olive M. Nicholes ELSA WAYNE sat huddled beside her husband in the high wagon seat, cradling her sleeping baby in the curved shelter of her weary body. The wagon tossed and rolled like a ship in a heavy sea as it toiled over boulders or floundered through the engulfing sand. Dust rolled up from the wheels ahead of them, from the wheels behind them,  an inescapable red cloud, the length of the wagon train. It mingled with the yell of teamsters, the crack of whips and the patient plod of many hoofs.
She glanced up at the man beside her. All the familiar contours of his features were hidden in a wilderness of beard. He turned gentle eyes upward and reached out a comforting hand.
"We're almost theyah, honey. You'll nevah regret comin', once you see the land. Theyah's no end to it. It's like Alabamy an' Cal'liny good cotton country. It'll be home, honey, the Dixie of Deseret."
"Not my home!" she muttered with stiff lips.
Oh, no; not her home! She glared about at the unfamiliar landscape as the dust rolled away and the wheels bit into the solid black lava of the ancient flow winding its tortuous way from the sleeping volcanoes to the northwest. Far to the northeast gigantic blocks and pinnacles were tumbled together in a gorgeous welter of color. Vermillion, bright ochre, orange, mauve and purple glowed and shifted in the sunlight.
She clung with terror to the man whose rapturous gaze shut her away, out of his new life.
"Jim," she choked, "what is it? Let me see, too!"
He turned and took her in his arms, "Theyah now, honey, ain't no call fo' you all to be afeared. It'll all look different in fifty yeahs. Homes an' farms an' cattle fillin' up the valleys. I reckon they'll be churches an' schools an' a temple, too."
Fifty years! Her weary eyes searched for a glimpse of familiar substance. The mountains where were her mountains?
Mountains lay at the core of her being. Born and reared in Switzerland, she had become a part of their permanence and beauty. They embodied the undeniable triumph of righteousness. It had been the vision of mountains that had swept her into the new religion among a peculiar people in a faraway land.
The Valleys of the Mountains! That had been her acolyte. It had lifted her up through privation, hunger and despair, from Missouri to Nauvoo, from Winter Quarters to the West.
She had met Jim at Winter Quarters, a convert just from the South. She had been drawn to him as to a magnet, big, dark, and handsome, with a swift, rare smile and a voice at once slow and decisive. He had been attracted by her vibrancy and fair, shy beauty. Her eyes had been a corn-flower blue, her red hair with promise. Her sunny hair had hung in a flaxen rope, as big as his wrist, almost to her knees. Page 461 She had been full of hope, then. She had been the one to encourage and sustain. Her unquenchable laughter and sweet singing had captivated everyone on that April morning when they joined the caravan. She, who had faced incredible suffering with fortitude, cringed, now, in abject fear. CHE rolled back the curtain of the years and plodded again behind the handcart. The brazen sunlight beat down from a bow! Of blue glass. The baked earth held it and threw it back, intensified, against their aching bodies. Jim, already sick and faint with hunger, staggered and dropped in the trail. The cart behind turned out and rejoined the one ahead. The last of the few wagons, carrying the sick and dying, rolled by, the driver leaning to her with a comforting word. She had not begged for a place for Jim. She knew without asking there would be no room. So many sick, so many dying, and now Jim! There had been a tangled clump of bushes, a heap of broken rocks, where a persistent trickle of water bubbled up to be swallowed, instantly, by the thirsty sand. She pulled Jim into the meager shade and rolled the handcart alongside the embankment to shield him from the merciless sun. Then, piling the bedding and sacks of clothing on the hard ground, she eased him tenderly to the makeshift bed. The driver of the "sick-wagon" limped back and propped a shovel against the cart. He bent over the sick man, felt his pulse, then straightened up and started across the shimmering prairie. He had loved Jim as a brother. They had come up from the south together, poling their way on a flat-boat, crawling on hands and knees through thicket and swamp. Now he turned and staggered away with a hopeless sag to his shoulders. The living must go on! She had watched him top the rise and disappear. She had turned, then, searching the vast sweep of prairie with anguished eyes. Not a moving thing in sight., "O God, spare my Jim," she begged, kneeling beside the sick man and clasping his hot fingers in her own. She gathered a few dead twigs and leaves and set a tin cup of water over the blaze she had kindled from tinder and flint. She would scald some scorched crusts and perhaps the tang of the hot liquid would staunch the ebbing tide of strength. If there were only a piece of beef to make a nourishing broth! They had seen no meat in weeks. They dared not go in search of game; lone huntsmen fell easy prey to skulking Indians. Indians! The thought crashed into her consciousness . She heard no sound, but they slid up around her, thirty or more, hideous with war paint, filthy with grease and grime. All thought of self was swallowed up in her misery for Jim. Now she could die with him. She rose and faced them in dazed expectancy. A big buck stalked to her side, his one good eye focused on the man on the ground. He pointed to Jim. "Heap sick," he grunted, squatting down beside the cart, and squinting into the dying face. She nodded, stupefied with wonder that she could be alive at all. His black eye swept over the cart with beady interrogation. From an exposed corner of the box a torn pillowcase displayed the bright embroidered folds of her great-grandmother's table cloth.
"Gimme," he demanded, snatching the gorgeous linen from its wrappings. He shook out the gay fringed length of it and watched it dip and ripple about his feet.
She felt instinctively that he understood English better than he would admit. He seemed familiar with the skillet, the pots and pans, the canister of salt and sugar. Somewhere, sometime, his contact with the white man had been merciful and kind.
He unfastened a buckskin pouch at his belt and sifted a fine trickle of dried leaves into the water, simmering on the dying embers. A pungent aroma billowed up with the steam as he tilted the cup back and forth to mix the darkening liquid. Satisfied, at last, he raised it to his lips and blew a gale of breath into the scalding brew. He gulped a swallow and squinted up at her.
"Heap big medicine," he grunted, stooping over Jim. He poured the stimulating draught between the parched lips. The liquid bubbled and welled out. The Indian clamped Jim's lips together in the vise of his cupped palm until the overflow seeped slowly back. He poured in more and more until only the gray leaves fringed the cup.
The dying eyelids flickered and drew apart. Recognition broke through the glazed film of death. The stiff jaws worked and the broken mouthful of soundless words
She flung herself down beside him and gathered him into her hungry arms while the circle of impatient eyes darted from the heap of bright embroidery to the buckskin pouch and back again.
"Gimme," the Indian demanded, snatching up the cloth and depositing the pouch in her lap.
"Yes, yes!" she choked, nodding her head in vigorous affirmation, so that her sunbonnet fell back and dropped to the ground. The flaxen web of her hair escaped and flowed over her shoulders and billowed around her feet.
Thirty pairs of gimlet eyes bored into her scalp. An excited clamor arose. The big chief snarled a command and they shrank back against the hill as motionless as the rocks.
The chief stooped and clutched handfuls of the silken skeins and pressed them against his face.
"Gimme! Gimme!" he shouted, his one eye alight with greedy anticipation.
She laid Jim's head tenderly on the pillows and drew the blanket over his relaxed and sleeping body. Was it not enough that God had taken him back to her, that he would reach the mountains? Should she risk their lives and lose all with exclaim! demands? Her people were starving, dying on their scanty rations. They must have meat for their wasted bodies if they were to reach the Valley and work for the redemption of Zion. How much dare she ask? Her thoughts flew wildly about like startled birds, beating their wings against the cage of her exhausted brain.
The old chief spoke to his braves who stripped themselves of ornaments and laid them at his feet. He pressed them into her arms until beads and shells and feathered finery spilled over her knees in a rainbow flood of color. "No want,  she cried, springing up and crowding the barter into his reluctant hands. "Meat meat plenty meat!" Her arms swept a wide arc of abundance. He slammed the trinkets at her feet and jerked a knife from its beaded scabbard. "No meat/" he snarled, "no can find meat." Across the prairie a cloud of dust spurted up from an arroyo as a thousand buffalo hoofs scrambled to the plains above. A shaggy, black mass, scarcely discernible in the distant haze, rumbled slowly out of sight behind a low hill. "See! See!" she shrieked, gesticulating madly. "Meat plenty meat!" The disgruntled savages turned in wonderment, stiffened and sprang to life. The old chief barked commands as they scrambled for their possessions and disappeared behind the hill. "No kill! No take!" she demanded of the waiting chief as she gathered her hair together and divided it into strands. Her knees turned to jelly and her legs threatened to crumble under them when Jim muttered in his sleep. She stiffend to his need and then began to plait the strands of her hair toether, her sensitive finger-tips guiding the intricate pattern until she could pull the thick rope of it over her shoulder and braid it to its tapering end. Drawing a buckskin thong from her pocket, she knotted it securely at the nape of her neck and motioned for the Indian's knife. At her signal he leaped forward and grasped the completed braid, slipping the knife between her hair prickling scalp. She felt the cold steel pressed against her flesh, heard the squeal of the blade slicing through the resisting strands. He stepped back with a satisfied grunt and held up the severed prize. He fastened it to his scalp-lock, swung the embroidered cloth over his shoulders, and strutted away to retrieve his pony from the broken rocks. She watched the old savage ride off in the wake of his diminishing braves, her great-grandmother's tablecloth billowing out beneath her flaxen braid that whipped out frantically in the wind. She turned and rekindled the fire and made fresh brew from the strange herb. She repacked their possessions, concealing the shovel from Jim's questioning eyes. Please, God, let it dig no more graves in the lonely trail! At last the long day wore itself out. Cool breezes whispered through the sunburned prairie grass. Jim awakened from his healing sleep. "The Indians! Elsa was it a dream? I can't recall " "No, mine Jim," she whispered, tears splattering down on the thin hands that stroked her cheek. She jerked off her sunbonnet to confirm the wild tale. "Oh, my brave Elsa, my ," he had staggered giddily to his feet and held her close in his wasted arms. He had been proud of her then. TWO years from now Utah will celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the arrival of the pioneers in Salt Lake Valley.
July 24, 1847, a small, but determined group of men, women and children, the vanguard of the Mormon pioneers, paused as they emerged from Emigration Canyon for a brief survey of Salt Lake Valley. Led by Brigham Young, they had traveled a thousand miles in search of a new home. After a few minutes study of the Valley, Brigham Young said, "THIS IS THE PLACE, DRIVE ON."
That night, around a camp fire, a tired, thankful, happy band of pioneers sang songs of praise, offered prayers of gratitude, and made a promise "We will make the desert blossom as the rose."
Just what we can do to honor the memory of that brave vanguard centennial cannot at present be determined, but the love trek of tens of thousands of people traveling under the conditions they faced, the conquering of an unconquerable desert, and the building of an empire far from the fringes of civilization, all add up to an event that had a profound bearing on this nation's history, and the hundredth anniversary of such an event cannot by any measure being recorded the finest celebration that conditions will permit.
We would like to invite the world to join in a great celebration. This 1937 legislature proposed a plan for a World's Fair, that Utah might put her national parks, and other scenic attractions on display, and bring people from the far corners of the earth to behold the natural wonders of which we are so justly proud. Before such a plan can be carried out, the war now being waged must end, and travel restrictions lifted. Then, like the careful and proud housewife who is expecting company, we will give the State a thorough house cleaning.
The most serious problem we face in this house-cleaning and rose-blossoming job is the vacant lot. All of us always a night-mare to every community. It is in charge of cleanup campaigns, and the citizen who is proud of his home town.
Every home owner has some pride in his property, and will occasionally clean up the place, even though it takes a lively beautifying campaign to awaken that pride, but there is no one living on the vacant lot, and none of the care of the property washes his hands or the vacant lot, he is merely regarding its appearance. Page  BEFORE AND AFTER Rubbish accumulates rapidly, soon it becomes an ugly spot growing more unattractive daily. The vacant lot is a dumping ground for everything the neighbors want to get rid of. It becomes a breeding place for rats, mice, flies, and other pests; weeds grow, ripen, and the fall winds scatter seeds in every direction. The vacant lot is the sore thumb of the neighborhood, holding down the value, and increasing the upkeep of surrounding property. Experience has taught us the futility of trying to awaken enough civic pride in the soul of the vacant-lot owner to arouse him to the point of keeping his property clean and attractive. I am convinced that the best solution of the vacant-lot problem is to place a law on the statute books that will give authority to cities and towns to compel the owners to keep their property free from weeds, rubbish, or any unsightly material. The owner would then either keep his property in presentable condition, or he would lease it to his neighbors to be put to practical use as a garden, a supervised playground for the neighborhood children, a parking lot, or some other useful purpose, with the understanding that the lessee keep the premises at all times attractive. If the lot cannot be put to practical use, all accumulated rubbish should be removed and shrubs or tall flowers planted across the front parallel to the street.
THE good housekeeper is ready to receive and entertain visitors at any time, her house is always clean and in order. Only by following her example will our towns and cities be made attractive and ready for company at the time we celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the pioneers' arrival.
We can make our State attractive, even including the vacant lot. We can complete the fulfillment of the promise. We can make the "desert blossom as the rose," by adopting the same co-operation that was preached and practiced by our pioneers.
We all have a share in the beauty, We all have a part in the plan, What does it matter what duty Falls to the lot of man? Someone has blended the plaster, And someone has carried the stone; Neither the man nor the master, Ever has builded alone. Making a roof for the weather, Or building a house for the King, Only by working together Have men accomplished a thing. Author Unknown

Gratitude Should Be Expressed Withhold not good from them to whom it is due, when it is in the power of thine hand to do it (Proverbs 3:27). MANY of the tools for building happiness lie so close at hand that their worth is often unrecognized. Among these tools, easy to use and free for the taking, is gratitude. Its possibilities for assuring personal contentment and spreading joy to others have perhaps not been fully discovered by any of us. Gratitude has many facets, but fundamentally it is the recognition of the good and the beautiful and thankfulness for them. "Count your many blessings" has been good advice since the world began. This philosophy is still a comfort and a compensation, an ideal to be cultivated, for it is still a paradox of human nature that the largeness of gratitude does not always correspond to the extent of the blessings received. Appreciation is an attribute of the generous mind and the open heart.
When the spirit of thankfulness attains its full stature, it goes beyond gratefulness for that which we personally possess and gains joy from blessings which others own.
Whatever type of gratitude may permeate our thoughts, its value is only half effective if we do not express our sense of gratefulness. Gratitude unexpressed is idle treasure. The thoughtful word of sincerity, the simple "Thank you," the note of appreciation, are all answers for favors received. The alert willingness to offer service to those who have given freely of their time and substance is gratitude expressed.
Gratitude to God is the leaven of religion. Gratitude for country becomes the vital force of patriotism. Gratitude for one's heritage forms the basis for that continuity of life which expresses itself in record keeping and ordinances for the dead. Today more than ever before, we realize an abiding gratitude to that courageous ancestor of the family who first listened to the gospel and believed.
Too often children, even sons and daughters who have attained adult status, fail to give credit to their parents for years of sacrifice and care. Too often the rush of daily life obscures the duties of gratitude. Parents, too, as they grow older and their thoughts turn inward, may be guilty of ingratitude. Through lack of forbearance and understanding, they may demand more of their children than can be given or should be expected.
The Lord has said (Doc. & Cov. 59:21) "And in nothing doth man offend God, or against none is his wrath kindled save those who confess not his hand in all thing, and obey his commandments."?V.P.C.

"RELIEF SOCIETY of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints" was voted the official name of the Society by action of the General Board of Relief Society at the Board meeting held June 27, 1945. This name replaces "National Woman's Relief Society" by which name the Society has been known since 1892.
When Relief Society was organized in Nauvoo, Illinois, March 17, 1842, by the Prophet Joseph Smith, the name chosen was "Female Relief Society of Nauvoo." Later when ward organizations were effected after the arrival of the saints in Salt Lake Valley, the designation "of Nauvoo" was dropped and, in 1872, by vote of the members, the word "Female" was also dropped from the title. "Relief Society" was used as the official name of the organization from that time until 1892 when the Society was incorporated for a period of fifty years under the name "National Woman's Relief Society." Since Relief Society is an auxiliary of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, whose message is to all the world, the name "Relief Society of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints," is felt to be the proper one.
Stake Planning Meeting Recommended During September
THE General Board, with the approval of the General Authorities, again recommends that a stake planning meeting be held during the month of September, preliminary to the beginning of regular weekly meetings in October, for all stake board members, ward officers, and class leaders. It is recommended that, wherever feasible, this meeting be arranged in connection with a stake priesthood meeting or a local board conference in order to keep transportation at a minimum. The purpose of this meeting is to stimulate all phases of Relief Society work at the beginning of the 1945-46 season, to preview lesson work and other activities planned for the coming year, and to give whatever instructions and help are deemed necessary by the stake board. Stake Relief Society presidents will please acquaint their respective stake presidents with the recommendation that special meeting be held, and arrange with them as to the
most favorable time for calling the meeting. Stake Relief Society presidents are requested to send complete details of this meeting to all ward presidents as soon as possible so that good ward representation may be assured. The General Board feels sure that stake board members will make every effort to take full advantage of this special meeting, and that they will be well prepared to conduct their respective departments for ward workers at this meeting.
Red Cross Classes in Nutrition Now Available
THE American Red Cross is now offering throughout seven Western and Pacific States; namely, Utah, Idaho, Nevada, Arizona, California, Oregon, and Washington, courses in nutrition designed to aid homemakers with the problem of substitute foods for rationed items and also with the proper preservation of food and food values. These courses are particularly valuable at the present time because of food restrictions and the possibility of future food shortages.
Two courses are available?one is a twelve-hour course; the other is a twenty-hour course. Classes are conducted once a week or at more frequent intervals according to the desires of those participating in the activity.
Relief Society groups wishing to take advantage of these courses are advised to get in touch with the nutrition chairman of the Red Cross in their local communities. Instructors will be provided free of charge and the necessary equipment will be supplied by the Red Cross.
Relief Society War Bonds to Be Deposited with General Board
DURING 1944, the General Board arranged for the pooling and safekeeping of war bonds purchased by Relief Society, so that none would be lost track of during the reorganizations of Societies which end of 1944, many bonds had been deposited with the General Board for safekeeping only, however, many Societies have not taken advantage of this service.
All stake and ward Relief Societies whose bonds have not been posted are urged to take advantage of the free safekeeping service offered by the General Board. No charge will be made for this service. Bonds mailed to the General Board for safekeeping be sent by registered mail. A receipt will be issued for each bond received, showing the name of the stake or ward Relief Society to which it was issued, the date of issue, the series, the bond serial number, the face value of the bond, and date of maturity. As the bonds mature, they will be returned by registered mail (Continued on page 477)

And For Eternity Olive Woolley Burt CHAPTER III Synopsis Delsa Marriott, trying to hide from her family and friends the fact that her fiance, Hugh Temple, serving in Australia, wants to break off their engagement, becomes interested in helping Jeff Holden, widower principal of the two-room school where Delsa teaches, take care of his motherless children. THE extra work at Jeffs every morning and afternoon crowded the days for Delsa so full that she had little time to think of Hugh and of what he wanted to do to her life. "I won't release him yet/' she told herself. "I owe it to us both to think this out clearly before I let go. If I decide that I cannot live without Hugh?and oh, how can I? ?and I hold on, maybe he will see that this is his life, right here in our own home town with our own home folks?the way we have always planned it. Maybe he will write again and tell me it was all a bad dream?a dream born of loneliness and distance and lost hope." So Delsa wasn't counting the days; she was just living and doing; picking up each task as it presented itself, laying it down when it was done. She was surprised, therefore, one afternoon to meet Millie Lewis on her way home from school?Millie Lewis with shining eyes and the breath of excitement about her. "Delsa," Millie cried, "it's club tonight. Have you forgotten?" Delsa stopped. She was on her way to Jeff's to take care of Trudy as she had been doing each day after school. And she had forgotten that tonight was club night. She smiled, excusing her forgetful ness. "I guess it did slip my mind, Millie," she said. "Where do we meet?" Millie looked at her in frank astonishment. "Why, at your place silly!" she cried. "You don't mean you really forgot that, do you?" Delsa nodded, embarrassed. "I've been extra busy this past week," she defended herself. The bright, eager look died in Millie's eyes and something cold and shadowy looked out at Delsa. "So I've noticed." she said shortly. "What do you mean, Millie?" Delsa asked. Millie stood there for a moment, silent, and then she raised her eyes and looked frankly at her friend. "Don't you think you're spending a good deal of time at Jeff Holden's?" she asked. Then she went on quickly, before Delsa could answer, "Oh, I know he needs help?who doesn't? But Hugh's mother doesn't like it?she's been saying things, Delsa. Why don't you let those older women step in and help Jeff out? They Page  can take on an extra job as well as you can, and no one would talk." "They didn't take it on, Millie,? Delsa said slowly. "Little Trudy was half sick." SHE stood looking at the road for a moment and then she said, I?ve been working with Jeff all winter?in the same building with him all day. No one ever said anything?" "Of course not! But they might have, if you hadn't been so very, very proper all the time. But now to add an extra hour every morning and every afternoon?and right in his house, too?" Delsa sighed. "People make me sick!" she said. "Let's forget it, Millie. That wasn't what made you come running down the road to meet me?as if you had wings on your feet!" Millie laughed. "No it wasn't. Listen, Delsa! Jim's home! He got in on the afternoon bus? has a whole month's leave. He's going to marry Lina, Monday?and spend his honeymoon right here at home. Says there's no place he'd rather spend it!" She paused to draw her breath. "Oh, Millie, how happy your folks must be! How does Jim look? Is he well? And how glad Lina will be, too!" Tears came to Delsa's eyes as she thought of Jim Lewis, her playmate since childhood, back from danger, safe at home. It meant a lot to her?to the whole town? that one of the boys could come back, out of the torment of war, to be himself again. It meant that the war hadn't yet destroyed the old life utterly. "But that isn't all, Delsa. That isn't all! Jim's brought a buddy home?Alec Windsor?to spend the whole thirty days here. Just think, Delsa?a beautiful man in uniform to dance with and talk to and look at! Oh, I'm so excited!" Delsa laughed, then. "You, excited, Millie over a strange man? And with that diamond on your finger?and your heart snugly tucked under a certain ensign's jacket?" "Yes, I am excited, Delsa Marriott, and I'll bet a dime you are, too. How can the boys blame us? If what the papers and pictures and stories say is true, the boys get excited when they see a girl after they've been in the jungles for months!" DELSA waved "her hand, indicating the bare fields about her, now showing the black earth through the snow which was fast melting under the spring sunshine. "This isn't exactly a jungle, Millie," she said. "But t see your point. And what is this Alec Windsor like?" "He's like Hugh Temple, Delsa," Millie said quietly. "It really gave me quite a start when Jim brought him in?the same long, thin darkness that Hugh has?the same intent brown eyes. Oh, Miss Delsa," she mocked, "you'll be excited too, when you. See him, but it won't do you any good? nor any of us. He's spoken for." The mention of Hugh's name had caused Delsa's heart to jerk, feeling a hurt, empty place at its core. But she assured a gusty she couldn't feel as she asked, "And by whom, please tell me?"
"I don't know who she is, Delsa. It's quite sad, in a way. Alec got leave to come to the U. S. to marry his sweetheart. She's a WAC. But when he and Jim got to San Francisco, his WAC had been shipped out?he doesn't even know where. So he had no place to go and nothing to do. He was all for going right back to the South Pacific, but Jim persuaded him to come on here and take the rest he needed. Gosh, if it weren't for Louis I'd certainly undertake to comfort him, poor guy!"
Delsa smiled at her chum. "We'll all undertake to cheer him up," she promised. "There's safety in numbers?for him as well as for us?so we can do a good job of it, without any of us running into danger."
"And guess what?" Millie went on irelandly. "I told Jim to bring him to club tonight, when he came to pick Lina up. Then I'll introduce him to the crowd. Won't that be a honey of a surprise?"
"O-oh?" Delsa exclaimed. "The club! I'll have to dash, Millie, if I get Trudy cared for and get home in time to get anything ready. And I must. I don't want the girls to know I forgot?"
She gave Millie a quick hug and hurried on down the street, Millie calling after her, "Your Mother and Aunt Martha are getting things ready. I came past there."
Delsa hurried on.
Of course her mother and Aunt Martha would be getting things ready. They always helped her when it was her turn to entertain the War Widows.
DELSA smiled to herself, thinking of their club name. Of course they were none of them widows?they were none of them even married. But they had felt so bereft when the boys all left that they had taken this somber name for their little group that met every few weeks to work on things for the homes they would have "some day." The truly married women had a club of their own and they met to comfort each other and to make baby things. Lina, Delsa thought suddenly, Lina would soon join that other club?the fist one of her crowd to break away.
She looked about her quickly, critically, as she entered Jeff's house, and she smiled with satisfaction. Mrs. Reeder wasn't half bad when she knew someone was watching her. She was really doing a creditable job now, caring for Trudy and Davy and cooking the foods Delsa told her to cook. The house was neat and clean, and the Trudy, laughing and happy, didn't look much like the dirty, crying child Delsa had found there only a week before.
The baby saw Delsa and laughed holding up her arms to the girl. Delsa picked her up and cuddled her for a moment, and then set to work checking what had been done and what was to be done.
"I can't stay to bathe Trudy tonight, Mrs. Reeder," she explained. "I have company coming this evening and I've got to rush on home. But you know how to do it." Davy came running into the house and flung his arms about Delsa's knees. She stooped and hugged him, and said, "You be a good boy, Davy, and mind Mrs. Reeder. Delsa's got to hurry home tonight." BUT in spite of her haste, the March twilight was falling before she could get away, and as she went swiftly up the walk to the house she could see, through the lighted windows, her mother and Hugh's mother, moving about the rooms. She opened the kitchen door and went into the big room, feeling the warmth from the stove upon her cool cheeks, smelling the fragrance of the cooking supper, feeling happy that this was her home. These good feelings made her forget her slight embarrassment at being late and at forgetting about the party. But she had no sooner closed the door behind her than she remembered and her happiness shriveled up. For her mother, busy at the stove, did not greet her with her usual cheerful, "Hello, Delsa!" and Hugh's mother's silence was like a cold wind across her. She tried to shake it off. "Hello, folks!" she cried gaily, and went and put her arms about her mother, giving her a squeeze. "You're a darling to get things ready. Mom. I hurried?" There was no answer, no yielding in the stiffness with which her mother's body answered her caress. Delsa turned to Hugh's mother, trying to ignore the rebuff. "How are you. Aunt Martha?" She couldn't for the life of her, make her voice sound light and casual. When Hugh's mother didn't answer, going about her work with stiff-lipped silence, Delsa turned to them and said quietly, "You are both angry with me. Why?" "I guess you have a hint," her mother said and Delsa felt almost like smiling, noticing how her mother couldn't bear to maintain the angry silence between them. "I know I shouldn't have forgotten the club meeting," Delsa said contritely, She thought, I can't stand it to have them angry. Then, determined to ignore their disapproval she went on, knowing her news would distract them, "Jim Lewis is home?but it's supposed to be a secret till tonight. Millie's going to have him call for Lina ? and guess what! He's brought his buddy home with him!" That caught their attention, and with the slight encouragement of lifted eyebrows and stopped movements, Delsa told about Alec Windsor and how he had come to return home with Jim, and of Jim's plans to get married. Hugh's mother sniffed audibly at this. "Jim's smart to grab Lina while he can," she said, "not that Lina ever would look at any one else. She's a mighty loyal little soul, is Lina." Delsa knew what Hugh's mother meant?she wondered, shall I drag her suspicions out into the open? Shall I try to clear them up? Or will that only confirm them? Deciding on ignoring the silent accusations, she went briskly about eating her supper, clearing up and preparing for the club.
But she was acutely aware that Hugh's mother was displeased with her?that something dear and intimate had gone out of their relationship, and she thought bitterly how easy it was for distrust to tear down in one week what years of love and trust had built up.
And she thought determinedly, I won't stop helping Jeff! That's silly?that would be admitting to myself that they are right. But I will do something, something to show them that a small, neighborly gesture doesn't mean anything. I'll have to do something?but it won't be leaving Trudy and Davy to the mercy of Mrs. Reeder's unsupervised laziness.
And the thought of Trudy brought the thought of Hugh and the aching knowledge that giving him up would mean giving up the hope of some day holding his baby and hers against her heart.

A CHILD'S PRAYER Sue Hopkins Holy Father, hear my prayer, Lead me through this world of care. Let my sins be all forgiven. Find me safe at last in heaven. Annual Report?1944 Vera White Pohlman, General Secretary-Treasurer 1940-1945 
RELIEF Society activities were carried forward during 1944 very much as in 1943, and the outstanding accomplishments were in the same fields; namely (1) sewing service including an extensive assignment for the Church Welfare Plan; (2) continuation of special war services; (3) a further substantial increase insubscriptions; and (4) continuation of the Society's educational program with a slight but heartening increase in attendance despite wartime restrictions and conditions.
These and other services and activities were carried forward by Relief Society women with their characteristic devotion, efficiency, and humility, despite their intense anxiety over the absence of sons and daughters and other loved ones due to the exigencies of war, despite the increased demands on their own time because of labor shortages in their homes and communities, and despite the great grief of the loss of gallant young sons.
To all these, the sisterhood of Relief Society has been an anchor and a blessing, a source of sympathetic understanding and deep spiritual support, a means of easing anxiety and sorrow in the blessed-ness of serving others, of gaining uplift and hope for the future, and of strengthening their faith in the divine plan of eternal life and progression.
The growth in Relief Magazine subscriptions was reported in detail in the issue for May 1945, pages 292 to 313, indicating that the exceptional gains resulting from the special effort of 1943 were not only maintained but further increased during 1944 by nearly 5,000 additional subscriptions. Attention is also directed to "Notes From the Field" appearing monthly in the Magazine and recounting various Relief Society activities as reported by stakes, missions, and local Relief Societies. These continuing reports serve to high light and delineate Relief Society activities which, in an annual report, can be treated only in summary. Pertinent figures from the 1944 report are compared with those of 1943 in summary tables appearing on pages 494-495.
RELIEF SOCIETY SEWING SERVICE
Sewing service at Relief Society work meetings in 1944 was the most extensive yet reported, aggregating a total of 716,760 hours' service and 254,004 units completed. Classified according to kinds, the 254,004 completed articles consisted of 14,019 quilts, 21,866 pieces of other bedding, 39,725 articles of children's clothing, 18,578 articles of women's clothing, 12,195 pieces of men's
clothing, and 147,650 miscellaneous items such as dish towels, rugs, and other unclassified articles.
However, the number of women doing this increased sewing declined slightly from 1943 to 32,676. It therefore seems advisable to repeat the following exhortation from the 1944 Annual Report: "... this group of sewing women represents less than one-third of the total membership of the Society, and it would seem that a larger percentage might be brought into the sewing program, even though some of the members are unavailable for this service because of war work or other employment. Suggestions for emphasizing and extending the Society's sewing program throughout the Church, and for enlisting the interest and participation of more women in the work meeting through promotion of sewing skills, appear on pages 378-389, this issue [July 1944] of the Magazine."
Sewing for Red Cross
Approximately one-fourth of the women sewing at Relief Society work meetings during 1944 worked on articles for the Red Cross. These women, numbering 7,874, gave 193,338 hours and completed 103,744 articles. Although fewer hours of service were given, the articles completed were more than double the number reported in 1943, indicating the making of a greater number of small articles requiring less time than articles previously assigned by the Red Cross.
Sewing for Church Welfare
The next largest number of articles was completed for the Church Welfare Plan and totaled 83,414 pieces. This is more than three times the number of articles completed for the Church Welfare Plan in 1943, but in that year the assignment consisted principally of quilts, whereas the 1944 assignment consisted principally of clothing for men, women and children and supplementary bedding and household supplies such as sheets, pillowcases and dish towels. There is no segregated record of the amount of time spent at Relief Society meetings on Church Welfare sewing.
Many stakes held impressive displays of the sewing accomplished for the Church Welfare Plan during 1944. (See "Notes From the Field," June 1945.) As in 1943, the General Board authorized the purchase of materials for this assignment from funds of the Society, and disbursements for this purpose doubtless accounted largely for the increase of $4,268.19, or 30 per cent over 1943 disbursements. Permission to use Relief Society funds for this purpose was not continued beyond 1944, when collection of funds by Relief Society visiting teachers was discontinued and when the General Board and the General Church Welfare Committee agreed to rely on the provision of the Church Welfare Plan which charges regional or stake welfare committees with responsibility for financing assignments which they receive. The following comments from a few stakes reflect the spirit with which Relief Society women accepted this assignment and the pride which they took in its fulfillment: From Rexburg Stake (Idaho): This assignment was almost equally divided among the fifteen wards and at a special meeting was given to the ward presidents for acceptance. It was with a great deal of trepidation that the assignments were given to the wards, but not a single word of protest was made. Each president accepted her list and went home to work out ways and means of fulfilling it. Cotton goods of any kind and white materials especially were almost off the market, but this did not daunt the sisters. With a will that finds a way, the assignments were completed before the close of the year?many of them, before six months had passed. Some of the wards used their charity or their general funds, or part of both, for the purchase of materials. Others gathered donations from the teachers' districts. For example, a certain district would be assigned the twenty-one dish towels, and the teachers on that district would either collect the goods or their equivalent in money. Most of the layettes were gathered at a baby shower at one of the work meetings. At the meeting beforehand, slips of paper with the names of articles required were drawn by the sisters, and on the day of the shower, they came with the article nicely wrapped. The occasion was made into a lovely party, with refreshments, programs, and games, after which the layette was displayed by the presidency. One ward made most of their assignment from poultry feed bags, which they collected from the poultry men in their area, washed and bleached and then made into slips and panties, pillowcases and dish towels. Some of the bags were dyed in pastel colors and made into dainty slips for the children. When completed, the assignments were pressed and beautifully packed and turned into the welfare center. Not a single article from any ward was lacking. We feel that neither mere words nor cold figures can tell the sacrifice, loyalty and devotion which the sisters put into the achievement of this huge task. Many of them bought their limit or two sheets, giving them to the Society and doing without themselves. Hours of sewing in the homes were required for the completion of this project. But we are sure that every Relief Society woman in the stake is gratified with her accomplishment. From Phoenix Stake (Arizona): During January 1944, representatives from each ward met and cut all the articles for our welfare sewing; 50 hours of cutting was done. The articles were then distributed to the wards for sewing. Our 1944 assignments were completed early in the year. From Cottonwood Stake (Utah): The women of the eight wards met the requirements of the welfare assignment in the most co-operative spirit, finishing the entire assignment long before it was due. Great pride was taken in making the layettes, fine handwork making them very dainty and attractive. Every organization displayed in its oven ward the finished articles before sending them to the regional storehouse. From San Francisco Stake (California): The stake and ward Relief Societies exhibited their welfare sewing in the amusement hall at the October stake conference. This exhibit consisted of ten large tables laden with handmade quilts, clothing, et cetera. This display helped to stimulate interest in welfare work and an appreciation for the industry of the Relief Society women. The following comment from Uintah Stake is a reminder of the timeliness of the bedding project recommended by the Church Welfare Committee and the General Board of Relief Society in 1941 and 1942 for the purpose of encouraging and assisting families to restock their bedding supplies: From Uintah Stake (Utah): - During 1944 our bedding project was still being carried forward in some wards with interest and beneficial results. One ward with an enrollment of forty-one members ANNUAL REPORT 481 completed forty-three quilts, almost an average of four quilts for each work day of the year. At the close of this year we all know that materials for quilt making are practically off the market. The president of this ward tells us they are very thankful this bedding project was assigned for now every family in their ward is more adequately supplied with bedding than ever before, and in working out the project they have had very happy times together, have increased the average attendance at meetings, and have grown spiritually. Other wards have also done splendid work in the line of bedding. Sewing for Other Purposes Articles made for Relief Society purposes, usually to replenish the Societies treasuries through bazaars and custom sewing, chiefly quilting, also increased over 1943 and amounted to 54,434 articles. In addition, 116,171 articles were made for other purposes, such as sewing for hospitals and other worthy community purposes, but a slight decrease of nearly 7,000 articles was recorded in this section during the year, doubtless due to decreased need for this service from community agencies. Here are some additional comments which relate to other Relief Society sewing activities and to the efforts made to increase participation in Relief Society work meetings with a view to teaching and benefiting the members themselves with their home sewing as well as to give sewing service for others: From Uintah Stake (Utah): Also on work days we sponsored a project of made-over clothing. To make this more interesting and beneficial some of our ward leaders participated in a three-day school conducted by an extension specialist from the Agricultural College. These leaders then demonstrated in die different wards the work they had received, and soon many little girls were thrilled with a new skirt made from daddy's old coat, or a slip or even a dress made from his old shirt. To finish off this project we had a display of "made-overs" at our stake conference in November. From Rexburg Stake (Idaho): Our board added four women's and four men's suits to our baptismal clothing cupboard; also some towels and a heavy rug. This project has proved a great blessing to the children and adults who come to the Tabernacle for baptism. A member of the board is in attendance each month. A small fee is charged for the use of the clothing?enough to pay for the laundry. Our aim is to supply enough clothing someday to have every one wearing uniform outfits. From Phoenix Stake (Arizona): Thirty-two baptismal suits were cut and made and donated to the Arizona Temple. From Pasadena Stake (California): A project on which our Relief Societies are really putting forth some excellent effort is the remodeling of used clothing. We are obtaining old clothes which are in good condition and making the hard-to-get children's clothing, and the materials are far superior to any new ones which can be purchased at this time. From Ogden Stake (Utah): The wards seem much enthused over the new procedure on work day, and we are happy to note a general pickup, and that the attendance is improving. From Snowflake Stake (Arizona): Several bazaars were held during the year. One ward working for a new rug for their room put pep into their work by choosing sides. Each group was given $20 to buy material with; the bazaar netted them over $300. From Highland Stake (Utah): At a planning meeting on September 19, we presented a display of new and remodeled clothing and other articles in an effort to stimulate an interest among the ward workers in introducing similar activities into their work meetings. One of the wards held a successful apron sale and one helped with a ward fair. In several of the wards cooking demonstrations have been held on their work days. A fairly large amount of quilting has been done in most of the wards. We feel that the new work-day program has been carried out very successfully in our stake. OTHER CHURCH WELFARE SERVICE In addition to sewing at Relief Society meetings on articles to be turned in to bishops' storehouses, Relief Society women have done sewing at some of the storehouses, have assisted at storehouses with the canning of a tremendous amount of fruits and vegetables, and have stimulated interest and activity in their various communities in increased canning for home use in order to conserve food supplies and to relieve commercial supplies for war use. Although reports of the number of hours given by Relief Society women on Church Welfare projects (other than sewing at Relief Society meetings) are still incomplete, a total of 524,915 hours' service by Relief Society women on such projects was reported last year, almost double the number of hours reported the previous year, an increase of 237,105 hours, or eighty-two per cent. Only a small fraction (five per cent) of this service is given by women whose families are being aided by the bishops, ninety-five per cent of this service being given by women whose families were not being assisted. In fact, the hours' service by women whose families were receiving aid from the storehouses decreased during 1944 by twenty-five per cent while service by other Relief Society women increased ninety-six per cent. Of this storehouse service and other activities in the interest of the Church Welfare Plan, a few stakes and one mission reported as follows: From San Diego Stake (California): Our women have spent many hours at the canning plant as well as at the sewing center. A laundry room has been built very recently and the board, with the ward organizations, donated equal amounts earned from the sale of used clothing and equipped it with a fifty-gallon tank and laundry tubs. From the Canadian Mission (Canada): The sisters in several of our larger branches have assisted in canning about 2,000 cans of fruits and vegetables, and are at present working on welfare assignments?making quilts, layettes and maternity bundle" for use in their own organizations, and, of course, preparing more "Bundles for Britain." From Uintah Stake (Utah): In all wards, classes sponsored by Relief Society were held by the home demonstration agent for instruction in pressure cooking testing. Many cookers were tested during these demonstrations. Instructions were also given on drying of vegetables and fruits and sulphuring of fruits. Three classes of Relief Society women were also given instruction in home gardening. From Cottonwood Stake (Utah): Early in the summer all of the women possessing pressure cookers were given the opportunity to test them. ANNUAL REPORT 483 Although no accurate count was taken of the amount of canning done, we feel sure that enough fruits, vegetables, and meats have been canned to top any previous year. From North Idaho Falls Stake (Idaho): We have co-operated with the county home demonstrator of the Department of Agriculture in the testing of pressure cookers, meal preparation, growing of vegetable gardens, and demonstration in canning, bread making, use of patterns, et cetera. All these were done with the hope of making our Relief Society members more efficient in these war times. From Snowflake Stake (Arizona): Another activity that has interested our women resulted from our aim to get a first-class recipe for canning our most productive Arizona crop?pinto beans. The stake welfare launched the project throughout the Relief Society. The results brought sixteen samples of canned or bottled beans, from which first and second choices will be made. From Mount Ogden Stake (Utah): The canning for the storehouse was participated in by each ward as the season's produce came in. CONTINUED WAR SERVICES Relief Society women continued their wholehearted support of wartime agencies during 1944, as more extensively described in annual reports for 1942 and 1943, and in "Notes From the Field" for October and November 1943, and August, October, and November 1944. In addition to sewing for the Red Cross, already discussed, Relief Society women have served extensively at Red Cross sewing and bandage-rolling centers, but time spent for this purpose is not included in the count of hours devoted to Red Cross work at Relief Society meetings. The ward first-aid kits, first recommended by the General Board in 1942, were still being maintained by ward Relief Societies at the end of 1944, in the number of 780 kits, and, in addition, 529 home-nursing supply chests were being maintained; 544 wards were also keeping current lists of nurses available in the community as had been recommended by the General Board. The value of these kits to a community in case of accident or disaster was demonstrated March 14, 1945, when twelve men were badly burned in a Kenilworth mine explosion. This ward, in Carbon Stake (Utah) reported: "Of greatest value were the ten woolen quilts and the two woolen blankets. Most of the men, wearing nothing but charred bits of clothing, needed warm covering immediately. The bedding was lifted from the chest standing in the entrance way of the hospital, the quilts doubled and placed over the sufferers as they lay about waiting further medical aid. Later, several of the quilts protected the men in ambulances speeding to Price. Medical attendants expressed gratitude for the quick availability of these coverings whose warmth helped to stave off shock. Because a mine hospital is well stocked with emergency materials, other supplies were untouched. However, the nurse said, "Just one more man and everything would have been used," adding, "it is a lesson to all Relief Societies that there is a definite purpose in having these kits in every ward." A member of the Society remarked, "I thought after the war we might sell those quilts, but now I see their use extends beyond a wartime precaution." Narrative reports from some of the stakes refer to their war service as follows: From Phoenix Stake (Arizona): On the fourth Monday of each month our ward Relief Societies have taken turns serving at the U. S. O. They furnish and prepare the food. Sandwiches, cakes, pies, and homemade cookies seem to please the boys most. On Christmas day the Second Ward officers served over 400 boys. They felt a great satisfaction in making Christmas more pleasant for servicemen. From San Diego Stake (California): Our members have spent many hours at the Red Cross, donated blood, kept children that others might work, opened their homes to out-of-town servicemen, fed and cheered them, mothered them and sent them on their way wih a prayer in their hearts for their safe return. Our Latter-day Saint women are more than anxious to do all they can to assist the war effort. From South Los Angeles Stake (California): At the beginning of this year we were aware that our mothers were anxious to help, as an organization, the work of the Red Cross. We, therefore, arranged with our local chapter to become a separate unit, The Sea Gull Unit, and during the year our sisters have completed 1,216 articles of clothing and spent 3,990 hours working to help this splendid organization to help their boys and girls who are a part of our armed forces. From Mount Ogden Stake (Utah): The Red Cross has received extensive aid, as will be noted through reports. The canteen has received several hundred dozens of cookies, as well as many women giving service there. The surgical dressing department of Red Cross received many hours' assistance from Relief Society women. From South Ogden Stake (Utah): Six of our wards furnished 495 dozen cookies for the Red Cross canteen during the year. From North Idaho Falls Stake (Idaho): Our first counselor acted as chairman of the Red Cross activities. She arranged with the county Red Cross officials for regular working hours for the wards and nearly all of our Societies have helped to fill the county quotas. From Canadian Mission (Canada): We have sent about 300 pounds of clothing, soap, safety pins, et cetera, to the Relief Society in Britain for distribution there. We recently received a letter from the Relief Society officers of the British Mission, in which they tell us that some of our clothing has been sent on to France to help relieve conditions there. This was made possible through the help of one of our officers who, although he is in the battle area, finds time to do this work of mercy for the children who suffer there. Some of our branches have done exceptional work. A recent bundle came in from the Hamilton Branch in which were many children's sweaters made from ends of new material purchased from a knitwear factory by one of the employees who is an enthusiastic Relief Society worker. These ends were made into lovely sweaters, suits, garter waists, and even underclothes. It was a beautiful bundle. The letter from Britain tells of the need "over there" for children's clothing, ages one to fourteen, and clothing for elderly people, also bedding. We have promised to help as long as there is need. During 1944, stake and ward Relief Societies purchased additional war bonds in the amount of $37,889.46. Purchases for the two previous years amounted to $44,623.08 bringing the total by the end of 1944 to $82,492.54. During 1944, the General Board arranged for the pooling and safekeeping of these bonds, so that none would be lost track of during the reorganizations which will occur prior to maturity. By the end of 1944, bonds to the value of $41,335.00 had been deposited with the General Board. All stakes and war Relief Societies whose bonds are not so deposited are urged to take advantage of the free safekeeping service offered by the General Board.
MEETINGS AND ATTENDANCE
Relief Society meetings of all types during 1944 numbered 89,629, an increase of 7,317 or 9.58 per cent from the previous year. All types of stake and ward meetings shared in this increase but local meetings for members claimed sixty-four per cent of these additional gatherings. Further analysis indicates that 77.91 per cent of the increase in meetings for members occurred in mission branches which conducted 5,585 more meetings in 1944 than in 1943, whereas wards conducted 1,670 more meetings. These several meetings with extent of increase are listed in the table on page 494.
Training-Report Meetings and Ward Preparation Meetings
It is heartening to note that a slight increase of 3.42, or four per cent, also occurred in the number of visiting teachers' training meetings, and that an even more substantial increase was felt in number of ward preparation meetings which advanced from 7,018 in 1943 to 8,515 in 1944, an increase of 497 or 7.08 per cent. The increases in these two types of meetings were doubtless due to the emphasis placed on them by the General Board to help bulletins to officers, through the pages of the Magazine, and through the discussion meetings conducted by representatives of the General Board during the latter part of 1943 and 1944.
The combination of the training and the report meetings for visiting teachers (recommended in the Magazine for September 1944), and the stress laid on the purpose and importance of this meeting, doubtless stimulated this increase which it is hoped will be even more evident as the new plan is carried through 1945. The increase in the vitally important ward preparation meeting for officers and class leaders was further stimulated by a detailed outline of procedure which was published in the Magazine for September 1944. Nevertheless, the number of such ward preparation meetings should nearly double in order to represent a monthly meeting of this kind for all local Relief Societies during the eightmonth period, September through April, and during the summer period as required. In furthering these two types of meetings and also in held demonstrations during 1944 which were attended by local officers. Here is what three stakes have to say regarding the ward preparation meeting: From Phoenix Stake (Arizona): At the opening of the fall season each board member was assigned a certain ward to visit once a month (preferably ward preparation meeting) and to bring to the board problems and accomplishments of this particular ward. At the next board meeting these problems are discussed and any suggestions from the entire board are then taken back to the ward. We feel that follow-up visits by the same board member will result in more helpful suggestions. From Highland Stake (Utah): We have worked hard during the past year to get all of our wards to hold regular monthly preparation meetings, as we are fully convinced that such meetings present an opportunity to the ward workers to become more familiar with the Relief Society program, and with the problems and interests of their individual organizations. At the beginning of the 1944-45 season, we, as a stake presidency, visited the monthly preparation meetings of each ward to see how they were conducted and to attempt to stimulate more interest in such meetings. All of our wards realize the necessity of getting their officers and workers together in such meetings and they are now being held regularly. We feel that the visiting teachers' training report meeting and the method of making reports have been more successful and more interesting than the former procedure. From Uintah Stake (Utah): Another thing we think is resulting in good to our wards was a demonstration, at union meeting, of an executive officers' meeting, and of a ward preparation meeting. Ward Conferences An increase was also recorded in the number of annual ward Relief Society conferences held, but the Sunday evening meeting in March, also for the ward membership in general, may have been included erroneously in some instances. A substantial increase of twenty-one per cent was noted in the number of officers' meetings held in connection with the annual ward Relief Society conference, the number increasing from 1184 in 1943 to 1424 in 1944. South Ogden Stake(Utah) comments on these meetings as follows: We succeeded in holding preliminary officers' meetings before each of our ward Relief Society conference sessions. A questionnaire was presented by the visiting board member, at each preliminary meeting, checking on each department of ward work. In connection with the ward conferences, we wish to report that our stake presidency was very considerate of us, appointing high councilmen to attend both the preliminary officers' meeting and the general session in each of the wards, as well as furnishing transportation to the outlying wards. We feel deeply appreciative for this courtesy, and we know that it added much to the success of our conference to have one of the stake presidency or one of our high councilmen in each of our conferences." Stake Meetings
All types of stake meetings showed increases (see table on page 494) except those held in lieu of union meetings which declined slightly, as would be expected in the face of a 64 per cent increase in number of actual union meetings held. ORGANIZATIONS AND MEMBERSHIP
The decline in Relief Society membership which has been in progress since the peak year of 1941 continued during 1944, but the rate of loss was much less than during the two preceding years. The net membership decrease from 1943 was 1,848 or 1.8 per cent, whereas the loss in 1943 was 3,373 or three per cent and in 1942 was 8,000 or seven per cent. The reasons for the decrease are the same as during the previous two years?unusual population shifts throughout the country occasioned by war employment and other war conditions, with the resulting lack of affiliation with the Relief Society in the new and often temporary location, and to the clearing from the rolls of names of women who joined the Society during the height of the membership campaign but proved to be not genuinely interested. Actually, there were more admittances to membership (12,730) during 1944 than in 1943 and also fewer removals and resignations, leaving the net number of members increased in 1944 at 102,961. Local Relief Societies should continue to solicit unenrolled women including new arrivals who in so far as may have been affiliated elsewhere.
The members are accounted for in a total of 2,217 local Relief Societies. The geographic distribution on page 493 shows the number of local Relief Societies and number of Relief Society members in each state of the United States and in other countries. These organizations and members are also listed according to whether they are located in stakes or in missions. There were 135 more ward Relief Societies in stakes in 1944 than in 1943, but nearly 2,000 fewer members. On the other hand, local Relief Societies in missions declined by twenty-four, but the number of members increased slightly (131). Another distribution of members?according to assignments in a Society?appears on page 494. As is usual, approximately half of the total membership is assigned to one or one or more capacities of the organization's elected officers, leaders, special workers or visiting teachers. ANNUAL REPORT 489 However, the number of stake officers and board members declined during 1944, doubtless as a result of curtailed activity on the part of stake workers due to war conditions. Executive and special workers in the wards increased slightly, as did the number of visiting teachers, but nearly 600 fewer class leaders were reported, as a result of the discontinuance of the home topic from the monthly work meeting, as announced in the Magazine for July 1944. Where there is a shortage of women for the various positions, one officer or class leader frequently serves in more than one capacity, but is counted only once in this distribution. From this same table it is noted that seventy per cent of all Relief Society members are Magazine subscribers? the highest proportion in the history of the Society. The percentage of subscribing officers and class leaders was about the same as in 1943, but sixty-seven per cent of the visiting teachers and other members was reported as subscribers in 1944 as compared with sixty per cent in 1943. VISITING TEACHING The continued decline in visiting teaching since the beginning of the war is again apparent from the 1944 report. Despite the fact that visiting teachers' districts were increased by 631 or four per cent, evidently in order to reduce the number of families per visiting teacher, the number of visiting teachers was increased by only 131, and the number of visits dropped by 46,368 or four per cent. Visits attempted where no one was found at home constituted 368,022 or thirty-two per cent of the total of 1,144, 519 visits made. Families were found at home in 776,497, or sixty-eight per cent of the visits attempted, a slightly better ratio than was found at home during the previous year's visits. Nevertheless, visits attempted in 1944 were actually fewer by 126,884 4% 4% 49444 immediately preceding the war. Although nearly 20,000 communications were reported by mail and telephone, in lieu of visits, contacts of this type were nearly 8,000 fewer than in 1943, or twenty-eight per cent less. This may be partly accounted for by the fact that the General Board discouraged the printing of visiting teachers' messages, some of which were doubtless mailed to unvisited families and were replaced by no other communication in lieu of a visit. The decline of nine per cent or 3,799 in average monthly number making contributions is a direct result of the change in policy, announced in the Magazine for September 1944, when collections by visiting teachers were discontinued, after being in effect for 102 years, from the Society's very first meeting. The new policy became effective in October 1944, so that the number of contributors shown in the annual report represents principally those making donations during the preceding nine months. COMPASSIONATE SERVICES Visits to the sick and homebound increased by seven per cent to 116,219 during 1944, but the number of days' care of the sick, both volunteer and paid from the Society's funds, declined by four per cent to 13,883. There was a decrease of twenty per cent in number of bodies prepared for burial, particularly with respect to those instances where complete preparation was given. This would indicate an increase in the services of morticians; on the other hand, there was a slight increase in the number of bodies dressed for burial by Relief Society women. It must be remembered, however, that many deeds of kindness, compassion, and helpfulness are performed for those in sorrow and distress which cannot be measured in terms of reports, as evidenced by the following excerpts: From South Los Angeles Stake (California): Every ward in our stake has performed its various activities cheerfully and efficiently, but there is one ward which we feel has had the spirit of service in rich abundance. The Maywood Ward sisters, under the direction of their president. Sister Irene Andrus, went in a group and painted and papered the entire house of one of their members who is confined to a wheel chair. From North Idaho Falls Stake (Idaho): The Sunshine Committee, which consists of stake board members, continued to make the weekly visits to the L. D. S. Hospital. We were especially desirous of visiting Relief Society women patients from distant towns, hoping to cheer them and to extend to them assistance when needed. From the New Zealand Mission: You will also notice under "Burial Assistance" there is a blank. This does not give a true picture of the situation as the Relief Society sisters are very active in their services for the dead. They have been complimented on many occasions by undertakers and hospital attendants because of the lovely manner in which they have dressed the dead. I have encouraged the sisters to see that elderly people and those whose health is failing keep on hand suitable white clothing for burial when the need arises. They have responded well to this request. Some of the Relief Societies are continuing to co-operate with local public health authorities in conducting well-baby clinics. September 1944 marked the twentieth anniversary of the Cottonwood Stake Maternity Hospital (Utah) which is operated by the Relief Society of that stake; 736 babies were born there during 1944. All together 8,595 patients have been admitted since the hospital was opened. This hospital is recognized as fulfilling all requirements of the U. S. Government for the acceptance of servicemen's wives. This stake has continuously operated a well-baby clinic since 1921. In 1944, a total of 387 children attended this clinic and all have the privilege of tree vaccination for smallpox and immunization for diphtheria and whooping cough, in addition to physical examination and consultation. Funds Expended Total disbursement of local, stake, and mission Relief Societies and the General Board during 1944 aggregated $539,155.22, an increase of ANNUAL REPORT 491 $98,552.90, or twenty-two percent over disbursements of 1943. Of this amount $110,354.57 was spent for charitable purposes and $428,800.65 for general operating expenses and the Society's educational work. The charitable disbursements represented an increase over 1943 of $18,168.69, or twenty per cent, which may be attributed chiefly to authorization by the General Board of the use of Relief Society funds for the purchase of materials for the 1944 Church Welfare clothing assignment. In addition. Relief Society funds were disbursed directly to needy families and health services were also provided in some areas. Commodities with an estimated value of $4,896.92 which had been contributed to the Relief Society were also distributed to the needy, bringing total charity disbursements to $115,251.49. Included in the disbursements for general purposes is a considerable but unidentified amount spent for improving Relief Society rooms and stake and ward buildings in general. The following few excerpts from narrative reports indicate the nature of these expenditures: From ???New Zealand Mission: Recently we have made a drive to raise money to install a community shower bath in one of the Maori Pas whose misfortune it is to be deprived of proper sanitary facilities. From North Idaho Falls Stake (Idaho): During the early part of the year the stake and ward Relief Society organizations purchased a carpet for the Relief Society room in the stake tabernacle. Although only ten in number at that time, we worked hard and intensely and with help from other Church members we were very successful. Our profits were $120.15. Total net assets of the Society as of the end of 1944, including cash on hand, wheat trust funds, war bonds, and other invested funds, value of real estate, buildings, furniture, and other property were reported to be $1,440,070.55.
