A cluster of log cabins nestled in a broad valley, turning to gold in the September sunshine. Two years slipped by. The hollows in Jim's cheeks disappeared. Firm flesh upholstered his gaunt frame. He fenced a piece of land, built a log house, made tables and chairs and a bed. He hired out and earned a wagon, two black oxen and the necessary tools and seed. One day when wild currants flamed in the canyons and choke-cherries fringed the waterways with "summer-snow," she gave Jim a son. Her heart had been too small to hold its burden of joy. She had gone, thankfully, to the Bowery on the first Sunday morning and sat with her baby across her knees. She had lifted her voice again in praise, had listened to Brother Brigham, secure in her dreams. It had all seemed so right, so wonderful to be in the Valley. Then had dawned the unforgettable day that brought her dreams crashing down. Brother Brigham was speaking. His voice seemed to drift in from another world. "The climate?suitable to cotton ?a mill site by adequate water power. Need men?skilled in growing of cotton?spinners?weavers?families who have proved their courage." Then, like a thunderbolt, Jim's name and hers! She had sat like one condemned, her cooing baby unnoticed in her lap. Jim came, his eyes aglow with a new purpose. Friends crowded around, some of them already bargaining their farms away. It seemed like sacrilege to her. She helped Jim pack as the weeks wore away and the harvesting began. Its abundance had furnished her scant pleasure. It mattered little whether she lived or died. She was leaving the mountains, going to a land she detested, a wilderness beyond the last outpost of civilization. When, at last, they joined the caravan at the "Square" on that early autumn morning, she climbed up on the wagon seat, hoping against hope that something would happen to turn them back. Men bustled about the wagons NOT TO THE SWIFT 497 packing and repacking. Oxen chewed their cuds and switched their tails with melancholy indifference. Women gathered in excited knots, restraining heedless little feet from the bedlam of activity. She sat on the high wagon seat, alone, staring at the mountains with desperate eyes. At last the command to start rang out like a pistol shot. A murmur swelled to a roar. Neckyokes creaked, oxen heaved and strained as reluctant wheels rolled into line. On and on they rumbled?past Ka-nosh, beyond Parowan and the Cove, up to Cedar Mountain and the Iron mines, over the Rim of the Basin and down, braking the wheels with logs of cedar and pine. SHE came to herself with a start. Jim was shaking her gently. She awoke into stark reality. "We're most theyah, honey," Jim reassured her. "But you'uns 'ill have to climb down while we take the wagon apart and lowah the pieces oveh the ledges with ropes." She lowered the yawning baby into his father's arms. "Walk about whilst I unpack, honey," he urged, setting her on her feet. She found a winding trail, worn smooth by the tread of moccasined feet. It led up to a lonely knoll, fluted and carved by age-long sculpturing of wind and rain. It formed a natural lookout, commanding the sweep of a country so vast one could only guess at its magnitude. Far to the south the hazy peaks of the Parashaunts melted into the misty sky. They seemed unfriendly and remote. Even the ridges to the west, like a giant steamboat plowing through clouds of foam, seemed but a shattered pile of rocks discarded by indifferent hands. Below, yawned the barren wastes of the desert cut through by the crimson flood of the river. She turned, hopelessly, to the north and?there was her mountain, rising above the crimson knolls in solitary splendor, girdled with pines that marched to its snowy crest, dimpled with little valleys that awakened memories of the almost forgotten homeland. Hot tears sprang to her eyes. All the old fears and bitter prejudices dropped away like a discarded garment. A healing peace enveloped her. The wind, pungent with sage and mesquite, swept up from the valley floor, singing through the fluted towers and pinnacles, calling to her, begging her to listen to the voice of the desert. "We are the everlasting hills, broken and sifted for your coming, O you strong ones!" they whispered. "We have grown hungry for the plowshare, thirsty for the harnessed waters of yonder river. Only the strong and fearless can subdue us. From our loins the fig tree and the vine shall spring, the pomegranate redden. Endure to the end, you faithful, that your children and your children's children may reap the harvest of your vision." She heard as only those who strive to love the desert can hear and understand. She began to hum in unison with the hidden chorus, and as she sang its message clarified within her heart. She saw Jim climbing up over the ledges to find her, the old proud look rekindling in his eyes as she ran down the trail toward him. LESSON DEPARTMENT Theology Church History Lesson 10?Brigham Young's Call to Leadership Dr. H. Wayne Driggs For Tuesday, November 6, 1945 Objective: To show the power of leadership under God. A N erect, broad-shouldered man in the vigor of his early forties stood one August afternoon in the year 1844 to address a multitude of saints. There were pain and anxiety in the faces that looked up at him, and a silence known only when the great moments of life hush human hearts. He began: Attention all! This congregation makes me think of the days of King Benjamin, the multitude being so great that all could not hear. I request the brethren not to have any feelings for being convened this afternoon, for it is necessary; we want you all to be still and give attention that all may hear. Let none complain because of the situation of the congregation, we will do the best we can (D. H. C., Vol. VII, page 252). Rows upon rows of men bearing the Priesthood of God appeared in order according to their various quorums. As of one mind they listened. Here was a man, a courageous leader, who had cut short his recent missionary assignment to the East to hasten home. His friends Page 498 needed him, for they, too, had heavy hearts like his. "Brother Joseph," their Prophet, lay dead, his voice was stilled, his sight taken. He had been their voice and their sight these many years. Who now was to hear the voice of the Lord and speak? Martyred while yet in his thirties, how could the people of this modern seer be expected to think so soon of the days when another would be appointed to lead the Church? That time had now come with shocking reality, and, within the hours of the day before them, there was a decision to be made. Would the Church be lead by a "guardian" or a president? It was Brigham Young who now stood before the assemblage to help the saints in their hour of decision. There was a firmness in his voice and a strength in his delivery which was so needed at this hour. Sidney Rigdon, who had spoken at the morning session of this August 8th conference, seemed too sure of his position as the rightful "guardian to build the church unto Joseph," LESSON DEPARTMENT 499 as he put it, to satisfy the hunger in the hearts of the saints. Yet Rigdon was a counselor to Joseph and had been with the Prophet during many of the most marvelous manifestations of the early years of the Church. Surely his claim to leadership could not be overlooked. But somehow the people felt the need of the voice that could speak the mind and will of the Lord on this most significant point, and Brother Rigdon had lost most of that sweet spirit so present among those in perfect fellowship. He had, because of his self interests, left Nauvoo for Pittsburgh sometime before the martyrdom of the Prophet (Doc. And Gov. 124:108-9). The saints could not but feel that his return now at this most critical hour of the Church had something of the opportunist element in it. In the afternoon of August 7 at 4 P. M., the day before the open-air gathering above described, there was held a meeting of the Church authorities at Nauvoo. A majority of the Quorum of the Twelve was present, together with the high council, the high priests, and the seventies. President William Marks of the Nauvoo Stake prayed, and President Brigham Young called upon Sidney Rigdon to speak, who said: The object of my mission is to visit the saints and offer myself to them as a guardian, I had a vision at Pittsburgh, June 27th. This was presented to my mind not as an open vision, but rather a continuation of the vision mentioned in the Book of Doctrine and Covenants. It was shown to me that this Church must be built up to Joseph,... And I must come to Nauvoo and see that the Church is governed in a proper manner. Joseph sustains the same relationship to this Church as he has always 'done. No man can be the successor of Joseph. The kingdom is to be built up to Jesus Christ through Joseph; there must be revelation still. The martyred Prophet is still the head of this Church; every quorum should stand as you stood in your washings and consecrations. I have been consecrated a spokesman to Joseph, and I was commanded to speak for him. The Church is not disorganized though our head is gone. We may have a diversity of feelings on this matter. I have been called to be a spokesman unto Joseph, and I want to build up the Church unto him; and if the people want me to sustain this place, I want it upon the principle that every individual shall acknowledge it for himself. I propose to be a guardian to the people; in this I have discharged my duty and done what God has commanded me, and the people can please themselves whether they accept me or not (D. H. C. Vol. VII, pp. 229-230). At the conclusion of Brother Rigdon's remarks. President Brigham Young rose to his feet and said: I do not care who leads the Church, even though it were Ann Lee; but one thing I must know, and that is what God says about it. I have the keys and the means of obtaining the mind of God on the subject. I know there are those in our midst who will seek the lives of the Twelve as they did the lives of Joseph and Hyrum. We shall ordain others and give the fulness of the priesthood, so that if we are killed the fulness of the priesthood may remain. Joseph conferred upon our heads all the keys and powers belonging to the Apostleship which he himself held before he was taken away, and no man or set of men can get between Joseph and the Twelve in this world or in the world to come. How often has Joseph said to the Twelve, "I have laid the foundation and you must build thereon, for upon your shoulders the kingdom rests." The Twelve, as a quorum, will not be permitted to tarry here long; they will go abroad and bear off the kingdom to the nations of the earth, and baptize the people faster than mobs can kill them off. I would like, were it my privilege, to take my valise and travel and preach till we had a people gathered who would be true. My private feelings would be to let the affairs of men and women alone, only go and preach and baptize them into the kingdom of God; yet, whatever duty God places upon me, in his strength I intend to fulfill it. I want to see this people, with the various quorums of the priesthood, assembled together in special conference on Thursday next at 10 a.m. (Ibid. page 230). A comparison of these two speeches strikingly shows the difference between leadership subservient to the will of the Lord and that prompted by the power of pride and self-esteem. The Savior pointed the way when he said, "... Not my will, but thine, be done" (Luke 22:42); "... Whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister" (Matt. 20:26). God blesses the leader and increases his powers of leadership if he will but be humble and seek instructions from the mind of the Lord. As if having accepted the spirit of Brigham Young on this day, the Lord miraculously manifested his will concerning this man who was to follow in the footsteps of Joseph. Before the assembled saints, that August afternoon, President Young spoke. The spirit of inspiration was his: Heretofore you have had a Prophet as the mouth of the Lord to speak to you, but he has sealed his testimony with his blood, and now, for the first time, are you called to walk by faith, not by sight.... I now wish to speak of the organization of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. If the Church is organized, and you want to know how it is organized, I will tell you. I know your feelings?do you want me to tell your feelings...? The Twelve are appointed by the finger of God. Here is Brigham, have his knees ever faltered? Have his lips ever quivered? Here is Heber and the rest of the Twelve, an independent body who have the keys of the priesthood?the keys of the kingdom of God to deliver to all the world: this is true, so help me God. They stand next to Joseph, and are as the First Presidency of the Church. (See Doc. And Gov. 107:23-24.) I do not know whether my enemies will take my life or not, and I do not care, for I want to be with the man I love. You cannot fill the office of a prophet, seer and revelator: God must do this. You are like children without a father and sheep without a shepherd. You must not appoint any man at our head; if you should, the Twelve must ordain him. You cannot appoint a man at our head; but if you do want any other man or men to lead you, take them and we will go our way to build up the kingdom in all the world. I know who are Joseph's friends, and who are his enemies. I know where the keys of the kingdom are, and where they will eternally be. You cannot call a man to be a prophet; you cannot take Elder Rigdon and place him above the Twelve; if so, he must be ordained by them.... Brother Joseph, the Prophet, has laid the foundation for a great work, and we will build upon it; you have never seen the quorums built one upon another. There is an almighty foundation laid, and we can build a kingdom such as there never was in the world: we can build a kingdom faster than satan can kill the saints off.... I will ask, who has stood next to Joseph and Hyrum? I have, and I will stand next to him. We have a head, and that head is the Apostleship, the spirit and power of Joseph, and we can now begin to see the necessity of that Apostleship (Ibid. pp. 232-235). It was during this inspiring speech that the transfiguration of Brigham Young occurred. The late President George Q. Cannon wrote of this event: If Joseph had arisen from the dead and again spoken in their hearing, the effect could not have been more startling than LESSON DEPARTMENT 501 it was to many present at that meeting; it was the voice of Joseph himself; and not only was it the voice of Joseph which was heard, but it seemed in the eyes of the people as if it were the very person of Joseph which stood before them. A more wonderful and miraculous event than was wrought that day in the presence of that congregation we never heard of. The Lord gave his people a testimony that left no room for doubt as to who was the man chosen to lead them. In the Journal of Elder William C. Staines of the date of August 8, 1844, AXA following statement is recorded: "Brigham Young said: 'I will tell you who your leaders or guardians will be?the Twelve?I at their head.' This was with the voice like the voice of the Prophet Joseph. I thought it was he, and so did thousands who heard it. This was very satisfactory to the people, and a vote was taken to sustain the Twelve in their office, which with a few dissenting voices, was passed." Wilford Woodruff described the event as follows: "If I had not seen him with my own eyes, there is no one that could have convinced me that it was not Joseph Smith, and anyone can testify to this who was acquainted with these two men" (Deseret Evening News, March 12, 1892). At the conclusion of President Young's remarks, Amasa Lyman, W. W. Phelps, and Parley P. Pratt spoke; then a vote was taken on the question as to whether the saints should have a "guardian" as a leader or the Twelve as the head who rightfully stood in line of authority next to the First Presidency. The hands raised showed a universal vote for the Twelve. In this manner the apostles, who were the rightful authorities according to the revelations of the Lord, were sustained by the vote of the people and by common consent, as the Lord had commanded that all things should be done. The matter of succession was' properly and rightfully decided, and was now binding on the members of the Church (Joseph Fielding Smith, Essentials in Church History, page Sidney Rigdon and William Marks were hurt by the action taken that day, and later found themselves outside the favor of the Church. Rigdon returned to Pittsburgh, Marks drifted away to Beaver Island in Lake Michigan where he joined the followers of James J. Strang. Both men were excommunicated. Brigham Young, having met the qualifications of leadership, was to go forward with the saints. Under the power of his office and endowed with wisdom from on high this great leader was to raise "up an ensign on the mountains" (Isa. 18:3) unto which all nations were to flow. Visiting Teachers' Messages sources of Strength?Charity Lesson 2?"Charity Suffereth Long and Is Kind" Dr. Lowell L. Bennion For Tuesday, November 6, 1945 Objective: To inspire patience and kindness in our human relations. THE most beautiful story of and is ?charity that suffereth long and is kind" to be found in all literature we believe, is Jesus' "Parable of the Prodigal Son."
Imagine the father's suffering when his younger son said to him (after he had worked and saved all his days for his children), "Father, give me the portion of goods that falleth to me." The father may well have guessed how his younger son would waste "his substance in riotous living." When the boy "came to himself" and started home, penitent, his father saw him "when he was yet a great way off." Seeing him, he had every right to rebuke him, to remind him of his folly and sins, to crush him in his shame, but instead he "had compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him." But let us not forget either that to his older son he said, "All that I have is thine." While the younger came back repentant, he did not share again.
Why was the father so long-suffering and kind? Because he was thinking not of his own wounded self but of the lad's life. The only thing that mattered now was that his son had come "to himself"? that "this my son was dead, and alive again; he was lost, and is found" (Luke 15:11-32). There is no more effective way to express charity than in kindness. Many people have no need of material help, which, anyway, is soon exhausted. Physical resources, too, are definitely limited. Yet there is no one who is not in need of kindness. And kindness, like all spiritual gifts, such as knowledge, love, and mercy, increases with giving.
Children need, above all things, kindness and love. Living in a world organized largely for the comfort, convenience, and advantage of grownups, they often live in fear of harsh words, scoldings, spankings, or indifference.
A friend told us of an ideal family where there were a large number of children, happy, cooperative, free from quarreling and wrangling. We asked her how she explained the success.
She replied, "I don't know, but their mother never raises her voice." This suggests strongly that the mother's charity includes patience and kindness.
Does kindness preclude discipline at home or in church work? Not at all! Discipline has the same root as disciple, which means learn, that is, to be a follower. The only effective discipline of a child's moral or spiritual nature is one which is preceded, followed, and surrounded with kindness. And kindness is born of charity and love.
Literature
The Bible in Our Literature
Lesson 2?How the Bible Is Woven into Our Literature
Dr. Howard R. Driggs
For Tuesday, November 25, 1945
SOME college students, taking a course in literature teaching, were stirred to active discussion one day by this statement from their instructor: "A good working knowledge of the Bible is absolutely essential to success in the teaching of our English and American literature."
"But we are not allowed to teach the Bible in the public schools," came a response.
"Not from any sectarian viewpoint," said the instructor. "It would be un-American to do so. Yet, how can our literature be adequately taught without constant reference to the Bible?"
"I am not sure just what you mean," said another student.
"Well, let us put some concreteness into the explanation. Most of you are teachers of literature. What are some selections you are called on to teach?"
"Evangeline," "Vision of Sir Launfal," "L'Envoi," "Snow-bound," came replies.
"They will serve our purpose," said the instructor. "Listen carefully now to some lines from the poems named:
And as she gazed from the window, she saw serenely the moon pass Forth from the folds of a cloud, and one star follow her footsteps, As out of Abraham's tent young Ishmael wandered with Hagar. ?"Evangeline," (Part III), Longfellow
Daily, with souls that cringe and plot, We Sinne climb and know it not. ?"Vision of Sir Launfal," Lowell
They shall find real saints to draw from? Magdalene, Peter, and Paul; They shall work at age at a sitting, and never get tired at? ?"L'Envoi," Kipling
"Take, eat," he said, "and be content, These fishes in my stead are sent By Him who sent the tangled ram, To spare the child of Abraham." ?"Snowbound," Whittier
"How can any of these, or hundreds of other lines containing like allusions, be explained without a knowledge of the Bible?"
"But aren't those examples somewhat old-fashioned?" asked a student.
"Your question seems to imply that modern authors are not weaving
the Bible into their creations. Well, here is a volume called Contemporary Verse. Perhaps it will help us to find an answer. Glancing through its table of contents I find a few titles that recall interesting hues: Poems are made by fools like me, But only God can make a tree. ?"Trees," Joyce Kilmer They gave their merry lives away For Country and for God. ?"Spires of Oxford," Winifred Betts And he who loves the least of these (And here I say and here repeat) Shall win himself an angel's pleas For mercy at my judgment seat. ?"The Outlaw," Robert Service Thank God for a world where none may shirk, Thank God for the splendor of work. ?"Work," Angela Morgan America! Americal God mend thine every flaw. Confirm thy soul in self control, Thy liberty in law. ?"America the Beautiful," Katharine Lee Bates Give them this for the morrow's meat, Then shall we feast in accord; Our half a loaf will then be sweet. Sweet as the bread of the Lord! ?"How Oswald Dined with God," Edwin Markham No one knows what will happen next, such portents fill the days and nights; Years prophetical! ?"Years of the Modern," Walt Whitman OK I go wherever men may dare, I go wherever woman's care And love can live? Wherever strength and skill can bring Surcease to human suffering Or solace give. ?"The Red Cross Spirit Speaks," John H. Finley Are not these lines from recent poetry all linked with the Bible? Joyce Kilmer's artistic tribute to God's surpassing power of creation; the touching lines of Winifred Betts to merry-hearted youth giving their all for country and for God; the use of precious words from the Savior by Robert Service; the gratitude expressed by Angela Morgan for God-given work?all clearly show that source of inspiration. In the prayer of Katherine Lee Bates for America?vital today and always ?that our liberty be preserved in Law, we feel the Bible spirit. It vibrates also in the lines of Edwin Markham, picturing a king sharing with the poor; and in Walt Whitman's words, so applicable to the living present. In John H. Finley's tribute to the Red Cross, one feels the helpful, courageous spirit of the Savior. In much of the literature of today the heart of the Good Samaritan vibrates. Such expression of gospel service is surely Bible-inspired. Of course, these illustrations from more modern poetry are somewhat different from those cited from earlier poets. Fashions change in literature as in other things; yet the constants are ever present. When the Bible came, it brought certain of these constants: reverence for God, charity, humility, service, sacrifice, a more democratic spirit, and other spiritual gifts for our salvation. It was like the pouring of a river, limpid and pure, into the old turbid stream of life. All our art expression since then has been clarified, enriched, inspirited by the divine contribution. LESSON DEPARTMENT 505 This is shown in both tangible and intangible changes wrought in our literature. As aleady illustrated, authors, particularly those of earlier years, made many more direct allusions to stories and characters of the Bible. It was the enriching thing to do. When Lowell, for example, says that daily "We Sinais climb and know it not," his line brings back the story of Moses going up into the mountain to commune with God. The poet also suggests that, without knowing it, we get close to God each day. To understand the inner meaning of this allusion, one must know the Bible story that lies back of it. Another tangible way the Bible is woven into lines of literature is by use of Biblical expressions-words, phrases, and even sentences. How deeply indebted our language is to this contribution may be more clearly realized by something of a comparison of literature today with that of pre-Bible days. Go back to the Northland myths for illustration. In these tales one finds a goodly number of words suggestive of brute strength, skill with weapons of trickery, cunning, deceit, of feasting, drinking, carousing, of giants, sorcery, mystery. Few, if any, words are found expressive of charity, meekness, kindliness, benevolence, tolerance, forgiveness, brotherhood, holidays (holy days). These, and like expressions of gospel import, came into our mother tongue largely through the Bible. Less tangible than words and allusions, yet even more vital, are the changes wrought through the influence of the Bible on the inner spirit of literature. It brought what may well be called a leavening effect on all forms of art. More hope, more joy, more faith, more whole-someness came to the varied kinds of expression. Naturally, literature was lightened and brightened and given added meaning and purpose by this spiritualizing force. With much of our great literature this infusion of new warmth and life and strength is to be felt rather than seen. Bible thought and themes are often so deftly woven into the creation by the author that, unless one is well-schooled in scripture, the close connection might be missed. Yet the stirring lessons of truth are there. It is the artistry of authorship not to preach them, but to portray them. In further studies, an interesting quest will be to find some of these Bible messages at the heart of time-tested literature. True it is that certain writers reveal precious little of Bible influence in what they produce. With cynical disregard of that source of inspiration, they have gone their own irreverent ways. Sometimes they create daring, cleverly-written literature, which, for the moment, wins wide attention. Then it as suddenly flickers out, as all such creations, if unsound and unwholesome, are almost sure to do. Folk may read, but few reread literature of that type. Our conviction is that authors do their finest, most lasting work when they are true to truth, when they produce that which is clean and artistic, when they help to overcome evil with good. There is no call here for "preach-iness" in literature; neither is there any exclusion of choice literature created for wholesome entertainment. Happily, we have many delightful creations which open our eyes and ears to the beauties of nature, to the joys of childhood, to home pleasures and uplifting friendships. Some of the selections help to cultivate in us a clean sense of humor, to get more pure enjoyment out of life. Outwardly or inwardly this literature may make no reference to the Bible; yet the spirit of goodness and wholesome fun is in it, and truly we need it to add a bit of leaven to our days. Something more than just this lightsome literature is also needed for our upbuilding. That is the literature which brings real re-creation. Such literature, as already portrayed, leaves us both mentally and spiritually uplifted. It brings to us lessons of truth and light. It leads us along paths of righteousness. It is Bible-inspired. (b) Make your meaning clearer by giving in brief the incident or meaning suggested by each of the following expressions: "like showers of manna"; "toiling up new Calvaries"; "our Lord's beatitudes"; "in Eden's delight"; "like the Patmos saint." 3. (a) Join with the class in making a list of twenty or more words other than those given in this lesson, which probably have come into our language through the Bible, (b) What in a spiritual sense is indicated by this enrichment of our vocabulary? 4. In what other vital way than by allusions and words has the Bible influenced our literature? Illustrate. 5. What type of literature may show no such Biblical influence and yet be of value in our lives? Give illustrations. 6. Science Modern Applications of Moral Principles Lesson 9?Problems of Personal Conduct Dr. Harold T. Christensen For Tuesday, November 27, 1945 Lesson link: We attempted last time to apply the moral principle of brotherhood to several specific social situations. It was shown how prejudice and animosity lead toward patterns of discrimination and persecution in the modern world. Religious intolerance was used as an example of the contemporary moral crisis in both Christianity and democracy. Lesson aim: To stress the importance of personal cleanliness, balanced conduct, and self-control to the good life. IT has been said earlier that the good life depends upon both personal and social factors; that the highest morality, which results in the greatest joy, comes from individual health and advancement plus love and service oriented toward others. Last month we looked at the brotherhood principle and examined a few of its perversions. This time we will turn attention to some of the moral problems of personal conduct.
Life is a process of continual adjustment to new situations, and where individuals lag or fail in their adjustment, personal and social problems result. Since the best adjustment means the most progress and the greatest happiness, anything short of the best possible adjustment is wrong. But adjustment is difficult, and there seems to be an all too-common human tendency to dodge that which is hard and remote in favor of the easy way leading to immediate thrills. Hence the prevalence of human suffering. When the energies of man become dissipated in the attempt to circumvent truth and escape consequences, opportunities are missed and misery ensues. It is to some of these dissipations leading to personal maladjustment and unhappiness that attention is now turned.
Drugs
The use of narcotics produces a temporary sense of pleasantness or well-being and permits the sufferer to forget for awhile his mental fears and conflicts. It is perhaps this element of escape from unpleasant reality that explains the rather wide
The proportion of the population addicted to the more serious drugs such as opium, heroin, morphine, and cocaine, is probably not very large; although occasionally we read of "dope rings" being uncovered and some authorities estimate that there are more than one million addicts in this country alone. Sometimes the habit is picked up innocently such as through the use of sleeping pills, pain-killers, or patent medicines. In using narcotic medicines, even under a doctor's prescription, great care should be exercised to use them moderately and only as absolutely needed. Once the habit is formed, the user's system has then become conditioned to the drug and he is a virtual slave to its use. Addiction to the use of drugs frequently results in poverty, ill-health, and crime, and the cure, if any be possible, requires rather long and expensive treatment at the hands of the psychiatrist.
A more serious problem than the taking of opiates and cocaine is the smoking of marijuana cigarettes?more serious because this drug is consumed largely by the young, because its results are particularly demoralizing, and because it may be even more widespread than the other practices. Under the influence of marijuana, restraint, moral judgment, and self-control are gone, and acts are frequently indulged in that head the boy and girl toward degradation. Marijuana comes from an innocent looking weed, and although many states by now have laws attempting its control, its suppression is proving particularly difficult. The taking of caffeine, nicotine, and other narcotic substances into the body through the use of certain drinks and through smoking is also habit forming and body harming. Our Church literature is replete with good material on these subjects. (See section 89 of the Doctrine and Covenants, and consult also some of the many articles and chapters on the Word of Wisdom found in the magazines and books of the Church.) Drink Just as drug addiction is an attempted escape from unpleasant reality and a crutch for unstable characters, so also is the use of alcoholic beverages. People who drink do so, for the most part, to forget the unpleasantries of life and to thereby capture the thrills of the moment. They fail to remember that no one can really escape life; he can only shut his eyes for awhile, stumble, and get behind in the race. The magnitude of the liquor problem is alarming. Some three or four billion dollars go into this industry in America each year, and, since alcohol is not a necessity, most of this is wasted money. But the greatest waste is human waste. Families are neglected and abused; lives are dissipated and shortened; accidents are increased, resulting in the death and maiming of many; morals are relaxed and crimes increased, particularly sex crimes; insanity very frequently overtakes the one so indulging. This human wreckage resulting from drink in the modern world, when all brought together, does not make a pretty picture. People who drink "to be a good sport" or because they think it is "smart" should remember that sportmanship without principle is a mirage, and that always the smart thing to do is the right thing. Those who drink to "forget" should remember that their euphoria is but illusionary and that in so behaving they only build up a vicious circle, for they only create more bad memories that they will want to forget. Gambling In one sense life is a gamble, for it is so filled with uncertainties and anomalies and it requires so much faith and courage to see it through. But there is a vast difference between this courage in the face of uncertainties in the struggle upward and the willful play on chance for the purpose of getting something for nothing; the one gives evidence of faith and results in effort and progress, while the other is based on selfishness and laziness alone. This "something for nothing" philosophy of life, coupled with the idea that "only the foolish work," makes of gambling an escape device designed to side-step morals for the sake of money. Large scale gambling involving cards, roulette wheels, and such, is illegal in most states; but illegal or not it finds ways of functioning under cover in many of the nation's "best" communities. Hidden from the police or "protected" by city officials, professional gamblers in especially prepared rooms encourage the gullible to participate in these nefarious activities; and through techniques well known to themselves, make sure that the "house" gets a heavy cut out of the winnings. LESSON DEPARTMENT 509 The spirit of gambling, once it has taken hold of a person, is like a narcotic or a liquor in its deadening and maddening effects. The thrill of an occasional win is enough to tide over several substantial losses and, in this way, keep the losing spiral going viciously downward until the participant's money is all gone. Always there is the thought, the desperate hope, that next time he can beat the game and then he will stop; but next time he loses once more, or, if he should win, there is the untempered greed that won't let him quit. Parents and community workers (and all parents should be vitally and actively interested in the welfare of the community) will do well to realize that the road to gambling frequently starts at the juvenile "joint" where there are marble games and slot machines to whet the appetite of the young. If these could be cleaned out or changed to eliminate the pay-off feature, as some of our communities have been farsighted enough to do, a great step in moral progress would be made. But this is not all. In addition, parents should teach their children that all things worth while cost effort, honestly and honorably given. Unchastity Sex life motivated by love and protected by marriage is sanctioned by society and blessed by deity. It is the misuse of sex that is immoral; practices impelled by selfish lust and irresponsible exploitation. That which is beautiful and sacred is too frequently cheapened and defiled by means of the vulgar remark, the smutty story, the erotic show, the lewd magazine, et cetera. Vulgarity is the profanity of virtue. When sexual irregularities are carried beyond the mental, the verbal, and the visual into the realm of overt conduct, the moral issue involved becomes particularly great. Unchastity, whether in premarital relations or extramarital relations after marriage, presents one of the most serious moral problems of the day. The following are some of the most important reasons for maintaining chastity: (1) It is a commandment of God. (2) It is sanctioned by society. The social stigma leveled by society against the offender often results in loss of both social position and employment, which is a high price to pay for a reckless moment. (3) It is necessary for mental health and peace of mind. The worries, fears, and guilt feelings connected with unchastity are sometimes enough to cause frustrations leading to chronic unhappiness, nervousness, and even psychosis. (4) It is important from the standpoint of physical health. The venereal diseases, resulting largely from sexual promiscuity, are among the most loathsome and miserable ailments of man. (5) It safeguards against premarital pregnancy followed by induced abortion, illegitimacy or forced marriage. (6) It is compatible with happy and successful marriage. In any number of ways unchastity may interfere with emotional and sexual adjustment in marriage. Statistical studies bear out the fact that those marriages are most successful where both partners have been chaste before the ceremony. To a Latter-day Saint there is no question of a double standard. Chastity is expected of the man and woman alike.
Excesses
Balance is a virtue that many, in their zeal to stress one certain point or principle fail to reach. Overemphasis on one thing usually means underemphasis on others, with the result that the total is misshapen. Things that are good in and of themselves are bad when overindulged in. Food, for example, is good, but overeating is a vice; fasting is a rich spiritual experience, but overfasting may lead to physical harm; athletics are good as exercise, but overtraining may burn the body out. It is possible to have too much of a good thing.
Because of this, it becomes ever so important that we learn to "see life steadily and as a whole." Distorted reality is, for all practical purposes, falsehood; and it leads to misdirected, abortive living.
In the field of personal conduct temperance is the keystone to virtue. The best way is the middle way. Life should be active, but in a balanced, harmonious way rather than impetuous or distorted. Steady is the word.
Anti-social Behavior
Every individual is an intrinsic part of society, and because of this it is impossible to make any clearcut distinction between public and private morals. All of these personal standards of which we have the lesson are harmful to society as well
as to the individuals who themselves indulge. Drinking, for example, may mean neglect of family, and unchastity may ruin two lives and bring sorrow to many others. Some people argue that, "What I do is my own business," but any thinking person can see that this is not true. We are our brother's keeper and our personal habits as well as our social acts affect profoundly those around us.
Anti-personal behavior then, is also anti-social behavior.
But some people go farther than this, and either thoughtlessly or willfully work against the best interests of the larger group. This is not the place to enter into any detailed analysis of crime and delinquency, but it is to be noted that the problem is extensive and that it is always greatest when personal disorganization is widespread, such as, for example, in time of war. Unless personal conduct can be made to be "right" in so far as the individual is concerned, and also right in the sense that it is directed toward the welfare of society, the standards of a higher morality will continue to be missed. It is the social slant in personal conduct that provides the highest moral test.
The Way Out
But regardless of how serious the problem may be, there is always a way out for those who are willing to plot the ground. There are too many today who, discouraged or blinded by the distance life has fallen, decide to lie there or even slip deeper rather than exert themselves for a better future. Life is
eternal, and progress is endless for those who climb; and every man can climb regardless of the point from which he must start. LESSON DEPARTMENT 511 The way out of the blind alleys in which many find themselves today is the way of repentance. Repentance is the key by which man can be unshackled from the follies of the past and the weaknesses of the present. More of us need to get the forward point of view. After a mistake has been made, as regrettable as it may be, it is then the future that is important. The past should be forgotten as rapidly as it can be atoned for. But repentance requires in addition to (i) remorse, both (2) restitution, and (3) reform; it is not enough to feel sorry, but the wrong done must be righted and the tendency to do wrong must be corrected. Man should learn to accept his mistakes as his own rather than projecting them upon society or the 'devil; and he should learn to repent, face the situation, throw away his crutches, and with his head up look and work for a better life. Problems for Thought and Action 1. Do you see any relationship between private and public morality? Explain. Show how the private behavior patterns discussed in this lesson affect others in society as well as the offender. 2. Analyze the major causes and effects of (a) drug addiction, (b) alcoholism, (c) gambling, and (d) unchastity. 3. Why is excess, or lack of balance, a moral problem? Discuss. Defend the "middle way" as a way of life. Does this justify the moderate use of tobacco, alcohol, et cetera? Why not? 4. What is meant by anti-social conduct? Are crime and delinquency immoral? Why? 5, What is the way out for the problem of personal conduct discussed in this lesson? Can you make any additional suggestions, being a little more specific, perhaps, than lesson space permitted here? What does repentance involve? Would you say that repentance is necessary to a moral life? Discuss pro and con.
