The Missionary Work of the Church-Its Contributions to the Church and Its Individual Members Elder Thomas C. Romney President Central States Mission How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him that bringeth good tidings, that publisheth peace; that bringeth good tidings of good, that publisheth salvation; that saith unto Zion, Thy God reigneth (Isaiah 52:7). And these are they who have published peace, who have brought good tidings of good, who have published salvation; and said unto Zion, Thy God reigneth 1 And O how beautiful upon the mountains were their feet! And again, how beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of those that are still publishing peace! And again, how beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of those who shall hereafter publish peace, yea, from this time henceforth and forever! (Mosiah 15:14-17). 
THUS sang Isaiah, the great Jewish prophet, more than seven hundred years before the birth of the Savior, and an American prophet several centuries later took up the refrain. Indeed it has been a theme of the prophets down through the centuries.
The Master of the world both by example and precept confirmed, in a superlative way, the truth of this message, and is appropriately referred to as the Prince of Peace. At the beginning of his ministry, he called to his aid twelve men, designated apostles, to declare the gospel of the kingdom to the world, first to the Jews and then to the Gentiles. All but a handful of the Jews rejected their Lord and his message of peace and "nailed him to a tree." It seemed that Christianity was doomed to perish from the earth. But out of Tarsus of Cilicia was to come forth a man of the tribe of Benjamin who was destined to go down in history as one of the greatest missionaries of all times. This character was of such potential worth to the cause of Christianity that the risen Redeemer paid him a visit following the Lord's resurrection and rebuked him saying, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?" And he said, "Who art thou, Lord?" "I am Jesus whom thou persecutest. ... Arise, and go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou must do." Saul was obedient to the heavenly command and Ananias baptized him into the kingdom following a visitation of the Master, who said: "For he (Saul) is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles and kings and the children of Israel." How well Saul, now Paul, fulfilled this commission is a well-known story to the student of the

New Testament. Practically the whole of the Mediterranean area was covered by him, and many converts were added to the Church. However, gross darkness ultimately covered the earth and the voice of prophecy was heard no more over the centuries. But at the beginning of the nineteenth century, the heavens were again opened. By divine command, the Church of Jesus Christ was restored to earth through Joseph the Prophet. Soon thereafter, the same voice, which nearly two thousand years before had called the lowly Galilean fishermen from their nets to become fishers of men, was heard again, saying: Behold I send you out to reprove the world of all their unrighteous deeds, and to teach them of a judgment which is to come. And whoso receiveth you, there I will be also, for I will go before your face. I will be on your right hand and on your left, and my Spirit shall be in your hearts, and mine angels round about you, to bear you up.... Wo, I say again, unto that house, or that village or city that rejecteth you, or your words, or your testimony of me; For I, the Almighty, have laid my hands upon the nations, to scourge them for their wickedness. And plagues shall go forth, and they shall not be taken from the earth until I have completed my work which shall be cut short in righteousness (Doc. And Gov. Sec. 84:87 et seq.). THE first great missionary movement in this dispensation was inaugurated in the fall of 1830 when the Church was only six months old. A company of four elders, headed by Oliver Cowdery and Parley P. Pratt, was appointed by the Lord to bear the gospel to the Indians at and surrounding Independence, Missouri, on the frontiers of Western America. Their labors met with but little success among the Lamanites, but a rich harvest of souls was garnered by these men at Hyrum in the vicinity of Kirtland, Ohio, resulting in a migration of the Church from Fayette, New York, to Kirtland, which now became its headquarters. A little later the gospel was taken to Canada by Parley P. Pratt, where he found awaiting him a noble band of God-fearing truth seekers under the leadership of John Taylor, later to become a president of the Church. From here the gospel was finally to cross the broad Atlantic to the British Isles. The missionary work of the elders in the British Isles, under the able leadership of Heber C. Kimball, was phenomenal. Thousands, in the course of a few months, became identified with the Church, many of whom migrated to Zion. The opening of the British Mission occurred in the fateful year of 1837, a year fraught with great peril for the Latter-day Saints. A financial crisis, nation wide, left its impress upon the membership of the Church. The "Kirtland Safety Society" sponsored by the Prophet and other leading brethren of the Church failed as a result, largely, of poor management. The cashier of the institution, a one-time faithful elder, was found guilty of immoral conduct and of misappropriating the funds of the society to the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars, thus placing the institution in a precarious condition. The Prophet gave warning of the impending disaster, but without avail. He therefore resigned his position as president, and withdrew from the concern with the remark, that "no institution of the kind, established upon just and righteous principles for a blessing not only to the Church, but to the whole nation, would be suffered to continue its operations in such an age of darkness, speculation and wickedness." MISSIONARY WORK OF THE CHURCH 517 Added to this financial disaster was the terrible treatment given our people in the State of Missouri by their enemies. They had been driven from their homes in Jackson County, and for a brief period had found respite in the northern and eastern counties. In the year 1837, the hydra-headed monster of vilification and persecution had begun to raise its head. As a result of the financial difficulties and bitter persecution, a dreadful wave of apostasy swept through the Church, carrying to their spiritual deaths, many of the leading officials of the Church, including several of the Twelve Apostles. The awful state of affairs led the Prophet to remark that it seemed *'as though all the powers of earth and hell were combining their influence in an especial manner to overthrow the Church at once, and make a final end." In this hour of deep sorrow and anguish, the Prophet appealed to the Almighty for wisdom and guidance, and in response came the voice of the Lord declaring that something new must be done for the salvation of the Church. Accordingly, on the 4th day of June, 1837, Elder Heber C. Kimball was called by the Prophet, while in the Kirtland Temple, "to preside over a mission to England, to be the first foreign mission of the Church of Christ in the last days" (D. H. C., Vol. II, page 489). In like manner, as the missionary labors of Paul and his associates saved the Church in ancient times from dissolution for a brief span, so did the preaching of the gospel in foreign lands by Heber C. Kimball and his companions save the Church in these latter days. The distinguishing difference between these two events was the fact that the Church of Christ in the meridian of time was not destined to survive the ultimate ravages of apostasy, while assurance has been given by the Almighty that the Restored Church shall stand forever amidst the wreck of nations and the crash of worlds. Not only has missionary work been the saving power, but also the enricher of the Church. I refer not to things of a material character, but to contributions on a spiritual and intellectual plane, as represented in language, literature, philosophy, and art. Every year over a period of several decades the Church has been represented by an average of two thousand young men and women, who have traveled as missionaries in most of the countries of the world. The return of these young people to the body of the Church has meant the infiltration of new ideas and new methods of doing things, thus rendering our culture the most cosmopolitan to be found in the world. Not only has enrichment come to the Church as a whole, but the development to be noticed in the missionary upon his return home is little short of phenomenal. He went into the world an inexperienced youth from the farm, the workshop, or the class room; he returns a well-rounded individual prepared through his experiences to meet almost any exigency that may arise in his journey of life. These young people have been called home to wear the colors of their country for the duration of the war, thus leaving the responsibility of preaching (at the Church upon the shoulders of a few of the older brethren and sisters and a very limited number of our young women, together with local brethren and sisters who are called to do part-time service.
But in spite of these restrictions, I am bold to declare that never before in the history of Mormondom has the leaven of Mormonism been more widely diffused than at the present time. The Church has nearly ten per cent of its membership in the service of the country. The vast majority of these young people, both by example and precept, are pleased to bear witness of the restored gospel to the great numbers whom they meet daily. Some of the strongest branches that we have in the Central States Mission are largely officered by servicemen and women, and the predominance in membership is composed largely of that class. Our branch at Ft. Sill, Oklahoma, is a splendid example of this. I think no finer, energetic
group of worshipers can be found anywhere in the Church than these army men and their wives. And what can be said of Ft. Sill can truthfully be said of many such branches throughout the world.
The spirit of these servicemen was beautifully expressed by a young man in an address before our Topeka conference recently. Following are his words as nearly as I can remember them:
My government has spent a great deal on me to make me a good soldier. It has supplied me with everything that modern ingenuity can devise for my comfort, with arms and ammunition, together with their proper use, as well as with other equipment, including the finest and most perfect protection that I shall carry with me when I go overseas to engage in combat for the Priesthood of the Son of God which I prize above all else. Upon it I shall rely, and I pray that I shall exercise it in righteousness before the Lord.
Some of our number have expressed themselves as feeling that we are in the process of gleaning human souls, but I am convinced that following this war, with the gospel seeds that are now being sown by our young men and women, we shall reap the greatest harvest in the whole history of the Church. God grant that this may be so. NEW TESTAMENT Dott J. Sartori Here, within this black morocco cover. Abide His word and sacred ministry, Among these printed symbols angels hover, And here is light to set the prisoned free.

entries.title: The Constitution of the United States

loose_match.content: the Constitution of the United States, granting suffrage to women, was introduced in both the House and the Senate of the United States, April 17, 1913. It was christened the Susan B. Anthony Amendment.Six more years elapsed before Congress passed the Amendment. On May 21, 1919, it passed the House of Representatives and on June 4, 1919, it passed the Senate. Before it could become effective, however, it was necessary that it be ratified by the legislatures of three-fourths of the states. On August 18, the final state to ratify, Tennessee, gave woman suffrage the constitutional majority it needed and victory was won. The amendment which stands now as the law of the land reads as follows: Section 1. The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex. Section 2. Congress shall have power by appropriate legislation to enforce the provisions of this article. Susan B. Anthony was a faithful and loyal friend to the women of Utah. She kept in touch with them all during her period of leadership, and they worked closely with her in the cause dearest to her heart. She visited Utah on a number of occasions, and from the year 1879 Utah sent delegates regularly to the meetings of the National Suffrage Association, where they took active part in the deliberations. She rejoiced with them when they had the vote from 1870 to 1886; and because of their experience and knowledge and their training in organization work, she solicited their interest and help in her national program. She sympathized with them when they were disfranchised by the Congress of the United States in 1886, and stood by them as a true, faithful friend. She rejoiced again with them when Utah became a state, in April 1895, "4 44 State constitution included a clause giving them full suffrage. She immediately wrote Mrs. Emily S. Richards of Salt Lake City, Chief Organizer for Utah and a member of the National Executive Committee, as follows: Well I am glad you are all awake to the cause out there in Utah. You have the power in your own hands, and if you do not move on to better things political, it will not be the fault of the men alone, you women will be equally responsible with them. You cannot therefore afford to be idle or indifferent to the political action of your city and state. With love to all and yourself the most, Susan B. Anthony. One month later, May 12, Miss Anthony and Dr. Anna Howard Shaw, who were touring the West, visited Utah where they were enthusiastically received. A suffrage conference for two days was held, followed by a reception given in their honor by Mr. And Mrs. F. S. Richards at their beautiful home. Hundreds of people attended, including State officials and military officers from Fort Douglas. Governor Caleb W. West and his staff in full regalia stood in the receiving line with the host and hostess and honored guests. The sincere love of the women of Utah and of the Relief Society for Susan B. Anthony was demonstrated at the time of her death, early in March 1906, when a memorial service was held for her in the Salt Lake City Assembly Hall on Relief Society anniversary day, March 17. To Mothers, Wives, and Sweethearts President Reuben Clark, Jr. Excerpts from an address "

Postwar Planning" delivered at the Friday afternoon session of the 115th annual general conference, April 6, 1945, in the Assembly Hall. I WOULD like to say a word about the returning soldier, that being a question about which we all talk and hear so much. I said something about postwar planning at the last conference and pointed out that we could and should plan to bring our soldiers back to homes of purity, chastity, and of righteousness, and that it took no worldly position, no wealth, to carry on that postwar planning. I want to add just a word along that line today... To bridge over the time when they [soldiers] return as heroes for achievements in war, until they may resume their peace-time occupations and become heroes in peace and in peaceful occupations, to bridge that over is one of the tasks we shall have to undertake and to which we must give our best effort and best thought. I am not thinking of the temporal side of the bridge-over, I am thinking of the spiritual side, and what that means; and in that connection it seems to me that they who are to play the greater part are the mothers, the wives, and the sweethearts of those who return. When all is said and done it will be our sisters who must take on that great load and that tremendous responsibility. Radio programs, magazines, and newspaper columns are more and more filling with instructions about how to treat our returning soldiers. All the deductions of modem psychology, and its kindred mental sciences are paraded for the guidance of the wives, the mothers, the sweethearts, in meeting, winning, and holding the boy back from the war. But I would not exchange the unerring inspired instinct of a good woman, fired with mother love, or wife love, or the love of a loyal, chaste sweetheart, for all that men have ever written. The boys say they do not wish to be regarded as problem children. They want to get home and enter again the family circle, and in its sacred precincts again to take up life and forget hate, carnage, and death. I believe their cry will be, "Let us live again in love"; and you mothers, wives, and sweethearts can bring to them this blessing. None other can. So in this crisis we turn to the women of the earth to save them and to save us men from ourselves. So it has been, in reality, in every great world crisis, however much it may have seemed otherwise. Yours, you sisters, has been the loyalty that has never wanted; your courage has not failed, has not been daunted, whatever the odds. You have often recognized a lost cause long before your men folks; you frequently have seen victory long before it came within the vision of those who battled. Your joy and tenderness and fortitude have succored the wounded and eased the passing of those who are called beyond. You never fail in kindness and mercy; your love endures forever. May God bless you, for you are angels of mercy. So, you mothers, wives, sweethearts, take into the sacred precincts of your heart around the altars of your homes these souls wounded in body, in mind, in spirit, and heal them as you alone. Page 523

Settling Raymond, Alberta, Canada Jennie B. Knight Former Member Relief Society General Board RAYMOND is situated in Southern Alberta, Canada. It was founded by Jesse Knight of Utah, and named after his oldest son. It was built by pioneers who had faith in its future, and it took real pioneers with courage, thrift, good judgment, and faith to cope with problems that confronted the early settlers of that region. That they were victorious and are still a prudent, progressive, and religious people is shown in their beautiful modern homes and schools, churches and public buildings, their farms and ranches, factories, mills and elevators that today dot the land as far as the eyes can see. The name of Jesse Knight is so interwoven in the history of this commonwealth and the surrounding territory that it is fitting to relate how he came to be its founder. He was a man who had implicit confidence in the leaders of his Church. At the ushering in of the twentieth century, President Lorenzo Snow sent his New Year's greeting to the world. This message greatly impressed Brother Knight who at that time was receiving great wealth from his metal mines in Utah. In this message, he read: Men and women of wealth, use your riches to give employment to the laborer! Take the idle from the crowded centers of population and place them on the un-tilled areas that await the hand of industry. Page 524 Unlock your vaults, unloose your purses and embark in enterprises that will give work to the unemployed and relieve the wretchedness that leads to vice and crime around you. Make others happy and you will be happy yourselves. Many propositions had been made to Brother Knight to invest his money, but none appealed to him until he heard about Canada. However, Apostle John W. Taylor and Charles McCarthy of Alberta came to see him and told him of the fertile lands in Southern Alberta and urged him to buy some of the thousands of acres. The project impressed him. He could see the possibility of using his money to magnify his "stewardship,*' for it was only as a steward, he believed, that wealth came to him. In the spring of 1900, he sent his two sons, Oscar Raymond and Jesse William, to Canada to investigate the situation, the result being that they purchased 30,000 acres of land and set to work to stock it. Later, their father met them in Canada. The weather was ideal, the country beautiful and green. It looked like a real paradise to Jesse Knight. He was there only a few days before he had a clear idea of what he wanted to do. He would build a sugar factory that would give employment to Latter-day Saints and others who would come where they might secure land on easy terms and make homes for their children and themselves. On July 10, 1901, he purchased 226,000 acres of prairie land from the Canadian Northwest Irrigation Company and the Alberta Railroad and Irrigation Company through their agent, Hon. C. A. Magrath. SETTLING RAYMOND, ALBERTA, CANADA 525; THRESHING SCENE IN RAYMOND, CANADA, ON THE HEREFORD RANCH Yield, sixty bushels to the acre He signed a contract to build a sugar factory, and have it ready to handle the beet crop in 1903 and to keep it in operation for twelve years. This contract was guaranteed with a pledge of $50,000. Who but a man of faith could have made such an agreement in so short a time with nothing but a vast, grass-covered prairie surrounding this location? RAYMOND townsite was selected soon after the contract was signed, and on a bright Sunday afternoon, at the request of Presi-ident C. O. Card, friends from neighboring towns and ranches met to dedicate this townsite. There was not a tree, or even a tent to be seen as they stood on the buffalo-trodden soil to participate in the exercises. In the town charter, which was read. Brother Knight had insisted that it contain a forfeiture clause to the effect that if liquor, or gambling houses, or places of ill fame were established on the premises, the property holders would forfeit title to the land. The dedicatory prayer was offered by Apostle John W. Taylor. Songs of praise and thanksgiving filled the air and a feeling of welcome and good will was felt by all. The town of Raymond grew rapidly,, for in less than two years there were over fifteen hundred settled there. Most of them were young, including many college graduates. Buildings sprang up with mushroom rapidity, the blacksmith shop of Ephraim Hicks being the first to break the horizon. Many of the early homes were of the ?lean-to" type, just one room with a slanting roof to which other rooms were added later. A church with a heating plant was built by Jesse Knight. This and the school house were the first public buildings erected. Charles McCarthy and T. O. And Louis King were the first to build mercantile stores. B. F. Rolf son was a carpenter and his house was the first to be finished. HANNAH GIBBS, who planted the first tree, arrived on September 3, 1901, with her nine children. George Munn, William Lamb, and families came September 2d. They experienced real difficulty in pitching their tents, as there was a bleak blizzard when they emerged from the mixed freight and passenger train. A number of families lived in tents during the first winter. Water for culinary purposes was hauled in barrels from the canal until Ray Knight had it piped into the center of town, and from there it was still hauled to the homes in barrels on sleds. In winter, the water was always frozen in the barrels, and if one wished a drink he had to chop the ice and melt it. Hannah Gibbs became the community nurse and doctor. She had her first experience as midwife March 16, 1902, when the first boy, Raymond Holbrook, was born. This nurse, taught by experience and faith, brought numerous babies into the world. She nursed each mother and babe for ten days for which service she received five dollars. She never lost a case. Even after Dr. Rivers settled in Raymond she was still called in on many occasions. Jessie Nilsson, a girl, was the first child born in Raymond. In the spring of 1902, people came very fast by rail, or overland with teams and wagons, driving their cattle. This spring was very cold and stormy. During one of these bad storms forty-seven new settlers arrived. It was necessary to house them in the church for ten days while other shelters were being provided. Under the direction of the bishop and Relief Society, with the help of neighbors and friends, they enjoyed cooked meals. KNIGHT SUGAR FACTORY, RAYMOND, CANADA Building completed in 1903, and sugar was manufactured that same year SETTLING RAYMOND, ALBERTA, CANADA 527 THE RAYMOND RELIEF SOCIETY was organized in the lean-to in the back of this building, the home of Emma }. Bevan, February 1902. THE ward was organized on October 10, 1901, with Jesse W. Knight as bishop, and Joseph Bevan and Ephraim Hicks as counselors. Brother McCarthy notified the Bishop of this appointment while he and Mrs. Knight were "riding the range" on the "K-2" ranch, where they were then living. They moved to Raymond and built a home where young couples were married and many royal guests entertained, among them being President Joseph F. Smith and wife, President Francis M. Lyman, Dr. George H. Brimhall, L. H. Hol-brook, and their wives, some of the apostles and their wives, and other Church and government officials, as well as dear friends and associates. The first couple married by Bishop Knight was Katie Pitt and William Jensen of Salt Lake City. They were at the dedication of the townsite. All of the auxiliary organizations were fortunate in having efficient officers from the beginning. The Relief Society commenced its work early in 1902 under the direction of its president Emma J. Bevan, at whose home it was organized. With Counselors Mary J. Selman and Annie Gibbs, with teachers and members, this thrifty organization did a wonderful work, throughout the years it carried on the traditions of charity, love, and preparedness for which it was organized. The Relief Society erected a granary on its own city lot, which was filled with wheat. Later it owned a quarter section of land on which wheat was raised for the benefit of the Society. HOME OF JESSE WILLIAM KNIGHT First bishop of Raymond The year 1903 marked the completion of the sugar factory, the major activity in all that section of the country at that time. Words fail to express what a Herculean task it was to build and operate a sugar factory in so short a time. The land which was covered with tall grass and "a million mosquitoes to every blade" had to be prepared to raise beets for the factory. Men and boys who were not building were ploughing and cultivating the land. Warren Depew, a veteran plowman, reports that 3,000 acres were ready on scheduled time. It took the combined efforts of men. Women, and children, augmented by Indians, Chinese, and itinerant laborers to plant, thin, top, and harvest the beets, as well as 150 to 300 men to build and operate the factory. This enterprise was fortunate in the intelligent personnel of the men who supervised the work. Foremost among them was Ephraim P. Ellison, a man of acute understanding and executive ability-. His posterity-are still builders in the Alberta country. Brother J. William Evans, who remained loyal to Raymond to the end. Was the first supervisor of the beet fields and later held important positions in the factory. Along with all the work the women had to do, it fell to their lot to foster the social functions, as related before. The very first Christmas party was given in the meeting house. Sister Elizabeth King, who is still stake president of YW'MIA, and Sister Lamb decorated the building and the tree, and the appropriate program and dance of that date set a pace worthy to be followed. The pioneers who still remain are unanimous in the opinion expressed by Dr. George H. Brimhall, whose sons and daughters were among the first settlers, that: God from on high lights up the way For man to go that's best, He pro\ides the opportunity, But man must do the rest. FIRST WARD MEETING HOUSE AND TAYLOR STAKE HOUSE, 1941

entries.title: Stay As Sweet As You Are
entries.author: Ada B. Monson

loose_match.content:
Stay as Sweet as You Are Ada B. Monson JIMMY was leading the way to the far side of the big waiting room. You shouldn't have come, Mother,? he said. ?Train stations are tough assignments for mothers these days." Mrs. Leeder started to speak. Jimmy interrupted, "Don't say it, Mother, I will?"the tougher the job, the harder you tackle." They both laughed and sat down on a long bench. Jimmy put. His suitcase between them on the seat. They both rested their arms on it and Jimmy put his hand over his mother's. "Seriously, Mother, Fm very grateful for all the sweet philosophy you've dished up for me. I'm gonna need it, but sure." Mrs. Leeder tried to smile, but her chin went wobbly. Then to herself?I musn't cry, I musn't cry. I must talk, that's it, I must talk every minute to keep from crying. Boys in khaki and blue were dashing hatless and coatless in and out of the station between trains. "They keep that girl at the newsstand really busy, and look, Jimmy, there are Fred and his mother coming in now, see, at the middle door?" Mrs. Leeder stood up to wave at them. Jimmy put out a restraining hand. "Let's stay here. Mother," he said. Mrs. Leeder sat down, "Why sure?all right," she said. "You'll get to see them out at the train," Jimmy said. He's afraid I'll break down in front of them all, she thought, but she said, "I hope you two boys can stick together through this like you did through growing up." "Can't though. Fred'll go in the air corps," Jimmy said. "Oh, I didn't know. Poor Ruth. She won't have anyone at home, now." "You be sure and call her up, sometimes." "Oh, I will. Son?every day," Mrs. Leeder said. Jimmy smiled. "She'll be calling you up, too." Mrs. Leeder smiled back and a lump came in her throat again. Talk fast, talk fast. "Fred's mother is a beautiful woman, isn't she?" "Yeah," Jimmy said, "clothes do an awful lot." Mrs. Leeder put her feet further under the seat and straightened up a bit. "I guess I could have worn my hat," she said, smoothing her hair with a workworn hand. "I've got those gloves you gave me for Christmas, too." Never before had she been so aware of her shabbiness, her lack of style. "You sure you don't want to see Ruth, Son?" she asked. Jimmy shook his head. "We said goodbye last night." He changed the subject quickly. "Wonder how I'll look in G. I. Cloth?" Page  "You'll look beautiful. Just beautiful? Mrs. Leeder said. They both laughed a little. Then, noticing the sudden activity, they both glanced at the clock. ?It's time, Mother," he said. She put out a hand, then quickly drew it back. Already he was standing, his suitcase in his hand. "No, Mother?don't get up?and don't come out to the train. I'd like it best this way." With one fleeting look at her he dashed through the door that led to the trains. Mrs. Leeder's glance followed him until he was lost in the crowd. She sat still on the long bench. It was funny how all alone she felt with so many people around her. At the other end of the room she could see Mrs. Chambers sobbing in Fred's arms. Fred was using his handkerchief on his own eyes, then they went out to the train. After a while, Mrs. Leeder stood up and went out the entrance toward home. Well, anyway, she hadn't cried. She had promised herself she wouldn't cry. But now she could let down if she wanted to. Funny she didn't, seem to be able to shed tears. It had all turned out so differently from the way she had expected. She was sure Jimmy had acted unnatural. He had kept that old suitcase between them so she couldn't take his hand or get close to him. And he didn't kiss her goodbye, or even take her in his arms. A December snow was falling. She buttoned her coat more closely around her. A plate-glass door panel caught her reflection. She paused, then started on?came back and stood still, shoving her hands deep into her coat pockets and straightening her shoulders. Then, after a minute, she hurried on. The picture she had seen wasn't exactly pleasing. Certainly not anything like Mrs. Chambers. Jimmy had said, "Clothes can do an awful lot." Jimmy hadn't wanted to join his friends. Could it be that he was? she wouldn't say it. Jimmy wasn't like that. And yet?something had been wrong. Suddenly she felt hollow inside, an emptiness which she couldn't shake off. That was it? of course it was. She had been so busy making a living for the two of them and getting Jimmy through school for the last five years she just hadn't taken time out to keep herself up. She hadn't been in a beauty shop for?well she couldn't remember. Oh dear! She had let Jimmy down, not purposely, but down, just the same. The wind blew little wisps of hair around her face, and suddenly it seemed colder. She buried her chin and nose down beneath her storm collar and hurried homeward. That's what she needed?home-home and a good cry.  IT was October and Mrs. Leeder entered the depot and walked over to the train schedule. Number Twenty-Six was due at nine o'clock. It was eight now. She stopped a redcap. "Can you tell me when Number Twenty-Six comes in from San Francisco?" she asked. "Nine o'clock, Mam," he said. She thanked him and walked to the far end of the waiting room. She placed one foot slightly back of the other one and sat down gracefully. Martin leaned back, she thought, always keep the back perfectly straight, shoulders relaxed. One of the beauty lessons had said, "Always choose chairs with a firm seat, or the knees might collide with the chin." Well, this seat was firm enough, and it was on this same seat that a mother had said goodbye to her son last December. And now, after almost a year, she was here to meet him, with one hour to wait.
Yes, she had been the mother, but a very different one. That mother wore a coat that slapped her legs too far below the knees; had straight hair pinned in a tight knot at the back of her neck, and broken nails; she had also had the analgesic not to wear a hat or gloves.
She recalled words from lesson twenty-seven: "Street clothes should be chosen with utmost care. Suits are best, and careful attention must be paid to accessories."
A little smile played about her lips as she slowly and nonchalantly tugged at the glove on her left hand. She removed only one. She wanted to admire again her long lacquered nails. Leisurely she worked the fingers back into the soft kid. Underneath her tailored suit her heart was racing. She glanced at the clock. Forty-five more minutes to wait for Jimmy. Would he like her? He'd be surprised, she knew. Maybe he wouldn't know her with her? He'd be surprised, she knew. hat with bright feathers right smack on the top. She was all of an inch taller in these new shoes, too.
Pretty minutes to go!
She just couldn't sit there that long, she'd have to move about. The place hadn't changed much in a year?the same clanging of trains and the same calling of trains, except that now the voice came from a loudspeaker overhead. Everywhere, boys in khaki and blue rushed in to buy magazines, candy, and postcards, then dashed out to get on their trains.
Mrs. Leeder found herself moving with them out to the platform. Soon a long train slowed to a stop. She noticed a neatly dressed woman in a fur coat and red-feathered hat glancing anxiously up and down; white dozens of men in uniform spilled out of the cars. A smooth-faced sailor with a cane and a slight limp detached himself from the crowd and hurried toward the woman. "Mother!" he exclaimed, "I hardly knew you." He clasped her in his arms.
"Boy?your coat. Mother, can you still afford mink with a war going on?" He laughed and patted her arm. "But I love you anyway. Mother. Gosh, is this black hair a wig, or does it wash out? I liked your hair with gray in it. But of course you are glamorous." He squeezed her again and guided her laughingly through the crowd. Mrs. Leeder watched them disappear.
Finally she came to the end of the platform and automatically turned and started walking back. She thought she knew what the boy had meant when he had referred to his mother's mink coat. He had tried to laugh it off but he hadn't liked her hair, either. It was awfully black for such a wrinkled face. Mrs. Leeder guessed the boys liked to find things the same when they came back from the war. And now she was glad she hadn't rearranged the furniture or moved the rose garden. And jolly well glad she was that she didn't have a new fur coat to plague her. Yes, she felt cozy in the thought that Jim would find everything about the same. The same? She ran her gloved hand up the back of her neck. Those loose locks on an up-sweep were so annoying! Up-sweep! And her hat was a monstrosity, so her boss had said. But then, men didn't know anything about women's hats. But it was more than that. Her nails were so long she'd given up playing the piano months ago. Mrs. Leeders' heart did a drop act. She ran inside and looked at the clock. Eighteen minutes to go. Like one pursued, she ran to the ladies' lounge. Behind a screen she found a dressing table and a chair. Frantically she tore off her hat,"" pulled out combs from her hair. A big black face appeared around the screen. "Ah's Mandy," it said. "You all seemed in such a powah-ful hurry. Cain I do somp'in foah you all?" Mrs. Leeder's heart came back into place for the first time in minutes. "Oh, Mandy," she exclaimed, "Never again will I doubt that prayers are answered. If you can lengthen this skirt two inches in ten minutes, you can name your price. Just baste it in, of course." Mrs. Leeder was already slipping it off. "Ah'11 be right back, quick as scat," Mandy said, and left with the skirt over her arm. Mrs. Leeder studied herself for a second in the mirror. She hurriedly wiped off the heavy print of lipstick, leaving just enough, then turned her attention to her hair. She ran her comb through it several times, until it fell glistening to her shoulders. Then deftly she pushed the soft waves loosely around her face and wound the length into a low bob on her neck. Then, with a nail file she set to work on her nails. Surely, swiftly, in no time at all, she had filed away the sharp claws, rounding the ends and smoothing them off. "Heah's you' skirt. Ma'am, and right on de dot a ten minutes," Mandy said, holding the skirt toward her. "Oh, thanks. Thanks, Mandy," Mrs. Leeder said, "help me pull it on, will you? It can't go on over my head, or my hair will be mussed. There. I'll fasten it. Run, see the time, please," slipping her a quarter. Mrs. Leeder finished dressing and hurried out to the platform, and stood among others who were waiting. From far away came the long, lonesome whistle of Number Twenty-Six. Everyone suddenly stood at attention, looking down the long track to where it curved out of sight. Mrs. Leeder thought, it won't be long now. Her stomach did a flip-flop. Again the whistle gave vent to two longs, one short, and a long, and soon the train came in, its engine puffing and panting. Mrs. Leeder's feet seemed glued to the platform. How could anyone see all the cars at once? She decided to stand in one place, near the main entrance. Then, if she didn't see Jimmy, he would see her after the crowd had thinned out.
But after a little while when the crowd had thinned out, and still no Jimmy, Mrs. Leeder grew anxious. Could it be that Jimmy had missed his train? There was another one due from the Coast in about nine minutes. But the telegram had said he would be on Number Twenty-Six.
There were two soldiers standing a little way down the platform. Maybe they could tell her something, she thought, as she started over to where they stood. One was bareheaded, and wearing dark glasses.
They were looking at her now and walking toward her.
"Why?that boy's hair is like Jimmy's!" she thought, but he didn't look like?yes, he did. It was the dark glasses that had puzzled her. It was funny!?Oh, Jimmy?Jimmy couldn't see. Her fast strides broke into a run, and then her arms were about him, holding him tight, tight.
She wanted to say so many things. She wanted to tell him it didn't matter. But not a sound would come for years. She just could only press them tight together and pray for it it had been important that she keep from crying when he went away, it was doubly so now.
She felt his fingers exploring her face, then her hair, and the loose softness must have confused him?then crinkly the eager fingers sought and found the low bob at the back of her neck. A smile relieved the sternness of his mouth. "It's all right, Lieutenant," he said, turning to the soldier. "This is my mother. Thanks for standing by me." He held out his hand and the Lieutenant shook it warmly, lifted his cap to Mrs. Leeder, then hastily left them.
Guiding Jimmy carefully through the station, she called a cab and they got in.
"That was Lieutenant Conrey. He's swell. On the train I told him about you. I said, 'You'll know my mother. She maybe won't be wearing a hat or gloves, and she combs her hair awful plain and wears it in a little knot on the back of her head.' Gosh, Mother, he knew you right off?"
Mrs. Leeder leaned over and laid her cheek against his.
"Oh, Jimmy," she said.

entries.title: Regular Weekly Relief Society Meetings Begin
entries.author: Belle S. Spafford

loose_match.content:
Regular Weekly Relief Society Meetings Begin for 1945-46 Season 
THE month of October marks the beginning of regular weekly Relief Society meetings for the 1945-46 season. Beginnings are always interesting. They represent a space or period of time at which action is taken in the fulfillment of dreams or in the realization of plans, many of which have been long in the making. Beginnings are accompanied by all sorts of reactions on the part of persons identified with them. Some approach them with enthusiasm, full of faith in that which has been initiated, and determined that the outcome will be successful and glorious. Others are skeptical, approaching them with doubt and criticism, seeing errors in judgment, weakness in plans, and insurmountable obstacles in the way of fulfillment. Still others are passive or indifferent toward beginnings, taking them much for granted and little concerned with their own responsibility toward that which has been started.
One cannot always judge the outcome of a beginning by its auspiciousness. Often beginnings which to all but a few seem of little import are proved by time to be of greatest moment, defining objectives, introducing activities, setting patterns that touch the lives of tens of thousands and that exert a profound influence in the forward march of society. Such was the case 103 years ago when eighteen Latter-day Saint women were organized by the Prophet Joseph Smith "under the Priesthood and after the pattern of the Priesthood" to "look to the wants of the poor, search after objects of charity, and administer to their wants, ... to assist by correcting the morals and strengthening the virtues of the community." These sisters were early taught the proper relationship to their husbands, and their position in the home was an integral part of gospel teachings.
Women, young and mature, were quickly drawn toward the new institution. Forty-four new members came into the Society at the second meeting. Something had been initiated that appealed to all.
Today, 102,000 women are awaiting the beginning of the regular weekly meetings for the 1945-46 season. The objective as set forth by the Prophet will be adhered to carefully, adapted to present-day conditions and in line with present-day Church procedures.
Welfare work will receive a great deal of our time, with full support being given to the Church Welfare Plan. Concern for neighbors will be emphasized. Page 536 EDITORIAL 537 WE must "cherish" one another, and graciously and willingly render service that will bring comfort and happiness into the lives of one another. Homemaking, too, will receive special emphasis during the coming season. It is the duty of Relief Society to train women to be skilled housekeepers and good homemakers. Attendance at Relief Society should give women an enlarged vision of the importance of maintaining their homes according to Latter-day Saint standards. Officers are urged to enlist young women as members of the Society, and to interpret and conduct the program so that it will attract them and meet their needs. The Latter-day Saint viewpoint and the spirit of the gospel should characterize all that is done in Relief Society, and the testimony of the truth of the restored gospel should be strengthened in every woman attending. Let us each resolve to be among those who approach the beginning of this season's work with enthusiasm, full of faith in that which has been initiated, and determined that the outcome of the year's work will be successful and glorious. -B. S. S. THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES "Other misfortunes may be borne, or their effects overcome. If disastrous wars should sweep our commerce from the ocean, another generation may renew it; if it exhaust our treasury, future industry may replenish it; if it desolate and lay waste our fields, still, under a new cultivation, they will grow green again, and ripen to future harvests. "It were but a trifle even if the walls of yonder Capitol were to crumble, if its lofty pillars should fall, and its gorgeous decorations be all covered by the dust of the valley. All these may be rebuilt. "But who shall reconstruct the fabric oi demolished government? "Who shall rear again the well-proportioned columns of constitutional liberty? "Who shall frame together the skillful architecture which unites national sovereignty with State rights, individual security, and public prosperity? "No, if these columns fall, they will be raised not again. Like the Coliseum and the Parthenon, they will be destined to a mournful and a melancholy immortality. Bitterer tears, however, will flow over them than were ever shed over the monuments of Roman or Grecian art; for they will be the monuments of a more glorious edifice than Greece or Rome ever saw, the edifice of constitutional American liberty." ?Daniel Webster, "Eulogy on General Washington," (1832).

Notes TO THE FIELD Auxiliary Regional Meetings and Monthly Union Meetings Authorized COPIES of the following letter "Further Instructions Regarding Conventions and Union Meetings" over the signature of the First Presidency of the Church were mailed to Relief Society stake presidents. It is reprinted herewith for the information of Relief Society officers: July 16, 1945 To Church Officers, Dear Brethren and Sisters: Further Instructions Regarding Conventions and Union Meetings Because of limitations set on automotive travel, the General Church Authorities on January 17, 1942, speaking through the First Presidency, advised General Boards of Auxiliary Organizations to discontinue the holding of monthly Union meetings, Institutes, and Conventions. Later, the Government itself placed a limitation upon assemblies throughout the entire country. The suspension of Unions and Conventions, of course, made less effective direct contact of Stake Boards as such with wards and branch officers and teachers, but placed greater responsibility upon the ward and branch organizations. We commend the local officers and teachers upon their willingness, ability, and increased effort to guide and instruct the members of their respective organizations during this Page 538 critical war-time period. It is gratifying, indeed, to note how efficiently the quorums and auxiliary organizations have functioned notwithstanding the limitations and difficulties under which they have had to labor. Occasional visits by General Board members to wards, stakes and districts requesting special help have contributed to increased efficiency in class work and in general spiritual uplift. A recent ruling by the Office of Price Administration, increasing the amount of gasoline for "A" coupons seems to point to such a relaxation with regard to the use of gasoline as will permit additional travel. Accordingly, we now authorize the holding of monthly priesthood leadership meetings that may include quorum members who may be especially invited to attend these meetings, monthly priesthood meetings, auxiliary regional meetings, and monthly union meetings where any such meetings may be held without violating the restrictions regarding the use of gasoline and rubber, and where the holding of such meetings will not interfere with quarterly conferences or other regularly established meetings. However, we do not, by these amended instructions, intend to authorize nor to countenance the holding of any of these meetings under circumstances which involve the violation of governmental rules and regulations regarding travel either by automobile or otherwise. NOTES TO THE FIELD 539 In this connection, we point out that experiences during the exigencies of war indicate that the visits of stake board members to wards produce even better results than having local officers and teachers travel to a central place for a monthly union meeting. Youth Need Guidance And Supervision In moving thus early to lift the ban hitherto placed upon the holding of Conventions and Union meetings, we are obedient to the necessity for close cooperation and personal contact between general and stake officers, and the young people of the Church. Every means that will foster such association must be made available wherever and whenever possible. The proper guidance of our children and youth is one of our paramount responsibilities. We are looking to those who represent the General Authorities in Priesthood and in Auxiliary work to discharge this responsibility in sincerity and prayerful devotion. Wherefore, now let every man learn his duty, and to act in the office in which he is appointed, in all diligence. He that is slothful shall not be counted worthy to stand, and he that learns not his duty and shows himself not approved shall not be counted worthy to stand. Even so. Amen. Sincerely your brethren, George Albert Smith J. Reuben Clark, Jr. David O. McKay The First Presidency Ward Relief Society Conferences, November 4, 1945 CONTINUING the plan first adopted in 1942 for auxiliaries to hold special meetings and annual conferences on Fast Sunday evenings, the Relief Society has again been assigned the evenings of Fast Day in November and March. Fast Day in November this year will occur November 4, and the General Board recommends that this evening be used for the annual ward Relief Society conference. Ward Relief Society presidents may therefore arrange with their respective bishops for holding meetings on the evening of Fast Day in November. This is a most favorable Sunday on which to hold the ward Relief Society conference, coming as it does only one month after the opening of the regular weekly meetings in October, thus affording opportunity for previewing the lessons and other work, near the beginning of the educational season. It is recommended: 1. That each ward conference be attended by a representative of the stake board who should be present at both the officers' meeting and the general session. 2. That each conference consist of  two meetings? a. An officers' meeting to be attended by the ward executive officers, special workers and class leaders, the ward bishop or his representative, and the visiting stake board member.
b. A general session for all Relief Society members and for the general membership of the ward.
The purposes of the officers' meeting are to discuss special problems confronting the ward Relief Society, and to provide opportunity for the stake board member to evaluate the condition of the ward Society and to advise, instruct, and stimulate the ward officers. In order to accomplish the purposes of the meeting, some stakes prepare a questionnaire or present and discuss data from the last annual report. At least one hour should be allowed for this meeting and, in some instances, a longer period may be required. The time for holding the officers' meeting is optional with wards, but should be at a time convenient for the visiting stake board member and bishop. For example, this meeting may be held immediately preceding the general session, as heretofore
suggested, the previous evening, or at some other time convenient for the bishop and visiting board member. This officers' meeting, held in connection with the ward conference, may constitute the monthly ward preparation meeting for the month in which the conference is held.
In order to insure a large attendance at the general session of the conference, it is recommended that advance announcement of the meeting be made in Relief Society and other ward gatherings. Relief Society members particularly should be urged to attend.
A suggestive program for use at ward conference will be sent to ward and stake presidents in bulletin form. Its use is optional and stakes and wards desiring to plan their own programs may do so. However, the General Board is very anxious that this meeting be used to acquaint ward members with the work of Relief Society and also with a view to enlisting the active participation of the women of the ward. TODAY Dorothy Mae Halls This moment was created for happiness. And now is the time to feel gay. If happiness be postponed till tomorrow. What shall I do with today? The breath of life must be breathed today, Or breathed it will never be; Tomorrow is always just out of my grasp, Today is confronting me.

Beyond This Dorothy Clapp Rohinson THE car was cruising effortlessly. It was a rare morning and a rare scene. Peaks of mountains and barbs of lava etched jagged holes through a downy quilt of shifting rain clouds. The scent of wet earth and green sage crept through the open window. In the back seat Mary Evans quivered with nostalgia. "It's camouflage,? she whispered to herself. "Cruel, selfish camouflage." The desert stretched before them with blue mountains for a backdrop. The soft rain came, then passed and came again. Quiescent, the mood of the travelers softened. Only Mary stiffened. '*We should be home by five o'clock." Home. These carefree people, Mr. McCollum, his wife and daughter, Patricia, would be home. Mary no longer had a home. Home meant a family and love and dreams. It meant building for the future. Her future lay behind. A roaring filled the sky. Between cloud puffs three bombers appeared flying in formation. The car stopped while the driver watched. "That's the life," he sighed. "Those kids are lucky." "Lucky." Mary spat the word. The girl beside her laid a hand gently on her knee but Mary moved. The hand was withdrawn. To these people war meant honor and glory. It even made them kind to their seamstress. They had brought her on this trip thinking it would make her forget. As if there were such a thing as forgetting. A quick smothered sob made her turn quickly, but Patricia's face was turned away. Gene had been the son every mother thinks she has. Strong, rugged, yet as full of dreams as a girl. "Don't you worry. Mom," he had said so many times. "Some day people are going to point to you and say, 'Know what? That's Gene Evan's mother. And you will swell with pride and I will tell the whole world the kind of mother you have been. And I'll pay the mortgage and buy new furniture. How's that?" "Perfect." Mary never doubted he would do just that. Gene had what it took to make dreams come true. The bombers passed and the car started again. Mary stared unseeing at the rocks and brush. It was such a little way back to his boyhood. "Know what?" he had asked once in a burst of confidence. He had finished mowing McCollum's lawn and they were sitting on their own back steps. The softness of a spring evening filled the dusk about them. "No. What?" "Some day after I go away and make my fortune, I'll come winging back out of the clouds in a big shining ship. I'll set her down over there on that vacant lot and everybody will come running to see. Page  Pat will be there, too. I'll be big then and strong, and I will pick her up in my arms and while everybody is watching we will fly away into the? into the land of Shining Mountains. DREAMS. Sweet dreams of youth. Their ending was of the essence of their birth. He had gone winging into the Shining Mountains, but Patricia was here and all the dreams had been for nothing. Mary had tried desperately to make the years less hard. Her efforts had been but fumbling beside the directness of his purpose. He had grown tall, hard of muscle and keen of eye. Handsome fellow, people said, and drew their daughters away. He would be like his dad. Mary knew better. From first grade on he'd had eyes for one girl only, Patricia McCollum, the untouchable. But his pride was as fierce as his strength. Mary glanced briefly at the girl, then looked again. She was staring ahead, her face a study in alabaster, hands motionless in her lap. Compelled by Mary's gaze she turned. Her mind came back slowly from long distances. There was something baffling in her eyes. Was it pity. Mary would have no pity. For herself or Gene. Oh, especially not for Gene. How he had managed flying lessons she never knew. It seemed impossible to add one more hour to his day. But he had. Then those flying lessons had suddenly become the important thing in his life?in all life. At twenty-one he had put aside the dreams of youth for the grim business of war. Mary tried to shut her mind to that first parting. He had stood on the back porch a long time staring in the direction of the imposing McCollum home, but he left without going over. Patricia had come the next day and if her eyes were bleak with sympathy, well, Mary's were bleak, too. She was left with only memories. The car picked up speed. The landscape became wilder, more stark. Was it like this in Greenland, she wondered? He'd been there the last year. He had written so few details. Don't worry, Mom. Our huts are warm, and we can take it. I am getting a leave the next time we hit the mainland. I hope it will be soon. There is nothing in all the world like the feel of good old U. S. Soil under a punk's feet. Nothing unless it is the sight of his Mom or his best girl. I'll come winging out of the clouds as I promised. And I am getting Pat this trip. Do you think she will spare me a week? I have learned basic values up here, and I am going to tell her what I should have told her long ago. But he hadn't asked Patricia to spare a week from her busy comfortable life. He had never whispered the wild sweet love that had been his secret dream through the years. In quick thought Mary turned, and wondered at the nakedness of the girl's face. Why?why it hadn't been pity. Patricia had been in love with him. She would have gone winging with him into the unknown. That explained so many little things. Mary sickened a little. The knowledge would have meant so much to Gene. It would have meant fulfilment to him. Now he would never know?or had he known? Of course. That. Explained what he had said about basic values. Her lips set stubbornly. Patricia had never known want or an unfulfilled desire. Let her suffer as Gene had suffered. In all her life Mary had had just her son. She was not sharing him now.
She had worked night and day to prepare for his coming. Her few carefully hoarded dollars had gone for paint and wallpaper. The money he sent home she was saving for him. She had changed her bed to his room. Maybe he would not recognize it under its coat of paint. She wanted him to have the best of everything.
And then?and then the very day he was to have arrived there came a cablegram instead. "Lost in performance of duty." A month?a long, long month?during which Patricia had stood by, white-faced, tight-lipped. How blinded Mary had been by her own suffering. A moment ended by a letter. His plane had been found. He and all his crew had been buried at an advance base, whatever that meant.
Yes, after all Mary did know what it meant. It meant empty, desolate years. It meant the end of the world. It meant the end of planning?and that Patricia would never know.
The rain clouds lifted and the rocks grew hot. They stopped at the Craters of the Moon. It had been very kind of the McCollums to bring her on this trip but she wished they would not stop so often. She watched impatiently while the driver paid an entrance fee and received instructions. More impatiently she saw him turn the car onto a road where no road should ever be. It lead into lava flows once spewed white-hot from a dragon's
mouth. Immediately her impatience vanished. For the first time in months she was interested. The bleakness and blackness found echo in her heart.
Weird, uncanny formations, terrifying in their stark nakedness, were sharply etched, as yet untouched by the raging power of time and the elements. Rising from the confusion, were several sharply sloping cones of coal-black pulverized cinders.
Something was rising unbidden in Mary. Something akin to justification. How like LIFE this barren waste was, bleak, impotent and utterly without form or purpose. Of no earthly use to God or man.
They rounded a quick turn and stopped abruptly. Leaving the car they stood at the edge of the road gazing in awe and bewilderment.
HEAVEN had laid a fleece of beauty over stark sterility. Every slope of every black hill was covered with a carpet of flowers. Wild snowballs, Gene had called them. From between two slender silver leaves a stem rose, topped by a snowball the size of a large marble. The balls graduated in color from pale canary through orange, to crimson.
Unbelievably, there was a tiny orchard of these among them. A Heaven by Gardener not only had planted, but had spaced them. Looking from any direction there were perfect rows with plants four inches apart. Silver, yellow, orchid, crimson, and, underneath, the rimming black lace of cinders. It was a miracle. The ash of black despair had given birth to HOPE, beautiful beyond compare.
At Patricia's gasp, Mary turned to face her. Tears were streaming unheeded down the girl's cheeks. This was the girl Gene had loved, who loved him; and there must be no despair. Patricia's must not be denied her. Mary took the girl's hand. "He meant to tell you," she whispered. "That is why he was coming home."

Planning For Safety THE great number of accidents occurring in the homes of America has intensified research into their causes. It has been found that many accidents are due to faulty home design, unsafe equipment, and careless actions. If the greatest degree of safety is to be obtained, careful consideration must be given to the elimination of hazards which are known to produce accidents. This may require changes in the house plan, rearrangement of the. Furniture, provision of places for putting things away, or the addition of more light to entrances, passages, and stairways. The National Safety Council tells us that falls cause about two-thirds of all home tragedies. All stairs should have an easy ascent with equal step heights or rises and treads of equal width. Sturdy hand rails should be provided. Good lighting is essential and may be secured by placing a switch at both the top and the bottom of the stairs. There should be non-slip floor surfaces and well-secured carpeting. Loose metal step guards or small throw rugs are malicious hazards. Rooms with floor levels of varying heights?a step up to the dining room or one down to the living room?are a constant danger. Any door opening into a hall should swing roomward and should not open directly on a down stairway. If this arrangement cannot be avoided, a safety lock should be placed on the door to give time for realization of a potential fall. Overhead obstructions should be removed or painted white, especially in the basement and attic stairways. Top and bottom steps, when painted white, will indicate when the end is reached. A gate to bar the stairs is essential if there are toddlers around. The bathroom is often the scene of falls, scalds, and burns if the equipment is not arranged to prevent them. The tub should have a flat bottom with at least one strong, solid grip on the wall to hold on to when getting in and out of the tub or shower. There should be a non-slip mat on the floor and a good container should be provided to keep soap out of the way. The water should be kept below scalding, about 125? Fahrenheit. Records tell of fatal results to children from too hot water being turned on them. Electric switches should be placed outside the bathroom or beyond reach of the tub or shower. Never touch an electrical appliance with wet hands. Many older people, as well as children, die from falls and burns in bedrooms. There should be light fixtures at both doors and bedsides. See that there is a straight path from the bed to the door to avoid bumping or falling over furniture. Children should be provided with safe cribs having the slats close enough to prevent the baby's head Page  being caught between them. Be sure that children's furniture and toys are painted with non-poisonous compounds. Reliable dealers should know the ingredients of their paints. Radiant heaters should be placed away from materials that could be ignited, and heating pads should be placed away from materials that could be ignited, and heating pads should be kept in good repair to prevent burns.
Windows need careful consideration. If they can be arranged to swing or turn in for cleaning, a very definite falling hazard will be eliminated, as sitting or leaning out of windows to wash them is dangerous. Screens and storm windows should be adjusted from the inside and the catches on all screens should be strong and secure.
The roof design of a home should be kept simple and the attic well insulated to eliminate the necessity of removing snow and ice from the eaves and gutters in heavy winter weather.
Make the living room livable by grouping the furniture where it will be most used, leaving clear paths for family traffic. Provide enough electric plug-ins to eliminate the necessity for long cords which may be tripped over or broken. Sew weights or rubber fruit rings on the under side of rugs to keep them flat and secure them from slipping or tripping. Use non-skid wax on the floors.
The kitchen is the most dangerous room in the house. Children should be kept out while cooking or canning is going on. All equipment should be kept in good repair. Shelves should be placed within reach, or where this cannot be done, a sturdy stepladder with wide treads or "step stool" should be used. Stoves with an open flame should not be closer than twelve to eighteen inches from a window. Curtains should be securely fastened so they won't blow over the flame and ignite. All floors, walls, and chimneys should be properly insulated from heating stoves. Matches and all sharp instruments should be put away from little fingers.
More than half of the home accidents happen outside the home. Provide adequate light for porch steps and walks. If paths cannot be cleaned from snow and ice, they should be sprinkled with salt or ashes. Clean rain gutters will form fewer icicles. Clothes lines should be arranged higher than the head or placed out of the line of traffic.
Take advantage of foresight and planning to prevent home tragedies. Good housekeeping is safe housekeeping.Therefore,... See that you are merciful unto your brethren; deal justly, judge righteously, and do good continually; and if ye do all these things then shall ye receive your reward; yea, ye shall have mercy restored unto you again; ye shall have a righteous judgment restored unto you again; and ye shall have good rewarded unto you again. For that which ye do send out shall return unto you again, and be restored (Alma 41:14-15).

His First Teacher Mildred Y. Hunt ONE of the ever-increasing wonders of my world is the capacity of the child mind for receiving impressions. In his quest for learning he is inexhaustible. In the beginning, his questions were very simple and the main problem was framing replies in language that he could understand. Day by day his interest has widened and with it my responsibility, for I must weave the type of fabric which I desire to be the basis of his future education. This is a part of motherhood in which I have always believed, but not until my own child reached this stage did its possibilities rise before me in such limitless proportions. The impressions made now, upon virgin soil, will take root and live to shape the conduct of his entire life. That which concerns me most at this stage is the foundation of religion. I feel certain that the responsibility for this belongs essentially to me, rather than to those who teach him outside of home. Their contribution will help, but mine is the task of building the main structure. Sunday School and Primary lessons will be more beneficial if he has a background of religious knowledge. It is well that repetition does not bore him, for each retelling strengthens his knowledge and widens his understanding. The characters of the Bible are real and interesting. He never tires of hearing about Jesus and all the incidents and happenings that bring out the beauty and purity of his life. Joseph Smith, too, lives for him in all his nobility. Adam, Enoch, and Noah, the stories of Joseph and the enslavement of the children of Israel, and their delivery by Moses are as interesting to him as any characters of fiction. This is the wonderful thing about teaching him, for once the child's interest is gained the teacher's work is easy and pleasurable. Our Church leaders have stressed the importance of early training for children. According to President Grant: The Lord has said that it is our duty to teach our children in their youth. Children are not born with a knowledge of the gospel. Each one must learn and study and gain that knowledge for himself. Brigham Young was very explicit in his direction to mothers: Let mothers commence to teach their children while in their laps; there do you teach them to love the Lord and keep his commandments.... If you, mothers, will live your religion, then in the love and fear of God teach your children constantly and thoroughly in the ways of life and salvation, training them up in the way they should go, and when they are old they will not depart from it. If we do not take the pains to train our children, to teach and " instruct them concerning these revealed truths, the condemnation will be upon us as parents. Page 547 The value of family prayers in training children for religious and spiritual lives cannot be over estimated. Sincerity and humility on the part of the parents seeking the spirit of the Lord in the home is one of the first profound impressions to be made on young minds.
It is easy to let less important tasks crowd out these essential activities. One of the most potent weapons of the adversary is procrastination. Our lives today move at a rapid tempo, but it is more important than ever that we remain calm, and hold fast to the enduring and everlasting principles of the salvation of souls.
for us but also for our children. Not one of the tasks constantly tugging at us is important enough to justify neglect of the great trust which is ours in the training of these little ones.
And so, of the two precious years that remain before I give him over to others to teach, there is no time to waste. In studying for the information which I must have in order to meet this goal, I, too, shall be immeasurably benefited. We shall share a rich and happy experience together which we shall be better able to give to others.

MATES Edward R. Tuttle The fabric of their love was never one Of fragile texture, made with silken twine And weft of dreams that later might be done, Somehow, into a workable design; But, was the homespun of a pent-up street Where pain-worn dwellers scarcely knew the soil. Expectancy had seldom turned their feet From an accustomed rendezvous with toil. They had preferred to let a slower growth Mature the rugged fibers in their care, Until a loom of years could furnish both With proper raiment for enduring wear. The mute concessions of this man and wife Had given each the condiments of life.

The Radiant Spirit A FANTASY Miranda Snow Walton IN the Beautiful Kingdom lay a broad, white roadway running like a pearled ribbon from the Mountain of the Great Throne to the Silver Sea. Many people, young and old, traveled along the Highway, for it was the Road of Life. This is a tale of two men who journeyed thereon.
Now, there was a legend in the Beautiful Kingdom that when a man had traversed the Highway's length, even unto the shores of the Silver Sea, the Radiant One would take him by the hand, and lead him into an enchanted land, where his eyes would behold things too beautiful for mortal men to look upon. None had ever returned to tell of its wonder, for the law was that a traveler walked that way but once.
It was springtime when Jan and Justin began their pilgrimage. All the earth was made fair and lovely by the silvery sunshine that fell from happy skies. Birds and flowers grew in rich abundance, and birds' celestial music filled the air like a blessed benediction.
Jan was in ecstasy. Nothing, he thought, could be as beautiful as this; no, not even the vision of the Radiant One.
Each day, each hour, brought new delight to his soul, and his feet tarried along the trail until Justin became impatient.
"Hurry," he would call to Jan,
"these are only flowers and trees and birds which we can see every day. Why linger among these common things? Let us not stop until we have reached the Silver Sea."
He would have hastened ahead, but he could not, for it had been decreed that they journey together. He complained bitterly when Jan delayed while they listened to the rustling of moonlit pines.
"Angel whispers, they are," he told Justin, but Justin could only hear the branches scraping one against the other, and he fretted to be on his way, until his heart became filled with worry and resentment.
Summer came, and passed; then autumn and the earth was more beautiful than it had been in the springtime. To Jan, each scarlet leaf became a miracle, each golden tree more exquisite than the last, and where green fields had lain in lazy loveliness, now abundant harvests gave the promise of royal riches to all men. But Justin's impatience waxed more strong.
"The nights are becoming chill," he complained, "it will soon be winter, and it is still a far journey to the Silver Sea."
"Yes, I know the nights are chill," said Jan, "but the stars hang low and close like diamonds upon earth's pure breast, and I would drink of this beauty while I can, for we will pass this way but once." So they tarried until the winter of life was upon them, and their footsteps faltered many times, for their bodies were tired from their long journeying. They knew now that they would soon reach the Silver Sea, and Justin inlaid his companion bitterly.
"See," he said, "you have wasted our strength and time along the way on transient trifles. Our eyes are dim with age. Tell me, how can we now see the Radiant One?"
And Jan replied, "I am glad for the experiences of the springtime, for summer's clouds and showers, for the recompense of the harvest. These things have given me power to understand the immenity of that which is to come."
Then the day came when they stepped beyond the sunset into the Silver Sea. With eager, expectant eyes they looked for the Radiant One, as the legend had told them.
Justin spoke first. "We are too late, or we have missed our way. This is only another sea, like the many we have passed, and I do not
I see a person standing in the sun."
But Jan did not hear, for his ears were filled with the chant of angel choirs, his eyes were filled with the beauty that was too great for mortal man to look upon. His soul stood singing, for it knew the ecstasy of immortality, the glory and the joy of heavenly things, the wonder of eternity.
The Radiant One took him by the hand.
"Only those who have known me as they journeyed along the way of life can see me here. I walk with all men, but there are those who will not see and some who will not hear. Blessed are you, Jan, for you have seen me in the sunrise, and in the sacred silence of a higher noon; have known me when I manifested myself in acts of kindness by fellow travelers. You have felt my
presence when life storms of the obscured your vision. I bless you, Jan, with eternal joy. I am the one whose mission it is to give happiness to men. I am the Spirit of Appreciation."

HOLLYHOCKS Delia Adams Leitnei Hollyhocks so prim and tall, All along my garden wall; Bright array of pink and white, Shades of red and yellow bright, Single, double, frilled and plain, Stately but without disdain; Such a regal air they bear. And their dignity they wear Kingly, but so graciously. They are the garden's royalty. PRESENCE Alice Money Bailey She is not gone. The rows of bottled fruit Arranged on cellar shelves still bear a mute But sharp reminder?berries, apples?keys To thrift. Her potted plants, her brooms, and these: The brightly colored rags she meant to braid. The handkerchiefs she ironed, her glasses laid With neat precision by her much-read book. No dim and fleeting wraith is hers. I look To see her laughter-crinkled face. I hear The briskness of her step, her accents clear. How can I feel the loss her absence gives. Or mourn for her whose vividness still lives? Page 556
