LESSON DEPARTMENT Theology Church History Lesson 12?Building an Empire in the West Dr. H. Wayne Driggs For Tuesday, January 8, 1946 Objective: To indicate the continued fulfillment of prophecy concerning the gathering of Israel. THE day which followed the arrival of the first company of saints into the valley of the Great Salt Lake was the Sabbath. Fittingly enough this should have been so, for these were a people who had chosen the Lord for their king. In their struggling efforts to establish his kingdom in the East, the Mormon people had found nothing but bitter opposition. Therefore, the Lord led his people where they would be unmolested in their efforts to establish his work.
To bring the nations of the earth to a knowledge of the literal establishment of such a kingdom was, however, the purpose of God. In his wisdom, therefore, he prepared a place for his saints to gather where they might become strong, a place of refuge among the towering rocks and hidden valleys of the mountains. Here, as a peculiar people, they too must be prepared, that they live and obey his laws, which eventually all men, too, must obey if they would enjoy peace and the blessings of prosperity.
President Brigham Young's first advice to the saints on that July 25, 1847, was concerning one of the laws of God?that of keeping the Sabbath day holy. Weakened as a result of an illness which had seized him just before the company of first pioneers entered the Valley, he expressed his wishes briefly. Elder Wilford Woodruff recorded his remarks as follows: "He told the brethren that they must not work on Sunday; that they would lose five times as much as they would gain by it. None were to hunt on that day and there should not any man dwell among us who would not observe these rules. They might go and dwell where they pleased, but should not dwell with us" (Josmer Paramos Saints without Halos in Church History, page 451).
These remarks and the spirit which prompted them were typical of the serious manner with which
Page 624 LESSON DEPARTMENT 625 the followers of this Prophet regarded the literal acceptance of God's word. Within the period of the first ten years that followed the entrance of the saints into the promised land, they set to work with zeal bringing about the fulfillment of many of the great and beautiful prophecies of the seers of old. It was an eventful ten years from 1847 to 1857. Within this decade, hundreds of Mormons, from many nations of the earth, having left their homes, streamed into the Valley. There was hard work to be done if the desert was to blossom as the rose, and scouting expeditions to be sent throughout the vast mountain regions if the stakes of Zion were to be set and lengthened (Isa. 54:2). An actual ensign was to be raised upon the hills that all people who would hear might know that Zion was again, and that they could flow into it. Temples were to be erected, since God had said that his people were always commanded to build a holy house unto his name (Doc. And Gov. 124:39). The land of Deseret or the "Honey Bee" it would become, as the Book of Mormon term implied. Visioning the industry and zeal with which the latter-day work of Israel would be carried forth, Isaiah, the ancient prophet, wrote: And they shall build the old wastes, they shall raise up the former desolation and they shall repair the waste cities, the desolations of many generations (Isaiah 61:4). And of the people and their abode, he said: He that walketh righteously, and speak-eth uprightiy; he that despiseth the gain of oppressions, that shaketh his hands firom holding of bribes, that stoppeth his ears from hearing of blood, and shutteth his eyes from seeing evil; He shall dwell on high: his place of defence shall be the munitions of rocks: bread shall be given him; his waters shall be sure. Thine eyes shall see the king in his beauty: they shall behold the land that is very far off. Thine heart shall meditate terror. Where is the scribe? Where is the receiver? Where is he that counted the towers? Thou shall not see a fierce people, a people of a deeper speech than thou canst perceive; of a stammering tongue, that thou canst not understand. Look upon Zion, the city of our solemnities; thine eyes shall see Jerusalem a quiet habitation, a tabernacle that shall not be taken down; not one of the stakes thereof shall ever be removed, neither shall any of the cords thereof be broken. But there the glorious Lord will be unto us a place of broad rivers and streams; wherein shall go no galley with oars, neither shall gallant ship pass thereby" (Isaiah 33:15-21). The actual story of the events which now are history and which now outline the early acts performed in laying the foundations of an empire in the West are filled with the color of human endeavor, courage and self-sacrifice. Soil was broken on the 23rd and 24th of July, that the seed so carefully treasured during the journey west might find its early germination in the Valley. When Monday morning, July 26th, arrived, eager exploring parties set out, some to the west of the valley beyond the Western Jordan River. John Brown and Joseph Matthews were among this group. Others went east into the canyons to return with reports of good timber. Wil-ford Woodruff and a party turned north to discover warm springs, and the next day they went west again into the Tooele valley. It was Orson Pratt who, on the trip, climbed a mountain to view Utah Lake. All companies returned with the feeling  that their present site in the valley of the Great Salt Lake was the best place in which to lay out the city with its temple to the Lord. It was on the 26th also that a party, including President Brigham Young ascended what is now known as "Ensign Peak" to the north of Salt Lake. Here it was the desire of President Young to lift up an ensign to the nations spoken of by the Prophet Isaiah.
By the 28th, President Young had designated the site upon which the temple to the Lord would be built. He said: "Here is the forty acres for the temple, and the city can be laid out perfectly square north and south, east and west."
Events throughout the rest of the summer months moved on smoothly. A fort was built on the square now known as Pioneer Park in Salt Lake City. This, it was felt, would serve as a protection against the Indians who by now were crowding around the saints to beg and steal. With the return of part of the Mormon Battalion, added strength was given to the colony. On October 3, 1847, a conference was held at which Elder John Smith, uncle of the Prophet Joseph Smith [and great-grandfather of President George Albert Smith], was sustained as the first president of the Salt Lake Stake of Zion. The year 1847 closed with a total of 2,095 souls in the Salt Lake Valley.
One of the most beautiful stories for the saints of the first years in the mountains is that of the crickets and the gulls. The feeding of Elijah by the ravens will ever be remembered to stir the love for birds and their courage to share when it is scarce, where in modern times can one turn for a more inspiring account of mercy from the skies than to that of the winged gulls from off the shores of Great Salt Lake.
No real crop was gathered by the saints for the season of 1847. The pioneers had arrived too late that year to expect much of a harvest. It was then to the spring and summer of 1848 that they must look for a yield if they were to live. The planting season for that year came, and, as the tender shoots pushed forth, the hopes for a bountiful harvest were high. May and June, however, brought not only the sunshine, but danger. Armies of marching crickets trooped down from the mountain sides to mow the fields. Trenches were dug, fires built, cattle and men called to tramp out the insects, but to no avail. Finally, in tearful supplication, the saints poured out their hearts to the Lord for deliverance. As they raised their eyes, what appeared to be a black cloud overhead shortly took shape in the form of hundreds of white-breasted gulls. At first, stricken by fear, lest these birds had come to finish what the crickets had left, the saints stolidly watched. But fear was not to be their lot, for, instead of feasting upon the crops, the birds hacked at the pests, and, gorging themselves, winged off to disgorge their feed. They returned again and again to repeat the attack until, with raucous cries, they wheeled into the air and vanished from sight. It was the miracle of the gulls these modern children of Israel had witnessed. Today, upon Temple Square in Salt Lake City, there stands the fine monument of its kind to a bird, and beneath its shaft is cast, in bronze, the story of the Utah seagull. LESSON DEPARTMENT 627 In other early accounts of this beginning empire in the West are recorded the stories of trips by President Brigham Young and others of the leading brethren back and forth across the plains to Winter Quarters. They were ever interested in bringing safely into the land of Zion the many souls who daily were embracing the gospel. It was on one of the trips back to Missouri that the apostles met and organized the First Presidency with Brigham Young, Heber C. Kimball, and Willard Richards as the first three men to hold these offices in the presidency since the martyrdom of the Prophet Joseph Smith and his brother Hy-rum. About that time, too, Oliver Cowdery returned to the Church and again was baptized a member. In Zion, in the month of March 1849, the first political convention was called. The saints were desirous of having their territory under the flag of the United States. Then, in September of 1850, President Millard Fillmore appointed the first federal officers for the Territory of Utah with Brigham Young as governor. The years ahead were to be stormy since, in the main, weak officials who sought personal gains in office were sent to assume control over the saints in their new Territory. A most important event of these years came with the laying of the cornerstones of the temple on April 6, 1853. Each stone was laid with dedicatory prayers of thanksgiving. Among the significant thoughts expressed that day were these by President Brigham Young: We dedicate the south-east corner stone of the temple to the Most High God. May it remain in peace till it has done its work, and until He who has inspired our hearts to fulfil the prophecies of His holy prophets, that the house of the Lord should be reared in the "tops of the Mountains" shall be satisfied, and say it is enough. (Joseph Fielding Smith, Essentials in Church History, page 482). Jenson, Improvement Era, July 1942. Visiting Teachers' Messages Sources of Strength?Charity Lesson 4-Charity Vaunteth Not Itself, Is Not Puffed Up Dr. Lowell L. Bennion For Tuesday, January 8, 1946 Objective: To show that true charity is self-forgetting. JESUS spoke this parable: Unto certain which trusted in themselves that they were righteous, and despised others: Two men went up into the temple to pray; the one, a Pharisee, and the other a publican. The Pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself, God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even as this publican. I fast twice in the week, I give tithes of all that I possess. And the publican, standing afar off, would not lift up so much as his eyes unto heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying, God be merciful to me a sinner. I tell you this man went down to his house justified rather than the other: for every one that exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted" (Luke 18:9-14). Jesus did not condemn the Pharisee because of his righteousness, because he was not an unjust person, an extortioner or an adulterer, nor because he paid tithes and fasted twice a week. These good deeds were all to his credit. His sin consisted in the self-righteous pleasure he took in his own goodness. It is only when we forget ourselves that we can be our best selves, that we can act in our full power and strength. Consciousness of self inhibits the free expression of oneself in any walk of life. A self-conscious speaker is ineffective. A beautiful girl loses much of her attractiveness if she acts conscious of it. Charity cannot both display and express itself at the same time. Charity means to love and to give. This, one cannot do with self-glorification or benefit in mind. That would be a contradiction. Jesus asked that we always act with singleness of purpose. He said not to give to be seen of men, but "when thou doest alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth." He wanted us to give for the sake of giving. He asks us to love our fellow men freely, spontaneously, without fear of punishment or hope of reward. A friend relates this experience in giving: "One Sunday afternoon I decided to visit a bed-ridden friend, thinking it would be a Christian way to spend the Sabbath and that I might render him a service. I found him in much pain, yet he talked cheerfully and not of himself. His suffering had tempered his spirit, developing in him humility and a deep compassion for others. I left his home profoundly moved and spiritually quickened, and I felt ashamed that I had thought of myself as they giver and of him as the receiver of my benevolence.? "Charity vaunteth not itself, not puffed up?seeketh not her own.? The only check on our charity should be effectiveness in the lives of others. Literature The Bible in Our Literature Lesson 4?Bible Influence as Revealed in Our Narrative and Epic Poetry Dr. Howard R. Driggs For Tuesday, January 22, 1946 CHAUCER, often called the father of English literature, gave us in his Canterbury Tales outstanding narrative poetry. In this group of stories, preserved vibrantly by a literary master, we have an artistic portrayal of England in the Middle Ages. With picturesque old English, which, well-voiced, brings a charm and flavor of its own, the poet tells of "myrie and Niceity in a companie of sondry folk" who are making a pilgrimage about Easter time to pay homage to a "holy blissful martyr" who has "holpen hem (them) whan that they been seke (sick)." To while time away on the long journey to and from Canterbury, the travelers relate favorite tales. These, like the different storytellers, mirror the spirit, the custom, the people of that "olden tyme."
Naturally, with such personages as a prioress, a nun, a monk, a pardoner, a friar, and a poor parson, in the company, we are brought closer to the religious thought and practices of the people, a keen observer, sketches these vivid characters in his prologue with artistry. He pictures the prioress as demure and neat and cultured. There are poetic shafts aimed at the monk who in this case was not pale and studious, but worldly and well fed. For show and sham and abuses of religion, the poet reveals little patience. His ire flames especially at the pardoner who went about selling indulgences, preying upon the poor and rich alike. For the poor parson, however, he has nothing but praise. "Riche he was in holy thought and work," says the poet; and further:
He wayted after pomp and reverence, Ne (not) maked him a spiced conscience, But Cristes lore," and his gospels twelve, He taught, and first he folwed it him selve.
"Meaning the gospel of Christ.
Because of the old-time language, which, after all, is mainly what we use today, only with some letters spelled differently, many folk miss the enjoyment of Chaucer. For those who do get over the not very difficult word barrier, there are delightful descriptions, touches of humor, bits of wisdom and gospel truths, as well as charming stories in his writings. He pictures for us typically human folk of not only his own day, but of all time. Throughout the work of this pioneer in English narrative poetry, the helpful influence of the Bible is plainly shown. Another of our great poets who drew from the Bible not only inspiration but divine themes for his masterpieces was John Milton. In him, as in Chaucer, we can see three major influences blended to help bring forth masterly creations. First, the freedom-demanding spirit of the Anglo-Saxon; second, the culture of classic Greece; third, the Bible, with its teachings of God and the gospel of Jesus Christ. For a helpful comparison here, think of the soil-laden waters of the Missouri as typifying the rugged northland folk; the clearer Mississippi as the more artistic Hellenes; and the "Beautiful Ohio" as the spiritualizing Hebraic and Christian contribution? all flowing together to make one great stream. In Paradise Lost, to apply this analogy, we have an excellent example of such a blended creation. Milton was trained in Anglo-Saxon love of freedom; he was a classical scholar, a devoted student of the scriptures. As secretary of Oliver Cromwell, he naturally was stirred to the depths by the arrogant assumption of King Charles the First, that kings had "divine right" to rule. To the poet this all had its prototype in the "War in Heaven" with Satan, father of tyrants, fighting to dominate the souls of men, and Christ leading the host battling to uphold man's right to exercise his God-given free agency. Here was a Bible-inspired theme, vital then and always. How could it be most splendidly expressed? All the artistry of poetry Milton had gained from his classic studies was brought into play. Paradise Lost most sublime of epics, vibrates with the spirit of liberty; it is stately in form, portraying heavenly characters, Satan and his legions in hell, the Son of God and his divine mission, Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, their temptation by the Devil, their fall, and expulsion from Paradise. Ringing lines of truth, precious descriptions, vivid moving pictures, all in the spirit of Job and Isaiah and the Apocalypse of John, bring this epic up to the world's greatest of literary creations. To feel its spiritual powers, its music and beauty, one must hear it effectively voiced. Further, it must be read and reread if the inner meaning of the poem is to be appreciated. Paradise Lost will yield its rare wealth only to those who are willing to pay the price of earnest study. Such effort, like that applied to the mastery of classic music, brings its rich and lasting rewards. Just a few lines can be given here to suggest some of the gems of thought and description within the great epic: Him (Satan) th' Almighty Power Hurled headlong flaming from the ethereal sky. The mind is its own place, and in itself Can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven?-so says the fallen Satan. LESSON DEPARTMENT When the Son of God offers himself to redeem the world, his Father, with tender love and admiration, makes promise that through this atoning sacrifice shall come, in time, New Heaven and Earth, wherein the just shall dwell. And after all their tribulations long. See golden days, fruitful of golden deeds. With Joy and Love triumphing, and fair Truth. Matchless portrayal of Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, of the subtleties of Satan, and of the driving of our first parents from Paradise, carry forward the great story to its closing lines: Some natural tears they dropped, but wiped them soon; The world was all before them, where to choose Their place of rest, and Providence their guide. They, hand in hand, with wandering steps and slow, Through Eden took their solitary way. The Canterbury Tales and Paradise Lost differ basically in form. Stories that Chaucer brings together in the first are individual, unrelated tales. It is only the outward plan, devised by the poet, of having the various pilgrims traveling together tell the different stories that holds them with something of unity. Paradise Lost, on the other hand, is made up of different stories, each of which helps to develop the central theme. This makes it an epic, similar to the Illiad, the Odyssey or to Hiawatha. The Canterbury Tales, in structure may be likened to a necklace; Paradise Lost is more wheel-like in its story unity. Idylls of the King by Tennyson is another great epic. Its various interesting stories of the Knights of the Round Table center in Arthur, their king. In Celtic tales this legendary hero was preserved through the years. In Mallory's Morte d'Arthur, one of the first of English books to be printed, stories linked with Arthur's name are in prose. Tennyson brings to us many of the same stories in more polished English blank (unrhymed) verse. Further, the poet portrays King Arthur more plainly as a champion of Christianity. With his chosen and tested knights, he strives to hold back the Anglo-Saxon pagans who, when the Roman legions were withdrawn from England, made conquest of that realm. With "We fight for our fair father Christ," as something of a battle cry, the courageous Arthur: Fought, and in twelve great battles overcame The heathen hordes, and made a realm and reigned. At the outset the King had announced: "The old order changeth, yielding place to new." Something more, however, than victory over pagan hosts was necessary to make good that vow. Stories, one after another, of the Knights of the Table Round, reveal the continuing struggle against sin, disloyalty to high ideals, and a falling from grace. Then into the epic comes the miracle of the Holy Grail. This sacred symbol, one legend has it, was the cup out of which Christ drank at his Last Supper. Taken to England, so the old story goes, by Joseph of Arimathea, it had remained there until the time-Grew such evil that the holy cup Was caught away to heaven and disappeared. Only by the absolutely pure could the cup again be seen. A sister of Sir Percival, of the Table Round, was first to win that precious privilege. 632 Said she: Sweet brother, I have seen the Holy Grail: For waked at dead of night, I heard a sound As of a silver horn from o'er the hills... And then Streamed through my cell a cold and silver beam. And down the long beam stole the Holy Grail. Rose red "with beatings on it, as if alive... And then the music faded, and the Grail Pass'd.... So now the Holy Thing is here again Among us, brother, fast thou too and pray, And tell thy brother knights to fast and pray, That so perchance the vision may be seen By thee and those and all the world be heal'd. Percival, heeding his sister's words, withdrew from the Table Round to an abbey, to pass his life thenceforth in prayer and fast and alms. Other knights, catching the religious fervor, likewise took up the quest of the Holy Grail. Among them was Galahad, youngest of all. To this splendid youth, King Arthur, dubbing him knight, had said, "God make thee as pure as thou art beautiful." That tiie prayer was granted is attested by the story that Galahad was one who did see the vision of the Holy Grail. But unrighteousness did not cease. The Table Round in time was broken up. At last came the passing of the king (Morte d'Ar-thur).And, as the great leader neared the close of his uplifting life, he said again: The old order changeth, yielding place to new?Pray for my soul. More things are wrought by prayer Than this world dreams of Outstanding among our American creators of narrative and epic poetry is Longfellow. His name, to most folk, will bring memories of Evangeline and The Courtship oi Miles Standish. Something deeper than just interesting stories are in these and other narrative verse by Longfellow. Evangeline is a symphony impressing "the beauty and strength of woman's devotion"; The Courtship oi Miles Standish likewise is a musically beautiful poem portraying conflict between love and duty. Both picture with artistry moving scenes in earlier American life: one a story of the Norman peasantry transplanted to Arcadia; the other a story of the Pilgrims in Plymouth. To get the full richness out of these classics, one must read and reread them and, in doing so, follow Longfellow's own advice from "The Day is Done": Lend to the rhyme of the poet The beauty of thy voice. All great poetry was created to be heard rather than just to be read silently. Another thing: to appreciate the inner meaning and spiritual beauty of these story-poems one must know the Bible. All through them are lines that call, as do the following, for a working knowledge of that Book of Books. These are typical ones from Evangeline: Harvests were gathered in; and wild, with the winds of September Wrestled the trees of the forest, as Jacob of old with the angel. Like unto shipwrecked Paul on Melita's Desolate seashore. Strutted the lordly turkey, and crowed the cock with the self-same Voice that in ages of old had startled the penitent Peter. Hot and on his lips still burned the flush of the fever As if life, like the Hebrew, with blood had besprinkled its portals. LESSON DEPARTMENT 633 That the angel of death might see the sign and pass over. And these from The Courtship of Miles Standish: This is the hand of the Lord; it is laid upon me in anger, For I have followed too much the heart's desires and devices, Worshipping Astaroth blindly, and impious idols of Baal. This is the cross I must bear, the sin and the swift retribution. Giants in hearts they were, who believed in God and the Bible, Ay, who believed in the smiting of Midianites and Philistines. Forth from the curtain of clouds, from the tent of purple and scarlet. Issued the sun, the great High Priest, in his garments resplendent. Holiness unto the Lord, in letters of light on his forehead. Another of Longfellow's creations, in structure like that of the Canterbury Tales and doubtless inspired by Chaucer's creation, is Tales of A Wayside Inn. In his later years, the American poet, as professor of the chair of poetry at Harvard, gathered round him friends and students from not only his own but other countries. Go to the Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Massachusetts? preserved now as a shrine by Henry Ford, in tribute to Longfellow's work which gave the place literary immortality?and you may see photographs of some of these friends hanging on the wall. There, as the poet devised the setting for his tales, the group of friends would gather round the fireside, and share their stories. From the genial landlord, they were given the first one, "Paul Revere's Ride." Another, "King Robert of Sicily" came from a Sicilian; still another, already mentioned in the first of our lessons "The Saga of King Olaf" was related by the musician, Ole Bull. A Spanish Jew, a poet, a theologian, and a student, all add their favorite tales. And these, with prelude and interludes, are held together as with a strand?story gems made into a literary necklace. Many of the stories are closely linked with the Bible. This is true especially of "King Robert of Sicily," "The Legend Beautiful," and the "Legend of Rabbi Ben Levi." Others, like "The Birds of Killingworth" vibrate with the Christian spirit. And this may be said not only of Longfellow's poems as a whole, but of story-poems created by Whittier, Lowell, and other fine American poets. Space forbids more than this passing tribute due these creators of interesting, uplifting literature. Discussion and Activities 1. (a) What, in brief, does Chaucer portray in The Canterbury Tales? (b) Which of the religious pilgrims in the poem were worthy the name of Christian? Which were not? Why? 2. (a) Tell very briefly the background Bible story of Paradise Lost, (b) How does the theme of man's free agency link with the founding of our nation? With the world wars we have had? (c) What basic preparation had Milton for this masterwork? 3. (a) What, briefly, is the legend of the Holy Grail? (b) What qualities in Sir Galahad made it possible for him to see this vision? (c) How does Lowell in his Vision of Sir Launfal bring the Holy Grail closer to our lives? Sketch his story.  4. (a) Why may Longfellow be aptly called a great poet for both schools and homes? (b) Most folk get just story enjoyment from his narrative poems. What other riches are to be had from appreciative re-reading of Evangeline, The Courtship of Miles Standish, and Tales of A Wayside Inn?
5. (a) Prove with brief quotations from Chaucer, Milton, Tennyson, Longfellow, or other creators of narrative poetry, that a good working knowledge of the Bible is essential to an understanding of their story-poems.
6. Name from another poet?English or American?a narrative poem which links with the Bible in title, allusions, thought or spirit; for example, "Abou Ben Adhem" by Leigh Hunt.

Social Science Modern Applications of Moral Principles Lesson 10?Leisure and Morals Dr. Harold T. Christensen For Tuesday, January 29, 1946 Lesson link: Drug addiction, alcoholism, gambling, unchastity, and other moral problems of personal conduct were analyzed last time. Causes and consequences in each of these areas of defiant behavior were emphasized, and it was shown that the effects of private immorality reach much farther than the offending persons themselves. Repentance was given as the way out. Lesson aim: To demonstrate a relationship between modes of recreation and morality, and to suggest ways for improving the morals of society by making better use of leisure time. MAN has not always enjoyed the leisure that he knows today. There was a time, not so long ago, when recreational activities were largely reserved for the privileged upper classes, and the common man was required to toil from dawn until dusk. But all of this has now been changed. No longer is there a special leisure class monopolizing both idleness and opportunity; instead, today, every class is a leisure class. In a remarkably short period of time the machine age has cut the working day in half, releasing, thereby, many surplus man hours for leisure-time activities. And the end is not yet. It is not at all improbable that technological progress in the future will reduce the working day to four or five hours, thus assuring the average man a large amount of leisure time.
But time is a responsibility as well as an opportunity, and, where improperly used, may prove to be a liability rather than an asset. Most people who get into trouble seem to do so in their spare time. The statement, "Idleness is the devil's workshop," is as true today as when it was first uttered, and yet there is more time for idleness now than ever before. Personal debaucheries, such as those discussed in the previous lesson, are in many cases the direct result of the dissipation of leisure time.
Recreation for Profit
Literally the term recreation means to revive, refresh or create anew; in other words, to "re-create." Actually, judging by the dissipation and immorality frequently carried on under its name, it could sometimes better be spelled "wreckreation" with emphasis on the "wreck." Leisure time is potentially a blessing, giving opportunity for rest, hobby activities, sports, social life, cultural developments, and artistic expressions; but it is often wasted or used unwisely, wrecking both health and character, and leaving misery in its wake.
The major reason for this perversion of leisure-time opportunity is the profit motive. Business interests, seeing the great increase of leisure that has taken place in the modern world, have capitalized upon the situation for the sake of private profit. It used to be that practically all recreational activities were in the home or other primary groups, were largely spontaneous, and were free. Now, however, there is an all-too-common feeling that to have any fun one must go out of the home and spend money for recreation. When the desire for profit comes in conflict with the welfare of the public it usually suffers, which explains the reason for so much of the corrupt in our leisure-time activities. With a few exceptions, commercialized recreation is concerned with profit rather than morals, and it is this disregard for the best interests of the public that accounts for so many of its lurid appeals and unfortunate influences.
Then, too, commercialized recreation is so often of the passive variety that, aside from any directly unwholesome influence it may have, it fails to restore or revive, and it may even actually fatigue or destroy the personality. We are too frequently spectators and too infrequently participants in leisure-time activities to get the most out of them. It is better to be an active player than a passive watcher or listener; to be really effective, recreation must be active and creative.
Another unfortunate tendency accompanying the profit motive in commercialized recreation is the development and acceptance of the "thrill" psychology. Thrills and super-thrills seem to characterize the spirit of the times. The real danger in this, of course, lies in the fact that continual thrills of the physical and sensuous type tend to blunt the finer sensitivities of man, blinding him to the deeper spiritual joys of life, and causing him to feel that he must not stop until he has tried everything. And, in such a frame of mind, when the "giant racer" variety of thrill no longer satisfies, he will sometimes seek for bigger thrills in robbery, sex crimes, etc.
The Picture Show

the movies each week in this country, and that about twenty-eight million of these are minors. Since the picture show has such a widespread appeal as this, it might be well to inquire into its possible influence upon moral behavior.
There have been a number of studies dealing with the relationship between movie attendance and moral conduct, and they all point to the same general conclusion; namely, that movies are frequently a stimulus to delinquent conduct, particularly with youth.
The picture show is able to effectively dramatize and glamorize different modes of life to make them appealing. As a result, Hollywood sets the styles in mannerisms and morals as well as in clothes. Children and adolescents, because of their immaturity, are especially impressionable and susceptible to influence. In pictures dealing with crime the bad man usually gets caught, it is true, and the implication is usually left that "crime does not pay"; but to the adolescent the criminal's glamorous life is often more vivid and thrilling than is the somewhat dry fact that he pays in the end. Love and sex themes frequently arouse the romantic and sexual emotions and condition the attitudes of youngsters, with sexual experimentation and promiscuity as the result. Many a juvenile delinquent, and no few number of adults, have testified that they got their start in crime from the movies.
All of this raises the question of control, and there are essentially three points at which control might take place; (1) In production centers. The Will Hays office of censorship in Hollywood is successful in eliminating many of the objectionable features of each play, but it needs to go farther. The Catholic Legion of Decency, and other similar pressure groups, though smaller, have succeeded in wielding some desirable influence on movie producers, but they are too limited in their scope and power. There is need for a united movement on the part of all the public to demand that better shows be produced. (2) In the community. Some states and a few local communities have censorship laws to control the type of shows allowed to come in, but in most places the market is open to anything that will bring profit to the company regardless of whether it is good or bad from the standpoint of the community. Citizens need to develop a community consciousness to the extent that they will tolerate only the better pictures to be shown. (3) In the home. Fortunately, no one is compelled to see a movie just because it is shown in the community. But there are too many families that seemingly don't care where their members spend their time; too many parents who are indifferent to their children's absence or who may even send them to a show (without first informing themselves as to the kind of show) in order to get them out of the way. Movies of the right sort can be valuable aids in character building, but there are too many of the wrong sort and too many parents who either don't know or don't care. Of such is immorality bred.
The Public Dance Hall
Dancing itself is innocent enough, but the conditions and temptations surrounding the average public dance hall of the day are enough to
make of it a real moral problem. LESSON DEPARTMENT 637 Men and women of all ages come together without chaperonage and usually in search of a thrill. Many are unescorted. The hardened and depraved rub elbows with the innocent and adventurous. Lights are dimmed. The orchestra plays softly and romantically. Liquor is brought and passed around. ?Pickups" are made for the rendezvous after the dance. Regrets and despair too often await the dawn. Some may think that this picture of the public dance hall is painted overly dark; but if it is, it is only for the sake of emphasis. All that is said here is true, and while it must be recognized that many can attend the public dance and remain unharmed, yet it must also be admitted that many others cannot; and therein lies the danger. If liquor, unescorted attendance, and pickups could be eliminated from the public dance hall, it would be far more acceptable from the moral point of view. Parents and community workers should insist upon these reforms, but in the meantime they should strive to keep their children free from all such dangerous, immoral exposures. Miscellaneous Decreative Patterns Although the picture show and the public dance were singled out for special analysis, it should be remembered that there are a great many other patterns of "recreation-al" behavior that are decreative or demoralizing in their results. And some of these are even more destructive than the two mentioned above. Thriller radio programs, comics, and pulp magazines all join with the movies in furnishing morbid and distorted stimulation to the young. It might be just about as logical to speak of "our radio-made children" or "our comic-made children" as it is to speak of "our movie-made children," for in each case the effect of continuous exposure upon attitudes and behavior is rather profound. Overstimulation and overexcitement with emphasis upon the brutal and the gruesome is characteristic of a proportion of them all. It is even difficult to understand why the so-called comic magazines are spoken of as comics at all. As for the dime novel and the pulp magazine, the slant is so definitely toward sex, erotic love, and cheap adventure as to be revolting to all mature persons. But youth are not mature, and to permit them to be exposed to some of this vicious literature is a moral crime of considerable magnitude. The night club, the cabaret, the roadhouse, the pool hall, the "beer joint," the gambling den, the taxi dance hall, and the burlesque or "girl" show, are a few other types of leisure-time activities that frequently lead to extreme personal and social disorganization. Alcohol and sex used for profit, either singly or together, create very dangerous situations, regardless of the name of the institution used as a shield. Often, too, the problem is primarily one of sheer idleness, starting in boredom and ending in mischief. Personal disorganization resulting from the misuse of leisure time is not restricted to the big city with its high-powered temptations and its opportunities for anonymity. The small town is frequently just as much to blame, and this for the very reason that it fails to provide wholesome and challenging activities and interests. But, whatever the community, idleness when permitted to exist creates real moral problems. Loitering on the streets, "killing time" in the pool halls, and seeking thrills in the back alleys, all start with idleness and end with trouble. Leisure Time and the Community The blessing of abundant leisure time, which has come to man and which will increase all the more in the future, carries with it a great moral responsibility. That responsibility is to use this extra time well, to let it be the means of lifting man up to the better and nobler things of life. When dissipated, leisure time leads to both idleness and debauchery, examples of which we have seen throughout this lesson. When utilized in line with moral principles, it leads to richer experiences, deeper appreciations, and loftier satisfactions. Our job is to eliminate the waste and the wreckage of leisure, and to put in their place the finer and more wholesome things of life. Students of crime and delinquency frequently point to the lack of adequate cultural and recreational facilities in the community as a major factor in immoral and anti-social conduct. This is especially true with reference to the young. With time on their hands and the desire for fun, young people often find themselves faced with the limited alternatives of loitering on the streets or participating in some relatively unwholesome commercialized, leisure-time offering. No wonder so many of them get into trouble. It is high time that more of our communities awaken to the problem, as some are now doing, and provide decent places and programs for the enjoyment and development of the young during their leisure hours. Recreational centers should be developed, appealing cultural programs should be offered, ct cetera. Schools, churches, service clubs, and other groups can give valuable assistance to such a movement by talking it up, offering their facilities for the various activities, and by manifesting their willingness to co-operate in the larger, integrated community program. There is much that can be done on a community basis to check delinquency and develop morality in the young. Latent resources that could be utilized to combat these evil influences are abundant in every community. But to accomplish this, as it should be accomplished, will require the interest and united effort of all. Problems for Thought and Action 1. Explain how the great increase of leisure time has been possible. Why does leisure time, sometimes prove to be a liability rather than an asset? Give examples. Do you agree that most people who get into trouble do so in their spare time? Explain. 2. How does the profit motive lead to corruption in recreational activities? Give examples. Why has the increase in commercialized recreation paralleled the increase in leisure time? Is commercialized recreation always "wreckreation?" Defend your point of view. What is spectatoritis? Is it good or bad? Discuss. 3. Why are picture shows so influential in the shaping of attitudes and conduct? Show how movies have contributed to delinquency (as a basis for this the class leader may want to have someone give a brief review of Forman's Our LESSON DEPARTMENT 639 Movie Made Children). Select one or two recent picture shows that most of the class would have seen and criticize as to good and bad features. How can the quality of pictures produced and coming into the community be controlled? What is the particular responsibility of parents regarding movie attendance? Suggest ways and means of selecting the better pictures and of directing the attendance of children. Describe the major evils attending the average public dance hall, and explain why each is an evil. Is dancing itself an evil? Why not? Can you suggest any ways of eliminating the evils of the dance without eliminating dancing itself? Show how certain radio programs, comics, and magazine materials are unwholesome. If possible, ask class members ahead of time to listen to certain radio programs for children. Criticize these programs in class. Bring selected comics and pulp magazines to class as a basis for discussion. Describe other disorganizing leisure-time activities that may be in your community. 6. Why does leisure time. Carry with it a moral responsibility? Discuss ways that your community might organize for a better use of leisure time, and show how individuals and groups can help. Could the Relief Society do anything about this problem? Discuss. 7. Why is the Family Hour program, recommended by the Church, so influential in shaping attitudes and conduct? AUTUMN Beatrice Knowlton Ekman Wearing her golden shoes, her flaming shawl And russet gown, Fleet-footed autumn glides through field and town And lone birds call.   From veils of haze, soft purple shadows fall On pastures brown. Where milkweed pods, with fluffed white down, Are prodigal. A hawk hangs motionless upon the sky Above the lane. Where wheel-worn dust, thirsting for drops of rain. Is sifted dry. Hedged farm land spreads a checkered counterpane Of flaxen dye. Where barren fields of furrowed stubble lie.... Winnowed of grain. The Cover: "Turkey Time," Salt Lake Tribune Photograph.  Priscilla" from a painting by George Henry Bougbton Copyright, 1915, by Eugene A. Perry

Thanks Be to God Christie Lund Coles O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is good: for his mercy endureth forever. Let the redeemed of the Lord say so, whom he hath redeemed from the hand of the enemy (Psalms 107:1-2). RECENTLY, I stood with hundreds of others at a service marking the end of war. Against a sky tinted with the last debate shades of sunset, with one star glistening like a symbol of hope above a back-drop of majestic mountains, I saw the American flag hoisted high upon a flagpole. I watched it flutter... Clean and bright and beautiful beyond utterance above me. I heard the band play "The Star Spangled Banner," and I felt a thrill throughout my entire being. I felt pride and gratitude and humility. I thought of free men all over the world who were witnessing a similar scene and feeling hope reborn within them. I thought how indescribably horrible it must have been for our boys to see that beautiful flag lowered to the dust while an enemy flag took its place. I thought of the prophetic words, '1 shall return," and their triumphant fulfillment. Then I thought of the boys who had given their lives. Some of them I had known since they were small boys with great dreams in their eyes, with great promise in the future. And even as my heart ached for them and for their parents and wives and sweethearts, I felt that could they see the flag as I saw it now, could they hear the band playing, they would feel that it had not been in vain. Most of all, I thought that never should a people have been more humble, more prayerful, more grateful than the people of America should be today. Never should we have felt more to bend the knee and bow the head in thanks and praise, than in this hour of victory and peace. For the terror of the past years is ended, the guns of war have ceased, men are turning again to their plowshares and their normal pursuits. We stand a free people, we stand still a nation victorious, a light unto the whole world, a beacon to peace and good-will. Thanks be to God. Yes, we have done great things, we have preserved liberty as a hope for all the oppressed and downtrodden people everywhere, we have proven that right is more powerful than might. We have come a 'heartthrob nearer to the end of wars.' Surely, no one can doubt the destiny, the supreme power, that has seen us through our dark days. Surely, no one can be too proud, too ungrateful, to kneel and give thanks for the preservation of his home and his God-given rights of freedom and justice, as well as for the gift of life for loved ones, for the future that lies ahead, even as the Pilgrim fathers before us offered thanks for their crops, for their preservation, for the land that had been a refuge. Page  Actually, we are not so different today. After their waiting and anxiety, after their travail and fear, they saw their crops ripen to abundance, saw the fruition of their hopes. They knew that God had seen fit to bless them. For, with all our scientific knowledge, with all our physical and mental accomplishments, how helpless we are, really, with all our learning, how frightened and alone in the presence of death or illness or the unloosed elements. How in need of the humble faith that looks upward and trusts, and gives thanks. Yes, giving thanks is an integral part of prayer. Christ thanked his Father in heaven for manifest blessings. He walked among men with implicit and utter trust. What father could turn a deaf ear to this? And what child is not better and worthier for having the grace of gratitude, for gratefully saying "Thank you," for a favor requested or granted. Many thinkers believe the secret of the miracles Christ was able to perform was his unerring trust in the Eternal Father. He gave praise and thanks, and he had implicit faith; he never for a moment doubted the power of God to do that which was asked in sincerity and tri4st. A person without gratitude is like a tree that is barren of fruit, that receives' bounteously, yet lacks the grace to give of itself in return. There were miracles in this war, many of them; there were strong men who had boasted of their unbelief brought to their knees when they were overcome by adversity beyond human help. We all know of those shipwrecked, thirsting and hungering men who literally saw manna come out of heaven, who saw the sky respond to their need of water when they could bear their thirst no longer. We all know of those miraculously saved in fox-holes, in the air, on the sea. These men were forced to their knees in humility, they came back different men, men purified by prayer and by thanksgiving. We, as individuals, as a nation, as a world, need the purification of these two things: prayer and thanksgiving. So, let us lift up our hearts, let us humble our spirits and be contrite and prayerful, let us thank our Father in heaven that we have been preserved, that we have been given another chance to make a good and a godly world, to find lasting peace, to do away with want and prejudice of race or creed, to live as brothers in the beautiful and bounteous world he has given us. In this time of rich harvest, this time of reunion, of happy homecoming, this time of serious meditation on man's dependence on a higher power, this time of gratefulness for a belief in a life after death, of immortality and eternal progression for those who have so nobly given their lives, let us humbly say. Thanks be to God. Thanks... Be... To God! Be

loose_match.content: Excerpts from the Idaho Falls Temple Dedicatory Prayer President George Albert Smith r\ thou great and eternal God, Father of our spirits, Creator of the heavens, the earth and all things therein; before whom all things are present, whether past or yet to come; full of mercy and love, guided by wisdom, judgment, and justice in their perfection; in humility and with thanksgiving and with our hearts filled with gratitude unto thee, we approach thee through thy Beloved Son, Jesus Christ, our Elder Brother, who, through the great and exquisite sacrifice wrought out for us, magnanimous beyond our comprehension, made it possible that we might approach thee in humility on this great occasion, with our petitions and supplications, in this House which we have built to thy most holy name. We pray thee that thou wilt cause our hearts to be purified in thy sight and our faith in thee to be multiplied and increased so that our petitions may reach thy holy habitation and be answered in our behalf in accordance with thy infinite wisdom and love, and grant that the blessings we here seek may be fully realized to thy name's honor and glory. We thank thee for having raised up thy servant, Joseph Smith, and that thou didst endow him and inspire him and reveal unto him thy great purposes, and that thou didst manifest thyself and thy Beloved Son unto him, and didst cause holy resurrected beings to minister unto him and to confer upon him the Holy Priesthood after the order of thine Only Begotten Son, and its appendage, the Aaronic Priesthood. We are grateful unto thee for those who now preside over thy Church. We pray that thy servant, George Albert Smith, may be endowed of thee with a vigorous body and mind, with health and strength, and with the spirit of prophecy, seership, revelation and of presidency, and with the ability to magnify thy great and holy name. Bless his faithful counselors, Joshua Reuben Clark, Jr. And David Oman McKay, whom thou hast given to advise him and assist him, that they may possess great wisdom and excellent judgment in all matters pertaining to thy Church. Grant that perfect love and confidence may exist in this thy Presidency that they may be united as one in all things pertaining to thy work. Page 645 Confer upon thy people, and especially upon thy leaders, in all of their various callings, thy precious gifts of love, wisdom, and judgment, knowledge and understanding, faith and the spirit of testimony, light, intelligence and capacity, and every attribute, blessing, gift and qualification either necessary or desirable for them to have and enjoy in order that thy great and important work may go forward to consummate its glorious purpose. Father, wilt thou preserve thy saints in the unity of the faith, in the way of truth, in the bonds of peace, and holiness of life. We pray for the daughters of Zion. May they be preserved in virtue, chastity and purity of life, be blessed with vigorous bodies and minds, and with great faith. May they develop into true womanhood and receive choice companions under the new and everlasting covenant for time and for all eternity in thy temples provided for this priceless privilege and purpose. May they too be privileged to enjoy as the fruits of their union a noble posterity which, we pray thee, may be taught at their mother's knee to believe in thee and in the divine mission of thy Beloved Son. We thank thee, O our Father, that thou didst restore that grand and glorious principle of marriage for eternity, and didst bestow upon thy servant the power to seal on earth and have it recognized in the heavens. We acknowledge this privilege as one of thy most marvelous gifts to us. May all the youth of thy Church come to know of its beauty and of its eternal importance to them, and to take advantage of it when they marry. May they, our Father, on the other hand, realize fully that the glorious opportunity for eternal companionship of husband and wife, and the power of eternal increase, may be forfeited by them if they fail, through negligence or indifference, to conform to thy requirements, or if having taken advantage thereof, they may still, through improper conduct, lose their blessings. Wilt thou, O Father in heaven, remember the Relief Society throughout the length and the breadth of the Church. May those who engage therein, either as officers or teachers, be abundantly rewarded for their unselfish sacrifices, for the services they render, for their acts of mercy and kindness, and for their ministrations to the sick, the needy, and the unfortunate. We pray thee that in their homes and in their responsibilities they may enjoy the rich companionship of thy Holy Spirit. With deep gratitude in our hearts we thank thee that the nations have ceased their warfare and the destruction of human life. We thank thee, O God, for the choice land upon which we reside, and for the marvelous promises thou hast made concerning America, that it should be free from bondage, and from captivity, and from all other nations under Heaven so long as the inhabitants of the land should worship the God of the land who is Jesus Christ.

entries.title: Remembering the Birthday of President Grant

loose_match.content: Remembering the Birthday of President Grant THIS November, President Grant would have been eighty-nine years old had his life been spared a few months longer. Members of the Church and a multitude of friends, all over the world will remember President Grant's birthday with gratitude and thanksgiving, appreciating the faithful and inspired service he rendered, his love and kindness that reached beyond his family, beyond his Church, and to an ever-widening circle of friends and associates. Among the hundreds of letters which poured into the homes of President Grant's family, following his demise, there are none which exhibit more reverence for him and more understanding of his true greatness than those written by his grandsons in the armed forces. Excerpts from some of these letters follow: PRESIDENT HEBER J. GRANT Page 647 In Italy, these words were penned to Sister Grant: I'm sure that Grandfather was a great man. His calling as God's servant was evidence that he was one of the Lord's choicest children. I'm thankful tonight for my noble heritage. I'm thankful for having known and loved my Grandfather. I'm thankful for his testimony of the gospel because it has helped me to understand life and the part I should play in it. Many times a person who has achieved greatness is misunderstood and his personal life is very often one of trouble and unhappiness. But such was not the case with Grandfather. One of the greatest joys he experienced was the love and understanding which you and his children have shown him. You created a home, and though sometimes it was in foreign places, it was ever a haven of love and peace where he could come. From Germany, another grandson wrote: It is hard to express one's thoughts at this time. They are intermixed with memories of the greatness and goodness of Grandfather's life and the knowledge that he is now released from a burden which he carried so cheerfully during his last years. Knowing this, we have little cause to mourn. We can only express our gratitude for the wonderful influence he had on our lives and the secure knowledge we have that we will be with him again. An expression written in Panama reads: I have relived a great many of the moments I was privileged to spend in the presence of this truly great man, and in so doing I have been awed at how richly endowed he was with character and personality and a fine zest for living. The greatest lesson he leaves for me is in his unquenchable spirit. My fondest memories of him will be of the times when we drove in the mountains with the top down on the car while he sang with a gusto which came from his deep and abiding love for the natural works of God. All of us whose lives have been touched by his owe him a debt which can be paid only in emulation. In Austria, another grandson had this to say: It is comforting to know that on the other side of the veil the joy of Grandfather's coming back and the joy of those welcoming him back far surpasses the sorrow of those who are left behind and who must part with the one they love. I feel so distant and far away to try to help at a time like this. However, there is always one thing that I can do and that is to go on living so that I may merit what has been given me and, in so 4oing, bring happiness to those who have given me so much. In Newfoundland, these words were penned (again to Sister Grant): I have always been proud that I have known both you and Grandfather. Your perfect family life, your cheerfulness, your generosity, your high standards in everything, make me humble indeed in your presence.... Please remember that I am one of the thousands who loved Grandfather and remember, also, that I love you. Space will not permit an inclusion of more excerpts from these letters, except for one which strikes the keynote of President Grant's greatness, for, after all, it was the gospel which made him great. This letter was written by a grandson in the United States: I have never been able to express how proud and humble I have always felt about having him for a grandfather. If I do my best all my life, I wonder if I'll be worthy of the heritage I have,... Thank God for the gospel of Jesus Christ and the absolute realization it brings that we shall see our beloved Grandfather again.

Dinner at Nora's Martha. Robeson Wiight BUT I'm not taking no for an answer,  Maddy  Nora said over the phone. "Ross and I have planned on this Thanksgiving dinner with you and Bruce as usual, and we have the turkey and all the trimmings ready to cook."  I told you I was sorry." Madeline couldn't help it if her voice was listless. Tt isn't any use." Nora made no attempt this time to be diplomatic. "Maddy Pearson, I'm your oldest, and I think your best friend. You're being selfish. Your staying home and refusing to eat isn't helping Tommy any. He wouldn't want you to be that way. And what about Bruce? He might enjoy coming." Madeline closed her brown eyes for a moment and shuddered. "You couldn't possibly understand, Nora," she said wearily, patiently, "I couldn't stand it all of that food on the table. The smell of it... When..." "I understand more than you think," Nora Blake said bluntly, "And I'm still expecting you and Bruce over here for dinner tomorrow." For a second Madeline wanted to scream at her. But she didn't. She hadn't been able to cry since word had come of Tommy's death. She'd tried it. There was pain, tightness, despair. Nora didn't know all of that, and there was no use trying to explain it to her. Instead, she said, "All right, Nora, we'll come. But don't expect me to eat anything. M-my stomach couldn't take it." "Bring your bottle of milk along, then," Nora ordered, "but I want you to be over here tomorrow with Bruce, or or I'll never speak to you again as long as we live," she finished quickly, and hung up. Madeline gasped and placed the receiver on the hook. As long as we live, she thought, as she turned from the phone. That didn't mean a thing. There's nothing to live for now... With Tommy gone.... Bruce was watching her from his easy chair by the radio. Tommy's tragic death didn't seem to affect him as much as it had her. He went about his business with the same cheerfulness as before. His gray eyes were a little less twinkling and his hair had threads of silver, but he seemed the same. Of course, no one could understand how a mother would feel. "That Nora again?" Bruce asked. Madeline nodded and pushed back a strand of brown hair. "She seems to have lost well, all sensitivity of feeling. You'd think she'd try to understand how I feel." Bruce shook his head slowly. "But she's right, you know. And we've had Thanksgiving dinner with her and Ross for twenty years... Since the first year their Jim and our Tommy were born." Madeline winced and her lips curled themselves in a grimace. "You, too?" How could he know the pain inside her heart... Almost unbearable at times? "All people Page  think about is eating... Eating... Filling themselves with rich food..." Bruce got up and began to pace back and forth in the room. "You ve got to face this thing out, Maddy/' he said kindly, "Going without food won't bring Tommy back. Going without food wouldn't have helped him when he was alive in that prison camp, slowly starving to death." She turned on him, fists clenched, mouth contorted. '1 was the first to give him food. I taught him how to eat with a spoon then a fork-how to feed himself. But I couldn't help in that prison camp. I wouldn't have minded so much his dying in battle... That's a kinder way... A quicker way. I see him... Every night... Lying there... Suffering... And thinking of the good food he always had at home. He loved my cooking... I know he must have thought of that... To the very end!" B RUCE stopped pacing and the look he gave her was strange. Almost as if he felt that she was to blame for everything that had happened. "Other mothers have lost their sons, Maddy." She forced herself to look at him intently. "Other mothers? Did their sons die in prison camps?" She caught her breath in a dry sob. Bruce came over and took her hands. "Everything will iron itself out, Maddy, if you'll try. Thanks for telling Nora you'd go. It won't be so bad. We have to learn to start mingling with people." Nora and Ross opened the door and helped them off with their coats. "Sure swell, seeing you folks," Ross said. "You look well, Maddy. The cold's put roses in your cheeks." "On her nose, too," Bruce said, grinning. Madeline shivered, but it wasn't from the cold. How could they be so callous? How could they joke like that when they knew that never again would Tommy be able to spend a Thanksgiving with them. "Come on in the living room," Nora said cheerfully. "We have two other guests I'd like you to meet." Madeline's heart contracted with pain. "Nora, I can't stay, now. I couldn't meet strangers." Ross took a firm hold on her arm. "Oh, yes you can, Madeline. We hadn't intended having anyone else but us, but these kids needed a home on this day of days. We'd have been heels not to have them here, too." "I want you to meet Sergeant Brent Sherwood, and Corporal Bill Benning," Ross said, guiding her to the young men. "Don't get up boys," he added quickly, at their indication of rising. "These boys have been in the hospital," he explained to Madeline. She felt that all the discordant sounds in the world had come into the room and were dinning in her ears. Her head was heavy and her eyes felt out of focus. These young men in uniform became a conglomeration of blurred features; and somehow Tommy's face became mixed in with theirs. She couldn't speak. She wet her lips and tried to keep the terrible pain from making her faint. As from a distance, she heard Ross saying, "Mrs. Pearson hasn't been well for several months, and the difference between DINNER AT NORA'S 651 the cold outside and this warm room has been a httle upsetting." She allowed herself to be led to a chair. She didn't dare look at the young men, who had so courteously acknowledged the introduction. She would have to try to convince Nora that she was too ill to remain if Nora would just come near enough to speak to. But Nora had disappeared into the kitchen. The young men chattered with Bruce and Ross, and through the fog of her grief, Madeline heard them laughing and joking. How could those soldiers laugh and joke like that? Didn't they ever remember the boys who hadn't come back? They were here in this room, whole, hearty, and happy. Gradually, the haze around her cleared and she leaned back against her chair. Nora meant well, and she was fond of her. But Nora's son, Jimmy, pal of Tommy, was still safe, and was coming home soon. Nora came bustling in from the dining room, eyes sparkling, cheeks flushed. "Dinner is served," she said. Ross came over to help Madeline to her feet. Nora went over to the boys. "I intend to have two gentlemen lead me to my table," she said, beaming up at them. She could beam, thought Madeline bitterly. She hasn't lost her son. The taller. Sergeant Sherwood, picked up a cane from beside his chair. Madeline was startled. She hadn't noticed the cane before. It had been lying on the side she couldn't see. "You'll have to wait until I get Bill here up on his new feet," he said grinning. "The guy's all right once he gets on them, but he's only had them two weeks." To her astonishment and inward horror. Sergeant Sherwood tapped his own right leg with his cane, "My old wooden leg makes me awkward without my cane. It's new, too. But Bill here doesn't need a cane, the lucky bloke, once he gets standing." MADELINE couldn't move, but sat fascinated, while Sergeant Sherwood helped Corporal Benning up from the chair... Or tried to. It was evident that Bill was deliberately teasing and trying to make the process more difficult than it really was. With exaggerated grimaces and clowning, with pithy comments, he finally sighed and groaned. "Can't make it. Brent, old man. Guess I'd better go back to the old cash and carry system." Brent Sherwood, almost double with laughter, gave one last heave and pulled Bill Benning to his feet. For a long moment Bill stood there, swaying uncertainly, as a doll does when it has been set on its feet not quite on the straight. Then he gave himself a tiny hitch, and held out his arm gallantly to Nora, and said, "Madam, will you honor me? Old Brent here has all he can do to manage his cane." And Nora, laughing up at him, said, "I am indeed honored. Corporal." They led the way to the dining table, Bill taking careful strides on his new feet. Madeline finally managed to extricate herself from, her chair, clutched Ross's arm and followed, with Sergeant Sherwood and Bruce bringing up the rear. There they sat, around the beautifully decorated table, the immense brown turkey glistening on its silver platter, candlelight throwing a soft glow over all. The two boys made twelve-year-old noises at the turkey. Madeline didn't look at them. On a Thanksgiving day, two years ago, her Tommy, so young, so boyish, so sweet, had done the same thing. And his last Thanksgiving dinner had been rotten fish heads. Tommy... her heart cried.
She toyed with the food on her plate, and the little she put in her mouth was as tasteless as paper. The boys ate like ravenous children, exclaiming, complimenting Nora until she looked as if she'd float to the ceiling if she hadn't been weighted with food.
"Oh, boy! won't I ever remember this dinner," Bill Benning said conceitedly, as Nora served him a slice of mince pie, one of pumpkin, and a piece of fruitcake for the second shelf. "When I get my insurance business going, and get me my wife, the Blakes are coming to our house for dinner. And Trudie had better be been learning to cook."
Bruce said, around a bite of pie, "Where are you going to start this business?"
"In my home town." Bill's tone indicated that anyone was foolish to suggest anywhere else. "I got a girl there. She's full of plans. I have quite a bit saved when you've got a girl at home you don't spend much money except to send her stuff."
MADELINE found herself thinking that this Bill had personality, and that's what it took, as much as business ability, to get ahead in insurance. How could he look forward to a future, though, without feet? She suppressed a shiver. How could a girl...
"My girl says it isn't feet that make the man... and she's right... as if I didn't know," Bill went on. "I can go tramping through the woods... in all kinds of weather... can get my feet frostbitten."
Both boys laughed at this, but Madeline wanted to cry. A boy with no feet probably couldn't play tennis, couldn't dance...
"But what do you plan to do, Sergeant?" Ross asked Brent.
"Oh, I figure a pegleg's good for almost anything. I've got me a big ranch out west. That is, I sent the money to my folks when I was in the hospital, and they bought it for me. I'll raise horses... race some of them, maybe... I like to ride. Always have. Swell setup."
Madeline, for the first time since she arrived, felt the urge to speak directly to them. "You can ride horses?"
He grinned at her. "Yes'm, it'll be a cinch. Great future in the horse business."
"Oh, boy! when this is all over, the future sure is going to be hectic," chuckled Bill, "lots of competition... the spice of life... my dad always says."
"What tells you turn out," Brent scoffed.
As Madeline heard their laughter this time, it didn't shock her as it had at first. A great future, these boys said! How did they know? Their future was filled with handicaps. If Tommy... And sad-denly, she know that Tommy, clean, wholesome Tommy, was taken care of. A boy as fine as he would be in eternity. She realized that Tommy had no handicaps. But these boys had theirs... and their future was facing it. After all of the horror they had been though they still seemed to feel that the world was a wonderful place. If they had been frightened once, they had recovered.MADELINE knew, then, that she hadn't been frightened or grieved because she was feeling sorry for Tommy half as much as she had been feeling sorry for herself. Nora was right. She had been selfish. Her sadness came because she could no longer have the comfort of Tommy's presence, the opportunity to mother him. For the first time since word of Tommy's death, she felt a loosening of the tension and pain within her. Her heart quieted. These boys with their love, their faith, their fearlessness... They had come from blood-drenched battle fields, but they hadn't allowed the suffering to show. They were now thinking of it, not as suffering, but as a ticket of admission into the future. They had learned that they must watch their step; but that didn't mean that they thought the world was hopeless. She remembered when she was young... She could almost hear her grandparents saying that this younger generation was not as stable as the older folk. As people grew older they seemed to become more frightened... Many of them because they weren't strong enough in their faith. She knew now that the future held whatever one wanted it to hold. Bruce had known that... Dear Bruce... But she hadn't allowed him to try to tell her what he knew. For the first time since Tommy was taken prisoner, she felt sure that she could weep. If she were alone she would lie on her bed and let the tears bathe and refresh her awakened heart. But she was not alone. She found herself turning to Sergeant Sherwood and smiling at him. "If you gentlemen are still in this part of the country at Christmas time, my husband and I would like to have you spend Christmas with us." At Nora's pleased start of surprise, she said, "Tou and Ross, too, of course, Nora. And Jimmy will probably be home by that time, too."

There will surely be more sports and greater crowds with an all-time record for gate receipts. The impetus for this frenzy was provided by wartime games and recreational promotions. RICHARDS AND AB JENKINS IN A 1901 MODEL CAR Page 654 SPORTS AND UTAH'S CENTENNIAL 655  Photograph by Bill Shipler AB JENKINS IN THE "MORMON METEOR" AT THE UTAH SALT FLATS A lot of speeches were made and countless words written concerning the need and importance of sport while the great conflict was on, all of which was quite unnecessary. I have never believed that sport needed any defending. It is a big part of American life the American way. It can stand on its own. There are times when one can "protest too much." There are just three reasons why sport will go on from here to new standards of performance and patronage: 1 "The majority of the people want it. Last year, supposed to be a "flop" year, was one of the biggest in the realm of sports. 2 It is something needed in the way of physical fitness, where to attain any decisive result, it must be based largely upon the competitive side. 3 Sports provide a most useful vehicle for the raising of funds for charities. This was proved during the war. It could do a much bigger job in peacetime with the proper organization. One of the major promotions that was hit hardest during the war was automobile racing. This is one activity which is not only a sport, so far as public interest is concerned, but is of great importance to mechanical research. It is fortunate for our State and our people, that we have, right here, the world's greatest automobile racing course. MORE records have been set on Utah's Bonneville Salt Flats than any other place in the world where sport is projected. None of this activity was indulged in during the war for obvious reasons, but the Utah race course is certain to get a brisk going over from this time on. The developments and advancements of automobile and airplane construction and operation are to come in for still further tests and perhaps much that is valuable to the automobile industry will be revealed. It is reasonably certain that John Cobb and Sir Malcolm Campbell, the famous English racers, will come here again with new types of cars and fresh ideas on record breaking. Photograph courtesy A. Lee Christensen SKIING AT ECKER HILL, NEAR PARK CITY, UTAH It was my privilege to help promote their previous appearances here, and I can testify as to the great good they did for Utah and the Bonneville Salt Flats through the favorable impressions they received. I expect to set still more records with a 3400-horse-power car, which will be 1,000 hp. More than any automobile I ever drove. It will also be the lightest of my several racing automobiles. What is planned in automobile racing during the Centennial year. Is typical of what is scheduled in other sports. College football will go big league in Utah that year. It is planned to bring one of the major aggregations of the country, such as Notre Dame, Southern California, or Michigan, to play the University of Utah. Another nationally important eleven will be brought in for Utah State and another for Brigham Young University. The new American Basketball League, in which Salt Lake has taken a franchise through the sponsorship of a club by the Deseret News, plans for the national AAU tournament for the teams of that league SPORTS AND UTAH'S CENTENNIAL and the University of Utah to make a bid for the national collegiate championship. Salt Lake has already been granted the national clay courts tennis tournament for the Centennial, and the Professional Golfers' Association is considering a petition to bring the P. G. A., biggest event in golf, to one of the Salt Lake courses. 657 In baseball, swimming, wrestling, boxing, bicycle riding, rodeo and every game played in Utah, something extraordinary is being planned by the Utah Centennial Sports Committee.
