LESSON DEPARTMENT Theology Church History Lesson 13?Stakes of Zion Increased Dr. H. Wayne Diiggs For Tuesday, February 5, 1946 Objective: To suggest the firm and sure way the Lord has of extending his purposes in the earth. AS a people, the Latter-day Saints have always closely linked the temporal with the spiritual. To them, faith without works is dead. There can be no true religion unless the widow and the fatherless are visited, the naked clothed, and Church members hold themselves unspotted from the world. This practical wisdom found in the Epistle of James, the Prophet Joseph Smith applied in all his teachings. He always set his followers to work knowing that if they did good, they would be good. On August 2, 1833, only three years after the organization of the Church, the Lord gave a revelation to Joseph Smith which touched upon the practical plans for bringing about the future city of Zion (Doc. And Cov. 97). There was to be work ahead for the saints. In June of that year, labor had started on the Kirtland Temple. Presiding Bishop Edward Partridge shortly before had been sent plans for this. Also he received a blueprint in words of the future beautiful cities of the world. How effectually the cities would combine the aesthetic and functional may be seen by the following: The first city plat was to be one mile square, divided into blocks containing ten acres each, except the middle range of blocks, which were to contain fifteen acres each. All the blocks, except those containing schools and public buildings, were to be divided into half-acre lots, four by twenty rods each. The dwelling houses were to stand twenty-four feet from the street. The plat would accommodate from, eighteen to twenty thousand inhabitants, and they would need twenty-five buildings for schools and public worship. These buildings would be temples, and none would be less than eighty-seven feet by sixty-one. There were to be no barns or stables in the city, but these were to be situated on lands laid off for that purpose, on the north and south sides of the settlement. The farms would be situated east and west of the city, but the tiller of the soil, as well as the mechanic, merchant and others, would live in the city. Page 695 "When this square is thus laid off and supplied, lay off another in the same way," the Prophet wrote, "and so fill up the world in these last days" (ANDREW JENSON, Historical Record, page 635; see Doc and Cov. Commentary, page 751).
What room would there be for slums with their attendant political vice, vice, and crime in such cities? The farmer, the worker, and the professional man here might live in mutual fellowship for the good of all and of society. There, country and city life would be blended and the place of religion and education be one.
But who could plan and build such communities? Certainly not those motivated by selfish interests of worldly minds. These centers of spiritual and social life could only come from a people who were "pure in heart, for this is Zion" (Doc. and Cov. Sec. 97:21). Consider the words of the Lord, that Zion first is a state of mind, before ever it is a city or place upon the earth. God requires the heart as well as the hand. Without a first of these there cannot truly be a second. He has said he will plant the stakes of Zion throughout this land. Stakes in the first meaning of the word are pointed pieces of wood, to be driven into the earth as a mark for support to which may be tied lengthening cords used to hold above a flexible covering, adjustable to the changing conditions and needs of those who seek shelter beneath. In a religious sense, the meaning becomes even more significant. Stakes are territorial units of the land governed by presiding officers of the Priesthood of God, who plant within the marked boundaries the wards and branches of the Church, (which unitedly work for the common good of all the
souls who will be pure in heart). To set, therefore, the stakes of Zion would mean to build up the wards and branches of the Church from the standpoint of helping men to realize material as well as spiritual values. Ward chapels and stake tabernacles have with steadily increasing number been built within the large centers of urban life, as well as upon the rolling rural hills of the farm lands.
President Brigham Young, in realizing the wise and far-reaching effects of the Lord in setting the hearts and hands of his people to work in the cause of redemption, commended upon the Prophet's vision of this great work as follows:
It was a perfect sweep stakes when the Prophet called North and South America Zion. Let us go to and build the temple (i.e., at Nauvoo and then building) with all our might, that we may build up the kingdom when established and her cords lengthened. It is a perfect knock-down argument, some say; but to the old and faithful elder (and I may say member), who cannot if he is humble and diligent, build up the church (REMARKS, B. H., A Comprehensive History of the Church Cent. I, Vol. VI, page 502).
To bring about this sweep of stakes called for sacrifice and unselfish efforts on the part of the people of the Church everywhere. Filled with the zeal of the restored gospel, hundreds of saints found themselves on their way to the tops of the mountains. The country was wide and the stretch of sky distant. There would be room for all in this land God had prepared. As fast as sufficient numbers could gather, they were sent to colonize the fertile valleys in the domain rimmed round with majestic mountains. With each group went the organizing power of the priesthood to lead in the work of salvation:
... Arise and shine forth, said the Lord, that thy light may be a standard for the nations. And that the gathering together of my saints may continue upon her stakes, may be for a defense, and for a refuge from the storm, and from wrath when it shall be poured out without mixture upon the whole earth (Doc. and Cov. 115:5-6).
Books could be filled with the colorful stories that came to pass with the early fulfillment of these words. To relate but a few connected with the conquering of the intermountain region may stimulate the desire of the reader to hunt more such human-interest stories of the settlement of the West.
One cold January in 1878 where the turbulent waters of the Colorado River cut down through the solid rock below Lee's Ferry, a party of saints under the leadership of John W. Young lined the banks of the stream for a crossing into Arizona. Elder Young was on his way to organize the first stake of Zion there. The barrier of these waters called for sober judgment. More than one adventurer had lost his life in the whirling rapids that washed the canyon walls. But, as though by divine providence, the day the group arrived a bridge of solid ice spanned the danger zone. While the grip of winter held, the party could pass. First, the driven cattle were thrown, their legs roped, and then they were dragged sled-like over the slippery surface of the frozen river. Heavy wagons followed, often carrying 2,500 pounds or more. One ox was lost, being dragged by the chain of loaded oxen that followed their way into the sun-striped cactus
water at a wider place in the river where the ice had broken.
The colonizers continued to come several days after Elder Young and his party had made a successful crossing. Some distance above, at Lee's Ferry, Elder Anthony W. Ivins remained to help these saints across. He made the trip by ferry some thirty-two times.
Among the stories of Arizona's colonization is that of the Mormon Battalion and one of its men, Lot Smith. This soldier and elder later became the first stake president in Arizona. As his first counselor he chose Jacob Hamblin, who was known as the "apostle to the Lamanites" and "Leatherstocking of the Southwest." President Brigham Young instructed this understand-ing elder to feed and not fight his Indian brothers. In order to reach and own, Elder Hamblin often was forced to live on pine nuts. One time he killed crows for his food while on a preaching mission. He became known as a true friend to the Indians because they learned he never spoke with a "forked tongue."
As a member of the presidency of the Little Colorado Stake in Arizona, his kindness and understanding did much to make life enjoyable for the saints who lived the United Order in those communities. A bell called the group together night and morning for songs and prayers and often words of counsel from the brethren. Their work was done in common together. The crossing at Lee's Ferry by the handful of Mormon colonizers in 1878 was but a beginning of hundreds of such migrations made by the saints on their way westward and their way into the sun-striped cactus lands of New Mexico; some pressed on across the arid wastes of Nevada; some braved the biting winds and snow of Idaho and Wyoming; and yet others scaled the rugged Rockies eastward into Colorado. The Rocky Mountain prophecy of Joseph Smith given that August day in 1842, while in his hand he held a cool glass of water that suggested. To him the clear streams of the West, was literally being fulfilled. Intrepid Mormon pioneers played a major role in bringing to pass his words, and in first setting the American flag in the majority of the intermountain states (Children's Friend, "The Stakes of Zion? April 1942). Since those early years of establishing the first stakes of Zion, there has been a steady and impressive growth of these ecclesiastical divisions of the Church. Zion has truly touched both shores of the United States, and enlarged her borders to include parts of Canada, Mexico, and an isle of the sea. At the close of the year 1940 there were 133 stakes of Zion, 1,055 wards, 92 independent branches and 24 dependent branches in the stakes. All the European missions were under the direction of local Elders and were carrying on with marked success under the stress and hardships occasioned by the great war. There were in the stakes of Zion 86,432 men and boys holding the Aaronic Priesthood and in the missions 15,547. There were also in the stakes 95,625 men holding the Melchizedek Priesthood and 9,730 in the missions. The proclamation of the Gospel had been made in nearly all parts of the earth and had been brought to the attention of kings, presidents, potentates and rulers. At the close of this year (1940) there were many signs given spoken of by our Lord as presaging his second coming [Essentials in Church History, page 647). Bennion For Tuesday, February 5, 1946 Objective: To show how charity is tactful and courteous because it is inspired by a reverence for life. Jesus went unto the mount of Olives... And all the people came unto him... And the scribes and Pharisees brought unto him a woman taken in adultery;... They say unto him, Master, this woman was taken in adultery, in the very act. Now Moses in the law commanded us, that such should be stoned: but what sayest thou? This they said, tempting him, that, they might have to accuse him. But Jesus stooped down, and with his finger wrote on the ground, as though he heard them not. So when they continued asking him, he lifted up himself, and said unto them, He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her. And again he stooped down, and wrote on the ground. And they which heard it, being convicted by their own conscience, went out one by one... And Jesus was left alone, and the woman standing in the midst... He said unto her, Woman, where are those thine accusers? Hath no man condemned thee? She said. No man. Lord. And Jesus said unto her. Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more (John 8:1-11). This incident offers an interesting study in contrasting attitudes. The scribes and Pharisees were thinking of the law, of punishment, of tempting Jesus, and had no feeling for the inner life of the woman. Jesus believed in the law of chastity and even enriched its meaning (note Matt. 5:27-28), but he also had reverence for the soul of the woman. He replaced her shame with hope and faith. He handled the situation with tact and graciousness. Even after the multitude left he asked her no personal questions, but simply, "Where are those thine accusers? Hath no man condemned thee?" Think of the hope, love, and gratitude she must have felt as she left with his gracious words to cherish in her memory: "Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more." (Notice, however, that he did not say, "Thy sin be forgiven thee.") Charity has a deep reverence for life and expresses itself with tact and courtesy so that it will not embarrass nor offend nor give pain to an already wounded spirit. A charitable person gives in such a way that the recipient is hardly aware of the distinction between giver and receiver. There is a gentle, quiet, spontaneous, courteous way of giving which is wholly uplifting in its effect. The secret of developing this type of charity is to keep in mind, not the giver nor the gift, but the need and joy of the person who is to be the recipient of one's love and good will. "Charity doth not behave itself unseemly." Literature The Bible in Our Literature. Lesson 5?Bible Influence as Revealed in Our Drama Dr. Howard R. Driggs For Tuesday, February 19, 1946 ENGLISH drama had its beginnings in religion. After plays and pageantry had been banned for centuries because of the vileness to which they had sunk in fallen Rome, the priests began to introduce dramatic elements into church ritual. A simple portrayal of the story of the resurrection or of the angel and the shepherds and the coming of the wise men, might be given as part of the commemorative ceremonies of Easter and of Christmas. Other significant stories from the Bible also might be portrayed?all to bring the scriptures closer to the common folk. What began thus simply with the priests, gradually developed into more elaborate dramatic presentations. A calendar of holy days set by the church opened the way for remembering various events in the life of Jesus at different times of the year. Laymen, as well as priests, began to take part in these religious plays and many of them were performed outside the church. They offered recreation to help lighten the so-called Dark Ages. With the nearing of the Renaissance came other developments. Miracle plays, depicting legends connected with the saints, began to appear; with them came the moralities, or moral plays, in which the various virtues and vices were allegorically presented. In time, these dramas, intended to impress truth and righteous living, were given in the common language of the folk, and performed largely apart from the church. Then groups of "strollers," or wandering actors, would take the plays from village to village or castle to castle. Such a troupe of players, as many will remember, is employed by Hamlet when he would prove the king guilty of the crime that Hamlet feels he has committed. Naturally, with the gradual separation of the drama from church ceremonies, there came other than just religious themes into it. Expansion and development of the histrionic art, following the Crusades and the discovery of America, brought a "Golden Age" of play writing and play acting, especially to England. During the long reign of Elizabeth, the theatre flourished, and plays unsurpassed in dramatic and literary art were created. Those were days, remember, when the drama to succeed had to stand on its own merits. There were no such accessories as electric lights to flash rainbow effects round the players; no scenic settings nor music to accord with the varying emotions stirred by the play. Theatres, on the contrary, were rather crude affairs with a platform on which the actors played their parts. Below them, standing "in the pit," were the common folk; above, in circular rows of stalls, were the lords and ladies or other people of means who could afford seats. It took drama of gripping appeal to hold such an audience.
One playwright and producer who took the challenge in such a situation and succeeded marvelously was William Shakespeare. Not a great deal is surely known of his earlier life. He certainly must have grown up with the drama?probably taking active part in his younger days with strolling players, and helping to shape the plays themselves as he went from place to place. Some basic training such as this, added to his superb natural talent, gave him the wit and wisdom and the art that have made him the greatest dramatist of all time. That he has held the highest place is attested by the fact that for decades hardly a year has gone by without seeing his name on Broadway; and the further fact that thousands upon thousands of students are taught his plays year after year as the finest examples of drama ever created. They live for all time.
Something even deeper than mere genius must explain this phenomenon in literature. Quests to learn the inner secret of his art?and thousands upon thousands through the years have made the search?are about as conclusive as the efforts to learn how the firefly gives its light, or why the skylark rises to heaven when it sings. This, how-
ever, we do know of Shakespeare: he did create plays, a good many of them, that have brought stirring and uplifting entertainment to humanity through centuries. He has left mankind both thrilled and thinking.
May the writer be pardoned here the telling of a personal experience. His first real contact with Shakespeare came at a Saturday afternoon performance in the old Salt Lake Theater. Julius Caesar was the play. This youth sat entranced for two hours?and came out different. He bought a copy of the play, and for weeks thereafter was studying and reciting its lines. It was the beginning of a lasting love for great drama, and the setting of a helpful standard of appreciation.
Not long after that experience he saw another play in the same old theater, Gismonda, it was called. There were thrills aplenty in the colorful drama, with one of America's leading actresses of the day in the stellar role. It gave stirring entertainment, but not re-creation. There was no running out to buy the play, no reciting of lines ringing of truth such as these:
... lowliness is young ambition's ladder.

Cowards die many times before their deaths;
The valiant never taste of death but once.

His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand Up and say to all the world, "This was a man."
?Julius Caesar
Shakespeare had the skill to portray life?outward and inward life; to create scenes that move and stir the heart and leave the mind informed. In Julius Caesar we have Brutus, the man of honor, the idealist, made a prey by scheming politicians. In this, as in all the best of Shakespeare's plays, w6 have situations, scenes, characters that are true to life for all ages. More than this, with unforgettable lines, this master voices truth for all time. There is no preaching of religion, yet in his plays sin does not triumph, but good is the victor even though the story ends in tragedy. Bible influence may always be felt and often seen in his words and lines and allusions to Holy Writ. Just a few illustrative excerpts will add concreteness here: The quality of mercy is not strained, It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath. It is twice bless'd: It blesseth him that gives and him that takes. ?Merchant of Venice *o 4 O, how wretched Is that poor man that hangs on princes favors: And when he falls, he falls like Lucifer, Never to hope again, ?King Henry VIII Had I but served my God with half the zeal I served my king, he would not in mine age Have left me naked to mine enemies. ?King Henry VII Act I This above all: to thine own self be true. And it must follow as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man. ?Ham Jet, Act I Shakespeare's plays, like Milton's epics, and like the Bible, deal with searching problems of life. They reveal sin in its ugliness, but only as a darker background against which virtue and nobility may be more impressively portrayed. His purpose, like that of all high-minded artists, is to inspire a love of the good, the beautiful, and the true. In all this he is in perfect accord with the Bible whether that source of inspiration is revealed openly or not. Successful dramatists since those days of Elizabeth, have followed the basic pattern set by the Bard of Avon. Directly and indirectly their best plays reveal Bible influence. Generally it is to be felt only in the spirit of the play as it vibrates in the scenes and in characters of noble, of lovable qualities. Outwardly it is shown in allusions and quoted lines from scripture. Occasionally, the theme may be taken from the Bible, or, as in the Passion Plays of Oberammergau, it may faithfully portray characters and scenes of Holy Writ. Within recent years the Bible story has been presented rather elaborately in pageantry and moving pictures. One such performance was "The Eternal Road," which was short-lived. Another, ?The Ten Commandments," portrayed the story of the escape of Israel from Egypt, the giving of the Commandments to Moses, and then applied all this in a modern drama. Will Rogers, after seeing this play, remarked, "It is easy to see where God left off in the play, and the movie-picture man began." The spectacle again was short-lived. People seem not to like to have the Bible preached at them, particularly in shows. A Biblical play of comparatively recent creation, which had a longer run" was "Green Pastures." LESSON DEPARTMENT 703 It was, as the author says, "an attempt to portray a living religion in terms of its believers." In this case, the believers were negroes of the Deep South, who with "spiritual hunger and true humility" have adapted the Bible to their everyday lives. Sincerity and reverence, such as one feels in the truly Negro spirituals, vibrate through the literal words, scenes, and characters portrayed. The play recalls lines from Longfellow's Hiawatha: Feeble hands and helpless Groping blindly in the darkness Touch God's right hand in that darkness And are lifted up and strengthened. Plays of the above literal type are not often presented. What usually is seen in the theater is just shows, dealing with folk in all their typical problems and life situations. Among the welter of these presented on the stage, in the photoplays, and over the radio, earnest search must be made constantly to find the few that do bring recreational uplift. It is not unlike digging for gold-one must generally shovel and wash away a ton of sand and gravel to get a nugget. Each one will doubtless recall some play or plays which have been like precious nuggets. Tastes differ, of course, in the drama as well as in other kinds of art. Yet, in the essentials, the play that wins and holds our hearts leaves a clean, wholesome aftermath. It may have been just for entertainment, but as such it brought pure joy and uplift. It may have presented more serious aspects of life; yet it left the audience with new strength and faith in man and God. It is only such dramas that are worth time. Everyone reading these lines will probably begin to list in mind plays that measure up to these standards. No two of these lists would be exactly alike, but that is immaterial. One the writer keeps in treasured memory is Maeterlinck's The Bluebird. It was an enriching experience to follow the two children on their quest for the bluebird, happiness, only at last to find it in their own home. Barrie's Peter Pan, as Maude Adams brought it to us, was another delight?just a sweet little story portraying the joyous, imaginative life of youth. More recently Sherwood's Abe Lincoln in Illinois with Raymond Massey in the title role brought audiences close to the real Lincoln during his developing years. "Honest Abe" speaks to our hearts through the lines. The Bible influence in his life can be felt; it radiates impressively in the beautiful prayer he made for the recovery of the little pioneer boy (see, page 577), and during other dramatic moments of the story. Another heart-lifting play, portraying the life of a great woman, who, with Lincoln, gave her best to help free the slaves, is Harriet. In this convincing drama, recently presented on Broadway with Helen Hayes in the part of the heroine, we are brought closer to the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe, and made to feel her masterful contribution to a challenging cause. Historical drama, provided it is created and acted with artistry, often rises to the highest in dramatic art. One of the leaders in the field of drama, a successful director of plays, an actor with talent as well as a scholar, was asked lately to name one or more current plays that stand out as great drama. "I regret,? was his reply, "that none I know of deserve that distinction except Shakespeare's Tempest/ now being played on Broadway, and the real play there is being obscured by too many scenic effects, too much light and music." "Of course," he continued, "we do have several clever light operas and other shows, good, bad and indifferent, which are gathering the crowds. Performances of this sort come and go all the time. They offer passing entertainment, but not recreational uplift." "Might not a little more Biblical influence in the modern drama be of help in getting plays of lasting worth?" came another question. ?Yes, if it is woven into the play with artistry. Remember, a drama to get and hold an audience, must be good entertainment, first of all. It may be such, as the masters have shown, and yet through fine character portrayal, and natural gripping dialogue, vital life lessons can be impressed. We need more of such upbuilding plays." "How can we get them?" "Well, concerted action on the part of home, church, and school to educate young and old away from what Shakespeare would call "dumb shows and noise," might: help. More good oral reading in the home, more community dramatics, more literary recitals would promote a taste for a higher type of drama than we are now wasting time and money to hear. As with music, this taste must be cultivated. Those who have control over the radio, the moving pictures, and the theater would, I believe, respond helpfully to such united effort for uplift." This leader's comments will have a familiar ring to Latter-day Saints. From pioneer days our people have been taught that every pure enjoyment is from the Lord, and that it is the abuse, not the proper use of such delightful means of entertainment as the drama, that constitutes evil. Wholesome plays have been encouraged for relaxation and recreation, to help us keep our elasticity and to renew our vigor for the sterner drama of life. Now, with allurements of commercialized entertainment in varied forms, there comes a new challenge to every home. A positive way to meet this challenge is to fight fire with fire. The love of uplifting drama, like the love of good music, begins at the hearthside. Mothers and fathers can begin the work and get closer to the hearts of their children through playing stories with them, by helping them get the best out of radio programs and photoplays. It is natural to carry forward these home joys into the encouragement of home dramatics. There should be more earnest group study of the drama by parents and teachers with the purpose of finding plays that are Bible inspired, that promote a love for the good, the beautiful, the true. Concerted effort not only to cultivate appreciation for the highest and best in the drama, but to have it produced on the stage and screen and over the radio, should bring richer, more uplifting returns for all. Should be available in Relief Society stake and ward libraries.) Social Science Modern Applications of Moral Principles Lesson II?Women and Morals Dt. Harold T. Christensen For Tuesday, February 26, 1946 Lesson link: It was shown last time that there is a fundamental relationship between certain leisure-time activities and immoral conduct. The rise of abundant leisure for all classes during this machine age has presented mankind with both an opportunity and a responsibility. But too often leisure time is wasted in idleness or dissipated in debauchery, so that the opportunity it affords is lost and the responsibility it implies is ignored; too often "wreck-reation" crowds out real recreation. Suggestions were made for improving this situation by individual, family, and community effort. Lesson aim: To analyze some of the social and moral problems peculiar to women in this modern world, and to emphasize woman's moral role and responsibility in the field of ethics. 
ALTHOUGH the number of women in the world, under normal conditions, is just about equal to the number of men, the moral influence that they wield is probably much greater. This is because of two special advantages that women have over men in this respect: (1) Their position as mothers puts them closer to the developing child during his most impressionable years, which means that women have more to do with the building of character and the shaping of personality than do men. (2) Their womanly charm, or "sex appeal" as it is sometimes called, gives them a tremendous power and advantage over the male who, in respect to some of the follies of the flesh, might more accurately than women be called "the weaker sex."
But since every opportunity rightfully carries with it a moral responsibility, it is well to ask if women are using this special power which is theirs to good advantage or are turning it to their own selfish use. Are the women of today being good mothers, wives and sweethearts, true to the moral obligations implicit in these roles, or are they using their position and turning their opportunity to their own personal and selfish advantage? Some of each, no doubt, but enough of the latter to invoke real alarm and serious concern. It is primarily to mothers and the sweethearts of
men that we must look for the balance and guidance in morals so sorely needed in the world today.
Before attempting any criticism of contemporary womanly conduct, however, it will be well to try to understand the modern woman in the light of recent social trends. So great have been these changes in society that many women today find themselves confused or lost, not even understanding themselves. And to make matters worse, most discussions on "youth problems" deal only with the boy, and most of the literature on adult delinquency is concerned mainly with the male. It is time for people to realize that the adjustment problems of girls and women in this rapidly changing world are in many ways even more difficult than those of boys and men, and to realize also that one of the keys to morality is moral womanhood.
The Emancipation of Women
Historically, woman has almost always had a role in society inferior to that of man. This is not to say that she is innately inferior or has in any way deserved such a lowly station, but only that man has seen fit to use his greater physical strength and freedom to subjugate and abuse woman for his own self-gratification. And, as a consequence, in virtually all of the dealings between man and woman, man has benefited at the expense of woman. LESSON DEPARTMENT 707 Woman, for example, at times has been confined entirely to the home, deprived of property, bought and sold like chattel, beaten, killed, et cetera; and all because she was woman. But recently in the western world the general trend has been away from all of this, toward an equality of the sexes. Politically, in America, woman can vote and hold public office as well as can man. Economically, she can find employment outside of the home and can personally control her own income and property. Socially, she can enjoy many freedoms that were formerly the prerogative of "men only." Yes, woman has come a long way in her struggle for emancipation and equality. Even so, she has not yet arrived; the fight still goes on. Although there are few legal barriers keeping woman from public office, social disapproval has a very powerful restraining effect. Although woman can and does compete with man in gainful employment, she still, with a few exceptions, does not receive "equal pay for equal work." Although she is more free in the various patterns of social intercourse than she' once was, she is still watched more closely and judged more harshly when she oversteps than is man. There are still laws on the statute books of our states which discriminate against woman in the fields of property, profits, and morals. In these and many other ways America still treats its women in a similar manner to its racial minority groups, nominally equal under the assumption of democracy but actually inferior in the roles they are permitted to play. Some Consequences One of the unfortunate accompaniments of this equality trend is the tendency on the part of some women to mistake identity for equality. In their zeal for freedom many have deserted entirely their feminine roles and charms in order to better compete. They ape men in dress, in speech, in mannerisms; they prepare for and engage in the traditionally masculine jobs; they become coarse, crude, and vulgar. This masculinization of woman cannot help but lead to trouble for it is a perversion of the very nature of things. Since men and women are inherently different biologically, it is well also to expect personalities and social roles of the two sexes to be differentiated. The personal and social relationships of men and women should be supplementary and complementary rather than duplicative; co-operative rather than competitive. Equality is highly desirable, but equality does not require identity. It is entirely possible for men and women to be equal and still be different; they can be equal, each within his own field. An unfortunate consequence of this trend toward equality is the development of extreme individualism and independence on the part of some women, an independence so strong that it ignores responsibility and precludes co-operation. This is not to say that woman should necessarily be more dependent than man, but neither more independent. As woman finds her rightful place side by side with man, the masculine ego will have to adjust somewhat, and rightly so. But let the woman who is wise be neither too impatient nor too aggressive. Arguing, being obstinate, making demands, acting independently, fighting?these do not make one equal or free. Equality is more than the assertion of equality. The question of a career versus a home and family is often difficult for some women to decide. And there is no one answer that will apply in all cases. Some women are successful in having both; either stopping for a short career before starting a family, or fitting it in along with the family, or settling down to a career after the family has been reared. All of these arrangements present difficulties, but the last named is most likely to succeed. Some women choose a career in preference to a family; and some, without any real opportunity for marriage, turn to a career as a second choice or a substitute. A great many women wisely look upon homemaking as a career and, by focusing attention and energy upon their responsibilities as wives and mothers, are able to make the greatest contributions to the moral welfare of society that it is possible for woman to make. Motherhood is the one function that is reserved exclusively for women, and yet, in their scurry for recognition and equality, many are deserting or neglecting even that. Employment and career activities outside of the home are justifiable if they can be successfully fitted in to a happy home life, but for every normal woman the home and family should come first. Men and women should be equal, but it should be a differentiated equality; both sexes should be free, but it should be a responsible freedom; women should be active and creative in their own right, but it should be a co-operative individualism that spurs them on. The Prostitution of Womanhood There are a great many women in this modern world who want the freedom that equality promises without accepting the obligations entailed. They seek for special privileges, for rights without responsibilities; and in order to obtain them they are ever ready to prostitute their virtue, to sell their birthright for a "mess of pottage." Figuratively speaking, they want to have their cake and eat it too. But the idea itself is as wrong as are the selfish and sometimes cowardly methods used to try to bring it about. There is a basic difference between the emotional nature of men and women, a difference that should be well understood if the moral issue we are here talking about is to be recognized. Sex passion is natural and real for both sexes; but with the male it is more elementary, more constant, more easily aroused. Women's sex nature is more complex, more involved with the emotional and mental processes, more easily controlled. This difference helps explain why man is more frequently the aggressor, and the offender, in the field of sex. It also explains why woman's influence is so profound in the lives of men. There is nothing that can contribute to a man's stability and success like a good woman; and conversely, there is nothing that can contribute to his downfall like a bad woman. LESSON DEPARTMENT 709 Man, then, in some ways is weak, weak where woman is strong; and he needs the strength of woman to help him through. But, unfortunately, there are those women who are willing to use sex selfishly, use it as a power device for control over men, use it as a weapon to fight for selfish advantage. Here are some of the ways: (1) They resort to flattery, coquetry, and deceit to lead man on. (2) They cry when they don't get their own way, or otherwise appeal to the man's affection or gallantry in order to control him. (3) They wear clothes which accentuate the anatomical features peculiar to their sex, and they similarly use language and actions designed for erotic suggestion and stimulation. Sometimes these things are done innocently, with a simple desire for attention from the elusive male. If so, the girl may wonder why masculine eyes follow her down the street or why her partner becomes so amorous. But other times it is done deliberately, with the cause and effect relationships well understood. (4) They "gold dig" in courtship, offering favors in intimacy as payment for the money spent; or they marry for money, exchanging sexual favors for a life of leisure and luxury. (5) They enter commercialized prostitution, or they engage in one of the various sexual rackets whereby they seek to extort money from respectable citizens by threatening to smear their names. It is only this last category that is commonly referred to as prostitution; but actually all of these ways in which womanhood is used to unfair advantage could logically be so called, for in all of them virtue and right are "sold" for selfish advantage. Women, too, often leave their natural personalities relatively undeveloped and rely simply upon sex or physical charm to attract men. This is a mistake, for while it gets attention it certainly does not get respect, and after a time even attention is lost. Great women are those who, through the attainment of social and emotional maturity, demonstrate their greatness by the very dignity and power of their personalities. No need for them to quibble about equality or to let down moral standards in order to get along in the world. Conclusions Although the emancipation of woman has confused woman's social roles and led to some moral blundering and considerable exploitation, it has also cleared the ground and laid the foundation for a better world. Woman of today, for the first time in history, has the real opportunity of being man's partner rather than his servant or his slave. Equality for woman is in sight, but if it is taken as mere license it will become a liability rather than an opportunity. Woman's standards of morality are still higher than those of man. Man still looks up to good women for guidance and strength and inspiration. May the time never come when this ceases to be, for man needs the tempering and chastening effect of wholesome womanhood. Woman has a particular moral mission to perform in the world today, a unique opportunity, a deep responsibility. May she not fail! Problems for Thought and Action 1. Do you agree that women wield a greater moral influence in the world than do men? What two advantages do women have in this respect? Elaborate each. Is the problem of adjusting to the changing world as difficult for women as for men? Discuss pro and con. 2. What is meant by the emancipation of woman? From your knowledge of history give examples of the low status of women in earlier societies. Trace the woman's rights movement in this country. Give present day examples of woman's inequality. Do you think she will ever be entirely equal with man? J. Show how the equality trend has often meant the masculinization of woman. Criticize this tendency. Show how some women mistake license for freedom. Criticize. Contrast the double and single standards of morality and show in which direction society is moving. Defend the single standard and discuss ways of obtaining it without lowering morals. How has the emancipation of woman sometimes resulted in the development of extreme independence and individualism? Evaluate this tendency. Analyze the problem of careers for women. Why should the home come first? 4. What is meant by the prostitution of womanhood? Show how the emotional natures of men and women differ. Why does this fact give woman a special moral opportunity and responsibility? What is a great woman? Why do so many women fail to reach real greatness? Selected References Standard Works: Bible: Proverbs 11:22; 31:10-31. Writings by L. D. S. Authors: WIDTSOE, John A., "The Mormon Woman," TheVol. 30 (June-July 1943) pp. 372-375.

WAITING SPRING MabeJ Jones Gahhott The days of garnering from fields and trees Are finished. On my shelves in jaunty rows Are bright tomatoes, amber peaches, peas, And somber grapes and jams. Now autumn goes To join the season's great processional, Her russet cloak already brown and sere; Fall winds and rain sing earth's recessional. Soon winter's ermine garment will appear. And in this time of ending tasks and sleep, And seeming death, when dormant seeds in dry Cool places wait the spring's return and keep Their silent tryst with earth and winter, I Too, wait, rich memories stored within my heart, Until our spring, when we no longer part.

PRAYER OF THANKS Eva Willes Wangsgaard I?thanked thee other years, dear Lord, For flowers and fruit, For beauty that the years afford From seed and root. This year I thank thee for the peace That faith can hold, For love that grew a sheltering fleece Against all cold, And for the wound my heart received. J I murmured when It came, but learned that while I grieved I grew. Amen. He

A NIGHT WITH THE WIND Lottie Hammer Singley Oh, could there be a thing more drear, more doleful Than wind with a coyote's voice and phantom sound That breaks upon the shadowed realm of night Like some wild, questing thing unbound? He strums weird tunes upon my open shutter, And morbidly he flutes my chimney pipe. Chants mournful dirges round my cottage corner; North Wind, be still, just for tonight! In fitful tones the strain continues. With tom-tom beats, he drums upon my sill. Makes windowpanes his clanging cymbals Till sun calls out a fervent ?Peace be still." Page 711 TIDE Myrtle E. Henderson I watch the tide come in on Monterey Bay? The tide come in from the ocean gray; It surges and leaps up over the land, Then slowly recedes with its burden of sand; But the tide leaves the seaweed, the jellyfish, crab-In colors of rose-pink, white, dark green, and drab, And there's beauty in some beyond words to compare In the sea dollar's star and the clamshell rare. Some are fragments, broken and torn apart. Mute tokens of beauty in nature's lost art; They are left on the beach where we frolic and play Wlien the tide has gone out on Monterey Bay. Is the tide like our lives from some ocean beyond. Fathomless, deathless, going eternally on. Each wave a new life as it breaks on the surf And contributes its bit?good or bad?to the earth? Some lives are mere symbols of what might have been. And others are wrecked by their burden of sin, But some lives there are with a perfect design Like my sea dollar's star, my clam's luster and Tine. They have given their best, be it great, be it small. And unselfishly served for the good of us all; When their tides go out and their sands slip away. There is more beauty left than I found in the Bay. Page 712 The Beloved King James Version ?? The Gospel in the Relief Society Educational Program
Elder Howard R. Driggs
I HAVE never faced in all my life so many good and beautiful women. It is an honor and privilege to stand before you, and I humbly pray to God to help me to say those things that will lift us all to higher levels as I am lifted this morning by this occasion. The keynote of what I should like to say is to be found in a song we all love to sing, "Thanks for our teachers who labor with care, that we in the light of the gospel may shine." No other word occurs more frequently or is echoed more beautifully throughout all our scriptures than the word "light." The Savior said, "I am the light and the life," and he advised us to let our
light so shine that a man seeing our good deeds would glorify God, who is in heaven.
If the teacher has one purpose above another, it is to radiate light. It is to illumine truth; it is to lead souls out of the darkness into the light. I think no more beautiful story has ever come to me as to the real work of the teacher than that found in the life story of Helen Keller. As a little girl, Helen Keller enjoyed one brief period of sunshine, of flowers, of bird song, of home joys. Then, suddenly, through dread illness, she was plunged, by being bereft of sight and hearing, into what she called "a prison house of darkness." GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 733 As she came back to consciousness out of that disease, she said she was beating the bars of that physical prison, trying to get back into the light. Yet in that darkness, she might have remained, "had not she come, my teacher, who was to set my spirit free/' Anna Suhi-van, a devoted, understanding, loving teacher, took that little human soul and led her back into the sunshine. She placed in her hands, literally, the key of language to open the prison house. She brought her forth into glorious womanhood, where she could make her contribution magnificently to the world. Every one of US is a teacher, either by example or precept, or both. Every human being is teaching other human beings. It is true that officers and teachers of great organizations such as this are called especially to the privilege. That doesn't take away the duty and the opportunity of everyone of us to lead souls into the light. This is especially true of gospel teachers. Our constant effort should be to make the world brighter, not only today but for all time. We should ever remember this, that so far as the teaching, of the gospel is concerned, the spirit of the gospel is "caught," rather than "taught." One cannot impart the spirit of the gospel by mere words or by a recital of facts. What is in you radiates from you. The Apostle Paul called our attention to this very picturesquely when he said, "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal." We carry the spirit of the gospel with us, or we do not. If we carry it with us, those around us catch the light of our illumination. It matters not whether we represent an arc light or one of less candle power, our business is to light up the dark corners where we happen to be. Dear old Dr. Maeser, with whom I was privileged to associate in the long ago years, said this once to a class of teachers in training: "You can't teach even arithmetic most successfully unless you radiate something of the spirit of the gospel." It is a challenging assertion, but it is true. Oh, of course there are teachers who seem to radiate little or none of the spirit of the gospel, but they would do better with that spirit, and they are always excelled by those teachers who combine intellect and spirituality. NOW, to your educational program. The Relief Society, in its marvelous way, has spread before its members and its officers and all the world, a well-rounded program touching the various phases of basic life. Every lesson that you teach goes to its highest level only when it is taught with a testimony of the gospel in your hearts. Even in your work meetings, where, with nimble fingers, sisters gather around a quilt and begin to sew, and generally to talk, if the spirit of the gospel is not in that spontaneous expression and in the hearts of those who are doing the work, there is something of vital worth lacking. Many a lesson in gospel service is lastingly impressed by those who scatter sunshine and uplifting thoughts while they work. Apply the same truth to your lessons in Church history. In this study one should keep the mind on the final outcomes and not be led into things of little consequence.
When I was a boy I was brought into this temple yard. On an excursion from Pleasant Grove and West Jordan, some of us school children were privileged to come here and see the temple which was being built. It wasn't up to the square. We were permitted to climb the winding stairs to the top and look over the city. One thing I remember was that this yard was littered with stones, with all sorts of tools. We don't see those things now; we see the glorious temple with its spires pointing heavenward.
Every man's life and every woman's life in the building is likely to have some litter about it, but by what do we judge the life? by the outcome. Think of this when you teach lessons in history. Let the gospel light guide this great work.
In the lessons on literature recently given we started out with that found in the Old Testament and in the New Testament. The central aim of all was to bring you back to the Bible, to make you love that book of books. These courses were not planned for one year. One cannot get out the Bible in eight or sixteen lessons. They were planned to lay a firm foundation for reading and rereading and enjoying the Bible. With that work as a basis and as a standard, we are now entering upon the study of the influence of the Bible and Christian teaching on our
literature. I think that we have here a measuring rod by which we can determine whether any literature that has been created is worthy of a place in our home libraries. A book that does not vibrate a spirit of the gospel is open to serious challenge as to whether it goes into the home or not. There is nothing narrow about this; it is soundly basic for all great literature that will be read and reread vibrates to the story of the Bible.
Parents have today the challenge, as never before, to get closer to the literature of their children. Nothing offers a better chance to get nearer to their hearts and souls than good books. We need to cultivate such a companionship in our homes.
May I pay tribute here to my dear mother, in closing. She made our library the center of our home, and she was ever ready to read some beautiful poem, to tell us some story. She saw to it that even though the linen closet or the china closet might not be as richly furnished as in other homes, she had good books in that room where we loved to gather.
We must pay more attention to the spiritual uplift of our homes. We must unite in getting better books in our homes. We must radiate the light of the gospel there.
God bless you in the great work you are doing, multiply and spread it, that the gospel may shine in every home in its simplicity, its purity, with its saving grace, I ask in the name of Jesus. Amen. Relief Society?s Expanding Welfare Service Elder Henry D. Moyle Chairman, General Welfare Committee THIS opportunity to advance the welfare program of the Church, though unsolicited, I can assure you is nevertheless deeply appreciated. Nor do I accept this invitation without a keen realization of the responsibility resting upon me. I appreciate this kind of consideration extended me by your able Presidency. I am sure, to the extent that any of us measures up to that which is expected of him, it is due entirely to the assistance he receives from his Heavenly Father. Without the assurance that he will and does help us, many of us, of whom I know I am myself one, would find our tasks insurmountable.
It is with this spirit of dependence upon the Lord that we must all approach our expanding responsibility?the welfare service of the Church. We must further acknowledge our individual insufficiency in carrying on the work by exhibiting a dependence upon each other. There is none of us in this Church so good or great or endowed with power sufficient to magnify his office and calling in the Church without receiving much assistance and in many ways?from his brethren and sisters in the wards and stakes of the Church in which he lives and works.
Welfare work is no exception to this well-established rule, which we might call "the rule of dependency" of the Church. That which I say is, of course, auxiliary to the priest-
hood, not to any quorum in particular, but to all quorums equally. Our spiritual and temporal welfare is so closely interwoven, there can be no clear line of demarcation between the two. No one can say the Relief Society takes care of either spiritual or temporal or secular? and not both. Every visit made by a Relief Society teacher, every class held, inspires someone to live nearer the Maker, and, at the same time, prepares that same person to take better care of herself and of her family temporally.
So we arrive at the first conclusion in projecting our welfare program into the future, and that is a complete organization is an absolute necessity. By this I mean we must first have a Relief Society fully officered and organized and functioning. Second, a welfare committee in each stake and ward on which the Relief Society presidency of the stake and ward are personally and actively represented. When this is the case, the stake Relief Society comes in direct contact each month with the president of the stake and the presidents of the various priesthood quorums, as well as the stake work directors, and the ward Relief Society meets each week with the bishop and the representatives of the priesthood quorums in the ward and the ward work directors, and, at this meeting, should become intimately familiar with the details of the welfare work of the ward and the needs of the membership, and it is at this meeting that they are assigned their duties and responsibilities for the coming month.
OUR basic problem in taking care of our own, as most of you know, is to render each family in the Church able to care for its own. We have perfected, to a marvelous degree, the production of the welfare budget. It is a pleasure for me to report to you all in time that the record of the Relief Society as an organization in assisting to produce this budget has not only been active in producing the budget, but has helped more than any other single agency in the Church to see to it that the budget, to the extent that it has been distributed, has reached those who needed it. I know of no failure, in the Church, of the Relief Society to promptly and adequately do that which they have been commissioned to do by their bishops since the inception of our welfare program. I am sure your future is to do more. We must increase materially our distribution.
You sisters appreciate that in planning for the welfare of the Church, we must produce more than we distribute in order to provide a surplus from which we can momentarily draw in case of a sudden or unexpected turn of events. It is, however, important while securing this insurance that we do not overlook these needs may not be apparent. By so doing we perform more fully our present responsibility and we are, at the same time, able to determine more accurately the extent to which, in the Church, we can better develop means and
methods of distribution, and in every other way fit and prepare and qualify ourselves to more adequately carry on our work in the future, and, above all, to more fully meet promptly any emergency. This, after all, is the best form of insurance of which we can conceive.
THE welfare work, as originally announced by the First Presidency, divides itself into four major subdivisions. We have thus far discussed the first general subdivision, that of temporary relief, involving, as has been suggested, the production and distribution of the budget. The second general subdivision deals with the permanent security of the members of the Church. A simple illustration suffices to bring out clearly the distinction between these two major phases of our work. A member in need can be given an order on the bishops' storehouse. This is temporary relief just as our budgets are temporary. They must be renewed every year to meet the temporary needs of that current year. It may be possible, however, to find this same needy member employment, and then we have solved his problem and removed the necessity for any temporary relief, and this latter we call permanent security.
Unquestionably, with the termination of hostilities in the world, the finding of employment and thus readjusting the lives of these, our brothers and sisters, whose lives were thrown out of adjustment by the war, is a real major problem. Before this problem has been successfully met, the Relief Society will no doubt have played a most important role in its ultimate solution. I commend this problem to you as one which justifies and calls for the best there is in the Relief Society.
To meet this problem, as well as all other problems that arise in the welfare program, the Church looks to the family for the final solution. If families cannot succeed in making each of their individual members self-sustaining through the united effort of all, there is little hope that any outside agency could add much toward any permanent solution of that individual's problem. As a matter of fact, it is natural for the family to always have some members dependent upon it. That's what families are for. The father and mother are dependent upon each other. It is to be hoped we shall always have children in our homes, and so long as we have children we shall have a family rather than an individual problem.
I WANT to go one step further and say that I hope we always have parents and grandparents in our homes, and, so long as we do, their problems as well as the problems of the children, are and should be the problems of the family. Up to date, at least, in Latter-day Saint homes, we have undertaken to provide in our homes for all members of our family, be they old or young. There has never been any difference in the nation made for spiritual guidance. We depend upon the priesthood of the father as the head of the family, assisted by his sons who may hold the priesthood. We unite the family daily in family prayer, we pray unitedly for the support, maintenance, welfare, spirituality and temporal progress we undertake to take in the family circle to direct
the footsteps of our children and to make the family influence predominate in the child's life, and expect the early training to be followed throughout life. The children in the Church, as they grow to maturity, reflect in their lives the teachings of their mother and father in the family. You mothers in Israel must continue to do your part. As a people, we must never be willing to give to another the rearing of our children.
Some say it is proper for the government to raise our families, send them to school, etc., because some of us pay taxes, or for some other equally absurd reason. We do not pay taxes for the purpose of having other people raise our children or care for our elderly people. If this were the reason for taxes, we might all very well keep our money and do the job ourselves without paying a large proportion of the sums used for that purpose for professional services.
As Latter-day Saints, we believe without any question that to destroy family responsibility is to destroy the family, and with the family destroyed, the Church would be gone. No church on earth claims for the family what we claim. The restoration of the gospel in this dispensation included the appearance of Elijah before the Prophet Joseph Smith in the Kirtland Temple on the third day of April, 1836, in fulfillment of the prophecy of Malachi, "to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children and the children to the fathers, lest the whole earth be smitten with a curse."
We can hardly say that our hearts often go to the cradles of our children or that our children's hearts have been turned toward us, if we are in the frame of mind which permits us to share in any way, shape, or form the responsibility of parenthood with the world or any of its agencies, and if this be true it follows as a necessary corollary that our children cannot prepare themselves for full fellowship in the Church or magnify their offices and callings in the priesthood if they shirk their responsibility toward their parents, or share it in ever so small a way with the world.
May I ask: Can we love our mothers and leave the determination of their needs to laws or strangers, and the provision of these needs to the unearthliness and insecurities of the world? A few years ago, no one of us would have thought in this Church of favoring a law which relieved the mothers of support of the children. However, there are bills in Congress today, in the Congress of the United States, that look toward giving the mothers assistance for their children, without any relationship to need. In other words, any mother, if these laws were passed, as they have been passed in other countries, would be assisted by the government. The government does not recognize the father as the head of the family for obvious reasons. Dealing with the mother, the question of legitimacy or illegitimacy of the children involved need not be questioned. Need we say more?
The question might be put rather bluntly and boldly in these words: Do we as a people so far worship money that we are willing to the slightest degree to relinquish parental control of our children for gold?
In projecting the ever-expanding welfare program of the Church, we call upon the Relief Society as an organization and all of its members individually in faith and humility to answer these questions directly, and to be a direct influence in our own families for maintaining family unity, family integrity, family faith, and family loyalty to the ways of the Lord.
The Relief Society, like all other organizations in the Church, is confronted with the necessity of converting our saints to the simple fundamental principles of life and of truth everlasting, and to avoid the conflicting philosophies and theories of men in the world. To accomplish this purpose is to accomplish the purposes of the welfare program. We must gather Israel to the standards of our Lord.
Need we say that to be married for time and eternity in the house of the Lord by the priesthood is but the first step in the eternal scheme of family progression? The first step becomes as naught if we fail to continue to go forward in righteousness, maintaining the sacred relationship of family life and assuming all the responsibilities incident thereto throughout life, as we hope to do throughout eternity.
The Relief Society can and will, I am sure, expand its service so far as necessary to keep our brethren and sisters in the fold and to give to the priesthood of the Church the kind of an example and the encouragement through love and affection which will induce them to fully magnify their position in the family and in the Church; and that this may be our happy lot, I pray in Jesus' name. Amen. Relief Society Leadership President Amy Brown Lyman THE type of leadership which the Relief Society wishes to develop is the type which Jesus exemplified when he said, "I am among you as one that serveth" (Luke 22:27). In this same verse he says that it is greater to serve than to be served.
The service to which he dedicated his life was a service of unselfishness, self-sacrifice, and helpfulness. It was divinely inspired, was born of brotherly love, and safeguarded by the conception he held of the sacredness of the human personality. It was intelligent service resulting from keen observation and long years of study and preparation, and most important of all, from divine guidance.
It is assumed that as a boy Jesus lived a normal, peaceful, protected life in a humble house where he was trained to labor and work and to live in the fear of the Lord. It is evident that in he grew up he became an industrious worker, a careful observer, and a profound student, that he gained much knowledge by his own effort, and through prayer and devotion to our Heavenly Father he was blessed with great wisdom. Even at the age of twelve in his interview in the temple, he astonished the learned doctors with his unusual knowledge and attainments.
What a glorious example and pattern of work, observation, and inspiration for leaders and teachers was his! He was perhaps the greatest of all
leaders and teachers, our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ.
The success of any enterprise depends largely upon its leaders. It is to them that people look for guidance, encouragement and inspiration.
Relief Society, with its many fields of activity, requires many workers and as the years go by and new avenues of service appear, new and additional workers, with new and additional preparation and experience, will be needed. Leaders are needed for executive work and for class teaching; for choral work and dramatics; for art-needlework and plain sewing; for homemaking and household management; for training for parenthood and family life; and for social welfare work. And with frequent changes in executive officers, practically all the members are called sooner or later to lead out in some activity and thus assume some responsibility.
One of the first requisites of Relief society leaders is to live the gospel. They should aim to be living examples of what they advocate and teach, being "doers of the word, and not hearers only" (James 1:22). They should conform to all the standards and requirements set for Latter-day Saints and be true to the ideals of the Church and of the gospel. They should honor and respect the priesthood and should hearken to any instructions the priesthood offers. They should practice what they preach and preach what they practice. They should cultivate spirituality and thus increase and strengthen their own testimonies and the testimonies of those whom they lead. Relief Society leaders should also seek to enhance their general scholarship and learning which will increase their ability and bear fruit in their efforts to lead and influence others. They should have some familiarity with the standard works of the Church. They should know something about the history and the background of the Church and its leaders. They should be familiar with the history, background, activities, and accomplishments of the Relief Society, and of the women who have directed its work. It is sometimes mistakenly claimed that only those who are born leaders or are born with an aptitude for leadership and teaching can succeed as leaders and teachers. Experience in Relief Society over a period of many years has demonstrated that this is not a correct conclusion and that leadership can be developed. The Society has seen women grow and develop as they have accepted calls to serve, and have sought the spirit of the Lord to guide them. It has seen women changed, yes, almost transformed through Relief Society service. Many at first too timid to take any part, have, through study and prayerful effort and practice, become resourceful, successful officers and class teachers, able conversationalists, and strong, well-poised individuals. They have learned much about how to meet life successfully, how to adjust to their environment, and how to get along and live and work with others. They have learned to be patient, tolerant, sympathetic, and understanding, and their love for humanity, which is one of the most important elements in leadership, as it is in life itself (brotherly love, if you please), has increased with the years of their service. In closing, I should like to salute all the leaders of Relief Society throughout the whole Church, all the leaders, past and present, who for one hundred years have guided successfully the destinies of this great and mighty organization. May the Lord continue to bless us all is my earnest prayer. Relief Society Membership President Louise Y. Robison IN a Relief Society meeting last season, the class leader had followed the outline for our work in the literature of the New Testament so inspirationally that, for the hour, we lived with the Savior and his disciples. It had taken us to a higher plane, and we had the desire in our hearts to live nearer to our Father in heaven. At the close of this meeting, one of the members came to the class leader and said, "I would love to have time to study the gospel as you have done, but it seems that home duties call me away from study." The understanding class leader said, "Yes, I know; I have taken care of my house all of my life, but I have never been told, nor do I believe, that my Heavenly Father gave me this precious earth life solely to do these things. Couldn't you try to adjust your time so that some of it could be used for the eternal principles? I have been taught through the teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith that we are saved no faster than we gain knowledge, and that a person cannot successfully serve our Heavenly Father without the knowledge of his laws."
Of course, the element of time is a consideration, but each woman has twenty-four hours of time given her each day to use as she desires, in her own way. Now, most of us, in buying our bread and butter for our families, go to the place where we have confidence in the goods, though the food may last only until tomorrow. But when we go to a place where we find good thoughts, where we learn ideals that we can take home to our children, it is of great importance! The home is the laboratory of the souls of those entrusted to our care, and a good idea, a good book, a good thought, or a prayer is of great importance, as we were told today by Brother Driggs, in this home that produces high ideals.
But there are so many interests, and we naturally look around and think, which is the most important to give for our time. And the question arises, How about Relief Society? What does it offer its members?
First, Relief Society offers elevating, beautiful friendships. The best friendships of my life have been formed through the Society, and
Our meetings are called together, and the first thing is to remember Him in song?which brings a sweet worshipful peace. Then the prayer is offered, a humble prayer offered by one of our humble sisters, but asking for that precious gift, the gift that God will send us?his spirit, which is light and truth.
This is followed then, and is the setting for the theology lesson which teaches us the will of our Father in heaven and his laws that will prepare us for his kingdom. Then, in testimony meeting, we have the opportunity of telling each other of the kindness of our Heavenly Father to us and of the beautiful principles of the gospel, and just as sure as we come in contact with his spirit, we take it to our homes. It is this spirit that builds up the faith of our children.
The second Tuesday of our Relief Society is more of a social day. We meet more informally, we learn to take care of our homes and our children, and we give service to others in our Welfare Plan, that we with better part may ask for God's blessing at the close of day.
Then, the study of the literature of the New Testament, that wonderful part of the Bible that inspires us with higher thoughts; and the innumerable poems and stories and songs, inspired by these truths, raise the standard of culture in our homes.
The fourth study is a practical study of character development, of honesty and morality and truth. Where these are taught in the home, supplemented by the faith that has been developed, children are fortified to meet life when they cross the bridge from the home to the work of the world. Nor are we left alone. Our Father in Heaven is as much interested ln our children?more so, even, than we, and he has said to us: *'Be thou humble; and the Lord Thy God shall lead thee by the hand, and give thee answer to thy prayers" (Doc. And Gov. 112:10). Is there any promise greater for us to receive in return for the time spent properly? Active membership in Relief Society makes this promise secure through the beautiful lessons provided for us through the inspired teacher or class leader, and through a prayerful study of the principles of the gospel of Jesus Ghrist. Membership in Relief Society is offered to all women who seek to live the better life. I leave my prayer and my blessing for these fine women, the Presidency of this organization and the General Board, who, through the priesthood of the living God, have been given the torch to light, to lead us into perfection, to make our homes clean and pure, that there will be no evil come in. I pray that the stake presidents may receive this light and carry it to the wards, and, most important, that the ward presidents may receive this light, and that they may have the blessing in giving and interpreting it to the individual members, that we will all, when we leave here, turn to our Father in heaven, that these precious souls that he has entrusted to our care, our children, may be pure and clean and sweet. May this be our lot, I humbly ask in the name of Jesus Ghrist. Amen. Feed My Lambs" Presiding Bishop LeGrand Richards IT should not be hard to say something to a group like this.
