GENERAL SESSION, AFTERNOON OF OCTOBER 4, 1945 Wartime Activities of Our European Relief Society Counselor Gertrude R. Garff HOW wonderful it is to meet in Relief Society general conference again! How privileged we are to be able to assemble and listen to the counsel of the President of our Church. I think we have never appreciated this privilege as we do now because we were not granted the opportunity of gathering in conferences during the war years. We rejoice that this opportunity has been restored to us. Today in this great gathering are Relief Society women from most of the stakes of Zion, and most of the missions of the Church are represented by the presence of Relief Society mission presidents or Relief Society mission presidents who have only recently been released. However, there is a great group of loyal, faithful Relief Society women who have no representation here today, with but one exception, and who, I know, are with us in spirit if not in the flesh. They are our European Relief Society sisters. My sisters, we in the United States have been in constant communication with the Church authorities. Many of us could listen to the conference proceedings over the radio. Also, we were visited quarterly at stake conferences by Church authorities, and at any time we could write in to headquarters and get any counsel and help that was needed. Many of our missions have been handicapped by the lack of missionaries, but they did have mission presidents and Relief Society presidents sent from headquarters to preside over and lead the work there, and were in communication with the Church most of the time. In spite of these handicaps, they accomplished a wonderful work in both war and regular Relief Society activities. Some even started welfare plans and had singular success with these ventures. Today, I wish to pay tribute to our sisters in Europe. These women who have carried on Relief Society work under handicaps that would be discouraging even with missionaries in their midst. Since the fall of 1939, when the European saints sang "God Be With You Till We Meet Again," while waving goodbye to the missionaries on board ships sailing to America, our European brothers and sisters (with the exception of the British who have had good communication with Church headquarters) have had very little direct communication with Church authorities and the leadership was placed in the hands of local brethren. They have suffered tribulation beyond our comprehension. The Church and auxiliaries through Brother Thomas E. McKay, Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, have made every effort to get lessons and communications to these good people. Barring accident to letters and lessons enroute ?Norway and Denmark were reached through Sweden; Germany, France, Belgium, Czechoslovakia and the Netherlands were reached through Switzerland; and conversely, any word we received reached us by the same route. Occasionally, we would get and send Red Cross messages; but they took six to eight months to get to their destination, and were only a few words long. However, we were thankful for the information received, though scarce, and, now, since the cessation of hostilities, many letters bearing foreign postmarks have arrived and the stories they tell are of great interest to us. So that these sisters may have a part in our conference today, I am going to tell you of some of their activities. Can you imagine our wards with none of the brethren present to conduct the meetings?to administer the sacrament? Quite generally throughout the European mission, and especially in Norway, Germany, and Switzerland, the men belonging to the Church were in service or had gone underground. The Relief Society women were called to hold the people together, to conduct all the meetings. They even had singing practice and in some places the Singing Mothers' groups were very active. The Relief Society visiting teachers were given added responsibility as there were no men to do ward teaching. Where it was possible and there were older men holding the priesthood, they would visit the branches periodically and ad-minster the sacrament. At all other times it was the Relief Society women who carried the full responsibility of keeping the Church membership together. With the beginning of the war the Relief Society plunged into war work along with their regular programs. In Britain, under the direction of Sister Anastasiou who is here with us today, the Relief Society, among other things, gathered clothing for refugee organizations and received a gracious letter of thanks from the council in charge of distributing this clothing. ONE of the most touching incidents to come to us from Europe is the story of Sister Zippro, the Netherlands Relief Society president. She was willing to face alone the dangers of an invading army in order that members of the Church might receive assistance from the Relief Society. After hostilities between the two armies ceased, this dear sister, knowing of the terrible destruction of Rotterdam, concluded to ride her bicycle (the only means of travel because train travel, etc., was thoroughly disrupted) sixty miles from Amsterdam to Rotterdam. She found many of the families living with other members, as they had lost all earthly belongings when their homes had been completely destroyed by bombs. She immediately ascertained their needs and started to raise funds from among the other members to help those most affected by the invasion. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE Her bravery and devotion to the ideals of Relief Society under such trying and perilous circumstances are worthy of our highest praise. Nor did our Relief Society sisters confine their benevolent work to their own missions, but gave generously of their resources to those of another country. The Oslo Branch Relief Society gave a dinner for the; old people of the branch and the food was furnished by the Danish Relief Society, otherwise no festival could have been held as food was almost as scarce in Norway as anywhere in Europe. Both the Swedish and Danish missions obtained food permits at regular intervals and sent food into Norway to be distributed among the Norwegian saints. It is amazing to note that in such a terrible period of our world's history, new Relief Societies were being organized. I want to read an excerpt from a letter to Brother McKay from Elder Fritz Johanssen, the Swedish Mission President: Between August 7 and 22, together with District President Claus A. Person and Sister Astrid Johanssen of the mission Relief Society board, I made a journey to Finland. The little Society was organized at my first visit shortly after the winter war 1939-40 to a regular branch. This time we had the great pleasure of baptizing three persons. This time I was inspired to undertake the Finland journey and at the same time write an additional part of its gospel history as far as Finland is concerned, namely, that the first female Relief Society was organized there. Time and again we felt as when the Lord through the Prophet Joseph Smith 747 organized the first Relief Society in the world. All of the letters I have read coming from Europe tell of the terrific need for clothing. Clothing is, of course, rationed, but even those with money cannot find the necessary items to buy. Our members in Denmark have gone stockingless for a year at a time and shoes are never seen in the shops. As is generally the case, the children are suffering the most. Now permission has been granted to send eleven-pound packages into all the missions except Germany and Czechoslovakia; and I am happy to report that packages are being sent by our Central Welfare Storehouse to the branch and Relief Society presidents for distribution to the needy members, which include nearly all since money is not involved. There just aren't any clothes to buy of either good or bad quality. My dear sisters, what inspired these women to perform these unselfish and thoughtful deeds? It was their membership in Relief Society, their knowledge of the purpose and ideals of Relief Society, that gave them the courage to undertake those difficult tasks. It was the Relief Society organization that empowered those women and made their efforts to gather funds and clothing and to send food to members in another country effective. Without this organization, they could not have been prepared to take over the responsibility of handling the work of the branches when they were left with no priesthood to officiate. Their letters thank us for our prayers in their behalf.Let us give thanks for these faithful sisters and brothers for their trials have indeed been greater than ours. In closing, I wish to bear my testimony. I am thankful for the gospel, for the meaning it gives to my life. I am thankful for the opportunity of serving the Lord and I feel to express with Moroni of old: And awake, and arise from the dust, O Jerusalem; yea, and put on thy beautiful garments, O daughter of Zion; and strengthen thy stakes and enlarge thy borders forever, that thou mayest no more be confounded, that the covenants of the Eternal Father which he hath made unto thee, O house of Israel, may be fulfilled (Moroni 10:31), Dream for a Relief Society Building Counselor Marianne C. Sharp T WOULD ask an interest in your faith and prayers for I feel that words are very inadequate to express the feelings which are in my heart today. I am grateful for the privilege we have as sisters?as mothers always working for the salvation of our children and as Church members striving for the furtherance of the work of the Church?to meet together once more in a Relief Society general conference. I am grateful, personally, for the opportunity I have to work in the Relief Society under Sister Spafford who is true and faithful, and I want to thank my Heavenly Father for this privilege. I love the Relief Society. I love the sisters in the Relief Society and have joy in association with them. Wherever I have lived or visited in the Church I have felt the close bond of love and service which links together the members of the Society today. The members today, however, are only links in a great chain of sisters which reaches back to include the valiant and great women of the past 103 years, and will stretch forward to encompass those yet unborn who will devote their services to working for the good of others, always seeking at the same time to improve themselves. I am thinking particularly this afternoon of those sisters who have gone on before. Ever since Sister Lyman appointed Sister Spafford and me to help prepare the book A Centenary oi Relief Society to commemorate the hundredth birthday of the Society, I have felt very near to the Relief Society leaders of the past and the faithful members who are the mothers, grandmothers, and great-grandmothers, even great-great-grandmothers, of the members today. They have stepped out alive for me from the pages of the Woman's Exponent and from the minutes of the General Board. Their testimonies have increased my testimony. I have shared in their joys and sorrows and, as nearly as one can, I have entered into their desires for the upbuilding of Relief Society. As we studied this history of the past, we read of one great dream which had gone unfulfilled. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 749 It is of this unfulfilled dream I wish to speak today. In order to introduce it, I will take you back forty-nine years ago yesterday to October 3, 1896, to a general Relief Society conference held in the Assembly Hall. Aunt Zina Young was the president of the Relief Society at that time and with her on the stand sat her three counselors, her vice-presidents as they were called, First Counselor Jane S. Richards, Second Counselor Bathsheba W. Smith, and" her third Counselor Sarah M. Kimball. It was near the end of the afternoon session that, according to the minutes taken by Sister Emmeline B. Wells, then secretary: President Zina D. H. Young, in her remarks, opened out upon the subject of a house for the Relief Society, to be owned by them. Women had done so much to help build other public buildings and temples that they had no means to build one for the Relief Society. President C. O. Card had said when they lacked the means to go on with the Logan Temple and the men were to be discharged because there was no means to pay them for their work, Sister Jane S. Richards raised five hundred dollars in the Relief Society of Weber County to keep the men working, and that stands as a memento to the sisters forever. Vice President Sarah M. Kimball confined her remarks to the subject of a house for the Society. She felt it a humiliation to be without a place of our own; we had contributed to all public places and at all times. Now we want to have a house and we want land to build it on and it should be in the shadow of the temple. It should be a place to receive strangers in when they come, a place where letters can be written" from and information given, I think we should vote on this matter, whether you representative women want this building or not; we want to put it to vote. Sister Kimball told the sisters what Joseph Smith had said in Nauvoo to the sisters of the Society there and had given them a lot belonging to the Church and a house on it which could be repaired and made useful. Now, said Sister Kimball, I want to ask you sisters if you want such a building as I have described. The motion was put and the vote was unanimous. Sister Kimball added, if you want this proposition carried out, then see how much can be done. The interest in building a house for the Relief Society continued strong and money began to be collected, however through the next ten years there also ran the fear, expressed quite often by those dear, faithful sisters as once stated by Sister M. Isabella Home?"don't branch out too largely at once, there is not much to do with, and the Relief Society must care for the poor.? In view of this great financial responsibility which they felt was theirs, the money was not quickly forthcoming, but the dreaming and planning went on. Their plans called for kitchens, pantries, banqueting hall, cooking utensils, a furnace and closets and a room for the janitor, and offices upstairs, "with library and bureau of information, that will be in the best sense educational, and be open to all members of the society, and where lectures may be given by distinguished professors in all branches of science, art and literature, and on general topics." In 1900, the Young Ladies Mutual Improvement Association and the Primary Association joined forces with the Relief Society with the hope that together the three could raise enough money for a suitable woman's building. March 1901, The matter was presented to President Lorenzo Snow who, in was reported to have said: The women must have twenty thousand dollars before commencing the house; in fact, before we could put a spade in the ground or have the land measured off, and when we had that amount on hand he would give the deed of the land, and we could be as sure of it as you will of happiness when you get to heaven. In speaking to the Relief Society at an outing at Saltair, July 9, 1901, President Snow said in part: You who are present today are members of the oldest organization in the Church outside of the Priesthood. The Relief Society was organized nearly sixty years ago, with 18 members (my sister, Eliza R. Snow being the secretary) by the Prophet Joseph Smith, under the inspiration of the Lord; and from that day to the present it has gone on without interruption growing in strength and usefulness, until today it is recognized as one of the most powerful forces for good in the Church. You are now 30,000 strong I am told, with a building fund of nearly $5,000, and with upwards of $100,000 worth of property in your possession. In addition to this you are the only ones among the Saints who are doing anything in a financial way against a day of famine. Your work in this direction is most commendable, and I hear as a result that you have 103,783 bushels of grain, together with an amount of flour and beans, safely stored against a time of need, as well as $3,331 to expend for the same purpose. In a letter of July 1901 signed by the First Presidency, Lorenzo Snow and Joseph F. Smith, it stated: We commend the undertaking [of a woman's building] and have contributed a valuable building site opposite the Temple, valued at $18,000. Sister Zina D. H. Young, President of the Relief Society, died in August 1901, and, in October 1901, President Lorenzo Snow passed away. The new president of the Church, President Joseph F. Smith, called Bathsheba W. Smith to be the new Relief Society president, and the plans continued to progress under her administration. The site which has been described on which a three-story building of yellow pressed brick with a stone foundation was to be built for a woman's building became the Bishop's Building?Relief Society donated $8500 toward its erection and was given quarters in it. The first Relief Society General Board meeting was held in it December 3,1909. This, in brief, is the story of the dream for a Relief Society building which was never built. It is a story of heartache for the Relief Society women who had planned and worked for it for so many years. Relief Society today, however, has already outgrown the space that would have been given it in the proposed woman's building. What seemed a tragedy may prove a blessing and joy to Relief Society in the future. I am thankful for the Relief Society women of the past. I am thankful for their vision. They were great and noble women, women who had faith in their own cause, who loved Relief Society, but who knew that the welfare of the whole Church was above all their welfare. They humbly accepted the decisions of the Church authorities with faith as being in their best interests. They were obedient. May we in our day be as devoted and as faithful? and in all things may we render as full and as unstinted an obedience to the authorities of the Church as did our sisters of long ago is my prayer. A Relief Society Building to Be Erected President Belle S. Spafford THIS is a glorious day for Relief Society, a day for which we have longed and prayed, knowing full well it could come only when the nations should still the guns of war. We are grateful to our Heavenly Father that the hostilities which have engulfed the earth, spreading destruction and breaking hearts, have ceased. We acknowledge his goodness that so soon after the disruptions of war we are privileged to meet in a general Relief Society conference.
This is the first general Relief Society conference to be held since the Society observed its 102th birthday. We are today setting our feet forward on the second century of Relief Society history. As we approach this new era, we do not anticipate any new nor great departmental purposes of the Society as set forth by the Prophet Joseph Smith and reiterated by each of the succeeding presidents of the Church.
The past is a force that is alive, and, like all living things, is growing and maturing while preserving a pattern that can be recognized and defined. From the past we inherit not only patterns and standards, but vision, strength, insight, faith and courage. The past has passed on to us, too, as a part of our heritage, its unfulfilled dreams and desires and bids us keep faith with it in regard to these, for these, too, are a constant invitation to advancement and progress.
Sister Sharp has brought to your attention today a deep-seated and sincere desire that has persisted in the hearts and minds of Relief Society women year after year as the century has rolled by?the desire for a Relief Society building, one that would beautifully and adequately represent the women of the Church. This desire, born and nurtured in the past, is today firmly rooted in our hearts. And, entering as we are upon a second century of Relief Society, a strong and growing organization rich in the blessings of the Lord, this seems the right and appropriate time to bring to fruition this dream of the past, to erect a building that shall stand a monument to Latter-day Saint women and a credit to the Church.
Our Church is the foremost organization in all the world with regard to women. The restored gospel gives to women a position of dignity and respect. It recognizes their spiritual and mental powers and their right to use their inborn talents to the full. Latter-day Saint women have been organized under the priesthood after a pattern of the priesthood and have been provided unlimited opportunities for development. The gospel teaches that women have an appointed place in the plan of salvation and that the Lord loves his daughters as he loves his sons and that the promises, blessings are the same for both. It, therefore, seems entirely fitting that a building should be erected as a symbol to all people of the lofty position accorded faithful daughters of our Heavenly Father in the gospel plan.
Nurtured by a Church recognizing woman's true position, women have, in turn, given full devotion to the Church. This has been true with regard to the building program of the Church. Even before the women were organized as a Society in Nauvoo, they banded together to help feed and clothe the men working on the Kirtland Temple. It was with the desire to aid the work of building the Nauvoo Temple that Sarah M. Kimball, in 1842, invited her neighbors to join with her in forming a "Ladies' Society." When the Prophet Joseph Smith was approached regarding this matter, he invited the women to meet with him and some of the brethren a week later, at which time (March 17, 1842) the women were organized as the "Female Relief Society of Nauvoo."
Lucy Mack, mother of the Prophet, spoke of the importance attached by the women to their activities in behalf of the Nauvoo Temple, as follows:
There was but one mainspring to all our thoughts and actions and that was the building of the Lord's house.
Relief Society women have given of their best according to their circumstances and conditions, toward the building, furnishing, and beautifying of temples erected by the Church.
Not only have Relief Society women been vitally interested in the building of temples but they have been generous in their donations to stake tabernacles, ward meeting houses, and other Church buildings, generally raising funds for these edifices as well as building funds,
cooking and serving dinners or conducting bazaars which have taken weeks and months of tedious preparation.
Yet, after more than one hundred years, during which time they have actively participated in the building program of the Church, they stand today with no home of their own.
The continuing growth of the Society, with the continuous expansion of the various departments connected by the General Board, also demand that provision soon be made to more adequately house the general offices, the temple-burial clothes, Magazine, welfare and other departments.
With the consent of the First Presidency, and with your support, it is our intention to go forward immediately with plans for the building and for financing its erection. It is our desire to have the building belong to the women of the Church and to have every Relief Society woman feel the pride of ownership in it. It is our desire to have the building not only house the general offices and the various departments maintained by the General Board, but to have it be of service to all members of the Society. We expect to include in it comfortable lounge rooms where you may leave your wraps, a well as meet a friend; check rooms where you may leave your bundles; a relic room where choice articles of historic value may be preserved and displayed; an auditorium with well-equipped work and exhibition kitchens where homemaking demonstrations and lectures may be given, as well as other features suitable to a Relief Society building and the work of the Society.

The Gospel in the Relief Society Educational Program
Elder Howard R. Driggs
I HAVE never faced in all my life so many good and beautiful women. It is an honor and privilege to stand before you, and I humbly pray to God to help me to say those things that will lift us all to higher levels as I am lifted this morning by this occasion. The keynote of what I should like to say is to be found in a song we all love to sing, "Thanks for our teachers who labor with care, that we in the light of the gospel may shine." No other word occurs more frequently or is echoed more beautifully throughout all our scriptures than the word "light." The Savior said, "I am the light and the life," and he advised us to let our
light so shine that a man seeing our good deeds would glorify God, who is in heaven.
If the teacher has one purpose above another, it is to radiate light. It is to illumine truth; it is to lead souls out of the darkness into the light. I think no more beautiful story has ever come to me as to the real work of the teacher than that found in the life story of Helen Keller. As a little girl, Helen Keller enjoyed one brief period of sunshine, of flowers, of bird song, of home joys. Then, suddenly, through dread illness, she was plunged, by being bereft of sight and hearing, into what she called "a prison house of darkness." GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 733 As she came back to consciousness out of that disease, she said she was beating the bars of that physical prison, trying to get back into the light. Yet in that darkness, she might have remained, "had not she come, my teacher, who was to set my spirit free/' Anna Suhi-van, a devoted, understanding, loving teacher, took that little human soul and led her back into the sunshine. She placed in her hands, literally, the key of language to open the prison house. She brought her forth into glorious womanhood, where she could make her contribution magnificently to the world. Every one of US is a teacher, either by example or precept, or both. Every human being is teaching other human beings. It is true that officers and teachers of great organizations such as this are called especially to the privilege. That doesn't take away the duty and the opportunity of everyone of us to lead souls into the light. This is especially true of gospel teachers. Our constant effort should be to make the world brighter, not only today but for all time. We should ever remember this, that so far as the teaching, of the gospel is concerned, the spirit of the gospel is "caught," rather than "taught." One cannot impart the spirit of the gospel by mere words or by a recital of facts. What is in you radiates from you. The Apostle Paul called our attention to this very picturesquely when he said, "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal." We carry the spirit of the gospel with us, or we do not. If we carry it with us, those around us catch the light of our illumination. It matters not whether we represent an arc light or one of less candle power, our business is to light up the dark corners where we happen to be. Dear old Dr. Maeser, with whom I was privileged to associate in the long ago years, said this once to a class of teachers in training: "You can't teach even arithmetic most successfully unless you radiate something of the spirit of the gospel." It is a challenging assertion, but it is true. Oh, of course there are teachers who seem to radiate little or none of the spirit of the gospel, but they would do better with that spirit, and they are always excelled by those teachers who combine intellect and spirituality. NOW, to your educational program. The Relief Society, in its marvelous way, has spread before its members and its officers and all the world, a well-rounded program touching the various phases of basic life. Every lesson that you teach goes to its highest level only when it is taught with a testimony of the gospel in your hearts. Even in your work meetings, where, with nimble fingers, sisters gather around a quilt and begin to sew, and generally to talk, if the spirit of the gospel is not in that spontaneous expression and in the hearts of those who are doing the work, there is something of vital worth lacking. Many a lesson in gospel service is lastingly impressed by those who scatter sunshine and uplifting thoughts while they work. Apply the same truth to your lessons in Church history. In this study one should keep the mind on the final outcomes and not be led into things of little consequence.
When I was a boy I was brought into this temple yard. On an excursion from Pleasant Grove and West Jordan, some of us school children were privileged to come here and see the temple which was being built. It wasn't up to the square. We were permitted to climb the winding stairs to the top and look over the city. One thing I remember was that this yard was littered with stones, with all sorts of tools. We don't see those things now; we see the glorious temple with its spires pointing heavenward.
Every man's life and every woman's life in the building is likely to have some litter about it, but by what do we judge the life? by the outcome. Think of this when you teach lessons in history. Let the gospel light guide this great work.
In the lessons on literature recently given we started out with that found in the Old Testament and in the New Testament. The central aim of all was to bring you back to the Bible, to make you love that book of books. These courses were not planned for one year. One cannot get out the Bible in eight or sixteen lessons. They were planned to lay a firm foundation for reading and rereading and enjoying the Bible. With that work as a basis and as a standard, we are now entering upon the study of the influence of the Bible and Christian teaching on our
literature. I think that we have here a measuring rod by which we can determine whether any literature that has been created is worthy of a place in our home libraries. A book that does not vibrate a spirit of the gospel is open to serious challenge as to whether it goes into the home or not. There is nothing narrow about this; it is soundly basic for all great literature that will be read and reread vibrates to the story of the Bible.
Parents have today the challenge, as never before, to get closer to the literature of their children. Nothing offers a better chance to get nearer to their hearts and souls than good books. We need to cultivate such a companionship in our homes.
May I pay tribute here to my dear mother, in closing. She made our library the center of our home, and she was ever ready to read some beautiful poem, to tell us some story. She saw to it that even though the linen closet or the china closet might not be as richly furnished as in other homes, she had good books in that room where we loved to gather.
We must pay more attention to the spiritual uplift of our homes. We must unite in getting better books in our homes. We must radiate the light of the gospel there.
God bless you in the great work you are doing, multiply and spread it, that the gospel may shine in every home in its simplicity, its purity, with its saving grace, I ask in the name of Jesus. Amen. Relief Society?s Expanding Welfare Service Elder Henry D. Moyle Chairman, General Welfare Committee THIS opportunity to advance the welfare program of the Church, though unsolicited, I can assure you is nevertheless deeply appreciated. Nor do I accept this invitation without a keen realization of the responsibility resting upon me. I appreciate this kind of consideration extended me by your able Presidency. I am sure, to the extent that any of us measures up to that which is expected of him, it is due entirely to the assistance he receives from his Heavenly Father. Without the assurance that he will and does help us, many of us, of whom I know I am myself one, would find our tasks insurmountable.
It is with this spirit of dependence upon the Lord that we must all approach our expanding responsibility?the welfare service of the Church. We must further acknowledge our individual insufficiency in carrying on the work by exhibiting a dependence upon each other. There is none of us in this Church so good or great or endowed with power sufficient to magnify his office and calling in the Church without receiving much assistance and in many ways?from his brethren and sisters in the wards and stakes of the Church in which he lives and works.
Welfare work is no exception to this well-established rule, which we might call "the rule of dependency" of the Church. That which I say is, of course, auxiliary to the priest-
hood, not to any quorum in particular, but to all quorums equally. Our spiritual and temporal welfare is so closely interwoven, there can be no clear line of demarcation between the two. No one can say the Relief Society takes care of either spiritual or temporal or secular? and not both. Every visit made by a Relief Society teacher, every class held, inspires someone to live nearer the Maker, and, at the same time, prepares that same person to take better care of herself and of her family temporally.
So we arrive at the first conclusion in projecting our welfare program into the future, and that is a complete organization is an absolute necessity. By this I mean we must first have a Relief Society fully officered and organized and functioning. Second, a welfare committee in each stake and ward on which the Relief Society presidency of the stake and ward are personally and actively represented. When this is the case, the stake Relief Society comes in direct contact each month with the president of the stake and the presidents of the various priesthood quorums, as well as the stake work directors, and the ward Relief Society meets each week with the bishop and the representatives of the priesthood quorums in the ward and the ward work directors, and, at this meeting, should become intimately familiar with the details of the welfare work of the ward and the needs of the membership, and it is at this meeting that they are assigned their duties and responsibilities for the coming month.
OUR basic problem in taking care of our own, as most of you know, is to render each family in the Church able to care for its own. We have perfected, to a marvelous degree, the production of the welfare budget. It is a pleasure for me to report to you all in time that the record of the Relief Society as an organization in assisting to produce this budget has not only been active in producing the budget, but has helped more than any other single agency in the Church to see to it that the budget, to the extent that it has been distributed, has reached those who needed it. I know of no failure, in the Church, of the Relief Society to promptly and adequately do that which they have been commissioned to do by their bishops since the inception of our welfare program. I am sure your future is to do more. We must increase materially our distribution.
You sisters appreciate that in planning for the welfare of the Church, we must produce more than we distribute in order to provide a surplus from which we can momentarily draw in case of a sudden or unexpected turn of events. It is, however, important while securing this insurance that we do not overlook these needs may not be apparent. By so doing we perform more fully our present responsibility and we are, at the same time, able to determine more accurately the extent to which, in the Church, we can better develop means and
methods of distribution, and in every other way fit and prepare and qualify ourselves to more adequately carry on our work in the future, and, above all, to more fully meet promptly any emergency. This, after all, is the best form of insurance of which we can conceive.
THE welfare work, as originally announced by the First Presidency, divides itself into four major subdivisions. We have thus far discussed the first general subdivision, that of temporary relief, involving, as has been suggested, the production and distribution of the budget. The second general subdivision deals with the permanent security of the members of the Church. A simple illustration suffices to bring out clearly the distinction between these two major phases of our work. A member in need can be given an order on the bishops' storehouse. This is temporary relief just as our budgets are temporary. They must be renewed every year to meet the temporary needs of that current year. It may be possible, however, to find this same needy member employment, and then we have solved his problem and removed the necessity for any temporary relief, and this latter we call permanent security.
Unquestionably, with the termination of hostilities in the world, the finding of employment and thus readjusting the lives of these, our brothers and sisters, whose lives were thrown out of adjustment by the war, is a real major problem. Before this problem has been successfully met, the Relief Society will no doubt have played a most important role in its ultimate solution. I commend this problem to you as one which justifies and calls for the best there is in the Relief Society.
To meet this problem, as well as all other problems that arise in the welfare program, the Church looks to the family for the final solution. If families cannot succeed in making each of their individual members self-sustaining through the united effort of all, there is little hope that any outside agency could add much toward any permanent solution of that individual's problem. As a matter of fact, it is natural for the family to always have some members dependent upon it. That's what families are for. The father and mother are dependent upon each other. It is to be hoped we shall always have children in our homes, and so long as we have children we shall have a family rather than an individual problem.
I WANT to go one step further and say that I hope we always have parents and grandparents in our homes, and, so long as we do, their problems as well as the problems of the children, are and should be the problems of the family. Up to date, at least, in Latter-day Saint homes, we have undertaken to provide in our homes for all members of our family, be they old or young. There has never been any difference in the nation made for spiritual guidance. We depend upon the priesthood of the father as the head of the family, assisted by his sons who may hold the priesthood. We unite the family daily in family prayer, we pray unitedly for the support, maintenance, welfare, spirituality and temporal progress we undertake to take in the family circle to direct
the footsteps of our children and to make the family influence predominate in the child's life, and expect the early training to be followed throughout life. The children in the Church, as they grow to maturity, reflect in their lives the teachings of their mother and father in the family. You mothers in Israel must continue to do your part. As a people, we must never be willing to give to another the rearing of our children.
Some say it is proper for the government to raise our families, send them to school, etc., because some of us pay taxes, or for some other equally absurd reason. We do not pay taxes for the purpose of having other people raise our children or care for our elderly people. If this were the reason for taxes, we might all very well keep our money and do the job ourselves without paying a large proportion of the sums used for that purpose for professional services.
As Latter-day Saints, we believe without any question that to destroy family responsibility is to destroy the family, and with the family destroyed, the Church would be gone. No church on earth claims for the family what we claim. The restoration of the gospel in this dispensation included the appearance of Elijah before the Prophet Joseph Smith in the Kirtland Temple on the third day of April, 1836, in fulfillment of the prophecy of Malachi, "to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children and the children to the fathers, lest the whole earth be smitten with a curse."
We can hardly say that our hearts often go to the cradles of our children or that our children's hearts have been turned toward us, if we are in the frame of mind which permits us to share in any way, shape, or form the responsibility of parenthood with the world or any of its agencies, and if this be true it follows as a necessary corollary that our children cannot prepare themselves for full fellowship in the Church or magnify their offices and callings in the priesthood if they shirk their responsibility toward their parents, or share it in ever so small a way with the world.
May I ask: Can we love our mothers and leave the determination of their needs to laws or strangers, and the provision of these needs to the unearthliness and insecurities of the world? A few years ago, no one of us would have thought in this Church of favoring a law which relieved the mothers of support of the children. However, there are bills in Congress today, in the Congress of the United States, that look toward giving the mothers assistance for their children, without any relationship to need. In other words, any mother, if these laws were passed, as they have been passed in other countries, would be assisted by the government. The government does not recognize the father as the head of the family for obvious reasons. Dealing with the mother, the question of legitimacy or illegitimacy of the children involved need not be questioned. Need we say more?
The question might be put rather bluntly and boldly in these words: Do we as a people so far worship money that we are willing to the slightest degree to relinquish parental control of our children for gold?
In projecting the ever-expanding welfare program of the Church, we call upon the Relief Society as an organization and all of its members individually in faith and humility to answer these questions directly, and to be a direct influence in our own families for maintaining family unity, family integrity, family faith, and family loyalty to the ways of the Lord.
The Relief Society, like all other organizations in the Church, is confronted with the necessity of converting our saints to the simple fundamental principles of life and of truth everlasting, and to avoid the conflicting philosophies and theories of men in the world. To accomplish this purpose is to accomplish the purposes of the welfare program. We must gather Israel to the standards of our Lord.
Need we say that to be married for time and eternity in the house of the Lord by the priesthood is but the first step in the eternal scheme of family progression? The first step becomes as naught if we fail to continue to go forward in righteousness, maintaining the sacred relationship of family life and assuming all the responsibilities incident thereto throughout life, as we hope to do throughout eternity.
The Relief Society can and will, I am sure, expand its service so far as necessary to keep our brethren and sisters in the fold and to give to the priesthood of the Church the kind of an example and the encouragement through love and affection which will induce them to fully magnify their position in the family and in the Church; and that this may be our happy lot, I pray in Jesus' name. Amen. Relief Society Leadership President Amy Brown Lyman THE type of leadership which the Relief Society wishes to develop is the type which Jesus exemplified when he said, "I am among you as one that serveth" (Luke 22:27). In this same verse he says that it is greater to serve than to be served.
The service to which he dedicated his life was a service of unselfishness, self-sacrifice, and helpfulness. It was divinely inspired, was born of brotherly love, and safeguarded by the conception he held of the sacredness of the human personality. It was intelligent service resulting from keen observation and long years of study and preparation, and most important of all, from divine guidance.
It is assumed that as a boy Jesus lived a normal, peaceful, protected life in a humble house where he was trained to labor and work and to live in the fear of the Lord. It is evident that in he grew up he became an industrious worker, a careful observer, and a profound student, that he gained much knowledge by his own effort, and through prayer and devotion to our Heavenly Father he was blessed with great wisdom. Even at the age of twelve in his interview in the temple, he astonished the learned doctors with his unusual knowledge and attainments.
What a glorious example and pattern of work, observation, and inspiration for leaders and teachers was his! He was perhaps the greatest of all
leaders and teachers, our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ.
The success of any enterprise depends largely upon its leaders. It is to them that people look for guidance, encouragement and inspiration.
Relief Society, with its many fields of activity, requires many workers and as the years go by and new avenues of service appear, new and additional workers, with new and additional preparation and experience, will be needed. Leaders are needed for executive work and for class teaching; for choral work and dramatics; for art-needlework and plain sewing; for homemaking and household management; for training for parenthood and family life; and for social welfare work. And with frequent changes in executive officers, practically all the members are called sooner or later to lead out in some activity and thus assume some responsibility.
One of the first requisites of Relief society leaders is to live the gospel. They should aim to be living examples of what they advocate and teach, being "doers of the word, and not hearers only" (James 1:22). They should conform to all the standards and requirements set for Latter-day Saints and be true to the ideals of the Church and of the gospel. They should honor and respect the priesthood and should hearken to any instructions the priesthood offers. They should practice what they preach and preach what they practice. They should cultivate spirituality and thus increase and strengthen their own testimonies and the testimonies of those whom they lead. Relief Society leaders should also seek to enhance their general scholarship and learning which will increase their ability and bear fruit in their efforts to lead and influence others. They should have some familiarity with the standard works of the Church. They should know something about the history and the background of the Church and its leaders. They should be familiar with the history, background, activities, and accomplishments of the Relief Society, and of the women who have directed its work. It is sometimes mistakenly claimed that only those who are born leaders or are born with an aptitude for leadership and teaching can succeed as leaders and teachers. Experience in Relief Society over a period of many years has demonstrated that this is not a correct conclusion and that leadership can be developed. The Society has seen women grow and develop as they have accepted calls to serve, and have sought the spirit of the Lord to guide them. It has seen women changed, yes, almost transformed through Relief Society service. Many at first too timid to take any part, have, through study and prayerful effort and practice, become resourceful, successful officers and class teachers, able conversationalists, and strong, well-poised individuals. They have learned much about how to meet life successfully, how to adjust to their environment, and how to get along and live and work with others. They have learned to be patient, tolerant, sympathetic, and understanding, and their love for humanity, which is one of the most important elements in leadership, as it is in life itself (brotherly love, if you please), has increased with the years of their service. In closing, I should like to salute all the leaders of Relief Society throughout the whole Church, all the leaders, past and present, who for one hundred years have guided successfully the destinies of this great and mighty organization. May the Lord continue to bless us all is my earnest prayer. Relief Society Membership President Louise Y. Robison IN a Relief Society meeting last season, the class leader had followed the outline for our work in the literature of the New Testament so inspirationally that, for the hour, we lived with the Savior and his disciples. It had taken us to a higher plane, and we had the desire in our hearts to live nearer to our Father in heaven. At the close of this meeting, one of the members came to the class leader and said, "I would love to have time to study the gospel as you have done, but it seems that home duties call me away from study." The understanding class leader said, "Yes, I know; I have taken care of my house all of my life, but I have never been told, nor do I believe, that my Heavenly Father gave me this precious earth life solely to do these things. Couldn't you try to adjust your time so that some of it could be used for the eternal principles? I have been taught through the teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith that we are saved no faster than we gain knowledge, and that a person cannot successfully serve our Heavenly Father without the knowledge of his laws."
Of course, the element of time is a consideration, but each woman has twenty-four hours of time given her each day to use as she desires, in her own way. Now, most of us, in buying our bread and butter for our families, go to the place where we have confidence in the goods, though the food may last only until tomorrow. But when we go to a place where we find good thoughts, where we learn ideals that we can take home to our children, it is of great importance! The home is the laboratory of the souls of those entrusted to our care, and a good idea, a good book, a good thought, or a prayer is of great importance, as we were told today by Brother Driggs, in this home that produces high ideals.
But there are so many interests, and we naturally look around and think, which is the most important to give for our time. And the question arises, How about Relief Society? What does it offer its members?
First, Relief Society offers elevating, beautiful friendships. The best friendships of my life have been formed through the Society, and
Our meetings are called together, and the first thing is to remember Him in song?which brings a sweet worshipful peace. Then the prayer is offered, a humble prayer offered by one of our humble sisters, but asking for that precious gift, the gift that God will send us?his spirit, which is light and truth.
This is followed then, and is the setting for the theology lesson which teaches us the will of our Father in heaven and his laws that will prepare us for his kingdom. Then, in testimony meeting, we have the opportunity of telling each other of the kindness of our Heavenly Father to us and of the beautiful principles of the gospel, and just as sure as we come in contact with his spirit, we take it to our homes. It is this spirit that builds up the faith of our children.
The second Tuesday of our Relief Society is more of a social day. We meet more informally, we learn to take care of our homes and our children, and we give service to others in our Welfare Plan, that we with better part may ask for God's blessing at the close of day.
Then, the study of the literature of the New Testament, that wonderful part of the Bible that inspires us with higher thoughts; and the innumerable poems and stories and songs, inspired by these truths, raise the standard of culture in our homes.
The fourth study is a practical study of character development, of honesty and morality and truth. Where these are taught in the home, supplemented by the faith that has been developed, children are fortified to meet life when they cross the bridge from the home to the work of the world. Nor are we left alone. Our Father in Heaven is as much interested ln our children?more so, even, than we, and he has said to us: *'Be thou humble; and the Lord Thy God shall lead thee by the hand, and give thee answer to thy prayers" (Doc. And Gov. 112:10). Is there any promise greater for us to receive in return for the time spent properly? Active membership in Relief Society makes this promise secure through the beautiful lessons provided for us through the inspired teacher or class leader, and through a prayerful study of the principles of the gospel of Jesus Ghrist. Membership in Relief Society is offered to all women who seek to live the better life. I leave my prayer and my blessing for these fine women, the Presidency of this organization and the General Board, who, through the priesthood of the living God, have been given the torch to light, to lead us into perfection, to make our homes clean and pure, that there will be no evil come in. I pray that the stake presidents may receive this light and carry it to the wards, and, most important, that the ward presidents may receive this light, and that they may have the blessing in giving and interpreting it to the individual members, that we will all, when we leave here, turn to our Father in heaven, that these precious souls that he has entrusted to our care, our children, may be pure and clean and sweet. May this be our lot, I humbly ask in the name of Jesus Ghrist. Amen.

GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 753 It is our earnest desire that it shall be built by the many rather than the few. That every person may be given opportunity to contribute to its erection and enjoy the sense of satisfaction and pride that comes from so doing, we believe that every one of our more than 100,000 members will want to make a contribution and thus become in reality a part owner in this Relief Society home and Latter-day Saint women's memorial edifice. We believe that throughout the Church are many men, as well, who will welcome the opportunity to honor a wife or mother by contributing funds, and that many other friends of Relief Society will wish to show their regard for the Society by assisting financially. Through the united support of all, we believe that the necessary finances will be readily and willingly contributed. We realize, however, that to erect the type of building we have in mind is a mammoth undertaking. We know that if we are to realize our ambition the full support of every enrolled member of Relief Society will be necessary. We would like at this time to know your attitude toward the proposed building program. Therefore, just as our sisters of long ago called for a vote on this identical proposition, so today, forty-nine years later, we too are calling for a vote of this great congregation composed of Relief Society women of our day representing most of the stakes and many of the missions of the Church. Your General Board proposes the erection at the earliest possible date of a Relief Society building that shall be monumental and beautiful, to adequately serve the members of the Society not only for today but in the years to come. Will all those in favor of this proposition please show it by the uplifted hand. (The vote was unanimous in the affirmative.) This is a glorious experience, not only to see your uplifted hands but to feel your support. As soon as plans for the building and its financing are perfected and approved they will be released to you. We feel assured of your support. We appreciate your support in all of the work of Relief Society. We are grateful for your righteousness and your spirit of service. We are grateful for the strength of your testimonies. We are grateful for the women of the past, for their vision and understanding of the needs of Latter-day Saint women, and for their great contribution to us and to the future. We are above all things grateful for the gospel. May the Lord bless you and comfort you and may our righteous and worthy ambitions know fulfillment I pray, in the name of Jesus Christ, Amen. [The address by President George Albert Smith, page 715, was then delivered. ] Success to a Relief Society Building Elder Marvin O. Ash ton First Counselor, Presiding Bishopric SUCCESS to you in this building! May you speedily start, and may you speedily finish it. If we are perfectly honest with your, and sometimes we are, we would say something like this to President Spafford, "Success to you in this building," and, as the host said to those guests he had in the house as he went into the closet to take out their coats, "Here's your hat, but what's your hurry?" Our building over there is crowded. You need a new building and so do we need more elbow room. Success to you! I wish that every building that is financed would be financed as easily as you are going to finance this building; and I hope I have the privilege, and I am sure it won't be denied, to give my pittance in this direction. In closing, inasmuch as President Smith has mentioned the Lamanites, I just want to pay tribute to a Relief Society worker; namely. Sister Flora Hicks, who has had charge, with her husband, of the Lamanites in the Papago Ward, Arizona. She was called down there ten or twelve years ago, and she passed away about eight weeks ago. We had the privilege of standing in that house as those Lamanites came in to pay homage to her. They are supposed to be cold; they are not supposed to be very enthusiastic in their emotions. VOL. 32 DECEMBER 1945 NO. 12 116th Semi-annual Church Conference  COLORFUL and impressive was the scene in Salt Lake City on the morning of October 5, 1945, the opening day of the 116th semi-annual conference of the Church. All roads appeared to lead to Temple Square as thousands of Latter-day Saints, conference bound, hearts rejoicing in the blessing of our Heavenly Father, eagerly anticipated words which would soon come from inspired Church leaders to guide, comfort, and sustain them. Four weary, anxious war years had passed since the general Church membership had met in the great Tabernacle in conference session, years in which souls had been tried and many had been called upon to mourn. The resumption of conference for the general Church membership, made possible through the cessation of hostilities, was indeed a comfort to the souls of Latter-day Saints, and a joy to their hearts. This conference, too, was an eventful occasion for a most important and impressive ceremony, one participated in by the priesthood and general membership but rarely a ceremony referred to in Church history as a Priesthood Solemn Assembly. Page 758 This ceremony is the custom when voting for a new president of the Church for the first time in general conference, and has been the practice of the Church since President John Taylor was sustained in conference general conference. Voting is by quorums, in order, beginning with the First Presidency and continuing down through the Aaronic Priesthood. Voting by the priesthood is followed by that of the remaining Church membership. In voting, the right hand is raised to the square to witness to the Lord that one sustains the officer for whom he is voting. The Solemn Assembly, presided over by President George Albert Smith and directed by President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. At the opening session of the conference October 5, voted to sustain President George Albert Smith as Prophet, Seer, and Revelator, and President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. President Smith came to this position on May 21, 1945, following the death of President Heber J. Grant. The humility of soul, accompanied by the power that comes with a deep and abiding testimony of the gospel, confirmed in the minds of the thousands who heard the voice of President Smith as he addressed the Church membership following the voting, the belief that they had indeed sustained one who was a prophet, seer, and revelator divinely appointed and endowed with divine authority to lead the Church in this great and perilous day. The Church membership also EDITORIAL 759 sustained President George F. Richards as president of the Council of the Twelve, and Elder Matthew Cowley as a new member of the Council of the Twelve. Strong and effective, and a terse reminder to the saints of the covenants they had made that day in voting were the words of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. When he said: Today I have given witness to President Smith, to you and to the Lord that I will sustain him as prophet, seer and revelator and president of the Church. Each of us has made a life covenant. God gives to each of us the strength and the power to be loyal; to give up fault finding; to follow the command of the Lord; to follow those whom we have ourselves sustained. Without leadership the Church cannot grow. Throughout all of the sessions of the conference, speakers paid high tribute to President Smith. With unusual clarity and conviction they bore testimony, expounded the doctrines and interpreted the principles of the gospel, and bade Church members to keep the commandments of the Lord. Pronounced emphasis was given the missionary program of the Church and the intention to expand it in the immediate future?to call many men and women into missionary service, was made clear. The music of the conference seemed unusually beautiful. Relief Society was proud that a combined chorus of Relief Society Singing Mothers from the stakes of the Salt Lake Region provided the music for the first two sessions. The desires of the thousands of Latter-day Saints who had so eagerly awaited this conference for the guidance and spiritual succor it might bring them were fully realized. This 116th semi-annual conference will go down in Church history as a great and blessed occasion. BSS. Christmas in the Bible WHAT shall we do on Christmas Eve? What shall we do when the fire blazes high upon the hearth and candles flame in the window? Beyond that window, in the darkness, stars line the black arch of night. Perhaps, far away or near at hand, in the hills, modern shepherds watch their flocks by night. There is no better way to enjoy this evening than to spend it reading the story of Christmas as it is written in the beautiful words of the Bible. Let these words be read aloud and pondered again, for there is need of their serenity and comfort?a great need for their steadfast message of hope: Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea in the days of Herod the king, behold, there came wise men from the east to Jerusalem, Saying, where is he that is born King of the Jews? With the establishment of his kingdom in the latter days, there has come the same opportunity to serve. Hardly had the Church been organized when the call was given to Parley P. Pratt and his companions to go upon a mission to the Laman-ites (Doc. And Gov. 32). And ever since that October in the year 1830, servants of the Lord in steadily increasing numbers have gone forth to preach the gospel, only to find that they, in turn, have become more converted to the faith. Nor have there been any limits set as to the distances these present-day disciples of the Lord were to carry the message of salvation. As in the days of Peter, so now the passage reads: Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost: Teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you: and, lo, I am with you always, even unto the end of the world (Matt. 28:19-20). It is good to have the comfort of the last thought the Lord gave in this injunction. He is always to be with his servants. Missionaries by the hundreds from the year 1830 to the present day have learned,. Through personal experiences, the need for such a priceless companion. The work of the elder or seventy has always been difficult. Page 767  Bitter opposition to the word of God has caused his servants much suffering and misery, even death.
When the first missionaries were sent to England in 1837, the forces of evil which blind the eyes of men were most dramatically made real. Heber C. Kimball, Orson Hyde and Willard Richards saw legions of devils and felt their physical violence. With hatred toward these brethren for the priesthood they held, and bitterness for the gospel they were to bring to the British people, the fiends of darkness assailed the missionaries. Elder Kimball was knocked senseless to the floor. He recalls the happening in these words:
I was struck with great force by some invisible power, and fell senseless to the floor. The first thing I recollected was being supported by Elders Hyde and Richards, who were praying for me . . . Elders Hyde and Richards then assisted me to get on the bed . . . when a vision was opened to our minds, and we could distinctly see the evil spirits, who foamed and gnashed their teeth at us. We gazed upon them about an hour and a half (by Willard's watch). We were not looking towards the window, but towards the corner of the room. Elder Richards finally saw the devils coming with their legions, who came towards us like armies rushing to battle. They appeared to be men of full stature, possessing every form and feature of men in the flesh who are angry and desperate; and I shall never forget the vindictive malignity depicted on their countenances as they looked me in the eye; . . . We distinctly heard those spirits talk and express their wrath and hellish designs against us. However, the Lord delivered us from them, and blessed us exceedingly that day (Doc. and Cov. Commentary, page 634; ORSON F. WHITNEY, Life of Heber C. Kimball, page 144).
The majority of the missionaries who have gone forth on their good tidings, while not encountering such exceptional experiences with the spirit world, have, nevertheless, seen the flames of hatred for God's work in the eyes of ill-informed men and women. The malice planted in their hearts by the adversary in the case of some nonbelievers has led to overt acts of violence. To be a Mormon missionary at times has meant not to be sure of life itself.
There is a love for the truth, however, which makes men brave. One day, they know, every soul must acknowledge Christ. This it is, among other things, that keeps those who have accepted the good word forever trying. The express command from the Lord, too, that his word must be preached puts an obligation upon the Church to have elders abroad in missionary service.
As we have followed the history of the saints from Palmyra to Salt Lake Valley, often amid their most dire trials has come the call for men to leave their homes and go abroad to preach the gospel. Through the service of home missionaries within the missions and the stakes of Zion, hundreds of faithful Latter-day Saints, not called up on to devote all their time to preaching the gospel, are also spending many hours seeking out the honest in heart. A steadily increasing number of converts are thus coming into the Church through these laborers. Even the recruiting of the Mormon Battalion in the year 1846 was not without its missionary service. Just so, today, our boys abroad in the armed forces are in the most real sense bearers of the truth. Their lives, when held in line with the teachings of the Church, will add to the glory of the latter-day work. 
LESSON DEPARTMENT 769 Before giving a few excerpts from the journals of early missionaries of the Church, let us look at the names and dates of the major missions opened over the earth, since Elder Heber C. Kimball and his companions first went to the British Isles in 1837. Most of this work*of the gathering of Israel was underway before the turn of the century in 1900. There are two dates before 1837 which should be mentioned again. One is 1830, which marks the first mission of all which was the one to the Lamanites. Oliver Cowdery, Parley P. Pratt, and Ziba Peterson were sent at that time. Six years later. Elder Pratt and others opened the mission to Canada. Orson Hyde went to Palestine in 1841; Noah Rogers and others to the Society Islands in 1844; and Erastus Snow to Scandinavia in 1850. Four other missions were opened in this same year, the French by John Taylor, the Italian by Lorenzo Snow, the Swiss by T. B. H. Stenhouse, and the Hawaiian by George Q. Cannon and companions. The following year three other countries were added to the foregoing fields: South America by Parley P. Pratt; Australia by John Murdock and Charles W. Wandell; and India. In 1853, Elders Jesse Haven, Leonard Smith and William Walker went to South Africa. In 1854 AA Zealand was opened; in 1861 the Netherlands, in 1888 Samoa, and in 1901 President Heber J. Grant opened the Japanese field. The harvest was ripe during the beginning years of the missionary work of the Restored Church. Parley P. Pratt records in his journal the following concerning the number of saints to leave England for Zion: Between the middle of September [1840] and my own embarkation in October, I chartered three vessels for New Orleans and filled them with the migrating Saints viz.: The 'Sidney/ with one hundred and eighty souls; the 'Medford/ with two hundred and fourteen souls; and the 'Henry,' with one hundred and fifty-seven. I next chartered the 'Emerald' on which I placed about two hundred and fifty passengers, including myself and family (Autobiography of Parley P. Pratt, page 361). Next to England, no field has been more fruitful than the Scandinavian. For a glimpse of the early mission encounters in that vineyard one may well turn to the journal of Andrew Jenson who served for many years as assistant Church historian. He relates this experience on the island of Mors in the province of Jutland, Denmark, under the date of July 1874. Bitter opposition had been encountered by the missionaries there before the incident here given was recorded. It was on a Friday evening that the two missionaries met on the Nykjobing wharf, and instead of putting up in the little city, they struck out in the country at once. Night found them in the village of Jorsby, ten miles to the north, where they found friends who kept them over night. Early the next morning the house, in which they had slept, was approached by a crowd of fishermen hailing from the west coast of Jutland. They had been out on the fjord fishing, but a storm had compelled them to seek shelter for a day or so in the village, which was situated on the east coast of the island. These men were known to be a rough set, and when the owner of the house where the missionaries stopped saw them approaching in their long watertight boots, their short jackets and heads covered with huge fishermen's storm caps, he felt alarmed, fearing that they came for the purpose of ill-treating his guests; and so expressed himself to them, but the young Utah elder told him not to fear, as nobody would get hurt. A loud rap on the door, a response of "vaer saa god" (please step in), and in filed a dozen or more strong, weather-beaten sailors, who immediately introduced themselves in their own peculiar way by saying that they had come out of pure curiosity to see the man from Utah, whom they had been informed stopped at the house. "Then I am perhaps the man you look for," said the young elder, as he rose from the table and shook hands with them all. "I shall be pleased to answer any proper question you may wish to put to me concerning Utah and her people" (Autobiography of Andrew Jenson, page 75). The distant travels of Elder George Q. Cannon to the Hawaiian people in the year 1850 opened one of the most colorful chapters in the story of missionary endeavor of the Church. It was the Book of Mormon, the greatest of missionary aids, that so often comforted Elder Cannon and his companions just as it has done hundreds of others of the Lord's servants. From his writings entitled "My First Mission," chapters 12 and 16, the following excerpts are taken: Before I commenced holding regular meetings, I had plenty of time for meditation, and to review all the events of my short life, and to think of the beloved home from which I was so far separated. It was then that I found the value of the Book of Mormon. It was a book which I always loved. But I learned there to appreciate it as I had never done before. If I felt inclined to be lonely, to be low spirited, or homesick, I had only to turn to its sacred pages to receive consolation, new strength and a rich out-pouring of the Spirit Scarcely a page that did not contain encouragement for such as I was. The salvation of man was the great theme upon which its writers dwelt, and for this they were willing to undergo every privation and make every sacrifice. What were my petty difficulties compared with those afflictions which they had to endure? If I expected to share the glory for which they contended, I could see that I must labor in the same spirit. If the sons of King Mosiah could relinquish their high estate, and go forth among the degraded Lamanites to labor as they did, should not I labor with patience and devoted zeal for the salvation of these poor red men, heirs of the same promise? Let me recommend this book, therefore, to young and old, if they need comfort and encouragement. Especially can I recommend it to those who are away from home on missions. No man can read it, partake of its spirit and obey its teachings, without bein" filled with a deep love for the souls of men and a burning zeal to do all in his power to save them.... The conversations, which I had with the natives concerning the Book of Mormon and the origin of the red men, made them anxious to see it. "It is truly surprising how soon the work of translation began. The first elders landed at Honolulu in December, 1850. Not long afterwards Elder Cannon deeply desiring to know the language had the gift of interpretation given to him. His progress in the new tongue must have been rapid, for in less than two months he was beginning to put the record of the Nephites before some of their descend ants. He writes: 'In the last days of the month of January, 1851, I commenced the work of translation. My fellow laborers, the elders, encouraged me, and from the First Presidency at home ?Presidents Young, Kimball and Richards?came words of cheer, approving of what I was doing, and counseling me to persevere.' "Naturally this work of translation could be only a part of the missionary work. Preaching, explaining the doctrines, meeting the opposition raised against them by Christian ministers, baptizing, traveling from place to place, administering to the sick, all had their time and place. LESSON DEPARTMENT 771In reference to his work after returning to Wailuku, where he had first found a friendly reception, and from which place he had removed to save his friend, J. H. Napela, from the persecution of the Presbyterian minister, who had so bitterly opposed the work, Elder Cannon writes: ?The preaching of the gospel created great excitement; the people came by hundreds to hear the testimony, and I had the satisfaction of seeing the missionary who had treated me so badly and who had so bitterly opposed and lied about the work, almost deserted by his congregation; they having left his church to hear us preach and see us baptize.... We baptized a large number of people at Wailuku and the adjacent towns, erected a large meeting-house at that place and smaller ones at the other villages, and organized large and flourishing branches of the Church!' " (Joseph J. Cannon, "George A. Cannon," Instructor, October '44, pages 456-458). Though the darkening shadow of war robbed the world of nearly all but home missionaries, yet the day will come again when the elders of Israel will resume their efforts to carry the gospel to the nations of the world. Suggestions for Active Reading and Discussion With the help of the suggestive readings given below have the class carry on the discussion as follows: first, answer the question; second, read the assigned part of the text to discover wherein we must "give heed unto his word." 1. Discuss the work of the seventies in relation to the missionary program of the Church (See Doc. And Cov. 107:25). 2. Have class members who are familiar with missionary work conducted at centers such as Temple Square, Hill Cumorah, etc., tell what they know of this work. 3. It has been said that once a person is a Mormon he is always a Mormon. Though this is not entirely true, there is enough basis for fact in it to cause one to ask?Why." Discuss this question. 4. As a people we are ever ready to explain our faith to others. Why? Read the word of the Lord to three of the early members of the Church and note the one charge he gave to all of them (Doc. And Cov. 4; 6:1-9; 11). 5. Read Doc. And Cov. 46:1-7. Note the attitude of the Lord toward him who is seeking the way of life. 6. Have class members who have filled missions, including home missions, relate interesting missionary experiences.
