entries.title: Address to the Members of the Relief Society
entries.author: George Albert Smith

loose_match.content: Address to the Members of the Relief Society PRESIDENT GEORGE ALBERT SMITH

Elder Matthew Cowley and Elva Taylor Cowley, daughter, Jewell Cowley Sheffield, and adopted son, Duncan Meha (Toni) Cowley. Elder Matthew Cowley Elder Thomas E. Towler President of Wells Stake SIX months before Elder Mathew Cowley left New Zealand, one of the native saints predicted that he would be chosen an apostle. His patriarchal blessing states: ?You shall come an ambassador of Christ to the uttermost bounds of the earth. Page 722 MATTHEW COWLEY 723Your understanding shall be great and your wisdom reach to heaven." Elder Cowley is eminently trained and qualified for such an exalted position. He was born of goodly parents and lived the gospel in his youth. In his early manhood he married a beautiful and talented young lady, Elva Taylor, and they have labored together to make the world a better place in which to live. Thirteen years of Elder Cowley's life have been devoted to missionary work in New Zealand. He labored there during both of the world wars. His experiences have taught him one of the great lessons of life, namely, 'There are two sides to every story." As a result, he is blessed with a sympathetic understanding, is kind and patient, honest and fair, does not excuse failings in men, but is ever anxious to assist them to overcome their failings. His nature is one of absolute loyalty and he does not like destructive criticism. Because of his genuine humility, he has never sought after any position in the Church. He is altruistic, liberal, and generous. Before leaving New Zealand, he literally gave the coat off his back. A faithful saint admired the topcoat he was wearing, and in a Christ-like spirit, he took it off and gave it to him. Blessed with a sense of wit and humor, coupled with a pleasing personality, has won for him a host of friends. Because of his great work among the Maori people and the thorough understanding he has of them. Elder Cowley is admired and respected by government officials of New Zealand, and has been given important assignments by them. Possibly his greatest achievement is his spiritual and intellectual strength by which he has become a powerful preacher of righteousness. As he travels throughout the Church, he will warm the hearts of the saints and stimulate them to righteous living. The leaders and saints of Wells Stake are appreciative of the life and labors of Elder Cowley at home and abroad. They are firmly convinced that his call came by inspiration and that he will be a tower of strength in the great work of the Lord which lies ahead for him.

CHRISTMAS AT NORTH-HEAD LIGHT Beatrice Knowlton Ekman The rock-bound lighthouse fronts the sea, Below, the breakers roar In angry combat endlessly Where waves on cliff rocks pour. All day the gulls wing overhead, Fog hides the outflung space Where sailors' hearts are filled with dread Watching the dark sea's face.... The ocean wind blown in to shore, The cries of birds in flight, Will carol round the lighthouse door To mark the Christmas night. General Relief Society Conference October 3 and 4, 1945 A General Relief Society Conference was held on October 3 and 4, 1945, at Salt Lake City, Utah, with President Belle S. Spafford presiding. The following sessions were held: An officers' meeting on Wednesday afternoon, October 3, in the Assembly Hall on Temple Square for general, mission and stake officers; A reception to honor retiring President Amy Brown Lyman and the retired members of her General Board, for stake and mission officers and specially invited guests on Wednesday night, October 3, in the Lafayette Ballroom of the Hotel Utah; Morning and afternoon general sessions for Relief Society workers and the general public on Thursday, October 4, in the Salt Lake Tabernacle at 10 a. M. And 2 p. M. This general Relief Society conference, the first held since October 1941, because of World War II, had a record-breaking attendance. The audience on Thursday afternoon completely filled the Tabernacle. A spirit of enthusiasm pervaded by a spirit of love and unity in Relief Society work was manifest throughout the sessions. A feature of the conference was the launching, with the approval of the First Presidency, of the erection of a central Relief Society building to be erected in Salt Lake City, detailed plans for which will be publicized later. The final session was blessed by the presence of President George Al-Page 724 bert Smith who delivered a moving address for the guidance of the mothers of the Church and all members of Relief Society. A number of other members of the General Church Authorities and members of the General Church Welfare Committee were in attendance at the Thursday sessions as well as specially invited guests. The music for the conference was under the direction of Sister Florence J. Madsen, member of the General Board. A solo 'The Voice in the Wilderness" was beautifully sung by Aline Peterson; and Lily Priestly, at the organ, rendered lovely selections for the prelude and postlude numbers at the Wednesday afternoon meeting. At the Thursday sessions, under the direction of Sister Madsen, with Brother Alexander Schreiner at the Tabernacle organ, a chorus of Singing Mothers from the sixteen stakes comprising the Salt Lake Region rendered beautiful and inspiring numbers. This same group was asked by the First Presidency to furnish the special music for the first two sessions of the 116th Semiannual General Conference of the Church held the following day, on Friday, October 5. The opening and closing prayers at the three sessions were offered by present and former Relief Society mission presidents. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 725 There were representatives from 146 stakes and 18 missions of the Church. On Monday morning, October 8, in the Relief Society General Board room in the Bishop's Building, a meeting was held by the Relief Society General Presidency and members of the General Board Mission Lesson Committee with the mission Relief Society presidents of 17 missions. The address delivered at the Thursday afternoon session in the Tabernacle by President George Albert Smith is printed in full as the feature article of this issue of the Magazine. Digests of the other talks given at the various sessions follow in the order of their delivery. OFFICERS' MEETING, OCTOBER 3, 1945

Report and Official Instructions President Belle S. Spafford WE welcome you all and we are grateful for your presence, your safe journey, your devotion to the work that makes you put forth the effort to be here, for the sacrifices of your families. I am sure that our hearts are filled to overflowing today in gratitude to our Heavenly Father for the privilege of this conference. We are deeply grateful for the cessation of hostilities that has made this conference possible. For four long years we have been bowed down by the strains, anxieties, and sorrows of war. Even though we know that many of the sorrows and problems of war are still with us, we acknowledge the goodness of the Lord at this time. Our last general Relief Society conference was held in October 1941, and we were enthusiastically looking forward to the observance of our Relief Society centennial in connection with the coming April conference. Interest and enthusiasm were running high, only to be cut short by war. Relief Society Activities, 1941-1944 At the close of 1941 we had an enrollment of 115,000. Then the advent of the war and the accompanying employment of women, together with the many war interests of women, affected in some measure our enrollment. Under these conditions we feel our membership has held up remarkably well. We have today an enrollment of over 102,000. Average attendance has suffered somewhat more than enrollment. The average attendance for the three-year war period, December 1941 to December 1944, is 30.41 per cent of the enrolled membership. The number of visits to homes by visiting teachers is perhaps the most discouraging of all aspects of our work. Figures show a steady decline through the war years, with 126,900 fewer visits being made last year than in 1941. Thehas given us pronounced concern during the war years. Government restrictions on paper, increased printing and engraving costs, labor problems, both at the printing offices and in our own department, have caused us many troubled hours. Moreover, the Magazine has never seemed of greater importance to us, being the major medium through which the General Board has been able to reach local officers and the

Relief Society membership. The circulation has increased from 55,500 in 1941 to 73, 620 as of July 1945. This splendid increase in circulation has been the main factor in enabling us to maintain the $1 subscription price. We are now pleased to announce to you that government paper restrictions are lifted and beginning with the November issue the Magazine will add eight pages. The Magazine has more than current value. It has reference and historical value, therefore we suggest that you keep in your ward and stake libraries files of TheExcellent standards of class work have been maintained throughout the Society. Recommended courses of study have been followed in most of the missions as well as in the stakes and these have been generally well received by Relief Society members.
Figures for the past four years on phases of compassionate service which can be tabulated are very interesting. For each of the four years, visits to the sick and homebound did not vary a great deal. During the period, December 1941 to December 1944, an average of 132,000 visits were made annually to the sick and homebound, and an average of 19,000 days' care was given the sick annually by our Relief Society sisters. Services rendered by Relief Society in time of death averaged 600 monthly.
Relief Society women have wholeheartedly supported the war effort. Extensive service has been given the Red Cross sewing and other programs. Relief Society women have also been active in salvage and food conservation programs. During the past four years tremendous amounts of regular Relief Society sewing have been done; ward conferences and special activities, such as Relief Society socials and anniversary programs, have gone successfully forward. Hundreds of meetings in addition to the regular weekly Relief Society meetings have been held, with encouraging gains being made in the number of ward preparation meetings held.
Changes in Leadership
Great changes have been made in our leadership. During the past four years, out of the present 151 stakes, 132 have new stake

Relief Society leadership, and twenty-eight missions have new Relief Society mission presidents.
A change in general Relief Society leadership occurred April 6, 1945, with the release by the First Presidency of Sister Amy Brown Lyman and her General Board. The same day, Belle S. Spafford was sustained as the new General President of Relief Society.
New Name for Relief Society
We begin the work of this new era with a new name being officially adopted for the Society. By action of the General Board of Relief Society, June 27, 1945, the name of the Society was officially changed from "National Woman's Relief
Society" to "Relief Society of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints."
Restoration of Union Meetings
This is also a day of restoration for Relief Society. Union meetings have been restored to us allowing stake officers to once more function normally. Visits to stakes by General Board members have once more been authorized by the First Presidency.
We urge that in the conduct of union meetings every possible effort be made to make them as beneficial to ward workers as possible. Let your preparation for these meetings be thorough and keep in mind the two great purposes of union meetings; namely, to aid wards toward fine performance in all phases of Relief Society work and to assist in developing ward leadership. Stake leaders are cautioned to do nothing that will hinder the ward in standing on its own feet.
New Recommendations
The General Board recommends that except when a stake counselor is needed in the department over which she has general supervision, or unless she feels a special need to conduct a department for ward counselors, that she attend the department conducted for presidents. Ward counselors should also attend the presidents' department unless a special department is being conducted for them. Secretaries, when not in departments specially planned for them, should also attend the presidents' department. We feel that tion when executive officers have an
opportunity to meet together in a consideration of Relief Society work.
The General Board also recommends that a

work meeting leader be appointed on stake boards and also in wards, to work under the general supervision of the counselor who is the work meeting program except directly responsible for all phases of the work meeting program except Church Welfare assignments which shall continue to be the direct responsibility of the counselor who is the work director. The stake work meeting leader shall be responsible for a department at union meeting to be attended by ward work-meeting leaders. Wards will plan the work-meeting day for themselves as heretofore, but the union meeting department should stimulate, encourage, suggest programs and aid wards in maintaining high standards of work-meeting activities.
Submittal of Annual Reports
Stake secretaries are requested to begin immediately to work toward getting annual reports into the General Office on time. Ward reports should reach stake secretaries not later than January 5. Stake secretaries should in turn submit their reports to the General Office not later than January 20. Sisters, we plead with you to see that these dates are met.
Stake officers are advised to remind ward officers that ward Relief Society conference programs should be planned with the purposes of the conference clearly in mind, namely, to report organization activities and accomplishments, to acquaint the ward membership with the program and needs of the Society, and to emphasize the blessings of membership in the organization. The ward conference is the Relief Society meeting from which Relief Society should derive benefits, and, with very few exceptions, it accomplishes its purposes best when presented by Relief Society women. The main goal of the meeting should not be merely to present a brilliant speaker or an entertaining program in order that a large crowd will be in attendance, but rather to present in a fresh, interesting, and appealing way a program that truly represents Relief Society, and that draws a large attendance because it does interestingly represent us. The work of Relief Society is appealing and dramatic in itself, and, if properly presented, is full of interest for ward members. Officers should not feel in making ward conference assignments that it is necessary to go outside the ward or stake for talent. The conference program provides excellent opportunity to use and develop local talent and to recognize capable, faithful Relief Society women. Every ward and stake has an abundance of excellent talent, if leaders will but search it out and make use of it. Support of No-Liquor-Tobacco Committees Suggestions will come from the General Board during the coming year in support of the efforts of the General No-Liquor-Tobacco Committee to abolish the use of alcohol and tobacco. We trust that stakes and wards will give full support to any programs that are released or projects that are initiated either by the Board or your local committees. Emphasis on Four Phases of Work We have been advised by our Church leaders to give renewed emphasis to four phases of our work: First, the ultimate objective of all that we do is to build testimonies of the truth of the restored gospel, and to teach women to apply the saving principles of the gospel in their every-day lives. Second, as Relief Society leaders, we must seek earnestly to spiritualize and strengthen Latter-day Saint homes. Third, we are counseled to take cognizance of our part in the Welfare Program of the Church. Love-inspired welfare service has been a fundamental part of our work since the very beginning of our existence as a Society. Under the impetus of the Church Welfare Plan, bishops are enabled to more fully discharge their part in relation to needy Church members in their wards, and Relief Society sisters, relieved of the necessity of maintaining a charity fund and serving as a source of supply, may more fully devote themselves to phases of the work that are in accord with their natures and ability. A fourth duty to which our attention has been called is that of bringing actively into Relief Society greater numbers of Latter-day Saint women, particularly young women. Every Latter-day Saint woman is entitled to the blessings of membership in this Society. Encouragement of Visiting Teaching We urge that special efforts be put forth to strengthen the visiting teacher program during the coming months. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 729 There is a need for organized effort to develop hopes and attitudes and sentiments, favorable outlook and points of view, the spirit of mutual purpose and co-operation; to implant religious conviction with its sustaining spiritual strength. Today's world offers such excellent opportunity for the intimate human service which our visiting teachers can render. May the Lord bless you to keep alive your sense of values, your sense of proportion, your faith that as you work unselfishly in this great organization, you are genuinely helping the women of this Church, you are helping to advance the work of the Lord.

entries.title: Homemaking Skills Developed Through the Work-Meeting Program
entries.author: Velma N. Simonsen

loose_match.content: Homemaking Skills Developed Through the Work-Meeting Program Velma N. Simonsen Member Relief Society General Board WHEN the Prophet Joseph Smith organized the Relief Society, he stated that the purpose of the organization was "to care for the needy, and to save souls." Through the wisdom of our leaders, a day has been provided whereby both of these aims may be served. This is the work meeting. This day is comparable in its cultural value to other prescribed courses, and may require more thorough preparation than any of the other courses to make it one of the best departments in the Society. It seems that there are two real objectives for each work meeting-first, to plan a very vital program, and second, to get the women to participate in that program. Sisters, the day is yours. Plan it thoroughly and wisely, and don't be guilty of planning something that will just "take up the time." The greatest strength of the Relief Society lies in the fact that direction and guidance are given it by the priesthood of God. Today, the* leaders have charged us to strengthen the home and to teach our members, especially the younger sisters, homemaking skills. Work meeting is our day of opportunity to fulfill that charge. It must be a day of training for homemaking skills. It is said that a man may build a house, but only a woman can build a home. Are mass production and machine-made articles which lack beauty and individuality taking us far afield, and are we losing not only the ability to create, but also the appreciation of fine workmanship? If so, work meeting is our opportunity to develop again these skills and appreciations. We must use this day to instil in our sisters a love for beauty and an ability to create it. It is an opportunity to encourage the incompetent home-maker to participate! I remember a period in my life when, as a teen-age girl, I was careless in the upkeep of my room. My mother conceived the plan of twice a week cleaning everything from the top of my dresser and putting a fine, clean, white dresser scarf on it. It wasn't very long before I saw to it that the rest of the room was as clean as the dresser scarf. And so it is with the woman who has never learned homemaking skills. Let her participate in beauty in Relief Society work meeting and it will carry over into her home. The woman who says, '1 do not wish to learn" creates another problem. An effort must be made to find some activity which will especially appeal to her. Getting people to attend work meetings for the first time may call for a personal contact. The most successful work days are those that meet the needs of the women best, whether it be in making a better loaf of bread or sewing a finer seam. The degree of success you achieve depends upon your attitude toward work meeting and upon your prayerful and thoughtful efforts. It has been said: A task without a vision is drudgery, A vision without a task is a dream. But a task with a vision is VICTORY. Relief Society has given us the task; Relief Society has given us the vision. May the Lord bless us with Victory.

Present-Day Visiting Teaching Opportunities Leone G. Layton Member Relief Society General Board HISTORY is never made in the abstract. Always it is something someone has done. History is never a solid mass of achievement; it is a mosaic of countless parts, each one perfected by the sacrificial devotion of some particular person" (Dr. Waldemar W. Argrow, Sunshine Magazine, July 1945). The history of Relief Society has been determined by the ideals, the plans, and the hopes of those who have gone before us. The program of visiting teaching is based upon an ideal, the ideal of the brotherhood of man, that man is indeed his brother's keeper and that love of man is a virtue all possess. The plan of those who instigated this program was that the sisters of the Church should be concerned with the welfare of the group in which they lived, that those who were sorrowing should be comforted, those who were hungry should be fed, and those who were naked should be clothed. It was not a new plan. One who had lived on earth many years ago had pointed the way, had put the principle to practice in his own life. The Prophet Joseph, in instructing the sisters, called attention to this, saying, "Said Jesus, ?Ye shall do the work, which ye see me do.' GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 731 ?Photograph courtesy of Deseret News. Centerpiece on Table at Reception Honoring Former President Amy Brown Lyman on the Evening of October 3, 1945, at Hotel Utah. Left to right: Lillie J. Roberts, teacher's topic leader and Gertrude J. Iverson, theology leader, Bear River Stake Relief Society Board; Mary Smith Ellsworth, President California Mission Relief Societies; Clarice G. Sloan, former Relief Society President of Portland Stake; Ethel B. Andrew, former General Board member, now Nampa Stake Relief Society President; Caroline T. Eccles, literature leader, East Mill Creek Stake Board. These Are the grand key-words for the Society to act upon." Today we have this mighty sisterhood. We have on the rolls of Relief Society 29,027 visiting teachers who call in the homes of the Church members. It has been a wonderful plan, it is indeed an ideal plan, and, because it is based on an ideal, it must be measured by that ideal. Percentages may measure accurately the number of visits made in homes, but the good those visits accomplish, the heart-warming, soul-stirring good they do can never be read from figures. Yet, sisters, we hear even from stake presidents, "Are we still going to do visiting teaching? We just can't get women to go. They say they are not wanted in the homes, and anyway there is no need to go now we no longer receive contributions." Are there no longer sorrowing people? Are there no longer those who hunger spiritually? Is there no longer a need for human love and interest among our Relief Society sisters? Too few visiting teachers are "called to the work." Rather, they are pleaded with after Relief Society or at any time they happen to be met. "Oh, Sister Jones, won't you help us out with visiting teaching? We just can't get anyone to go! We know just how hard it is to get away, but if you'll just help us out for a little while...."Does this give a sister a vision of the opportunity being presented to her? Attitude means everything in the accomplishment of work. No one who does not have within herself a love of Relief Society and of visiting teaching can do this as it should be done. We must love the sisters we visit with the pure love of the gospel. We must desire with all our hearts to serve them. Never has there been a greater opportunity for doing the Master's work than there is in the world today.
We have the greatest organization ever put on earth for women, but it is of no avail unless we use it. The
organization is here, the opportunities for doing good are here. The leadership which determines the use made of that organization and those opportunities is here today. Your attitude, your vision, your understanding and love of the work determine the fulfillment of the ideal enunciated to us. You here today hold in your keeping the future of the visiting teaching program. See that you guard it well.
Therefore, O ye that embark in the service of God, see that ye serve him with all your heart, might, mind and strength, that ye may stand blameless before God at the last day (Doc. and Cov. 4:2).
GENERAL SESSION, MORNING OF OCTOBER 4, 1945

Feed My Lambs" Presiding Bishop LeGrand Richards IT should not be hard to say something to a group like this. I love the Relief Society and I have reason to because I have served as bishop of three different wards, and I have said that I could get along as well without a first counselor as I could without the Relief Society president. We have been particularly privileged, the present Presiding Bishopric of the Church, to be able to labor as advisers to Sister Robison and her counselors, to Sister Lyman and her counselors, and now to Sister Spafford and her assistants. Recently our work has been divided so that we are only advisers in their temporal affairs and their work in caring for the poor and those in distress. We have learned to love and appreciate these women, and it is a delight to be here this morning, to listen to them, as I know it is to each one of you here present today. This is a wonderful Church! Yesterday we went to the temple, the General Authorities with the mission presidents, in a meeting that commenced at nine o'clock, and we left there at twenty minutes after five. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 743 As I sat listening to the mission presidents bring back to the headquarters of the Church the spirit of the work that is being done under their direction, from the fringe of the Church, where the Church is expanding, I said to myself, "Well, if the Prophet Joseph had died for the establishment of the missionary system of this Church only, he surely would not have died in vain." Then to come here this morning and see this grand group of Relief Society workers, and let our minds go out to what is actually being done in the Church everywhere, I say again that if the Prophet Joseph had died for the establishment of the Relief Society organization of this Church only, he surely would not have died in vain. I want to remind you of one statement of the Master. You will remember how he gathered his followers from their nets and their fishes. After Jesus was crucified, Peter said, "I go fishing," and you remember that others of the disciples followed him, and then how Jesus came and found them when they were not successful in their fishing and he told them to cast their nets on the other side, and you know then the success that followed. And then Jesus said, directing himself to Peter: Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these? (These fishes.) He saith unto him. Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him. Feed my lambs. He saith unto him again the second time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? He saith unto him. Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him. Feed my sheep. He saith unto him the third time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me? And he said unto him. Lord, thou knowest all things; thou knowest that I love thee. Jesus saith unto him, Feed my sheep (John 21:15-17). TAGW, sisters, I do not know anything in the world that we can do to more pleasingly demonstrate to our Father in heaven our love of him than feeding the sheep and the lambs of his fold. He has said that the good shepherd leaves the ninety and nine to go out after the one strayed away. We, from the Presidency down, are going to try in this Church to emphasize ward teaching as it has never been done before. We feel that we are becoming marvelously organized and equipped and qualified for doing our work within the sacred walls of our beautiful buildings, but there are many, many on every hand who do not gather to receive the word of God, that we must accentuate our effort and emphasize it, to go to the homes and there carry the message and the spirit of this great latter-day work about which you have been speaking this morning. The Relief Society has a program that parallels the great ward teaching program of the Church. You are messengers to the homes. I like that part of the Relief Society work, where it is done in the right spirit and by faithful and efficient women ?and we have thousands and tens of thousands of them in the Church today?who go into the homes of the Latter-day Saints, taking with them the spirit of the gospel, the spirit of Christ, looking after the lost ones and gathering in and helping and encouraging where encouragement is necessary. If the sisters of this great organization will unite in the spirit of the priesthood of the Church to try to awaken within the hearts of the Latter-day Saints, particularly in those who have been inactive and indifferent, a love of the truth, a devotion to God and his great latter-day work, I am sure we will see the work of God going on as it has never done before, and the day will come when we will learn how to do our work for the salvation and exaltation of our Father's children in a far better manner than we have ever done before. God bless each one of you in your various fields, in your wards and stakes, and give you vision and power and inspiration, that you may touch the hearts of your people, that you may arise in your great assignment to heights you have never dreamed of before, to the honor and glory of God and the blessing and the salvation of his children, I humbly pray in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen. ?Photograph courtesy Salt Lake Tribune. THREE GENERAL PRESIDENTS OF RELIEF SOCIETY President Amy Brown Lyman, 1940-1945; President Belle S. Spafford, 1945?-; President Louise Y. Robison, 1928-1939. (This picture was taken at the reception honoring President Amy Brown Lyman, October 3, 1945.) GENERAL SESSION, AFTERNOON OF OCTOBER 4, 1945

entries.title: Wartime Activities of Our European Relief Society
entries.author: Gertrude R. Garff

loose_match.content: Wartime Activities of Our European Relief Society Counselor Gertrude R. Garff HOW wonderful it is to meet in Relief Society general conference again! How privileged we are to be able to assemble and listen to the counsel of the President of our Church. I think we have never appreciated this privilege as we do now because we were not granted the opportunity of gathering in conferences during the war years. We rejoice that this opportunity has been restored to us. Today in this great gathering are Relief Society women from most of the stakes of Zion, and most of the missions of the Church are represented by the presence of Relief Society mission presidents or Relief Society mission presidents who have only recently been released. However, there is a great group of loyal, faithful Relief Society women who have no representation here today, with but one exception, and who, I know, are with us in spirit if not in the flesh. They are our European Relief Society sisters. My sisters, we in the United States have been in constant communication with the Church authorities. Many of us could listen to the conference proceedings over the radio. Also, we were visited quarterly at stake conferences by Church authorities, and at any time we could write in to headquarters and get any counsel and help that was needed. Many of our missions have been handicapped by the lack of missionaries, but they did have mission presidents and Relief Society presidents sent from headquarters to preside over and lead the work there, and were in communication with the Church most of the time. In spite of these handicaps, they accomplished a wonderful work in both war and regular Relief Society activities. Some even started welfare plans and had singular success with these ventures. Today, I wish to pay tribute to our sisters in Europe. These women who have carried on Relief Society work under handicaps that would be discouraging even with missionaries in their midst. Since the fall of 1939, when the European saints sang "God Be With You Till We Meet Again," while waving goodbye to the missionaries on board ships sailing to America, our European brothers and sisters (with the exception of the British who have had good communication with Church headquarters) have had very little direct communication with Church authorities and the leadership was placed in the hands of local brethren. They have suffered tribulation beyond our comprehension. The Church and auxiliaries through Brother Thomas E. McKay, Assistant to the Council of the Twelve, have made every effort to get lessons and communications to these good people. Barring accident to letters and lessons enroute ?Norway and Denmark were reached through Sweden; Germany, France, Belgium, Czechoslovakia and the Netherlands were reached through Switzerland; and conversely, any word we received reached us by the same route. Occasionally, we would get and send Red Cross messages; but they took six to eight months to get to their destination, and were only a few words long. However, we were thankful for the information received, though scarce, and, now, since the cessation of hostilities, many letters bearing foreign postmarks have arrived and the stories they tell are of great interest to us. So that these sisters may have a part in our conference today, I am going to tell you of some of their activities. Can you imagine our wards with none of the brethren present to conduct the meetings?to administer the sacrament? Quite generally throughout the European mission, and especially in Norway, Germany, and Switzerland, the men belonging to the Church were in service or had gone underground. The Relief Society women were called to hold the people together, to conduct all the meetings. They even had singing practice and in some places the Singing Mothers' groups were very active. The Relief Society visiting teachers were given added responsibility as there were no men to do ward teaching. Where it was possible and there were older men holding the priesthood, they would visit the branches periodically and ad-minster the sacrament. At all other times it was the Relief Society women who carried the full responsibility of keeping the Church membership together. With the beginning of the war the Relief Society plunged into war work along with their regular programs. In Britain, under the direction of Sister Anastasiou who is here with us today, the Relief Society, among other things, gathered clothing for refugee organizations and received a gracious letter of thanks from the council in charge of distributing this clothing. ONE of the most touching incidents to come to us from Europe is the story of Sister Zippro, the Netherlands Relief Society president. She was willing to face alone the dangers of an invading army in order that members of the Church might receive assistance from the Relief Society. After hostilities between the two armies ceased, this dear sister, knowing of the terrible destruction of Rotterdam, concluded to ride her bicycle (the only means of travel because train travel, etc., was thoroughly disrupted) sixty miles from Amsterdam to Rotterdam. She found many of the families living with other members, as they had lost all earthly belongings when their homes had been completely destroyed by bombs. She immediately ascertained their needs and started to raise funds from among the other members to help those most affected by the invasion. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE Her bravery and devotion to the ideals of Relief Society under such trying and perilous circumstances are worthy of our highest praise. Nor did our Relief Society sisters confine their benevolent work to their own missions, but gave generously of their resources to those of another country. The Oslo Branch Relief Society gave a dinner for the; old people of the branch and the food was furnished by the Danish Relief Society, otherwise no festival could have been held as food was almost as scarce in Norway as anywhere in Europe. Both the Swedish and Danish missions obtained food permits at regular intervals and sent food into Norway to be distributed among the Norwegian saints. It is amazing to note that in such a terrible period of our world's history, new Relief Societies were being organized. I want to read an excerpt from a letter to Brother McKay from Elder Fritz Johanssen, the Swedish Mission President: Between August 7 and 22, together with District President Claus A. Person and Sister Astrid Johanssen of the mission Relief Society board, I made a journey to Finland. The little Society was organized at my first visit shortly after the winter war 1939-40 to a regular branch. This time we had the great pleasure of baptizing three persons. This time I was inspired to undertake the Finland journey and at the same time write an additional part of its gospel history as far as Finland is concerned, namely, that the first female Relief Society was organized there. Time and again we felt as when the Lord through the Prophet Joseph Smith 747 organized the first Relief Society in the world. All of the letters I have read coming from Europe tell of the terrific need for clothing. Clothing is, of course, rationed, but even those with money cannot find the necessary items to buy. Our members in Denmark have gone stockingless for a year at a time and shoes are never seen in the shops. As is generally the case, the children are suffering the most. Now permission has been granted to send eleven-pound packages into all the missions except Germany and Czechoslovakia; and I am happy to report that packages are being sent by our Central Welfare Storehouse to the branch and Relief Society presidents for distribution to the needy members, which include nearly all since money is not involved. There just aren't any clothes to buy of either good or bad quality. My dear sisters, what inspired these women to perform these unselfish and thoughtful deeds? It was their membership in Relief Society, their knowledge of the purpose and ideals of Relief Society, that gave them the courage to undertake those difficult tasks. It was the Relief Society organization that empowered those women and made their efforts to gather funds and clothing and to send food to members in another country effective. Without this organization, they could not have been prepared to take over the responsibility of handling the work of the branches when they were left with no priesthood to officiate. Their letters thank us for our prayers in their behalf.Let us give thanks for these faithful sisters and brothers for their trials have indeed been greater than ours. In closing, I wish to bear my testimony. I am thankful for the gospel, for the meaning it gives to my life. I am thankful for the opportunity of serving the Lord and I feel to express with Moroni of old: And awake, and arise from the dust, O Jerusalem; yea, and put on thy beautiful garments, O daughter of Zion; and strengthen thy stakes and enlarge thy borders forever, that thou mayest no more be confounded, that the covenants of the Eternal Father which he hath made unto thee, O house of Israel, may be fulfilled (Moroni 10:31),

entries.title: Dream For a Relief Society Building
entries.author: Marianne C. Sharp

loose_match.content: Dream for a Relief Society Building Counselor Marianne C. Sharp T WOULD ask an interest in your faith and prayers for I feel that words are very inadequate to express the feelings which are in my heart today. I am grateful for the privilege we have as sisters?as mothers always working for the salvation of our children and as Church members striving for the furtherance of the work of the Church?to meet together once more in a Relief Society general conference. I am grateful, personally, for the opportunity I have to work in the Relief Society under Sister Spafford who is true and faithful, and I want to thank my Heavenly Father for this privilege. I love the Relief Society. I love the sisters in the Relief Society and have joy in association with them. Wherever I have lived or visited in the Church I have felt the close bond of love and service which links together the members of the Society today. The members today, however, are only links in a great chain of sisters which reaches back to include the valiant and great women of the past 103 years, and will stretch forward to encompass those yet unborn who will devote their services to working for the good of others, always seeking at the same time to improve themselves. I am thinking particularly this afternoon of those sisters who have gone on before. Ever since Sister Lyman appointed Sister Spafford and me to help prepare the book A Centenary oi Relief Society to commemorate the hundredth birthday of the Society, I have felt very near to the Relief Society leaders of the past and the faithful members who are the mothers, grandmothers, and great-grandmothers, even great-great-grandmothers, of the members today. They have stepped out alive for me from the pages of the Woman's Exponent and from the minutes of the General Board. Their testimonies have increased my testimony. I have shared in their joys and sorrows and, as nearly as one can, I have entered into their desires for the upbuilding of Relief Society. As we studied this history of the past, we read of one great dream which had gone unfulfilled. GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 749 It is of this unfulfilled dream I wish to speak today. In order to introduce it, I will take you back forty-nine years ago yesterday to October 3, 1896, to a general Relief Society conference held in the Assembly Hall. Aunt Zina Young was the president of the Relief Society at that time and with her on the stand sat her three counselors, her vice-presidents as they were called, First Counselor Jane S. Richards, Second Counselor Bathsheba W. Smith, and" her third Counselor Sarah M. Kimball. It was near the end of the afternoon session that, according to the minutes taken by Sister Emmeline B. Wells, then secretary: President Zina D. H. Young, in her remarks, opened out upon the subject of a house for the Relief Society, to be owned by them. Women had done so much to help build other public buildings and temples that they had no means to build one for the Relief Society. President C. O. Card had said when they lacked the means to go on with the Logan Temple and the men were to be discharged because there was no means to pay them for their work, Sister Jane S. Richards raised five hundred dollars in the Relief Society of Weber County to keep the men working, and that stands as a memento to the sisters forever. Vice President Sarah M. Kimball confined her remarks to the subject of a house for the Society. She felt it a humiliation to be without a place of our own; we had contributed to all public places and at all times. Now we want to have a house and we want land to build it on and it should be in the shadow of the temple. It should be a place to receive strangers in when they come, a place where letters can be written" from and information given, I think we should vote on this matter, whether you representative women want this building or not; we want to put it to vote. Sister Kimball told the sisters what Joseph Smith had said in Nauvoo to the sisters of the Society there and had given them a lot belonging to the Church and a house on it which could be repaired and made useful. Now, said Sister Kimball, I want to ask you sisters if you want such a building as I have described. The motion was put and the vote was unanimous. Sister Kimball added, if you want this proposition carried out, then see how much can be done. The interest in building a house for the Relief Society continued strong and money began to be collected, however through the next ten years there also ran the fear, expressed quite often by those dear, faithful sisters as once stated by Sister M. Isabella Home?"don't branch out too largely at once, there is not much to do with, and the Relief Society must care for the poor.? In view of this great financial responsibility which they felt was theirs, the money was not quickly forthcoming, but the dreaming and planning went on. Their plans called for kitchens, pantries, banqueting hall, cooking utensils, a furnace and closets and a room for the janitor, and offices upstairs, "with library and bureau of information, that will be in the best sense educational, and be open to all members of the society, and where lectures may be given by distinguished professors in all branches of science, art and literature, and on general topics." In 1900, the Young Ladies Mutual Improvement Association and the Primary Association joined forces with the Relief Society with the hope that together the three could raise enough money for a suitable woman's building. March 1901, The matter was presented to President Lorenzo Snow who, in was reported to have said: The women must have twenty thousand dollars before commencing the house; in fact, before we could put a spade in the ground or have the land measured off, and when we had that amount on hand he would give the deed of the land, and we could be as sure of it as you will of happiness when you get to heaven. In speaking to the Relief Society at an outing at Saltair, July 9, 1901, President Snow said in part: You who are present today are members of the oldest organization in the Church outside of the Priesthood. The Relief Society was organized nearly

sixty years ago, with 18 members (my sister, Eliza R. Snow being the secretary) by the Prophet Joseph Smith, under the inspiration of the Lord; and from that day to the present it has gone on without interruption growing in strength and usefulness, until today it is recognized as one of the most powerful forces for good in the Church. You are now 30,000 strong I am told, with a building fund of nearly $5,000, and with upwards of $100,000 worth of property in your possession. In addition to this you are the only ones among the Saints who are doing anything in a financial way against a day of famine. Your work in this direction is most commendable, and I hear as a result that you have 103,783 bushels of grain, together with an amount of flour and beans, safely stored against a time of need, as well as $3,331 to expend for the same purpose. In a letter of July 1901 signed by the First Presidency, Lorenzo Snow and Joseph F. Smith, it stated: We commend the undertaking [of a woman's building] and have contributed a valuable building site opposite the Temple, valued at $18,000. Sister Zina D. H. Young, President of the Relief Society, died in August 1901, and, in October 1901, President Lorenzo Snow passed away. The new president of the Church, President Joseph F. Smith, called Bathsheba W. Smith to be the new Relief Society president, and the plans continued to progress under her administration. The site which has been described on which a three-story building of yellow pressed brick with a stone foundation was to be built for a woman's building became the Bishop's Building?Relief Society donated $8500 toward its erection and was given quarters in it. The first Relief Society General Board meeting was held in it December 3,1909. This, in brief, is the story of the dream for a Relief Society building which was never built. It is a story of heartache for the Relief Society women who had planned and worked for it for so many years. Relief Society today, however, has already outgrown the space that would have been given it in the proposed woman's building. What seemed a tragedy may prove a blessing and joy to Relief Society in the future. I am thankful for the Relief Society women of the past. I am thankful for their vision. They were great and noble women, women who had faith in their own cause, who loved Relief Society, but who knew that the welfare of the whole Church was above all their welfare. They humbly accepted the decisions of the Church authorities with faith as being in their best interests. They were obedient. May we in our day be as devoted and as faithful? and in all things may we render as full and as unstinted an obedience to the authorities of the Church as did our sisters of long ago is my prayer.

entries.title: A Relief Society Building to Be Erected
entries.author: Belle S. Spafford

loose_match.content:
A Relief Society Building to Be Erected President Belle S. Spafford THIS is a glorious day for Relief Society, a day for which we have longed and prayed, knowing full well it could come only when the nations should still the guns of war. We are grateful to our Heavenly Father that the hostilities which have engulfed the earth, spreading destruction and breaking hearts, have ceased. We acknowledge his goodness that so soon after the disruptions of war we are privileged to meet in a general Relief Society conference.
This is the first general Relief Society conference to be held since the Society observed its 102th birthday. We are today setting our feet forward on the second century of Relief Society history. As we approach this new era, we do not anticipate any new nor great departmental purposes of the Society as set forth by the Prophet Joseph Smith and reiterated by each of the succeeding presidents of the Church.
The past is a force that is alive, and, like all living things, is growing and maturing while preserving a pattern that can be recognized and defined. From the past we inherit not only patterns and standards, but vision, strength, insight, faith and courage. The past has passed on to us, too, as a part of our heritage, its unfulfilled dreams and desires and bids us keep faith with it in regard to these, for these, too, are a constant invitation to advancement and progress.
Sister Sharp has brought to your attention today a deep-seated and sincere desire that has persisted in the hearts and minds of Relief Society women year after year as the century has rolled by?the desire for a Relief Society building, one that would beautifully and adequately represent the women of the Church. This desire, born and nurtured in the past, is today firmly rooted in our hearts. And, entering as we are upon a second century of Relief Society, a strong and growing organization rich in the blessings of the Lord, this seems the right and appropriate time to bring to fruition this dream of the past, to erect a building that shall stand a monument to Latter-day Saint women and a credit to the Church.
Our Church is the foremost organization in all the world with regard to women. The restored gospel gives to women a position of dignity and respect. It recognizes their spiritual and mental powers and their right to use their inborn talents to the full. Latter-day Saint women have been organized under the priesthood after a pattern of the priesthood and have been provided unlimited opportunities for development. The gospel teaches that women have an appointed place in the plan of salvation and that the Lord loves his daughters as he loves his sons and that the promises, blessings are the same for both. It, therefore, seems entirely fitting that a building should be erected as a symbol to all people of the lofty position accorded faithful daughters of our Heavenly Father in the gospel plan.
Nurtured by a Church recognizing woman's true position, women have, in turn, given full devotion to the Church. This has been true with regard to the building program of the Church. Even before the women were organized as a Society in Nauvoo, they banded together to help feed and clothe the men working on the Kirtland Temple. It was with the desire to aid the work of building the Nauvoo Temple that Sarah M. Kimball, in 1842, invited her neighbors to join with her in forming a "Ladies' Society." When the Prophet Joseph Smith was approached regarding this matter, he invited the women to meet with him and some of the brethren a week later, at which time (March 17, 1842) the women were organized as the "Female Relief Society of Nauvoo."
Lucy Mack, mother of the Prophet, spoke of the importance attached by the women to their activities in behalf of the Nauvoo Temple, as follows:
There was but one mainspring to all our thoughts and actions and that was the building of the Lord's house.
Relief Society women have given of their best according to their circumstances and conditions, toward the building, furnishing, and beautifying of temples erected by the Church.
Not only have Relief Society women been vitally interested in the building of temples but they have been generous in their donations to stake tabernacles, ward meeting houses, and other Church buildings, generally raising funds for these edifices as well as building funds,
cooking and serving dinners or conducting bazaars which have taken weeks and months of tedious preparation.
Yet, after more than one hundred years, during which time they have actively participated in the building program of the Church, they stand today with no home of their own.
The continuing growth of the Society, with the continuous expansion of the various departments connected by the General Board, also demand that provision soon be made to more adequately house the general offices, the temple-burial clothes, Magazine, welfare and other departments.
With the consent of the First Presidency, and with your support, it is our intention to go forward immediately with plans for the building and for financing its erection. It is our desire to have the building belong to the women of the Church and to have every Relief Society woman feel the pride of ownership in it. It is our desire to have the building not only house the general offices and the various departments maintained by the General Board, but to have it be of service to all members of the Society. We expect to include in it comfortable lounge rooms where you may leave your wraps, a well as meet a friend; check rooms where you may leave your bundles; a relic room where choice articles of historic value may be preserved and displayed; an auditorium with well-equipped work and exhibition kitchens where homemaking demonstrations and lectures may be given, as well as other features suitable to a Relief Society building and the work of the Society.
GENERAL RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE 753 It is our earnest desire that it shall be built by the many rather than the few. That every person may be given opportunity to contribute to its erection and enjoy the sense of satisfaction and pride that comes from so doing, we believe that every one of our more than 100,000 members will want to make a contribution and thus become in reality a part owner in this Relief Society home and Latter-day Saint women's memorial edifice. We believe that throughout the Church are many men, as well, who will welcome the opportunity to honor a wife or mother by contributing funds, and that many other friends of Relief Society will wish to show their regard for the Society by assisting financially. Through the united support of all, we believe that the necessary finances will be readily and willingly contributed. We realize, however, that to erect the type of building we have in mind is a mammoth undertaking. We know that if we are to realize our ambition the full support of every enrolled member of Relief Society will be necessary. We would like at this time to know your attitude toward the proposed building program. Therefore, just as our sisters of long ago called for a vote on this identical proposition, so today, forty-nine years later, we too are calling for a vote of this great congregation composed of Relief Society women of our day representing most of the stakes and many of the missions of the Church. Your General Board proposes the erection at the earliest possible date of a Relief Society building that shall be monumental and beautiful, to adequately serve the members of the Society not only for today but in the years to come. Will all those in favor of this proposition please show it by the uplifted hand. (The vote was unanimous in the affirmative.) This is a glorious experience, not only to see your uplifted hands but to feel your support. As soon as plans for the building and its financing are perfected and approved they will be released to you. We feel assured of your support. We appreciate your support in all of the work of Relief Society. We are grateful for your righteousness and your spirit of service. We are grateful for the strength of your testimonies. We are grateful for the women of the past, for their vision and understanding of the needs of Latter-day Saint women, and for their great contribution to us and to the future. We are above all things grateful for the gospel. May the Lord bless you and comfort you and may our righteous and worthy ambitions know fulfillment I pray, in the name of Jesus Christ, Amen. [The address by President George Albert Smith, page 715, was then delivered. ]

entries.title: Success to a Relief Society Building
entries.author: Marvin O. Ashton

loose_match.content: Success to a Relief Society Building Elder Marvin O. Ash ton First Counselor, Presiding Bishopric SUCCESS to you in this building! May you speedily start, and may you speedily finish it. If we are perfectly honest with your, and sometimes we are, we would say something like this to President Spafford, "Success to you in this building," and, as the host said to those guests he had in the house as he went into the closet to take out their coats, "Here's your hat, but what's your hurry?" Our building over there is crowded. You need a new building and so do we need more elbow room. Success to you! I wish that every building that is financed would be financed as easily as you are going to finance this building; and I hope I have the privilege, and I am sure it won't be denied, to give my pittance in this direction. In closing, inasmuch as President Smith has mentioned the Lamanites, I just want to pay tribute to a Relief Society worker; namely. Sister Flora Hicks, who has had charge, with her husband, of the Lamanites in the Papago Ward, Arizona. She was called down there ten or twelve years ago, and she passed away about eight weeks ago. We had the privilege of standing in that house as those Lamanites came in to pay homage to her. They are supposed to be cold; they are not supposed to be very enthusiastic in their emotions. When those people came in, about three hundred strong, one at a time and in groups, they cried like babies in the loss of that wonderful woman and what she had done for them. And as they put her under the ground, the little Lamanite president of the Relief Society put fifty dollars in the hands of Brother Hicks. They heard that he had had some intention of moving back to Salt Lake City sometime. She said, "Here is fifty dollars, and men have another fifty dollars. That is for a monument to this good woman. You are not going to move her from this sacred soil?" God bless her memory. She gave herself to help other persons raise their standards of life. God bless you. Amen.

Relief Society Wheat Project Elder Joseph L. Wirthlin Second Counselor, Presiding Bishopric THERE is no question but what I should like to talk to you for a you sisters have missed a great moment about a project in which many things in not being able to at you are vitally interested, namely, tend the sessions of the general the wheat storage project which conference during the past four originated in the days of President years, but I should like you to know Brigham Young when he counseled that we have missed you very much, the members of the Relief Society and we are happy that you are back, to store wheat against a day of need. If we were to continue attending In that day of long ago, the sisters general conference without our sis of the Relief Society went out into the fields after the brethren had harvested the crops and literally gleaned what was left, and from that day on until 1919, the sisters of the Relief Society had been accumulating wheat which eventually amounted to thousands of bushels. The Federal Government, in 1919, proposed the purchase of this wheat, and it was sold to the Government for the sum of approximately $400,000. With the approval of the First Presidency, the money was placed in trust in the Presiding Bishop's office with the understanding that this money would be invested in such a way as to insure its safety and return some interest. Over the years the interest has been paid to the Relief Societies of the Church, who in turn have used it for maternity and child welfare work. But about four years ago, the First Presidency deemed it advisable to invest the money again in wheat to the end that should there come a day of need, some provision would be made to provide for the members of the Church. Hence, a large elevator was erected on Welfare Square with welfare labor, which holds approximately 250,000 bushels of wheat. A small elevator was purchased at Levan, Utah, and another one at McCammon, Idaho. The recently purchased flour mill at Kaysville has an additional storage capacity of 72,000 bushels. At the present time the Relief Society has stored in the Salt Lake Elevator and the one at Levan approximately 215,000 bushels of wheat which has a value at the present market price of over $200,000, and there is a sizable amount of the original wheat funds that has not yet been invested in wheat.
As we contemplate this achievement by the women of the Church, the effort required, it represents to
all of us a grand and glorious achievement. More than that, it represents the principle of generosity and willingness to provide the staff of life for any members of the Church who might be in need. It is further evidence of the divine power that inspires men and women to do those things which are for the spiritual and temporal benefit of the Church.
AND now as you approach a new project in the way of a building for the women of the Church, there will be no question about your success and the final accomplishment of your objective. No doubt when this building project gets underway, the brethren of the Church will be given the privilege to contribute to the fund that will cover the cost of the building as an expression of appreciation and gratitude for the splendid service rendered by this great organization of women.
My mother was a Relief Society president. I say, "God bless her for her devoted service," for out of the service rendered in this great organization, she set her children an example which instilled in their hearts a love for the gospel of Jesus Christ. When I think of these ministering angels of the Relief Society, the words of the song just rendered express best the spirit in which they labor: "Peace I leave with you; my peace I give unto you, not as the world gives, give I unto you." The spirit of the Master motivates this great organization of our sisters to render a service which causes all of us to say, "God bless them."
May God bless you in all of your endeavors, I humbly pray in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen.Sixty Years Ago Excerpts from the Woman's Exponent December 1, and December 15, 1885 "For the Rights of the Women of Zion and the Rights of the Women of All Nations" ADVICE TO MOTHERS: Mothers, and those who have the care of young children and infants, should remember to be in school themselves every day of their lives, for even the infant imbibes the spirit of her who attends it day by day and hour by hour; delicacy and refinement should guard every action, for, be assured, the plastic soul will bear the impress given! Language, also, should ever be guarded, that no words or exclamations may fall upon the infant ear, but that which is sweet, harmonious, and loving.... You, young mothers, remember day by day and hour by hour the mighty responsibility that rests upon you.... Devote, at least, the next twenty years to maturing and educating your children; this will be to you the finest school on earth.?Hannah T. King. CHRISTMAS: Christmas approaches, and as the merry season draws near, our thoughts revert to a period... When the Eternal Son of God, the mighty Savior of the world, condescended to become the babe of Bethlehem, and descend below all things, that He might bring about the great scheme of redemption, and open up the way whereby a fallen world could be restored to the presence of the Father... He came unto his own, and his own received him not.... Then, when another Christmas day dawns upon the earth, let us remember the Holy One who has again restored the Gospel to the earth... Let us as Latter-day Saints, seek after the spirit of Him whose birth we celebrate, and strive to do the works that He did.... In this way we shall ourselves receive a blessing, and give to all a happy Christmas.? Phebe C. Young. WINTER: Winter at last is here in pomp and magnificence; it has ushered itself in. The beautiful carpet of grass has been replaced by one of pure white snow.... Who does not love, as in the evening they are seated before a cosy fire, to hear the wild winds of winter first coming like a low, moaning whisper, then louder, shriller, and more fierce.... Again, who does not love to view the trees on a clear frosty morning; they stand forth draped in their pure white robes of snow.... All, all in loveliness.... I thank God that I have been given an appreciative mind to enjoy all this loveliness of nature.?Ida. A CHRISTMAS PRAYER Enlighten, comfort, sanctify my heart, Sweeten my temper and subdue my will. I want to bring my sisters to thy throne, I want to love and honor Christ alone, I want to feel the spirit's inward power. And stand prepared for death's important hour.  I want to do whatever God requires, I want a heart to burn with pure desires. Lead me through life to glorify thy grace, And after death to see Thee face to face. -M. A. Greenhalgh Page 756

Woman's Sphere Ramona W. Cannon WINNIFRED M. TIBBS, Utah poet, who was ninety years old, October 26, and her sister, Miss Nellie Morris, who was eighty-three in March, were honored at an open house Sunday, October 28, at the home of Mrs. Tibbs' daughter, Mrs. Josephine T. Saville. Nearly three hundred guests called to greet the sisters. THE August number of Theillustrates the headdresses of Navajo girls. Sister Maggie Nielsen of Bluff, Utah, recently made a wedding dress for a Navajo bride, in which the skirt had twenty-two gores, each approximately one yard wide at the bottom. AT atea on November 5, honoring Utah's 8,000 Minute Women, Governor Herbert B. Maw presented each guest with a certificate of merit bearing the State seal. Especially honored were Mrs. John T. Wahlquist, State Chairman, and Mrs. L. A. Stevenson, Salt Lake City Chairman, unusually intelligent and dynamic organizers and leaders. Working on thirty-two salvage and conservation programs, the women have salvaged for example, six and one-half million pounds of tin, seven million pounds of waste paper, and forty-six and one-half million pounds of rags and old clothing. Miss Helen Blakenhorn of the national War Production Board said: Utah has the very best woman's organization for salvage in the United States. Mr. E. C. Seawell, national chairman of fat salvage said, "Utah has done the best salvage job in the United States. There is alive today a vivid imprint of the pioneer. Utah has retained the realities. She has combined qualities visible and invisible to set an example." VARIOUS professions in which Utah women have excelled are: Law?Judge Florence E. Allen, also poet, musician, and instructor in Greek, who has served on the Ohio Supreme Court Bench, and on the Circuit Court for Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky and Tennessee. Engineering: Young Inez Hansen was the third engineer hired at the Geneva Steel plant, and is now working on a great airport being built in San Francisco. Dentistry: Dr. Rose By water Valentine was Utah's first woman dentist, practicing forty-five years ago. She is now president of the Women Dentists Association of the Pacific Coast. Anthropology: Mrs. Huberta Berg Robison, a young Latter-day Saint girl, formerly of California, now of Utah, is employed by the Carnegie Institute, studying Mayan characters and culture, and making expert graphs. Page 757 EDITORIAL 

VOL. 32 DECEMBER 1945 NO. 12

116th Semi-annual Church Conference  COLORFUL and impressive was the scene in Salt Lake City on the morning of October 5, 1945, the opening day of the 116th semi-annual conference of the Church. All roads appeared to lead to Temple Square as thousands of Latter-day Saints, conference bound, hearts rejoicing in the blessing of our Heavenly Father, eagerly anticipated words which would soon come from inspired Church leaders to guide, comfort, and sustain them. Four weary, anxious war years had passed since the general Church membership had met in the great Tabernacle in conference session, years in which souls had been tried and many had been called upon to mourn. The resumption of conference for the general Church membership, made possible through the cessation of hostilities, was indeed a comfort to the souls of Latter-day Saints, and a joy to their hearts. This conference, too, was an eventful occasion for a most important and impressive ceremony, one participated in by the priesthood and general membership but rarely a ceremony referred to in Church history as a Priesthood Solemn Assembly. Page 758 This ceremony is the custom when voting for a new president of the Church for the first time in general conference, and has been the practice of the Church since President John Taylor was sustained in conference general conference. Voting is by quorums, in order, beginning with the First Presidency and continuing down through the Aaronic Priesthood. Voting by the priesthood is followed by that of the remaining Church membership. In voting, the right hand is raised to the square to witness to the Lord that one sustains the officer for whom he is voting. The Solemn Assembly, presided over by President George Albert Smith and directed by President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. At the opening session of the conference October 5, voted to sustain President George Albert Smith as Prophet, Seer, and Revelator, and President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. President Smith came to this position on May 21, 1945, following the death of President Heber J. Grant. The humility of soul, accompanied by the power that comes with a deep and abiding testimony of the gospel, confirmed in the minds of the thousands who heard the voice of President Smith as he addressed the Church membership following the voting, the belief that they had indeed sustained one who was a prophet, seer, and revelator divinely appointed and endowed with divine authority to lead the Church in this great and perilous day. The Church membership also EDITORIAL 759 sustained President George F. Richards as president of the Council of the Twelve, and Elder Matthew Cowley as a new member of the Council of the Twelve. Strong and effective, and a terse reminder to the saints of the covenants they had made that day in voting were the words of President J. Reuben Clark, Jr. When he said: Today I have given witness to President Smith, to you and to the Lord that I will sustain him as prophet, seer and revelator and president of the Church. Each of us has made a life covenant. God gives to each of us the strength and the power to be loyal; to give up fault finding; to follow the command of the Lord; to follow those whom we have ourselves sustained. Without leadership the Church cannot grow. Throughout all of the sessions of the conference, speakers paid high tribute to President Smith. With unusual clarity and conviction they bore testimony, expounded the doctrines and interpreted the principles of the gospel, and bade Church members to keep the commandments of the Lord. Pronounced emphasis was given the missionary program of the Church and the intention to expand it in the immediate future?to call many men and women into missionary service, was made clear. The music of the conference seemed unusually beautiful. Relief Society was proud that a combined chorus of Relief Society Singing Mothers from the stakes of the Salt Lake Region provided the music for the first two sessions. The desires of the thousands of Latter-day Saints who had so eagerly awaited this conference for the guidance and spiritual succor it might bring them were fully realized. This 116th semi-annual conference will go down in Church history as a great and blessed occasion. BSS.
